definitions.dtxt: Name of a large sea bird often caught by natives; also called aaianuheakane, feathers white.
Name of a small fish that bites at a hook; called also aakimakau.
Name of broken lava from the volcano; probably so called from being burnt. See A.
Name of the Hawaiian alphabet; also the first sheet on which it was printed.
Name of the white spots that appear in poi when pounding.
The jawbone; the cheek bone. A lana, upper jaw; a lalo, lower jaw.
The name of an instrument made of smooth bone, and used formerly for piercing or killing an unborn child. It was called the a oo, the piercing a; also a koholua. See KOHOLUA.
To burn, as a fire; ua a mai ke ahi, the fire burns; ua a mai ke ahi ma ka waha. the fire burned in their mouths.
To burn, as a lamp; to blaze, as a flame.
To burn, as jealousy. As anger.

Hoo or ho. To cause to burn, i.e., to kindle; to light, as a lamp; to kindle, as a fire. Also with ho doubled, as hohoa, to dry; na hua i hohoa ia, dried fruits. See the reduplicate form AA and Hoo. Gram. § 212.
Fiery; burning; he lua a, a fiery pit.

When; then; there; until. With verbs in a narrative tense, it signifies when, and when, etc.; as, a hiki mai ia, when he arrived. With nei it signifies a designation of place, as mai a nei aku, from here (this place) onward. Until, as noho oia malaila a make, he lived there until he died.

And; and then; and when. When it connects verbs, it usually stands by itself; as, holo ka waa, a komo iho, the canoe sailed and sank. When it connects nouns, it is usually joined with me; as, haawi mai oia i ka ai a me ke kapa, he furnished food and clothing. A with me signifies and, and also, besides, together with, etc. When emphatic, it is merely a disjunctive.
Lo; behold. It is expressive of surprise, disappointment, astonishment or admiration. It is similar in meaning to aia hoi, eia hoi, aia ka.

Of; to; in connection with motion, e hoi oe a ka hale, return to the house, (hiki i) understood. Laieik. 12. Unto; at; belonging. It designates the properties of relation, possession and place; and is often synonymous with o, but more generally distinct, giving another shade of meaning and implying a more close connection. Gram. § 69, 3.
And, when, until, to, etc.
Of, acquired by. This a forms part of the possessives, as in ka'u, mine, and kāna, his. (Gram. 9.6.1)

example_txt.txt: house acquired [or used] by the sun [mountain name]

definitions.dtxt: Abbreviation of ʻākau, north, as in surveying reports.
Prefix to numbers from one through nine, especially for counting in series. See ʻalua, ʻakolu, Pōʻahā. (Gram. 10.3)
Same as ʻā-.
Jaw, cheekbone. Fig. To talk a lot, jabber, jibber jabber. Ke ā nui, ke ā iki, big jaw, little jaw [bragging and wheedling, as of a man seeking the favor of a woman]. hoʻā To talk a lot, jabber.
An instrument made of smooth bone, formerly used for abortion, lancing, or bleeding. Also ā ʻōʻō, piercing ā.
Mold found in souring foods, especially poi, generally known as Oidium lactis or Oospora lactis, but now called Geotrichum candidum.

And prep. When, at the time when, until, to, as far as, and, or (rare), and then, but (usually preceding verbs, whereas a me usually precedes nouns; ā may also connect words translated by English adjectives, as he poʻe kuli ā ʻāʻā, a people deaf and dumb; nani ā pumehana kēia kakahiaka, this morning is beautiful and warm). (Gram. 9.5, 11.1) Ā also connects verb + noun compounds: see ʻai ā manō, holoāiʻa, Gram. 8.7.2. Ā hiki mai ia, when he arrives. Hola ʻelua ā ʻoi, a little after two o'clock. Noho ʻoia malaila ā make, he lived there until death. Prolonged ā may designate a protracted period of time or distance, a long continued action, or emphasis. Aloha ā nui, much, much aloha. Mahalo ā nui, thanks very, very much. Holo aʻela ia ā hiki i ka ʻāina kahiki, he sailed and sailed and sailed until he reached a foreign couentry. Hele ā uka, go clear to the uplands.
Iwi ā. Jawbone, mandible.
Pejorative suffix, often written wā after o or u. See ʻaiā, haiā, hainā, huā (huwā), kauā (kauwā), lonoā, (lonowā), makoeā, naʻauʻauā (naʻauʻauwā), poluā (poluwā), Gram. 6.5.
Personal article occurring only after the preposition i, written ia. (Gram. 9.3.1)
Simulative ligature in the sequence ‘verb + noun’ compounds. See ʻai ā manō, holoāiʻa, Gram. 8.7.2.

A word used only at the end of a sentence or phrase, with meanings such as: I told you so; don't you forget it; you should know; you dummy. Ua hoʻomaka ka papa i ka hola ʻehiku, ā. The class started at seven o'clock, you dummy. Niʻihau.
Fiery, burning; fire; to burn, blaze. Fig. To glitter or sparkle, as a gem; to burn, as with jealousy or anger.

example_txt.txt: to light an oven; one who lights an oven

definitions.dtxt: To set on fire, burn, ignite; to light, as a lamp. Fig. To incite, arouse.
Aa lava, or lava rock, as distinguished from smooth unbroken pāhoehoe lava (formerly preceded by ke); to flow, as aa lava.

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻole ʻoia i ʻā e noho.
He did not dare to stay.

definitions.dtxt: Same as ʻaʻa 1, to dare.

Red-footed booby bird (Sula sula rubripes), brown booby (Sula leucogaster plotus), masked or blue-faced booby (Sula dactylatra personata); all indigenous and also breeding elsewhere. Also ʻaʻa. Legendary birds believed to have taken the shape of this bird are ʻā ʻaia, ʻāʻaiʻanuheakāne and ʻāʻaianuinūkeu; ʻā by some were considered ʻaumākua. See also Kep. 33.
Young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi). Also ʻaʻā. ʻĀ ʻaki maunu, bait-taking ʻā [said of petty thieves; a var. phrase is ʻā ʻaki makau, hook-taking ʻā].
Oh! Well! Ah! Er … (Gram. 12)
To drive, as fish or cattle.
Caus/sim.
The letter “a.”
In the nature of (as hina, white, ʻāhina, somewhat white, gray; pali, cliff, ʻāpali, like a cliff). There are many examples, as ʻālewalewa, ʻālualua, ʻāmokumoku, ʻāoʻo, ʻāpono, ʻāwela. (Gram. 6.3.1)
Active, as a volcano.
In the nature of (as hina, white, ʻāhina, somewhat white, gray; pali, cliff, ʻāpali, like a cliff). There are many examples, as ʻālewalewa, ʻālualua, ʻāmokumoku, ʻāoʻo, ʻāpono, ʻāwela. (Gram. 6.3.1)
Burning; raging, as a fire, he ahi aa loa; also as anger.
Silent; still; lonely, as a house uninhabited; he aa ko ka hale, the people of the house are silent.
Spiteful; quick angry; also roguish; mischievous.
Stony; abounding with lava; rough with broken lava, as ground to walk over, or to work in. See A, broken lava, above.
A belt; a girdle.
A burning; a lighted fire, etc. Laieik. 78.
A covering for the eyes.
A daring; tempting.
A dwarf; a small person. Kanaka poupou aa; ua ike an i kahi keiki i komoiii, aa no hoi ke kino.

A pocket; a bag. SYN. with eke. Aa moni, a purse; a scrip; a bag to carry provisions in for a journey; aole kanaka aa ole, no man without his scrip; a bag for weights (of money). The name of the envelop for a fœtus. Laieik. 190. Kuu kaikaina i ka aa hookahi.
Chaff; hulls; the outside of seeds or fruit.
Dumbness; inability to speak intelligibly; also a dumb person. I loheia e na aa lololohe; i mau aa lolo kuli.
Name of a reddish fish. See A above.
Name of a sea breeze at Lahaina and some other places on the islands.
Name of the cloth-like covering near the roots of cocoanut leaves, aa niu. Hence,
The name of a coarse land of cloth, he aa haole.
The outer husk of the cocoanut; the skin of the banana, same as paaa.
See A above. Broken lava, i.e., sand, earth, stones and melted lava, cooled and broken up; hence.
See A above. Name of a bird that hunts fish during the day, but flies back to the mountains in the evening.
The caul of animals; aa maluna o ke eke, the caul above the liver. The midriff:
The small roots of trees or plants. Also called weli.
The veins or arteries for blood, from their resemblance to the fine roots of trees, aole lakou i ike ke koko maloko o na aa. Anat. 1.
The lower part of the neck.
Offspring.
A doubled. See A, verb, before. To burn fiercely or furiously, as a fire; to burn constantly.
To kindle; to burn furiously, as anger.
Hoo. To cause to kindle; to burn, as a fire; to light, as a lamp.
To burn, as anger.
To rage; to be angry.
To be bold; to dare.
To tempt; to challenge. To defy.
To venture, ua aa anei oe e hele i ke kaua? Ua aa anei oe e hele i ke alii?
To accept a challenge; to act presumptuously. He aa ka manao; he wiwo ole.
To gird; tie around, as a loose garment.
To make a noise, as in trying to speak, as a dumb person; hence,
To be dumb, ua aa ka leo.
To send love in compliment; as. e aa mai ana o mea ma ia oe; the answer would be, Anoai wale laua, or welina wale laua, or aloha wale laua.

To brave, dare, challenge, defy, check, venture; to accept a challenge; to volunteer, involving a difficulty; to act wickedly or presumptuously; bold, venturesome, valiant, intrepid. See ex., mea 1. He poʻe ʻaʻa hewa, a people acting wickedly. He ʻaʻa ka manaʻo, he wiwo ʻole, thoughts are full of courage, fearless.
Belt, girdle, waist; to gird, tie on. Kākiʻi maila ʻo Kahakaloa i kāna laʻau pālau, a loaʻa ihola ka ʻaʻa o Kawelo (FS 89), Kahakaloa brandished his war club so as to reach Kawelo’s waist.

Bag, pocket, caul, envelope for a fetus, scrip; fiber from coconut husk; cloth-like sheath at base of coconut frond; cloth; chaff, hull; skin covering eyeballs. See ʻaʻa moni. ʻAʻa haole, foreign cloth. ʻAʻa maluna o ke ake, caul above the liver. Ka ʻaʻa o ke au ma ke akepaʻa, the caul of the bile and the liver. ʻAʻole kanaka ʻaʻa ʻole, no man without his scrip.
Same as Maʻaʻa, a wind.
Same as ʻā 4, booby bird.
Small root, rootlet, vein, artery, nerve, tendon, muscle. Fig. Womb, offspring. See ex., cerebral hemorrhage.

example_txt.txt: throbbing vein or artery, pulse; throbbing, as with excitement or passion
aerial roots, as put forth by ʻōhiʻa trees at high altitudes or in damp climates
kuʻu kaikaina i ke aʻa hoʻokahi
my younger sibling of the same womb
ke koko maloko o nā aʻa

definitions.dtxt: To cause a plant or slip to take root; to take root.

example_txt.txt: Ā e aʻa ana ʻo mea mā iā ʻoe.
Then they send their regards to you.

definitions.dtxt: To send greetings or love; joyous hospitality; joy at greeting a loved one. Cf. haaʻa.

To burn, blaze, glow; fire; staring, as eyes (see ʻaʻā maka). Fig. Angry; fury. ʻAʻā koke, combustible, inflammable. Ua ʻaʻā ka puʻu, the throat is on fire [with great thirst]. Ke ʻaʻā maila ka wahine, the woman burns hither [Pele and her volcanic fires approach]. Ua ʻaʻā ʻia au i ke aloha (FS 21), I burn with love. hoʻaʻā To kindle, light. Mea hoʻaʻā, fire kindling.
ʻAʻā lava; stony, abounding with ʻaʻa lava.
Sirius, a zenith star that passes over Tahiti and Raʻiātea, formerly believed used by navigators; one of the brightest stars in the heavens. See Sirius for var. names.
Young stage of damselfish (ʻāloʻiloʻi). Also ʻā.

Dumbness, inability to speak intelligibly, a dumb person; dumb, silent, still; to stutter and stammer, as a dumb person. Poʻe kuli a ʻāʻā, deaf mutes. Ua ʻāʻā ka leo, the voice is unintelligible. He ʻāʻā kō ka hale, the people of the house are silent. I lohe ʻia e nā ʻāʻā lololohe; i mau ʻāʻā lōlōkuli, it was heard from the dumb one who could hear, about those who were deaf and dumb.
Dwarf, small person; dwarfish, small. Kanaka poupou ʻāʻā, a short stout person. He ʻīlio ʻāʻā (KL. line 577), a short-legged dog.

Demented, panic-stricken. See ʻaʻā maka, ʻaʻaia. Holo ʻāʻā, to run about in a panic. hōʻāʻā To look about or search in confusion, stray, wander; disconcerted. E hōʻāʻā ana i nā makaaniani, looking in confusion for the spectacles.
Probable var. of ʻā 4, booby bird.
Male ʻōʻō bird.
Hospitable; friendly; kind to strangers, he makamaka aloha; SYN. with haaa.
Uninhabited, as a house or village; lonely.
A house without inhabitants; also a low or humble dwelling, he hale aaa, aole kiekie.
Cloth-like sheath at base of coconut frond; vascular bundles in taro corm, chaff, tissue; fibrous, stringy. Also hāʻaʻa.
Network of veins.
Redup. of ʻaʻā 1; lava cave.
Redup. of ʻāʻā 1.
Redup. of ʻaʻaʻa. ʻAʻaʻaʻa hoʻi kēia ʻuala, this sweet potato is full of fibers.
Bag for carrying fire-making equipment (ʻaʻa, bag, and ahi, fire).
Scion or shoot of sandalwood.
Tissue, as structural material of a plant or animal. ʻAʻaʻa hunaola ʻailakele. Adipose tissue, i.e., animal tissue in which fat is stored. See haʻakupu ʻailakele, ʻailakele.
Redup. of ʻaʻaki.
To bite often. See AKI, to bite.
A certain form of commencing worship anciently.
Aae, e kaulei, e lelei, e ku i kiona la oe e Kahamuili.
Second or third crop, as of taro; taro patch where the taro has been pulled up. Also ʻae.
See AA, fine roots. A kalo patch where the kalo is pulled.
The young shoots of kalo remaining in the ground after the old is pulled. SYN. with oha. as, pau ke kalo i ka hukiia, o ka oha wale no koe, oia ka aae.
The sound ay that infants make in calling for attention; to make this sound.
A word used by children in addressing parents before they can speak plainly.
Netted carrier for a calabash, made of sennit or olonā cord. More commonly called kōkō. Cf. ʻaha, sennit.
Name of some kind of outside covering for a dish. He ipu i hanaia i ka aaha a paa, the cup was held with the aaha, and tightly.

Arteriolosclerosis, in medicine. ʻO ke aʻahaʻapupū, ʻo ia ka paʻa ʻana ʻo loko o ka ʻili o ke aʻa koko puʻuwai a hoʻēmi ʻia ke kahe o ke koko. arteriosclerosis is the hardening of the inner walls of the arteries slowing blood flow. Comb. aʻa+ haʻapupū. Cf. aʻalāʻau.
A, bag, and ahi, fire. A bag in which fire and fire materials were carried; he kieke ahi.
Same as ʻiliahi, sandalwood. (And.)
Name of the iliahi or sandal-wood when young.
Burning fire. hoʻā ahi To set on fire.
See definition of AAMOO. Perhaps a and ahi, to burn, as with lust.
Pas/imp. of aʻa 2.
Thatch purlin; rails, as in a fence. See ʻahohui, ʻahopiʻo, ʻahopueo. Pā ʻaʻaho, corral, rail fence.
Container, as for pia, arrowroot starch; to put pia in small packages so that it may keep sweet.
A container in which pia is put up.
To put up pia in small packages, that it may keep sweet.
Hill, a kīpuka, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi (Macdonald and Abbott 390).
Same as haupia, coconut and arrowroot pudding.

Clothing in general, garment, array, attire, costume, mantle, gown; to put on or wear clothing, especially shirt, suit, or coat; to cover or wrap, as the body with a blanket. E ʻaʻahu aku ʻoe i kēia, wear this. ʻAʻahu hoʻohiwahiwa, festive attire, evening gown. ʻAʻahu i kau lula ʻia, formal attire. ʻAʻahu au i ka pono, I have clothed myself in righteousness. hōʻaʻahu To put clothing on someone else; to dress, supply with clothing, clothe.
Clothing. Nā ʻaʻahu hana keaka. Wardrobe, as stage costumes for a play, movie or video production. Usu. nā ʻaʻahu.
See AA, kind of cloth, and AHU, a fine mat. An outside garment. A cloak; a garment thrown loosely over the shoulders.

definitions.notes: Note: The aahu was formerly some kind of kapa; mamua, aahu kapa, mahope, aahu lole.
definitions.dtxt: A robe. A covering for ornament; aahu kapa maikai, the dress of a dandy, i.e., dandyism.
The bark of the mulberry soaked in. water for making kapa.
Aahu kaua, armor.
To cover with kapa; to cover, as with a cloak.
To put on or wear clothes; to put on one’s garment.
Aahu iho au i ka pono, I have clothed myself with righteousness.
Hoo. To clothe one; to provide clothes for one. SYN. with hookomo kapa.
Pas/imp. of ʻaʻahu.
Pass of ʻaʻahu for aahuia. Gram. § 211. Clothed; dressed; covered.
To speak reproachfully, contemptuously, deride, jeer; jealous challenge. (Gram. 6.5) ʻAʻahuā nohoʻi kāna mau ʻōlelo, his words are contemptuous.
To speak reproachfully; to use words of strong contempt for one.
Var. spelling of ʻaʻahuā.
Regal attire, a royal robe, a type of colored tapa worn by people of rank.
A fabulous being said to have had extraordinary strength, to have come from the center of the earth, and to have been the creator of all dwarfs. Cf. haʻakualiki.
The name of a god.
ʻāʻa, dwarf, and hualiʻi, diminutive. Small; low in stature; defective in bodily structure; noinoi.
Head shield; protection for the head in war, as helmet, shield.
Aahu, covering, and poo, head. A covering or clothing for the head; a defense in time of peril; a shield in war. A buckler. Connected with mahiole and palekaua.
Aching veins, varicose veins.
Aa, vein, and hui, pain, ache.
Lit. An aching vein.
A desire for pleasure, attended with some sense of pain. Pau ke aahui, ke aakoni oloko, the painful desire within has ceased.
Aahu, garment, and kapu, forbidden. A consecrated or holy garment.
Armor, war garment.
Tendon. See ex., wikani.
Military uniform; also written ʻaʻahu koa.
A long malo or ornamented band made of the soft makaloa rush; to put on or wear this garment.

definitions.der: [aahu, garment, malo and loa, long malo]
definitions.dtxt: To clothe one, or put on the long malo; ua aahuia ka maloloa, nolaila, he aahupawehe.
A large yellow robe worn by the king or high chief; no ka hanohano nui o ka aahumamo.
Full regalia, dress uniform.

Garment made of pāwehe, patterned mat; mat made of soft material and woven in the pāwehe pattern; to put on and wear this garment. No laila i ʻōlelo ʻia ai he ʻaʻahu pāwehe hiwa na ka makani, so it was called the choice patterned mat made by the spirits.
A garment made of a kind of mat called pawehe; nolaila i oleloia’i i aahupawehe hiwa na ka makani.
Var. of ʻahu ʻula.
A cloak or royal dress adorned with red feathers, considered very valuable; o ka aahuula, he waiwai makamae nui ia.
East slope of Mauna Kea, Hawaiʻi, (perhaps so called because of volcanic eruptions).

Redup. of ʻai 1; eating, spreading, festering, increasing, as a sore; ulcerous, cancerous, malignant; to eat away, corrode; to take bait readily, as fish; erosion. See ʻaʻaiole. He maʻi ʻaʻai, a spreading sore, infection, or cancer. ʻAʻai ka hīnālea i ka ʻōpae, the hīnālea fish takes the shrimp [bait] readily. Nā manaʻo ʻaʻai ʻawa kaniʻuhū, heartbreaking, sad thoughts.
Bright, vivid, as of contrasting colors. ʻAʻai ka lei hulu melemele i ka holokū ʻeleʻele, a yellow feather lei appears brighter on a black Mother hubbard.
Same as ʻaʻei, a net.
Maʻi ʻaʻai ʻanapuʻu. Lymphoma.
The progress or continuance of a sore.
See AI, to eat. To eat to satiety; to consume much.
To increase or grow, as an ulcer.
To ulcerate; to eat or make progress, as a sore.
FIG. To give pain; irritate. 2 Tim 2:17. Aole hoi e aai ka hewa iloko o ka poe e ku. paa ana, sin will not increase in those who stand fast.
Name of the net used to catch the fish opelu and maomao; as, aai opelu, the opelu net; aai maomao, the maomao net; also written aei.
The action of the surf at high tide, when dashing ashore and then receding, thus wearing away the gravel; spelled also aei.
Eating; increasing; continuing, as a sore; he mai aai, an increasing sore, he lepera aai ia.
Demented.

example_txt.txt: ʻO Moikeha, mai Kahiki ka hele ʻana mai, i ʻaʻaia i ke aloha o luʻukia.
Moikeha was from Kahiki, where he was mad with love for lu'ukia.

definitions.dtxt: Legendary bird believed to have taken the shape of the ʻā, booby bird. See ʻā 4.
Weathered; weathering.

definitions.der: [Lit. eroded by surf. Pali ʻaʻaianalu. wave-cut cliff]
definitions.dtxt: Eroded or cut by waves, as a cliff.

definitions.der: [Lit. caterpillar eater of Kāne. See ʻā 4]
definitions.dtxt: Legendary bird.
Erosion; to erode; eroded.
Redup. of ʻaʻina.
Loudly; strongly, as a sound, kani aaina; also continually. See AAI, to increase.

Inferior, weak, said of breadfruit or fruit with a weak stem that may fall before maturity; weak object. (Kep. 93) Fig. Of persons dying before their time. mai lou i ka ʻulu i luna loa, o lou hewa i ka ʻaʻaiole, eia nō ka ʻulu i ke alo, don't pluck the breadfruit on top or you will pluck one not securely fastened, there is the breadfruit in front.
The bread-fruit which is ripe and fallen down of itself.
ʻaʻai, to grow, and ʻole, not. Falling before ripe, as bread-fruit; applied to men who die before their time, i.e., before maturity.
Surly, cranky, roiled, complaining, irritable, peevish, bad tempered, cantankerous, cross; severe, as labor. See ex., papaioa.
To act surly, to pretend to be cross.

Dry, as coral of the reef at low tide; parched, wrinkled, dry and thirsty; peeling off, as the tough skin of such fish as the humuhumu after it has been in the fire; to crackle, burst, as a ripe melon.
Rocky undersea cavern, (PH 219, Malo 26)
Wood of the naio, bastard sandalwood.
Harsh speaking against one; a grumbling; a fault-finding.
Name of a species of sandalwood. When young it is called naio; when old and when mature, it is odoriferous. It is very durable when used for house posts.
Coarse; illiberal; fault-finding; hard; severe.
Peeled; skinned, as a banana.
Dry, as the coral of the reef at low tide.
5th conj. of aka. See Gram. § 209. To laugh at; to ridicule.
To complain, as a person of a perverse or sour temper; to grumble; chide; find fault; to strive. Iole makou e aaka a koea iho, that we may not think hard and refuse.
To be very dry; to be exceedingly thirsty.
To burst or crack open, as a ripe melon or banana.
To be hard, severe, as labor or toil; aole i aakaia ka hana a na haku, the work for the lords was not hard.
Ridge, Waimea district, Kauaʻi. Lit. roiled.
Ancient surfing area, Lahaina, Maui. (Finney and Houston 28) Lit. roiled.
A Step, as on a carriage; running board of an automobile.
The clear burning or splendor of the heavenly bodies in a clear night.
Gulch, Puʻukapu qd., Oʻahu.

Civil disobedience, i.e., breaking a law because it goes against personal morals. Ua kaulana ʻo Martin Luther King no kōna aʻo ʻana i ka ʻaʻa kānāwai ʻana me ka hakakā ʻole. Martin Luther King was famous for his teaching of non-violent civil disobedience.

Redup. of ʻaki 1; to nip repeatedly; to take a nip and hold on (cf. nahu, to bite with the whole mouth, and nau, to chew); a bite, nibble. Fig. Thick, obscure, dark, penetrating; to feel pangs, as of love or childbirth.

example_txt.txt: Ka naho manini nui, ke ʻaʻaki nei i ka limu.
The cleft with the large manini fish, nibbling now at the seaweed.
to close the mouth so tightly that the molars cling, as in lockjaw
Ua ʻaʻaki paʻa ʻia ke aloha wela i luna o Kaʻōnohiokalā.
Hot love was firmly clutched upon Kaʻōnohiokalā.
Ke ʻaʻaki nei ka pō ʻeleʻele.
The utter blackness of night is all-engulfing.

definitions.dtxt: A biting; ka naho manini nui, he aaki nei i ka limu.
5th conj. of aki. To bite frequently; to bite in two; to bite, as the bark from a stick, or the rind from sugar-cane.
To grate the teeth; ua aaki ke kui, ua make loa, he grates his teeth, he is dying.
To feel the severe pangs of child-birth.
To surround or come upon one, as darkness; ua pouli loa, ke aaki mai nei ka poeleele.
To experience palpable darkness.
To be caught or held by a thing; ua holo ia kanaka i ka moana, ua aaki i ke koa a paa, that man sailed out upon the ocean, he is caught in the coral, and is fast.
To come upon, as a fit of love; na aaki paa ia ke aloha wela iluna ona. Laieik. 197.
Thick; obscure, as darkness,
A hook nibbler, said of small fish that nibble away the bait; to nibble at a hook.
A hook-biting fish; the name of a small fish noted for its readiness to bite at a hook. See A.
Vein. Also aʻa koko kino. Cf. aʻa puʻuwai.
Jugular vein.
Pulmonary vein.
Renal vein.
Femoral vein.
Iliac vein.
Tibial vein.
See wenakawa.
Redup. of ʻako 1, 2; repeated plucking; insatiable lust; to get into action (rare). ʻAʻako aku i ka hana, get going with the work.
Ako, the name of a disease.
The furor uteriensis of females; insatiable desire of coition; aako kahi mai i ka hana hewa.
The itch; he maneo; he lalawe. This last form of the word expresses the name of the last stage of the disease, followed by death. A primary stage is expressed by ako, to itch.
Used in the imperative; be quick; go to work, etc.
5th conj. of ako. To cut or clip off, as the spray of the sea when the surf strikes against a bluff of perpendicular rocks and is met by a wind from the land, and cuts or clips off the spray.
Vein, blood vessel.
A vein; a blood vein. Anat. 43.
Vein. Also aʻa kino. Cf. aʻa koko puʻuwai.
Artery. Also aʻa puʻuwai. Cf. aʻa koko kino.
A root running horizontally that produces roots below and above; a rhizome, creeping root.
An artery, perhaps; pau ke aahui, ke aalihui, ke aakoni oloko.
Name of a combination of diseases: liver complication resulting in hardening of the veins, bloody dysentery accompanied by fever.
Gulch and old heiau for human sacrifices, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
Varicose veins.

Fragrant, sweet-smelling; fragrance, perfume, fume, aroma, sweet scent. Fig. Of high rank, royal. He ʻaʻala nō ʻo Kaʻahumanu, Kaʻahumanu is of sweet high rank. Pupuka hoʻi paha, he ʻaʻala ka inoa, ugly perhaps, but a noble name.
Winds.
ʻAla. An odor.
A kind of scrofulous sore, so called from the smell.
He ʻaʻala nō ʻo Kaʻahumanu, a sweet perfume is Kaahumanu.
5th conj. of ala, to perfume. To emit a perfume; to be fragrant.
To smell of perfumery. Hal 45:8. Aala i ka ihuana ka uka o Kawela.
Ala, odoriferous; aala ka hala, sweet the hala; aala ka rose, sweet the rose; o na kaikuwahine aala o Aiwohikupua. Laieik. 62.
Lane, park, street, and section 13 of Honolulu (map 6). Lit. fragrant (said to be named for the sweet smell of nearby laundries; TM).
Arteriosclerosis, atherosclerosis, hardening of the arteries, in medicine. Cf. aʻahaʻapupū.
Name of a wind accompanied by rain associated with Hilo.

example_txt.txt: Ke honi maila kō Hilo pali kū, kū ka makani he ʻAʻala Honua kiʻi ua.
Those of Hilo with its sheer precipices inhale as the rain-bringing Earth-Fragrance wind blows.

definitions.dtxt: The millet butterfly fish (Chaetodon Miliaris). § Hawaiian Annual, 1889.
Young of the ʻalaʻihi fishes.
A species of fish, small and yellow.
Wild, demented person; uncivilized.
Name of a wild ferocious man who lived in the forest; hence,
Wildness; ferocity; a savage appearance; kuku ka aalaioa.
Insipid, unsavory, tasteless.
Large, plump. Cf. ʻuʻulukai.
See ALAKAI. Large; plump; full fleshed.
Wind name.

A i ka la hoomalolo i ka hiku o ka hora, holo aku la au maluna o ka lio, a pii i ka pali o Aalaloloa me ka lio no. A ma Kealia aku, hele au ma ke alanui ma kula a me Haliamaile, a hiki i Haiku, a iho au i kai. Maikai no ke ala, maikai hoi kela mau aina, kupu nui mai na mea kanu; aka, ua waiho wale ka nui o keia aina maikai, a lilo i ka nahelehele.

Komo iho la keia koko hou a maikai ma ka pepeiao hema o ka puuwai, upa koke iho la ia, a komo ke koko iloko o ka opu hema; upa ka opu hema, a holo ke koko iloko o ke aalapuu, a malaila aku ma na aalele e manamana aku ai ma ke kino a puni.

Velvety-green, succulent-appearing seaweeds, one of several species of Codium. It yields a red liquid when placed in a container overnight with brine, after chopping or pounding. Both the liquid and the seaweed are well liked, being eaten plain or with other food. (KL. line 47) ʻAʻalaʻula is the common name on Kauaʻi and Maui, wāwaeʻiole elsewhere.
Pulse.
An artery, from its motion. Anat. 8.
Redup. of ʻali 1; scarred, marked, grooved; depression, groove; wattles of a fowl; slight depression under the gills of a fish.
A small or low place between two larger ones; he puali.

Native hardwood shrubs or trees (Dodonaea, all species), 30 cm to 10 m high, more or less sticky at branch tips; leaves narrow, 2 to 10 cm long; flowers small; fruit a yellow, red, or brown papery capsule about 1 cm long and with two to four wings. Fruit clusters are made into leis with their own leaves or ferns and worn in the hair. A boast of the people of Kaʻū, is: He ʻaʻaliʻi au, ʻaʻohe makani e hina ai, I am an ʻaʻaliʻi shrub, no wind can push me over. See similar ex., ʻulaʻa. Also ʻaʻaliʻi kū makani (ʻaʻaliʻi standing [in] wind), ʻaʻaliʻi kū ma kua (ʻaʻaliʻi standing in back).
Name of a hard timber; more generally alii.
Same as pūkiawe, shrubs.
Scarred. (PH 218)
Large, fat, weak, as a fat person.
Large, fat and weak, as a fat man.
Redup. of ʻalo 1, 2.
To resist, as water on corrosive things.

example_txt.txt: water-resistant watch, also uāki ʻaʻalo wai

definitions.dtxt: 5th conj. of alo. To dodge often; to dodge, as one does a stone.
Cloth-like sheath at base of coconut frond; European cloth.
The name first given to cloth by the people of Kauai.
Nerve.
Nerve.
A nerve; aalolo hoao. Anat. 18.
Receptor, as of nerve endings in the body, in biology.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ke aʻalonoa o ke aʻalolo ke ʻike mua i ke kūlale.
The receptors of the nerves are the first to sense stimuli.

definitions.dtxt: Ravine, small stream, valley, depression. Cf. ʻalu, depression.
Dim. of alu. A ravine; a small brook, valley or ravine.
A large, black, edible crab (Grapsus tenuicrustatus) that runs over shore rocks.

example_txt.txt: rock crab with yellow back; Fig. swift, strong warrior.

definitions.dtxt: To spread and relax, as the fingers. [The ʻaʻama crab was offered in sacrifices so that the gods would loosen (ʻaʻama) and grant the request.)
Redup. of ʻama 1; to talk.
That motion of the hands when a person would try to seize hold of something while it rolls down a pali.
The act of stealing or pilfering.
A black crab living on a rocky shore.
Name of a four-footed animal in the sea.
A person who speaks rapidly, concealing from one and communicating to another.
One who is expert in gaining knowledge.
To stretch out the hands for the purpose of catching something.
To steal small articles; to pilfer.
To stare or glare with wide-open eyes, as in desire, fear, or intent to frighten; one who does so. hōʻaʻā maka To stare.
Gulch, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi.
Place name in Kohala; mentioned in the 1835 Census.
Coconut-leaf or pandanus-leaf bag used for carrying birds.
Land section, Hāmākua qd., Hawaiʻi.
Same as ʻamo 2; contraction of anal muscles.
Insatiable in lust; never satisfied; applied to females; he wahine aamo, ana ole.
Broken blood vessel.
Purse. Biblical.
Young cloth-like sheath at base of coconut frond; gauze, as of a veil; diaphanous cloth. Lit. ʻaʻa portion.
Snakeskin; slime, as on fresh water.
See AA. The cloth-substance around coconut leaves; a veil; thin white cloth; o ka moa keokeo e lalahi ana i ka moo, he mea lahilahi a puaweawe; whatever is light, thin, as thin cloth.
Light; thin, as cloth; o ka inoa o ka lole lahilahi loa.
To use abusive language, revile, malign. Cf. ʻaʻa, daring. Mai ʻaʻana mai ʻoe, donʻt use defiant language. hōʻaʻana Caus/sim.
To speak angrily; to fret; olelo aana mai oia.
I kuu ike ana i ka wai i hookaheia mai loko mai o kona opu, manao iho la au, mawaho wale no ia wai o ka aanaau, aole ma kahi i holo ai ka wai a kakou e luu nei i ka wa pono.
Adventure, as a story or movie. Comb. ʻaʻa + nahoa.
Redup. of ʻanai.
Var. of kakanaliʻi, stunted.
Redup. of ʻanapuʻu, bumpy.
To crook in different directions; to be small and large, i.e., to be uneven in size, as a rope.
An interrogative adverb, and marks a question like anei; sometimes it is used of place, as pehea aanei la oe? where are you in the matter?
To criticize maliciously; malign.
To be jealous of a man’s friend, or to discover jealousy.
Clothlike sheath at base of coconut frond.
The covering like a coarse cloth around cocoanut leaves; a hookahekahe ma ka aaniu.
Overbearing, arrogant, bold, defiant, daring; bully. Cf. ʻaʻa.
To act the bully, bluff, defy, boast of courage that may be lacking; to challenge, take risks, act bold or defiant, dare.
The 7th conj. of ano. Hoo. To change one’s form; to become another in appearance; ua hooano no oukou he poe akamai; to feign; to pretend to be something one is not.
Greedy, voracious.
Uncultivated bananas.
Greedy, as dogs; always ready to eat, or seize food.
A species of tall, wild banana, he maia aao.
Same as ʻao kahi. E hele ke kalo ā ʻaʻao hoʻokahi, the taro grew until there was only one leaf left.

definitions.der: [aa, vein or artery, and koko, blood]
definitions.dtxt: Epithet of any substance red hot, as fire, iron, stone, etc.; probably from the raging or rapid flow of blood.

He kinikini na aaomo e hookomo ana ko lakou waha ma na naau a pau, he liilii me he hulu puaa la ka nui, a ua piha lakou i ka ai heehee, ua like me ka waiu kona ano. Huiia na aaomo i hookahi ma ka aoao hema o ke kuamoo, ua like kona nui me he hulu nene la, he keekee nae ka waiho ana.
Redup. of ʻapa. Cf. ʻapaʻapa.
Presumptuous, as when a drunken man lies down on a precipice.
Valve of a vein.
Pothos. Redup. of ʻape + hihi. ʻAʻapehihi lau liʻi. Philodendron.
ʻAʻā lava or flow, volcanic.
Warped, curved.
5th conj. of api. To bend, as the gills of a fish; to spring or warp, as a board.
To learn quickly, to catch the meaning quickly, apt. Cf. ʻapo, ʻapoʻapo.
One who snatches.
One who learns quickly; a ready scholar.
Ready, quick to receive knowledge; quick at apprehension; he aapo ka naau o na kamalii.
5th conj. of apo, to catch. To snatch, as several persons at once; to catch at, as several hands at the same thing.
To receive readily in the mind; to grasp mentally, as a truth; ke aapo nei makou a malama.
Flanker, in football. Comb. ʻā- + ʻapo.
The skin, flesh and sinews on the back of the neck; he aapoo ka mea ma ka ai he aapoo bipi. Kam.
Coconut-shell cup; cup-like. Also ʻapu.
To form a cup of the hollow of the hand; to fold a leaf into a cup.
To warp, bend, ruffle.
See APU, a cup. A thin piece of wood, such as will bend up.
A concave vessel.
A valve of a vein. Anat. 45.
To warp or bend, as a board in the sun.
To wrinkle or ruffle, as cloth; mimino. See AAPI.
Hoo. To turn the hollow of the hand upward; e hooaapu ae i kou poho lima.
Pepeiao ʻaʻapu. Semilunar valve, of the heart.
Same as aʻapau.
Arrow case, quiver.
An arrow case; a quiver.
Girdle, belt.
Capsular ligament.
Knots in a fish net.
A capsular ligament.
Sharp or waterworn, coarse gravel or rock.
Artery. Also aʻa koko puʻuwai. Cf. aʻa kino. See entries below.
Carotid artery.
Pulmonary artery.
Renal artery.
Femoral artery.
Iliac artery.
Tibial artery.
Same as ʻapuwai, a variety of taro.
To move here and there, wander, rove; to ripple, as the sea. Ka lele ʻaʻau o ka manu, the flight here and there [as in fright] of the bird.
Redup. of ʻau, stalk. ʻAʻau loa (Malo 59, 63), long stalks; Fig. Long-suffering and patient, as of a chief who cared for his people.
See AU. To swim dispersedly; a flock, as of birds when frightened; a school, as of fish as they come together and frightened; suddenly separate.
A slight ripple on the surface of calm water by a light breeze.
To ripple mildly, as a calm sea, by a slight wind.
To separate, as a flock of birds when frightened, or a school of fish.
Ka lele aau o ka manu o Kiwaa,
The frightened flight of the birds of Kiwaa.
Ka aau mai Kukona ke koae,
The flock from Kukona, the koae.
Ke koae nui hulu meamea,
The great feathered koae.
Coarse, as wrinkled or blotched skin; lean, as fish. Also ʻaua, māʻaua. Puaʻa ʻaʻaua, old tough pig.
Epithet of a woman as she begins to advance in age, has wrinkles about the eyes, etc.
Strong scented, as the skin of a hog in dressing.
Wrasse fishes, Hawaiian hogfish (Bodianus bilunulatus), considered ʻaumākua by some. The name ʻaʻawa may be qualified by the terms ʻeʻa, hai ʻeʻa, lelo, ule holu (pliable penis). Also poʻou.
Same as ʻaʻawa hua kukui.
Name given for an insect that destroys potatoes. (And.)
Ancient surfing area near Waiehu, West Maui. (Finney and Houston 28)
See AWA. Name of a species of fish, reddish and striped; he ia kokoke like ke ano me ko ka ea.
Also the name of a tree.
Name of an insect that destroys sweet potatoes; ua make ka mala uala i ka hoopalu, i ke pai, i ka peelua a me ka aawa.

A native tree (Pittosporum hosmeri and its varieties), about 6 m high, with leaves 10 to 25 cm by 1.5 to 6 cm, shiny and wrinkled above, brown-wooly beneath; small, clustered, cream-colored flowers; ovoid fruits about 5 cm long, each with two to four thick valves containing orange pulp and black oily seeds. Also hōʻawa, hāʻawa.
Small island (0.35 acres, 40 feet elevation), Kahakuloa qd., Maui.
Small island (0.09 acres, 40 feet elevation), Kahakuloa qd., Maui.
Same as ʻawe, to carry.
5th conj. of awe. Used imperatively with mai, bring here; with aku, take away.
Mountain, Hanalei district, Kauaʻi.
Father; he makuakane.
An irregular movement of the ocean; he wahi ano ia ma ka moana, a ma ka ae kai, a ma ka aina.
The coming in and receding of the sea upon the shore; the flux and reflux of the tide. See AEKAI.
Name of an east wind.
A species of sea moss.
The water or liquid as wrung from the leaves of vegetables, as kalo. etc.; he ae kalo, he ae wauki, he ohi.
To pass, physically or mentally, from one state, condition, or place, to another.
Specifically, to break a kapu, ua ae lakou iluna o kahi laa; to violate a law or agreement, i.e., to transgress, as a law, to break a covenant.
To pass over, as the mind, i.e., to yield assent to the thought or opinion of another; to assent to the request of another; to say yes to a request or to an affirmation.
To permit, grant permission for a thing to be done; he mea ae ia, a thing permitted or allowed.
To pass physically from one place to another, from one situation to another, as from land on board a ship; ua ae aku lakou iluna o ka moku, iluna o ka lio, to embark, to mount a horse. Hoo.
Verbal directive. Gram. § 234, 4. Implies an oblique motion of the verb, either up, down, or sideways. It often follows after nouns, also adjectives, as aohe kanaka e ae, there is no other man.
Yes; to say yes, consent, conform, grant, agree, approve, let, confirm, admit, permit, allow, accept, yield; approval, admission, permission. Cf. aʻe nei.

example_txt.txt: Ua ʻae mai ʻoia i koʻu hele.
Kahe ka ʻae o ka waha.
Mouth saliva flows [mouth waters; Fig. To desire avidly].

definitions.dtxt: Sap wrung from seaweed or leaves of plants such as taro; liquid remaining after dregs have settled, as of pia, arrowroot starch; saliva, drooling of the mouth. ʻAe limu, juice remaining on the pounding board after seaweed (limu) is pounded; mixed with salt it is used to flavor sauce for ʻōʻio or other fish.

example_txt.txt: fine portions of ti root baked in the oven; to break ti root so cooked into fine bits

definitions.dtxt: Fine, mashed, comminuted, as dust or powder; silky soft, as down; smooth, as well-mixed poi or bread dough.

example_txt.txt: a hot glowing fire that pulverizes

definitions.dtxt: To make fine, pulverize, refine, soften.
To rise, of the tide.
Caus/sim.

A native fern (Polypodium pellucidum) commonly seen at Kīlauea Volcano. It has oblong fronds 15 to 40 cm long, once divided into about fifteen or more pairs of oblong segments, each of which bears many round fruit dots. Cf. ʻae lau nui.
Same as ʻaʻae.
Shoots from main root portion of the wauke plant. See ohi 3.
See ʻae kai, water’s edge.
To lend, not to borrow.

example_txt.txt: E ʻoluʻolu e ʻae mai i kāu peni.
Please lend me your pen; may I borrow your pen?

definitions.dtxt: Assent, expressed by one person to the thought or opinion of another; approval of the conduct or opinion of another; consent; agreement.
Consenting; agreeing; he olelo ae like, an agreement.

See verb 2. Yes; the expression of affirmation, approbation or consent; opposed to aole, or aohe. With paha, as ae paha, a polite way of assenting when full belief is withheld; ae ka paha. even so, be it so.

To step over, get on top of, tread upon, trespass; to raise; to massage the back with the feet; to break a taboo or violate a law; counter sorcery; to inflict sorcery on a sorcerer; to get into by stepping up, as into a car; step. Fig. Oppressed.

example_txt.txt: to trespass, break a law or taboo deliberately; disrespectful of taboo
Ua ʻaʻe lākou i luna o kahi laʻa.
They trespassed on a taboo place; they broke an agreement, law, taboo.
ʻaʻohe i ʻaʻe i ka wela a ka lā
not oppressed by the heat of the sun

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.

Several native trees, the soapberry (Sapindus saponaria f. inaequalis), and all species of Zanthoxylum (also known as Fagara, Zanthoxylum having yellowish wood formerly used for digging sticks and spears); seeds of all (largest in the soapberry) are black, round, and used for leis. Also mānele.
Northeast tradewind. Cf. Aʻe Loa, Moaʻe, naʻe.
Blight. (Malo 199)

Directional particle. Upward, sideways, nearby, contiguous, adjoining, next, approaching (often expresses space and time near the addressee, table 2, Gram. 7.2). Aʻe also commonly expresses the comparative degree: maikaʻi aʻe, better. Followed by nei, aʻe indicates recent past. Aʻe + demon. lā is pronounced and written as a single word, aʻela.

example_txt.txt: the one born just before me [older sibling, the one before me].
ia lā aʻe, ia lā aʻe
Ua hele aʻe nei no Maui.
He said to someone nearby. (Cf. aku 2)

definitions.dtxt: Replacement of e in songs (commonly written a e, but a glottal stop is pronounced before ʻe).

chants.mltran: ♫  We do not care about the government’s sum of money.
chants.mltxt: ♫  ʻAʻole mākou aʻe minamina i ka puʻu kālā a ke aupuni.

definitions.dtxt: Maui name for maua 2, trees.
To rise up; to raise the head; to come up from under water.

chants.mltran: ♫  Dive down and come up
chants.mltxt: ♫  Luʻu aku a aea mai

definitions.dtxt: Cord, as used in joining two or more nets into a larger one.
Pas/imp. of ʻaʻe 1.

Wandering, shiftless, unstable; to wander, stray; tramp. Cf. hōkū ʻaeʻa. ʻAeʻa haukaʻe, vagrant person, tramp, beachcomber, trespasser; to trespass (lit., defiled wanderer). Kanaka ʻaeʻa, wanderer, drifter, tramp (less pejorative than ʻaeʻa huakaʻe). One ʻaeʻa, shifting sands. hōʻaeʻa To cause to wander; to wander. Na ke kaumaha i hōʻaeʻa iāia mai ke one hānau mai, it was grief that caused him to wander from his homeland.
A vagabond; an outcast. He poe aea, fugitives.
The name of the rope connecting two fish nets. See KUKAI.
Wandering; unstable; shifting a place; he one aea ke one o Hoohila; unsettled, as kanaka aea; a vagabond; wandering about.
Wanderingly, in a loose unstable manner.
To wander away from a place; mai ko'u alo aku, aole oe e aea, from my presence, do not wander away; to wander from place to place. Nah,. 14:33.
To wander; go astray morally.
To remove; to be removed; to go to another place.
To live unsteadily; as, i kona wa i ona ai, nui kona aea ana, in his seasons of drunkenness, he lived principally here and there.
To toss or throw back the head, as a person with pride, as a horse on putting on a bridle; e aea ae ke poo o ka lio i ke kaulawaha.
Comminuted; small or fine, as dust; fine, as poi well pounded; he poi aeae, he poi uouo, he wali.
Dark, obscure, as a vision, indistinctly seen; po aeae, a night of indistinct vision, not totally dark, i.e., light and darkness mixed.
Conj. 13 of ae, 4. To be a frequent transgressor, he aeae oe maluna o kahi kapu.
To step over a thing often.
To work over and over, as in pounding poi, until very fine.
To be or become very small or fine, as dust. 2 Nal 23:6.
To interrupt one in his speech.

A prolonged sound, wail; to prolong, stretch. hoʻāeae A style of chanting with prolonged vowels and fairly short phrases, much used in love chants; to chant in this fashion; to read or recite Bible passages or multiplication tables.
Andante.
Redup. of ʻaʻe.
Redup. of ʻae 3. See lole, mehelu.
To make soft, fine, etc.

A small native shrub (Lycium sandwicense) growing near salt marshes and among rocks near the sea. It has light-colored bark; succulent, narrow pale-green leaves about 2.6 cm long; small white to blue-tinted flowers; and small red berries. Also ʻākulikuli ʻaeʻae, ʻākulikuli ʻōhelo, and ʻōhelo kai.
Water hyssop, a succulent herb (Bacopa monnieria). Niʻihau
Redup. of ʻae 4. ʻAeʻae kai, raise of the tide; froth of the sesa.
Fine, as sand. Cf. mānoanoa.

example_txt.txt: aʻeaʻe mōhala i luna o ke kukui
streaks of silvery gray showing on the candlenut tree [said of a graying person]

definitions.dtxt: Mixing of a dark or brilliant color with a lighter one, as feathers in a lei; of dark hair of a young person with streaks of gray; to mix, as drinks.
A kind of banana with green and white striped leaves and fruits. Also koaʻe and manini.
A fish (no data).
Banana variety with green and white striped fruit and leaves.
A small green fish resembling the hīnālea, used as pani (food or drink taken to finish a medical treatment) for certain diseases of children of the ʻea type.
Name of a star (no data).
See AE, before. The ebbing and flowing of the sea.
See ʻaeʻa.
A variety of wild sweet potato, good only as pig food.
To cross, as a street. See ʻaʻehina.
Crosswalk. See ʻaʻehi.
Fine net, as used for ʻōpelu and maomao fish; it was held open at the mouth by kuku, stretching poles.
Name of the net used in catching the opelu and the maomao.
A kind of rope, of the medium size.
See AAI, before. Oia ka malama e kalai ai i ka kuku aei o Pelu.
Chant refrain.
Chant ending.
See AAIOLE. Bread-fruit, ripe and fallen down, he ulu haule wale.
Place where sea and land meet; water’s edge.
The name of the place in the sea where the surf breaks; o kahi o ke kai i poi iho ai, he aekai ka inoa.
Ancient type of tapa (no data).
To break the law. Also haʻihaʻi kānāwai. Cf. pale kānāwai.
Aegean. Ke kai ʻo ʻAekeana. Aegean Sea.
Falcon, vulture.
Name of an unclean bird.
Eagle.
Alto See ʻaleko.
An eagle. Gr. αετός
Golden eagle.

definitions.der: [Lit. white-haired eagle. Also ʻāeto poʻo hina]
definitions.dtxt: Bald eagle.
Directional part. aʻe + demon. lā. See ex., aʻe 4.
Same as ʻae 5, with large leaves.

Agreement, contract, truce, accord, deal; to come to an agreement; contracted. Palapala ʻaelike, contract. Nā mea ʻaelike, terms or conditions of agreement. ʻAelike hoʻokuʻu ma kahi, compromise, one side gives up.
See entries below. Hoʻokuʻu ʻaelike. To cede, as land or territory. Kūkaʻi ʻaelike ʻuniona. Collective bargaining.

Cloture, i.e., a method of ending debate and causing an immediate vote to be taken. Ke hāpai maila ka luna hoʻomalu o ka ʻaha kenekoa e komo i ka ʻaelike hoʻōki i hiki ke hoʻopau i ka paio kālaimanaʻo a hoʻoholo i ka pila. The senate leader is proposing that the session enter into cloture so that the debate can end and the bill be decided.
Compact, i.e., a written agreement to make and obey laws for the welfare of the group.

Rotten, of eggs that do not hatch due to infertility. Fig. Spoiled, worthless. Hua āelo, rotten egg; Fig. In vain, worthless. E mālama hoʻi o hua āelo ka luhi o ka hoʻoikaika ʻana, be careful, lest the wearisomeness of the effort be in vain.
Rotten; applied to eggs. Fig. Ua like makou me na hua aelo.
Name for the trade wind. See ex., kiʻekiʻe. Cf. Aʻe 2, Moaʻe, welo 1.
The northeast trade wind on the ocean; same as moae.
Violation, as in basketball.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ke kake iki akula nō ia o Niu, a hoʻōho maila ka ʻuao i ka ʻaʻena ʻekolu kekona.
Niu just shifted a little, and the official called him on the three-second violation.

definitions.dtxt: Violation, as in volleyball.

example_txt.txt: three-meter line violation, see laina ʻekolu mika
ten-foot line violation, see laina ʻumi kapuaʻi

definitions.dtxt: Bread-fruit. See AAINEI.

example_txt.txt: E like me kaʻu i ʻōlelo aʻe nei.

definitions.dtxt: Just now, lately; nearby, not far; ordinary, insignificant.
To be here; to be present; to be in existence.

NOTE. This word seems to be compounded of ae, No. 4, expressive of a passing or transfer, and nei, which refers to present time or present place; something not fixed or exactly defined, but near by, either in time or place, as at this present.
Now, i.e., about this time, just now, within a short time past or future.

Here; hereabouts; near by; not far off; ua holo aenei, he has just now sailed; ua olelo aenei, he has lately spoken; ua make aenei no ke alii, the king died a short time ago; ua hele aenei no kahi i noho ai, he is gone a little ways to his place of residence.
Stilts.
Hawaiian stilt bird (Himantopus mexicanus knudseni), an endemic subspecies of stilt, formerly common on the main Hawaiian Islands, endangered. Also kukuluaeʻo.
Same as kīholo 1, wood fishhook. Kauaʻi.
Train of a dress (origin uncertain). (KAM. 76:99)
To be well supplied with comforts and necessities. He nohona ʻaeʻoia, a well-supplied way of life. Ua ʻaeʻoia aʻela ka ʻohana, the family has all it needs.
A kind of fine tapa, used in kuni and other ceremonies, as for divining with pebbles. Also kahaloa, pālauanahu.
A kind of kapa made of wauke, and colored with charcoal, kuina aeokahaloa.
Pogo stick.
Solvent front, i.e., the leading edge of a moving solvent as in a developing chromatogram. Cf. ʻae kai.
Sandy beach.
To go out of bounds, in sports. Lit. trespass (a) boundary.
See ʻāeko poʻo hina.
Thin, tall spindly; to weave to and fro, as seaweed; to sway, as a branch or sea eddy. Cf. ewa, māewa. Ulu maikaʻi a āewa hua ʻole (Kep. 159), growing well but spindly and fruitless [of bananas].
Possessing a family or lineage. Cf. ēwe 1. Hānau ka huelo māewa, he āewa kona (KL. line 525), born [those of] tail-end [junior] rank, they have their lineage.
Afghanistan, spelling used in 19th century newspapers.
Afghanistan; Afghan, Afghani. Also ʻApekanikana.
An agate; a precious stone.
An interjection of surprise, wonder, etc. Ua heluhelu lakou, aha; ua loaa lakou e moe ana, aha.

Declinable with the definite article; indeclinable with the indefinite. Gram. § 159. Heaha, what? often united with the article; why? for what reason? No keaha? i keaha? It is also used as an interrogative adverb, why?

A company or assembly of people for any purpose. Often compounded with some qualifying word; as, ahaaina, ahaolelo, ahakanaka, ahahookolokolo, ahamokomoko, etc. See these compounds, which are sometimes written in one word, and sometimes divided. Ahaakohipa. a company for shearing sheep.
A cord braided from the husk of the cocoanut.
A cord braided from human hair.

Strings made from the intestines of animals; ka naau i mea aha moa, the intestines for strings to tie fowls with; he aha, pulu niu; he aha waa a me ka aha hoa waa, a cord for tying and strengthening a canoe in a storm; he aha palaoa, he lauoho i hili nilo ia.

Name of a certain prayer connected with a kapu; ina walaau ke kanaka i ka aha, make no ia, if a man should make a noise during the prayer, he would die, i.e., he would be guilty of an offense for which he would forfeit his life. The name originated in the fact that cocoanut fibre (see AHA, below) is very strong when braided into strings; so this prayer, with its rigid kapus, was supposed to be very efficacious in holding the kingdom together in times of danger.

The success or answer of a prayer, or such a proper performance of prayer as to insure success; loaa ka kakou aha, we have received our prayer, i.e., the answer; ua lilo ka aha, alaila, e pule hou, the prayer is lost, (of no avail,) then pray again.
Name of a small piece of wood, around which was wound a piece of kapa, and held in the hand of the priest while offering sacrifices.
Name of a kind of kapa made on Molokai.
The earwig.
The name of a species of long fish swimming near the surface of the water.
Used in the expressions, ua like na aha, the sides are equal; aha like, meaning side—measure perhaps.
See HA. Four; the number four; also eha.
To stretch the cord by which the first posts of a house were put down or set straight; e kii i ke kaula e aha ai, fetch the rope to make straight with.
Aha, oia ka ana a me ka aha pololei no ke aupuni, aha, that is, to measure and direct straightly the government.
To what; to do, etc.; e aha ana oia? what shall he do? Of course it is used only in the interrogative.

definitions.der: [PPN haa and probably hafa, PEP afa]
definitions.dtxt: Why? What? For what reason? To do what? To ask what? (Aha frequently follows he and is often written heaha; cf. Gram. 4.6, 8.5) He aha? What is it? what? He aha kēlā? What is that? He aha kāna? What has he got there? What does he have to say about it? What business is it of his [sarcastic]? I ke aha? Why? What for? He aha ia mea? What of it [frequently spoken with an outward gesture of the right hand with palm upwards]? He … aha? What kind of? For what purpose? He hale aha kēlā? What kind of a house is that? What is it used for? He mea aha? What’s it used for [annoyance]? Why? He aha ihola lā, no one knows why, for no apparent reason. He aha ihola lā ʻo ka ua nō ia, for no reason it’s raining. To what? Why? E hele ana ʻoe i ke aha? Why are you going? No ke aha? Why? E aha ana ʻoe? What are you doing? e aha ʻia ana? What is being done? E aha ana lā lāua nie? (FS 231) What are the two doing here? I aha ʻia ke kaʻa? What happened to the car? I aha ai ka hele ʻana? (pronounced iahai), Why go? E kamaʻilio ā e aha? What’s the use of talking? Aha maila ke kahuna, “He mea aha?” (Kep. 21) The priest asked, “What’s that?” O aha? Lest what? What will happen then? O ahaʻina (contraction of o aha ʻia ana)? Lest what happen?
Meeting, assembly, gathering, convention, court, party. Many types of ʻaha are listed below.

Sennit; cord braided of coconut husk, human hair, intestines of animals; string for a musical instrument; to stretch the ʻaha cord for the outline of a house so that the posts may be properly placed; measurement of an edge or border.

example_txt.txt: The sides are of equal length [as of a rectangle].
E kiʻi i ke kaula e ʻaha ai.
Get a cord to stake out the house with.

definitions.dtxt: To make or braid ʻaha; to tie up a calabash.

example_txt.txt: Ua lilo ka ʻaha, ā laila pule hou.
The prayer has not been successfully given, so pray again.

definitions.dtxt: A prayer or service whose efficacy depended on recitation under taboo and without interruption. The priest was said to carry a cord (ʻaha). (Malo 180–1)
Millepede, so called because it coils itself up like a string.
Any of the needlefishes of the family Belonidae. The young are called ʻahaʻaha. Varieties are qualified by the terms holowī, mele, and uliuli.
Design supposed to resemble the continuing track of a duck, carved on tapa beaters. Also ʻahaana and kapuaʻikoloa.
Council. See entries below.
Four (usually in counting in series): four times. Pōahā, Thursday.
Aha (exclamation of surprise). Āhā, loaʻa pono ke kolohe! Ah, the culprit is caught red-handed!
To go or walk in a mincing or irregular manner. Hooahaaha, hele hooahaaha, hele hoohaha.
To pant, to breathe hard with heat, as a dog. Cf. hā, breath.
Cordage.

To sit with back stiff and upright, arms akimbo, head up, as with haughty air of superiority; to sit cross-legged; to stand with hands on hips (considered rude and overbearing). He aha lā hoʻi kā ia nei e kū ʻahaʻaha mai nei? What’s he standing here haughtily with hands on hips for? hōʻahaʻaha To sit or stand thus.
Young of the ʻaha, a fish.
Sitting squarely; uprightly, etc.
Feast, dinner party, banquet; to feast. Lit. meal gathering. Many types of ʻahaʻaina are listed below. hōʻahaʻaina To feast, give a feast.
Banquet.
A company for eating.
A feast for pleasure or enjoyment; ahaaina olioli, a joyful feast.

A feast as a celebration of a past event. Ahaaina is often qualified by the following word; as, ahaaina hebedoma, a feast of weeks. ahaaina kauhale lewa, feast of tabernacles. Ahaaina laa, a solemn feast. Ahaaina moliaola, feast of the passover.
The food for the company in such cases. Ahaaina awakea, a dinner; ahaaina ahiahi, a supper.
To collect together for eating.
To eat together; to feast; to partake of a banquet; to hold a feast.
Holy Communion, Lord’s Supper; feast of the Lord.
Feast of weeks.
Feast of consecration or dedication, as of a house, church, canoe, or fish net.
Feast of dedication.
Commemorative or anniversary feast.
Feast given at the time of a boy’s subincision. Called in Christian times ʻahaʻaina ʻoki poepoe.

definitions.der: [Lit. feast to care for. Cf. kahukahu]
definitions.dtxt: Feast given at the completion of a student’s first work (as mat, quilt, tapa, net), or of a child’s first fish catch; one purpose was to ask the gods to grant greater knowledge and skill to the craftsman.
Feast given to ask pardon of the gods.
Feast of Tabernacles. Biblical.
Initiation feast.
Feast held after completion of a joint project or cooperative undertaking, especially harvest.
Similar to ʻahaʻaina maka luhi.
Feast given to honor those who prepared the feast and served, the workers being served by those who had celebrated before; also a feast to celebrate completion of a particularly laborious project.
Funeral feast, intended to comfort the mourners.
Wedding feast or reception.
Feast given shortly after the birth of the first child, intended to clear the way (māwaewae) of misfortune for that child and for all others to follow.
Feast of the Passover. Biblical.
Holy Communion.

definitions.der: [Lit. feast for completion of the year]
definitions.dtxt: Feast on the first birthday of a child, or to celebrate any anniversary.

Feast given principally to break the monotony of couentry life; those instigating the feast would sprinkle (pī wai) their friends with a little water; those sprinkled brought food to the feast or, later, gifts of coins.
Graduation feast.
Graduation feast, as for hula dancing or lua fighting.
Feast of tears, held on the first anniversary of a death, a happy occasion, as the death by this time has been accepted by the family (Nānā 138).
Design said to resemble duck tracks, carved on tapa beaters. Also ʻaha and kapuaʻikoloa.
District court.
United Nations (UN).
Convention of delegates; name for American presidential conventions.

See HA, to breathe. To pant; to breathe hard on account of heat, as a hog or a dog from a chase; ua ahaha ka ilio i ka wela, a i ka maloeloe i ka loa, the dog panted hard from heat and from long weariness.
Var. of ahahana. (FS 13)

Syllables repeated in chants, usually at ends of verses, similar to ēhē; a taunting singsong teasing phrase, used especially by children, meaning “Oh! Oh! aha! Shame on you! You are going to catch it!” As a verb, to tease. See ex., lei 1, ʻuhene. Also ahana and ahana kōkō lele, both meaningless. Mai ahahana ʻoe i kou pōkiʻi, don't tease your young brother.
Cord support for gourd water bottles.

Ceremonial measuring of the dimensions of a mana house within a place of worship; a priest carried a line to the four corner posts of the mana, and the chief sacrificed a pig; name of the line. (Malo 166–7)
Song festival, concert.
Annual meeting of Sunday Schools, as of Congregationalists.
Executive council.
Probate court.
General name for court assembly. Names of several types of courts are listed below.
Māhele ʻaha hoʻokolokolo. Judicial branch, of a government.
District court.
Police court.
Circuit court.
Old name for ʻaha kākau, court of records.
Supreme Court.
Military court, court martial.
Superior court.
Lower court.
Convention, i.e., an assembly of people who meet for a common purpose, in politics.

Hearing, i.e., a time for presenting official testimony or argument. E mālama ʻia ana kekahi ʻaha hoʻolohe e pili ana i nā kuleana wai o ka ʻaoʻao Koʻolau o Oʻahu i Kāneʻohe i kēia ahiahi. A hearing will be held regarding water rights on the windward side of Oʻahu in Kāneʻohe this evening.
Administrative body, assembly.

data.word: ʻAha Hoʻomalu lawaiʻa o ka Pākīpika Komohana

definitions.dtxt: Western Pacific Fishery Management Council.
Land court.
Court of domestic relations.
Probate court.
Society, club, association, organization, company, convention. Various types are listed below.
A term used in 1911 for evangelical conference of all the islands.
Christian Endeavor Society.
Temperance union.
Academy, learned society.
Hawaiian Sugar Planters' Association.
Sunday School association.
Humane Society.
Secret society.
Sons and Daughters of Hawaiian Warriors.
Hawaiian Historical Society.
Corporation, association.
Congregational.
Corporation, i.e., a business that is separate from the people who own it and acts legally as a single entity. Comb. ʻahahui + -na.

data.word: ʻAhahui Wāhine Kalikiano Hōʻole Wai ʻOna

definitions.dtxt: Women’s Christian Temperance Union.
Assembly for ballroom dancing; a ball.
Ancient assembly for the hulahula religious ceremony.
Bristle worm, a hairy sea creature (Eurythoe complanata).
Breaking off and carrying away; ka manu ahai kanu awa e, the bird clipping the twig of a tree and planting it elsewhere; poetical.
The name of a pillar, wood or stone, which a chief sets up in memory of some great exploit. The exploit itself is a pao (arch.) Alaila, kau ka ahai maluna iho o na pao.
To take away; to carry off; to bear away. [Laieik. 18]. Hence,
To flee; to be routed, as men in battle.
To flee from fear; to forsake the care of; ua ahai na makua i na keiki, aole hoihoi hou mai i ke kula, the parents took no care of the children, and did not send them back to school.
To arrive, as a set day or proper time for doing a thing; ahai ia ka la e hakaka ai.
Commemorative wooden or stone pillar (probably short for ʻā hailona, symbolic stone).

example_txt.txt: ka ʻāhaʻi ʻana i nā poʻe haʻihaʻi kānāwai

definitions.dtxt: To carry off, chase, rout; to flee, run away.
Halfback, in football.
See above. Ka manu ahaihai kanu awa e, the bird breaking off the awa plants.
Redup. of ʻāhaʻi. Na ka manu ʻāhaʻihaʻi, kanu lau ʻawa o uka (song), it was the birds who carried, planting kava leaf in the upland.
To go with the wind, to disappear completely. Ua ʻāhaʻikapupuhi mua akula ka ʻeuʻeu Koʻolau (Kel. 55), clever Koʻolau had completely vanished.
Aha, assembly, and iki, small. A small party for private conversation; a small council or collection of people; a secret council respecting war or an emergency.
Small gathering for private conversation; small or secret council, as called in an emergency.

See AHAI. The person who alone survives or escapes after a battle, or a canoe out of a fleet, all others being taken or lost; pepehiia a pau, aohe ahailono. [Laieik. 104]. See next page of Laieik. 105.
Reporter, messenger, bringer of news; in legends, the sole survivor of a disastrous defeat who reports the news; to tell news.
Short for aha ʻia ana. See aha.
Same as ʻāhaʻi.
Land divisions, gulch, and peak, Hālawa qd., south Molokaʻi.
Relating to banqueting or to a drinking feast; a wine-drinking feast. Hale ahainu.
Aha, company, and inu, to drink. To partake at a drinking feast.
Drinking party, as ʻaha inu waina, wine-drinking party, ʻaha inu lama, rum party.

Aha and inu, to drink, and awa. An assembly for drinking awa; he ahainuawa no na kanaka kahu akua hoomanamana ia Nahienaena, an assembly for drinking awa by the protectors of the god worshipped by Nahienaena.
An assembly for drinking rum or any alcoholic drinks, formerly practiced by chiefs and people.
Aha, inu and waina. A wine feast; a feast for drinking wine.
Messenger; to carry word.
Circuit court.
Court of records.
Aha, assembly, and kanaka, men. A great company; a multitude; an assembly. Na kanaka lehulehu, paapu.
A sacred assembly.

Sacred sennit cord belonging to a high chief and kept on a high place before his house; trespassers entering the house were killed if the cord remained in place, but if it fell down and the stranger stepped over it, this was a token of the stranger’s high rank or kinship with the owner of the cord. Some chiefs had several such cords, each given a name, and some were used after the owner’s death in making the kāʻai, container for his bones.
Session of the legislature.
An 1854 name for the highest court.
Probate court.

Native trees (species of Bobea) with small to medium-sized, oblong leaves; small greenish or white flowers; and small, purple-to-black juicy fruits. The wood is yellow and formerly was used for poi boards and canoe rims. I ke aha hoʻi? I ka ʻahakea. Why then? The ʻahakea [a saucy, retort containing a pun on the word aha, what].
Same as haokea, a taro.
Name of a species of yellowish wood used for rims of canoes. It is also used for making poi boards, canoe paddles, etc.
He manele ka laau a he laau e no kekahi, ke ahakea, ka lehua, ka ohiaha, ka lama, ke koa, a me ka akupa.
A small-leafed ʻahakea (Bobea elatior var. brevipes).
A large-leafed ʻahakea (Bobea elatior).
Senate.
Supreme Court.
Grand jury.
Same as ʻAha Hoʻokolokolo Kiʻekiʻe.

definitions.der: [Lit. court (to) sue for small claims or damages]
definitions.dtxt: Small-claims court, small-debts court. Ua hoʻopiʻi ʻia ka wahine i ka ʻaha koi pohō ʻuʻuku e hoʻonā ai i ka hihia o nā kini ʻōpala i hōʻino ʻia. The woman was taken to small-claims court to settle the case of the damaged trash cans.

example_txt.txt: Now lay down the measuring line.

definitions.dtxt: Cord used for measuring, as in laying out a garden or house.
Cabinet, assembly of ministers.

Cabinet, a council that advises a president, sovereign, etc. Ua hoʻokohu ʻia ʻo Keoki Kahaele i ka ʻaha kuhina no ka nui o kōna kākoʻo a kōkua i ka Pelekikena i kōna holo moho ʻana. Keoki Kahaele was appointed to the cabinet for his great support and help to the President in his campaign efforts.
Council meeting, discussion meeting, advisory council, conference.
Conference. Cf. hui. See entry below.
Privy council, secret deliberative meeting.

Summit, i.e., a conference of highest-level officials, as heads of government. ʻO ke poʻomanaʻo kūkā nui ma ka ʻaha kūkā poʻo aupuni, ʻo ia ka hoʻokele waiwai ʻana. The main topic of discussion at the summit was the economy.
Aha, four, and like, alike. Four sides alike or equal; a quadrangular; aoao ahalike. Like na aoao, like ka loa me ka laula; four square.
Name of the square bone in the wrist joint; he iwi ahalike maloko o ka pulima.
See limalima.
Four sided, with two sides parallel. Anah. 43.
Rectangle.
Presbytery, meeting of elders.
A court room; a judgment hall. Court; sanhedrim.
Judiciary session, meeting of judges.
A feint; a show; a sham fight.
The part of the face in front of the ears; ma ka aoao elua, ma kela maha ma keia maha.
Place or assembly for practice of athletic games, as sham fights.
A kapa fastened at each end between two posts and swinging between; na kapa e kau ana ma ka manuea mai hope a mua, he moe lewa.
A brave man skilled in a knowledge of the lua and of war.
An assembly for prayers.
Hammock, as of tapa, fastened to the manuea, center support of a house; hammock in general.
Cord with which edges of cracks in gourd bowls were sewn together in crisscross patterns suggestive of net mesh; the technique for such repair.
Strangling in lua fighting, as with green vines.
Secret meeting of priests to pray for a chief.
A Yellow-spotted needlefish.
Concert, song concert, song festival.
Name of the assembly collected at a cock-fight; he ahamoa o ka naau o ke kanaka; ua kau ia i ahamoa.
An assembly watching a lua contest of the kind called hakakāamoa.
A cord made from the entrails of an enemy killed in a lua fight of the hakakāamoa type.
Aha, meeting, and mokomoko, boxing. An assembly for boxing; a boxing match. Laieik. 21.
Island conference, with representative from a single island, especially of congregationalists.
Street, Sheridan Tract, Honolulu, named for a Chinese merchant who lived there. (TM)
Same as ahahana.
Inquisition, inquest. ʻAha nīele kumu make, coroner’s inquest.
Court of inquiry.

A native sedge (Machaerina mariscoides subsp. meyenii) with pointed, leathery leaves about 90 by 1.6 cm, mostly basal around a more or less zigzag spike, which bears light-brown scattered flower clusters. See also ʻuki, all species of Cladium and Machaerina.
Probably similar to hao 3, 4. (FOR. 6:472)
Aha, a company, and olelo, to speak.
A council; a body of chiefs assembled to regulate public affairs.
A consultation.
In modern times, a legislature; a body to consult and enact laws for the good of the kingdom.

Aha, assembly, and olelo, to speak. To take council; to consult together to get the united wisdom of all present; ahaolelo iho la na 'lii, the chiefs held a consultation. In modern times, to meet and consult, as the legislative bodies of Nobles and Representatives, to make and adopt laws for the nation,
Legislature, assembly, council meeting, congress; to hold such meetings; to serve in the legislature.
Kānāwai ʻahaʻōlelo. Statute, i.e., a law enacted by the legislative branch of a government. Māhele ʻahaʻōlelo. Legislative branch, of a government. ʻĀpana ʻahaʻōlelo lāhui. Congressional district.
Legislature, lawmaking body.
Congress of the United States; national assembly.
Conference of elders.
Congress.
District court.
Convention of delegates from all the islands, especially as held by the hawaiian Evangelical Association of Congregational Christian Churches.

definitions.der: [Lit. court (for) answering accusation. See hoʻopiʻi kūʻē]
definitions.dtxt: Arraignment, i.e., a court hearing in which a defendant is formally charged with a crime and enters a plea of guilty or not guilty. Hoʻopiʻi paʻalula ʻia ke kanaka ma ka ʻaha pane hoʻopiʻi, a pane akula ʻo ia ʻaʻohe ina kū i ka hewa. The man was formally charged in the arraignment wherein he entered a plea of not guilty.
A kind of tapa dyed with kukui bark and decorated with fine lines, for chiefs.
Congregation, prayer assembly.
Frapper.
Board of arbitration.
Council of chiefs.
Waterhead, beginning of a water-course; to overflow. (AP)
To collect together, as water, to overflow a low place; ua ahua, ua ahawa.
A place of refuge in Koolau.
Breeze; to blow or breathe gently. waft; softly blowing.
A wind; a slight breeze.
Anything light, gentle or soft, as a light breeze, ke ahe makani puulena. Laieik. 34. Ahe koolauwahine, he makani aheahe ka makani.
Zephyr.
A hacking cough; to cough. Also ʻehē. Cf. ʻahēʻahē, ʻehēʻehē.
A slight or hacking cough; he aheahe, he mai kunu.
To exclaim, to oh and ah; yes, so that’s it, so, oh.

example_txt.txt: So that’s your opinion, is it [in indignation]?
ʻOia ka malama a ka poʻe mahi ʻai e āhē ai i ka ulu maikaʻi a nā mea kanu.
This is the month the farmers exclaim about the fine growth of the crops.

definitions.dtxt: Used, for ae, yes. Ae, oia no; ahe, he oiaio paha; yes, so it is; yes, it is perhaps true; ahe, kuhi au ua hala lakou, aole ka! ahe, pela kou manao ea?
Timid, shy, wary.
Wild taro. Kauaʻi. Varieties are qualified by the colors keʻokeʻo and ʻulaʻula. Called ʻāweu on Hawaiʻi.
Used only with the future; when? at what time? Ahea ka ina o ke keiki e ku imua; ahea ka inoa o ke alii; ahea no la nalo ka moe ke aahi la i ka pili o ka houpo.
When; used only with reference to the future.
Same as ʻāheahea 2.
Pas/imp. of ahe. Lohe lau āhea, hearing of the many breezes [rumor].
When (future). (Gram. 11.2)

example_txt.txt: he kamumu o ke aheahe mālie
rustle of the gentle breeze, sound of quiet whispers
Aheahe kahi ʻōpū i ka pōloli.
The stomach feels weak with hunger.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ahe; soft, gentle in sound; weak.
Gentle breeze; dust raised and small branches move, in meteorology. See makani.
See AHE. A light gentle breeze.
A faint diminishing sound; he kamumu o ke aheahe malie, a sound of a still, small voice. Aheahe ka makani ma Pu; aheahe mai ke kaiaulu o waianae.
To be hungry; he pololi; aheahe kahi opu i ka pololi.
Redup. of ʻahē. I ka manawa ʻahēʻahē, kau maila ka ʻahēʻahē make maluna o lāua, at the time of coughing, a deadly coughing seized upon the two of them.
A cough; a hacking cough; i ka manawa aheahe, ke kau aheahe make o Kahalaia ma laua o Humehume, in the time of coughing, there lighted a deadly cough upon kahalaia and Humehume.
To wilt, as a plant; warm, insipid.

A native shrub (Chenopodium oahuense) and air introduced weedy herb (C. album), both with narrow to triangular or rhomboidal, thickish leaves; flowers small, in panicles. Young plants, leaves, and plant tips are used for greens, wrapped in ti leaves and cooked on hot coals. Also ʻahea, ʻāhewahewa, alaweo; alaweo huna (Niʻihau), ʻāweoweo.
Var. name for pakai 2.
Same as heahea, to call.
Warm, as water by standing in the sun.
A shade; shadow. See AKA.
Street, Pauoa, Honolulu. (TM)
Street name.
A slight breeze; ahekolo ka makani, aheahe malie, a creeping, gentle wind.
To creep; to crawl along; ke i ae la e ahekolo kana hele, he says he walks creeping along.
Snare; to snare. Also pahele. ʻAhele pulu niu, snare of coconut fibers, as for ʻaʻama, a crab.
A snare; used in a former translation for pahele. A snare; same us pahele, but is more used.

example_txt.txt: Mamuli o kona ʻāhewa ʻia ʻana ua hopu hou ʻia.

definitions.dtxt: To condemn, blame, censure, reproach, convict; condemnation, blame, conviction.
To find guilty, blame, condemn, pronounce guilty, convict, curse.
Walleyed, cross-eyed (with maka).
Oʻahu name for the mānā fern.
A mimosa tree. (AP)
Evil; condemnation.
A and hewa, wrong, sin.
To turn off the eyes, as one cross-eyed.
To plead against one.
To condemn for a crime or fault.
To cause to be under a curse. To condemn one. Hoo. ua hooahewaia oia e make, he is condemned to die.
A hanai aku ahewa ae ka waha loaa ka hale.
Same as ʻāheahea 2, a shrub.
Name of a tree on the mountains.
Punishment; condemnation.
The state of being accused or under a curse. E ka poe i ahewaia, ye cursed.
Fire, match, lightning; to burn in a fire, destroy by fire. See ahikao, ahikoe, ahi koli, ahimakani, ipo, limu ahi, pau ahi.

example_txt.txt: a cowry shell used for octopus fishing, colored red by toasting over fire
hot fire, love hot as fire
the famous firebrands thrown over cliffs at Kamaile, Kauaʻi

definitions.dtxt: Pale ahi. Flame retardant.
A fire; he ahi e a ana, a burning fire.

Hawaiian tuna fishes, especially the yellow-fin tuna (Thunnus albacares), an important fish in the Honolulu market. The name ʻahi may be qualified by the terms hiʻu wīwī (thin tail) or kaʻakaʻalāʻau, kaha uli (dark stripe), kananā (young stage, Lit. the defiant one; cf. he aha sananā), kihikihi or ʻōpū hemo (loose belly), lepalepa, maha ʻōʻō (piercing brow), mālailena, maoli, pālaha, and poʻo nui (large head).
Name of the fish called albacore.
Faded.
How many? Ahia ka nui o ka waiwai? how many articles of property? See eHIA.
definitions.notes: Note: There is a nice distinction in the use of ahia and ehia, difficult to understand; in many cases they are synonymous.

definitions.dtxt: See AHIAHIA.
Same as ʻāhiahia.
How many.
Tinder resulting from plowing with the fire plow; the powdery rubbings that ignite.
A false report concerning one; a defamation; a slander.
The after part of the day; ua aui ai ka la; the afternoon; towards night; ua napoo ka la; evening.
definitions.notes: Note: When it is dark, it is po.

definitions.dtxt: To be or become evening; a ahiahi iho la, hoi mai ia, when it was evening he returned.
To spread slanderous reports; e olelo ino.
To complain falsely of another; e niania.
To defame; to tell tales; e holoholoolelo, to reveal secrets.
Evening, late afternoon; to become evening.

example_txt.txt: Ua manaʻo māua e hiki ʻē i ʻaneʻi, ʻo ke ahiahi ʻia ʻana ihola ia.
We thought of arriving here earlier but were overtaken by evening.
Aia a hele aku au e hoʻāhiahi me ʻolua.
When I get there I’ll spend the evening with you two.
E kali kāua a hoʻāhiahi iho.
Let’s wait until evening begins to fall.

definitions.dtxt: To become evening; to spend an evening; to detain until evening; to darken, obscure.
The after part of the day; to be or become evening. I ke ahiahi komo aku la oia iloko, In the evening she went in.
A defamation, a slander.
To defame, slander, tattle against; false report, defamation, slander. He poʻe … e hele ana me ka ʻahiʻahi, people … walking with slanders.

Obscure; faded; dim, as colors in kapa or calico; kohu maikai ole; as cloth having lost color; ahiahia ke koko, the blood is colorless; applied to the uncolored parts of dyed cloth or kapa; he ahiahia ka palapala, the writing is dim, not plain; ulaula ahiahia, faded red, that is, purple.
Obscure, faded, dim, as colours in textures. Hana iho la ia i ka paku lole uli, a me ka ulaula ahiahia, He made the veil of blue, and of faded red.
Faint, obscure, faded; dim, as colors in tapa or cloth. ʻUlaʻula ʻāhiahia, faded red.
Pas/imp. of ahiahi; overtaken by evening. (Gram. 6.6.3)
Christmas Eve, Christmas night.
New Year’s Eve.
Earth-consuming, as a volcano; constantly burning; unquenchable.
Ahi, fire, ai, to eat, and honua, earth. Epithet of a volcano; earth-eater or consumer.
Volcano, volcanic fire.
Silvery gray, faded. Niʻihau.
Name of a tree or shrub in Nuuanu; he lei no ka huakaihele o Kona.
To be united with another or with others in mischief or error.
To conspire with; to be involved with another or others, as in ignorance; ua ahihi pu aku la lana ilaila, they were both involved in that matter; ahihi i ka naaupo. See HIHI and HIHIA.
Point, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi. Bay, Mākena qd., Maui. Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
Bay, Mākena qd., Maui.
Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
A low spreading bush (Metrosideros sp.), formerly numerous in Nuʻuanu. Also ʻāhihi lehua, lehua ʻāhihi, ʻāhihi kū ma kua.
Any plant with long runners or creepers, as cup of gold; any creeping vine. cf. hihi, entangled.

definitions.der: [Lit. fire (for) amusement. See ahikao, ihoihokī, hōkūpaʻalima, lūpahū, pahūpahū]
definitions.dtxt: Fireworks.
Same as kananā; a shark or a fierce and courageous fighter. See nanā. Ka pūkaua ʻahi kananā, the warrior, fierce as an ʻahi fish.
Fireworks (perhaps from scow [kao], as fireworks were first displayed from ships of explores) Also kao lele.
Rocket, as space or fireworks. See ahihoʻoleʻaleʻa, kelena moku ahikao.

example_txt.txt: Manned Maneuvering Unit, as for a space flight

definitions.dtxt: Skyrocket, rocket.

One of the three peaks (the least pointed one) of Mount Olomana, near Kailua, Oʻahu, on the Waimānalo side, named for the overseer (konohiki) of Kaʻelepulu and Kawainui ponds. (Sterling and Summers 5:266-267) See Olomana.
Street name.
Match. Also ahipele, kūkaepele.
To pass fire from one candlenut to the next on a chain (koli) or candlenut torch. Lit. to fire the torch.
To cut off even, as in trimming a lamp.
Seven (especially in counting in a series); seven times.
Seven; with the article, the seventh. Gram. § 110, 1st. The root is hiku.
Fire fountain, firebrands thrown over cliffs at Kamaile, Kauaʻi. See ahi and chant, Kauahae.
Tromper, trompeur, tromperie.
Bits of crustacea and bones found at the opening of an octopus burrow.
Gasoline. Lit. wind fire,
Gray, gray- or white-haired.
Blue denim cloth, dungarees, blue jeans.
A gray color.
Gray, as the head of an old man; he poo ahina; applied to a dry tree; he laau ahina. See HINA and POOHINA.
Applied to Molokai; Molokai ahina, gray Molokai, from the fog around the top.
Street, Diamond Head, Honolulu.
Same as ʻāhina 1, 2.

The silver-sword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense), a native plant found only at altitudes of 1,870 m or more on Maui and Hawaiʻi; the many long silvery leaves forming a rounded rosette to 60 cm in diameter; about a hundred purplish, daisy-like flowers borne on an erect, leafy stem, which is about 1.8 m high. Also hinahina.

A native spreading shrub to 1 m high, (Artemisia australis); leaves divided into narrow segments, hoary on under side; flowers in panicles, small, daisy-like. pounded leaves are used for asthma. Also hinahina.
Same as hinahina 2, Florida moss.
Plain near Kīholo, Hawaiʻi.
Street, Pālolo, Honolulu.
Name of a species of grass.
Name of a plant living in cold, dry places; so named from its color, a light silver gray; known as the silversword.
The life-everlasting plant.
Very light blue; gray; slate color.
Maui greensword.
A native fern (Cyrtomium caryotideum), with fronds 25 to 35 cm long, once divided into 6 to 18 broadly sickle-shaped pinnae, lobed at the base. Also kāʻapeʻape.
Lazy, indolent; to shirk work, loiter.
Albacore, Thunnus alalunga (family Scombridae).
Match.
Pinwheel (fireworks).
Street, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu. (A bonfire was kept laid here ready to warn chiefs of invaders from Koʻolau; Sterling and Summers 6:191.)
Wild, untamed, as animals or plants.
Name of a wind common in the mountains of Kahana, Oʻahu and by the sea. I aloha aʻe au i ka ʻĀhiu o Kahana, I greet the Wild Wind of Kahana.
Wild, general term; shy. Cf. lapa. See lōhiu, lakauā.
The name of a wind.
