Wild; untamed, as a horse; he aa; aole laka mai. See HIHIU.
Redup. of ʻāhiu 1.
Dark, dusky, somber.
Fomalhaut, a star.
Line, cord, lashing, fishing line, thong, kite string. Aho kākele, aho kālewa, trolling line. Aho loa, long line, as with several hooks for deep-sea fishing or for sounding.
Breath; to breathe. See ahonui, pauaho, paupauaho.

example_txt.txt: to hold the breath for a long time, as divers and chanters, or as children playing in the water (cf. nāʻū); a long breath (cf. aholoa).

definitions.dtxt: A narrow escape; to escape by a slim margin; to have courage; to put forth great effort.

example_txt.txt: E aho nō ia, hala no ka lā.
It’s good enough, the day passes [it is good enough for the needs of the day].
E aho ka hele ʻana mamua o ka noho ʻana.
It is better to go than to stay.

definitions.dtxt: It is better or preferable (used after e, sometimes in comparisons). see ahona, Gram. 4.6.

Art., ke. A line; a cord, as a fish line; ke aho lawaia; a kite string; ke kakaiapola a me ke aho; alaila, hoolele aku i ka lupe i ka lewa, a paa aku ma ke aho, (prepare) the kite tail and the string, then send off the kite into the air, but hold fast by the string.
Art., Ke. The natural breathing of a person; the breath; hence,
Patience; i nui ke aho, let the breath be long, i.e., be patient.
MET. Spirit; courage. Resolution; also kindness.
To be patient, submissive, humble; to be merciful, kind; to be ready to do a kind act. See the compounds AHONUI and AHOLOA.

(Impersonal.) It is easier; it is better; it is less severe; e aho nau e kokua mai ia makou, it is better for you to help us; it implies a comparison. e aho nae ko lakou hope i ko kakou, their end. however, will be more tolerable than ours; it is better that, etc. It had been better if, etc. It is better, preferable; e aho iki no ke hoi kakou, it will be a little better for us to return; e aho no ka hole mamuli o ka noho ana me ka pilikia, it is better to go than to stay in perplexity.
A line, cord, as a fishing line: Nikiniki iho la ia i ka uha puaa i ke aho. Then he tied the hams of the hog with a cord.
Cf. ao, light, day.
Thatch purlin. Also ʻaʻaho. See ʻahohui, ʻahokele, ʻahopiʻo kuahui, ʻahopueo.

example_txt.txt: a thatch purlin that is too short

definitions.dtxt: To tie ʻaho to the frame of the roof.
The name of the small sticks used in thatching.
definitions.notes: Note: Art., Ka

definitions.dtxt: An aho or string too short; not long enough for the purpose.
Monofilament.
Thatch purlin support.
Small lashing on the pueo main purlin.
Horizontal thatch purlin. (Kep. 183)
Name given for roof thatching on top of the ridgepole. Also weʻo (FOR. 5:645)

example_txt.txt: He āhole ka iʻa, hole ke aloha.
Āhole is the fish, love is restless [of āhole fish used in love magic].

definitions.dtxt: An endemic fish (Kuhlia sandwichensis) found in both fresh and salt water. The mature stage is āhole, the young stage āholehole. Because of the meaning of hole, to strip away, this fish was used for magic, as to chase away evil spirits and for love magic. It was also called a sea pig (puaʻa kai) and used ceremonially as a substitute for pig. Foreigners were sometimes called āhole because of the light skin of the fish.
Name of a species of white fish.
Rock islet (0.15 acres, 40 feet elevation), Kīpahulu qd., East Maui.
Stroke in lua fighting. See Keaholehi.
Young stage of the āhole, Hawaiian flagtail.
Name of a species of fish. See AHOLE above.
Sliding rock, landslide, avalanche. (FOR. 6:472)
Avalanche, landslide. ʻĀholo hau. Snow avalanche.
Same as more common ahonui. For aho loa see aho 1.
A long string for fishing or sounding in deep water; he aholoa, loa i ka mio; he aholoa i ka luu ilalo o ka moana.
Aho, patient, and loa, long. Patient; long suffering. See AHONUI.
See loto 4.
Ahona a kui maoli aku kela, lele liilii. Laieik. 42.
Better, well, well-being, fortunate, improved; to need (aho 3 + -na).

example_txt.txt: How do you feel? A little better.
She’s a little better just now.
Ahona mākou i ka ʻike ʻia e ka uka.
We were fortunate to be seen by those on shore.
Hahana ka ʻāina, i ahona i ka makani.
The heat of the land was relieved by the breeze.
I ahona iki nō au lā ia mau kānaka.
I do have some need for these men.
Ua ahonui nō ʻoe i no pōpilikia.
You have been patient in the times of trouble.

definitions.dtxt: Patience; patient, enduring, long suffering; to tolerate. Lit. great breath. Cf. aholoa, pauaho, paupauaho; see ex., lawe 2, makua.

example_txt.txt: E hoʻāhonui aʻe ā pau kēia pilikia.
Be patient until this trouble is over.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
Forbearance; long suffering; patience.
To be patient, gentle, kind, etc. See AHOLOA.
Patient; enduring; long suffering.
Lashing fastening kaupaku roof to kua ʻiole, upper ridgepole.
Thatch purlin support.
Lashing on the pueo main purlin.
Main purlin in a house. Also pueo.
Heap, pile, collection, mound, mass; altar, shrine, cairn; a trap-like stone enclosure made by fishermen for fish to enter; laid, as the earth oven. Cf. ahu waiwai, ahuwale, Oʻahu.

example_txt.txt: A heap of excreta [hence worthless; sometimes shortened to ahu only or to e ahu ana]!
A heap of squid ink! Not worth much!
a large inheritance or transfer [said of reward, vengeance]
ahu kapanaha iā Hawaiʻi ʻimi loa
a mass of wondrous things in deep-delving Hawaiʻi
E hoʻāhu ana i ka huhū ma luna o kēlā poʻe.
Heaping up anger against those people.

definitions.dtxt: To pile, gather, accumulate, heap up; to lay away, as goods for the future; collect; collection, mound. Fig. To resent, dislike.

example_txt.txt: Ahu iho ka pua wahawaha i Wailua.
The despised blossoms were collected together at Wailua.

definitions.dtxt: To gather, collect.
To lie strewed over the ground.
See AHA. An assemblage or collection of things; ahu ai, a place for storing food; a collection of provisions. Wahi ahu, a place for something. Ahu pohaku, a pavement; a heap, as of stones.
A heap of stones as a way mark.
As a memorial.
Storing; collecting; hale ahu, a store-house.
To gather or collect together. Ahu iho la i kahakai, hu ae la ka lolo, they gathered them together (dead bodies) on the sea shore, the brains flowed; to collect one’s food where there is little.
Ahu iho ka hoka i ka pakai,
Ku i ka pakai ka mea haku ole,
Lele ae no ka manu i Houa,
Hapapa wale iho no ka hokahoka.
To collect but gain little; ahu wale iho no, aole wahi kapa; ahu wale iho, aole ai; ahu wale iho no i ka oneanea.
To lay up, as in a store-house; to lay up for future use, as goods. to store in the memory.
To lie strewed over the ground.
To cover one with a cloak; to be merely covered. To clothe.
Hoo. To collect what is scattered.
To fall together, as men slain in battle.
To keep; treasure up, as anger; hooahu iho la i ka huhu maluna o kela poe, he kept in reserve his anger for that company.
To pile up, as stones. To gather up; glean, as a field.
To bring condemnation upon.
To reply to; to object to something said.

Garment or covering for the upper part of the body and shoulders, as a cape, shirt, coat; to put on or wear such; fine soft mat, formerly often used as a cloak; mat used as a canoe cover; short for ʻahu ʻula. Cf. ʻaʻahu, ʻahu ʻao, ʻahu hīnano, ʻahu moena, ʻahunā liʻi 1, ʻahu ʻoʻeno, ʻahu ua, ʻahu uhi waʻa, ʻahu ʻula.

A fine mat; a coarse one is moena; a mat for covering a canoe; o ka uhi ana i ka ahu, ea, oia ka mea e pale aku i kekahi ale, the spreading over a mat, that is what will keep off some of the waves; ahuao, ahu mokoloa.
To swell, as a wave; heap, mound, hillock, knoll, pile; heaped, humped; tremendous.
To pile up or heap up; embankment.
Young, as of the aku, kawakawa and moano fishes. Cf. ʻōhua.
Any elevated place; to be raised up on a platform; a bank in the sea.
See AHU, collection. Any place elevated in the manner of a high path.
A bank in the sea; a bank formed by the sand at a mouth of a river; hence,
A ford; a place for passing a stream or river. He puu; a hillock; he kiekie ma kekahi aoao.
To be raised up on a platform; ua ahua, ua ahawa.
Ancient surfing area off Coconut Island, Hilo, Hawaiʻi (Finney and Houston 26).
Point, ʻEwa qd., Oʻahu.
Street, Moanalua, Honolulu, named for an ancient fishpond in the area (TM).
Heap, mound, hillock.

Healthy, vigorous; strength and vigor, as of animal or plant; to grow rapidly, thrive. Also ehuehu. Ulu ahuahu, to grow fast, to be big for one’s age. Ke ahuahu kō (FOR. 5:646), a healthy sugar-cane plant.
Young shoots or layers, as of sugar-cane.
A boy or girl that grows quickly.
Young sprouts or shoots from layers, as from sugar-cane.
A boy or girl that grows up quickly.
Angry; fretful; unwilling, as when one receives orders to work, and from fatigue or indolence he is unwilling, he is then ahuahu.
Unwillingly; fretfully.
To be sullen; unwilling to do a thing ordered.
To overeat, waste food, squander. Mai ahu ʻai, donʻt overeat. Ka ahu ʻai wale ʻana i ka nui o kona waiwai, the senseless waste of most of his property.
Place name in Puna; mentioned in the 1835 Census.
Hill (3,557 feet high), Kīlauea Crater, Hawaiʻi. Probably.
Var. of ahuwale. (FOR. 4:533)
To lie slain, as many bodies slain in battle; aia hoi, e ahualala kukui ana ka heana, behold, they were dead bodies fallen to the earth.
Kukui branches strewn about, as after a storm.
Land area on Hawaiʻi just southeast of Honokaʻa on the old road to Kamuela.
Resting place near the beach at Mahaiʻula and Kaʻelehuluhulu, Kona, Hawaiʻi.
Mound back of Kekaʻa rock on the grounds of the Sheraton-Maui Hotel near the golf course, Lahaina qd., West Maui. See Kekaʻa.
Choice mat of fine strands of soft white young pandanus leaves, about 3 cm mesh.
The young and tender leaves of the hala for making mats; ahu moena, ahu pawehe, ahuao.
Small hill south of Kahuku, Kaʻū; heiau, Kailua qd., Hawaiʻi. (FOR. SEL. 174; RC 35)
A species of strong rush of which cords are made; the leaves are made into hats.
The name of the cord itself; mai hoka au i ke ahuawa.
A sedge (Cyperus javanicus) about .3 to 1.3 m high, with a basal tuft of long narrow leaves and a radiating inflorescence borne at the tip of a long slender stem. Also ʻehuʻawa, puʻukaʻa haole.

example_txt.txt: born in a clump of ʻahuʻawa [of a humble birthplace]

definitions.dtxt: Another coarse sedge (Cyperus hypochlorus) similar to the preceding one, but with green instead of brown flowers.
Kava dregs. See ex., hoka 2.

The umbrella plant, a leafless ornamental sedge (Cyperus alternifolius), 30 to 180 cm high, the umbrella-shaped flowering head with about 20 grasslike rays at the top of a slender stalk. Also puʻukaʻa haole.
To make two thicknesses by folding; to double up, fold, as paper or tapa.
See HUE, to lie. To steal; to take without liberty. See AIHUE.
To double up; to turn up, as a piece of kapa or paper.
Amas, groupe; grappe, peloton.
Air mass, as in weather.
Heiau for human sacrifices (RC 180) restored by Kamehameha I, adjoining his residence at Kamakahonu, Kailua, North Kona, Hawaiʻi. (Ii 122, 123) A heiau formerly at Hālaulani, Oʻahu.
Soft, fine mat garment plaited from fine strands of dried bracts of male pandanus fruit.
A garment or cloth made of the hala leaf.
Earth’s mantle.
Cache, as in computer program. See hoʻokoe.
Bunch or cluster, as of bananas, grapes; whole pandanus fruit consisting of keys. ʻĀhui waina, cluster of grapes.
A bunch or cluster of fruit, as bananas, grapes, or hala.
Street, Kakaʻako, Honolulu.
Pandanus fruit.
Protuberance of the vagina resulting from syphilis; the roughness of the skin was thought to suggest the pandanus fruit.
To lie sick; to be weak; e ahuili auanei ka poe hooko i ka eha.

definitions.der: [Lit. bird cluster (perhaps so called because the birds from nearby Mokumanu were caught here and tied together in bunches)]
definitions.dtxt: Land division, stream, ranch, and subdivision, Kāneʻohe qd., Oʻahu. In 1845 kamehameha III granted a tract of land in this area to the Catholic mission for the first Catholic school in the Islands. Each street name in the subdivision combines hui-(flock) with the name of a bird. See ʻĀhulimanu.
A bunch or cluster of grapes.
Capital, i.e., anything produced in an economy that is accumulated or used to produce other goods and services. See paikāloaʻa.

example_txt.txt: Ke piʻi paʻa mau mai nei ka nui ahu kāloaʻa o ka pūʻoi hana a Kale ma ke kumuloaʻa a me ka lako.
Kale’s business has been steadily increasing its capital in profits as well as equipment.

definitions.dtxt: Coastal land section and landing north of Nāwiliwili, Kauaʻi, named for a son of laʻamaikahiki, who came from Tahiti. Former heiau at Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻokahi wale nō kumu e make ai ʻo Kawelo, ʻo ke kaua i ke ahukū.
There was only one way to kill Kawelo, burial beneath stones.

definitions.dtxt: To stone to death; slaughter by burying the victim under a pile of stones. Hākau, half brother of ʻUmi, was killed in this fashion (FS 141), and this method was used unsuccessfully against the hero Kawelo (FS 107).
To stone; to bury with stones or other missiles; e hailuku, e hoonou, e hooulua.
Ti-leaf raincoat or cape.

example_txt.txt: Ahulau ihola nā kanaka i ka make.

definitions.dtxt: Pestilence, epidemic, heaped up, as dead bodies.
A pestilence among men. A murrain among cattle. A sickness like a pestilence.
definitions.notes: Note: NOTE. The most destructive raged while Kamehameha lived the first time at Oahu; kamehameha himself was attacked, but recovered. Thousands were swept off by it at that time; probably in 1804.

definitions.dtxt: Epidemic; pestilential; mai ahulau, a pestilence;
To have the pestilence; to die with it; ua ahulau ae la na kanaka i ka make.
Tomber.

example_txt.txt: He ʻāhuli ia o ke ōewe.
It’s a mutation in the gene.

definitions.dtxt: Mutation; to mutate. Var. of kāhuli.
Peak, Kīpahulu Forest Reserve, Kaupō qd., Maui. (For a song, see Elbert and Mahoe 29-30) Perhaps formerly ʻĀhulili,
Pool at ʻĀhuimanu, Oʻahu.
Overheated, as over stones; white-hot.
Heated hot, as stones in the oven; heated to whiteness; ahuliu ka imu, the oven is exceedingly hot.

definitions.der: [Lit. long heap (a cave here was used for storage)]
definitions.dtxt: Area in Hoʻōpūloa qd., South Kona, Hawaiʻi.
Overdone, overcooked; overcultivated, as soil. ʻAi ahulu, overcooked food; Fig. To pray to death, poison.
To be overdone, as food cooked too much; ua ahulu loa ka umu ai, ua ulaula ka ai, to be too hot.
Overdone, as food; baked too much; cooked hard.
Spoiled, as eggs, or medicines by long lying.
Unnatural in appearance; dirty; defective; ua ahulu ke kai, i.e., dirty or green, not blue and clear.
Over-done, as food baked too much: aiahulu, food baked too much.
Discolored, foamy, feathery, choppy, uneven, mussed.
Young of the kūmū fish.
Same as huluhulu 2. Koʻi ʻāhuluhulu, planning adze, as for rough (ʻāhuluhulu) lumber.
A species of small, red fish; some kind of mechanical tool; koi ahuluhulu.
Land section, Waikiʻi qd., Hawaiʻi.
Fine patterned mat, plaited with materials of different colors.
A figured fine mat, or a fine mat of small figures of different colors. Laieik. 112.
Pile, heap.
Coat, garment, ti-leaf raincoat.
A tapa for chiefs, colored with candlenut and noni and striped red.
Issue of a union of a male chief and a commoner. Also waikī and kūkae pōpolo.
A colored kapa; he mamaki ahunalii, he mamaki i hooluuia, a colored mamaki kapa.
A small chief.
A land division.
Name given for a fish of the ʻōpakapaka type.
Matting with twilled pattern, associated with Kauaʻi. (Laie 479)
Clue; to give a clue about. Comb. a+ huoi.
Islet (3.1 acres, awash at high tide), off Kahaluʻu, Kāneʻohe Bay, Oʻahu.
Abbreviation for ahupuaʻa.
Hill (1,470 feet high), Pāʻia qd., East Maui.
Composite, as volcanic cone.
Name of a kind of striped mat made on Niihau; he ahupawehe no Niihau.
Cloth bound about the head of warriors. (Ellis 102)
Bay and gulch, Kahoʻolawe.

Land division usually extending from the uplands to the sea, so called because the boundary was marked by a heap (ahu) of stones surmounted by an image of a pig (puaʻa), or because a pig or other tribute was laid on the altar as tax to the chief. The landlord or owner of an ahupuaʻa might be a konohiki.
The altar on which the pig was laid as payment to the chief for use of the ahupuaʻa land.

Name of one of the smaller divisions of a couentry, made up of several ili, and under the care of a head man; a hog paid the tax of that district to the king. He ahupuaa o Wailuku; o na aina maloko o Wailuku. he ili, he moo.
A city; a village; a settlement, as the capital of said ahupuaa.
Bay and gulch, Kahoʻolawe.
Bay, Kahoʻolawe.
A heap; a pile; a collection of things; he ahuua waiwai, he ahuua kiekie, a pile of goods, a high heap.
To heap up; to put in heaps; ke ahuua mai la. See AHU.

Old type of raincoat made of dried ti leaves fastened to an olonā net, or consisting of a small mat about 1.2 by 1.8 m, made of makaloa sedge, and so supple that it could be rolled up; to wear this garment. Today, raincoat is kukaweke and kuka ua.
Mat canoe covering that protected paddlers in storms.
Street, Kalihi Kai, Honolulu.

Feather cloak or cape made of the feathers of the ʻōʻō, ʻiʻiwi and other birds, usually red or yellow trimmed with black or green, formerly worn by high chiefs and kings. Today about 160 have been located in museums and collections of the world, the largest being in the Bishop Museum, Honolulu. Imitation cloaks of plush, felt, paper, or dyed feathers (rare) are worn today in pageants and by members of Hawaiian societies.
Same as Kaʻahuʻula.
See limuʻahuʻula.
A red feathered cloak; a cloak made of the feathers of the oo and the red feathers of the iiwi, worn by kings and high chiefs; a gorgeous dress. Laieik. 112.
A kind of fish net; ka upena puni, a haku a maikai.
See ʻupena ahuulu.
Storehouse, heap of goods. Hale ahu waiwai, storehouse.
The property of a treasury; belonging to a place for storing property.

example_txt.txt: real thoughts or nature are exposed, as of something revealed in its true colors

definitions.dtxt: Exposed, conspicuous, prominent, obvious, in plain view; heaped up.

example_txt.txt: predictable, as the ending of a story

definitions.dtxt: See hoʻokuʻia ahuwale.
To be in plain sight, as a hill, or a house on a hill.
Street and place, ʻĀina Haina, Honolulu.
The neck; he a-i ko ke kanaka, oia kahi e hui ai ke poo me ke kino, man has a neck, it is that which unites the head with the body. A-i oolea, a stiff neck.
Figuratively, perverseness; disobedience.
Consuming; destroying; spoken of fire.
Adv., for aia. There; near by, but not in contact; ai no iloko o ka hale, there in the house.
There, at another place, however distant; there; when; as, Auhea o kekuaokalani? Ai ae no mauka mai. Where is Kekuaokalani? There he is coming by land.
Food; vegetable food, in distinction from ia, meat. Ai oo, ripe food; ai maloo, dried food; ai, maka. green food, vegetables. NOTE—Ai, food, is the representative of property generally.
To eat; to consume food, as persons or animals.
To devour, as animals.
To destroy, consume, as fire.
To consume; spoken of the sword.
To eat, consume, as a sore; aole ai ka mai, the disease has made no advance.
To taste, eat, enjoy the benefits of, have the profits of, as land; e ai i ka aina. 19th conj., 3d hoo.

To cause to eat, i.e., compel or induce to eat; huhu loa ia (Kekuokalani) i ka hoai noa ana a lakou i ke alii (Liholiho,) he was very angry at them for causing the king to eat freely, i.e., contrary to kapu.
To have sexual intercourse; applied to both sexes; also, to animals.
Verbal directive. Gram. § 242. It has reference, generally, to a preceding noun, verb or adverb, expressive of time, place, cause, manner or instrument; often contracted, thus, hana'i, for hana ai.
Maʻi lele ai. Sexually transmitted disease (STD).
Coition; to have sexual relations, cohabit (frequently pronounced ei).
To breed, as a horse.
Same as wai inter. pronoun.
Linking or anaphoric part. frequently pronounced ei. (Gram. 7.3)
Short for aia, there. Cf. ai loa, ai luna. Ai i loko o ka hale, there in the house.

Food or food plant, especially vegetable food as distinguished from iʻa, meat or fleshy food; often ʻai refers specifically to poi; harvest; to eat, destroy or consume as by fire; to erode; to taste, bite, take a hook, grasp, hold on to; edible. Fig. To rule, reign, or enjoy the privileges and exercise the responsibilities of rule, and one who does so, as ʻai ahupuaʻa: to rule an ahupuaʻa, the ruler of one; ʻaiʻāina: to own, control, and enjoy land; the owner of land; ʻai aliʻi, ʻai lani, and ʻai liʻi, to enjoy the comforts and honors and exercise the responsibilities of being a chief; ʻai ʻili: to control an ʻili land division, one who does control the ʻili; ʻai moku: to rule a district or island [moku], one who rules one. Cf. ʻaialo, ʻai kanaka, ʻai nui, ʻai ʻokoʻa, ʻai paʻa, ʻai pala maunu, ʻai pilau, ʻai ʻuhaʻuha, ʻai waiū. Various ways of eating may qualify ʻai, as ʻai, hele, ʻai lau, and ʻai noa, to eat freely and without observance of taboos (see also ʻai kū); ʻai kapu, to eat under taboo; ʻai kau, to feed by dropping poi directly from the fingers into the mouth, especially to feed a favorite child this way; ʻai maka, to eat raw; ʻai pau, to eat all. Hiki ke ʻai ʻia, edible. ʻAi ʻaha, to tie with sennit. Mōhai ʻai, cereal offering. Pāʻū ʻai kaua (FOR. 4:53), sarong worn in battle. ʻAʻohe kapu o kaʻu pā hula, he ʻai kū, he ʻai hele, there are no taboos in my hula troupe, eat standing, eat on the run. ʻAʻoheʻai ʻo ka maʻi, the disease makes no advance. Kāna ʻai, his food. Kona ʻai, his eating. hōʻai To feed, give food to, board.
Score, points in a game, stake, wager. ʻEhia ʻai e eo ai? How many points to win?
Dancing style or type. Cf. ʻai ʻami, ʻai haʻa.
Stroke or hold in lua fighting; spear thrust. Ka ʻai a ke kumu i koe iā ʻoukou (FOR. 5:409), the teacher’s stroke that you do not have [have not been taught]. Kaʻai a ka uʻi, the stroke of the youth.
Stone used in the kimo game other than the stone that is tossed and caught, which is the pōhaku kimo.
To take, as medicine or a pill. Cf. inu.
Byte, in computer terminology. See huna, ʻai pākaukani, ʻai pāmiliona, ʻai pāpiliona.
Credit, as for a school course.
Point, as in a game or sporting event. See entries below and heluʻai, kāpuka ʻai, lāʻau make ʻai, lilo ka ʻai iā Mea.
Same as aʻiaʻi 1.
Part. replacing i often in songs; usually written a i. Cf. aʻe, aʻo. Malihini ka ʻikena aʻi nā Kona, seeing the Kona districts for the first time.
Nonproductive transitive suffix. See huaʻi, luaʻi, lumaʻi, Gram. 6.6.4. Cf. kauaʻi, kaulaʻi.
Interjection of surprise.
Neck, neck of a shirt or dress, neck of the iheihe fish net. Cf. ʻāʻīkū, ʻāʻīlepe, ʻāī oeoe, ʻāʻī ʻoloʻolo, ʻāʻī pahāha, ʻāʻī palaʻe, ʻāʻīpau, ʻāʻī puʻu, ʻāʻī uaua. Lei ʻāʻī, necktie.
Collar. Also ʻāʻī lole, ʻāʻī kala, kala.

example_txt.txt: neck stretches, i.e., a warm-up exercise for sports such as volleyball; also to do this exercise

definitions.dtxt: Ungodly; irreligious.
Bad, sore, watery, as the eye; onohiaia, a sore or watery eye.
There, referring to place; aia malaila ka hana ana, there the work is doing.
Then, referring to time, generally in connection with some other event.
Expressive of admiration or surprise, of triumph or contempt. Aia hoi, behold! see there; aia ka, there now! Aia la, there yon have it! an expression of triumph with contempt.
An unprincipled or ungodly person.
The practice of ungodliness itself; he hoomaloka; he hoole akua.
To be or show one’s self contrary to the gods.
To disregard the will of the gods; to be ungodly in practice.
To have the character of an ungodly person. See HAIHAIA.
Aia i loko o ka papa. To take a class. Aia wau i loko o ka papa ʻōlelo Hawaiʻi i kēia kau kula. I’m taking a Hawaiian language class this semester. Cf. komo.

There, there it is, there are (sometimes shortened to ai, with loss of the following part. i, see ai lalo, ai luna). Cf. also aia hoʻi, aia kā, aia lā, aia naʻe, ai lā, ai loa, Gram. 4.6. Aia kēia, furthermore, besides. Aia malaila ka hale, the house is there, there’s the house. Aia i hea ka hale? Where is the house?

Depending on, only if, only when, whatever, whenever. Aia nō ia iā ʻoe, depending on you; as you want; it’s up to you; suit yourself. Aia nō ia i kāu hoʻoholo ʻana, whatever you decide. Aia nō i kahi e hana ana, it doesn't matter where the work is done; depending on where the work is done. Aia nō i kāu hele ʻana mai, whenever you want to come; depending on your coming. Alia wau e ʻae aku, aia ʻae mai ʻo ʻAiwohikupua (Laie 485), before I consent, ʻAiwohikupua must agree. Aia ā pau ka uhi ʻana o ka noe … ia manawa e ʻike aku ai i nā mea apau (Laie 499), when the mist covering is gone, then everything may be seen. Aia ā pau kēia hana, when [or whenever] this work is done. Aia ā hele aku au, when I go. ʻAʻole ʻoe e ola i ka mele hoʻokahi, aia ʻelua mele (FS 239), you won't be saved by one song, only with two songs. Aia aku ā aia mai, ʻai kākou i ka naʻaukake, every now and then we eat weiners. Aia hea ka puke? Where’s the book?
Here! Here it is!
Ungodly, godless, irreligious, wicked, unbelieving, careless of observance of taboos; wickedness. hōaiā To act wickedly or lead others astray.
A term applied to those who disregard the kapu while others observe it. When the kapu is generally disregarded it is called ainoa; hence,
A hypocrite: an irreligious person.
To break secretly the kapus of the gods, but to observe them openly; to act hypocritically.
To conspire secretly against one.
To defraud one’s landlord by withholding the tax and using it himself.
To pray to death. Similar to anaana.
Irreligious; unmindful of the kapu; nani ke kanaka aiahua. See AIAHULU.
Behold! See there! Lo! Suddenly. ʻĪ maila ke Akua, Aia hoʻi, and God said, Behold.
Same as ʻaiā.
Food baked a long time in the oven till it is brown.
To pray or poison to death.

definitions.notes: Note: The agent of the intrigue is called kalaiino, niania, paopaonohonia. See these words in their places.
definitions.dtxt: To procure the death of another by any fraudulent means, or for any political or selfish purpose.
See AI and AHUPUAA. A division of couentry; he alii aiahupuaa. enjoying the office and perquisites of an overseer of land. Laieik. 34.
Nearly.
Brightness; clearness; ua like ke keokeo me ka aiai.
Bright, as moonlight; fair; white, He malamalama aiai. Pure, as milk. Clear, as glass. Pure, as gold. White, clean, as linen.
Found only in 15th conj. Hoo. To make white; splendid; to beautify; e hooaiai ana i ke kula o Lele, beautifying the upland of Lele.
To reduce to very small particles; to make small. To reduce to powder.
See ʻōpū ʻaiʻai.
Dependent, one living on the resources of another.
Bright as moonlight; fair, white, clear, pure, brilliant, shining; brightness, clearness.

example_txt.txt: woman with skin that is fair and clear

definitions.dtxt: To whiten, clear, shine, whitewash, remove rust or dirt; white, clear, shining. Fig. To clarify, brighten, as a tarnished reputation. see ex., kāhela 1.
A native tree or shrub (Streblus sandwichensis [Pseudomorus sandwichensis and p. brunoniana are synonyms]), with narrow-ovate leaves, and milky sap; a member of the fig family.
Transparent.
Redup. of ʻaiā. He aliʻi ʻino a me ka ʻaiʻaiā (Kep. 63), a chief wicked and impious. hōʻaiʻai.ā Caus/sim.
Name of a god, the son of Hinahele, his mother, and Kuula, his father. He was a god of fishermen; he akua lawaia.
Swinging, unsteady motion.
Opaque.
Ai, to eat, and aina, land. Lit. To eat the land, i.e., to enjoy, to possess land; to own land; aole ia i aiaina, he did not possess land.
To rule or own land. hōʻāiʻāina To award land, as by a chief. (Nak. 27)
Name given for persons sacrificed for not observing taboos during the offering of prayers by the priest (pronunciation not certain). (Kep. 139)
There now! So it’s there after all!
Same as hulu manu, a seaweed.
Ai, food, and akakai, a rush. New, fresh, sweet food, like poi newly pounded; he ai hou, he ai manalo. Such food is also called pololei.
A native trailing, woody plant (Coprosma ernodeoides), with narrow, tiny leaves and black, berry-like fruits. Also kūkaenēnē, leponēnē, pūnēnē.
There! I told you so! There it is!
Ai, to eat, and ala, or alaala, odoriferous. The scrofula.
Same as ʻāʻīpalaʻe.
To rule (or eat) as a chief.
E hoohanohano, to enjoy the ease, honor and dignity of a chief; to act the chief. See NALINALI.
Attendant of the chief’s household, intimate of a chief.

definitions.der: [ai, to eat, and alo, in front]
definitions.dtxt: To eat before.
The people about the chief; his attendants, in distinction from the poe makaainana; kanaka aialo no ke alii.
A prince or princess; those about a king. Pau loa na makaainana a me na aialo i ka pii iuka, all the common people and those about the chief went up the mountain.
A small division of land less than an ahupuaa; na kanaka o na aina, a me na ahupuaa, a me na aialo.
One who is a hanger on and lives lazily with a chief and eats his food.
To eat like a shark. Fig. To have a ravenous appetite. (Gram. 8.7.2)
Type of hula with little foot movement, but with hip revolving throughout the dance; to dance thus.
Walking wearily up and down precipices; he hele aikena, he maloeloe.
The Hawaiian pronunciation of iron; a flat iron.
Clothes iron; to iron, press, as clothes.
But, furthermore.
There; just by; not far off.
To eat nutritious food. Comb. ʻai + a + ola. Cf. paiola. Kūlana ʻaiaola. nutrition.
To eat like a pig; to eat greedily; to wolf food.
To pray or poison to death, as was formerly practiced.
To look about with covetous or jealous eyes; to practice sorcery or poisoning.
Weary, discouraged by long continued work. See ex., kupaliʻi 2.
In debt; owing; under obligation to render some equivalent for something received.
E haawi aie, to give to be paid again.
Indebtedness; the state of being in debt; he poe aie kakou, we are debtors.
A debt; that which is due for any cause; e lawe aie, to go in debt for a thing. E haawi aie, to give (lend) on usury.
Ai, to eat, and e, before hand, i.e., to eat or enjoy a thing before it is paid for; from the custom of paying for work before it was done, and the pay consumed.
To owe; to be indebted; aole oia (o Kamehameha) i aie, he (Kamehameha) never went into debt.
To enjoy something yet to be paid for; e lawe e i ka waiwai a mahope hookaa.

Debt; to owe. See ʻaoʻao ʻaiʻē, lawe ʻaiʻē. ʻAiʻē pohō, ʻaiʻē kaʻa ʻole, ʻaiʻē pono ʻole, bad debt. Hāʻawi ʻaiʻē, to lend on usury. hōʻaiʻē To lend, loan, charge on account, borrow, ask for credit; charge account, loan, credit. Hale hōʻaiʻē, pawnshop. Ua hōʻaiʻē nō anei ʻoe i ka hale kūʻai? Did you charge to the store?
Loan, i.e., money lent at interest; to have a loan. Also lako ʻaiʻē. Cf. hoʻolako ʻaiʻē, lawe ʻaiʻē.
Fatigue; weariness.
Name of a species of tree found on Lanai and other islands used for finishing off canoes.
Land sections, mill, village, bay, stream, field, recreation center, and schools, west of Honolulu, Oʻahu. (RC 169).

All species of the endemic Hawaiian genus Nothocestrum, soft-wooded shrubs and trees with ovate or oblong leaves, yellowish flowers, and whitish to reddish berries. One slender species was used for thatching sticks (ʻaho) and fire-making.
Same as kāwaʻu, a native Ilex; holly. Kauaʻi.
Exhaustion.
Same as ʻaiea 3.
Hula step danced with bended knees; the chanting for this dance is usually bombastic and emphatic (UL 266); to dance thus.
Allegro.
Ace, in volleyball. Niʻihau. Also ʻeki.
Ai, food, and haha, skin of kalo tops. The food of poor people; e aihaha ana na luwahine.

definitions.der: [ai, eat, and halale, to sup up, as a liquid]
definitions.dtxt: To be lazy; to do nothing; to be the reproach of others; to eat the food of others without work. See lOMALOMAAIHALALE.
Ai, food, and hamu, remnants of food.
The food left after a meal, especially when little is left.
Crumbs and scrapings, that which is burned on to the stones of the oven.
Ai, to eat, and hamu, refuse food.
To eat refuse food.
To eat up clean; ua aihamuia kaumala uala.
Applied as an epithet of reproach to the poe kahuna anaana, the priests who practiced sorcery.
See hamu 2.
Center of a taro corm.
Ai, there, and hea, where. At, or towards what place? the answer, ailaila, there.
NOTE: The a may be a No. 2. NOTE: And ihea the auialo of hea. See Gram. § 165, p. 93.
Where? See hea 5.
Similar to ʻai kū. (KAM. 64:87)
Point from block, dunk, or spike, in volleyball. Niʻihau.
To remove food from one’s mouth and then eat it again, as gum.
Basket, a score in basketball. See ʻai kolu.
Touchdown, in football. Cf. ʻai hopu, ʻai manuahi, ʻai peku.
To eat proudly of high-priced food, as a rich person; Fig. To have many women. Na nei selamoku e ʻai hoʻokano (song), this sailor who has so much to eat.
Touchback, in football. Cf. ʻai holo, ʻai manuahi, ʻai peku.

Stream tributary to Mānoa Stream, and the area near Puʻupueo, Mānoa, Honolulu, where Kauhi killed Kahalaopuna, whom he suspected of having an affair with kiʻihelei. (Westervelt, 1964b:129; for another version, see Pohakea; see also awaawa-Kiʻihelei.) An owl ʻaumakua (personal god) saw the murder, dug up the girl’s body, and resuscitated her.
Vagabond; to wander, roam. (And.)
To pass from one place to another and find a dwelling place.
He poe aihuawaa, wanderers that have not settled down in any place.
Found in all the above forms. Stolen; taken secretly.
A thief; one, who steals.
Ai, food, and hue, to steal. Lit. To steal food. But ai represents property of all kinds. See AI.
To steal, rob, pilfer, filch, cheat; thief, robber, theft, larceny. Cf. Marquesan kaihue.
To steal, in basketball. ʻAihue akula ʻo Kevin Johnson i ke kinipōpō, a holo akula no ka ʻai. Kevin Johnson stole the ball and went in for the goal.
Passive form of the verb aihue; to be stolen. For these forms, see Gram. § 211: 1st, 2d.
Pas/imp. of ʻaihue.
Pas/imp. of ʻaihue.
Passive form of the verb aihue; to be stolen. For these forms, see Gram. § 211: 1st, 2d.
Passive form of the verb aihue; to be stolen. For these forms, see Gram. § 211: 1st, 2d.
To kidnap; kidnapper.
Pas/imp. of ʻaihue.
These are all passive forms of the verb aihue; to be stolen. For these forms, see Gram. § 211: 1st, 2d.
Pas/imp. of ʻaihue.
To eat in order to destroy; to destroy wantonly or by violence or sorcery.
To have the use of fish ponds (loko); to control the interior (loko) land division known as ʻili.

definitions.der: [Ai, to enjoy, ili, the skin, surface (of land.) loko, that which is contained in something else]
definitions.dtxt: To have or possess a division of land less than an ahupuaa.
Hard and poor tasting, as thin or inferior fish.
See kahaʻula and cf. FS 251.
See MOEKAHAULA. A dreaming of committing adultery or fornication; a lascivious dream.

definitions.der: [Lit. eat scrape (as the sides of a poi bowl; thus, to eat all)]

SEL. 32-113) An ancient name for Pūkoʻo harbor, Molokaʻi, where inhabitants were washed into the ocean by a Kona storm and eaten by sharks (Jarrett 21). Pandanus groves here produced fine fruit (Ka Leo o Ka lahui, February 22, 1894).
Cannibal, man-eater; to eat human flesh.
Friend; friendly; to become a friend. See hale aikāne. Kāna aikāne, his friend. Moe aikāne, to commit sodomy (rare). hoʻaikāne To be a friend, make friends, befriend.

A privileged friend who shares the profits of a friend’s land, sometimes sharing in the work; one who shares a friend’s spouse; to share land or spouse; to pay part of a debt but withhold the remainder. Lit. eat [on the] border.

Being cut obliquely off, so as to make uneven parts; o ko'u ia, ua oki aikepa ia aku nei a uuku loa, my fish, it is cut off obliquely, and is very small; he lole i oki aikepa ia a pono ole, the cloth is cut off obliquely, and not straight.

Lit. Being eaten. Used passively; to be destroyed; to be devoured; eaten up. aina o Hawaii e ka pele, Hawaii is eaten by the volcano; aina ke kanaka e ka mano, the man was devoured by a shark; aina ka ai e ka puaa, the food was eaten by a hog.

A bunch on the shoulder from carrying heavy burdens.
Name of the person who has such a bunch.
The name of a disease; also called leholeho. Ka pilikia no ke kau ana mai o ka mai aipuu a e anai mai, the difficulty from the attack of the disease aipuu causing waste, etc.; he kokua leholeho.
Lumpy poi.

Steward, butler, said to be so called because the chief’s steward got calluses (puʻupuʻu) on his shoulders from carrying food. Waʻa ʻāʻīpuʻupuʻu (Laie 461), canoe with provisions. hoʻāʻīpuʻupuʻu To appoint or make one a steward; to act as one, as by waiting on the table; to issue provisions.
A servant who prepares food; a steward; a cook; a servant generally; originally, applied to stewards of chiefs.
Ai, food, and puupuu, to divide out. See PUU.
Hoo. To serve out provisions to others; to supply with provisions.
To serve or wait on at table.
To act as a servant in any manner.
Stiff neck. Fig. Stubborn.
A stiff or cramped neck.
To eat wastefully; a wasteful or riotous eater.
Epithet of a lower class of chiefs; eating riotously, or riotous eaters.
Coït.
The simple form is iwa. Nine; the number nine.
Nine (usually in counting in a series); nine times.
Same as āiwaiwa. Kapuāiwa (name of Kamehameha V), mysterious taboo.
Defensive corner back, in football.
Nursing, suckling, as an infant; to nurse, suckle; a nursing child, unweaned animal. Lit. to eat milk.
Ai, to eat, and waiu, milk. Milk-eating; epithet of a sucking child; an infant. Lit. A milk-eater.

To be very good, beneficent and kind, or the contrary. Aiwaiwa refers to the excess of character, very good or very bad. Aiwaiwa ke kanaka akamai i ka naauao; aiwaiwa no hoi ke alii lokomaikai; aiwaiwa no hoi ke keiki kolohe. Aiwaiwa refers to a person accomplished with learning; it applies to a very kind-hearted chief; it also applies to a mischievous child.
To look long and steadily at a person or thing; aiwaiwa nui i ka nana loihi a ike, he persevered in looking for a long time.

Inexplicable, mysterious, marvelous, strange, amazing, fantastic, fathomless, incomprehensible, wonderful because of divinity; wonderfully proficient or skilled; weirdly bad, notorious. See ex., kapolakā. hoʻāiwaiwa Mystifying, causing wonder; to mystify.
A remarkable person or animal; applied to the fabulous dog Kalahumoku, of tahiti; a ike aku la ia Kalahumoku i ke aiwaiwa o Tahiti. Laieik. 108.
Ivy. Also lau hihi pā.
Ancient surfing area, Waikīkī, Oʻahu. (Finney and Houston 28)
Abbreviation of ʻākau, north.
Abbreviation for ʻaoʻao kau (base).
Abbreviation for ʻākau (north).
Carefully, slowly. Cf. akaʻai, akahai, akahana, akahao, akahele, akahoe, akaholo, akakuʻu, akalewa, akaluli, akanahe, akanoho, akaʻōlelo, Gram. 6.3.3.
A particle set before verbs to express carefulness, regularity of proceeding, etc.; as, aka hele, go carefully; aka holo, sail or run slowly; aka hana, work carefully; aka noho, sit quietly.
Shadow. Cf. hoaka 4.

example_txt.txt: shadow of the multitude; Fig. A well-worn path
ʻŌlelo i ke aka ka hele hoʻokahi.
One going alone talks to the shadow.

definitions.dtxt: To cast a shadow.

Reflection, image, likeness; faint glimmer preceding the rising of the moon; essence of an offering rather than the flesh; to appear, of moonlight. Many words compounded with aka express clarity, brightness, related to this meaning. Cf. hoaka 3.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ke aka kā ʻoukou, ē ke akua, ʻo ka ʻiʻo kā mākou.
Yours is the essence, O god, ours the material part.

definitions.dtxt: Embryo at the moment of conception.
Newly hatched fish in the stage in which its body is still transparent. Cf. hāuli, mana, kākau.
Knuckles, as of hands or ankles; joints of the backbone; node and stalk of kava; kava slip for planting.
Shadowed, as on computer or in typesetting. See hoʻāka.
The shadow of a person; the figure or outline of a thing; a similitude or likeness.
definitions.notes: Note: The shade of a tree or house is malu.

definitions.dtxt: The dawn or light of the moon before rising.
The knuckle joints; the protuberances of the ankle joints; the joints of the backbone.
A shadow; frailty; impotence.
To light up, as the moon before rising; ua aha ka mahina? kokoke puka, ua aka mai la, how is the moon? it is near rising, it lights up.
To go up and down, as on a hilly road. (See No. 2 above, joints of the backbone.)
To be split or peeled up, as the bark of a tree.
To be torn off, as the kaupaku of a house; ua aka ke kaupaku o ka hale.
To laugh; laughter. See ʻaka hene. Kū i ka ʻaka, funny. ʻAka iki, sly laughter: to laugh a little, giggle, chuckle. hōʻaka To provoke laughter; laughter. cf. hoʻomākeʻaka.
To laugh; to deride; i ko'u noonoo ana i keia kumu manao, ua aka iki mai no ka pono, in thinking of this composition, I smiled at its correctness. (The 13th conj., akaaka, is more generally used.)
But, however, nevertheless, on the other hand, notwithstanding.
But; if not; on the other hand. The word is generally used to express strong opposition of idea.

To tear off, peel; to break open, as a seal; to fall off or down, as old thatching of a house; to break up, as the sides of a house; to uproot; ruffled, as feathers. Niu ʻākaʻa, coconut with flesh that shakes; such coconut flesh. hoʻākaʻa. Caus/sim.
To break open, as a seal. To tear or take up, as a mat.
Anything broken up; not cohering; he akaa wale, he pipili ole.
A type of fine white tapa. (GP 8) Cf. akaaka 2.
To eat slowly, carefully, Cf. Easter ʻaka kai, eat more.
Clear, luminous, transparent, visible, manifest, plain, intelligible; thin, as cloth; shining, bright, distinct. Cf. mōakaaka.

example_txt.txt: nā mea apau i hoʻākaaka ʻole ʻia ma ke kānāwai
all things not expressly provided for by law

definitions.dtxt: To clarify, explain, render or make intelligible, provide clearly for, prescribe, describe; explanation, clarification.
A white and very thin tapa. Cf. akaʻaʻamo.
A downy, thorny branching plant (Solanum aculeatissimum), 30 to 90 cm high, from tropical America. It bears round scarlet fruits 2.6 em in diameter, which are strung for leis. Also kīkānia lei.
Same as aka 5.
To laugh, ridicule; laughter, merriment. hōʻakaʻaka To cause laughter, create mirth, jeer, ridicule, pretend to laugh; comic. ʻŌlelo hōʻakaʻaka, witticism, amusing speech. Kiʻi hōʻakaʻaka, cartoon.
Laughter; exhilaration of spirits. Hal 126:2.
See AKA, to laugh. To laugh; to laugh at. Hoo. To cause to laugh; to have joy.
Poor; destitute.

example_txt.txt: ua māhuna i ka ʻawa, ua ʻākaʻakaʻa

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻākaʻa; peeled, as the skin by sunburn or by drinking kava; peeling; ruffled. Fig. Exhausted, thin.
To be peeling, as skin from sunburn.
The falling off of the scarf-skin after a course of drinking awa.
Ua mahuna i ka awa,
Ua akaakaa ka ili,
He puahilohilo ke kua i ka lepo,
Ua akaakaa.
See AKAA, to break up. To fall off, as the old thatching of a house.
To break up, as the roof or sides of a house; ua akaakaaia e ka mea kolohe, it was pulled off by some mischievous one.

An endemic begonia (Hillebrandia sandwichensis), a succulent herb with oblique, rounded lobed leaves 10 to 20 cm in diameter and with sprays of small pink or white flowers, found only in shaded, damp ravines. Kauaʻi. Also pua maka nui.
Same as akahiʻu.
Bulrushes out of which mats and bags are made.
Onions have taken the same name from the similarity of the tops.

An ambiguous passage in FOR. 4:157: maluna o ka waʻa naku akaakai … kona waʻa akaakai, in the bulrush canoe … his bulrush canoe. (Reference is to a canoe bound tor Kahiki to search for ʻOlopana. Thrum’s note [FOR. 4:156] says that canoes were not made of bulrushes and thinks naku here is ‘to search’ [see naku 2]. An alternative interpretation of akaakai is akaaka, clear, + -i, transitivizer, which might also mean ‘search’ in the sense of clarification.)

The great bulrush (Scirpus validus, formerly called S. lacustris) that grows on the edge of fresh or brackish water marshes in Hawaiʻi. The plants have unbranched, slender, green stems, 1 to 3 m high, looking like giant onion plants. formerly Hawaiians used them for house thatch or plaited them into mats for the lower layers of beds or for some temporary purposes, as the material is not durable. S. californicus on Niʻihau.

example_txt.txt: to eat bulrushes [fresh poi, which was not liked]

definitions.dtxt: The common onion (Allium cepa); the tops look like those of the great bulrush.
See ilo ʻakaʻakai, lina, ʻoʻa.
A common variety of onion.
Big, yellowish onion.
A purplish annual onion.
Green onion (Allium fistulosum); its leaves are eaten with salt salmon.

definitions.der: [Lit. moon onion, so called because the curve of the section of the bulb suggests a crescent moon]
definitions.dtxt: A wild onion, used for sore throat.
Bulrush.
Garlic (Allium sativum).
Garlic.
Afterglow.
Not clear, vague, indistinct.
A variety of seaweed.
Reflection, in math. See ʻālikelike aka.
A tall endemic climber (Smilax sandwichensis) with tendrils and shiny, leathery, heart-shaped leaves; used for tying rafters. Also hoi kuahiwi.
Same as ʻēkaha, bird’s-nest fern.
Name of a tree. One species has long leaves and grows inland; one species by the sea. It is a hard tree, like the uwea; also called ekaha.
Modest, gentle, unassuming, unpretentious, unobtrusive, docile, decorous, meek, suave; meekness, modesty.

example_txt.txt: Pōmaikaʻi ka poʻe akahai, no ka mea, e lilo ka honua iā lākou.
Blessed are the meek for they shall inherit the earth.

definitions.der: [aka, with, care, and hai, to speak]
definitions.dtxt: Meekness; modesty; gentleness. poe akahai, the meek.
Modest; gentle, etc. Soft in speech.

definitions.der: [aka, with, care, and hai, to speak]
definitions.dtxt: To be tender of heart; meek.
Name of a kind of white tapa.
To work carefully or slowly.
To pick up carefully, as food.

example_txt.txt: E hikiwawe mai i ka lohe, e akahele hoʻi i ka ʻōlelo.
Be quick to hear but slow to speak.

definitions.dtxt: Slow or moderate, cautious, careful, prudent (see ex., pukapai).
Caus/sim. precautionary; to take precautions.

See AKA and HELE, to go. To go slowly or moderately in doing a thing; to go carefully; the opposite of hikiwawe. E hikiwawe mai i ka lohe, e akahele hoi i ka olelo, be quick to hear, but slow to speak. Used also imperatively; beware; be cautious; e akahele ka pepehi mai o oukou i ke akua, beware of your striking the god; e akahele ka huhu, mai hikiwawe, be slow to anger, not quick.
To laugh at teasingly, jeer. ʻAka hene iki, to titter.

definitions.der: [aka, to laugh, and henehene, to ridicule]
definitions.dtxt: To laugh to scorn; to laugh in derision or mockery.
One (especially in counting in a series). Pōʻakahi, Monday. ʻA kahi kahi ana, ʻo ka ʻEwa iki, ʻo ka ʻEwa nui, a single unit, then lesser ʻEwa and greater ʻEwa.

For the first time, never before (usually followed by nō). (Gram. 4.6) ʻAkahi nō ʻoe ā hiki maʻaneʻi? Is this the first time you have come here? Have you ever been here before? ʻAkahi nō au ā ʻike iā Hilo, this is the first time I’ve seen hilo. ʻAkahi nō au ā lohe i ka hekili, I’ve never heard such thunder.
To have just. ʻAkahi nō ā pau kaʻu haʻawina, my lesson is just finished.
The number one; root, kahi.

One; once; just now; expressive of greatness or superiority. Emphatically, akahi no an i lohe i ka hekili, once have I heard it thunder, i.e., thunder loudly; akahi no au i ike i ka ino, once have I witnessed a storm, i.e., never so great a one before.
Hill (1,538 feet high), Hālawa qd., south Molokaʻi. Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.

Lit. Once by once; of little experience; a novice. Aole ka mea akahiakahi e holo i ka ino o make auanei i ka moana a pae kupapau aku i Lanai, let not the inexperienced sail out in a storm lest he die in the ocean and his dead body float ashore on Lanai.

example_txt.txt: E akahele ka mea ʻakahi akahi i ka luʻu.
Let the inexperienced be careful in diving.
Aʻole nō i ʻike loa no ka mea ʻakahi akahi.
[I] did not know much because of inexperience.

definitions.dtxt: Inexperienced, trying out for the first time; novice, beginner.

Hill near Huʻehuʻe, North Kona, Hawaiʻi. Three Menehune tried to remove the top of this hill but were prevented by a cock’s crow. On the second night they traced the crowing to a cave. There they found a cock which they killed and roasted in an oven (reported still there in 1924). Again they tried to remove the hill-top, but again heard crowing. They opened the oven, but it was empty. The god Kāne has resuscitated the cock and removed it. The Menehune gave up their attempt. Later, a legendary strong man, Kaleikini, thrust a kauila stick into the hill to secure the peak that had been almost severed.
Base of caudal fin. Also akaakahiʻu.
To paddle carefully, silently.
To sail or run cautiously.
By the sea. Kō a kai, those by the sea.
Large, potbellied, plump.
To laugh a little, snicker.
A rejoicing in consequence of hope; desire in proportion to the prospect of receiving a thing.

definitions.der: [aka, to laugh, and iki, a little.]
definitions.dtxt: To be pleased; to smile; to be gratified on receiving a favor; akaiki lakou me ka olioli no ka loaa o ko lakou waiwai, they smiled with pleasure on obtaining their property.
To laugh in one’s sleeve; to laugh secretly; na hoa nohoi i kani ai ka akaiki i ua wahi la, the companions also chuckled at us in that place.
To sneer at. See AKAAKA.
Clear, as water.
Lucid; bright, as the moon.
Certain; distinct; transparent; he akaka, kokoke like me ke aniani kona akaka ana, clear, almost like glass.
Akaka loa, very plainly; very clearly.
To be plain; to be clear, as a thought or the expression of an idea; to be distinct, intelligible, as language.
To be clear, transparent, as glass. Anat. 2. Clear, as a liquid.
Hoo. To make plain; to expound, demonstrate; to bring to light.
To set up boundary lines.

Falls (422 feet high) and State park near Hilo, Hawaiʻi. When a stone here called pōhaku-a-Pele (stone of Pele) is struck by a lehuaʻapane branch, the sky darkens and rain falls. A large stone in mid-stream about 70 feet above the falls is named pōhaku-o-Kāloa.
Var. spelling of akaaka 1.
A rent, split, chink, separation; to crack, split, scale.
Also agata n. Agate.
Rent; torn; dead. See NAKAKA.

Projecting spur of the mountain range at the head of Mānoa Valley; a street near the Chinese cemetery, Mānoa, Honolulu, named for the mountain that is said to be the grandparent of the Mānoa princess, Kahalaopuna (HM 152).
Poetical for akalani.
A heaven of light; a great light; the heavens much lighted; he akakalani no ka uhane Hemolele. Mel. Creat.
Hawaiʻi ʻākepa (honey creeper), Loxops coccinea coccinea, endangered. See ʻākepa.
Name of a small bird found in the mountains.
Agate.
Name of a precious stone; an agate. See above.
Spry, quick, nimble, especially about getting into people’s way or into trouble.
Spry; light, as one walking or running; not loaded; he akake no kau, you are spry, quick at walking.
Agate.
Name of a precious stone; an agate. See above.
Same as ʻakakē.
Negative of a photograph.
Photo negative.
Cashew.
To set up on the edge.
Point, Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi.
Destitution, poverty; poor.
Vision, trance; reflection, as in a mirror; hallucination; to see a vision. hoʻākakū Caus/sim.
See kino aka.
A subsiding of a storm, wind, etc.
A delirium; a trance. An ecstasy; vision. He moe uhane. Hoo. A vision.
Gentle, etc.
To cease; to abate; to grow calm, as wind, rain, surf, anger; ua akaku mai ka makani, the wind has abated; ua akaku mai ka ua; akaku mai ka ino o ke kaikoo; to be gentle; quiet.
The phenomenon known as the Specter of the Brocken, seen at Haleakalā Crater. hoʻākakū ānuenue Caus/sim.

example_txt.txt: Ua akakuʻu mai ke aliʻi, ʻaʻole inu lama hou.
The chief has calmed down, he doesn’t drink any more.

definitions.dtxt: Lessened, diminished, mitigated; to cease, abate, grow calm, stop, as wind, surf, rain, anger, grief, pain; settled, calmed, quieted, appeased.
Gentle; quiet; kind; calm.

To be settled; calmed; quieted; appeased; ua akakuu mai ka huhu o ke alii i na kanaka, the anger of the chief towards the people is appeased; ua akakuu mai ke alii, aole inu rama hou, the mind of the chief is settled, he will, drink no more rum.
A kind of cloth, e like me ka lole alaihi.
The end of a house. See KALA.
Pink.
Two endemic raspberries (Rubus hawaiensis and R. macraei); and the thimbleberry (R. rosaefolius), from southeastern Asia. Also ʻākalakala, ʻōlaʻa.
Dye made from ʻākala juice.
A pink tapa.
Same as kala, a seaweed.
A berry, something like a strawberry; a raspberry.
Street, Sheridan Tract, Honolulu.
Same as ʻākala 2, 3.
Pinkish.
Vieux; usé.
Same as akaakalani.
See AKAKALANI above.
A heavenly shadow; a splendid light.
The ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others, a sign of calamity.
See KINOAKALAU and WAILUA. A ghost that appears to some people, but not to others.
Ghost or spirit of a living person seen by others.
String of multicolored glass beads.
See LEI. A lei worn on the neck.
To sway the hips daintily, deliberately, and gracefully. See aka-, lewa 2.
Farthing.
Land section, Honolua qd., West Maui.
Land section, Honolua qd., West Maui.
To move slowly, carefully. See aka-, luli.
Adamant.
Adamant.
Smart, clever, expert; smartness, skill, wit. Cf. akeakamai.
To make wise or smart; to make a pretense of wisdom; to show off, display erudition; theorist.
Wisdom; skill; ingenuity. Hoo. Exhibiting wisdom.
Wise; skillful; iagenious; expert; sagacious; learned; akamai ma ka naau.
To be wise; makemake an e akamai oukou a pau, I wish that you may all become wise; mostly used in the causative. Hoo. To be or become wise; to make wise; skillful. To think one’s self wise.
Adam.

definitions.der: [Lit. Adams (named for Annie K. Adams, owner of the subdivision; TM)]
definitions.dtxt: Street, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu.
Careful, gentle in behavior and speech. See aka-, nahe.
Arkansas; Arkansan. Also ʻAkanasā.
Arkansas; Arkansan. Also ʻAkanakā.
Land near Kīlauea Crater, Hawaiʻi, where Kamapuaʻa taunted Pele. (PH 225)
Substance. See kumumea, meakino, pūhui.
To sit quietly, live cautiously. See aka-, noho 2.
To speak cautiously, deliberately, in moderation. See aka-, ʻōlelo.
Aka and olelo. To speak cautiously; to speak deliberately, advisedly.
Stingy, miserly, hard.
A full grown shadow; applied to a person who is close, hard or stingy.
Same as ʻapapane, a bird.
Right (not left). Cf. mākaukau, hema.

example_txt.txt: Lālau ka ʻākau, lū ka hema.
The right [hand] grabs, the left throws away [of a spendthrift].

definitions.dtxt: North (when one faces west, the direction of the sun’s course, the right hand is to the north).
North. Abb. ʻĀk. See wēlau ʻākau. Ke Kai ʻĀkau. North Sea. Kōʻai ʻākau. clockwise. Poepoe hapa ʻākau. Northern hemisphere.

The right; on the right; lima akau, the right hand; ma ka aoao akau, on the right side. In geography, the person is supposed to stand with his face to the west; hence the right hand is towards the north, and his left to the south. Aoao akau, north side; aoao hema, south side; welau akau, north pole, etc.
To go here and there, vagabond; vagabond.
Red sunset, looked upon as a sign that rain will clear.
Liver. Cf. akeloa, akemāmā.

example_txt.txt: Ake nui nō lākou e hāʻule ka ua.
They want very much for rain to fall.

definitions.dtxt: To desire, wish, be eager, yearn [the emotions and intelligence were thought to be centered within the body].
Liver.
The liver of an animal. Akepaa, same.
A-KE is a general name for several internal organs, qualified by different terms; see below.

To desire. To wish for a thing; ake nui no lakou e haule ka ua, they greatly desired that rain should fall; to pant after; ake nui kahi poe i ka waiwai, certain people greatly desire property; to wish to do a thing; ake no na kamalii e paani; to be willing; ake no na kanaka i ka hewa.
To find fault, criticize, slander. See kē.
A lie; a falsehood; a slanderous report of one; noho o Lahainaluna i ke ake, the people of Lahainaluna live under slanderous reports.
To blab; to tattle; to prate; to slander; tell lies; e wahahee; e imi hala; to go about talking nonsense.

example_txt.txt: a public report; to lay before the public
Ke hoʻolaha ʻia aku nei ma ke ākea.
There is being widely advertised hereby.

definitions.dtxt: Broad, wide, spacious, open, unobstructed, public, at large; full, as a skirt; breadth, width. Fig. Liberal.
To widen, broaden, extend, enlarge, make public; broadening, expansion; extension; to escape (rare).
Var. of Wākea.
Width or breadth, in math. Also ana ākea. See laulā. Cf. loa, lōʻihi, hohonu, kiʻekiʻe.
Broad, wide, spacious, unobstructed.
A broad open space; a place not concealed.
Broad; spacious; open; not crowded; public; ua kaawale ka hale, ua akea oloko.
To be broad or wide, as a land.
To be separate, as different, things, a space being between them; ua akea ka aina, aole pilikia. Mostly used in the causative sense.
Hoo. To enlarge; widen out.
To make room for one, i.e., to set free from difficulty, and supply one’s wants.
To enlarge one’s heart. To become generous.
Openly; publicly; ua hana akea, ia, it was done publicly.
Starboard or outer hull of a double canoe.
Starboard hull of a double-hulled canoe or right side of a ship when looking forward. Cf. ama, muku.
To block out or screen, in basketball. See entries below.

example_txt.txt: Ua neʻe akula ʻo Kalama i mua o Mānai no ka ʻākeʻa ʻana i kā ia ala ʻāpō ʻana mai.
Kalama moved in front of Mānai to block out his attempt to rebound.

definitions.dtxt: A lover of wisdom, seeker after knowledge, philosopher, scientist, scholar; philosophy, science; scientific. Lit. to desire wisdom.
Science. Also ʻepekema.
Ake, desire, and akamai, skill. A lover of wisdom; epithet of a philosopher.
Quick, ready, as to do a kindly, deed, helpful.
See AKE, to desire. Quick; ready; smart, especially to do a kindness; cheerful in entertaining strangers.
Hawaiian storm petrel (Oceanodroma castro cryptoleucura).
Same as hākeakea, faded; to fade.
A kind of gray tapa.
To fade, as kapa or cloth colored; to lose the color; to fade out; he akeakea ka ulaula, he ula akeakea ka palapala, the red is faded out, a faded red is the printing.
To block, hinder, obstruct, interfere; obstruction, block.
Illegal screen, in basketball. ʻAʻole hiki ke ʻākeʻa neʻe i ke kūpale me ka holo pū ʻana. Screening while moving along with the defender is not allowed. Lit. moving screen. See kuʻia ʻākeʻa.
Pick and roll, in basketball; to make such a play. Paʻakikī ke kaupale ʻana i ke kaʻaneʻe ʻākeʻa ʻūniu. Defending the pick and roll play is tough.
Acetate, a salt/ester of ascetic acid. ʻĀkeka ʻeto. Ethyl acetate.
Var. of kēkē, potbellied.
Name given for the ʻoʻopu hue, puffer fish, and listed by Malo. (Malo 46)
A singular little animal of the sea.
A small quantity of dust; aole nui o ka lepo.
A species of bird. See KEKE.
Cindery or pebbly soil; cinder.
Cinder. See one ʻā. Puʻu ʻākeke. Cinder cone.
A honey creeper (Loxops coccinea caeruleirostris). Usually called ʻākepa in Eng. Also ʻōʻūholowai.
Name of a little brown bird resembling the wren found on the mountain of waialeale, on Kauai; it was formerly worshipped by the natives as the god of the mountain.
A species of bird. See KEKE.
Ruddy turnstone (Arenaria interpres), a winter migrant to Hawaiʻi, occurring in small flocks which rise and wheel together. Also keke.
To talk loquaciously in a friendly, hospitable manner, bidding a guest to feel at home, make himself comfortable, eat plenty. Cf. heahea.
Redup. of ʻākeke, cinder.
Acetone.
Atlantic.
Atlantic. Also ʻAtelanika.
Acre.
An escape from great danger, as a person in a canoe in a storm; he akelekele wale no ka pakele, mai make.
To escape from danger or sickness; to have a narrow escape.
See ʻūhini ʻakelika.
Spleen.
Spleen.
The spleen.
Spleen
Edible raw liver.
Lung. Also akemāmā, akepāhola.
The lungs. See AKEMAMA.
Lung.
Lung. Aʻa kino akemāmā. Pulmonary vein. Aʻa puʻuwai akemāmā. Pulmonary artery.
Ake, liver, and mama, light. The lungs; the lights; oia ke ake e hanu ai, that is the lungs by which we breathe.
To boast, brag, admire, praise. Kūʻē akena, to taunt, defy. Keiki akena ā haʻanui, child boaster and exaggerator.
Pride; haughtiness; feeling of superiority over others.

To be proud; boasting; to be high minded; proud of some favor received; ua akena mai o Poki i na mea pono o ke Akua ana i ike ai, Poki was boasting of the favors which God had permitted him to see; akena ia ia iho, to boast of one’s self; to behave boastingly, as in war, joined with singing.
Proudly; loftily; boastingly.
Agent, factor.
Notary public.
Traveling salesman, commercial traveler.
Redup. of akena.
An intensive of akena in all its meanings.
Spleen.
See AKELOA. The spleen.
See Keakeomilu.
The name of a bird.
A sprightly, active man.
Sprightly; active; turning this way and that.
Group of small scarlet or yellow-green Hawaiian honey creepers (Loxops coccinea). See ʻakakane, ʻakekeʻe, ʻakepeuʻie.
Quick, nimble, sprightly, active.
Liver (more specific than ake).
The liver.
The lights, etc. See AKEMAMA.
Lung.
Lung.
Ake, liver, and mama, light. The lungs; the lights; oia ke ake e hanu ai, that is the lungs by which we breathe.
Azerbaijan.
To stand up every way, as uncombed hair; akepakepa mai la na ia ma ke opi a pau, the fish were cut cross ways and every way.
Unkempt, as hair; oblique. ʻOki ʻākepakepa, to cut obliquely, as fish.
Var. of kepakepal 1.
Tuberculosis, consumption.
Oʻahu ʻākepa (honey eater), Loxops coccinea rufa, presumed extinct; Maui ʻākepa, L. c. ochracea, endangered.
Uhini akerida, a grasshopper.
Active, lively, quick; pleasant, sociable.
Active; ready; skillful; receiving kindly one’s friends. SYN. with he mikimiki, he oleole. See AKEAKE.
Redup. of ʻakeu.
To find fault, contradict, criticize, hinder.
Backbiting; reviling.
A disease; the headache.
Locks of hair left behind the head, while all above is shorn off; ho lauoho aki loloa mahope; ka aki lauoho pupuni waiwai.
Backbiting; speaking ill of another.
The stools on which canoes are placed when standing on shore.
To begin to heal or scar over, as a wound.
To lop or double down, as the top of A sail when there is much wind; aki ko oukou pea; from aki, locks of hair, etc.; see below.
To bite; to bite in two, as a thread; to bite, as in peeling sugar-cane or cocoanut; e aki i ke ko, e aki i ka niu.
To backbite; to speak reproachfully of one behind him; to taunt.

To spread false reports; aki wahahee, e ake e hewa ka mea hewa ole; to slander. Hal 50:20. NOTE—Some of the meanings of aki are similar to ake. This verb has various forms; as, aki, aaki, aaaki, akiaki, which see in their places.
Land division, Lahaina qd., Maui.

To take a nip and let go, snap; to nibble, as fish; to bite off the bark of sugar cane to heal, as a wound; to scar over; sharp recurring pain, as in head or stomach. Fig. To attack, taunt, malign, snap at; slander; backbiter. ʻŌpū ʻaki, severe stomach-ache. ʻAki ka nuku, to press the lips tightly together. Pēlā e lilo ai ia i mea i hōʻino ʻia ai, i mea e ʻaki ai, so it shall be a reproach and a taunt. hōʻaki Caus/sim.
Height, tip, top (preceded by ke). Kū i ke ʻaki, to stand at the top [to have success].
Pillow.
Block on which a canoe is placed on the shore. Also lona.
Filled, as a canoe with waves.
Same as ʻakiʻaki 2, a rush. (KL. line 66)

Hair switch; knot fastening plaits or braids of hair; to add long strands of hair. Ua ʻākī ʻia ka lauoho, ua like ka lōʻihi o ka ʻākī me ka pūpū olonā, the hair is lengthened with long switches; the switches are as long as olonā bunches.
To furl, as sails.
Same as kikī, fast.
Name of an intoxicating shrub; its qualities are like the auhuhu; it is also called haakea. The bark is used to poison fish in fresh water as auhuhu is in salt.

Endemic shrubs and trees (Wikstroemia spp.) with small leaves, tiny yellowish flowers, and yellow to red, small, ovoid one-seeded fruits. The bark yields a fiber; the bark, roots, and leaves (as W. oahuensis) a narcotic used for fish poisoning, and according to Kep., used in ʻanāʻanā sorcery. varieties are qualified by the terms lau nui. mānalo, and pehu. Also kauhi.
Solanum nelsoni. Niʻihau.
To ferment; very sour, as poi. ʻAi ʻākia, sour poi.
Pas/imp. of ʻaki 1.
Also Asia. Asia; Asian, Asiatic.
Asia; Asian, Asiatic. Also ʻĀsia.
Same as kanawao 1, small endemic trees.
A backbiter; a reviler; a slanderer.
A disease; the dog colic.
Redup. of ʻaki 1; to nibble, as a fish; constant snapping at, attacking.
Seashore rush grass (Sporobolus virginicus), a coarse grass growing on sandy beaches; used to exorcise spirits. Also mānienie ʻakiʻaki, mānienie māhikihiki, and mānienie maoli.
A kind of coarse red seaweed (Ahnfeltia concinna) which because of its toughness must be eaten in little bites; a good source of carrageenin, a colloid. (KL. line 41) Called ʻeleau on Maui.
Name of a species of seaweed adhering to the rocks; it is eaten for food.
See AKI. To bite in two repeatedly.
To take away by little and little.
To nibble, as a fish at a hook.
To pilfer; he aihue liilii.

Buffalo grass (Stenotaphrum secundatum), an American grass used for lawns. some people believed that buffalo grass could be used to exorcise spirits because it had been given the same name (ʻakiʻaki) as the seashore rush grass, which was used for this purpose. Also mānienie ʻakiʻaki.

A group of Hawaiian honey creepers with long, curved bill, olive or yellow-green above, lighter below (Hemignathus obscurus), with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (H. o. o.), Lānaʻi (H. o. lanaiensis), and Kauaʻi (H. procerus). The latter is endangered; it has the longest curved beak, for sipping honey at the base of ʻieʻie and hala pele leaves. Cf. ʻiwi, ʻiʻiwi. Also ʻakihi loa, kipi.
Same as ʻakihi poʻo lāʻau.
Mountain, Honuʻapo qd., Hawaiʻi.
Birds. See below.
ʻAkihi Mountain, Honuʻapo qd., Hawaiʻi.
Same as ʻakialoa and ʻakihi loa. (Malo 39)
A small black sea bird, probably a stormy petrel (Oceanodroma), of which two dark, sooty species are known about the Hawaiian Islands, especially those to the northwest.
Same as ʻakialoa.
Name of a small yellow bird; o ka akihialoa, he manu hulu lenalena.
A bird listed by Malo. (Malo 39)
Name of a small bird with red feathers.
The nuku puʻu honey creeper of Hawaiʻi (Hemignathus wilsoni). See nuku puʻu.
Drydock, Lit. floating canoe-rest.

definitions.der: [aki, stools for canoes, and hoolana, to float]
definitions.dtxt: A dry dock.

example_txt.txt: ka hana ana i ka akihoolana i ke awa o Honolulu
building a dry dock in the harbor of Honolulu

definitions.dtxt: Dip net, as used in fishing uhu. Also ʻupena pākiʻikiʻi.
Name of a round fish net to catch the pahuhu in; he upena akiikii.
Acid., E mālama pono iho ʻoe i ke kīʻaha wai ʻakika (song), watch carefully for the glassful of acid.
An acid; he mea omo i ka puna. Anat. 2.

Acid. Pepa ana ʻakika. Litmus paper, for measuring pH. ʻAkika haidorokoloriku. Hydrochloric acid. ʻAkika kalapona. Carbonic acid. ʻAkika naikokene. Nitric acid. Also ʻakika nikiriku. ʻAkika pūhui kalapona. Carboxylic acid. ʻAkika ʻūpalu kūlohelohe. Naturally occurring weak acid. ʻAkika forimiku. formic acid. ʻAkika sulufuriku. Sulfuric acid. ʻAkika tanika. Tannic acid. ʻAnahai- daraside ʻakika. Acidic anhydride.
Carbolic acid.
Dwarfed; dwarf. Cf. ʻukiki.
Same as ʻūkīkiki, young of ʻōpakapaka fish.
A dwarf; a person of full age, but a child in size; he keiki kahiko, aole nui.
The endemic Kauaʻi creeper (Loxops maculata bairdi, formerly Paroreomyza bairdi).

Alkali; alkaline. Comb. ʻā- + kili + kai. Mekala ʻākilikai. Alkali metal, i.e., one of the family of elements in Group 1 of the periodic table. Mekala honua ʻākilikai. Alkaline earth metal, i.e., one of the family of elements in Group 2 of the periodic table.
Adriatic. Ke kai ʻo ʻAkilikika. Adriatic Sea.
Lye. Sh. ʻākilikai + lehu.

A wrasse fish of the hīnālea type (Gomphosus varius). Also hīnālea ʻakilolo. This fish was used by priests as the pani or closing medicine for head diseases. The taro or sugar cane of the same name might substitute.
A variety of sugar cane, striped with green and deep purplish-red when young, with yellow and red when older; named for the fish.
A variety of taro.
The name of a fish; a species of small fish.
A variety of sugar cane, with purplish leaves. See nānahu.
To take with a lou or fruit-plucking stick.

definitions.der: [aki, to bite, and lou, a hook]
definitions.dtxt: A hook biter, that is, a thief.
definitions.notes: Note: Thieves formerly supplied themselves with hooked rods to assist in obtaining articles of property; hence akilou, to apply the hook, was to steal.

definitions.dtxt: Aki and lou, to bend over. To eat secretly the food of another.
Feast of unleavened bread.
Admiral.
Archimedes. Ke kulehana a ʻAkimika. Archimedes' principle, i.e., the buoyant force on an object submerged in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by that object, in science.
Same as ʻinamona, kukui nut relish.
Street in Kalihi Kai, Honolulu, named for Representative Joseph A. ʻAkina, speaker of the first Territorial House of Representatives. (TM)
Biting; bite.
Reste.
Actinoid, i.e., one of the fourteen elements that follow actinium on the periodic table.
An endemic, small, hairy, pink-flowered shrub (Hibiscus youngianus), usually found in marshy places. Also hau hele.
Name of a tree; also called puahanui.
Name of a plant; the marshmallows; the same perhaps as akiahala above.
Axiom.
Archbishop.
To nip. ʻAkipohe nā manu i ka lehua, the birds nip at the fringes of the lehua flowers.
Round, as a leaf; compact, concise. ʻAkipohe ke ʻike aku i ka nani o Waipiʻo, compact the view of the beauty of Waipiʻo.
Name of a wind of Waiheʻe, Maui.
To center or concentrate in one place, as wind, rain.
To search, seek, probe, penetrate, spy.
To probe.
Used in a prayer as follows: Akele akiu kelekele akiu, kau aku akiu iluna ke kau lua he wai akane, etc.
Redup. of ʻakiu. A me ka makani ʻākiukiu kīpē pua hala a Puakei, and the penetrating wind pelting the pandanus blossoms of Puakei.
See KIU. To act the part of a spy; to search into; to penetrate.
Searching; penetrating; a me ka makani akiukiu kipe pua hala o Puakei, the searching wind pelting the hala blossoms of Puakei.
Thatching; to thatch. Mea ako hale, thatcher.

example_txt.txt: The house is thatched [if during an emergency it was impossible to erect a temple, the priest merely gestured that the house was completed and thatched].

definitions.dtxt: To thatch; to cover a house with thatch; ua akoia ka hale.
The art of thatching; ua pau ka hale i ko ako; mea ako hale, a house thatcher; mea ako hipa, a sheep shearer.
To cut, shear, clip, trim, as hair; to break or pluck, as flowers.
Itch, throat irritation, venereal disease. Fig. Lust.
To cut, as with scissors; to cut, clip off; to crop off.
To pluck, as flowers or fruit. To shear, as sheep. To cut off, as hair. Ua ako ia ka lauoho; ua ako ia i ka hulu o ka hipa; ua akoia ka lau o ka nalu i ka makani.
To clip off, as the wind the top of the surf.
Name of a disease of females of bad character; he ako na wahine hana hewa; he ako ka mai o na wahine hana hewa.
A small tree resembling koa; dye was made from its bark, and to color tapa. (And.) But cf. kūʻoulena.
Kapa of a snuff color; so named from the dye made of the akoa tree; he kapa i kuku ia ma ka akoa; he paupau akoa.
Redup. of ʻako 6 1, 2.
Crest of a wave; to break or swell, as waves.

chants.chtran: The great chiefs ascend to the crest of the waves, to the crest, to the heavenly height.
chants.chtxt: Pipipiʻi i ka ʻakoʻako nā liʻi nui i ka ʻakoʻako, i ka ʻiu lani.

definitions.dtxt: See AKO. TO move, as the lips in speaking to one’s self.
To itch in the throat before coughing; akahi no ka akoako o kuu puu no ka maneo, uncommon is the tickling of my throat on account of itching.
To have a hacking cough in the throat.
Akoako ka ale, to swell up, as a wave just before breaking; kuku ka lili o ka nalu.
To assemble; assembled, collected, heaped.
To assemble, congregate, muster, throng; to collect, gather. ʻImi ā hoʻākoakoa, to search for and gather, as data.
Assembled; collected.
To assemble, as people for business.
To collect together what is separated; ua akoakoa na kanaka ma ka hale pule, the people are assembled at the meeting house. Hoo. To gather together, as men.
To collect together, as waters. To come together again, as a dispersed people. E hoouluulu ae ma kahi hookahi.
Collectively, in heaps; e waiho akoakoa, to lay down in heaps.
Coral in general, coral head.
The horned coral.
Coral generally.
A precious stone.
Mushroom coral (Fungi scutaria).
The crested honey creeper (Palmeria dolei), formerly endemic on Maui, endangered.
Name of a small bird making its nest on the ground.
A variety or taro.
A nut.
Mel.
A variety of sugar cane, deep-red and green when young, changing to purple and brown-yellow; pith dark-brown; larger and stronger than ʻakilolo, especially in wet districts.
Endemic shrubs and trees (Euphorbia spp.) with jointed stems, opposite leaves, and milky sap. Buds and leaves of one species (E. multiformis) were chewed for debility. Also ēkoko, koko, kōkōmālei.
Bloody. Also kokoko.
Name of a fruit found on Hawaii.
Same as ʻaikola, gesture and expression of contempt.

To triumph over the ills or misfortunes of another. To triumph, as over an enemy; hooakola mai oia ia lakou me ka olelo ana, akola! he triumphed over them, exclaiming hurrah! akola! pakele mai nei no au, well done! I have just escaped. See AIKOLA. Honaikola is another form.
An exclamation of triumph of any kind; a word of contempt for not getting a thing, or for losing.
Poor, destitute, shiftless.
A large endemic fern (Dryopteris unidentata), 1 m or more high, with triangular-oblong fronds much subdivided.
Poor, in consequence of squandering one’s property.
See KOLE. To make or render one’s self poor. SYN. with e hooilihune, e hoowaiwai ole.
A native fern (Athyrium microphyllum syn. A. poiretianum) with beautiful, large, lacy fronds. See hākonakona 1.
A small mollusk (Epitonium perplexum). Often called pipipi ʻākōlea or kōlea.
Name of a species of shrub, grass, or fern.
Accordion.
See kōkua hua mele.
Ostrich.
A cant word, expressive of contempt.
To creep, attempt to creep; to put out small roots, as potatoes.

definitions.der: [a for aa, and kolo to run]
definitions.dtxt: To run into small roots, as potatoes, and bear no fruit.
Running and branching, as roots of plants; good above and small below. SYN. with aakolo, he kolo pu.
A species of fern.
Three (as in counting in a series); three times. Pōʻakolu, Wednesday (lit., third day).
See KOLU. Three; the number three; also written ekolu.
Automatic. Hānai ʻakomi. To auto feed, continuous feed, as paper into a computer printer.
Atomic.
Caffeine. Comb. ʻā- + kope.
Adobe.
Sp. A species of brick made of earth and water mixed with grass or straw and dried in the sun.
See uinihapa ʻakopie.
Clear; unclouded; spoken of the moon when fully up; he aku ka mahina, the moon is clear.
To follow.
Bonito, skipjack (Katsuwonus pelamis), an important food; to run, of aku. Young of this fish are called kīnaʻu and ʻāhua.

example_txt.txt: Bonitos are running at Mahaiʻula [place at Keāhole quadrangle, Kona, Hawaiʻi].

definitions.dtxt: Particle expressing direction away from the speaker, and time either past (with nei) or future (without nei, sometimes translated soon). (Table 12 in Gram. 7.2) aku contrasts with mai and sometimes may be translated away. Aku + demon. lā is pronounced and written as a single word, akula. Aku sometimes expresses the comparative degree. In an idiom, aku is sometimes used as a noun after the plural definite article nā.

example_txt.txt: Na Ioane aku i nā ʻekalekia.
He said to someone far away (cf. aʻe 4).
nā mea nui aku i kēia
He mea ʻai i nā aku.

definitions.dtxt: Name of a species of fish, smooth, round; the bonito; the name of one of the two fish that accompanied Pili in his voyage to these islands; aku helped paddle (haluku) the canoe, and opelu calmed the winds when too strong. D. Malo 4:13. See OPELU.

A verbal directive. See Gram. § 233, 2, and § 236. In Hawaiian, the motion or action of verbs is supposed to be towards one (mai,) or from one (aku,) or upwards (ae,) or downwards (iho,) or sideways, which is also ae. Aku is mostly connected with verbs, sometimes with nouns and adverbs; it implies motion or tendency from one, onward, etc.; as, e hele aku, to go off, go from one; the opposite of e hele mai, to come towards one. In narrative tenses the verbal directives are generally followed by the syllable la; as, hele aku la oia, he went off; noho iho la ia, he sat down, or he dwelt.
An endemic lobelia (Cyanea tritomantha), a small tree 2 to 3 m high, with clustered leaves (up to 78 by 20 cm), somewhat downy beneath. The leaves were cooked and eaten like cabbage. Cf. ʻakūʻakū.

God, goddess, spirit, ghost, devil, image, idol, corpse; divine, supernatural, godly. Akua might mate with humans and give birth to normal humans, moʻo, or kupua (Nānā 23). Children of Kamehameha by Keopuolani were sometimes referred to as akua because of their high rank. Kauā, or outcasts, were sometimes called akua because they were despised as ghosts.

example_txt.txt: to have a prodigious appetite, as though possessed of gods [as youthful heroes in legends]
Nāna nō i hāʻawi i ke akua.
Through her given to the god [death by sorcery, cursed].

definitions.dtxt: To deify, make a god of; godlike, supernatural, extraordinary, divine. Cf. hoa kua.
God (Christian).
“It” in a game of tag or hide-and-seek.
Name of the 14th night of the full moon.
Same as maiʻa Polapola, a banana.

Among Hawaiians, formerly, the name of any supernatural being, the object of fear or worship; a god. The term, on the visit of foreigners, was applied to artificial objects, the nature or properties of which Hawaiians did not understand, as the movement of a watch, a compass, the self-striking of a clock, etc.
At present, the word Akua is used for the true God, the Deity, the object of love and obedience as well as fear.

The name of the night when the moon was perfectly full; a akaka loa o ia poepoe ana, o Akua ia po; hence it would seem that the ancient idea of an Akua embraced something incomprehensible, powerful, and yet complete, full orbed. The names of the four principal gods of the Hawaiians were Ku, Lono, Kane, and Kanaloa.
Hoʻomana akua kahi. Monotheism; monotheistic. Hoʻomana akua lehulehu. Polytheism; polytheistic.
Spirit eater of scraps, designation of a god sent on errands of destruction by sorcerers.

A spirit that destroys its keeper; a god sent on an evil errand who returns to destroy his keeper rather than the victim; any evil practice, as excessive drinking, gossiping. He akua ʻai kahu ka holoholoʻōlelo, bearing gossip is a spirit who destroys its keeper.
Spirit eater of filth. Same as akua ʻai hamu.

Supernatural with dual roles as akua to unrelated persons and ʻaumakua to relatives, as formerly the four major gods to high ranking chiefs, and later only as pele, Hiʻiaka, and Laka to mortals. (Nānā 36)
The ancestors of those who died long ago, and who have become gods; the spirits of former heroes.

definitions.der: [Akua, god, hai, to speak, and amio, to be silent]
definitions.dtxt: A god speaking silently.
A god to whom one appealed with offerings for help, as in fishing, farming, or killing an enemy.
Spirits, as of a recently dead kinsman, who were fed (hānai) offerings (such as food) and sent out to destroy an enemy.

The kauila, nioi, and ʻohe “poison” woods of Molokaʻi, which were kept by sorcerers in their houses, wrapped in tapa, and to which food offerings were made daily; scraps of these woods were used as poison, and poison itself was sometimes called akua hānai.

The god that fed poison to people; the god of poison; hence, poison itself; he akuahanai ka rama, rum is a poisonous god, a he moonihoawa ka aie, and a poison toothed lizard (serpent) is going into debt.
God sent on errands of destruction.
