A class of gods who were sent on errands like mercury of the Greeks; the names of some of them were Keawenuikauohilo, Kapo, Kapua, kamakukou, and many others.
Feather image. (Ii 39)

Stick image (general name); image wrapped in tapa; image consisting of a carved staff, with a tuft of feathers at the top, bound to its bearer by a sash (kāʻai) (Malo 80) and carried into battle; staff with a carved figure at the head, used in ceremonies to procure offspring (Malo 135, 139).
Holy Trinity. (Kep. 175)
A god to whom offerings and sacrifices were made.
Same as ʻuhane kīhei pua.
Image representing a god.
The god represented by an image; hence, an idol; a god made.
Done in a hurry; therefore, badly done; he akuaku iho kou, you were in a great hurry; he akuaku kana hana, his work is badly done.
Sailing, as over a rough sea, or traveling over a rough road; hele akuaku ma ke ala; holo akuaku ka moku; with one end up, then down.
Up and down, as an uneven road; having the form of stairs; he ala akuaku.
A species of rush.
Swaying, as a canoe in rough sea; not steady; bumpy, as a road. ʻAkūʻakū ka ihu o ka waʻa, the prow of the canoe rises and falls.
Hasty, poorly done, rash.
An endemic lobelia (Cyanea rollandioides) 1 to 1.4 m high, with rough leaves to 50 by 15 cm. The leaves were cooked like cabbage or taro tops or sweet potato leaves, with pork or salt beef. Cf. ʻakū.
Similar to akua hānai 1, 2; sent out in the shape of fireballs to kill, or inserted in a victim’s food, water, or tobacco. (KAM. 64:134–5)
Ghost, specter, apparition, evil spirit.
A ghost; a specter; an apparition; an evil spirit.
definitions.notes: Note: According to the old people, the poe akualapu were the spirits of deceased persons seen in the night about burying and other places for the purpose of frightening people.

definitions.dtxt: Flying god, usually a poison god sent to destroy, sometimes in the form of fireballs (pōpō ahi). See akua hānai.
A meteor; an ignis fatuus.
definitions.notes: Note: When the Hawaiians were first shown the representation or imaginary picture of an angel, they at once called it an akualele, a flying god.

definitions.dtxt: A tall image, especially an image of Lono carried on a circuit of the island during the makahiki, harvest festival; it was called loa, long, because of its “long” travels. The image consisted of a staff about two fathoms long. Pieces of pala fern, feather leis, and skins of the kaʻupu bird were fastened to a crosspiece tied near the top of the staff, in the center of which was a tiny carved head. A long and white tapa banner was attached to the crosspiece. (Malo 143–5, but see Malo text, chapter 36, sections 22–4) Tribute was collected. Also Lono Makua.
Secondary activity, of a volcano. Comb. ʻā + kualua.
Foreign god, epithet often applied to Pele because she had come from a foreign land.
A spirit that takes possession of people and speaks through them as a medium. (Malo 115–7)
Name of a class of gods supposed to be the spirits of men deceased; they were supposed to dwell with, or be over men as guardians.
Image representing the god of sports that accompanied the akua loa on its circuit, to preside at the sport festivals. (Malo 145, 154)
The god of nightmares; a god who carried persons to distant places in their sleep, especially if they had eaten certain fish, as the weke.
Last and slow-moving image in a procession during kauila nui ceremonies, (Ii 41)
Same as pepeiao akua.
Similar to akua loa, except that it was taken to a poko. See poko 3.
A god that inspires or possesses people.
The god which came upon one and inspired him to speak; the god of inspiration.
Goddess.
A short, low woman; he wahine poupou.
Club-footed; deformity of the feet. Cf. kukuʻe.
To be black, blue or dark colored. See KUKUHE.
Same as ʻōkuhekuhe, a fish; fish form of the god Kānemilohai (HM 452).
To pound.
Probably similar to ʻākuʻikuʻi 2. He lāʻau ʻākuʻi … no ka wā ʻupena kuʻu, (FOR. 5:621), sticks used with gill nets.
Chipmonk. (Ute ʻakwiisi.) Also kiulela ʻakuiki.
To pound. See kuʻi 1.
A long fish net; to drive fish into the net by striking the water with sticks. Also pākuʻikuʻi.
Name of a particular fish net. See AKUIKUI above. Also, the name of the stick used to drive fish into the kuikui.
Same as kihe, a red seaweed.
Adjutant.
Adjutant general.
The juice of the tree called koko, used among Hawaiians as a cathartic.
To beat, as tapa. (Kep. 99)
Tossing about, agitated; jolting, as a vehicle on a rough road. He ʻakūkū nalu lā i poʻi, an agitation of waves that broke.
The standing up of water when wind and current are opposite; me he akuku nalu la i poi iloko o ka malama o Kaulua. Laieik. 167.

Lessened, diminished, mitigated; to cease, abate, grow calm, stop, as wind, surf, rain, anger, grief, pain; settled, calmed, quieted, appeased. Ua akakuʻu mai ke aliʻi, ʻaʻole inu lama hou, the chief has calmed down, he doesn't drink any more.
Directional part. aku + demon. lā. See ex., aku 2.
An epithet of an aged person; an old man or woman. See ELEMAKULE.
Big-eyed or goggle-eyed scad fish (Trachurops crumenophthalmus), Stages of growth are pāʻāʻā, halalū or hahalalū, and akule.

example_txt.txt: Ua wehe ke akule i ka hohonu.
The akule has fled to the depths [of escape].

definitions.dtxt: Name of a species of fish.
To give property or a right to it; to delegate responsibility.
Caus/sim.

example_txt.txt: He hōʻailona ia o ka luhi a me ka hoʻākuleana.
This is a sign of toil and of obtaining property.

definitions.dtxt: Mana ʻākuleana. Delegated powers, as of Congress.
Adultery.

example_txt.txt: ʻĀkuli ke aka o ka lāʻau i ka wai.
The reflection of trees is cast on the water.

definitions.dtxt: To collect, as leaves in a stream; to dam a stream thus; forest pool where leaves and rubbish have accumulated. Fig. To cast a reflection.
To collect in a stream of water, as leaves, blossoms, etc.
To dam up the water by such collection; ua akuli ka wai, a ua halana; a ua akuli ka lau o ka laau iloko o ka wai.
Akuli ka pua o ka laau i ka wai,
Lulana ahu i ka ae waililua,
He wai hoopaa ia nolaila.
No ua’kua la, o Maua, o Limaloa.
General name for succulent plants.

A coastal herb (Sesuvium portulacastrum), known in many warm regions, somewhat like wild portulaca (ʻākulikuli kula), but with longer, narrower leaves, and with small white to magenta flowers at leaf axils.
Portulaca cyanosperma. Niʻihau.
A kind of water herb, perhaps purslane; he mea ulu ma ka aina, ma na aliali, a he papapa kekahi inoa.
Same as ʻaeʻae 2.
A tropical American, low succulent (Batis maritima), commonly forming a continuous green cover by salt marshes. Locally called pickleweed.
Same as ʻaeʻae 2.
Purslane (Portulaca oleracea), a cosmopolitan weed, a small succulent, prostrate herb, with spatula-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. It is eaten by people, poultry, and stock.
Portulaca.
Same as ʻākulikuli kula.
Ice plant (Lampranthus glomeratus) from Africa, a low succulent, with thick, narrow leaves, and pink, rose, or orange flowers (used for leis).
Same as ʻaeʻae 2.
A species of color or colors; he akulu moe wai, a eleele uliuli.
Name of a species of fish.
Broken or cut off, as a pencil point; blunt, stumpy.
Broken or cut off till very short; applied to anything cut or broken off piece by piece, as a pen in mending, or a pencil in sharpening.
Redup. of ʻakumu.
A while ago, last. See aku 2.
Same as ʻōkuhe, an ʻoʻopu fish.
A small endemic tree (Bobea mannii). Cf. ʻahakea.
Fair eyed, but blind; ala ka maka, e like mo ko ka elemakule, dim sighted, as an old person.
Round or oval, as a smooth stone or bullet; hence, heavy; kaumaha, e like me ka ala o kahawai, heavy, as a smooth stone in a water course. See ALA, a round, smooth stone.
Spicy; perfumed; aromatic.
A path; way; road; often alanui, great road; it is used in some places as synonymous with kuamoo; he kahi e hele ai; kuu aku ana keia i ke ala; po oloko i ke ala. Laieik. 62.
A variety of kalo, tough and stringy.
A round, smooth stone; a pebble, such as has been worn by the water; he pohaku maloko o ka muliwai. Ala o ka maa, a sling stone.
To anoint; to dress a sore or a limb.
To wake from sleep; to watch, i.e., to keep from sleep.
To rise up, as from a sleeping posture; e hikilele oia ma ka hiamoe ana. Ala ku e, to rise up against one.
To rise up, as a new generation of people; to come forward.
Hoo. To cause one to rise; to lift up; to rise from the dead.
To raise up; excite to action; to stir up, as the mind.
To stir up; excite to evil.
To raise up, as a deliverer or benefactor.
To repair, as a broken down wall.
Fast, quickly. Cf. alaheo, alamimo, alapine, alawiki, Gram. 6.3.3.
Path, road, trail. Cf. alaloa, alanui, alawai.

example_txt.txt: a pathway on which there is no returning [death]
a bird’s trail [a life difficult to emulate]
the small path of priests [a difficult way of life]

definitions.dtxt: To waken, stay awake; awake.

example_txt.txt: a chant intended to awaken a sleeper

definitions.dtxt: To awaken someone. Also spelled hoʻoala.
To rise up, arise, get up, come forward. Cf. ala hou.
To arouse, stir up, incite, renew, restore, revive, raise; to restore, as a building; summons.

example_txt.txt: Ā na lākou nohoʻi kēia hoʻāla iaʻu.
This summon to me was from them.
Ke hoʻāla mai nei ʻoia i koʻu ʻuhane.
a chant said at the construction of a hula altar (kuahu hula), calling on the gods, especially Laka, to possess the altar
Ua ala ka iʻa i ka makau.
The fish takes the hook whole.

definitions.dtxt: Var. of ale 1. Cf. alaō, alapoho.
There (same as the more frequent lā and -la). Cf. e lākou ala, e lauala, e (verb) ala, Gram. 7.4, 8.2.
Aisle, as in a supermarket. Also alakaha. See entries below.
Lane, as on a highway or in a bowling alley.
Awake.
Fragrant, sweet-smelling, perfumed; fragrance, perfume (preceded by ke). Fig. Esteemed chiefly. Cf. ʻaʻala.

example_txt.txt: a fragrance so strong that it causes dizziness

definitions.dtxt: To perfume.
A variety of taro, said to be pungent-smelling when cooked. Varieties are qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, ʻōpelu; cf. also ʻalaopuna.

Dense waterworn volcanic stone, as used for poi pounders, adzes, hula stones; hard lava, basalt. Kinds of ʻalā rock, as used for adzes, are qualified by the phrases pia maka hinu, shiny-faced arrowroot; mahinu, shiny; and maka hinu, shiny face. Also (KAM. 76:122) ʻalā haumeku ʻolokele, ʻalā lelekepue. ʻAlā o ka maʻa, slingstone. Kaʻalāwai (place name, Honolulu), the watery basalt.
Iwi ʻalā. Cortical bone. Pōhaku ʻalā. Boulder, in Hawaiʻi, referring to poi pounder-size stones and larger. Cf. nukahaku.

A large endemic tree (Planchonella spp.) with smooth, oblong leaves, shiny-green above, bronze beneath, the fruit yellow or black, to 5 cm long. The sticky, milky sap was used to trap birds, the wood for spears and ʻōʻō handles. Also āulu, ʻēlaʻa.
ʻŌʻō digging stick made of ʻālaʻa or any wood; to prod or dig with a stick, as in taro cultivation. Fig. To dig into the mind; to be dislodged, as by the wind.
Small corm, as of taro.
A kind of tree.
To work with the oo in cultivating or digging off green sward.
A strong Hilo wind.
Ink sac in octopus or squid; after salting, drying, and broiling on the fire, it is mixed with ʻinamona or chili peppers and eaten; mixed with ʻauhuhu juice it is used as bait. Fig. Useless.

example_txt.txt: Just a pile of squid ink sac [no use]!
He aha ka ʻalaʻala o kēnā mea āu i hoʻihoʻi mai nei?
What’s the good of that octopus ink sac you've brought home?

definitions.dtxt: Scar of a scrofulous sore; to be so scarred; perhaps tuberculosis adenitis (KAM. 64:115).

example_txt.txt: Mai ʻalaʻala paha auaneʻi i ka ua kawaʻahia.
Perhaps his neck will be scarred in the rain of Kawaʻahia [in trouble].

definitions.dtxt: Aerial tubers of bitter yam, hoi (Dioscorea bulbifera).
A soft substance in the squid used for bait in fishing; he alaalahee.
Soft, flabby flesh; soft and tough, as some kinds of food.
The name of potatoes that grow on the leaf of the potato.
Scrofulous.
Ala, round, etc. A scrofulous sore; an ulcer, particularly on the neck; the ringworm; poha ka alaala me kukae uli.
Small ʻalā stones.
See laʻa 2.
Small tubers, as of taro.
Lukewarm; half-cooked.
Hard, or half cooked, as kalo; aohe maneo, moa puehuehu, he maneo ia.
Ku i Hawaii ke one,
Alaalae ke one,
He pehu ka mai. he liki ka lau.
The spawn or black substance found in the squid. See ALAALA. He alaalahee me kahi kukui inamona, the spawn of the squid with kukui nuts as a relish.
Same as māhoe 2, kinds of trees.
Name of a bird.
Redup. of ālai 1, to hinder.
Type of taro patch built on artificial mounds, known near Hilo as kipi (HP 125); mucky clay-like soil, as in this type of patch.
Same as waimakanui, a kind of large coarse endemic fern (Thelypteris keraudreniana).
Argillaceous earth.
The name of a kalo patch formed by bending down the rushes and covering them with dirt and irrigating it; hence.
Same as ʻuhaloa, a weed. Aia i kula, i ka ʻalaʻala pū loa, there in the fields, for ʻalaʻala pū loa [a wild-goose chase].
The name of a species of fish of the squid kind; he alaalapuloa me ka wekaweka no.
A plant with small yellow blossoms; called also uhola, a species of useless shrub; auhea o mea? aia i kula i ka alaalapuloa, i.e., gone on a wild goose chase, or on a fool’s errand.
Redup. of ʻalawa. ʻAlaʻalawa ka maka o ka ʻaihue, the eyes of the thief glance this way and that.

The compound, frequentative, poetical form of alawa; to look frequently one way and the other, as in fear of being seen; alaalawa ka maka o ka aihue, alaalawa na maka me he pueo la, the eyes of the thief look this way and that, they look here and there like an owl.
All species of Peperomia, small native succulent forest herbs, related to ʻawa. The name is qualified by the terms kāne (on Oʻahu) or kupa liʻi (on Hawaiʻi), pehu, pōhina. Also ʻawalauakāne.
A small weedy herb (Plectranthus parviflorus), in the mint family. this name may be qualified by the terms pua kī, wahine.
Name of a large tree whose fruit is used in dying.
Name of a small plant growing in stony places; he a ahi ulu liilii ma ke ahu pohaku.
Name of a god of the winds; the Eolus of the Hawaiian Islands.
Huai mai ka ipu makani.
Alaamaomao ke akua makani.

definitions.der: [Lit. awake (during) daylight. Cf. ala pō, ala mōlehu]
definitions.dtxt: Diurnal, i.e., active during the daytime. Lawe ʻia mai nei ka manakuke i hawaiʻi nei no ke kāohi i ka ʻiole, akā, he ala ao ka manakuke a he ala pō ka ʻiole, no laila, ʻaʻohe i kō ka makemake. The mongoose was brought to Hawaiʻi to control the rat population, but the mongoose is diurnal and the rat is nocturnal, so the objective was not achieved.
To tell publicly, as of the past.
Type of ancient dramatic hula. (UL, chapter IX.)
Long cloud formation.
To disclose to another what one has said of his character.
The name of a kind of dance; he alaapapa kahi hula.
River ford; place on a trail where one swims or wades across a stream.

A West Indian shrub, night cestrum (Cestrum nocturnum), Chinese inkberry, with narrow leaves and narrow, tubular, green-to-creamy white flowers, which are most fragrant at night. Also kūpaoa, onaona Iapana.
Alabama; Alabaman, Alabamian. Also ʻAlapama.
Albania; Albanian. Also ʻAlepania.
Alabaster Gr. αλάβαστρο; he ipu alabata.

Mudhen or Hawaiian gallinule (Gallinula chloropus sandwichensis), a black wading bird with red frontal plate; cry of this bird is believed a bad omen; some considered the ʻalae an ʻaumakua; endangered. For the coot, see ʻalae kea. Also koki. See saying, keʻu.
Same as ʻiwa, a fern.

Name of a bird with a red skin on the upper part of its bill; oia ka mea (o mauiakalani) nana i imi i ke ahi, a loaa i ka alae, he it was (Mauiakalani) who being in search of fire, found the alae; alae, he moa eleele loa, a very black fowl. the alae was formerly worshipped as a god, especially the alae keokeo, the white alae.

Land section, Honomū qd.; pit crater near Kīlauea Crater, Puna qd., Hawaiʻi, active in 1969 (Macdonald and Abbott 101). Land sections and homesteads, Puʻuokali qd., Kula, Maui. Peak (2,000 feet high), above Kalaupapa peninsula, Molokaʻi.
School and land sections, Kealakekua, Hawaiʻi.

Water-soluble colloidal ocherous earth, used for coloring salt, for medicine, for dye, and formaly in the purification ceremony called hiʻuwai; any red colloring matter; according to Dr. Frank Tabrah (KAM. 76:149), brick-red soil containing hematite. See ʻiʻo ʻalaea, kuhi ʻalaea. Ua ʻalaea (FOR. 4:399), red rain [red of the rainbow].
Flesh like redness, especially the dark red meat close to the spine of some fish, as of the aku.

Annatto dye plant (Bixa orellana), a tropical American shrub or small tree, bearing fruit with scarlet seeds, used for dyeing. Sometimes called ʻalaea lāʻau to distinguish from the earth; locally also called lipstick plant. Also kūmauna.
Tribe or clan; people in a district who have intermarried.
Bad breath, halitosis.
Fore part of thigh; long narrow thigh muscle. (And.)
Tribe, i.e., people in a district who have intermarried, specifically referring to Hawaiʻi. Cf. hapū, nāki.
Red dirt; a kind of Spanish brown dug from the earth.
Any red coloring matter; red ochre.
Red, as the flesh of the fish aku and ahi. See foregoing. Huki koke ka io alaea a me na io a pau; name of a muscle. Anat. 50.
A family, tribe or clan.
The descendants of servants; the descendants of Keopuolani are the alaea of Nahienaena.
The fore part of the thigh.
Relating to the practice of the priest offering the yearly sacrifice; hele mai ke kahuna alaea me ke kanaka, nana e lawe ka ipu alaea.
Dark-red ʻalaea.
Light-red ʻalaea.
The introduced Australian gallinule Porphyrio poliocephalus, P. p. melanotus. also applied to a form of ʻalae kea, with brownish frontal knob.
Same as ʻalae ʻula.
Land section near Kīpahulu, East Maui.
An edible crab of the Portunus sp., sand colored, and found in shallow water.
Hawaiian coot (Fulica americana alai), a marsh and pond bird, distinguished front ʻalae ʻula by its ivory-white frontal knob; endangered.
Same as ʻalae kea.
Poetic for aia la, there it is.
Same as ʻōlaelae 1; having a number of capes and land points.
Var. of mālaʻelaʻe.
A wind of Mānoa Valley, Honolulu. Kuʻu kāne mai nā makani anu o ka ʻāina, he mālualua me ke Alaʻeli, my husband from the cool winds of the land, the Mālualua and the Alaʻeli.
Land division and point, Honolua qd., Maui.
Coastal area, Honolua qd., Maui.
Land section near ʻAlae Iki, Kīpahulu, East Maui.
Same as ʻalae kea.
Hawaiian gallinule or mudhen (Gallinula chloropus sandwichensis), distinguished from ʻalae kea reddish bill and frontal plate; endangered.
Plank bridge, rough road over ravines or chasms, trestle, ladder.
A ladder.
A rough road, with many ravines or chasms. Laieik. 71.
Bay and cliff near Hōnaunau, South Kona, Hawaiʻi.
Type of braid used in the pāpale ʻie.
Mountain ladder or steps cut into a cliff.
Alley, alleyway.
Railway, railroad track.

A large native shrub or small tree (Canthium odoratum; synonym Plectronia odorata) with shiny leaves and small, fragrant, white flowers. The wood is hard and was formerly used in making the ʻōʻō digging stick; also used medically. Also ʻōheʻe.
Name of a shrub, the leaves used in coloring black.

Name of a tree; a species of tree, very hard, of which instruments were made to till the soil with; o na oo mahiai i ka wa kahiko, o ka ulei a o ke alahee, the diggers for farming in ancient times were made of ulci and alahee.
Mock orange (Murraya paniculata), an ornamental hedge plant with shiny, dark-green leaves, small fragrant white flowers, and red berries. Also walaheʻe haole.
Slalom course.
Hiking trail.

example_txt.txt: kuleana ala hele e hiki aku ai
ʻO ka pono koʻu ala hele.

definitions.dtxt: Pathway, route, road, way to go, itinerary, trail, highway, means of transportation.
Pedestrian’s road, sidewalk.
Also written alanui hele wāwae.
Gone, departed.
Pas/imp. of ala 2, 3.
Caus/sim. to awaken; wakefulness, insomnia.

chants.chtran: The time to be awakened comes, awake, awake.
chants.chtxt: I ka hiki hoʻālahia nei lā, ē ala mai ʻoe.

definitions.dtxt: Hem or finished border of a plaited mat or hat.
A species of wood; bastard sandal-wood.
A row or hem, as on a mat.
Ramp.
Wooden bridge.
Name of a light Hilo breeze. Also ʻAʻalahonua.
The south-west direction from Hilo; ke ala ana i ka manawa i makemake ole ai; o ke alahonua ana mamua, aole i hiki i ka manawa.
To wake up early for no reason.
Name of a Molokaʻi wind. (FOR. 5:103)
Resurrection; to rise again, resurrect. Ka lā i ala hou ai ka Haku, Easter [Protestant; Lit. the day the Lord rose again]. hoʻāla hou, to restore, revice.
Ala, to rise, and hou, again, and the participial termination ana. A rising again; a rising from the dead. A resurrection.
Marine railway.
A frequented and well-known path; to frequent such; to tread or trample, as on a taboo being broken (And.).

example_txt.txt: Alahula Puʻuloa he ala hele na Kaʻahupāhau.
Everywhere in Pearl Harbor lies the path of Kaʻahupāhau.
I am very familiar with this place.

definitions.dtxt: A thoroughfare; a path or place much frequented; ua maa i ka ikeia, ua hele pinepine ia.
A road made on a pali on which a stranger cannot go, only traveled by residents.
A place where it is necessary to swim past a cliff that intercepts the passage along the beach, as Elelu on Hawaii.
To break a certain kapu; ua alahula kahi kapu, ua noa ke kanawai.
Alahula Puuloa, he hele na Kaapahau.
To make a road through one’s house or farm by constantly passing through it; ua lilo i alanui hele mau ma ia wahi.
Gentle, as a breeze. Cf. laʻi.
Obstruction, hindrance, block, bar, screen; to obstruct, hinder, block, defend, stand in the way, oppose, hamper. Cf. ala'ala, ānai.

example_txt.txt: to fascinate the eyes, as beauty
Ua ālai ʻia ʻoia e ka hilahila ā hiki ʻole ke pane aku.
He was hindered by embarrassment and could not answer.

definitions.dtxt: Two sticks carried with the akua loa in the makahiki festival; they were used to mark the boundary of the taboo area.

To obstruct; to hinder one in any way; ua alai ia e ka hilahila a hiki ole ka pane aku, he or she was hindered by shame and could not answer. Laieik. 127. To block up a door or passage by sitting down in it.
To form a circle round one for his defense in danger.
To defend; oppose one.
To be so thronged as not to see out.
NOTE. The double form, alalai, is more generally used. Ua alai ia, ua paapu loa, aole ike aku kahi mea, ho was thronged thickly, he could not see out.
Small thin surfboard, as of breadfruit or koa wood, and heavier than the olo board. Also omo.
A small, thin surf board.
An upland bird, gray, about rite size of the ʻelepaio, reported in 1863. See ʻeʻea. (KL. line 308)

Various species of squirrelfishes of the family Holocentridae, including flammeo sammara (spotfin squirrelfish, 185 mm), Adioryx lacteoguttatus (whitespotted, 117 mm), A. diadema, (crown, 109 mm), A. xanterythrus (Hawaiian, 132 mm), A. tiers (Tahitian, 259 mm). The young are called ʻaʻalaʻihi. Unidentified kinds are qualified by the terms ākoʻakoʻa, kala loa or kanaloa, lā kea, māhū, maoli, and pilikoʻa.
Pale pink tapa; any faded color.
A variety of sugar cane named for the fish, either a deep-red mutant of ʻāwela or related to it; internodes barrel-shaped, leaves purple. (HP 221, 224)
A species of small red fish.
Name of a red cloth.
Appropriation of property by force, as practiced by some chiefs on their travels; to do so.
The practice of quartering in one’s house or seizing one’s property when a chief traveled with his people.
See laila.

Refers both to time and place; there, when place is referred to; then, when reference is made to time. Like many other adverbs, it is declinable with the simple prepositions. Gram. § 68 and § 165, 2d.
Obstacle, obstruction.
Alaska.
Alaska; Alaskan. Also ʻAlaseka.
Aisle, as in a supermarket.
Land section and stream, Honomū qd.; stream and water-fall, Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi.
Potbellied, bloated.
Large; pot-bellied; plump.
Sea course, path where one must swim past a projecting cliff.
He alakai ke alanui hulaana o na pali, a path where one must swim around a projecting cliff or bluff.
To lead, guide, direct; leader, guide, conductor, head, director (a putative PCP ala, to lead [cf. Maori arahi] + -kaʻi, transitivizer: Gram. 6.6.4).

example_txt.txt: leading teacher; exemplary teacher, pattern, or example

definitions.dtxt: A leader; conductor; guide.
To lead along the path; to guide or conduct one on a road.
To lead, as captives.
To take, as a person, from one place to another.
To lead, as an animal; alakai ke keiki i ka puaa, the child loads the hog; ua alakaiia ka lio i ka pa. Hoo. To cause to lead.

example_txt.txt: one who sings the melody of a song

definitions.dtxt: Kumu alakaʻi. Precedent, i.e., something done or said that may act as an example to justify it being done again.
Swamp and trail, Waimea district, Kauaʻi. (PH 45)
A guide on the mountains and inland; what a pilot is on board ship.
Leadership, guidance.
Alkyne. Cf. ʻalakane, ʻalakene. Pūkaʻina ʻalakaine. Alkyne series, i.e., the group of unsaturated hydrocarbons with one triple bond.
Driveway.
Alkaloid.
Alkane. Cf. ʻalakaine, ʻalakene. Pūkaʻina ʻalakane. Alkane series, i.e., saturated hydrocarbons where all the carbon atoms are joined by single covalent bonds.
Detour.
Allspice.
Mode of transportation, as motor vehicle, space vehicle, etc. Comb. ala + kau.
To jump, hurry from place to place.
Name of a star, probably used in navigation.
Name of a downtown Honolulu street.

definitions.der: [Lit. while street (this street, leading to Honolulu harbor, was once paved with while coral stones; Clark 9)]
definitions.dtxt: Street, downtown Honolulu.
Alligator.
Alkene. Cf. ʻalakaine, ʻalakane. Pūkaʻina ʻalakene. Alkene series, i.e., the group of unsaturated hydrocarbons with one double bond.
Arsenic.
To drag, pull along.
Bird-catching pole. Also ʻaukuʻu.

definitions.der: [ala, path, and ko, to drag along.]
definitions.dtxt: To drag along the ground.
To lead, as a criminal; kindred with alakai. E kauo, e huki.
To trail, as a gown in the dust; he aloko mai i ka lepo, to drag in the dirt.
To draw or influence one.
To drag, as in computer program.

example_txt.txt: E alakō i ka ʻiole, a kuhikuhi i ke kiʻiona.
Drag the mouse, and point at the icon. Also kiʻi a alakō.
to drag onto. Also alakō a kau ma luna o.

definitions.dtxt: Street, Waiʻalae, Honolulu. (TM)
Point near Wailua Bay, Kauaʻi. A heiau here was named Kūhua.
A large crab (Carpilius maculatus), with 11 dark red spots on its back, usually found concealed in rocks or under stones.
Place for climbing a cliff, usually with ropes.
Runway. See kuʻu, ala lele mokulele.
Aral. Ke kai ʻo ʻAlala. Aral Sea.

example_txt.txt: Hele ka makuahine, ʻalalā keiki i kauhale.
When the mother goes, children bawl at home [a neglectful mother].

definitions.dtxt: To bawl, bleat, squeal, cry, caw, yelp, wail, scream; such noises.

example_txt.txt: He aha lā kāu i hōʻalalā mai nei i kēlā keiki?
Why did you make that child cry.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.

example_txt.txt: he ʻalalā, he manu leo nui
a crow, a bird with much talk [a talkative person]

definitions.dtxt: Hawaiian crow (Corvus tropicus), named for its caw; endangered.
A style of chanting with open mouth vibration and tremor of the voice, and prolonged vowels; to chant thus.
To gargle.
Hill at Kulaʻimano, Hawaiʻi.
The cry of young animals; a crying; weeping; a bleating, crying, etc., of flocks. The squealing of hogs. Laieik. 17.
To cry, as the young of animals.
Name of a bird; a species of raven on Hawaii; so named from its cry, resembling that of a child. Laieik. 29.
High point between Kailua beach and Lanikai, Oʻahu. A tall stone at the point is used by fishermen as a landmark to locate a fishing station at sea.
Sweet potatoes that bear front branch (lālā) vines.
A specie of potato with fruit on the leaves. See ALAALA.
To consecrate; to render sacred by coming in contact with some sacred object.
Redup. of ālai. Ua alalai mai ʻoia i koʻu hele ʻana, he obstructed my going.
To hinder one from doing a thing.
To obstruct one’s road.
To be in the way of another; ua alalai mai oia i ko'u hele ana, he hindered me in my passage; he keakea.
Cave near Kamāʻoa, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. Channel between Kahoʻolawe and Maui.
To dry or wither leaves over a fire, as of tobacco. Also lala 2, ʻōlala, ʻōlani.
To spread out tobacco leaves over or before a fire to dry for use.
Bleating, wailing. See ʻalalā 1.
Young of the red ʻāweoweo fish. Appearance of schools of this fish near shore was an omen that royalty would die. Also ʻalauwā.
A species of small fish; called so when small or young; when larger or older they are called aweoweo.
Sickly, weak, fretful, as a child; fretfulness. He ukuhi ʻōhemo nā keiki, ʻōmino ʻalalehe, ka ʻalalehe, ka uwē wale, weaning children are sickly, crying and fretful, weak, just crying.
Sick; weak; hungry, as a child; he ukuhi ohemo na keiki, omino, alalehe, ka alalehe, ka uwe wale.
Flight corridor.
Sharp shrill yelp, sudden screech; to yelp, screech.
A, jaw, and lalo, under. The lower jaw of men and animals; the lower mandible of a bird.
Highway, main road, belt road around an island, a long road.
A highway; path. etc. SYN. with alanui.
Craindre, trembler, étourdissement.
Protection, defense.

definitions.der: [ala, path, maawe, any small substance, and iki, little]
definitions.dtxt: A small, narrow, indistinct path; it is applied to the departure of the soul when one dies; he is said to have gone along the alamaaweiki, i.e., the untrodden path; he alaoloii.
Bowling alley.
Name of a stone at Maiao, flat and shining; applied to a disobedient child; he alamakahinu i ke alii.
Pierre dure et noire.
To be too ripe; rotten, as anything lying out in the rain; ua kapule alamea, i ka ua.
Hard volcanic stone, used for adzes.
The name of a species of hard stone from volcanoes, out of which stone axes were made.
Nutmeg. Sh. huaʻala +
A common black crab (Metopograpsus thukuhar). Also ʻelemihi, ʻelepī. ʻAlamihi ʻai kupapaʻu, corpse-eating black crab [a scavenger].
Two places, one on each side of Mānoa Valley, Honolulu. On the death of a Mānoa native, a rainbow spanned the valley from one Alamihi to the other.
Quick, fast. Nā kupuaʻi alamimo o nā kini maka lehua o nā ʻōpio, nimble soles [dancing feet] of the many lehua blossoms of youth.

Boulevard, shopping center, beach park, harbor, section 23 of Honolulu (map 6), and surfing area (Finney, 1959a:108). A “left-slide” surfing area seaward of the Ala Wai yacht harbor is called Ala Moana Bowl today; Hawaiʻi State surfing championships are held here.
A species of stone.

definitions.der: [Lit. awake (during) twilight. Cf. ala ao, ala pō]
definitions.dtxt: Crepuscular, i.e., appearing or flying in the twilight. He lele kekahi mau ʻano ʻōpeʻapeʻa i nā hola mōlehulehu o ke ahiahi, no ka mea, he ala mōlehu ia mau ʻano holoholona. Some kinds of bats fly only in the twilight hours of the evening because they are crepuscular creatures.
An endemic fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish (Len tipes concolor). Hilo. Also hiʻu ʻula and hiʻu kole.
Street, ʻĀina Haina, Honolulu.
Cut off or unfinished road, dead-end road. Fig. An incomplete rainbow, rainbow fragment.
Light; not heavy; easily floating on the water; ho hookomo ole; not sinking.
A present made by a chief to a priest to procure his prayers.
A present made to a god; he makana e haawi aku ai i ke akua.
An oblation or free will offering for any purpose.
A sacrifice. Alana hoano, a holy oblation. He alana ka mea e haawiia aku ai e kalaia mai ai ka hala o ka mea lawehala.
A fee prepaid to a physician to attend upon a sick person.
Alala, to cry, and ana. A crying; the voice of suffering or of complaint; ke oho alana makuakahi, the voice of complaint from an only parent.
To give or bring a present as an offering. To offer a sacrifice.
Awakening, rising. See ala 2, 3. Ike ʻia ke alana o ka pua, the upward flight of the arrow was seen. Alana ʻia (Kel. 29)! Rise up!
See kīkē ʻalāna.

Offering, especially a free-will offering, contrasting with a mōhai that was prescribed by a priest; to offer. He ʻālana ka mea e hāʻawi aku ai e kala ʻia mai ai ka hula o ka mea lawehala, an ʻāana is the thing given so that the sin of a transgressor will be pardoned. Ē ke kahuna ʻiʻo a me ka ʻālana ʻiʻo, O true priest and true victim [of Christ]. Moʻokaʻao … ʻālana ā hoʻolaʻa ʻia i mua o ka lāhui hawaiʻi, a story … offered and dedicated to the Hawaiian people.
Light, buoyant, easily floating. See lana.
Alana, offering, and aloha, love. A peace offering; an offering for making peace with another to procure one’s favor; he alana e aloha mai o hai ia ia.
Peace offering, offering of love.
Alana and kuni, to burn. An offering to procure the death of a sorcerer; e make ai ka mea nana i anaana; a burnt offering.
Burnt offering, offering to procure death by sorcery.
An offering made to the gods to procure a curse; he alana e molia i kipi aina, to curse the rebels; ke alaua e molia i ka mamala ku i ka pa; he alana e molia i ka olulo pae i kapa.
Ala, path, and neo, silent.
Clear; serene; unclouded, as the atmosphere on the mountains; alaneo ka uka, aole ao, clear was the upland, no clouds.
Desolate; without people, as a couentry; alaneo kauhale, aole kanaka. see NEONEO.

The name of a disease where the patient is swelled greatly in every part except the face; he olelo a na kahuna lapaau; ina olelo aku i ka mai, pela he alaneo kou mai, o ke ano o ia olelo, he mai kanaka ole, aole lehulehu o kanaka nana e kii i ka laau.
A class of gods, males only.
The name of a cloak or royal robe made of the feathers of the mamo only; o ka aahuula i hanaia i ka hulu mamo wale no ua kapaia he alaneo.
Clear weather; no clouds.

Clear, calm, serene, unclouded, free from impediment; clearness, calm, stillness; emptiness, nothing; desolate. ʻAlaneo ka uka, ʻaʻole ao, clear were the uplands, without clouds. Ē Lono i ka pō laʻilaʻi, kuʻua mai ka ʻalaneo (Malo 183). O Lono of the clear night, let down clear skies. Hāhā nā lima i kahi e loaʻa ai, a hoʻokuʻi me ka ʻalaneo (Kel. 136), the hands grope at places to find things and collide with nothing at all.
Of a single color or texture, especially of a feather cloak without design and made of feathers of a single kind and color.
Swelling disease, dropsy, generalized edema, kidney disease.

Name of a class of 12 male supernatural beings called papa pae māhū, said to be hermaphrodite healers from Kahiki. One at least was according to legend turned to stone and has been moved to Kuhiō Park, Waikīkī, Oʻahu. See Paemāhū in Pukui, elbert, and Mookini, 1974.
Lulu ʻalaneo. Rain shadow.
The Hawaiian pronunciation of the word orange; an orange, a foreign fruit; also, the name of the tree.
Name of a land breeze at Lanai, from the name of the mountain.
Name of a species of limu, bitter, and very similar to the limu lipoa.
Name of a timber tree used in fitting up canoes.
The name of the mountain on Lanai and some other places.

Brown seaweeds (Dictyota spp.), regularly divided into narrow segments. they are so bitter that they will taint other seaweeds put with them and can be eaten but little and by some are considered poisonous. Medical kahunas used them in small quantities to treat asthma. This name is sometimes qualified by the terms kai and ʻula. Also maka and false līpoa. Cf. kūālani.

An Oʻahu tree (Pelea sandwichensis or P. oahuensis), with oblong, fragrant leaves (like the mokihana of Kauaʻi), which were used for scenting tapa. The bark, was used for medicine. Also other species of Pelea.
An upland moss.
Drive, Woodlawn, upper Mānoa, Honolulu, perhaps named for a tree (Pelea sandwichensis).
Any kind of orange, both fruit and tree, as Citrus sinensis.
Poloka kau lāʻau ʻālani. Orange tree frog.
Smooth, as the ocean, without wave or ripple; aole apuupuu, he kalania.
Smooth, even, not rough.
Calamondin (Citris mitis), a small tree with flattened-globose fruits to 2.6 cm in diameter, orange-colored, few-seeded, sour.
Ala, path, and niho, tooth. Name of the long strips of tatoo made on the skin by means of a shark’s tooth.
Long tattoo stripe.
All species of Pelea. Also kūkaemoa.
Alanine, an amino acid.
Tangerine, mandarin (Citrus reticulata cv. ‘deliciosa’), a small tree with small leaves and small, loose-skinned, orange, flattened globose, sweet fruits.
On Niʻihau, identified as C. grandis.
Grapefruit. See iāpona, pomelo.
A low native shrub (Pelea waialealae), found only on high, wet parts of kauaʻi. Also ʻanonia.
Ala, path, and nui, large.
A highway; a road; a frequented path. See ALALOA. In some places kuamoo is used.

Street, road, highway, thoroughfare, waterway, course. alanui hele, any traversed road. Alanui o ke keʻa, station of the cross. Poetic names for the equator are alanui a ke kuʻukuʻu, road of the spider, and alanui i ka piko o Wākea, road at Wākea' navel. Alanui polohiwa a Kanaloa, the dark path of kanaloa [southern limit of the sun in its yearly cycle, about the 15th and 16th days of the month Hilina Mā. Alanui polohiwa a Kāne, the dark path of Kāne [northern limit of the sun, about the middle of the month Kaulua]. Alanui maʻawe ʻula a kanaloa, road of the scarlet footprint of Kanaloa [the western sky].
Avenue, boulevard, wide street.
Avenue, boulevard, wide street.
Sidewalk.
Also written alanui hele wāwae.
An ancient trail connecting Kekaʻa Point and Kahakuloa, West Maui; only the two ends of the trail are visible.
Pathway of the navigator stars; star course followed by navigators. Probably also hōkū ʻai ʻāina.

definitions.der: [Lit. smoke tobacco road (said to be a place where people pause to smoke and rest)]
definitions.dtxt: Ridge and road, Hālawa qd., Molokaʻi. See Puʻupā.
Mission, as in the mission statement of an organization. see nuʻukia. ʻŌlelo ala nuʻukia. Mission statement.
Name of a class of heiaus.
The eating of the oopu oi other fish raw, and even before dead; ka alao mai no i na wahi oopu, a me na wahi opae.
To swallow whole, as a fish or shrimp. Also alaʻoma. Ke alaō mai nō i nā wahi ʻoʻopua me nā wahi ʻōpae, swallowing whole small ʻoʻopu fish and shrimps.
Heiau or temple that had no lele altar.
Road cut, short cut.
Name of a Kauaʻi wind, said to bring good weather. (FOR. 5:97)
Street, Foster Village subdivision, Hālawa, Waipahu qd., Oʻahu. Name suggested by mary Kawena Pukui in 1956.
Rue, sentier.
Ala, path, and ololi, narrow. A narrow path; a lane, as of a city.
Narrow path, lane, alley.

To receive into the mouth; to swallow greedily, as a fish the bait; alaoma ka waha o ka oopu a me ke aholehole i ke koe; the mouths of the oopu and the aholehole greedily swallow the worm; alaume momoni.
Var. of alaō 1, and alaʻume.
A variety of taro, growing wild, also cultivated dry in Puna, Hawaiʻi; fragrant when cooked, like kāī. Also welowelolā.
Ua like me alao. See the foregoing.
Ugly; poor; thin in flesh, as a hog.
Athletic, active; athlete; an epithet for Kamehameha I; name of a company of kalaniʻopuʻu’s warriors. Nā ʻālapa e mākaukau ana no ka mokomoko, the athletes skilled in boxing.
Athlete; athletic. Haʻawina kālā ʻālapa. Athletic scholarship.
Slander, falsehood, deceit; slanderer; to slander, defame, deceive, lie. He ʻalapahi moe ipo kā nāna, so it is a lie of his about sleeping with the sweetheart.
Slander; detraction; falsehood; he alapahi moe ipo ka nana; a lie; false speaking.
Olelo alapahi, a slanderous or false report.
To spread false reports; to slander.
To deceive; to lead others astray.
To deceive, as a demagogue.

Coastal area, Kamalō qd., north Molokaʻi, probably named for Alapaʻinui, leader of the Hawaiʻi forces that invaded Maui in 1738 and combined with the Molokaʻi forces to defeat Oʻahu invaders. See Kawela. Street on the boundary between downtown and Thomas Square sections, Honolulu, named for a chiefess who was a companion of Nāahiʻenaʻena (daughter of Kamehameha I) and the wife of John Young II. (RC 74, 340, 342; TM)
Alpine, i.e., relating to the biogeographic zone above timberline. See lalo ʻalapaina, wao laʻalāʻau. Panoa ʻalapaina. Alpine desert.
Alpaca.
Also alabata, Alabaster, ointment vase of alabaster.
Same as ʻalapaka 2.
Prefix (Haw.); suffix (Eng.) -athalon. Comb. ʻālapa + kona. See entries below.
Triathalon. Comb. ʻālapakona- + kolu.
Pentathalon. Comb. ʻālapakona- + lima.
Decathalon. Comb. ʻālapakona- + ʻumi.
Exceedingly fragrant, too much so, or too strong to be pleasant.
Place, Diamond Head section, Honolulu.
Médire; tromper; séduire, égarer; rapport.
Alabama; Alabaman, Alabamian. Also ʻAlabama.
Tunnel.
Gulch, Kahakuloa qd., Maui.
Alfalfa.
A mean man of no character who goes before the king; ka mea ino pii i kahi o ke alii.
Athletic person aspiring to the lineage of Kū (said of Kamehameha).
Arabia, Arabian.
A heavy cloth resembling serge.
Arabia, Arabian. Also ʻArabia. Aupuni ʻEmira ʻAlapia Hui Pū ʻia. United arab Emirates. Ke kai ʻo ʻAlapia. Arabian Sea. Saudi ʻAlapia. Saudi Arabia; Saudi. also Saudi ʻArabia.
Ala, path, and pii, to ascend. A ladder; stairs. An ascent. He alahaka, he alaulii; he alapii pali ino o Wahinekapu.
Stairs, steps, ladder, stile, doorstep, ascent, scale (musical). See ex., ʻoʻopu 1.
Point, northwest Kauaʻi.
Lua fighting stroke.
Steep road or path.
Escalator, moving stairs.
Musical scale.
Musical scale: pā, kō, lī, hā, nō, lā, mī, pā. Also pākōlī.
Belly of a fish, considered choice.
Parallel, as of a computer port. See ala pūkaʻina. Awa ala pilipā. Parallel port.
Frequency, in math.
Quick, fast. He ʻuleu nā poʻe o ke kai, alapine nā lima i ke kaula, the boys of the sea are spry, quick hands on the lines.
Frequent, often. Cf. ala-, pinepine.
Redup. of alapine 1, 2.
Sidewalk.
Night awakening. hoʻāla pō A summons sent at night. (GP 10)

definitions.der: [Lit. awake (at) night. Cf. ala ao, ala mōlehu]
definitions.dtxt: Nocturnal.
Orbit of the stars, circular road.
To gulp, swallow whole.
Shipwrecked. Same as ʻōlulo.
Name of a dark basalt. Also kai ʻanuʻu.
Having scrofulous sores, as on the neck, legs, etc.
Applied to kalo which has spots of dry-rot; he kalo alapuka.
Body sores; to have such sores; affected with dry rot, as taro.
Serial, as of a computer port. See ala pilipā.
Small, young, of creatures. ʻAlapuʻu moʻo, scalawag of a baby grandchild. ʻAlapuʻu heʻe, baby squid.
Alaska; Alaskan. Also ʻĀlaka.
Place where a wind is parted, as the east wind at Hana, Maui.
To knock with the knuckle on anything hard, as a board; olou.
Dividing, branching, as of winds and lineages. He makani alau kō kēia wahi, the wind here in this spot divides.
An island (4.5 acres, 40 feet elevation) off Haneoʻo, East Maui; believed to have been formed by Pele. Headland, Kalaupapa peninsula, Molokaʻi.
To look upon one’s self with admiration; e alaua ana ia ia iho me ka manao ua nani oia.
Var. spelling of ʻalawa, to glance.
Same as ʻalalauā, young ʻāweoweo fish. Pupū ke kai i ka ʻalauā, the sea is congested with ʻalauā fish [of difficulties; omen of death of royalty].

Endemic Hawaiian honey creepers (Loxops maculata), Oʻahu creeper (L. m. maculata), endangered; Lānaʻi creeper (L. m. montana), presumed extinct; Maui creeper (L. m. newtoni); Hawaiʻi creeper (L. m. mana), endangered.
Vile; bad; worthless; slovenly; negligent; pupuka.
Badness; worthlessness; vileness; the offscouring or dregs of society; he hana inoino pupuka alauka.
Homely, vile, slovenly, worthless; homeliness, vileness, dregs of society. he hana ʻinoʻino, pupuka, ʻalaʻuka, it is wicked, nasty, vile conduct.
Ala, road, and ula, red.
A streak of light, such as is seen after the setting and before the rising sun. Hence,
The first dawn of the morning. The early dawn or first gleam of morning light.
Red dust in a road; the red dust of a pali; red dust generally.
A kind of red chalk in which nothing will grow.
A kind of seawood, blackish; a species of limu.
Light of early dawn, sunset glow.

example_txt.txt: the flaming path of Kāne [the eastern sky]
Ka wehe ʻana o ke alaula, ʻoia ka paoa.
The opening of the flaming pathway is the dawn.

definitions.dtxt: Way, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Same as ʻaʻalaʻula, a seaweed (Codium spp.).
Red dust in a road, red dust.
Clothes, tapa, mats; to envelop, clothe. Cf. laulau, wrapper.
Sheer trail as for climbing a cliff. Also hūlili.
See ALAOMA.
To draw, pull, attract, as a magnet. Malalo ka huila e niniu ai, alaʻume nā ʻili i ka nui hao (hula song), the wheels revolve below, the fan belts pull the immensity of the metal.
Var. spelling of ʻalauā.
A species of bird, small and yellow. See LAUWI.
Var. spelling of ʻalauahio, a bird.
Same as ʻalauahio.
A turning of the eyes to look behind; he alawa na maka i hope e ike i ka poe e hele mai ana.
To look on one side, then on the other, as one who is afraid of being seen; e hoi oukou me ko oukou maka alawa ole io a io.
To look up, as one downcast.
To lift up the eyes in pride.
To lift up the eyes to see a thing. To take a survey.
To turn the eyes in an oblique direction.
To turn one’s head to look about.
To be lifted or turned up, as the eyes; alawa ae la kona man maka.

To glance, look quickly; glance. ʻAlawa maka (KAM. 64:98), to see at a glance; to diagnose by insight. He ʻalawa nā maka i hope e ʻike i ka poʻe e hele mai ana, the eyes glance back to see the people coming along. hōʻalawa Caus/sim.
A bird (no data).
Canoe course.
Road, highway.

Boulevard, section 30 of Honolulu (map 6), parkway, canal, boat harbor, clubhouse, golf course, playground, field, elementary school, and promenade. The canal was constructed 1919-1928 with funds appropriated for the Waikīkī Reclamation project “to reclaim a most unsanitary and unsightly portion of the city.” See Waikīkī, Waikolu.
Channel, canal.
Dark lines on stomach of a pregnant woman, converging near the navel.
Same as ʻāheahea 2, a shrub.
Same as ʻāheahea 2, a shrub, Niʻihau.
To shriek; shrill. Cf. wī, to squeal. Alawī ka niho no ka paʻakikī i ka hele, [he'll] shriek through the teeth for being so insistent on going.
Upland bird, reported to be the young of the ʻanianiau, and on Kauaʻi, the ʻamakihi.
To hurry; quick, fast. Cf. wiki. Mai lohi mai ʻoe, e alawiki mai, don't be slow, be fast.
To swallow, engulf, gulp, absorb. Huaale, pill.
Hollow or cavern on the sea floor.
An endemic mountain plant (Plantago princeps), 60 cm to 2 m high, rarely branching, stem woody, with long narrow leaves at top; related to the laukahi,
To swallow, in various senses; e moni aku.
When anything disagreeable is to be taken.
To drink in, as water.
To drink in, as the earth drinks water.
To swallow up, as the earth. To absorb; to swallow, as a flood; to destroy.
To overpower, as an army. Ale wale, to swallow without choking.
Ke ale mai, to come up into, as tears into the eyes; as poets say, the tears welled up in her eyes.

Wave, crest of a wave, billow; to ripple, form waves, stir; to well, as tears in the eyes; rippling, stirring. See poale. Many types of billows are listed below. ʻAle lau loa, wave long and large. ʻAle poʻi, breaking wave, ʻAle pā puaʻa, pig-pen wave, of a wave striking the side of a canoe. Ka ʻale wai hau a ke kua, the snow water wave of the gods [it was believed that the gods made snow]. hōʻale caus/sim.; to surge (PH 51).
Gust.
Also are. Are, a unit of measure.
Wave, as a swell in the open ocean. Cf. nalu. See hokua, honua, kiʻekiʻena, kōā.

A wave; a billow put in motion by the wind; a wave of the sea. Aloia mai ai na ale ino o Lao Hao, having escaped the raging billows of Cape Horn; make iho nei ia iloko o ka ale o Pailolo, he was lately drowned in the waves of Pailolo; loi ale no i ke alia o kolo. Fig. Ale o ka make. Holo pipi ka ale o ka moana, the crest of a wave; ka ale, water put in motion; ka ale wai hau a ke ’kua, water of snow of the god.
definitions.notes: Note: It was supposed that the gods made the snow.

definitions.dtxt: Marshy; marsh, swamp.
Pas/imp. of ale 1.
A fish, said to be short for hīnālea, or a kind of hīnālea. Also ālealea.
Area.
Sweet-voiced.
See LEA. Having a pleasant voice for singing; agreeable, as the voice.

definitions.der: [Lit. wave (of) solar fire. Cf. kiko lā, lapa ahi lā, puapuaʻi lā]
definitions.dtxt: Solar granule, i.e., gigantic waves of gas which roll across the surface of the sun.
A swamping wave, as one striking a canoe broadside from prow to stern, See ʻaki 5.
Wounded, pierced; wound, sore. Less common than pōaleale.

Redup. of ʻale 1; stirring, moving, undulating, tossing, rippling, full to the brim. Ā ka wai, ua piha ā ʻaleʻale ke kaʻekaʻe, the water is full, the edge is brimful. hōʻaleʻale To stir up waves, agitate, confuse; to cause tumult.
See hawewe ʻaleʻale.
Land section, south coast, Kahoʻolawe.
A moving, swelling, stirring, as the waves of the sea; as water anywhere.
13th conj. of ale. To make into waves; to stir up. as water; to trouble; to toss about, as restless waters. Aleale ka wai, ua piha a aleale ke keakea. Hoo. To stir up, as water.
A shellfish (Turbo sandwichensis); its shell.
Same as alea 2.
A sharp, white, small shell fish found near the shore; he pupu alealea.
Heiau near Haleokeawe, Hōnaunau, South Kona, Hawaiʻi. This heiau was used for sports and games after Hale-o-Keawe became the major heiau.
Land section, Pāʻia qd., Maui. (HM 19)
Algeria; Algerian. Also ʻAlekelia.
Snare, noose; to snare. Also ʻahele.
A snare; a noose; he ahele, he pahele.
Same as pūlehu, to broil.
Ashes. (FOR. 6:482)
Var. of ʻalaʻihi, a fish.
Large tree of the pine family, cedar, fir.
Arsenic.
Heron.
Heron, general term. See ʻalekuʻu.
Algeria; Algerian. Also ʻAlegeria.
Argentina; Argentine, Argentinean.
Alto.
Alcohol.
Alcohol.
Pool (no longer in existence) in Nuʻuanu Stream, Honolulu. (For a song, see elbert and Mahoe 30-31; UL 108)
Whitecaps, white spray.
Whitecap. See niho.
Long-backed billow.
Algum tree. Biblical.

A later orthography for aleguma; name of a timber tree, as below; name of a tree found in the deserts of Arabia; the algum tree. Also, by a change of letters, alemuga. See below. Supposed by Kitts to be the sandal-wood.
Dashing billow.

Egret, general term. Papapū ka ʻāina mahi kō i ka ʻalekuʻu kau pipi ma hope o ka puhi ʻana i ke kō. The cane field is covered with cattle egrets after the cane is burned. Sh. ʻalekea + ʻaukuʻu. See ʻalekea. ʻAlekuʻu kau pipi. Cattle egret.
See uhi ʻālela, a yam.
Var. of ʻelele, messenger.
A messenger of a chief; an ambassador. See ELELE.
He kiu ka pua kukui;
He alele hooholo na ke Koolau.—Mele.
See LELE and ELELE. A messenger; one sent on business; he alele wau i hoounaia mai nei, I am a messenger sent hither. Laieik. 79. See LUNA.
To go or act as a messenger.
To go or act as a spy.
To look or examine the condition of another. See LELE.
Land area in the approximate center of Kailua, Oʻahu, formerly a plain called kulaoʻālele, a sports area.
To skip, jump, fly.
Tongue, language. Also elelo. Cf. pelu.
Meat of the sea egg or sea urchin (wana), so called because of resemblance to a tongue.
Concave curve of the lower portion of the lei palaoa, whale-tooth pendant, suggestive of a tongue.
Point at the tip of a paddle.
Tongue. Kūʻau alelo. Back of the tongue. Lau alelo. Blade. Mole alelo. root. Waena alelo. Central portion. Wēlau alelo. Tip.
The tongue, of man or animals. See ELELO.
The tongue; he alelo wana ka ono, he ono ke alelo wana, he okulikuli.
A kind of introduced flower (no data).
Party favor.
Coated tongue.
Tongue-tied, paralyzed tongue.
Paralysis of the tongue, believed sometimes caused by a kahuna. Also alelo pehu, alelo pelu, lelo puʻu.
Alma Mater.
Almanac, calendar.
Calendar. ʻAlemanaka puke. Date book, appointment book. Cf. puke ʻalemanaka.
An almanac; the first was published in Hawaiian in 183—.
Ripe.
Precious, as a child.
A bird (no data)
See iki ʻalamea.
Armenia; Armenian.
Almond (Prunus dulcis), hazel tree, almond.
A hazle. The almond tree.
Of an almond.
Same as ʻalekuma.
A lowland perennial weed (Boerhaavia repens), with long, thin, prostrate branches, bearing small leaves and flowers. The swollen roots were used medicinally, acting as a diuretic. Anena on Niʻihau.
Same as kōnane, clear.
Channel between Hawaiʻi and Maui.
Street, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Tower, high lookout, gazebo; towering. ʻAleʻo puhi ʻohe, bandstand. Nā pali ʻaleʻo, towering cliffs.
High; applied to a house or a room; a look-out on a house-top.
Billows that follow one after the other.
Alpha.
Alpha. Huna ʻālepa. Alpha particle, i.e., a positively charged particle made up of two protons and two neutrons.
Alepa, alpha Gr. άλφα; name of the first letter of the Greek alphabet; hence, the first, ka mua.
Albania; Albanian. Also ʻAlabania.
Alphabet.

Old, worn-out, as tapa, mats, clothing; worn-out tapa, clothing; objects of inferior quality. Also pāleuleu. He moku ʻāleuleu, districts of raga-muffins [said of Kaʻū and Puna by Kamehameha’s followers because the farmers worked hard and wore old clothes].
Old kapa or mats; also applied to all kinds of bad kapa.
Aleut; Aleutian. Ka pae ʻāina ʻo ʻAleuta. Aleutian Islands. Ka ʻauwaha ʻo ʻAleuta. Aleutian Trench.
Same as ʻālewalewa.
Drive, playground, and section 9 of Honolulu (map 6).
Buoyant, floating.
A cloud or smoke floating in the atmosphere; hookaa ka punohu ka alewalewa.
Same as aliali.
Scar, depression, groove, imbedded mark. Also ʻeli. Cf. ʻaʻali, ʻālina.
Var. of ʻeli, to dig.
To dig (the ball), in volleyball. See ʻali ʻūlau. Mea ʻali. digger. Also ʻali. ʻAli ʻūlau. Pancake dig.
A scar on the face.
To have a scar on the cheek; ua ali ka papalina i ka mai; to have a scar anywhere.
Hoo. To shake; to wave; to move to and fro, etc. See HOALI.
By and by; after a little.
The name of two sticks carried by a person before the god of the year.
To wait, stop; before; usually as a command: stop! wait a minute! Alia kāu puke, away with your book. Alia wau e ʻae aku (Laie 485), before I agree. hoʻālia To stop, check, restrain, wait.
To wait; to stop one when doing a thing; to restrain.
Used imperatively, stop; wait; applied to a person in the way; take care; stand aside.
Salt bed, salt-encrusted area; salty, brackish. He ālia hoʻohaʻahaʻa paʻakai; loʻi ʻale nō i ke ālia o loko, it is a low salt bed; water comes in to flood the salt bed inside.

Name of two kauila or māmane sticks carried by priests before the makahiki god; also the two crossed spears with upright spear in the center, used as insignia for the present-day Māmakakaua society; small flag or streamer. See ʻAhahui māmakakaua.
A large flat surface where it is white with salt; he alia hoohaahaa paakai; loi ale no i ke alia okolo, salt bed.
A word of similar import with nane and i nane, let us see, show it to me, etc.; as aliane. referring to something spoken of, let us see; let me see.
White, as snow or paper; he wai aliali, he keokeo; he huali.
Crystal clear, white; clarity, whiteness. Also aniani. hoāliali To whiten, cause to shine.
Redup. of ʻali 1; scarred, grooved; profound, Cf. ʻeliʻeli. E ʻaliʻali kapu, e ʻaliʻali noa (Kep. 184), profound the taboo, profound the release to freedom. hōʻaliʻali To scar, deface.
Ua aliali, to have scars; to be rough with scars; to be scarred; ua kalikali, kokoke e piha; ukali ae no hoi; hulihuli.
He alialia paakai, a bed where salt is dried; he alialia manu; na alialia o na wai puna huihui. See ALIA above.
Ground which is smooth, dry and barren, as that which is baked in the sun, or covered with salt.

example_txt.txt: He ālialia paʻakai, he ālialia manu, nā ālialia o nā waipuna huʻihuʻi.
It is a salt bed, a salt bed for birds, salt-encrusted places with cool springs.

definitions.dtxt: Same as ālia.
Marsh, with salt or brackish water and no trees. See nāele, ʻolokele.

Schools, playground, and crater near Salt Lake, Honolulu. (The goddess Pele and her family lived here once. When they left, Pele dropped some salt, and the pet bird of Hiʻiaka, Pele’s favorite sister, escaped. Birds gathered here.)
Same as ʻoliana, let me see.

Salt Lake, Oʻahu, said to have been dug by Pele on her first circuit of the islands. Some of the viscid matter from her eyes dropped and formed salt. Hawaiians believed that the lake was connected to the sea by a hole in the center of the lake. (Ka Nupepa Kuokoa, March 28, 1874)
Aldrin, a kind of insecticide. Cf. dielidirina. See lāʻau make.
Unwillingly.
H inserted; a captain of a company. Alihi kaua, a general.
To be ready to work for the sake of gain, but at other times absent.

Cords or fine ropes threaded through marginal meshes of upper and lower edges of nets, to which were attached floats and sinkers; loops at the top of a kōkō net holding a calabash. See below and ʻupena ʻalihi.
Horizon (sometimes qualified by lani or moana). Cf. lihi, edge.
Deceit, trickery; to deceive, cheat. (AP)
See ʻalihikūlele.
General, commander in battle, strategist.
Alihi (alii) and kaua, war. A general; commander; one who directs in battle.
Commander in chief.
Lower cord in a net to which lead sinkers were attached.
Quarterback, in football. Sh. ʻalihikaua + kūlele. Also ʻalihi.
The horizon.
Dragnet, mullet net.
Name of a drag-net; the net for taking the anae.
Line for lashing down the paūʻū mat covering of a canoe.
Upper cord in a net to which floats were attached.
Lower cord in a net to which stone sinkers were attached.
The lines of a fish net; o ke kaula ma ka pikoni.
The cords holding the sinkers of a net.

The upper part of a calabash strap; he alihi no ke koko o ka umeke; o ka alihi maluna o ka waa e kalai hou a haahaa ka niao o ka alihi maluna o ka umeke; ma ka alihi moana, e pili aku ana i kumu lani, at the edge of the ocean, i.e., where the ocean and sky meet. D. Malo 5:13.
Name of a hard timber tree, used for posts of houses and other purposes; also called aalii.

Chief, chiefess, officer, ruler, monarch, peer, headman, noble, aristocrat, king, queen, commander; royal, regal, aristocratic, kingly; to rule or act as a chief, govern, reign; to become a chief. Fig. kind (see naʻau aliʻi, ʻōpū aliʻi).

example_txt.txt: his chief (controlled directly or raised by him)
Ua lilo ia i aliʻi no Kauaʻi ia wā, ā malalo mai ona nā kānaka o kauaʻi, pēlā i aliʻi ai ʻo Makaliʻi.
He then became chief of Kauaʻi, with the people of Kauaʻi beneath him, thus Makaliʻi became chief.
Ua hoʻāliʻi aku ʻoia i kāna kāne.
She treats her husband like a king.

definitions.dtxt: To make a chief, establish royalty in office; to imitate royalty; to treat as royalty; regal, royal, kingly; to be made an officer, be commissioned.
Fishpond, Kaunakakai qd., south Molokaʻi. Surfing beach, Haleʻiwa, Oʻahu, used by oceanic Foundation for experimentation.
A chief; one who rules or has authority over other men; a king, qualified by various epithets.
Ke alii moi, the supreme executive.
Ke alii aimoku, a chief over a division, i.e., a governor under the alii moi.
Alii koa, a chief over soldiers, i.e., a general, leader of an army.
Alii okana, chief of a district.
Mea noho alii, a ruler. Alii weliweli, king of terrors.
To act the chief; to be chief or principal. To rule over men. To govern.
Hoo. To crown one a king; to make one a king; to make one’s self a king; to rule; to have power or influence with.
Chief who rules a moku (district)
Archangel.
Presiding officer, ruling officer; chairman, viceroy.
Male chief, king; husband (polite, not said of one’s own husband or to him). pehea kāu aliʻi kāne? How is your noble husband?
Former heiau, Kahaluʻu, Oʻahu. (Sterling and Summers 5: 82a.)
A general of an army.
Military officer, officer of army or navy.
Commissioned officer.
Warrant officer.
Power behind the throne.
Independent chief, aristocrat.
True chief, commissioned officer (old term).
Same as Kealiʻiokonaikalewa.

Elementary school, Kaimukī, Honolulu, and judiciary building, downtown Honolulu, constructed 1871-1874; both were named for Kamehameha V. This was one of his names, probably a contraction of Aliʻiiōlani, chief unto heavens (one of heavenly repute). (Kuy2:174-175)
Non-commissioned officer, petty officer (old term).
Name of a child where the mother was a chief and the father not.
Offspring of a high chiefess and commoner (or lesser chief) father. Cf. papa aliʻi.

The ornamental cannas (Canna indica, forms and hybrids), large tropical american herbs, with large oval or narrow leaves and large red or red and yellow flowers. The round black seeds are worn in leis and are also placed in fruit shells of the laʻamia for hula rattles. Cannas are both cultivated and wild in Hawaiʻi. Also liʻipoe.
Lesser chiefs who served other chiefs. Cf. kauā.
An exalted chief (probably from pūʻōʻā, tower). (FOR. 6:303)
Boatswain.
Alii and wahine, woman. A Queen.
Chiefess, queen; wife (polite, not said of one’s own wife or to her).

definitions.der: [Lit. Alec (named for Alec Dowsett, grandson of Samuel Dowsett; see Dowsett)]
definitions.dtxt: Avenue, Dowsett Highlands, Honolulu.
Volcanic cone (7,843 feet), Mauna Loa qd., Hawaiʻi, now called ʻĀlika. Probably.
Arctic. Aia i ʻĀlika ku ihu o ka moku (song), the prow of the ship turns to the Arctic.
Arctic.
Clammy, sticky, tenacious, tough. Fig. Stingy. Cf. lina, linalina, nina, ninanina, ʻūlika, ʻūlikalika.
Clammy; sticky; tough, as kalo baked; as mud.
Stingy; not liberal.
Alike (often repeated: ʻālike ʻālike, like ʻālike, alike, just alike, identical, equally, midway. E hiamoe ana ke keiki ā hiki ʻālike ʻālike o ka pō, the child slept until the middle of the night).
Identical, matching. Nā hapa ʻālike. Identical parts. Mana ʻālike. concurrent power, as powers shared by federal and state governments.
See LIKE. One-half; an equal division of a thing.
Alligator.

Symmetry; symmetric, symmetrical, in math. Redup. of ʻālike. Kaha ʻālikelike. Line of symmetry, a line on which a figure can be folded so the two parts fit exactly, in math. Kinona ʻālikelike. Symmetric figure. ʻĀlikelike aka. reflection symmetry. ʻĀlikelike kau. Translation symmetry. ʻĀlikelike wili. rotational symmetry.
To tighten, tie tightly. hoʻālikiliki Caus/sim. Cf. liki 2.
See LIKI; see OPUOHAO.
To be swelled tight as the skin can hold, as in the dropsy.
To be girded tightly.
Artichoke.
Arizona; Arizonan, Arizonian. Also ʻArizona.
The common turbo shell (Turbo sandwichensis).
Same as hoʻolili, sparkling.
Alima hea ko alakai,
Ke ani peahi la ia Limaloa.
I hoapili no manu a kepa ka ua—he.
See AULIMA, the stick held in the hand in rubbing to obtain fire.
Five (especially in counting in a series); five times. Pōʻalima, Friday.
Five; the number five. See LIMA.
Arithmetic.
A low servant; a slave.
Low; degraded.
Scar, blemish; scarred, disfigured, injured, maimed (FS 93) (preceded by ke). Fig. Low, disgraced, degraded, dishonored. Kau ke ʻālina (FS 93), blemished. ua ʻālina ka inoa, the name is dishonored.
Scar (preceded by ke). Also ninanina.

To be defiled or contaminated, as by marrying one of low birth; mai moe oukou i ka poe keiki a ka poe kauwa, o alina auanei ka oukou mau keiki; applied to a chief who married a low woman and had children of low order; alina oe i kou mare ana i kau kauwa.
To be scarred, as one burned badly; to be scarred by scrofula; ua alina oe i ke ahi.
To have spots or blemishes on one’s person.
Morally, to be disgraced or implicated in sin.
To be filthy, as food; ua alina loa o Mea; ua alina ka kakou, ua makole.
Limpet (Cellana sandwichensis).
A shell fish of the sea; the young or small of the opihi.
A mark; a sign; nearly SYN. with hoailona.
Corrompu; dégradé; mésalliance.
Stream and land section, Kawaihau district, Kauaʻi.
Longtemps.
A long time.
Alley-oop, a basketball play. E kakali wale ana ʻo Loa i ke kīloi ʻia mai i hiki ai iā ia ke ʻaliupa. Loa was just waiting to be passed the ball so that he could make the alley-oop play.
The front; the face; the presence of one. Ma ke alo, before; in front.
The breast or belly. Ua hiki mai i ko’u alo nei, it has come to my front, i.e.,to me; ma kona alo iho, directly in front of him. Ma ke alo alii, persons living with and in the favor of the chief.
The name of a four-footed animal in the sea.
Front, face, presence; upper surface, as of a bowl; leeward. Cf. ʻaialo, aloaliʻi, pali. (Alo refers to a wife: cf. pilialo.)

example_txt.txt: the favorite grandchild, a grandchild reared by grandparents
Eia ʻoe i ke alo o ka ʻaha.
Here you are in the presence of the assembly.
Ua laupaʻi koʻu alo i nā moʻopuna.
I have many grandchildren with me here.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
Face, as one side of a space figure, in math. See kāʻei alo, pale alo and entries under ʻōpaka.

example_txt.txt: opposite leg or side of a right triangle

definitions.dtxt: To dodge, evade, elude, avoid. ʻAlo ʻana, dodging, avoidance, oversight, omission. ʻAʻole e hiki ke alo aʻe, it canʻt be helped. hōʻalo To shun, dodge, avoid, escape, omit, skip; omission; to alternate or place irregularly, as strips of thatch (FOR. 5:651).

To be with, come near, go with, attend, escort, accompany, share an experience, endure, resist. Kuʻu hoa ʻalo i ke anu, my companion who shared the cold. Kū ana ʻo Mauna Loa, kuahiwi ʻalo ehuehu (song), stands Mauna Loa, mountain that resists storms. E ʻalo aʻe ʻoe iā mākou ā hiki aku i Molokaʻi (FS 267), escort us to Molokaʻi.
To elude or dodge the stroke of a weapon.
To pass over from one place to another; ua alo aku nei na kaulua i na kumu i molokai.
To skip or pass over something; e alo i kekahi la, e hana i kekahi la.
To pass through the water by swimming; to extend the hands in swimming.
To set one’s self against; to be opposed to; e alo ia ia, to face him; to turn and front him.
To meet some difficulty or resisting force or opposition; ua nui ka makou hana i ke alo ana me na haku i ka maka o ke kaua, we have much work to do in resisting with our masters the front of the war.
To resist boldly, as a difficulty; face, as an enemy in danger. E alo i na ino a pau e hiki mai ana e like me kaua i alo hoomanawanui ai i ka la o ka makalii.
To double, as a cape; e aloia mai ai na ale o Lae Hao.
To face; to be against. To resist.
To consume; devour.
Hoo. To pass away; forget.
To shun; eschew.
Same as makaʻāloa, a crab.
Name recorded for olonā fiber.
To lengthen, enlarge.
Emotional stress.
In the presence of chiefs; royal court.
All kinds of hibiscus, including the native white hibiscus (Hibiscus arnottianus); often called pua aloalo, pualoalo.

example_txt.txt: Hibiscus, an introduced variety with red double flowers 8 cm. wide or less
Hibiscus mutabilis, during the day flowers changed from white to pink or red. Formerly the blossoms were used as laxatives.

definitions.notes: Note: A law was passed in 1923 making the aloalo the flower of the Territory of Hawaiʻi.

definitions.dtxt: Squilla (Pseudosquilla ciliata, Lysiosquilla maculata), highly desired as food. Also Squilla sp.
Loved and served by many persons, as a chief or favorite child; esteemed. Cf. alo.

chants.chtran: His title is Prince of Hawaiʻi, child of Keʻelikōlani, mine, born with many to serve and love [him]
chants.chtxt: Haku o Hawaiʻi he inoa, hānau aloalo aʻu a Keʻelikōlani

definitions.dtxt: Tapa made from māmaki mixed with wauke. (KAM. 76:115)
To go after, as a servant; to bring things; to wait on; he ai puupuu, he poi puupuu.
Redup. of ʻalo 1; to dodge rapidly or continuously; to look about slyly; evasive. hōʻalo.ʻalo Caus/sim. ʻŌlelo hōʻaloʻalo. Excuse, pretext.
Redup. of ʻalo 2; one who follows, escorts, accompanies.

chants.chtran: I am one who follows rainfall in the Koʻolau [mountains].
chants.chtxt: He ʻaloʻalo ua au no ke Koʻolau.

definitions.dtxt: Lumpy, as poi,
A kind of small inshore fish (no data).
Double form, of alo. To turn this way and that; to look one way and another, as if in fear, or about to do mischief. Aloalo na maka o ka aihue.
See ALO. To dodge; to flee from, as a shower, i.e., to run from one tree to another; aloalo ua, aloalo makani, kipakipa, pukauhale, to dodge the rain, etc.
Far, at a distance. hoʻāloa. loa To keep at a distance.
Same as hāloʻaloʻa, turbulent, rough.
Pitted, as rocks. Also loʻaloʻa.
Var. spelling of ʻalolio.
Private land. Also ʻalokio. Cf. ʻāina no ka lehulehu.
Variant spelling of ʻalokio.
Aloe, any plant of the genus Aloe; also the pānini ʻawaʻawa.
Aloes. Mel.

Aloha, love, affection, compassion, mercy, sympathy, pity, kindness, sentiment, grace, charity; greeting, salutation, regards; sweetheart, lover, loved one; beloved, loving, kind, compassionate, charitable, lovable; to love, be fond of; to show kindness, mercy, pity, charity, affection; to venerate; to remember with affection; to greet, hail. Greetings! Hello! Good-bye! Farewell! Alas! The common greetings follow. Cf. aloha ʻāina, hanaaloha.

example_txt.txt: May you be loved or greeted, greetings (to one person).
May there be friendship or love between us, greetings (to one person); dear Sir.
Same as above, but to more than one person.
Greetings! (The nō may be prolonged for emphasis.) (Gram. 4.6)
What a pity! Alas! [Expression of regret, either great or small.]
love of god; divine love, pity, charity
considerate and thoughtful of parents and elders, filial
with the love (or greeting) of Kawena
ʻO wau iho nō me ke aloha.
I remain, with very best regards.
Aloha ʻoe, ē Maria, ua piha ʻoe i ka maikaʻi.
Ē Maria hemolele, e aloha mai ʻoe iā mākou.
Holy Mary, have mercy on us.
E aloha aku au i ka mea aʻu e manaʻo ai e aloha aku.
I show mercy to those I want to show mercy to.
Aloha nō ia mau lā o nā makahiki he kanalima i kūnewa akula!
Affectionate [memories] of these days of fifty years past!

chants.chtran: We remember fondly the footprints of the king.
chants.chtxt: Aloha aʻe ana mākou i ke ehu wāwae o ka lani.

definitions.dtxt: Rare var. of hoʻālohaloha. Cf. hoaloha.
Kinipōpō aloha. Aloha ball, in volleyball.
A word expressing different feelings; as, love; affection; gratitude; kindness; pity; compassion; grief; the modern common salutation at meeting and parting.
Loving; beloved; favored.
To love; to regard with affection; to desire.
To have pity or compassion upon.
To show mercy; to be merciful as a habit. To spare; to pity.
To salute at meeting or parting.
definitions.notes: Note: Aloha, as a word of salutation, is modern; the ancient forms were anoai, welina, etc.

definitions.dtxt: To salute contemptuously; aloha ino kaua, alas for us two.
Hoo. To give thanks as an act of worship.

Love of the land or of one’s couentry, patriotism; the name of a Hawaiian-language newspaper published 1893–1920; aloha ʻāina is a very old concept, to judge from the many sayings (perhaps thousands) illustrating deep love of the land. (Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini 268–9) Cf. the song Kaulana nā Pua (Elbert and mahoe 62–4).
Nationalism, patriotism.

example_txt.txt: Na ka poʻe aloha ʻāina Hawaiʻi i kākoʻo ka mōʻī.

definitions.dtxt: Brotherhood.
Bible spelling of aloha ai.
A verbal from the verb aloha above used as a noun. Favor; kindness; loaa ia ia ke alohaia mai, he obtained favor; favor; good will.
Aloha and ino. An intentive; it expresses great love, pity or compassion for a person in a suffering condition. It is also used by way of contempt, as poor fellow! good, enough for you!
See aloha.
Redup. of aloha (less used than hōʻālohaloha).
To make love, express affection, gratitude or compassion; expression of love or affection (FS 93); to give thanks; friendly, loving, lovable.
To love much.
Hoo. To give thanks; to express affection for; to bless in worship.
To salute.
To speak kindly to; to entreat gently.
Name given to the kāmole plant used in hana aloha sorcery.
See aloha.
Pitiless, merciless, ungrateful, without love or affection.
To shine, glitter, sparkle; bright, brilliant; splendor, brilliancy. ʻAlohi e like me ka lā i ke awakea, bright as the sun at noon. Ke ʻalohi kea o ke ano kakahiaka, the white light of morning,
A bright shining; brightness; splendor.
To shine; to become shining or bright; to reflect brightness. Alohi e like me ka la i ke awakea. Fig. To shine, as Christian character.
Pas/imp. of ʻalo.
Families united by marriage, in-laws.
Brightness of heaven, a term applied to the heavenly courts of the goddesses uli and Kapo.

Redup. of ʻalohi; radiant. Maka ʻālohilohi, eyes bright and sparkling, blue or light brown eyes. Ka haole nui maka ʻālohilohi, ē Kama lepo puaʻa (FS 201), big stranger with bright eyes, O Kama with excreta of a pig [said to the pig-god, kamapuaʻa].
Splendor; brightness. Light. Sparkling, as the eye; ka inoa he akua i ke alohilohi o na maka, I thought they were gods by the brightness of their eyes.
Malamalama alohilohi, bright light.
To shine brightly. To shine, as light.
Double jeopardy, i.e., to be tried in court twice for the same offense. Lit. endure two court cases.
Same as ʻāloʻiloʻi.

Crater active in 1969 and 1970, Puna qd., Hawaiʻi, perhaps named for Kahawali’s pig, ʻĀloʻipuaʻa. Kahawali, an expert in hula and hōlua riding, refused to race an unknown woman. She was Pele, and in the form of fire she chased him toward the sea. he fled to Puʻukea hill (Waikiʻi qd.), said goodbye to his wife and children and his favorite pig, and escaped from Pele in a canoe. See Kahōluaokahawali.
Mud puddle, pool. Cf. loʻi.

example_txt.txt: He ʻāloʻiloʻi ka iʻa waha iki o ke kai.
A damsel, small-mouthed fish of the sea [one with little to say].

definitions.dtxt: A damselfish (Dascyllus albisella). Also loʻiloʻi. The young stage is ʻā or ʻaʻā.
Humble.

chants.chtran: Standing humbly in the house of the god.
chants.chtxt: Kū ʻāloʻiloʻi i ka hale o ke akua.

definitions.dtxt: Same as loʻiloʻi 1.
A species of small fish.
Single weft in plaiting; mat of a single thickness, with only one shiny side. cf. alolua.
Attractive, of fine appearance. Alokele ke ʻike aku i ke alo o ia kuahiwi (hula song), a pleasure to see the face of that mountain.
A red bird reported by Kepelino (no data).
Alodial title, alodium, fee simple.

example_txt.txt: kuleana malalo o ke ʻano ʻalokio
ʻalolio i ke ʻano ʻae like

definitions.dtxt: Private land. Also ʻalodio. Cf. ʻāina no ka lehulehu.
See limu alolio.
Exclamation of triumph at the ills of another, as the fall of an enemy. See lOLO.
Same as ʻaikola.
Two-sided, two-faced; facing one another, as cliffs on opposite sides of a valley.
Double weft in plaiting; plaiting with a reversible side, with two thicknesses. Cf. alokahi.
Two-sided; double-faced; applied to men and things; moena alolua, a double mat, having two faced sides.
Aroma.
Shiftless, dependent on others for a livelihood, Cf. lōpā.
Fox.
A fox Gr. αλεπού.
Arctic fox. Also ʻalopeka ʻĀlika.
Persons shouting, as in mourning. Ua hiki aku i ke alopihe, went to the lamenting people.
Alo and pihe, the sound of mourning as it floats in the air.
Belly of a fish, choice to Hawaiians.
Rainy side, as of a mountain.
See mākala ʻūhā.
Combined; acting together; he man ilio alu i ka hakaka.
To combine, as several persons in aiding another either in a good or bad cause.
To give aid or assistance. To help, as in quarrels where one is likely to be killed and several aid in effecting his escape.
To unite together, as several persons for a particular object.
To be connected, as the joints of the human body.
To adhere to; to act with; e alu aku mahope; make o Manono no ka nui o kona aluia, Manono died for the strength of her adherence to him.
Combined, acting together; to cooperate, act together.

example_txt.txt: E alu, e alu, e kui lima!
E alu ka pule iā Hakalau.
he mau ʻīlio alu i ka hākākā

definitions.dtxt: Drive, as for cans; to conduct a drive.

Depression, gutter, ravine; lines of the hand, loose skin over the eyeball; tuck in a garment, shirring, ruffling; descent, as of trail or road; of low rank (Kep. 125); to bend, duck, hang, sag, slacken, stoop; to relax; to ruff, as a mat. cf. pūʻalu.

example_txt.txt: tuck creaser, of a sewing machine
to make tucks, shirring; tucker on a sewing machine
Wela ka hao, ʻalu ka uwea.
The iron is hot, bend the wire [now is the time for fun, a saying originating at the Honolulu Iron Works].
Ua ʻalu ihola ka paniolo e lālau i ka pūʻolo.
The cowboy leaned down to pick up the package.

definitions.dtxt: To slacken, loosen, hang down, bend down, stoop; depression, slack.
Lax, as articulation, in linguistics. Cf. mālō.
Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
The lines of the hand.
A gutter; a ravine; kahawai awawa; a road descending a hill.
A courtesy.
The muscles of the eye.
The skin and soft parts of men, fish, and all animals, when the bones are taken out. See ALUALU.
A name given to women who have borne children. See ALUALU.
To relax; hang down; be weak.
To bend the knees; to courtesy.
To stoop down, as in entering a low door; to stoop down, as in hiding behind a low object; alu ae la maua e pee ana. Laieik. 207.
To ruff up, as a mat; ua alu na moena i ka nakuia.
Hoo. To loosen, as the tongue.

A word signifying admiration; it applies to what is good, great, admired, etc.; the a is often dropped; as, aohe ona lua, there is none like him. See LUA. Ka inoa o ka ona no kona waiwai (iho,) o ka mahuna alua, surely drunkenness (by awa) has its own reward, the wonderful scaling of the skin. Laieik. 35.
Two, twice. Pōʻalua, Tuesday; Lit. second day. ʻAlua aʻu hele ʻana i kēlā wahi, I’ve been to that place twice.
The number two; two. See LUA.
Old, worn-out, faded, dilapidated; old and wrinkled, as a person.
To follow, pursue, chase; to run, as for political office. Alualu loloa, to run after persistently. hoʻālualu Caus/sim.
Alu, doubled; 13th conj. of alu. To come upon one.
To follow; pursue; overpower.
To pursue, as an enemy.
To chase.
To persecute.
To be wrinkled, as the cheeks and forehead of old persons.

Loose, flabby; misshapen, as a premature baby; slack, as a rope; to sag; wrinkled, uneven, rough, lined; foetus; skin, rind, peel. Hua ʻaluʻalu, egg with very soft shell. Keiki ʻaluʻalu, premature baby. Pala ʻaluʻalu ka ʻai a kamaliʻi, mostly peel when matured are the food crops of children [infants are not strong enough to make good farmers]. hōʻaluʻalu To slacken, loosen; to make gathers, as in a skirt; a gatherer, as on sewing machines; yielding, loose, flexible, soft.
Bark, of a plant; skin. Niʻihau. Also ʻili.
The flexible skin or hide of an animal; he alualu bipi.
The soft parts of flesh when the bones are taken out; the appearance is flabby, loose and wrinkled, etc.
The fetus of animals or men; kanuia ka alualu i ka lepo, the fetus was buried in the dust.
The skins, rinds and refuse of melons after the substance is eaten; ua aiia na ipu, a o ka alualu wale no koe.
Loose; flabby; premature; shapeless, as an untimely birth. Laieik. 12. slack, as a rope or string.
Uneven; rough; full of lines.
He ili alualu, a loose skin; applied to an untimely birth; he keiki alualu, ua like me ka iewe ke ano, an imperfect child, like a placenta.
A crack, as in the wall of a house.
A rough road, full of ravines and difficult passes; he alualu inoino ke alanui e hele ai i Kahakuloa.
A second-hand garment, full of wrinkles.
The name given to the numeration table, beginning thus: elua lua aha, two twos are four; ma ke alualua ko lakou ao ana i ka helu, through the multiplication table they learn arithmetic.
Rough, bumpy, as a road; full of knotholes, as a board; pitted with holes, as a reef. Cf. lua, hole.
Multiplication tables.
Papa ʻālualua. Multiplication tables. See ʻālualua.
Rock islet (0.14 acres, 40 feet elevation), Keʻanae qd., East Maui.
Loose, as a bundle not securely tied; flabby, ill-fitting, loose-jointed.
Loose, as a bundle not well bound; banging flabbily.

Crowd, heap; mixed, crowded, heaped. ʻĀluka moku, group of irregular-lying islands. ʻĀluka ka pala a ka ʻōhiʻa, mountain apples ripen everywhere. Kaua ʻāluka (FOR. 5:151), widespread war. hoʻāluka Caus/sim.; to bring together, collect.
The uniting or mixing together of things of different or opposite qualities; ke aluka o ka hewa o ka pono.
To jumble together, as parts of two stories.
To mix together, as contributions for different purposes, or different taxes.
To mix together, so as not to distinguish.
Hoo. To cause a mixture, as above; e ao. o hoa’uka i ka waiwai hookupu; similar to huikai.
To destroy; destructive.
Bay, Kailua qd., North Kona, Hawaiʻi.
