An endemic member of the lobelia family (Brighamia spp.), presently known only on Molokaʻi and Kauaʻi, believed extinct on Maui and Niʻihau, an unbranched, succulent, thick-stemmed perennial about 1.5 m high, topped with a rosette of large oval leaves and racemes of long, white, fragrant flowers. Also hāhā. see pua ʻala, ʻōlulu.
To incline the head, sway.
To turn the head on one side; he aluli ke poo, he kekee.
See alu.
Quickly, hastily (used after hele, hana, holo, holoholo, hopuhopu). Holo hopuhopu ālulu mākou, we grabbed and fled in great haste.
Quick; in a hurry; he hopuhopu alulu kona hele ana no ka lohe ana he make.
Quickly; hastily; holo hopuhopu alulu aku la makou a ee maluna o ka waa.
Paupière.
Aluminum.
A, the jaw, and luna, upper, over. The upper part of the mouth of a person; of the bill of birds; of the mouth of animals. Laieik. 104. The roof of the mouth. The upper jaw.
Descent, loosening, slackening, stooping. See ʻalu 1.
See palena ʻāluna o ka hewa.
Late afternoon or early evening.
Early afternoon (FOR. 6:379)
Tromper, surfaire, extorquer; fraude, escroquerie, tromperie.
Greedy, covetous, rapacious; greed, greedy person. Also ʻanunu.
Oppression. Usury. Extortion; covetousness. he alunu, an extortioner.
Covetous; greedy of gain; waiwai alunu, property unlawfully taken. Waiwai alunu is also lucre. Alunu is opposed to lokomaikai.
See LUNU. To defraud. To be overbearing in a bargain. To oppress; to be hard upon one.
To accuse falsely.
To be desirous of possessing property.
A strong desire to take what is another’s; extortion; robbery.
Ante meridium, a.m. (pronounced ʻāmū). See p.m.
AM, amplitude modulation (pronounced ʻāmū). Cf. FM. See ʻanini laulā hawewe.

To offer to the gods ohias and melons; mostly found in the conj. haa and hoo; as, hoama, haama, etc.; haama ka ohia; haama i ka ipuhaole; akahi no a haama ae i ka ipu aimaka. See AMAMA, to offer, etc.
Outrigger float; port hull of a double canoe, so called because it replaces the float. Also iama.
Port or left side of a double-hulled canoe or a ship when looking forward. Cf. ʻākea, muku.
The longitudinal stick of the outrigger of a canoe.
Talkative, prattling, tattling. Cf. ʻaʻama. He waha ʻama iā haʻi, a mouth prattling about others.
Light, bright. (Kep. 25) Cf. māʻamaʻama.
Young ʻamaʻama fish, usually called pua ʻama.
Satisfied; satiated, as with food.
Talkative; revealing secrets; tattling; he ahiahi; he waha ama ia hai, a mouth revealing to others. See AMAAMA.
Slanderous, as the mouth of one ever ready to speak evil; he waha amaama, ka leleoi, ka waha hikiwawe i ke kamailio ma na olelo i manaoia e huna.
See AMA 2. To reveal secrets; to tell another’s faults; to slander; amaama ka waha i ka hai i ka hewa o ka mea e.

Mullet (Mugil cephalus), a very choice indigenous fish. Stages are (finger length) pua ʻama, pua ʻamaʻama, pua poʻolā, ʻoʻolā; (hand length) kahaha (or pahaha); (20 cm) ʻamaʻama; (30 cm or more) ʻanae. Fig. An easy mark (modern slang). see ʻōpele 2.

example_txt.txt: Donʻt strive for the ʻamaʻama fish! [be satisfied with what you have, why look for a rich person?]

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻama 1, 2.
A species of fish; young mullet perhaps.
Ama, satisfied with food, and amau, still.
To eat much; to be satisfied with food; e ai nui i ka ai me ka amaamau.
To eat quickly or fast, as one who is hungry and has a keen appetite.
In rapid succession. Cf. maʻamau. ʻĀmaʻamau ka holo o nā kaʻa, the cars followed one behind the other very quickly.
In rapid succession.
Poisson.
See AMIKA, to desire food. To desire food, as we say, his mouth waters for it.
To have a desire for that which cannot be obtained.
To cause death, defeat.

example_txt.txt: sour ʻamakihi [person with a sour disposition]

definitions.dtxt: A group of small endemic Hawaiian honey creepers, Loxops virens; abundant on Hawaiʻi (L. v. v.), Maui (L. v. wilsoni), and Kauaʻi, uncommon on Oʻahu (L. v. chloris) and Molokaʻi, rare on Lānaʻi. The feathers are yellow and greenish, and were formerly used in feather capes. The Kauaʻi form was also called alawī kihi.
Name of a small yellow bird; he manu hulu lenalena ia.
A species of small bird.
Armadillo.
Armorer, blacksmith.
Stream, Lahaina qd., West Maui.

Finished, of a pre-Christian prayer (said almost at the end of a prayer); to finish a prayer, to pray and sacrifice. ʻAmama, ua noa, the prayer is said, the taboo is over. Ua ʻāmama aku ʻo ʻUmi i ke kino o Hākau i mua o Kāʻili, kona akua, ʻUmi offered the body of Hākau in sacrifice to Kāʻili, his god.
The offering of a sacrifice; ka amama ana i ke kanaka i ke akua.
Conj. 9th of ama, to offer, etc. To give over to the gods in sacrifice.

To offer sacrifice as an act of worship. O ke kino uhane ole e waiho ana, amama ae la ke alii, the body lying without life the king offered in sacrifice; ua amamaia aku la i kona akua ia Kaili, he was sacrificed to his god kaili; to offer prayers; amama, ua noa, like our term Amen to a prayer. Laieik. 104.

Y-shaped crosspiece at the end of a pole (as of a lāʻau kia); horizontal line on an upright; branches of a tree in the form of a Y; gallows; T-shaped; shaft of an octopus lure (KAM. 76:68). Cf. keʻa, koʻokoʻo ʻāmana, noho ʻāmana, peʻa, and mana, branch.
Kuʻi ʻāmana. To bump (the ball), in volleyball.
Two sticks crossing each other at oblique angles.
The branches of a tree in the form of the letter Y.
Amana mau ke kani ana o ka pu; amana mau ke kani o ka pu a ka anela.
Crossing; put together in the form of a cross or gallows; na laau amana kauia’i o Kuhama; he aleo kahi hale, he amana kekahi hale.
Dichotomous key.

Bronchus, bronchiole; bronchial. Comb. ʻāmana + puʻu. ʻĀmanapuʻu kuamua. primary bronchus. ʻĀmanapuʻu kualua. Secondary bronchus, lobar bronchus. Āmanapuʻu kuakolu. Tertiary bronchus, segmental bronchus. ʻĀmanapuʻu kuahope. Terminal bronchiole.
The Hawaiian orthography for the word armorer; a blacksmith.
definitions.notes: Note: The first ships that visited the islands were ships of war or of discovery, and their blacksmiths were called armorers; hence the word.

definitions.dtxt: Amazon. Ka muliwai ʻo ʻAmasona. Amazon river.
To hush up; to keep one from speaking or complaining; ua amau aku au e noho malie, aole pono e pane mai. See HAMAU.

All species of an endemic genus of ferns (Sadleria), with trunk more or less evident. The fronds are narrower, smaller, and less divided than those of the hāpuʻu. At least one species has at the top of the trunk a mass of soft scales (pulu) used as pillow stuffing. Formerly, in times of famine, the tasteless pith of the trunk was cooked and eaten. The fronds were used to mulch dry-land taro, the stems for plaiting and as sizing for tapa. The ʻamaʻu was one of the forms that kamapuaʻa, the pig god, could take at will. Also maʻumaʻu, maʻu. See maʻumaʻu.
Place where ʻamaʻu ferns are found.
Street, Kāhala, Honolulu. (TM)

Oʻahu thrush (Phaeornis obscurus oahuensis), dusky, olive-brown above, ashy-gray beneath, endemic, presumed extinct, with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (ōmaʻo), lānaʻi (olomaʻo), Molokaʻi (olomaʻo), and Kauaʻi.
A species of small bird.
The fern; the brake.
A god growing among the ferns on the mountains; i na ’kua amaumau o ke kula.
Similar to maumau 1.

chants.chtran: Gusts blow steadily.
chants.chtxt: Ke amaumau aʻela i nā kīkīao.

definitions.dtxt: Young ʻamaʻu ferns; many ʻamaʻu ferns, ferny, abounding in ʻamaʻu ferns; a covering of ʻamaʻu ferns (preceded by ke). (FS 215)
Section in the town of Hilo, Hawaiʻi.
And (sometimes written ame). (Gram. 11.1)
Amethyst.
Amethyst.
America; American.
America; American. See entries below.
North America, North American.
North America; North American.
South America, South American.
South America; South American.
United States of America, American.
United States of America; American.
Central America, Central American.
Central America, Latin America; Central American, Latin American.
Amen; to say amen.
Ka amene, an epithet of Jesus Christ as a true and faithful Savior.
Amen; so be it; truly; pela no.
Armenia.
Amber.
An amethyst Gr. αμέθυστος; a precious stone. also,
Hinge, joint; to turn on hinges. Ihu ʻami, nose with irregularly shaped bridge.
A hula step with hip revolutions; to do this step. Three types are ʻami kāhela, ʻami kūkū, and ʻami ʻōniu. See also ʻami honua, ʻami kuʻupau, ʻami ʻōpū, and ʻami poepoe.
Measuring worm.
Hinge. ʻAmi puka. Door hinge. Also ʻami ʻīpuka.
A hinge; a butt for a door.
A joint of a war harness. Joint of an animal. Joint of a limb.
A small worm which, in crawling, doubles itself up; he peelua kuapuu.
A swinging, pendulous motion.
The name of a long slim fish; he ia kino oeoe.

To turn, as upon hinges; as a door; as the lid of a chest, etc.; to move back and forwards; to make any motion back and forth; to swing back and forth, as a gate; to move up and down, as the chin in eating.
Redup. of ʻami 1, 2; elastic, pendulous, springy; jerking of the hips back and forth in a crude or vulgar ʻami hula; motion of sexual intercourse; to move on hinges.
Elastic; pendulous.
A term used to reproach one just married; ka amiami ana o ka puaa.
Same as ʻāwihiwihi.
Exaggerated and rapid revolving of the hips in the hula; to do so. Also ʻami kuʻupau.
Joint.
Ball-and-socket joint.
Similar to ʻami kuʻupau. See hue 3.
Same as ʻāmikamika.
A desire or relish for food.
To desire food or drink.
Hula step; hip rotations with weight on the right hip as the left heel lifts very slightly, then reversing; to do this ʻami. See ʻami kūkū.
An amphipod (Caprellid amphipods) that clings to seaweeds or hydroids; it has a long slender body and is the color of the seaweed or hydroid on which it feeds.
A relish, morsel, or bit of food, scraps of food. E hoʻohui aʻe i nā ʻāmikamika e kupa me ka pipi kū, mix the scraps to make soup with the beef stew.
A remainder wished for.
See AMIKA. TO eat, but not enough: the desire is for more; aole i onoono iho kahi puu i ka mea ai, aole i amikamika, iho; aole ona o ka awa, aole amikamika iho.
Hill on Mauna Loa, Molokaʻi. On a hill east of here was a long maika course that was destroyed when pineapples were planted. (Cooke 120)

A hula step with ʻami; like the ʻami kāhela except that the revolutions are smaller and faster and in groups of three; sometimes two slower kāhela revolutions are followed by three faster kūkū revolutions; to perform this step.
Very rapid revolution of the hips in the hula; an uninhibited (kuʻupau) ʻami; to do so. Also ʻami honua, 'ami hue.
Name recorded for a type of lava rock on Lehua Island. Niʻihau.
Amino. ʻAkika ʻamino. Amino acid,
Narrow channel, as to a sea pool; to move through such a channel; to blow in a current; to pass in and out; gusty. Fig. To die. Cf. mio.

example_txt.txt: Hē āmio ka makani, e pio auaneʻi.
The wind blows a draft, [the light] may go out.

definitions.dtxt: See Keāmio.
That which enters silently, as death; as a fish floats unseen and comes not to the top; a gentle moving to and fro.

To walk or move still and slyly, so as not to be heard; maanei no i, amio iho nei a nalowale, he came here silently just now and is gone; mai kukulu aku oe i ke kukui ma ka puka; to flare, as the blaze of a lamp in the wind; he amio ka makani. e pio auanei; to move silently this way and that.
Redup. of āmio.
The figure-eight hula step; the revolving hips (ʻami) form an eight, with weight shifting; to perform this step. Lit. spinning ʻami.
An 'ami hula step with abdomen thrust forward, considered in poor taste; to do this step. Lit. stomach ʻami.
Same as ʻami kāhela but a new term.
Hinge of door or gate.
To carry a burden on the shoulders, to lift weights; a burden. Fig. Responsibility. Cf. ʻauamo. E amo pū! Shoulder arms!
A burden carried on the shoulders.
To bear or carry a burden on the shoulder. To bear or bring along a weight; to carry.
definitions.notes: Note: To carry on the back is haawe; to carry under the arm is hii.

definitions.dtxt: To perform difficult offices of any kind. SYN. with lawe.
Hoo. To put upon the shoulders of one.
Wink, sparkle; to wink, sparkle, glimmer, twinkle.
Contraction of the anal muscles, anal opening, vagina. Cf. pī ka ʻamo under pī 2. 'Amo hulu, rectum, vagina.
To wink, as the eye.
To twinkle, as a star; ke amo mai la ka hoku; often doubled, as amoamo; applied to the winking of any animal. See IMO.

See iwi kuʻe ʻamo. Mākala ʻamo. Sphincter, i.e., an annular muscle surrounding and able to contract or close a bodily opening or channel. Puka ʻamo. Anus, i.e., the posterior opening of the alimentary canal. Also puka kahiko.
Pas/imp. of amo.
Pass, for amoia; also amoaia; a double passive, ua laweia.
To raise or mount high, as waves; high, raised.
To be high; to be raised up, as a high precipice; to rise high, as the crest of a wave; amoamo iluna o ka pali o Kihiopua; amoamo iluna ka lau o ka nalu.
Redup. of ʻamo 1, 2. Hōkū ʻamoʻamo, twinkling star or eyes.
A winking; a twinkling, as of the eye or a star; a sudden change of the wind.
See AMO, to wink. To wink repeatedly.
For aumoe; midnight; e holo, ua nui ke kai o ke amoe.
Weight lifting; to lift weights. Lit. lift iron. Also hāpai hao.
E papani ka amohulu o ia nei; a lascivious word.
A stick for carrying burdens on the shoulder.
Irregular, uneven.
Stem of fruits or tubers; small end of sweet potato tuber.
Genitals of male. Also ʻanakiʻi, ʻanakiʻu, ʻanamiʻu.
Abounding in islets or rocks, as a reef; full of stumps; cutting, severing.
Amomum, a genus of plants in the ginger family.
The general name of odoriferous herbs mentioned in Latin, amomus.
Mépriser, haïr.
Ammonia.
Ammonia.
Ammonium. ʻAmoniuma molaibadahate. Ammonium molybdate.
Work for women; he kuku amoomoo, he palaholo ke kapa.
Small strip of tapa or matting such as can serve as a sample.
Young stage of the ʻōʻio fish.
A kind of fish; a small fish; also the ulua.
Maigre; abattu.
Thin, emaciated, lean.
Lean; thin in flesh; hakake, olala; a word used in caviling.
To curse, revile. Cf. kūamuamu.
To eat. Cf. hamu,
Name of a Kauaʻi wind. (FOR. 5:97)
To use profane language; to revile; amuamu i ke Akua. to blaspheme; amuamu i ka huahaule, to curse the friendless.
To trim, shear, shave; shaving, shearing. Pahi āmū, razor. Lauoho āmū, trimmed hair.
To shear or shave the hair from the head. To trim the hair; ua kolikoliia no a amu.
Relating to shearing or shaving; he pahi amu, a razor. He lauoho amu no kona, he has his hair cut.
Redup. of amu 1. Ke amuamu ʻana i ke aliʻi me ka hoʻohiki ʻino, reviling the chief with profane oaths.
A cursing; a reviling; reproaching; ka amuamu ana i ke alii me ka hoohiki ino, a cursing of the king with profanity; he kuamuamu, a reviling of sacred things.
Ke amuamuia la i ka ue wale,
O ka ue wale iho no la,
O ka ke kamalii hana’na no ia.
To use profane language; to revile; amuamu i ke Akua. to blaspheme; amuamu i ka huahaule, to curse the friendless.
Redup. of āmū.
Suffering from penetrating cold, bitter cold, bitter to taste.
To feel the chilling breeze of a cold morning when the skin contracts with cold; to suffer the same from being long in the water.
Assembly, i.e., a gathering of people for a specific purpose. Tah.
Reported as a var. name for the kāhala fish.
Cut off. Same as ʻāpahu.
See MUKU, to cut short. To cut off: to cut in pieces. See OMUKU.
Same as ʻāmokumoku.
Dull, blunt; dullness, bluntness.
Bluntness; dullness, as a tool.
Blunt on the edge; dull, as a tool. See KUMUMU.
A word of reproaching or reviling; he kanaka amupu. small, insignificant.
Abbreviation for ʻauneki (ounce).
A measure, as for cloth. A measure of any kind. Ana ohe, a measuring rod.
Grief; sadness; sorrow; trouble from the conduct of others.
The feelings of a parent towards a child that refuses his instructions; a mixed feeling of weariness, anger and love.
Fatigue from hard labor or toil.
To suffer; to undergo, as an experiment of healing in sickness.
To be grieved; troubled.
To be affected at contempt or vile treatment.
To praise much and covet another’s wealth.

To measure, survey, evaluate, rate, fathom; survey, measurement, standard, pattern, design, plan, model, meter, gauge, die. Cf. anana, ana ʻole, and numerous types of measurements listed below. See lani 2.
To make measurements, rearrange, put in order.
To have enough or too much, satisfied, satiated, surfieted.

example_txt.txt: Ā ana nā kūpuna o Kawelo i ke kāhumu ʻai na Kawelo.
The grandparents of Kawelo had had enough of tending food ovens for Kawelo.
I’ve had all I can take; I’m disgusted.
ʻAʻole e ʻōlelo mai ana ke ahi ua ana ia.
Fire will never say that it has enough [of love].

definitions.dtxt: Cave, grotto, cavern.

example_txt.txt: kokoke aku i kahi ana o ka pō
near the cavern of the night /depths of the night

definitions.dtxt: Larynx.
Part; after e (verb). See e (verb) ana, Gram. 5.3.
Following verbs indicating a single event, whether a command or a statement, whether completed or incompleted. (Gram. 7.4) See also e 1.

example_txt.txt: Iāia nō ā hala, kū ana ke kaʻa.
As soon as he had gone, the car came.

definitions.dtxt: Measurement; dimension, in math. Also nui. See entries below. Ana ākea, ana laulā. Width. Ana hohonu, ana kiʻekiʻe. Height. Ana loa, ana lōʻihi. Length.

example_txt.txt: ʻEhia ke ana o kēia lumi?
What are the dimensions of this room?

definitions.dtxt: A cave; a den formed by rocks.
Name of a hollow place in the mouth, by which the voice is modified. Anal. 11.3. A cave for the retreat of the van quished; a place where the conquered are found.
To measure.
To measure in any way; e hiki ia'u ke ana i ka loa, a me ka laula, a me ka hohonu, a me ke kiekie o keia mea; met.
Ana wau i kou pono a me kou hewa, I measured your good and your evil; no ke ana ana, in measuring. Mea ana hora, a dial. Hoo. To set apart; to set aside. To restrain; keep back.
To be satiated; satisfied, as thy eye with seeing.
To have a sufficiency of property.
To drink sufficiently, as the sword drinks blood, i.e., to be revenged.
Hoo. To satiate, as with food. As with drink. Ua ana, it is enough.
Satisfied, as with food, having eaten sufficiently; maona.
Pumice, used as a rubber.
Siliceous sponge (Leiodermatium), used as medicine and as sandpaper.
Nominalizing part. (Gram. 6.6.2)
The participial termination of verbs answering to the ing; as, lawe ana, carrying; hana ana, working; but it has some peculiarities.
The ana is not united with the verb as ing is in.

The ana may be separated from the verb, and any qualifying word or words, and also the verbal directives may come between. Gram. § 233. As, e kukulu hale ana ia, he is build house ing; e hopu bipi ana, he is catch cattle ing, etc. In many cases the participial termination ana becomes united with a noun and becomes a participial noun; in which ease the first a of the ana is dropped, or coalesces with the last letter of the preceding word, and they both become one word; as hopena for hope ana; haawina for haawi ana. etc.
A kind of light stone found in the sea, used by nurses to cure the ea, or the white fur on the tongue; also used in rubbing and polishing off canoes and wooden calabashes.
Iwi ʻana. Cancellous bone.
His, her, hers (singular, a-form, zero-class; Gram. 9.6.3).
The oblique case of the pronoun, third person sing.; of him; of her; of it; his; hers. Gram. § 139. Auipili.
An eating circle. 2. A congregation of people for any purpose, provided a space be left in the center; a congregation.
Land surveying. See above. Anahonua.
Ana, to measure, and aina, land. To survey or measure land.
Land surveying; to survey.
Acid indicator. Lit. measure acid. Pepa ana ʻakika. Litmus paper.
Red pumice.
Kaha anaalike. Directrix, as a line which divides a parabola into two equal areas, in math. Cf. kaha kau.
Pellet-shaped, as goat dung.
To shiver, tremble. (And.)
To be in a tremor, as the muscles after great fatigue; anaana pu na wawae i ka maloeloe i ka hele ana.
In small balls, as the dung of sheep or goats; he anaana ka lepo o ke kao a me ka hipa; anaana ka lepo i ka ai liilii.

Black magic, evil sorcery by means of prayer and incantation; to practice this. See kahu ʻanaʻanā, kahuna ʻanāʻanā. ʻO ke kahu ʻanāʻanā aka mai ma ke kala ʻana i ka ʻanāʻanā ʻia mai e kekahi, the master of black magic skillful in countering the sorcery being directed at him by another.
A kind of sorcery or prayer used to procure the death or a curse upon one.
Witchcraft. Divination.
To practice divination or sorcery by prayer; e anaana ana ia kakou, they were practicing sorcery upon us.
Divining; consulting divinations; kahuna anaana, a diviner. pule anaana, a praying one to death.
To be angry; perhaps to nestle.
Angry.
To rub; to rub out grain with the hand.
To grind; to scour; to brush down thatching; to polish; kalai a maikai, anai apakika. To smooth. Hence,
To blot out; cut off; destroy. To lay waste. To blot out.
To nullify one’s character or pretensions.
To rub repeatedly, as one’s eyes. Niʻihau. Cf. ʻānai.
Redup. of ʻānai.
Frequentative of anai.
Redup. of ʻanapa.
Redup. of anapau; to move briskly. Ua ʻike au i ka mokuahi Kīlauea anaunapau ka holo, I saw the ship Kīlauea briskly sailing along.
To undulate, as the air under a hot sun.
To flash, as lightning; ka anaanapu ana o ka uila ma ka po; to send forth light.
To crook often; to have many crooks. See ANAANAPUU; also ANAPA.
Bent; crooked; out of a straight line; he kaula anaanapuu o ka hilo ana; he lopi anaanapuu ana; he anuu hanuu loa o anaanapuu.
Redup. of ʻanapuʻu. ʻAnaʻanapu'u ka uila, the jagged lightening flashes.
Redup. of ʻanau.
Stupid; palaka.
Idiotic, foolish, as one under the spell of sorcery.
Ammeter, an instrument used to measure the amount of electric current in a circuit.
Andaman. Ke kai ʻo ʻAnadamana. Andaman Sea.
See ANA E. Hoo. To set aside; to set apart.
Full-sized ʻamaʻama mullet fish.
A species of fish; the mullet.
Name of a species of fish; o Kaulua, oia ka malama e pae mai ai ka pua anae.
To save for future use. hoʻānaʻe To withhold for the future. Ka hoʻoilina … ua hoʻānaʻē ʻia ma ka lani, inheritance … reserved in heaven.

Village, bay, and development area, well known for spectacular petroglyphs (Cox and Stasack 85), Puakō qd., North Kona, Hawaiʻi. Bishop Museum archaeologists in 1971 believed the site was occupied in A.D. 800 but that most of the petroglyphs date from after 1500. See Pōhakukūlua.
Angola; Angolan.
Reflection of light. (And.)
The reflection or glancing of light; the flashing of light.

Anhydride, i.e., a compound formed from another by the removal of water. cf. nele wai. ʻAnahaidaraside kuapapa. Basic anhydride, a metallic oxide that forms a base when added to water. ʻAnahaidaraside ʻakika. Acidic anhydride.
Gulch, Airport qd., Molokaʻi.
Repeated reflection or gleaming of light.
Repeated reflection or gleaming of light.
Pedometer.
Same as nahenahe, soft, gentle.
Corona Borealis, a constellation. Tah.
Mountain, land section, village, bay, ditch, river, and weir, Kawaihau district, kauaʻi. See Kanahāwale.
Hourglass.
Land measuring; geometry; me ka ike aku i ke anahonua.
The title of a school book, geometry.
Ana, to measure, and honua, flat land. To survey land.
Geometry.
Geometry. Also moleanahonua. Papakui anahonua. Geoboard.
Surveying, to measure the surface of the earth.
Model, pattern.

definitions.der: [Lit. standard (for) comparison. Hoʻopaʻa i ke ana hoʻohālike. To set the standard]
definitions.dtxt: Standard, i.e., an established model or example.
The second son of Luahoomoe; he kahuna makapo, akamai, he akua no ka poe mahiai; the god of husbandmen.
Deformed, disfigured, stoop-shouldered, lopsided; such a person.
Caus/sim.
A tall man bending over; stoop-shouldered; ke kanahua, he oohu.
Protractor. Ana huina kūpono. Right angle protractor.
Trigonometry.
Period of ten days; for ten days; to pass ten days. Kū anahulu ka moku, the ship arrives once in ten days; the ship stays for ten days.
Large moana, a fish from 30 to 80 cm long.
A period of ten days; a decade. A malaila i noho loihi ai ekolu anahulu. Laieik. 61.
To arrive at, or amount to the number ten; applied to days; a anahulu ae, alaila hiki mai, when ten days had passed he arrived.
Stream, Waiʻalua, Oʻahu. (Ii 98)
Same as ālai 1; screen; attraction. Ke ānai maila ka ʻiwa ānai maka (UL 197), the frigate bird that fascinates the eyes is attracting attention.
To rub, scrub, scour, polish, grind, grate, blot out, lay waste, destroy; rubbing, scrubbing, etc.; friction. Cf. ʻaʻanai, ʻānaʻanai, ʻānainai.
To curse.
To rub, as one’s eyes. Niʻihau. Cf. ʻanaʻanai. See entry below.
Haku ʻānai. Neolithic, in anthropology. Ke au haku ʻānai. Neolithic age, period.
To rub; to rub out grain with the hand.
Calorimeter, an instrument used to measure changes in thermal energy.
Congregation, audience, assembly, gathering, crowd; to assemble.
An assembly; a multitude.
An eating circle. 2. A congregation of people for any purpose, provided a space be left in the center; a congregation.
To assemble around a person or place; to meet around a thing.
Funeral wake or gathering.
Congregation for worship.
Redup. of ʻānai.
To rub often; to polish, etc. See ANAI.
Royal reception or audience.
See ANAINA. A congregation of people. An assembly of men.
Gekko; polecat, ferret.
A ferret.
Anchor. Leikō ka ʻanakā, let go the anchor.
Lava tube.
Unit of measurement.

Unit of measurement. Cf. kūana helu. Anakahi mekalika. Metric unit of measure. Anakahi ʻAmelika. US standard or customary unit of measurement. Anakahi nuipaʻa ʻātoma. Atomic mass unit. See nuipaʻa ʻātoma. Hakina anakahi. Unit fraction.

definitions.der: [Lit. electric unit of measurement. Cf. ʻome]
definitions.dtxt: Volt, in electricity. ʻO ka 7,200 anakahi uila ka ʻawelika o ka nui o ke anakahi uila o nā uea o nā pou kelepona o kaʻe o nā alanui. 7,200 volts is the average voltage contained in the utility lines alongside roads.
Uncle.
Gulch, Honolua qd., West Maui.
To weigh; weight.

definitions.der: [Lit. water weight gauge. Cf. ana kawaūea]
definitions.dtxt: Hydrometer.
Hygrometer. Cf. ana kaumaha wai. Ana kawaūea ʻōpuʻu pulu a maloʻo. Wet-and-dry-bulb hygrometer. Ana kawaūea kūlua. Psychrometer. Maʻa ana kawaūea kūlua. Sling psychrometer.
Aunt, auntie.
Bent, crooked, misshapen.
Anarchy, anarchist. Also ʻanekomio.
Altimeter.
Same as ʻamokiʻi. (FOR. 5:533)
Sextant.
Name of a people mentioned in the books of Deuteronomy and Joshua remarkable for their size. They lived mostly in the south and south-west parts of Canaan.
Angiosperm. Comb. angio (Gr.) + pua.
Nothing remains to be done. A pau a ʻanakoe, kū ana kēlā mea i luna o ka waʻa, when all was done, each one stood up in the canoe.
Inflammatory swelling of a lymph gland, venereal tumor, bubo.
A swelling in the groin. See HAHAI.
Andorra.
Andromeda. Ka wiliau hōkū ʻo ʻAnakolomeka. Andromeda galaxy.
Anatomy.

Equilibrium. Ke kaulike ʻelua manehu i ka pahu ʻana o kekahi i kekahi, paʻa maila ke anakonu. When two opposing forces are equal, equilibrium is achieved. (Sāmoan agatonu [equal].) Mīkā anakonu. Isostasy, i.e., the equilibrium of the earth’s crust, in geology.
Template. Comb. ana+kuhi. Anakuhi mahaka. Stencil. Pepa anakuhi lālani. linear unit paper, in math.
Var. of akakuʻu.
Regular, as in shape. Sh. ana + maʻalahi. Cf. laukua. Huinalehulehu analahi. regular polygon. Kinona analahi. Regular shape.

definitions.der: [Lit. gauge (to measure) intoxicating drink (in) breath. Cf. nui lama koko]
definitions.dtxt: Breathalyzer.
Wee, stunted. Also ʻaʻanaliʻi, kakanaliʻi.
A native fern (Asplenium lobulatum) with narrow fronds to 45 cm long, having many narrow lobes along two opposite sides of the axis. Also piʻipiʻilaumanamana.
Isometric. Comb. ana+ like. Pepa kiko analike. Isometric dot paper.
General name of the stars near the horizon at any point of the compass. See aNALIPO.
Tail feathers.
Same as analipo.
Distance, faraway space, beyond the horizon. Cf. kumulipo.
Name of the place supposed to be beyond the stars, i.e., out of sight, but really below the horizon.
Measurement of length.

Street, Puʻunui, Honolulu, named for Judge Lorrin Andrews (1795-1868), associate justice of the Supreme Court and judge of the probate court, the author of a hawaiian dictionary and grammar and many translations into Hawaiian. His home was on nuʻuanu Avenue(TM)
Pattern, as a word or sentence pattern in Hawaiian grammar. Comb. ana + lula. cf. lauana. Puke aʻo analula. Pattern book, as for teaching grammatical patterns in reading.
Anemometer.
Opinion survey, poll; to conduct an opinion survey or poll. Comb. ana+manaʻo. See entry below.

To canvass, i.e., go door to door handing out political information and asking people which candidate they support. Manaʻo aku ka meia he pono ke mālama ʻia he anamanaʻo pāloka ma ke kaona e ʻike ai i ka papaha o kōna lanakila ʻana ma ka holo moho hou ʻana. The mayor felt it was necessary to canvass the town to.
Tempo marker in music; Maelzel’s metronome marker.

definitions.der: [Lit. air pressure gauge. Ana mīkā ea kuhikuhi. Aneroid barometer]
definitions.dtxt: Barometer.
Same as ʻamokiʻi.
To break off the root which unites the potato to the main root; e emiemi iho la lakou i ka uala nuia hahai ae la i ke anamiu o ka uala.
Metric weight and measure.
Alderamin, a star.

Fathom: formerly the distance between tips of longest fingers of a man, measured with arms extended on each side; Catholic writers equated anana with one meter (KAM. 76:50–1); to count by this measurement or by fathoms. Cf. ana 1.
A common but indefinite measure formerly used; the length of the arms and body when both arms were extended, to the ends of the longest fingers.
A fathom.
Conj. 9th of ana, to measure.
To strain, as juice or poi. Same as kānana.
Wingspan.
Jackfruit.
A variety of hīnālea fish.
Redup. of ʻanau.
Leafless, bare.
Same as ʻamokiʻi.
The root which holds the potato to the main root; e mohai ke ananio.
Coastal area, Kamalō qd., north Molokaʻi.
Turnip.
See LAULELE. Name of a plant used for food, boiled.
Daikon.
To collapse or deflate, as a balloon.
Deflated, as a balloon. Also puhalu (dic.), emi (Niʻihau). cf. pakiʻi. See hoʻopūhalalū.
White pumice with fine pores.
Seismograph.
Seismograph. Also mīkini ana ōlaʻi.
Without equal, unsurpassed, immeasureable, incomparable (in this sense, similar, to launa ʻole and lua ʻole), limitless, unlimited, never satisfied. See ex., lani 2.
Ohmmeter. See ʻome.
To shine, gleam, glitter, flash, sparkle; brightness, gleam. hoʻanapa caus/sim.
To shine with reflected light, as the moon reflected from the water; like the sun reflected from a mirror.
To flash like lightning, or like the burning of gunpowder.
To light suddenly.
Street, Foster Village subdivision, Hālawa, Waipahu qd., Oʻahu. Named suggested by Mary Kawena Pukui in 1956.
Cubic measure. See ex., paʻa 1.
Point, Kawaihau district, Kauaʻi.
A species of limu.
The dazzling of the sun on any luminous body, such as strikes the eyes with pain.
Redup. of ʻanapa.

Hawaiian soap plant (Colubrina asiatica), a twining shrub, distributed from africa, India, and Australia to Polynesia, with ovate- to heart-shaped leaves and small round fruits. The leaves form a lather in water and have long been used as soap on Pacific islands. The plant is mistakenly reported to be poisonous. Also kauila ʻānapanapa, kukuku; kolokolo on Niʻihau.
Red seaweeds (Gelidium spp.); small, stiff, branching, edible plants. Also limu loloa.
A species of tree, the bark of which is used for soap.
Scales, as used for weighing something. Anapaona home. Bathroom scales. usu. anapaona. Anapaona kaulike. Balance scales. Anapaona pilina. Spring scales.
A machine to measure weight; a balance.
Scales, balance; to weigh.
A crook in a thing; a bending; a turning; a hinge.
To turn; to bend; to warp; to turn, as on hinges; to crook round.

To leap, frisk, frolic; frisky. [Now heard only in the song: He aha ka hana a ʻAnapau (mele maʻi for Queen Liliʻuokalani)? What does Frisky do?] hōʻanapau To caper, cavort; to twist and turn the body, especially in the finale of a hula with rapid hip movements.
Measurement of capacity.
Specific heat, in physics.
Thermometer, for taking temperatures; to take temperature. Lit. fever (Eng.) measure.
To set, as the sun. Niʻihau. Usu. napoʻo.
Same as ʻanapa. ʻAnapu ma ka honua mea, flashing hot on the reddened earth.
A flash of light. See ANAPA. Hoo. To send forth lightning. See ANAANAPU.
To burn; scorch, as the direct rays of the sun; e wela ana ka wawae i ka la.
To quiver, as the rays of the sun on black lava.
A glimmering, as of light.

definitions.der: [Lit. cave with holes (fishermen tied their canoes in these holes)]
definitions.dtxt: Shore cave, ʻĪlio Pt. qd., Molokaʻi.
Underground passage, tunnel.
Redup. of ʻanapu.
Heat or light reflected, or both; the light and heat of reflection.
Boundary, circumference, perimeter; to encircle, go around. Komo akula i ke anapuni a Lima loa, entered the circle of Long-arm [where others have the upper hand].
Circumference, in math; perimeter. Lākiō anapuni. Constant of proportionality.
A circle.
Ana, to measure, and puni, around. To encompass, as a boundary line. See aNAHONUA 10.
Bumpy, lumpy, jagged, uneven; bump hump; to hump along, buck; to project, as the bones of a thin animal. Cf. ʻaʻanapuʻu, ʻanaʻanapuʻu.
Caus/sim.
Lymph.
A corner formed by two lines meeting.
To crook, as a rafter, or as a rope large in some places and small in others.
Contorted; blunt.
The science of dissecting animal bodies; applied mostly to human bodies. Gr. ανατομία
Name of the book teaching that science.
To move with a jerky motion; to go gadding from place to place. Cf. ʻananau, ʻānaʻanau. ʻAnau nohoʻi ʻoe i kauhale, how you go gadding from house to house.
To pace, as a horse.
To go about irregularly from house to house.
To traipse up and down.
Rain gauge; to measure rainfall.
Same as ʻanianiau, a honey creeper.
To go here and there, gad.
Mealybug (Coccidae) and scale insects.
Same as hanauna, generation.
Same as naunau 3, shellfish.
A small shrubby mustard, called peppergrass (probably a native species, lepidium bidentatum var. o-waihiense); the root was used medicinally. Also kūnānā, naunau.
According to Rock (1913) a large native peppergrass (Lepidium serra), with narrower leaves, found only on Kauaʻi.
Diameter.
Diameter, in math.
A diameter of a circle. Anah. 23.

definitions.der: [Lit. A long diameter, that is, the diameter of an ellipse the long way. Anah. 24]
definitions.dtxt: As above.
The short or conjugate diameter of an ellipsis. Anah. 24.
Water meter.
Liquid measure.
Thermometer, measurement of heat; to measure heat.
Thermometer; to take the temperature of. See anu, mahana, mehana, wela, kēkelē.
A dermestid beetle that destroys feathers in feather-work; mites, as in chickens; ringworm; insect-eaten, gnawed. Lehu ane, fine ashes.
The breath of life, passing of a breeze. Cf. aneane.
Pimple, scabies.
Name of a small insect that eats wood, but is not itself visible.
The worm dust of wood; powder-post.
The cutaneous disease called ringworm.
A soft stone used in polishing wood; also written ana.
To eat, as small insects eat wood.
To be near doing a thing; to like to do it, but not quite; as, ane aku au e hoonou i ka pohaku, I was near throwing a stone. See ANEANE. Ane like iki, it is almost like.
Light, as worm-eaten timber; not heavy; mama.
Same as ʻaneʻane, to draw near. Ua ʻane hiki mai, almost here. Ua ʻane aku i ka manawa, it is almost time.
Var. of ʻana 1, pumice.
With difficulty; scarcely; nearly; generally followed by ole; ane haalele ole ia ia, it hardly leaves him; ane hiki ole ke hali, which can scarcely be carried.
Huaʻāne. Spermatozoon, sperm, in biology. Cf. huaʻine.
Positive, as of electrical charge or north pole of a magnet. Inv. See hohoki, ʻine, ʻūholo uila ʻāne.
For aneia; pass. of ane; to be worm-eaten; to be light, as worm-eaten wood; to be dry, as timber.
Insipid, tasteless.
Vibration caused by heat.
Pas/imp. of ane 1; moth-eaten. Fig. A battered tramp.
Bare, leafless.
Pas/imp. of ane 2; gentle, as a breeze.
The dry-rot of wood, occasioned by heat, or the action of insects; applied to timber very old; also to other things. See ANOA.
The heat of the sun; more properly the apparent vibration of the air caused by the heat of the sun.

Insipid; tasteless, as the inside of worm-eaten food, or of poor food; applied to persons having no appetite for food, on account of oppressive heat; exhausted, as men by hunger, by long abstinence, by long sleep, or by diving in deep water. See KANEA and ANEANE.
Antarctic.
Antarctica; Antarctic.
See ANE. Nearly; almost; in danger of; liable to; applied to number; he aneane pono ole ko’u noho ana maanei; aneane make, unto death, almost dead.
A jest; a kind of jocose denial to a request.
A vacancy of the stomach for want of food or from sickness; he aneane no la; he aneane pupuka no la; he aneane pono la; he aneane hiki no la.
Faint, feeble, exhausted; nauseous dizziness. Cf. puaaneane.
See ANE above. Faint; feeble; low; weak, as a sick person.
Nearly, almost, scarcely, hardly, not quite, fairly; near. Ua ʻaneʻane hoʻi e paʻa, it is almost finished. ʻAneʻane i ka make, near death.
To be exhausted, as a man with hunger or by long abstinence: by long sleep, or by diving in deep water.
To blow softly, as a light breeze or zephyr.
To be almost something; to be almost at a place. Laieik. 71. Aneane oia e hoohiki ino aku i kona akua, he almost cursed his god. Laieik. 158. Almost to do something. See ANE.
Redup. of ānea.
To move along by jerks, hitch along, sidle.
To go where one is not welcome, to wear out a welcome.
One who goes from house to house telling fortunes, begging, or for any such purpose; a beggar.
To hitch or move along, like a cripple; to walk on one’s knees.
To go about from house to house begging; aia no oia ma ka huahuelo kahi i anee ai.
Moving about from place to place; going about begging; kanaka anee, a beggar; a fortune teller.
Parasite or sponger on a chief; royalist (disparaging).
Redup. of ʻāneʻe 1, 2.
Old clothing; small mat that is carried about to sit on.
Mats old and worn; he wahi moena aneenee uuku, a small mat about a fathom long.
Endangered. Also ʻane make loa, ʻane nalowale loa. kānāwai Lāhulu ʻAne Halapohe. Endangered Species Act.
To come upon quietly, move stealthily, poise. Ānehe akula ia e kuʻi, he stole up quietly to strike a blow. Ānehe mai nā kānaka e kaua (FS 71), the people were poised for fighting.
To be on the alert; ready for a start, as a cat for a mouse; as a bird to fly.
To be ready to seize upon a person or thing when circumstances require.
When? (in the future).
Violence; disorder, etc., as of a mob.
Redup. of ānehe.
The double root of the above; to be prepared; all ready to do a thing; to be on the look out to do it.
He hala.
Transgression of the law, wrong, fault; to transgress. (And.)
See NEI. To sweep off; to cause to disappear.

Part. indicating that a question may be answered by yes or no, always following a word or phrase. (Gram. 7.5) ʻAʻole anei? Isn't it so? Isn't it? Pēlā anei? Is it that way? Is that so? E hele ana anei ʻoe i ke kaona? Are you going to town?
The sign of a question, used after verbs or nouns; as, mai anei oia? is he sick? ua holo anei ia? has he sailed? he mai anei?

Here (usually after ma-, i, or kō: Gram. 8.6). See ex., nei 3, ʻōi. Ē kuʻu aloha, maʻaneʻi mai, neʻeneʻe mai nō ā pili (song), my loved one, come here, sidle up close. ʻAʻohe o ʻoneʻi wahine e like me ʻoe, ā inā nohoʻi no ʻaneʻi aku nei, ʻaʻole nō e hele mai i ʻaneʻi; he kapu o ʻaneʻi, he make (FS 259), none of the local women are like you, and had [you] been of this place, [you] would not have come here; it is taboo here, death.
Part. Doubtful (used idiomatically). Same as auaneʻi 2. (Gram. 7.5) He paʻakai ʻaneʻi e heheʻe ai, so, like salt that melts [said by one who doesn't mind going into the rain].
Here; in this place; like maanei; mai anei aku. I ko kakou hoi ana anei a hiki i Kauai, on our returning along this way till we reach Kauai. Laieik. 87.
Anglican.
Var. of ʻanikelikeko.
Andes.
Angle.
Antelope; gazelle, roebuck.
Dill, anise.
An herb; anise.
Mealworm. Comb. ane+koʻe. Cf. ane ʻuku.
Var. of ʻanakomia, anatomy. (FOR. 5:543)
Angel; designation for Hawaiian gods and spirits by those converts to christianity who had kept some of the old gods. ʻĀnela kiaʻi, guardian angel.
An angel; a messenger from heaven.
Street, Woodlawn, upper Mānoa, Honolulu.
Endangered. Also ʻane halapohe, ʻane nalowale loa.

definitions.der: [Lit. near island (perhaps a translation of French presqu’île)]
definitions.dtxt: Peninsula.
Same as alena, an herb. Niʻihau.
Endangered. Also ʻane halapohe, ʻane make loa.
See ANEENEE.
A game; the stone called hiu was said to have been used in this game.
To itch. Cf. maneʻo.
An antelope.
Mealy bug.
Dizzy, unsteady, as one ill or intoxicated Cf. newa, dizzy.
To be inactive, as asleep.
Indolent; sleepy.
Redup. of ānewa.
To be as dead.
To be in a fainting fit; unconscious, as men; as fish poisoned with hola.
In morals, to be unmindful of evils around us. See KUNEWANEWA. Ke anewanewa kakou hoolono io ana ke kihi, huna pala iki ke akamai.
To beckon, wave; to blow softly, as a breeze; to draw a net over the surface of water; to pass over the surface, as a hand; beckoning.

example_txt.txt: to threaten to throw at, as a dog

definitions.dtxt: To beckon, wave, signal; to let wind.
Drawing; dragging, as a net for fish; he upena ani.
To pass over a surface, as the hand over a table.
To draw a net over the surface of the water.
To beckon one with the hand; to make signs secretly to one.
Ani malu ka ike ilaila.
I ka mauli hoaaloha wale,
Aloha opa, opa he ake.
To blow softly, as a gentle breeze; ke ani nei ka makani, ke ani peahi la ia limaloa, the wind blows softly, it fans Limaloa with a fan.
Pas/imp. of ani; breezy. See ex., nāhāhā.
Smooth.
To be hard and smooth on the surface.
Smooth and even. See NIANIA, ANIANIA and MANIANIA.
Scorched, singed, parched; hot, as an oven.
Mirror, glass; clear, transparent, obvious. Cf. makaaniani, pukaaniani. Several types of aniani are listed below.

chants.mltran: ♫  Techniques are clear to the Nautilus.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Aniani nā hana i ka Naukilo.

definitions.dtxt: Cool, refreshing; to blow softly, gently. Fig. To travel swiftly.
Mirror. Also aniani nānā, aniani kilohi, aniani kilo. See entries below.
A glass; a mirror; a looking-glass. He aniani nana helehelena; he kilo kekahi inoa; called by Hawaiians kilo.
See ANI 4. To cool; to refresh one heated; aniani mai la ka makani. To blow gently, as a wind; aniani puka alohi na ka haole paha la; aniani poaeae na maka o Kuawili.
Agreeable; cool; refreshing.
Smooth, calm.
See ANIA. Smooth and even, as the surface of a planed board; smooth, as the sea in a calm; applied also to the skin when burnt hard; he paapaa ili mawaho no ka lapalapa o ke ahi.
Redup. of ʻānia.

A small, bright olive or yellowish-green Hawaiian honey creeper (Loxops [formerly Chlorodrepanis] parva), endemic to Kauaʻi, and related to the ʻamakihi. the young birds which are confused with young ʻamakihi, were reported to have been called alawī. The greater ʻamakihi (L. satittirostris) is presumed extinct.
Fiberglass. Cf. aniani ʻea.
Plexiglass. Cf. aniani awe.
Magnifying glass, microscope, telescope.
Magnifying glass, hand lens. Cf. aniani kaulona.
Name of a star said to be in the Milky Way.
Lamp chimney.

definitions.der: [Lit. glass (for) observing closely. Cf. aniani hoʻonui ʻike. Aniani kaulona ʻeʻele. Concave lens. Aniani kaulona ʻeʻemu. convex lens]
definitions.dtxt: Lens, as for a camera or microscope.

definitions.der: [Lit. glass for placing and pushing along. See paepae aniani kaupaneʻe]
definitions.dtxt: Slide, as for a microscope. Usu. aniani.
Land section, Kaunakakai qd., Molokaʻi.
Mirror looking glass.
Rear-view mirror for a car. Also aniani kaʻa.
Rear-view mirror for a bicycle. Also aniani kilo paikikala, aniani paikikala.

definitions.der: [Lit. stand beckoning (a Papakōlea girl stood at this place beckoning to a girl in Mānoa who was chanting)]
definitions.dtxt: Street, Pauoa, Honolulu, named for Anianikū Stillman, wife of James Robinson Holt iI. Their son, Valentine Holt, gave this name to the first hybrid hibiscus developed in Hawaiʻi. (TM)
Standing mirror.
Full-length mirror.
Electric-light bulb.
Mirror, looking glass.
Hand mirror.
Hand mirror. Also aniani lima.
Small mirror kept in a purse. Also aniani liʻiliʻi.
Climate. Lit. air movement (over) time. Cf. anilā. Aniau hāiki. microclimate.
Unfriendly, angry, hardhearted, hostile. Cf. kamaniha.
To be provoked at the mischief of one; to be angry at a person on account of lying and deception.
To be hardened in crime; capable of committing any offense.
Easily provoked; captious; caviling.
Redup. of ʻāniha.
Nearly, almost. ʻĀnihaniha mākou ā pae, loaʻa i ka makani, we were almost landing when [we were] caught by the wind.
To be near obtaining an object and fail; anihaniha makou e pae, a loaa ka makani.
Precarious. Cf., nihi. ʻĀnihinihi i ke ola, life hanging [as by a thread].
Small taro tubers. Less used than ʻōnihinihi.
Kalo tops; he kalo, he anihinihi, he oha. See ONINIHI.
See NIHI. Near to falling off a pali; to stand in a dangerous place.
A small fish (no data).
Antichrist. Also shortened to ʻanekaliko.
Weather. Lit, air movement (during the) day. Cf. aniau.
Dwarfish, stunded, tiny.
To vary, as great and small waves.
Awning.
Eaves (preceded by ke).
Stream and beach, Hanalei district, Kauaʻi; also called Wanini.
Small; dwarfish; stinted, as men or animals.
Eurya sandwichensis, a native tree or shrub in the tea family. Also wānini.
Amplitude modulation. Also AM (pronounced ʻāmū). cf. FM.
To wave or beckon, as with the hand, fan.
Root connecting sweet potato to vine.
Fear; dread; ua kau mai ke ano ia'u la, fear fell upon me; ke kau mai la ke ano hewa ia oe.
Likeness; resemblance; image of a thing.
The meaning of a word or phrase.
The moral quality of an action, as good or evil, or the moral state of the heart.
The character of a person, as to his life and manners; the explanation of a thing obscure.
Awe, reverence, peacefulness, sacredness, holiness; feeling of awe, fear, or oppression; weird solitude, oppressive quiet; awestruck, lost in thought.

example_txt.txt: Ano wale mai nō kō aloha.

chants.mltran: ♫  The forest is silent, there are no birds in the plains.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Ke ano mai nei ka nahele, ʻaʻohe manu o ke kula.

example_txt.txt: Poʻe Hōano o nā Lā Hope Nei
Ē kō mākou Makua i loko o ka lani, e hōano ʻia kou inoa.
Our Father which art in Heaven, hallowed be Thy name.

definitions.dtxt: Holy, devoted to sacred use, hallowed, solemn; to reverence, sanctify, attribute divine honor, hallow.
Time (in songs, and usually before ahiahi, rarely before kakahiaka).
To be in fear; ano wale mai la no au. See ANO or ANOANO. To be silent; solitary, as a deserted village; ua pau i ke kaua, hauaia na kanaka a pau i ka hana.

Kind, variety, nature, character, disposition, bearing, type, brand, likeness, sort, way, manner, shape, tendency, fashion, style, mode, circumstance, condition, resemblance, image, color, moral quality, denomination, meaning (preceded by ke).

example_txt.txt: way of life, standard of living
What is [it] like [sometimes said scornfully]? What kind of nonsense is that?
He aha nō lā kou ʻano?

definitions.dtxt: To cause to take a definite shape, produce a resemblance.
Somewhat, rather; to show signs of.
To have a form or appearance.
With hou, to change the form or appearance of a person or thing; e ano ae, to become new. To change the state of things.
With hoo, to boast; to glory; to hallow; to consecrate.
To transform; to change the external appearance.
With e, to set apart to another purpose; to consecrate.
With hou, to change; to transform.
With e, to change, as the countenance, from mirth to sadness and fear.
Now, present. (Gram. 8.6)
Now; at the present time; ano nei, ano la. Soon.
Often used more as an expression of earnestness or certainty of something doing, or to be done, than of anything literally doing now.
It is used after some other event has been spoken of as a consequence. Ina no ano, even now.
Dry, parched, barren. Same as panoa.
Pas/imp. of ano 1.
Same as ano above. Now; at this time; immediately; anoa no hele; ahea hele? anoa no.
To end, give up.
Greeting, salutation, news; to greet. ʻAnoʻai kākou, greetings (to more than two persons). Nā ʻanoʻai o Kona ʻĀkau, news of North Kona.
Unexpected. ʻAnoʻai kō māua hui ʻana, our meeting was unexpected.
Perhaps.

chants.chtran: Perhaps there the dwelling house of desire.
chants.chtxt: ʻAnoʻai aia paha i laila ka hale noho a ka ʻiʻini.

definitions.dtxt: A warm salutation; as, aloha, welina; a salutation; a bow; a courtesy.
But; except; lest; perhaps; malia paha.
Godlike, divine; godly form.
Redup. of ano 1.
Redup. of hoʻāno.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻānoano wale mai nō mehe haili lā e kau iho maluna.
Awe-struck as though a spirit has descended from above.
I Wailua ā ho ʻānoano ka ihu o ka waʻa.
[Turn] the prow of the canoe to Wailua and place under taboo.

definitions.dtxt: A solemn stillness.
A sacred, hallowed place. See ANO.
Solitary; still; retired. He wahi anoano, mehameha loa no ka makau i ka make; aohe lua o ka noho ana i ua kula anoano kanaka ole nei.
Seed, kernel, germ; dried and salted Chinese watermelon seed. Fig. Progeny, offspring.
Seed. Wahī ʻanoʻano. Seed pod.
Seeds; the seeds of fruit, as apple, onion, melon, etc.
definitions.notes: Note: The fruit itself is hua; also, the seeds incased in pods or husks are called hua; anoano oili, seeds destitute of meat.

definitions.dtxt: The semen of males.
Descendants; children of men.
To be different from something else; to take a different form or character. see ANO and E.
Strange, odd, unusual, uncommon, grotesque, peculiar, eccentric, freakish, queer, quaint, different, uncomfortable. hōʻano ʻē Caus/sim. Hoʻano ʻē iki aʻe kona helehelena, and altered his features.
Individual presiding over the ʻume game. (Malo 215)
Method, case, technique, as in solving problems.
Sitting taboo. (Kep. 137)
A custom; a practice, as strict as a law; ina e ku ke kanaka i ka anoho ana o ko ke alii ipuwai auau, a me ka anoho ana o kona kapa, make no ia.
New variety, fashion, or kind; new, unusual. hōʻano hou To renew, change the nature or character.
Compound, as of fractions.
Complex, as of fractions.

Desire, longing, love, desired one, lover (see ex., pouli 1); to desire, yearn; loved, beloved. ʻAnoʻi pua, cherished flower, sweetheart. ʻAnoʻi ka manaʻo, hope. Ka mele i ʻanoʻi nui ʻia, the greatly beloved song. ʻAnoʻi aku e ʻike iāia, great desire to see her.
A thirst; a strong desire for a thing; eia ka pono, o ka noonoo, o ka anoi, o ke ake e loaa.
To desire very strongly; to covet; e anoi ana na alii wahine.
Stream in Kapunahala subdivision that enters Kamoʻoaliʻi Stream, Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu; now called Kapunahala.
A modern coined word perhaps; of heavenly character; good; pure; he manao anolani, he naau anolani, he kino anolani.
Of heavenly or royal character, celestial, noble, royal, pure.
Resembling, of similar nature or type; resemblance, similarity. Nā mea ʻano like ʻole, assortment, miscellany.
Similar, in math. Kinona ʻano like. Similar figure.

example_txt.txt: E hele ʻoe i ka ʻānonanona, e nānā i kona ʻaoʻao e hoʻonaʻauao iho.
Go to the ant, study her ways and learn. [The newspaper Ka Nonanona (1841–5) was named for this saying.]

definitions.dtxt: Same as naonao and nonanona, ant.
An ant. See NONANONA. Name of a periodical formerly printed at the islands; aloha oe e Anonanona.
To mix, interweave, intertwine, mixed. Fig. Confused, doubtful. Koko ʻānoni, mixed blood. ʻĀnoni ʻia me ke koko Pākē, mixed with Chinese blood. ʻAnoni ka manaʻo, a confused, doubting mind.
To mix together several ingredients, as different kinds of food; to make a garment of different textures of cloth; to mix together falsehood and truth; to corrupt.
To ponder with anxiety, as an act of the mind; to revolve in one’s mind.
To be agitated with anxiety; to be troubled in mind, so as not to sleep.
To be in doubt or suspense what judgment to form respecting one’s meaning. See ANONONI.
Pas/imp. of ʻānoni.
Same as alani wai, a plant.
Redup. of ʻānoni, perplexity.
See ANONI. To doubt; to be in suspense as to the result of a thing; ua anoninoni ka pakele ana i ka make.
Doubtful; uncertain; he pono anoninoni na paani nawaliwali.
Angry.
Same as ʻānoninoni.
See ANONI. To doubt; to hesitate; to be in suspense, as one in an inquiring state of mind.
Important, vital, main; importance. Mea ʻano nui, important person, loved one, V.I.P., celebrity.
Insignificant, trivial, of no consequence, unattractive; nonsense. He wahi kumu, ʻano ʻole, ʻo ka huhū nō ia, it was such a trifling reason for anger.
Property, i.e., distinctive attribute, as of a number, in math (preceded by ke). See entries below.
Property, as of a number; fraction.
One property, in multiplication (preceded by ke).
Number property, in math (preceded by ke).
See ʻanopili kaʻina hoʻi hope.
Distributive property, in math (preceded by ke). cf. ʻanopili kaʻina hoʻi hope.
Associative property, in math (preceded by ke).
Grouping property, in math (preceded by ke).

definitions.der: [Lit. property (with) order reversed. Also ʻanopili hoʻi hope. Cf. ʻanopili hoʻoili]
definitions.dtxt: Commutative property, in math (preceded by ke).
Equality property, in math (preceded by ke).
Chemical property (preceded by ke).
Opposites property, in math (preceded by ke).
Zero property (preceded by ke). ʻAnopili ʻole o ka hoʻonui. Zero property of multiplication.
Abbreviation for anapuni (perimeter).
Cold; the absence of warmth; ua make au i ke anu, I am dead with the cold; huihui ko’u mau wawae i ke anu.
To be cold; to feel cold; ua anu au i kahi kapa ole, I am cold, haying no clothes; anu aku. la o Maunakea i ka hoilo, Maunakea feels cold in the winter.
Cold; hui, huihui.
Cool, cold; coolness, temperature.
To cool.
Cold, influenza; to have a cold.

example_txt.txt: ʻEhia ke anu o kēia lā?

definitions.dtxt: Temperature, when weather considered cold. Cf. mahana, mehana, wela. See kēkelē. Lit. cold.
Heap, mass, pile.
A pile, as of mats piled one upon another.
Redup. of anu, cold; chilly. hoʻanuanu Caus/sim.
Cold; chilliness.
Cold; huihui. See ANU.
A rainbow.
Hill in uplands of Kaʻahakea, Hawaiʻi, said to have been elevated by a turtle.
Rainbow.

example_txt.txt: E wai ānuenue ana nā wāwae o nā koa.
The feet of the soldiers form a rainbow pattern [of marching soldiers in colored uniforms].

definitions.dtxt: Scallop-like design on tapa and tapa beater.
School in Kaimukī; street, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Caterpillar. Also called ʻenuhe, nuhe.
A large worm that destroys the leaves of vegetables; he peelua, he poko.
A large worm that destroys the leaves of vegetables; cf. enuhe.
Cool, soft fragrance, as of upland forests; sweetness; to be cool, fragrant, and sweet. Also waianuhea. Kō ʻala anuhea kaʻu i honi aku (song), your cool soft fragrance I inhaled.
Infested with caterpillars.
Wrinkled, furrowed; to pucker, wrinkle, shrivel.
Var. name for nenue fish. (AP)
Name of a species of fish; also of limu.
The eating of bad food, fish, or meat, that is spoiled.
Rarely done, as food not sufficiently cooked.
Rough with cold, anuhenuhe ka ili i ke anu, the skin is pimpled with cold.
édifié; sacré; ||en sorte que.
Perseus, a constellation. Māori.
Annuity.
Variants of ʻālunu, greed. Palapala ʻānunu me ka pākaha (song Elbert and Mahoe 63), greedy document of extortion.
To be covetous; to be greedy, etc. See ALUNU, by change of syllables.
To mix up, as hash; awiliwili.
Change of n for l. See ALUNU. An oppressor; one greedy of gain.
See ALUNU. Oppressive; hard; extortionate; he makee, he paa.
A native genus of cucurbit vines (Sicyos). Cf. kūpala.
Chercher a faire des disciples.
A building in a sacred inclosure formed by long poles overhung near the top, which also were tied and covered with white pieces of kapa.
A high place in the heiau before which the idols stood, and where the victims were laid. Laieik. 164.
Name of a ship formerly at the islands; no ka naaupo, ua kapaia aku e makou ka moku he anuu. Lam.
Stairs, jogs, steps, terrace, dais, ledge.
Tower in ancient heiau, about 7 m high and 5.5 m square, as enclosed with white ʻōloa tapa. Cf. nuʻu 1.
Sprain, strain, disjointed vertebra; to stumble, trip, sprain; to land heavily or jar, as when one steps down but there is no step; jarred. Fig. Error, slip; to err. Cf. māui.
A step between two notes on a musical staff. Pili ʻanuʻu, to go up an interval (in music).
Noun indicating comparison of adjectives. ʻAnuʻu kumu, basic stage. ʻAnuʻu waena, comparative degree. ʻAnuʻu loa, superlative degree.
Stair, step. See entry below. Papa ʻanuʻu lalo kai. Underwater terrace.
A rest or jog in a wall. I.
Stairs or steps for ascending a height. Anuu wili, winding stairs. 1 Nal 6:8.
A ledge of rocks.
Jogs or steps in ascending a steep place.
In music, a tone.
A sprain by a false step.
To sprain, as a muscle; hina iho la au maluna o ka papaa lepo a anuu kuu kua, eha loa iho la, I fell upon the hard ground and sprained my back, with great pain.
Step, as in problem solving. Also ʻanuʻu.
In music, anuu, a tone, and hapa, a part. A semitone.
Half-step in music.

data.word: ʻanuʻu hapa a me nā ʻanuʻu maoli

definitions.dtxt: An augmented second in music.
Full step in music.
To strike; to beat; to pound, as kapa.
Hoo. E hooanuunuu ai ke poo, to raise, to elevate the head.

Having steps; wavy, curly, vibrating, undulating; to beat with regular rhythm; to jerk the body, as by osteopaths or masseurs. Alapiʻi ʻānuʻunuʻu, stairs. hoʻānuʻunuʻu To vibrate, undulate, wave, jerk, make steps; wavy, as hair. Leo hoʻanuʻunuʻu, quavering, trilling voice.
See ANUU. Stairs; steps for ascending or descending.
A plaid in a plaided garment.

Having steps like stairs; provided with or made with steps; e ku kakou, a pii aku i ke alanui anuunuu, let us arise and go up the road made with steps; formed in the manner of stairs; he papale anuunuu; rough, as a bad road.
Abbreviation for anawaena (diameter).
Abbreviation for ʻauneki wai (fluid ounce).
A cloud. Ao pouli, a dark cloud. Na mea nana i ke ao. observers of clouds.
Enlightened; informed; instructed; mostly connected with naau, as naauao, and written as one word.
Light; day, in distinction from po. night. For the different periods of time through the night, see Laieik. 30.
The world. O ke ao nei, o keia ao, this world; o kela ao, the future world; na wahi ao, heavenly places.
Light; applied to the light-green of fresh leaves of plants or trees; the green fresh buds; a kupu, a lau, a loa, a ao, a muo, a liko; the middle or new leaf of plants; as, ao ko, ao kalo.
Knowledge; instruction; ke ao ana, doctrine.
To be or become light or day, as in the morning; ua ao ka po, the night has become light.
To awake, as from a vision or dream.
To come to one’s right mind or self-possession.
To teach; instruct.
To enlighten; instruct in one’s duty or conduct.
To reprove; take heed; beware; to warn.
To regard with reverence; to obey.
To charge strictly.
To learn to do a thing; to learn, to study, as a language; e na kumu e, e ao oukou i ka olelo Hawaii, O teachers, study the Hawaiian language.
To copy the example of others. In the imperative, e ao, look out; watch; be on your guard; take heed.
Found only in hoo.
Light, day, daylight, dawn; to dawn, grow light; enlightened; to regain consciousness. Cf. aokanaka.

example_txt.txt: Piliwaiwai lākou ā ao ka pō.
They gambled until night became day [all night long, until dawn].
kēlā pō ā ao aʻe i nehinei
night before last (Lit. that night that dawned yesterday)
ā ao ka pō ā pō ke ao
when night becomes day until the day becomes night [for a night and a day]

definitions.dtxt: To marry; marriage (old term)
Night of the day called Huna, eleventh night of the month, when the hoʻāo nuptials took place

Any kind of a cloud, including ʻōpua, but specifically, high clouds that when wind-blown scud along (kaʻa). See ex., pūnohu 1, and cf. aokū, ao loa, ao ʻōnohi, aouli, ʻōpua, pālāmoa, pāpalamoa, puapuaʻa.

example_txt.txt: a cloud over the distant sea of Kāne [away out, where only cloud and sea are seen]

definitions.dtxt: World, earth, realm.
To be careful, beware, watch out.

example_txt.txt: E ao naʻe ʻoe iā Kalahumoku.
Be careful or you'll be hurt.

definitions.dtxt: Var. of wao, upland area.

example_txt.txt: ʻo ka makuahine nō aʻe ao

definitions.dtxt: The exact image of (preceded by aʻe).
A kind of fine mat.
A kind of fish (no data).
Cloud, general term. See entries below and lālahilewa, loa, ʻōpua. hōkelo ao. Cloud chamber, i.e., a scientific device which detects nuclear particles through the formation of cloud tracks.
Ala ao. Diurnal, i.e., active during the daytime.
A new shoot, leaf, or bud, especially of taro. (UL 17) Cf. ʻahu ʻao, ʻao kahi, ʻao lūʻau.
Dried baked taro or sweet potato; in Kaʻū this food was hung in baskets in the wind so that it dehydrated; it was used on sea journeys and is perhaps related to ō, sea rations.
Ship biscuit, pilot bread, hardtack.
Dried kalo or potatoes (i.e., kalo or potatoes baked and dried,) used for food.
Sea-bread or any hard bread was called ʻao by Hawaiians when they first saw it.
Abbreviation for ʻaoʻao (page).

Newell’s puffin or shearwater (Puffinus puffinis newelli), said to be the only sea bird endemic to Hawaiʻi, and to breed only in Hawaiʻi; glossy black above, white beneath; endangered. Also liʻo. Hoʻokahi nō hua a ka ʻaʻo, the ʻaʻo lays but a single egg [said of an only child].
Art., ka. Name of a species of bird. Laieik. 29.

Instruction, teaching, doctrine, learning, instruction book, manual, advice, counsel; to learn, teach, advise, instruct, train, tutor, coach, prescribe, admonish. Many kinds of instruction are listed below as aʻo heluhelu, aʻo hōkū, aʻo kiko, aʻo loko, aʻo palapala, aʻo piliʻōlelo. See lohe for idioms.

example_txt.txt: briefly taught; to learn a little [said of lowly individuals]
E aʻo kākou iā ʻoe i ke kino lele o kō wahine.
We will teach you the flying power [lit., body] of your wife.
E hoʻāʻo mai ana ʻoe e hīmeni?
Won't you sing a little? [Pidgin, “try sing”]
kalohe ā lohe mai ke aʻo
nani ā lohe mai ke aʻo

definitions.dtxt: To test, try, attempt, taste, undertake, experiment, endeavor, tempt; to do a little (equivalent of the pidgin English “try” before verbs; see ex., kuhi hewa).

example_txt.txt: ʻo nā pali aʻo Koʻolau Loa
The woman, Pele, is very active.

definitions.dtxt: Part. replacing o, of, and ʻo, subject marker, in songs. (Gram. 2.8, 9.13)
Kiʻina aʻo. Pedagogy, i.e., the art of teaching.
A snail; he pupu.
Also the name of a species of small fish.
Name of a tree, not found on these islands, but in some foreign couentry; often spoken of in the ancient meles.
To bark, as a dog; to howl, bowwow; lamentation, cry of distress; doleful creature, sad (perhaps aoa).
To make a dog bark or howl.
A small shellfish (Melampus castaneus), strung in leis. Also makaʻaoa.
Same as ʻiliahi, sandalwood. (AP)
Name for sacrificial places near fishponds where semiannual offerings were made, as of taro, bananas, mullet, kohekohe sedge, and black pigs. (Ii 26)
Name of a sea breeze associated with Honolulu and elsewhere. Also ʻAoʻaoa or Ulumano.
Hour. (Ka Nonanona, 1844)
A howling, as of a dog or ravenous beast; a wailing for the dead.
To howl, as a dog or wolf.
To howl or wail for grief for the loss of friends; to howl for a calamity that has come upon one.
To cry, as one in distress and anguish. To howl as in despair.
Howling, as of a ravenous beast. Holoholona aoaoa, howling beasts. Hence, cross; angry; rough in language.

Ao, for wao, a desert place, and akua, God. A lonely place; generally a barren place; a desert. More properly written waoakua, the region of the gods, ghosts, hobgoblins, etc. See WAOAKUA. The proper orthography is auakua.
Godly cloud. Fig. Rainbow.

definitions.der: [Lit. teach until (becoming a) teacher. luna aʻoākumu. Student teacher field service supervisor]
definitions.dtxt: Student teacher; to student teach.
A rainy wind at Niʻihau, said to be so-called because it creeps (nihi).
To make one’s escape from justice; to depart secretly from fear of being taken; e aoao malu ana, i mahuka, to escape secretly, to run away.
To show or point out a way for one to go; aoao aku la o mea, eia ko alanui.
What one has been taught to say or do; kahea iho la e like me ke aoao ana, he called out as he had been instructed. Laieik. 170.
To accustom; to practice; e hoomaamaa. See MAA. To repeat frequently.
To teach; to give instruction to one how to act on occasion. Laieik. 12.
Side, boundary, hemisphere. See ex., ʻānonanona.

example_txt.txt: on the other side, on the other hand
ke koho ʻana o nā ʻaoʻao
option of the parties [to an agreement]

definitions.dtxt: Group, team, denomination; party (political).
Page.

example_txt.txt: ʻO kona mau ʻaoʻao āpau he maikaʻi wale nō.
All his ways are very good.

definitions.dtxt: Way, habit, mode of living, education.

example_txt.txt: We have the owl as our family god.

definitions.dtxt: Family gods, ʻaumākua.
Leg or side, of a triangle. See entries below and kukuna, ʻaoʻao huli alo, ʻaoʻao launa, ʻaoʻao pili.

example_txt.txt: side stroke, in swimming; to swim the side stroke

definitions.dtxt: See kīloi ʻaoʻao.
Almak, a star.
Street, Kalihi Uka near the approach to the Wilson tunnel, Honolulu.

The side of a thing, as land, couentry; the coast of a couentry. Ma ka aoao o puna a me Kau ka holo ana, along the shore of Puna and Kau was the sailing. Pehea na aoao o Ferani? what are the boundaries of France?
Trop. A way, habit, manner, peculiar to any one. A course of life.
Stratagem, plot, advice, counsel.

A small seaside shrub (Wikstroemia sp.). The root bark is used externally for sores, and stems and bark of branches for coughs. Branches and leaves are mixed with rasped seeds of Barringtonia asiatica (syn. B. speciosa) to stupefy fish. See ʻakia 1.
Redup. of ʻaoa 1.
Same as ʻaoa 5, a sea breeze.
Name of a pleasant seabreeze at Honolulu; he paa o aoaoa lani.
Debit side (in bookkeeping).
Right or leeward side of air island. See Kona.
Aupuni ʻaoʻao ʻelua. Two-party system of government.
Majority party, in politics. Cf. ʻaoʻao hapa ʻuʻuku, ʻaoʻao kālaiʻāina.
Minority party, in politics. Cf. ʻaoʻao hapa nui, ʻaoʻao kālaiʻāina.
Cover page. Ua loaʻa ka inoa a me ka helu wahi o ka mea kākau ma ka ʻaoʻao hoʻākāka. The author’s name and address are found on the cover page. Also ʻaoʻao inoa.
Reform party.

definitions.der: [Lit. side (to) bring a complaint. Cf. ʻaoʻao kūpale. See loio hoʻopiʻi, mea hoʻopiʻi]
definitions.dtxt: Prosecution, i.e., the prosecuting party in a court case.

definitions.der: [Lit. side (which) faces (the right angle). See ʻaoʻao pili]
definitions.dtxt: Opposite leg or side, of a right triangle.
See ʻaoʻao hoʻākāka.
Political party.
Political party. See ʻaoʻao hapa nui, ʻaoʻao hapa ʻuʻuku.
Base, as of a triangle, in math. Abb. ʻak.
Opposition, opponent, as in a trial; minority party.
Defense, as in a trial.

definitions.der: [Lit. side (which) defends. Cf. ʻaoʻao hoʻopiʻi. See loio kūpale, mea hoʻopiʻi]
definitions.dtxt: Defense, i.e., the defendant’s case or counsel in a lawsuit.
Defense, in sports. See entry below. Also ʻaoʻao pale.
Perpendicular, of a triangle.
Corresponding side, of a triangle. See ʻaoʻao huli alo, ʻaoʻao pili.
A variety of taro (no data).
Scalene, in math. Huinakolu ʻaoʻao like ʻole. Scalene triangle.
Hypotenuse.
Windward side.
Death, afterlife.
Base, as of a triangle.
Young of the kūpīpī fish, or alternate name.
The name of a species of broad fish; he ia kino palahalaha.
Same as ʻaoʻao kūpale.
Defense, in sports. Also ʻaoʻao kūpale.
Adjacent leg or side, of a right triangle. See ʻaoʻao huli alo.
A green fish. (And.)
A species of fish of a green color.

See OE. To move along with a rustling, rippling noise, as a wave of the sea; to make a noise like a rippling wave; aoe ka ale o ka moana, the slight wave of the ocean ripples, etc.; he hele wale no e like me ka aoe.
Same as ʻaʻole, not. See chant, wāhia. ʻAʻoe e ʻole! Certainly not! ʻAʻoe hoʻi e ʻole! Absolutely not! ʻAʻoe au e hele, I will not go.
One of the forms of the adverb of negation; aohe, aole, aoe, no, not, nor, a universal negative.
Used as adverbs and interjections. What! how great! truly so; a confirmation of the declaration of another; also, surprising; admirable; never so many, etc.

None; no, not; to have or be none; there is no one who (in subordinate phrases). ʻAʻohe is a contraction of the negative ʻaʻole and he, the indefinite article (Gram. 10.2). It is often followed by zero possessives, as ʻaʻohe āna hana, he has no work; ʻaʻohe o ʻu makemake i poi, I don't want any poi. Today a gesture is commonly used by all races to replace ʻaʻohe koena, there isn't any more, or ʻaʻole, no. The gesture, taken front Hawaiians, is a quick flick of the hand with the palm turned downward and away front the body, originally significant of an empty hand. ʻOia kamaʻilio aku ā ʻea ka waha, ʻaʻohe lohe ʻia mai, while talking until the tongue is coated, [yet] no one is listened to.
No; not; not at all; by no means. See AOLE and AOE.
Used as adverbs and interjections. What! how great! truly so; a confirmation of the declaration of another; also, surprising; admirable; never so many, etc.
Used as adverbs and interjections. What! how great! truly so; a confirmation of the declaration of another; also, surprising; admirable; never so many, etc.
Used as adverbs and interjections. What! how great! truly so; a confirmation of the declaration of another; also, surprising; admirable; never so many, etc.
Inappropriate. Niʻihau.
Ao, to teach, and hele, to go.
To teach as one travels; to preach traveling about; ua aohele o Kaahumanu me ka hoohuli i na kanaka a pau ma ka pono, Kaahumanu went about teaching the people and turning them to do what was right.
To declare; publish, as a law; as a chief when he went from place to place; aohele na 'lii i na kanawai.
To teach while traveling; to act, as itinerant teacher, preacher, missionary.
Reader, primer; to learn or teach to read.
Used as adverbs and interjections. What! how great! truly so; a confirmation of the declaration of another; also, surprising; admirable; never so many, etc.

Resistance, i.e., opposition to the flow of electricity, or any opposition that slows down or prevents movement of electrons through a conductor. Sh. kāohiohi. Āohiohi ea. Air resistance, i.e., the force of air against a moving object. Lima āohiohi. Resistance arm, i.e., the distance from the fulcrum to the resistance force in a lever. Manehu āohiohi. Resistance force.
Name of a star, possibly Jupiter, Lit. star light. Cf. Hōkūao.
Astronomy, astronomer; to teach or learn astronomy.
Astronomy as a science; also an astronomer; pepehiia ae la ke alii moku a me ka mea aohoku, the captain of the ship was slain and the astronomer.

definitions.der: [aʻo, to teach, and hōkū, a star]
definitions.dtxt: To teach astronomy.
To reteach. Lit. teach again. Puke aʻo hou. Reteaching book.
Same as oka, dregs.
To be crushed or chewed finely for swallowing.
Ao, cloud, and kahaea. A kind of cloud as it appears in the heavens; he aokahaea i kinohinohiia.
One remaining leaf (ʻao) on an old taro stalk, said of an old taro about to die.
Traditional knowledge-based learning. Lit. learning (with a) traditional knowledge base.
Performance-based learning, kinesthetic-based learning. Lit. learning (with a) behavior base.
Language-based learning. Lit. learning (with a) language base.
Spiritually-based learning. Lit. learning (with a) spiritual base.
To think or behave reasonably; human enlightment, civilization; rational.
Redup. of ʻāoka.
Any fine particles of matter, as saw-dust, lees of wine, dregs of any liquid; hence,
An offensive smell, as connected with such matter.
See OKA. TO pulverize; make fine; to bruise or pound fine; aweluawelu. See oKAOKA.
Spelling book; to learn or teach spelling.
Manual of punctuation; to learn or teach punctuation.
Rain cloud, mist.
The name of a rain; he ua aoku.
Realm of homeless spirits.
Nature. Puni ao kūlohelohe. Naturalist. Also kanaka puni ao kūlohelohe.
Street, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Socialization; to socialize, i.e., fit, teach or train (someone) for a social environment or to associate sociably with others. Lit. teach (to) associate (with) people.

No, not, never; to be none, to have none, -un. Commonly pronounced ʻaʻale (Gram. 2.7). Cf. ʻaʻohe. ʻAʻole loa! Certainly not! Not at all! I should say not! never! ʻAʻole loa anei ʻoe i hele i Hilo? Have you ever been to Hilo? ʻAʻole paha, probably not, perhaps not (polite). ʻAʻole i maʻamaʻahia, unfamiliar.

Not, no; a universal negative. It is also found as aole, aoe, ole, etc.: Aole ku, aole hina, aole moe. Never quiet, never falling, never sleeping. Aole hai ke hoihoi aku. He does not cease, though sent away.
To not; not to do; aole oia i hana, he did it not.

definitions.notes: Note: The sense 2, to deny, is more generally found under the form ole.
definitions.dtxt: To deny; refuse to do a thing; aole ae la ia i hoopono ia ia, ia manawa, he refused (he did not) reform himself at that time.
Not to be; no existence. Aole e ole, a phrase signifying the strongest affirmation, as, it cannot but be, it cannot be otherwise, it will not fail of being so, there is no not in the case, etc.

An adverb of denying, refusing; no; not; a universal negative; for euphony’s sake, it takes different forms; as, aohe, aole, ohe, ole, and aoe. The form ole is privative in its meaning, and may be added to almost any adjective, noun (proper names excepted,) or verb in the language. It is equivalent to the English inseparable negative particles, less, in, un, etc. See OLE.
See AOLE above. It cannot but be. Lit. It cannot be not.
A very affectionate salutation; now used only among the old people; the modern term is aloha.
See under AOHAA. How very! Aole loa, God forbid.
“Stay tuned” or “to be continued” as during a TV program.
Street, Honolulu airport, named by Mary Kawena Pukui.
A strong affirmation; how true; true indeed; so it is.
Street, Honolulu airport, named by Mary Kawena Pukui.
Same as ālai. I ʻapa kāua i ka ʻāolo o ka ʻōkaʻi me ka pulelehua i kō kāua ala hele, we were delayed by the obstruction of the moths and butterflies in our way.
Long cloud; high or distant cloud; stratus cloud along the horizon. Fig. A distinguished person.

Ao, cloud, and loa, long. A comparison of clouds, as high and low; applied also to men, as more or less honorable; o Ku ke aoloa, o Ku ke aopoko, Ku is the long cloud, Ku is the short cloud. See AOPOKO.
Street, Honolulu airport, named by Mary Kawena Pukui.
Innermost teaching, inspiration. I ka haʻalele ʻana aku i kou aʻo loko ʻana mai, from the neglect of Thy inspirations.
Unexpanded leaf blade of taro; to offer as a sacrifice. E ʻao lūʻau a kaulima, offer young taro leaves five times as sacrifice.
To procure abortion; oo no lakou i na keiki, aomilo a hahai, ua nui na kamalii i make.
definitions.notes: Note: The methods of procuring abortion were numerous and various.

definitions.dtxt: Sandy; sandy soil.
Dirt; he lepo, he lau one. See ONE, sand.
Six, especially in counting in a series; six times. Pōʻaono, Saturday;
See ONO, the simple form. Six; with other forms, eono, ke ono, he ono.
A contracted poetical phrase for aole no ka e kala, not lately done, long ago.
The name of a broad mass of clouds extending over a great space.
A mass of pillar clouds as seen at night.
See A oo under A. Name of an instrument for destroying unborn children, etc. see KOHOLUA.
Elderly, middle-aged. Cf. oʻo.
See Oo, to be mature. Epithet of a full grown man when all his faculties of body and mind have come to maturity; he aoo ia, he is full grown.
See ā 2.
Cloud with rainbow (ʻōnohi) colors.
He aoonohi ulaula; an expression signifying that a storm is near.

Ao, cloud, and pua, an arrow. Sharp-pointed clouds as they appear in the sky; me he mau aoopua la e kau ana, pela ke kau ana o ka make maluna o na kanaka, as sharp-pointed clouds hang in the sky, so death hangs over men.
Instruction, education; to teach or learn writing.
Grammar, instruction in grammar; to teach or learn grammar.

definitions.der: [Lit. A short cloud. Fig. Men of little weight of character]
definitions.dtxt: See AOLOA.

New Zealand. I ka hiki ʻana o ke kanaka mua ʻo Kupe i ka ʻāina ʻo Aotearoa, ʻike akula ʻo ia he ao keʻokeʻo lōʻihi ma luna o ia ʻāina. When the first man, Kupe, arrived in New Zealand, he saw a long, white cloud over the land. Māori. Also nukilani.
Firmament, sky, blue vault of heaven.
Var. of ʻōuli.
A blue cloud, i.e., the sky, the firmament. The visible arch of heaven.

example_txt.txt: aia iluna lilo ke aouli la

definitions.notes: Note: In grammar, it is used for mood; as, aouli hai, indicative mood; aouli kauoha,imperative mood; aouli kuihe, subjunctive mood; aouli kuwale, infinitive mood.

definitions.dtxt: The stars collectively; the host of heaven. Heaven itself.
Street, Honolulu airport, named by Mary Kawena Pukui.
Abbreviation for ʻāpana, land parcel, used in surveying.
Abbreviation for ʻApelila (April).
Meddling; officious; busy; mischievous, as a child; careless; blundering; slow; tardy; nahili, he lohi.
Roll or ream, as of paper; bolt, as of cloth.
See lima ʻāpā.
A roll; a bundle, as a piece of cloth, or a ream of paper.
Name of a wind; i kuipeia e ka makani apaa, he was knocked down flat by the wind apaa.
Name of a region of couentry below the ma’u or waokanaka on the side of the mountains.
Arid, dry; dry area, clod of dirt. Pili hoʻōla ka ua i ka ʻāpaʻa, akin to a healer is the rain to the arid plains.
Land one has lived on for a long time (a term of affection related to paʻa, firmly bound).
Same as wao ʻilima.
Native of a place and descendant from its earliest line of chiefs. (Malo 24)
Endemic. Cf. ʻōiwi.

Redup. of ʻapa 1; to procrastinate, deliberate, slow. hōʻapaʻapa To slow down others; to lag, dillydally, bother. He ʻaumakua hoʻoluhi, hōʻapaʻapa i ke kahuna, a family god who bothers and interferes with the priest.
Guile, deceit; to practice such. See ʻapakeʻe.
Guile; deceit; evil generally. That which is untrue; false in opposition to truth and stability. Haalele i ka oiaio no a mea apaapa, forsook the truth for a false thing.
One who frequently changes his situation.
To be evilly disposed; to be treacherous; to deceive; to be mischievous.
Unsettled; unstable; irresolute.
Without truth; deceitful; lalau wale iho no ka olelo.
Careless; without thought; kapulu. See APA.
The name of a species of fish; he ula apaapaa.
Name of a strong wind associated with Kohala, Hawaiʻi.
Dry, parched.
Same as ʻāpaʻa 2.
A kind of lobster (no data).
Firm, hard, compact. See ex., mahani.
Old settlement area near Lapakahi, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi, excavated by Bishop museum archaeologists in 1968; named for a strong Kohala wind.
Name of a wind at Kohala.
Firm; hard; compact, as a well made road; he alanui apaapaa, aole pueho o ka lepo.
Small pieces, fragments. Cf. ʻāpana.
Delay, procrastination.
Quick, effective repartee; to retort thus.
A speech in opposition; a rapid reply. See APANI.
To oppose one with words; to reply quickly; to overwhelm with words.
To make one forget the subject of dispute.
To doubt; perhaps, maybe.
See paha 6.
Var. of pahū, explosion.
The sound of a trumpet; the bursting forth of a sound suddenly; the sound from a sudden falling of a substance.
To cut squarely off, chop; a piece cut off at right angles.
Same as kūnehi, a sunfish.
Conspicuous, as one dressed oddly. (And.)
To cram, pack full, stuff (And.)
Pieces cut off or cut in two, as wood, sugar-cane, etc.
A kind of pau.
To cut up; to cut square off, as a piece of timber.
To cut in pieces; to chop off; to cut in two, as pieces of wood or sugar-cane.
To stuff food into one’s mouth.
Marked; distinguished by some mark or dress or cut of the hair; nani na kanaka apahu.
To repel, as like charges in a magnet. Comb. ʻā- + pahupahu. See entry below.
