Faded, as material which has been left in the sun. Niʻihau.
Same as pai 5, a fish trap.
A deep, long fish net for catching the opae.
To seize, lay hold of, disarrange, displace; to spread, as sunlight. Ka ʻapakau ʻana iho o nā kukuna a ka lā maluna a ka ʻili o ke kai, the spreading of the rays of the sun on the surface of the sea.
To seize upon; to lay hold of; to hold on to, as on falling.
To lay hold of things and displace them, as a child.
To give thoughtlessly, as a man gives away his food until it is all gone.
Deceit, dishonesty: deceitful, corrupt, inaccurate.
Apple (Pyrus malus syn. M. sylvestris). Also poma.
To go into the presence of a chief, and on account of shame, return without making a request.
Hilly, craggy. Fig. Impertinent, rude.
Redup. of ʻāpali.
To hurry, hasten. (And.)
To hurry; to hasten.
Bolt of material. See ʻīālole.
Red on the flesh when burned; hence, applied to anger.
Red; flushed with anger.

Piece, slice, portion, fragment, section, segment, installment, part, land parcel, lot, district, sector, ward, precinct; chop, as of lamb. A kuleana, land division, may consist of several ʻāpana, Cf. kapa ʻāpana. Kōmike komo ʻāpana, visiting committee, as of a church.
Same as mile 1. (KAM. 76:45)
Makaʻāinana ʻāpana. Constituent, i.e., a voter in a district who is represented by an elected official.
Valley, central Niʻihau.

A fragment; a patch; a piece; a slice; a piece, as of bread; a portion; apana poohiwi, a shoulder piece for a garment. A piece of any substance; of a human body. A division of people. Apana V., a sector of a circle. Anahon. Apana uuku, a little piece.

Congressional district, in government. Ua hoʻi aku nei ke Kenekoa i kōna ʻāpana ʻahaʻōlelo lāhui ponoʻī e hōʻike ai no nā kānāwai i puka. The Senator returned to his congressional district to report about the laws that had passed.
Errand. Trad. Also hana.
Quadrant. Cf. ʻāpana noiʻi.
Potsherd.
Line segment, in math.
Increment, i.e., one of a series of additions in groups or quantity. Comb. ʻāpana + kahi.
Phylactery.
Quadrat, i.e., a rectangular plot used for ecological or population studies. Cf. ʻāpana hapahā.
Redup. of ʻāpana; fragments, pieces; to cut into pieces (FOR. 5:591) Nā pōkā ʻāpanapana, shrapnel.
Moena ʻili ʻāpanapana. Floor tile. Also kile ʻili, kile papahele.
Central business district. Cf. kaona.
Apana and poai, to surround. A segment of a circle. Anah. 23.
Segment of a circle.
A kind of lehua tree with dark-red flower.
Short for ʻapapane, a bird. See ʻōhiʻa ʻāpane.
Red, flushed, blushing.
A species of bird much valued on account of its red feathers.
A species of the lehua, the ohia, with red blossoms, which are food for birds.
To block, shut. Fig. An unwelcome visitor who monopolizes conversation.
To go from house to house tattling and doing nothing valuable; he mea hele kauhale e apani ana ia hale aku ia hale aku me ka holoholo kauhale.
Window pane.
See APANI above and APAAPANI.
Redup. of ʻāpani, to block.
Name of a strong wind blowing over Kohala Point.
To deceive. See APAAPA.
Stratum, flat, especially a coral flat.
Legendary upper stratum and abode of the gods (preceded by ke).
Chiefs of the highest rank, as nīʻaupiʻo; gods. E ala, ē ʻāpapa nuʻu, e ala, ē ke ʻāpapa lani! (UL 196). Awake, gods of high station, awake, gods of highest station!
A Hawaiian honey creeper (Himatione sanguinea), with crimson body and black wings and tail, found on all the main Hawaiian Islands. Its feathers occasionally were used for featherwork. Also ʻakakane.
The name of a bird on Hawaii; a i kani aku ka leo o ka apapane. Laieik. 29. It has red feathers. Hulu apapane, the red feathers of the apapane.
Same as laupapa 1, reef.
Reef. Niʻihau. Ula ʻāpapapa, Slipper lobster. Also ula pāpapa. See ʻōmā.
All, entirely.
All, entirely. Nā kānaka āpau, all the people, everyone, everybody.
Large taro-like plants (Alocasia macrorrhiza, Xanthosoma robustum).
definitions.notes: Note: A number of beliefs concerning ʻape have been recorded. ʻApe was planted by a gate or fence because the irritating sap of the leaves was thought to ward off evil spirits; leaves were placed under tapas or mats on which the sick lay for the same reason. ʻApe was not planted near the house for fear the residents might become sick. Varieties are qualified by the colors kea or keʻokeʻo (white), or hiwa or ʻeleʻele (dark).

definitions.dtxt: A plant with broad leaves, acrid to the taste, like kalo, but more so; it is eaten for food in times of scarcity.
Full of knots, as a string; full of small round stones, as a road.
All endemic species of Gunnera, huge leafed forest perennial herbs, with thick, prostrate stems rising at the tip to about 120 cm. Called hāhā on kauaʻi.
Elastic, flexible, limber.
The motion of the gills of a fish in water; the breathing of a fish. See aPI.

The name of a remarkable plant found near the top of Waialeale on Kauai; length of stalk, twenty feet or over; leaves, six feet in diameter, somewhat resembling, in shape, the ape ; the leaf is round and attached to the stem in the center.
Same as peʻapeʻa, bat.
An unidentified cephalopod.
Same as ʻōpeʻapeʻa 3, half leaf.
A species of squid not eaten; he apeapea noloko o ke kai.
Var. of līpeʻepeʻe, a seaweed.
A species of limu; he limu apeepee.
Afghanistan; Afghan, Afghani. Also ʻAfekanisana.
The Kauaʻi ʻelepaio (Chasiempis sandwichensis sclateri).
Old, aged.
Volcanic lava or ejecta of any kind, rough lava, lava flow.
Apricot (Prunus armeniaca).
Africa; African.
Africa; African. Also ʻApelika. ʻAferika Hema. South Africa; south African.
Africa; African. Also ʻAferika. Lepupalika ʻApelika Waena. Central African Republic. Līlia ʻApelika. Amaryllis. ʻApelika Hema. South Africa; South african.
April.
April. Abb. ʻAp.
Name of the month April.
Same as ʻāleuleu; long coarse mats used to hold food.
A species of poor mats; ua lawe aku au i apeu moena; large mats, but very poor ones.
Kind of tapa, wrapped about images. (KAM. 64:12)
Same as ʻāleuleu. He wahi ʻāpeupeu moena kaʻu i lawe mai nei, I’ve just brought some ordinary coarse mats [a polite way to disparage a gift that may actually be fine].
See the foregoing. Apeupeu applies to kapa as well as mats.
Soft spot in the temples; soft part of the human body between the pelvic cone and the lowest rib; under part of an animal’s body (sometimes preceded by ke).
A surgeonfish (Acanthurus guttatus), 20 cm long.
Fish gills; to breathe through gills.
To palpitate, throb, tremble, shake, quiver; to beat, as the pulse; to stir, as waves; palpitation, quivering.

A decoy stick basket with a wide opening; it was baited, and after the fish were accustomed to coming for food, a trap was substituted. Ke ao 'ō'ō, ke ʻapi wai (FS 201), the sharp-pointed cloud, the water basket (a cloud full of rain].
To gather together, as people or things. (And.)
The gills of a fish; same as mahamaha.
The fins with which a fish swims.
The beating of the pulse.
Greediness; covetousness; ke api o ka ia nui pimoe.
A small net.
The name of a very flat fish.
The drinking (breathing) of a fish in the water.
The flowing of water or of blood in the veins.
To flap, as the gills of a fish when breathing out of water.
To shake, as a cocoanut leaf in the breeze.
To tremble, as the liver of a hog when killed.
To throb; to beat, as the pulse.
To be greedy; to covet this and that thing.
To gather together, as people to one spot; to bring into a small compass, as baggage; e api mai a uuku.
Redup. of ʻapi 4; elastic, springy; short of breath.
Redup. of ʻapi 3.

Filled, as a basket; abundant, as a feast. ʻAhaʻaina ka lani i ka lolo o kūkahuilalani, ʻapiʻapi kanalani (FOR. 6:398), the chief feasts at the lolo ceremony of Kū the-heavenly-lightning, abundant repletion.
Curly.
Tapa-beater design.

A variety of taro in the piko group, having light-colored corms which are good for poi or table taro; red (ʻula) and white (kea) forms exist; it is called “curly” (ʻāpiʻi) because of crinkles under the leaf.
A ti plant with green, crinkly leaves.
A species of large kalo.
Wavy, crimpy, kinky, very curly; tempestuous, as waves.
A kind of seaweed that is tough and not eaten much, perhaps Amansia glomerata.
Name of a species of shrub or bush.
Curling, as the hair; he lauoho apiipii.
Having suction cups, as the tentacles of the octopus; suction cups; spotted.
Halo ʻāpikapika. Suction cup fin, as beneath the stomach of an ʻoʻopu.
Spotted. See OPIKOPIKO.

Crafty, cunning, mischievous, deceitful, dishonest, naughty, treacherous, peculiar, strange; trickery, treachery, rogue, rascal, mischief-maker, humbug. Ka mea ʻāpiki, however, but, yet. Lei ʻāpiki, a name given to the ʻilima lei because it was believed to attract mischievous spirits; some did not wear this lei but others considered it lucky.
Sleight; cunning; craft.
To sport at the expense of another; to be roguish; to act mischievously.
To beg; to live at the expense of others.
Roguish; mischievous; lawless; addicted to roguish tricks.
Of or belonging to the ilima, yellow flowers, etc.
Deceitful; he hoopunipuni; he lei apiki, he lei ilima.
Troubled, agitated, as the sea. Cf. kūpikipikiʻō.
Fold, pleat; to fold, pleat.
To clean taro greens by peeling the stems.
A kind of variegated or spotted tapa.
A kind of agitation of the mind; anxiety; doubt.
A particular kind of kapa.
To fold up, as a piece of kapa.
To spread out one upon another for the purpose of folding, as sheets of paper, kapa, cloth, etc.
To multiply thoughts.
Lane, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu, named for John K. Apio, caretaker of Oʻahu Cemetery for about 50 years. (TM)
Abib, a Hebrew month.
Name of a month.

The principles of the Hebrew calendar are found in the Torah, which contains several calendar-related commandments, including God’s commandment during the Exodus from Egypt to fix the month of Aviv as the first month of the year [Exodus 12:2].
United, joined, coupled; double. He waʻa ʻāpipi, a double canoe. hoʻāpipi To join, couple.
United; joined together, as the two canoes of a double canoe; he mau waa elua i hoapipiia.

Circle, circuit, hoop, loop, band, bracelet, hoop-shaped earring, girdle, belt, ring, embrace; to span, reach around, embrace, put an arm around, clasp. Many compounds with apo are listed below. Cf. kahaapo.
Union of the molar or cheekbone with the temporal bone.

A hoop; a band; apo hao, an iron hoop; in grammar, kaha apo, the sign of a parenthesis, thus: ( ); a ring or clasp for the fingers or arm; apo gula, a golden ring. He apo gula pepeiao, a golden ear-ring. In geometry, a circle. Fig. Apo o ka make, bands of death. A certain kind of belt worn by women.
Apo na poe a ka ua kuahine,
Noho hoomakue i ka uka o Kahui.
Ka hookohukohu puahi ole a ka ua.
The union of the cheek bone with the iwi maha. Anat. 11.
To catch, grasp, grab, hug, seize and retain, catch, acceptance, admission. Fig. To perceive, understand. Cf. ʻaʻapo, ʻapoa, ʻapoʻapo. E ʻapo ʻia e nā kila, covered by patents.
A variety of sweet potato (no data). (FOR. 5:664–5)
A variety of taro (no data).
To catch, as a ball; to receive or reception, in football. See lawena, ʻapo lilo.

example_txt.txt: Ua ʻapo kōna hoa kime i ke kinipōpō, a holo akula i ke kī pai.
His teammate caught the ball and went in for a layup.

definitions.dtxt: A particular variety of sweet potatoes.
To catch at, as with the hand; to hook in.
To span or reach round. To put one’s arm around another. Laieik. 117.
To receive; to embrace, as a long-absent friend.
To fall upon one, as an expression of affection.
To contain, hold or encircle.
To receive, as into the mind; to apprehend intellectually.
To receive and embrace, as a truth.
To receive; to take out of sight, as a cloud.
To rebound, in basketball. He 45 ʻai a me 8 ʻāpō a Karl Malone. Karl Malone has 45 points and 8 rebounds. Var. of ʻapo.
Pas/imp. of ʻapo. Ua ʻapoa e ka ua nahua o nā pali, caught by the pelting rain of the cliffs.
Dog collar.
Highest heavens or space.
Hill, as of sweet potatoes; bunch, as of taro; to hill up plants.
A bunch, as of kalo; a hill of potatoes; he apuepue.

Redup. of ʻapo; catching, grasping; attack, fit, heart palpitation, agitation; to have an attack, fit. Ā lohe aʻela ʻo Heloke ke aliʻi, ʻapoʻapo aʻela kona ʻōʻili, when Herod the king heard, his heart was troubled.
Half-grown stage of the āhole, a fish.
A catching; a seizing; a forcing.

See APO. To catch at frequently; to snatch or scramble for; to seize upon a person or thing; to seize or come upon one, as fear; apoapo ka naau i ka makau; to be troubled with doubt, anxiety; apoapo ka oili; to be troubled with jealousy. Apoapo, lelele ka oili, to palpitate, as the heart.
Camp, i.e., a gathering of people to learn or practice certain skills. Sh. ʻāpoʻepoʻe. See hoʻomoana. ʻĀpoʻe kamepiula. Computer camp. ʻĀpoʻe pōhīnaʻi. basketball camp.
To assemble.
Apo, ring, and gula, gold.
A gold ring, but often applied to an earring of any material.
Same as ʻōkuhe, an ʻoʻopu, a fish.
Iron hoop or band, named for the king’s guard under the monarchy.
Apo, hoop, and hao, iron.
An iron hoop, See APO.
A name formerly of the king’s guard.
Orbit, as of stars and planets.
Depression, hollow, hollowed, pitted.
Geologic depression, as Death Valley.
Redup. of ʻāpoho.
Pounding, slapping, as the sea. Cf. poho, ʻūpoho.
Fullback, in football. Comb. ʻā- + pohu (var. of pahu).
Belt loop, as on a pair of pants. Ua hala iaʻu kekahi apo ʻili kuapo i koʻu komo ʻana i koʻu ʻili kuapo. I missed a belt loop when I put on my belt.
To pounce; to crouch in order to conceal (UL 203); to attempt to conceal an article rather than share it.
Apostate.
Phonics.
Var. of ʻapakau.
To take hold of and displace. See APAKAU.
A short piece; cut, broken off; to cut into short pieces.
A short piece cut off.
To cut up into short pieces.
Apostle.
Telephone receiver.
Apocrypha.
Apostle.
Gold bracelet; formerly a gold ring.
Rubber band.
Point, Kaupō qd., Maui. Also known as Lae o Apole (Coulter.)
Smooth. Also molemole.
To record a voice.
Magical voice snatching (a sorcerer was believed able to snatch a victim’s voice so that he could not chant or sing); to snatch a voice thus.
Redup. of ʻāpole.
To intercept (the ball), in football. Lit. take-possession catch.
Bracelet, signet.
A signet; a finger-ring.
Headphone, headset.
Comprehension; to comprehend. Lit. grasp meaning. Nīnau ʻapomanaʻo. comprehension question.
Embracing, grasping, catching. Cf. ʻapo 1.
A take, i.e., a successful shot in movie or video production. See paʻi.
To approve, confirm, justify, ratify, recommend, commend, consent, accept, endorse, adopt; to pass, as a bill. Cf. pono, proper, right.
To approve, accept, justify, find not guilty in a trial; approved, worthy; approbation, sanction, approval.
To approve; to treat as innocent. The opposite of ahewa.
To justify; to be accepted.
Hoo. To exculpate from blame.
To clear, as one charged with a crime. The opposite of hoohewa.
To ratify, as a legislative bill or a treaty.

example_txt.txt: Ua ʻāpono ʻia ka pila ma ka ʻAhaʻōlelo Lāhui.
The bill was ratified in Congress.

definitions.dtxt: Approval (sometimes preceded by ke). See ex., kaʻa malalo 2.
Hoo. Justification; treatment of one as just.
Guarantee, assurance. Nani ka mahalo i nā kuʻikahi, mehe ʻāpono ola e paʻa ai ke aupuni, much impressed by the treaties that seem to assure the security of the nation.
To hide, seek shelter; to gad about, a gadder.
An idle, lazy person who goes from house to house; aia i ka apoo kauhale.
To go from house to house, doing no work; ua apoo hele i kauhale i ka ua.
Paper tray slot, as for a computer printer. See poho pepa, poho pākuʻi.
Hollow, cavity; depressed.
A deep or hollow place, as the hollow of the hand or foot; the frog or hollow place of a horse’s foot.
Hatband.
Apo, a ring, and pepeiao, ear. A ring for the ear; an ear-ring.
Hoop earring.
Tomorrow (often preceded by kēlā, that; perhaps related to pō, night, since the Hawaiian “day” began at nightfall). Sometimes shortened to pōpō. (Gram. 8.6)
Tomorrow.
Lit. When the night nights, i.e., tomorrow. Apopo kela, la, aku, day after tomorrow.
Hairband. Niʻihau.
Parentheses. Cf. kahaapo.
Type of Hawaiian dog with solid grayish-brown body and nose tip and eyes of the same color, believed to love water and consequently offered as a sacrifice to moʻo water spirits.
To be a grayish-brown color, as a horse, perhaps bay.

example_txt.txt: Ē! loaʻa akula ke kalo, ʻo ka ʻapowale.
O, you get taro, to grasp-foolishly taro [a waste of time, pun on ʻapo wale, to grasp needlessly].

definitions.dtxt: A native variety of wet-land taro grown chiefly for poi.
A file; a rasp.
To snap or snatch with the teeth; snatching. Fig. To destroy, ravage, ruin.
Same as apuapu 2.
To run after; to chase with a design of overtaking another.
To devour food greedily.
Coconut shell cup; to drink (FOR. 6:471).
General name for medical potions, as made of taro, yam, or herbs.
A taro cultivar, perhaps related to the ʻapuwai. (TC3)
A cup made of cocoanut shell for drinking awa; he apu ka iwi o ka niu.
A dish; a cup of any material.
MET. Affliction; suffering; he kiaha; also,
Water in which kalo has been soaked, a kind of medicine; apu kalo, apu laau; the cup gives name to the drink.
A shell or cup for scooping up the oopu; he apua oopu.
Same as pai 5, a fish trap. Puka ma ka ʻāpua, got out of the trap [of one going scot free].

example_txt.txt: to get away through the handle [to escape]

definitions.dtxt: Handle, as of a laulau food package; shank knob of a fishhook (also puapua); twisted top of a paper sack that may serve as a handle.
Disloyal, disobedient, rebellious; such a person. ʻĀpua pale leo, to disregard orders; one who does so, as a chief or priest.

Land division, Waipiʻo qd.; land division and point, Puna qd., Hawaiʻi (a lava flow with voluminous fountains from ʻĀloʻi and ʻAlae craters reached this point in june 1969; Macdonald and Abbott 102); ancient village in Puna that was swept away in the 1868 tidal wave (Hawaii Natural History Association Guide 14-16). Flat land area, Kualoa, Koʻolau Poko, Oʻahu (UL 52).
A man who disobeys or disregards the commands of his chief.
To be disloyal; to disregard or disobey the orders of his chief.
A variety of kalo.
Same as pai 5, a fish trap.
Rain name associated with Koʻolau Poko, Oʻahu, said to be named for a beautiful woman, ʻĀpuakea, changed to rain by the goddess Hiʻiaka. See song, Elbert and Mahoe 61.
Land division, Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu, probably named for a local rain.
Point, Mākena qd., Maui. Old stream that debouched near the present Moana Hotel, Waikīkī, probably named for a rain. (FOR. SEL. 53; Ii 93)
Epithet of a chief who obeyed not the word of the priest.
Apua, to disobey, pale, to reject, and leo, voice. To disobey; not to comply with a command.
Redup. of apu 1.
File, rasp; to smooth or sharpen with a file.
Beard of a fishhook. (And.)
Rasp (tool). Cf. waiehu.
A file; a rasp. 1 Sam 13:20.
The beard of a fish-hook.
Cup-shaped.
Type of agricultural land, as for sweet potatoes, mentioned in 1848 land claims, perhaps a pocket-like area.
File or polisher for fishhook.
Apu, cup, and auhuhu, the poison plant. A cup for containing the auhuhu.
Cup containing ʻauhuhu plant concoction used for stupefying fish; poison cup.
Apu, cup, and awa, a plant. The awa cup; a cup out of which awa was drank.
Same as ʻāpuʻepuʻe.

Difficult; difficulty; to struggle, strive (preceded by ke. Komo ʻāpuʻepuʻe, barely able to get in; to enter with difficulty. ʻĀpuʻepuʻe nā kānaka i ka ʻai i ka wā wī, the people struggled to get food in time of famine. Ke ʻāpuʻepuʻe o ka loaʻa ʻana mai o ka ʻike kūpono i ka ʻōlelo haole, the difficulties of getting proper knowledge of English.
Strife between two persons to get the same thing; attempting to get what another wants.
A difficulty; a contention; hiki apuepue, to obtain with difficulty.
A bunch of kalo; a hill of potatoes. See APOAPO.
See PUE, to force. To solicit one of the other sex.
To strive; to contend, as two persons endeavoring to get the same thing; apuepue na kanaka i ka ai i ka manawa wi.
With strife; with difficulty. Mat 19:23.
To deceive, lie, cheat.
A shellfish resembling the hīhīwai, found in brackish water.
To swindle, cheat, defraud; forgery, embezzlement; fraudulent. Kālā ʻāpuka, money gained through fraud or embezzlement. Palapala ʻāpuka, false or forged document. hoʻāpuka Caus/sim.
To emerge, come into light. Waiʻāpuka (place name), water coming through a tunnel. hoʻāpuka Caus/sim.
Deceit; treachery.
A thief; e manaoia oia no he apuka, he shall be considered as having stolen. kan. Haw.
Apuka, in law, is forgery.
To hide; to secrete; to steal.
Pitted.
Short.
Apu, cup, and koheoheo, causing death.
The cup in which deadly ingredients were mixed, and out of which they were drank, such as auhuhu and awa.
O ka hewa, oia ka apukoheoheo make ai na kanaka a pau i ke ao nei, sin is the cup of death causing all people to die.
Deadly poison, as given to prisoners.
Same as hāpuku, to collect.
Old; worn out; he waa apulu, an old canoe; he upena apulu, a worn out mat; apulu is applied to things as elemakule is to men.
Worn out, as a garment; to show wear and tear; rough, dingy. Hale ʻāpulu, shack.
A shred, or anything old and rotten or decayed, as a garment, a house, a canoe, etc.; he wahi apulu hale, the ruins of a house; he wahi apulu kapa, a remnant of a garment, etc.
To wax old; ready to be laid aside.
Redup. of ʻāpulu.
Angry or noisy dispute, quarrel, wrangle, brawl; to brawl.
Ill-omened, inauspicious.
The name of a day supposed to be inauspicious to one’s enemies; e hee ai kou hoapaio ia oe, no ka mea o apuni keia la, he la hee.
To come together, as two persons, and scold and threaten and curse one another, but separate without fighting.
An endemic fern (Sadleria squarrosa), 30 to 60 cm high, with short trunk, narrow oblong leaves; related to ʻamaʻu.
Hill, mound. Cf. ʻāpuʻupuʻu.
See ʻāpuʻupuʻu.
Gulch, Hālawa qd., Molokaʻi.
Lumpy, bumpy, pimply, rough, hilly, rugged.
Young stage of hāpuʻu fish. Also hāpuʻupuʻu.
Kaʻa holo ʻāpuʻupuʻu. Any off-road vehicle, e.g. ATV, dirt bike, 4x4, etc. Also kaʻa ʻāpuʻu.
Hillocks; rough places; e hoomania i na apuupuu a palahalaha ae, smooth down the rough places till they are smooth.
See PUU. Rough; uneven, as land; as a road. Full of hillocks.
A variety of taro: its corm is used for poi and table taro, its leaves for lūʻau. Varieties are white (kea) and red (ʻula).
Arabia, Arabian. Also ʻAlapia. Saudi ʻArabia. Saudi Arabia; Saudi. Also saudi ʻAlapia.
Argon, an element.
Name of an unclean bird.
Name of a tree; the cedar or fir.
Arizona; Arizonan, Arizonian. Also ʻAlikona.
Gr. A farthing.
Acetylene.
Asia; Asian, Asiatic. Also ʻĀkia.
Atlantic. Also ʻAkelanika.
Atom, atomic. Lou ʻātoma. Bond between atoms or ions as a result of gaining, losing, or sharing electrons.

A territory; district of couentry; generally compounded with other qualifying words; as, auakua, a desert, a place of gods, ghosts, etc. See AUAKUA. Aukanaka, an inhabited couentry; aupuni, a large region, etc.
definitions.notes: Note: Au is the term representing all places where food grows; as kaha represents such places as are on or near the shore where food does not grow. This applies mostly to the leeward side of the islands.

definitions.dtxt: Name of a fish with a sharp nose.
Name of a soft porous stone.
The gall of animals. Met.
The handle or helve of an axe. The staff of a spear. the handle of a sword. The handle of an auger, etc.; an koi, au pahi.
With a more protracted, smooth pronunciation than the foregoing, one of the auipili cases of the 2d per, sing. of oe. Gram. § 132. Thine; of thee.

To long after, or be wholly bent on; to be fully engaged in a course of conduct; alaila, au loa wau i na iuo o ke ao nei, then I was wholly engrossed in the vileness of the world; makemake, puni, lilo loa. See Au, current, above.

example_txt.txt: E kala kahiko i au wale.
Gone a long time ago, long past.
Na ke au o ka manawa e hōʻike mai.
The passing of time will tell.

definitions.dtxt: Period of time, age, era, epoch, cycle, the passing of time. See aumoe, au nele.
Current; to flow, as a current.

example_txt.txt: strong current; Fig. A strong warrior

definitions.dtxt: Movement, eddy, tide, motion; to move, drift, float, walk, hurry, stir; succession or train, as of thought, trend.

example_txt.txt: E au, ā e wiki mai.

chants.mltran: ♫  The thought comes to mind, how fares Niagara.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Ke au nei ka manaʻo, pehea ʻo Niakala.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.; to cause to float, as timber.
Gall, bile; gall bladder.

example_txt.txt: Take care not to break the gall bladder [do not cause bitterness].
wānana i ke au o ka manawa

definitions.dtxt: Weather. See ex., Koʻolau 1.
Small sweet potatoes of poor quality that grow from the vine.
Pumice.
Grain of wood.
To weed.
To rub, massage, polish.
To set, as a net or fish trap.
Same as above; fishermen who set nets in kuʻu fishing.
Same as heau (Exocarpus spp.)
Hedyotis acuminata, a native shrub (coffee family), with small green flowers, and unpleasant-smelling, ovate or narrower leaves. Cf. pilo 2.
Also wau. pronoun. I. (Gram. 2.1)

Pers. pron., 1st per. sing. I; when prefixed or preceded by the emphatic o, as o au, the compound sound resembles that of w; hence it has the forms au, o au, wau, and o wau; the o is no part of the word, and should be written separately.
The current in the ocean; au maloko o ka moana; o kahi o ke kai e wili ana, he au ia; he wili au kahi inoa.
The grain in wood.
The motion of the hand in mixing poi.
An action of the mind; as, ke au wale nei no ko'u manao e ake e pulelo iki ae, my mind is exercising, etc. See AU v., below.
Time; a period of time, more or less definitely designated, as the reign of a king.
The time of one’s life; i ke au ia Kalaniopuu; i ke au o Liholiho, in the time of Kalaniopuu, etc.
A season. A portion of time.

Age, epoch, era, period. See Au Palaʻo, au paʻahau. Ke au haku kūlohelohe. Eolithic age, in anthropology. Ke au haku kā pahi. Paleolithic age. Ke au haku kā nahau. Mesolithic age. Ke au haku ʻānai. Neolithic age. Ke au haku keleaweʻula. Aeneolithic age. Ke au keleawekini. Bronze age.
Current. See entries below. Au uila. Electic current.
Mood. See au manaʻo.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ka hoʻāeae, he au pilialoha kōna.
The hoʻāeae (style of chanting) has a romantic mood.
Naue ka manawa i ke au o ka puolo.
The time moves to the mood of the music.

definitions.dtxt: To swim, travel by sea. ʻAuikekailoa (personal name), travel in the distant seas. Ua ʻau ʻia nā kai loa, the distant seas were traveled. hōʻau To teach to swim, learn to swim; to swim with a drowning person; to douse, as clothes being washed; the man sets a kuʻu, drop net.
To jut out into the sea, as a land point; to project. Aloha Makapuʻu, ʻau i ke kai, greetings to Makapuʻu [Point), reaching out into the sea.

Handle, staff, stem, stalk, shaft; bone of lower arm or leg. See ʻau kī, ʻau lima, ʻau wāwae. ʻAu loa, long bones in arm or leg; long-limbed, long-shanked. ʻAu kīpāpali (FOR. 6:61), shaft-like cliff slope.
Group (followed by a qualifier, as moku, waʻa.) Cf. ʻaumakua.
To swim; ua au na kanaka i ka moana, a pakele i ka make, the people swam the ocean and escaped death.
To float on the surface of water; to turn, as the eyes to look at something: i na ua ike oe e au ana kona maka. Laieik. 145. SYN. with nana ia.
Hoo., 3d conj. To cause to swim, to float: hooau hele aku la i na pahu o lakou, they floated along their (water) casks.
To convey, as on a raft.

To swim through the water by the exertions of the arms and other limbs; poho ka uhane o ka poe make i ka moana, aole paha e hiki ke au iuka, the souls of those who sink in the ocean are lost, they are not able to swim ashore. Used imperatively, to quicken, to hasten; more generally doubled, as auau, which see.

Handle, as of a bureau drawer, faucet, frying pan, toilet, etc. (preceded by ke); neck, as of an ʻukulele, guitar, etc. Niʻihau. Cf. kākai, pōheo. See ʻau hoʻokuʻu wai o ka lua, ʻau kī wai, ʻau paikikala, ʻau pā palai, ʻau ʻume. See also ʻukulele.
So written for aau, one a dropped and the apostrophe supplied. It is the auipili. one of the oblique cases of au, I. See Gram. § 124. Of me; mine.
There is a sensible break in the pronunciation, to distinguish it from au. the 1st person, and from au, of the 2d person next below.
Swordfish, sailfish, marlin, spearfish (Istiophoridae). See sayings, laʻa 2, ʻoloʻolo 3.
Me (used after e and me and fusing with iā to form iaʻu; Gram. 9.6.3).
My, mine (a-form, zero-class; Gram. 9.6.3).
Your, yours (singular, a-form, zero-class; Gram. 9.6.3).
The name of a fish.
To look, observe.
Same as ʻāʻaua; lean, as fish. Lau ʻaua, wrinkled leaf; Fig. Experienced, as warrior or strategist.
Cawing, as of the ʻalalā, crow.
Name recorded for the star Betelgeuse.
The voice of the bird alala.

Stingy, selfish, to withhold, detain, grudge, refuse to part with; stinginess; sparingly. Home hoʻopaʻa ʻauʻa ʻia, detention home. Mai hoʻi mai māua i nehinei, ʻo ka ʻauʻa hoʻi o ka makamaka, we would have returned yesterday, but were detained by friends. Ua ʻauʻa ke kahuna, the sorcerer refuses to part with his knowledge.
A kind of ʻōpelu fish said to be larger than others in a school and hence more visible. When net fishermen see an ʻauʻa they know a school is present; the ʻauʻa then can not be caught [he refuses].
Hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa. Detention, as punishment at school. Hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa i ka wā kula. in-school detention. Hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa muli kula. After-school detention.
Stinginess; closeness.
Close; hard; parsimonious; stingy; he pi, he paa.
To dislike to part with property; to be stingy in giving.
To keep back what should be given to another; to withhold.
Not to give a thing asked for; to be stingy.
To think so much of a thing as not to part with it. Ua hewa no kahi aua ana o na Lunaauhau, some of the stinginess of the Lunaauhaus is wrong.
To look with regret upon a thing.
To forbid; withhold.
To refuse assent to a proposal; not to be pleased with it. Laieik. 140.
Rhizome.
Expert; cunning; provident.
Laziness, indolence; one who spends time idly.
To be lazy; to spend time idly; e kalauea, e kaialili.
See AUWAE, the chin. A lana ka auae kahi uuku.
See ʻumiʻumi ʻauae.
Drift current, in oceanography.
For auwaepuu. Hoo. To be lazy, indolent.
This word is related to uahi, smoke. One source says it refers to lowly or humble persons. Malo 109 says it may refer to a distant relationship.
An unknown herb, the bark and leaves of which were used as medicine.
Dishonest. See keʻe 1.
Ghost-ridden; haunted or unfriendly land. Lit. ghost bile. (Cf.) ʻAʻohe maikaʻi kānaka o kēia wahi, he auakua, the people of this place are not good, they are most unkind.
Also written wauakua and waoakua. Au, a place, and akua, a god.
A region remote from inhabitants, and supposed to be the haunts of spirits, ghosts, hobgoblins, etc.
A desolate place; uninhabited. He anoano kanaka ole.
A variety of ʻoʻopu goby fish found in both brackish and fresh water. Also kāniʻo.
Terraced taro patches.
Name of a kapu sacred to Kama, an ancient chief of Maui; o ka noekole aualii kapu o Kama.
Royal, chiefly. Ua noho aloha lāua me ka lani aualiʻi, they lived in friendliness with the high chief.
Overcome by intense emotion, as love, grief.
Au, place, and alo, in front. A shed or verandah adjoining a house for storing canoes, calabashes, and other property.

Pole or stick used for carrying burdens across the shoulders; yoke, palanquin, burden; to carry on the ʻauamo. Lit. carrying handle. Also ʻaumaka and māmaka. See amo, pipi ʻauamo. ʻAuamo kiʻi, carrying pole with carved heads near the ends. hōʻauamo Caus/sim.

Au, a handle, and amo to carry. A stick or pole with which burdens are carried across the shoulder. A staff or pole for carrying a burden. Hale auamo. a palanquin. Mel. A yoke. Fig. A burden; service.
To carry on the shoulders or back; e halihali. e mamaka; to carry on a stick across the shoulder. See above.
Auamo, to bear, and e, extra. To bear a very heavy load, so as to sprain or bruise the neck; e auamoe me ka nanaha o ka a-i, to carry a load with the straining of the neck.

To wander, drift, ramble, go from place to place; to stray morally or mentally. Cf. hula ʻauana. ʻA uana ka noʻonoʻo, delirium. hōʻauana To cause to wander, disperse, as a conqueror disperses an enemy.

Also written auwana. Au, to swim, and ana, the participial termination ing. A swimming off. The word has its origin in the overturning of a canoe, when men and all the cargo of the canoe float off in different directions.
To be scattered; dispersed, as things disperse in the upsetting of a canoe.
To go astray, as the mind; auwana hewa ka naau; to be wandering, as the thoughts.
To scatter from each other, as people.
To go here and there in search of something.
Hoo. To scatter; disperse abroad; to cause to wander; to go from place to place. Ua hooauwanaia ka poe hewa i ka make, the wicked are scattered in death. See AUWANA.
Scattered; wandering; dispersed.
Var. of auneʻi.
Soon, by-and-by, presently, shortly, just. (Gram. 7.5)

example_txt.txt: He lohe mai auaneʻi i ka makua!
Actually paying attention to [his] parent [implication that he is not].
ʻO ka ʻike auaneʻi iāia, ua lawa ia i ka makemake.
Just seeing him, the desire was satisfied.

definitions.dtxt: Probably, merely, probably not, possibly, doubtful. see ex., ʻā wale. (Gram. 7.5)

Au, time, and anei, now, hero, etc. It refers to an indefinite future time, but not far off; hereafter; by and by; soon; used only after verbs. E ua auanei, ke opiopi mai nei ke ao, it will rain soon, the clouds are folding up; e ino auanei, ke okupukupu mai la ka hao ino.
definitions.notes: Note: After a word ending with a, it is often written uanei.

definitions.dtxt: Side stroke, in swimming; to swim the side stroke. Lit. swim (on the) side.
Passing of much time on a piece of land, as an old family.
A bathing; washing; ua hele i ka auau, he is gone to bathe.
Of, or belonging to bathing; as, he wai auau; wahi auau.
A snare for catching and killing birds; he pahele e make ai ka manu; he auau manu.
Name of a certain aho (a small stick) to be thatched first in the process of building a heiau.
Name of a long slim fish; the guard-fish that swims near the surface of the water.
The stalk of loulu made into a spear; he ihe.
Conj. 6 of au, to swim. To bathe in water, as a person.
To wash; cleanse with water.
To take out wrinkles from a piece of cloth. Hoo.
Hill, northeast Kauaʻi. Channel between Maui and Lānaʻi.
Same as au 1; to walk lightly and swiftly. ʻO kāne hānau i ke auau pō ʻeleʻele, man born in the age of darkness.
Redup. of au 3. hoʻāuau To hasten, hurry, rush, excite to action.
Redup. of au 10.
Same as au 11. hoʻāuau Same as hoʻāu.
To bathe. Cf. ʻau 1, wai ʻauʻau.
To give a bath.
Stick, stem (as of ti plant); spear made of loulu palm, with shark teeth on its end; extra ridgepole.
Trap, snare, as for catching birds. (And.)
Small aʻu fish.
Same as ʻāʻaua, coarse. ʻIli ʻauʻaua lena, yellow wrinkled skin.
Young eel.
A fish said to resemble weke (no data).
To take a shower, bathe by showering. See kililau, lumi ʻauʻau.
Same as ʻaukoʻi, a weed.
Land section, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
Birdbath.
Probably for auanei, which see.
To snorkel. See paipu hanu.
Also aupapaohe. Name of a fish, a variety of the species auau.
Same as aʻupapaʻohe. (And.)
Redup. of ʻauwaha; furrowed.
Au, a place, au doubled and waha, a mouth. To dig a furrow or ditch; to dig up into furrows, as for planting, Hoo. To make a furrow by digging. See aUWAHA.
Bitter gall. Fig. Ingratitude.
Same as ue 3.
Oh! Oh dear! Oh boy! Alas! Too bad! Goodness! (Much used to express wonder, fear, scorn, pity, affection; see ex., huʻahuʻa 1, Gram. 12) To groan, moan, grieve, bewail.

example_txt.txt: Alas for us! Woe betide us!
Auē! Nānā aku ʻoe iā Lei mā!
Say! You should see Lei and the others!
e auē ana i ke aloha keiki
grieving for love of the child

definitions.dtxt: See also AUWE. To cry; to weep; to lament for any loss, suffering or calamity.
Also auwe. O; oh! woe to; alas; O dear; expressive of regret, of grief, of pain, of disappointment; aue ka make! aue ke ano e! See AUWE.
Same as au wale.

Recession, i.e., a period of reduced economic activity. Ma muli o ka hopohopo nui o ka lehulehu i ka nele i ka hana, ua hoʻomaka ka hoʻokele waiwai e komo i ke au emi. Because of great public concern about unemployment, the economy entered into a recession.
A calling, crying, humming, buzzing.
Molting, of a chicken. (FOR. 5:495)
Outhouse, as for storing canoes; shed, shelter.
A shed or house for putting canoes to screen them from the sun; he auolo no ka waapa. See AUOLO.
Name of a star, companion to Hōkūʻula and Paikauhale. Perhaps the three are sigma, Antares, and Tau Scorpii.
To tear; to rend, as clothes. See UHAT.
Spindle-legged; spindleshanks; an animal with slender legs.
Epithet of a man with long, spindling legs, like the legs of a horse; he kanaka wawae loloa auhaka loihi, e like me ka lio wiwi auhaka.
A man tall, poor and thin, especially his legs; spindle-legged; me he wawae auhaka la ka eaea.
Name of a star (no data).
Name of a species of wood for making spears; he hau ka ihe e kaua ai, he auhau kekahi ihe, the spears for war are made of hau, some spears are made of auhau.

Tax, assessment, levy, charge, tariff, toll, tribute, price; to levy a tax, pay tribute, tax. ʻAuhau kino, ʻauhau poʻo, poll tax. Kū i ka ʻauhau, taxable. ʻAuhau helu waiwai, excise tax. Hale ʻauhau, building where taxes are collected. Kou ʻauhau, your tax (that you pay). Kāu ʻauhau, your tax (that you impose). Luna ʻauhau. tax collector. Nā poʻe hoʻokaʻa ʻauhau, taxpayers. He aha kāu ʻauhau no ka pāpale loulu? What is your price for the loulu hat?
Femur and humerus bones of the human skeleton.
Stems of plants whose bark can be stripped, such as wauke and olonā, but not maile. Inā e kua ʻia ka wauke, ā hohole ʻia ka ʻauhau, … if the wauke is cut and the stems stripped, …
Tax. Mea uku ʻauhau. Taxpayer. Pākēneka ʻauhau. Tax rate. ʻAuhau komo pū. Tax included. ʻAuhau kumukūʻai. Sales tax.
A tax; a revenue for the benefit of chiefs; kahi auhau, a place for collecting taxes; similar to hookupu.
definitions.notes: Note: In ancient times every article of value was taxed, to be paid in kind; at present, the auhau dala is the great thing.

definitions.dtxt: To put a people under tribute. To tax; assess a tax.
To exercise lordship; to exact of one.
Stalk of a hau tree, spear made of hau wood. Ahi ʻau hau, firebrand (of light wood, as hau).
Var. of uhau hui, a prayer.
A religious ceremony in the hoopiopio; perhaps, to strike regularly.
Land section and ancient surfing area, Kailua qd., Hawaiʻi. (Finney and Houston 26)
I na auhaumaule ka pa, ua huna ia malalo o ka weuweu.
Misplaced or concealed noʻa stone in the game of pūhenehene. (And.)
Tuesday tax, a term used in 1852, probably an educational tax.
Beggar; to go from door to door asking for charity.
A beggar; one who solicits favors of chiefs; he auhaupuka na kanaka noi wale.
Beggary; a system of living by beggary; ma ka auhaupuka e loaa ai ka ai a me ke kapa, by begging they obtain food and clothing.
To beg; to ask for a thing. SYN. with noi, but more modest. See NOI, MAKILO, aPIKI, etc.
Where (in questions). (Gram. 8.5)
Listen (in commands, common in songs). See ex., ʻaumakua 2. ʻAuhea ʻoukou (Laie 473)! Hear ye! ʻAuhea wale ana ʻoe, ē ka pua o ka lokelani, now pay attention, O blossom of the rose.
Sir [formal beginning of a letter].
Au, place, and hea, what.
Where? what place?
A call of attention to what one has to say; auhea oe? auhea oukou? where art thou? where are you?
Where indeed (with implication of neglect or indifference)? Where’s the interest? Where’s the care? ʻAuhea hoʻi ka hele mai o lākou e kōkua, they'll never come and help, they don't care.
Au, to swim, and hee, to melt, causing an intensive.
To melt; to flow, as a liquid.
To flee from one; to slip off from danger; auhee mai la ka auwaa, the fleet of canoes hurried off (from fear;) to flee, as from temptation.
To flee or be put to flight in battle. 1. To be scattered; disappear.
Used imperatively, go away; let me alone; forbear. 2 Oihl 35:21.
Hoo. To put to flight, to rout, as an enemy.
To drive away; to dispel, as darkness. See HEE.
To be destitute; to be bereaved; to be deprived of all comforts; to make desolate.
Ua lilo kuu aina, ua auhee au,
My land is gone, I am poor.
Ua make kuu wahine, ua auhee au,
My wife is dead, I am bereaved.
Ua wela kuu hale, ua auhee au,
My house is burned, I am destitute.
Ua make kuu alii, ua auhee makou,
My chief is dead, we are friendless.
To flee from danger; routed, dispersed, defeated. ʻAuheʻe pūʻiwa, to flee in fright, stampede. E ʻauheʻe i ka ʻino, refrain from evil. hōʻauheʻe To rout, put to flight, flee.
Redup. of ʻauheʻe.
Au and hele, to move.
To cut out clothes, i.e., to move round, as the shears or scissors in cutting out clothes. This is a modern word, or at least a modern use of the word; equivalent to helehele.
To sail from one place to another; auhele au ma ka moana, a pae mauka, I sailed about on the ocean, and then went ashore; auhele makou a pae i o.
To go looking from place to place without any definite course, to drift or sail aimlessly, drifting. Ma ke auhele o ka hewahewa (Kel. 99), on the drifting path of error.
To turn off the course, wander, deviate. Ua lili ke Akua ia wā no ke auhili ʻia o nā kānaka i ka ʻino (Kep. 35), God was jealous then because of the turning away of men to wickedness.
Delphinium. Comb. ʻau + hōkū. Also pua ʻauhōkū.
See HOLA. The name of the plant with which fish are intoxicated and caught. see AUHUHU.
From the foregoing. To catch fish by means of the auhola or hola.
Same as ʻauhuhu., a shrub.
Au, time, and honua, earth. The time of the earth, i.e., as long as the world has stood, of old time, from the beginning.
Ancient age, era, epoch. See mauliauhonua. I ke auhonua hānau o Papa i kēia mau moku, in the ancient time Papa gave birth to these islands. I ke auhonua o nā kaikala, in the age of the Caesars.

data.word: ʻau hoʻokuʻu wai o ka lua

definitions.dtxt: Toilet handle (preceded by ke). Also ʻau hoʻokuʻu.
Corm, scientific usage. Comb. ʻau + hua. See hua.
A shrub; the name of a plant used in poisoning or intoxicating fish, that they may be caught. See AUHOLA.
Point, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi, named for a small legume with pods used for poisoning fish. The plant grew wild here, and the residents traded it, along with taro, for fish from the coast.

A slender, shrubby legume (Tephrosia purpurea syn. T. piscatoria), 30 to 60 cm high, with small, compound leaves, small white or purplish flowers, and narrow pods, used for poisoning fish. The plant is known from tropical Asia eastward into polynesia. Also ʻauhola, hola. Cf. pōpō ʻauhuhu.
Var. name for the month of Makaliʻi, a time so dry that the ʻauhuhu plant became brittle (paʻina). See month.
The act of swimming round a pali where there is no road; he poe auhulaana no ka pali; those swimming round the pali; ke hele la ka poe auhulaana o Milolii ma kauai.
To swim around a hulaʻana, or precipice facing the sea; course or route for swimming here.
Au and huli, kalo tops for planting.
To thrust downwards, as in planting kalo; to plant kalo.
To send downwards; to drive away.
To overturn, as a kingdom.
To overturn, overthrow, upset; to till. hoʻāuhuli Caus/sim. Ka hoʻāuhuli ʻana, revolution, upset.
A change of governments or rulers; an overturn of government; a revolution.

Pass, of auhuli, with h inserted. Gram. § 48. To be overturned; to be dispossessed of land and tenements; to be turned off or driven from house and home; to be driven to ruin. Auhulihia ke aupuni a lilo aku i ka mea e, the kingdom is overturned and gone to another.
Pas/imp. of auhuli. Kaua auhulihia, revolutionary war.
To stick together, as little things, by wetting them in the mouth.
A wave of the sea; a billow. He aui no ka nalu.
The name for case in grammar. Gram. § 99.
To decline, as the sun in the afternoon.
To be turned aside in a course; a i ka moana, auiia ka waa e ka ale, when on the ocean, the canoe was turned aside by a wave.
To vary from a direct line; to turn aside, as the head; ua aui ae nei ka la; ua aui ae nei ka ia.
To swell, as the sea, in great rollers.
To pass by a certain time.
To shun a blow by inclining the head.
To roll up roughly, as high waves of the sea; ke aui mai la ka nalu; aui mai la ka ale o ke kai. Conj. 9. Au-i-au-i, to roll up, as the sea, etc.
To turn aside, digress, deviate, pass by, decline, bend down. Cf. auinalā. nā ʻaui ʻana, variations, deviations. hōʻaui Caus/sim. Ke hōʻaui maila ka lā, the sun is beginning to descend to the west.
To swell and roll, as the sea; to pitch; billow, roller. ʻAui ʻale, large swell, billow.

Declension, case; to name declensions or conjugations (term devised by Andrews based on Latin declinare, to turn aside); never used extensively and not entered in Hitchcock’s 1887 English-Hawaiian Dictionary. hōʻaui To conjugate, decline. Ka hōʻaui ʻana, declension, conjugation.

A hula step: the dancer turns to the side and points out one foot once or several times, drawing the foot well back between each pointing; at the same time the body is tipped, with a lowered hand pointing to the outpointing toes, and the other hand raised in the opposite direction; to dance thus. Cf. ue.
Ouch!
Pas/imp. of ʻaui.
Aui and ale. A swell of the sea, not a small wave; so called from the motion, passing by.
Accusative case.
See AUI.
Redup. of ʻaui 1.
Vocative case.
Case denoting separation, as shown by mai, from, ablative.
Case denoting association.
Agentive case.
Genetive or possessive case.
Possessive case.
Nominative case.
Dog paddle, in swimming; to dog paddle. Lit. swim (like a) dog.
Locative case.
Aui, to decline, and ana, the participial termination. The declining or turning aside; i ka auina la, at sun declining, that is, in the afternoon. Laieik. 49. See AUWINA.
Bending, sloping; descent, slope.
Band, gradient, as of colors.
Afternoon.
Midnight, late night.
Dative case.
Possessive case. ʻAuipili laulā, o-form of the possessive. ʻAuipili paʻa, a-form of the possessive.
Similar to ʻauina pō. (FOR. 6:420).
Abbreviation for ʻAukake (August).
A.
Tired; weary, as of sitting still.
A bar, as of soap.
A bar of unwrought silver, iron or gold.
In architecture, a fillet.
A bar of a city gate.
To be wearied; fatigued with doing a thing.

example_txt.txt: Ua auka au i ka ʻuʻumi.
I am weary with holding in.

definitions.dtxt: Weary, exhausted.
Tired, weary.
Out (in games).
Out, in baseball. Ua ʻauka wau iā ia. He put me out. Cf. hala akula i waho. See hōʻauka.
Bar, as of soap or gold, nugget; ridge or strip between the flutes of a column, facet, fillet, capstan bar, bar across a roadway; stump.
Long stems, as of some species of mangoes.
Wood woven through sticks in ʻie kala fish trap.
Stools, feces.
See entries below. Pakuhi ʻaukā. Bar graph. Pakuhi paʻa ʻaukā. Double bar graph. papa ʻaukā helu. Ten-strip board, in math.
Equatorial current, in oceanography.
Desolate, dreary, nonproductive.

definitions.der: [Lit. strip (to) count tenths. See moena helu hapa haneli, papa ʻaukā helu]
definitions.dtxt: Tenth strip, in math.
Au and kahi, to cut smooth.
Smooth, without knots or protuberances, as a canoe; he waa aukahi, aole lala, aole opuupuu, a canoe, smooth, no knots, no protuberances.
Level and straight, as a floor; smooth and straight throughout; hookahi ano o ka au o ka laau.
Straight and smooth, as a looking-glass.
Applied also to a well composed speech; correct; eloquent.
Direct current (DC). Cf. au māʻaloʻalo.

example_txt.txt: coherent light, i.e., light in which all the waves vibrate in a single plane with the crests and troughs all aligned

definitions.dtxt: Even, smooth, clear. Fig. Suave and pleasant in speech and manner. Aukahi ka puaʻa, a smooth pig [a sacrificial hog with uncracked skin, believed perfect for sacrifice; Fig. Of perfection].
United, flowing together.

chants.chtran: The waves move with one accord, the Pacific is calm.
chants.chtxt: Ua aukahi mai nā ʻale, ua malino ka Pākīpika.

definitions.dtxt: Fill bar, in a computer program.
Street and lane, Kāhala, Honolulu, named for Edward K. Aukai, caretaker of the Judd property at Hakipuʻu, Oʻahu (Clark 20); beach park, Kahana qd., Oʻahu.
To travel or swim by sea; seafaring; sailor, seafarer.
Baton. Comb. ʻau + kaʻi. See entries below.
Signal baton, as used by a marching bandleader.
Baton for twirling. See wili.
Au, wave, and kaka, hook. A place far out at sea where fish are caught; o ka pililua o lawaia o ke aukaka.
Deep coral bed with overlapping ledges where fishes hide.
August.
August. Abb. ʻAuk.
Counting rod or strip, in math. Also ʻaukā. Cf. moena kōkua helu, paʻaʻiliono kōkua helu.
Bar of soap.
Name of a fish with a sword snout.
Short for au kanaiʻi (see au) 2. Ke aliʻi i makana ai, he koa a he aukana ia, the chief who gave the gift, a warrior and a strong soldier he.
Au, place, and kanaka, men. A place or region where men are found, in distinction from auakua, region of the gods.
Emphatically, a thickly peopled place; he wahi kanaka, he wahi paapu, a lehulehu.
The habited world.
Inhabited place, settlement; inhabited. Nā wahi aukanaka apau, all inhabited places.
Inland; fishing grounds, identified by lining up with landmarks ashore.
Australia; Australian.
Austria; Austrian.
Austria; Austrian. Also ʻAuseturia.
Au, to swim, and kela, to excel. To swim ahead of others.
Short for ʻAukelenuiaiku, a hero.
For lauki. The ki leaf; also, 2. A species of fish.
Stem of a ti plant.
A fish, perhaps a marlin.
Stream current, in oceanography.
Faucet handle (preceded by ke). See kī wai.

definitions.der: [Lit. tropic bird hastens, it is calm]
definitions.dtxt: Name of a stroke in lua fighting.
Axe handle. Pili ʻau koʻi, a trusted friend or relationship.

Coffee senna (Cassia occidentalis), a tropical American shrubby legume, each leaf with eight to ten leaflets, and with yellow flowers and narrow, many-seeded pods. Used medicinally for ringworm. Also ʻauʻaukoʻi, mikipalaoa, pī hohono.
Same as ʻawaiāhiki.
A disease in the groin, resulting from pollution; he ewai, he auwakoi.
Crawl (swimming); to swim thus.
Free style, crawl, in swimming; to swim using this syle.
Undertow.
A stream, so shallow that a person can wade through with his clothes on; a shallow stream, not deep.
Name of a road or path leading up hill.
Au, to swim, and ku, to stand.

To swim or sail uprightly, as a vessel rising and pitching in a heavy sea; auku ka ihu i ka makani; to stand up, as the bow of a vessel by the wind, from the resemblance to a man’s position in swimming uprightly in a rough sea.

To toss up the nose, as an expression of pride, anger or contempt for a thing; auku ka ihu o ka wahine huhu wale, the angry woman turns up her nose; auku iluna ka ihu o ke kanaka haaheo, the nose of the proud man is turned up.
To climb, as a man, up a precipice.
To rise up, as the end of the nose at a bad smell, or the end of a canoe in a surf.
To pitch and toss; to raise, lift.
Uphill path.
Shallow. (AP)
To tread water.
Broadbill swordfish (Xiphias gladius).
Back stroke, in swimming; to swim the back stroke. Lit. swim (on the) back.
Name of a bird which makes a loud, yelling noise at night; a sea-bird.
A swelling up of the water of the sea; the rise and rapid flow of water in a river; moana ke kai kele a kaa aukuku ke kae ka hohonu.
Tapa beater.
Crowded, close.
Agitated; agitation.
Apprentice canoe maker.
The action of a person vomiting.
A kind of fish-hook.

The name of a bird; me he aukuu la ke kau i ke ahua, as an aukuu, lights on a bank; ua hoolikeia ke kanaka hana hewa me ka aukuu, a bad man is likened to an aukuu; no ka mea, he ahua kahi e kau ai ka aukuu, because the aukuu sits on a bank; nolaila i olelo mai ka poe kahiko; hence the ancients say:
Me he aukuu la ke kau i ke ahua,
As the aukuu sits upon a sand bank,
Alaalawa na maka me he pueo la,
Its eyes looking about like an owl.
Black-crowned night heron (Nycticorax nycticorax hoactli), a non-migratory land bird, which feeds on small fish and the larvae of insects in water. See sayings, heron.
Kind of fishhook with a long slender shaft, perhaps named for its resemblance to the heron’s neck.
A long bamboo pole with two maile stalks across the top that were gummed with lime to catch birds. Also alakō.
To vomit, retch.
Cords held by the fishermen (hoʻāu) who managed the net in kuʻu fishing. also kāwelewele.
A variety of ʻaukuʻu heron.
Name given by Kepelino for a bird resembling the kioea, and not an ʻaukuʻu.
Stinted, as vegetables; barren, as ground; he palakai, he aula, he ponalo.
Stunted, sun-baked.
Reddish, brownish. Cf. hāʻula.
An edible seaweed, perhaps the same as limu hāʻula.
Strip, as in a stripmat counting system, in math (preceded by ke). Sh. ʻau + lahilahi.
To give or cause light around. See LAMA. He kolikukui, i aulamaia.
To light with a torch.
Messenger of a chief.
Twig, small stick (preceded by ke). Sh. ʻau + laʻolaʻo.
A bundle of cane or other leaves bound together, used in taking fish. See aUMAIEWA.
To gather leaves to wrap fish in for cooking, as leaves of pōhuehue, mānewanewa, lauaʻe, ti; to frighten fish into a net with leaves.
Leaves strung on lines at ends of seines, as ti leaves.
To fly off in flocks, as many kinds of birds.
To fly, as a frightened flock of birds.
A variety of native banana. (HP 177)
Name of a long slim fish.
Sailfish (Istiophorus orientalis).
Dark. Hānau ke poʻo āuli, he uliuli kona (KL. line 509), the dark heads are born, they are dark.
Pas/imp. of au 2, 3. Aulia manu, flight of birds. Wai aulia, flowing water.
Pas/imp. of ʻau, to swim.
Neat; nice; excellent.
Street, ʻĀlewa Heights, Honolulu. (TM)
Dainty, neat, trim, cute, exquisite, nice, perfect. hōʻauliʻi To make attractive, neat.
A small staff. Hila ʻauliʻi, high heels.
Even and smooth from end to end, as a piece of timber; he laau aulike, a straight, smooth piece of timber; he aukahi.
Au, to swim, and like, alike. To swim evenly; to swim abreast, as two or more persons.
Even, smooth, as timber.
To treat kindly. He poʻe aulike i nā malihini (Kep. 75), a people who treat visitor kindly. He hoʻokipa a me ke aulike kekahi i kekahi, hospitable and helpful one to another.
To swim evenly or abreast.
A beautiful, well-formed person.
Any article beautifully made.
An expression of commendation or praise, connected with boasting or pride of one’s circumstances or privileges, as being skillful, expert or reflecting.
Precision; precise. Redup. of ʻauliʻi.

definitions.der: [au, a handle, and lima, the hand]
definitions.dtxt: The name of the stick held in the hand when rubbing to produce fire. The name of the stick rubbed is aunaki.
definitions.notes: Note: The action of rubbing is hia.

definitions.dtxt: Bone of arm below elbow.
Stick held in the hand and rubbed in the fire-plow to produce fire by friction. Cf. ʻaunaki.
Mildew. Also kūkaeloli.
Rough, raging, as sea or wind; to injure, harm, rage.
To grow.
A tall endemic tree (Pisonia sandwichensis), with large, oblong, dark-green leaves; small, rounded flower heads, narrow, sticky fruits, and very soft wood. Cf. kaulu, pāpala kēpau.
Same as ʻālʻa 1, Planchonella spp.
Same as lonomea, Sapindus oahuensis.
Injure, harm, rage; rough, raging (as sea or wind).
See PAIAUMA. A person in distress or pain, so as not to be still.

definitions.der: [Lit. current passing back and forth. Cf. aukahi. uila au māʻaloʻalo. Alternating current electricity]
definitions.dtxt: Alternating current (AC).
Many persons engaged in taking fish and using the lau halaakia.
Large-mouthed net placed at the wings of the papa hului net to receive fish; used in deep water. (Malo 212)
Au, a handle, and maka.
A pole to carry baggage on. See MAMAKA.
Same as ʻauamo, carrying pole.
Jet stream.
A variety of sweet potato.
He akua aumakua, able, that may be trusted as a child trusts to a parent; ua ola ke akua aumakua.
Kukuluia ka hale no ko Kamehameha mau iwi, i mea e hoolilo ai ia ia i akua aumakua, a house was built, for Kamehameha’s bones that he might become a substantial god.
A person so called who provided for a chief or for chiefs; a trusty, steadfast servant; one who is not easily provoked to leave his place.

Name of a class of ancient gods who were considered able and trustworthy; na akua i ka po, o na aumakua i ke ao, gods of the night, gods of the day; o Kiha i ka po, o Liloa i ka po, o Umi i ka po, o Mea i ke ao.

Family or personal gods, deified ancestors who might assume the shape of sharks (all islands except Kauaʻi), owls (as at Mānoa, O'ahu and Kaʻū and Puna, hawaiʻi), hawks (Hawaiʻi), ʻelepaio, ʻiwi, mudhens, octopuses, eels, mice, rats, dogs, caterpillars, rocks, cowries, clouds, or plants. A symbiotic relationship existed; mortals did not harm or eat ʻaumākua (they fed sharks), and ʻaumākua warned and reprimanded mortals in dreams, visions, and calls. (Beckwith, 1970, pp. 124–43, 559; Nānā 38) Fig. A trustworthy person. (Probably Lit. ʻau 4, group, + makua, parent.) See pulapula 2. hōʻaumakua To acquire or contact ʻaumākua.

To offer grace to ʻaumākua before eating; to bless in the name of ʻaumākua. ʻAuhea ʻoe, ē ke kanaka o ke akua, eia kā kāua wahi ʻai, ua loaʻa maila mai ka pō mai ka pō mai; no laila nāu e ʻaumakua mai i ka ʻai a kāua (prayer), hearken, O man who serves the god, here is food for you [lit., our food], received from the night, so bless our food in the name of the ʻaumakua.
To ask someone to hula; the request was not refused without giving the caller a lei or flower. ʻAumakua iā Kamuela, Samuel must dance!
Plural of ʻaumakua.
Butterfly stroke, in swimming; to swim the butterfly stroke. Lit. swim (like) a mālolo fish.
Tributary. He ʻaumana ʻo Misouri no Misisipi. The Missouri is a tributary of the Mississippi. Comb. ʻau + mana. ʻAumana kahawai. Stream tributary. ʻAumana muliwai. River tributary.
Tone, as of a literary work.
Alnitak, a star.

A pulling from one person to another in contention; an acting with opposition and force; he huki aku, huki mai, a puepue, there was pulling this way and that with force; he ola nae, he ola aumeume, there was life, however, but life with contention.

A and ume, to pull, draw out. To contend, to strive for a thing, in order to obtain it from another; to pull from one to another; aumeume na kanaka i ka ia, the people contended for the fish; aumeume na kanaka i ka lole, the people contended for the cloth.
Opposition, struggle, contention, strife; to struggle, oppose. Also ʻāʻuʻume. Ola ʻāʻumeʻume, struggle between life and death.
Au and miha. To float off in the air, as miasma; contagion; evil influence supposed to attend the graves of the dead.
To float off in the air, as miasma; evil spirits thought to attend graves.
To grieve, regret, be sorry. Cf. mihi.
To sorrow; to repent; to grieve for the loss of a thing. See MIHI.
Grieve, regret, be sorry.
Outgoing current.
Fresh water mixed with noni juice, drunk after kava.

example_txt.txt: aumiki aku i ka ʻapu ʻawa

definitions.dtxt: Same as miki 2; to sip.
Water kept in a calabash, and the chief drinks awa, (which is very bitter,) then drinks this water, which he thinks is sweet.
To care for; protected. Cf. moamoa. ʻO ka ʻape aumoa ka hiwa uli (KL. line 379), the protected ʻape, the black sacredness.
Street, ʻĀlewa Heights, Honolulu.
Swimming the ocean; name of a class of Kamehameha’s laws.
To travel on the open sea; sailor.

Name of laws enacted by Queen Kaʻahumanu, so called in commemoration of her attempt to commit suicide by swimming out to sea. She was saved by a child who swam after her and refused to leave her. She returned to shore rather than cause his death.
Nautilus. Usually called ʻauwaʻalālua, moamoa, moamoa waʻa.
Late at night, as about midnight.
To pass the night.
The season when the world is asleep; night, specifically, midnight.
Late at night, midnight.
Fleet of ships.
Navy. Trad. Also pūʻali kaua moana, ʻoihana moku.
Epithet of the stones of an oven, that is, oven stones; pohaku aumu.
A place for baking; an oven; he wahi e kalua ai i ka ai; a place for cooking food. See UMU and IMU.
To bake; to cook by baking or burying under ground.
A collection or flock of birds; as, auna kolea, a flock of koleas; auna kolea e wili ana me he auna manu la, a flock of koleas mingling together like a flock of birds.
Large group, flock.

example_txt.txt: he kohu ʻāuna manu o ke kula
like flocks of birds of the plains

definitions.dtxt: To flock, collect (intransitive).
The name of the stick rubbed upon in obtaining fire by friction. See aULIMA.
Stick rubbed in obtaining fire by friction. Cf. ʻau lima.
Also ʻaunake, ʻauneki. Ounce.
A common gastropod (Nassa serta), a shellfish.
YN. with auanei. A particle referring to future time, but not distant. Soon; pretty soon; by and by.
Ounce. Abb. ʻan. ʻAuneki wai. Fluid ounce. Abb. ʻan w.
Hard times, depression, recession.
Belonging to a temporary building; ahaaina auolo, feast of tabernacles.
Au and olo, to vibrate. A tabernacle; a temporary house. An out-house for sheltering canoes; he auolo waa; also written auwolo.
Shelter or shed, as for canoes; outhouse, temporary house; tabernacle. Ke keʻena auolo mua o ka hale aliʻi, the front reception hall of the palace.

Ice age. Nui ka nūnē ʻana a ka poʻe ʻepekema no ke kumu o ke au paʻahau, ʻo ia hoʻi ka wā i paʻa ai ka honua holoʻokoʻa i ka hau. There is much speculation among scientists as to how the ice age began when the whole world was frozen in ice.
Handlebars, on a bicycle (preceded by ke). Niʻihau. Also kalaiwa paikikala.

Some representatives of an endemic genus (Isodendrion), members of the violet family. They are small shrubs beating greenish-white or reddish flowers, which have equal petals and none spurred. Cf. wahine noho kula.
Niʻihau name for naupaka kahakai.
Kingdom, in Egyptology.
New Kingdom, in Egyptology, 1574-1085 BC. Ua noho Palaʻo ke keiki ʻo Tutankhamen i ke Au Palaʻo Kūhou o ʻAikupita. The boy Tutankhamen ruled as Pharaoh over Egypt during the New Kingdom.

Old Kingdom, in Egyptology, 2780-2280 BC. Kaulana ke Au Palaʻo Kūkahiko o ʻAikupita i ka mohala hikiwawe ʻana o ka ʻoihana kuhikuhipuʻuone. The Old Kingdom is marked by rapid mastery of stone architecture.

Middle Kingdom, in Egyptology, 2133-1780 BC. Ua hoʻokumu ʻia ʻo Tebesa i kikowaena o ka hoʻomana ma ʻAikupita i ke Au Palaʻo Kūwaena. Thebes became established as the religious center of Egypt during the Middle Kingdom.
Rhythm, in linguistics. Comb. au + pana. Cf. papana.
A man who, in swimming on a board through the surf, loses his board; hence,
A person who has lost his property, i.e., his board was his dependence.
To be poor; to lose one’s property. Fig. Ohina aupapa. the swimming board is lost. Same as pau ka waiwai.
Everything, as of things taken or lost; destitute. He mea lawe ʻaupapa ke kaua, the war deprives one of everything. He 'ohina 'aupapa maoli nō kāna, he gathered up absolutely everything.
Frying pan handle (preceded by ke).
Name of a fish similar to auaupapaohe, a species of the auau.
A variety of aʻu fish.
According to Kepelino and Kamakau, a relationship extending back 24 generations. (FOR. 6:268)
To catch fish with a net when the pulale is used; he mea e loaa'i ka ia e like me ka lau, a thing for obtaining fish like the lau.
Fishing with a pula stick or pūlale to drive fish into a net.
Relating to the kingdom or government; he hana aupuni, government work; he mau lio aupuni, horses, the property of the government.
Au, a place, and puni, around.

definitions.notes: Note: Originally the word did not imply a large couentry, as there were formerly several aupunis on one island.
definitions.dtxt: A region of couentry governed by a chief or king.
A kingdom; the dominion, and jurisdiction of a king.
To be in an undisturbed state; to be in a state of peace and quietness, as a kingdom.
To exist or be known as a kingdom; ua aupuni keia pae aina, these islands are at peace.
To become a kingdom.

Government; national. Cf. kaumokuʻāina, kauʻāina, māhele ʻāina, mokuʻāina, pekelala. See entries below. Paimana aupuni. Communism. Pāka aupuni. national park. ʻAha Aupuni Hui Pū ʻia. United Nations (UN). ʻAha kūkā poʻo aupuni. summit, i.e., a conference of highest-level officials, as heads of government. ʻOihana Pāka Aupuni. National Park Service.

Government, kingdom, dominion, nation, people under a ruler; national. aupuni ʻemepela, empire. Aupuni koloniala, colonial government. Aupuni hui, union of nations, confederation. Nā ʻA upuni Hui ʻIa, United Nations, League of Nations. aupuni kākoʻo, ally. ʻAupuni makaʻāinana, commonwealth. Aupuni a ka lehulehu, democracy. Aupuni kūikawā, provisional government. Aupuni mōʻī, monarchy. Aupuni pelekikena, republic. Aupuni pekelala, federal government. Luna aupuni, government official. Hana o ke aupuni, official or government business Nā lā o kona noho aupuni ʻana, the days of his reign.

Two-party system of government. ʻOiai ua loaʻa he mau ʻaoʻao kālaiʻāina ma ke aupuni o ʻAmelika Hui pū ʻia, ʻōlelo wale ʻia nō he aupuni ʻaoʻao ʻelua ia no ka nānā nui ʻia o ʻelua wale nō ʻaoʻao. Although there are a number of political parties in the U.S., it is generally said that it is a two-party system since only two parties are considered by most.
Empire. Wahi a ka ʻōlelo kahiko, “ʻAʻohe napoʻo ʻana o ka lā ma luna o ke aupuni ʻemepela Beretānia.” As the old saying goes, “The sun never sets on the british empire.”
Emirate. Also aupuni ʻemira. See entry below.

data.word: Aupuni ʻEmira ʻAlapia Hui Pū ʻia

definitions.dtxt: United Arab Emirates.

definitions.der: [Lit. government (of) laws by the people. Cf. aupuni na ka lehulehu]
definitions.dtxt: Direct democracy, i.e., a government in which laws are made directly by the citizens.
Municipality, i.e., a city or town having its own incorporated government for local affairs. See kānāwai kūloko.
Dictatorship.
United Kingdom.
Kingdom of Tonga.

definitions.der: [Lit. government by the people. Cf. aupuni kānāwai na ka lehulehu]
definitions.dtxt: Democracy. ʻO ka nui o nā ʻāina o ʻEulopa, he mau ʻāina aupuni na ka lehulehu ia, no ka mea, na ka lehulehu nō e koho pāloka i nā luna aupuni. Most european countries are democracies since the public elects the government leaders.
Same as makaloa 2, a shellfish.
Same as mo'opunaakalīpoa, a common seaweed.
Austria; Austrian. Also ʻAukekulia.
Breast stroke (swimming); to swim thus.
Breast stroke; to swim the breast stroke.
Same as ʻāʻumeʻume (FOR. 5:553).
Drawer handle (preceded by ke). Cf. pōheo ʻume.
A different orthography for aua. See AUA. To forbid; refuse a favor when asked.

Au, a place, and waa, a canoe. A cluster or fleet of canoes; o ka nui o ka auwaa, ua pau i ka lukuia, the greater part of the fleet of canoes was destroyed; any number of canoes in company; e hoomakaukau i ko lakou auwaa iho, to get ready their own canoes.
Canoe fleet.
Name of the little ships which children make of cane leaves; auwaalaki hooholoholo. See AUWAALAUKI.
The name of a species of fish; he wahi mea holo maloko o ke kai, o like me ka waa, an animal that sails in the sea like a canoe.

definitions.der: [Lit. fleet of canoes with two sails. See ʻaumoana 3]
definitions.dtxt: Paper nautilus (Argonauta argo).
Auwaa and lau ki, ki leaves. Ki leaves folded up so as to sail for children’s sport.
The chin of a person; auwae. kahi malalo o ka waha, the auwae is the place below the mouth.
The jog cut in the top of the post of a Hawaiian house. See AUAE.
Chin. Fig. Indifferent, scornful. Cf. papa ʻauwae.

example_txt.txt: old man with yellowed chin [of the very old]

definitions.dtxt: To show no interest; scornful, disrespectful of taboo.
Curved notch cut on the outer side of a post below the base of a tenon, also called maʻi wahine (FOR. 5:643).
Portion of the point of a pearl-shell lure which overhangs the shank.
Distant, remote, deep. Pō nui auwaea (Kep. 90), the remote great darkness [age of the mythical beginning of the earth].
A present out of respect to the hakuaina of a hog or other fruits of the land.
definitions.notes: Note: When a land was transferred to a new owner, and he reinstated the people upon it, they usually bring a present from the land; this present of hogs, food, kapa, fish, nets, etc., was called auwaeaina.

definitions.dtxt: Tribute of the best selected (wae) hogs or fruits of the land to the landlord; to inspect land. E here ana i ka ʻauwaeʻāina o lākou nei, going to look over their land.
See Kaʻauwaelewa.
Firmly opposed, set against. Lit. firm chin. He mea ʻauwaepaʻa ʻia ihola ia e ʻoukou, ʻo ke kiʻi hoʻi i ke kāne, you all were dead set against my sending for the man.
Mumps.
Close relative. (Malo 199, Emerson note.)
Laziness; indifference. See AUAEPUU.

Indifference to work, discouraged. Lit. chin lump. hōʻauwaepuʻu To thrust out the chin and twist the lips to the side, or stick the tongue under the lower lip to form a lump (a gesture of refusal or contempt); to sulk, act indifferent or hostile.
To squat.

Au and waha, mouth. An opening of the ground, as a furrow; plowed ground. A ditch. A channel; a place dug like a pit. He lua loihi i eli ia a puni ke kihapai, a long pit dug around the garden. See aUAUWAHA.
To make a groove in wood; to cut forked, like the foot of a rafter on a hawaiian house.
Hoo. To make a ditch or furrow, i.e., to plow.

Ditch, furrow, trench, gutter, canal, channel; groove, as in a tapa beater; to notch, as tops of house posts (FOR. 5:643). Hāʻule nō i kāna ʻauwaha i ʻeli ai, fallen in the ditch he himself dug [caught in his own trap]. hōʻauwaha To make a ditch, plow a furrow; to cut a wedge or fork.
Outhouse, as for storing canoes.
Geologic trench, as Aleutian Trench.
Var. spelling of auahi.
Land section, Mākena qd., Maui.
Au, furrow, and wai, water. A brook; a small water course. The outlet of a pool. The general name for streams used in artificial irrigation.
Ditch, canal. ʻAuwai lawe mea ʻino, sewer; Lit. ditch carrying rotten things.
Gulch and spring between Keʻāmuku lava flow and Puʻuanahulu, North Kona, Hawaiʻi.
A running disease in the groin from impure habits; he wai ma ke kumu uha, he aukoi, he ewai, he auwakoi; a swelling in the groin and under the arms.
Same as ʻawaiāhiki.

Playground and street, Punchbowl, and an area near the mouth of Pauoa Valley, honolulu. Long hair of a moʻo woman (some say she was Kahalaopuna), bathing there at a ditch, resembled moss. (The name may once have been ʻAuwaiokalimu.)
Conduit, solid ditch.
Flume.
He auwaiahiki; a swelling in the groin; a bubo.
Entangled, snarled, as fishline.
Destitute, especially of the rich who lose ever everything.
See au 1.
See AUANA. In this, like many other cases, the w is a mere expletive, as the words may be written both ways and the pronunciation continue the same.
To wander; to go from place to place.
To scatter; disperse, as an army.
Hoo. To cause to wander, etc.
To go astray morally; to deviate from the path of rectitude.
Var. spelling of ʻauana, to wander.
Leg bone.

See AUE. An exclamation of wonder, of surprise, of fear, of pity or affection, as oh! woe! alas! Auwe kakou, alas for us! auwe ka lehulehu o ka poe i poho, alas for the multitude of those who were lost!
Also an expression of execration or cursing.
The cry of persons lamenting for the sick or dying; lamentation for any great loss or calamity.
Affection; love.
Also aue. To express an affection of the mind, as love, grief, disappointment, etc.
To mourn for one beloved.
To cry to one for help. To cry in great distress.
To groan; to sigh; to groan inwardly. See AUE.
Var. spelling of auē.
Same as ue 3.
Var. of ʻauwaeʻāina.
Name recorded for kauā, outcasts.
Var. spelling of auēuē.
See AUI. To decline; to incline from a perpendicular.
To move off; to pass along, as the sun is supposed to do; to decline, as the day.
Var. spelling of auī.
Au, tide, and wili, to turn.
A returning tide; he nalu mauka aku, au outward current.
A declining, etc. See AUINA.
Var. spelling of ʻauina.
Au and wini, sharp pointed. The sharp end of a potato leaf drooping with the rain; he auwiniwini ke au o ka uala luea i ka ua.
Sharp end of a leaf; term of raillery applied to men, referring to the male member. Cf. wini 1, sharp.
See AUOLO.
A harbor; a landing place; an entrance between two reefs; he awa o Kou ma oahu, he awa ku moku; he nui na awa hookomo waa, there is the harbor of Kou on Oahu where ships anchor.
Fine rain; mist; he ua awa, ma ka mauna ia ua.
A species of fish.
Name of a plant, of a bitter acrid taste, from which an intoxicating drink is made.

The name of the liquor itself expressed from the root of the plant; the drinking of awa causes the skin to crack and flake off for a time; i ka manawa e inu ai kekahi i ka awa, he maikai kona ili ke nana aku; a mahope, mahuna ka ili, nakaka, puehoeho, inoino loa ke nana aku.
Bitterness, from the name of the plant.
To converse earnestly.
Port, harbor, cove; channel or passage, as through a reef.

example_txt.txt: the many channels [or lochs] of Pearl Harbor

definitions.dtxt: Milkfish (Chanos chanos). Stages of growth are pua awa (puawa), young; awa ʻaua, medium size; awa, commercial size; awa kalamoho, very large.
Port, as in a computer.

The kava (Piper methysticum), a shrub 1.2 to 3.5 m tall with green jointed stems and heart-shaped leaves, native to Pacific islands, the root being the source of a narcotic drink of the same name used in ceremonies, prepared formerly by chewing, later by pounding. The comminuted particles were mixed with water and strained, When drunk to excess it caused drowsiness and, rarely, scaliness of the skin and bloodshot eyes. Kava was also used medicinally. Many varieties of kava are listed below.

example_txt.txt: to perform ceremony of offering kava to the gods [an unusual reference, as kava was not taken ceremonially, as in Sāmoa]
the tree-resting kava, growing in tree crotches and famous in poetry concerning Puna, Hawaiʻi

definitions.dtxt: Sour, bitter, poisonous.

example_txt.txt: The net is sour [of a net into which fish will not enter].
How bitter the gall [a sour disposition].

definitions.dtxt: To make bitter to make a concoction of leaves or bark to extract dye colors.
Cold mountain rain, fog, mist; to rain or mist. Fig. Tragic misfortune or ordeal; in PH this word is preceded by ke and may refer to volcanic eruption.

example_txt.txt: Uwē au, puni ʻā i ke ʻawa.
I weep, surrounded by lava in the downpour.
ʻO ka uahi noe lehua, ʻo ke ʻawa nui i ka mauna.
The lehua mist smoke, the great outburst on the mountain.

definitions.dtxt: A premature infant, believed caused by a “sour” condition of the mother.
A kind of bitter seaweed.
Noisy, loud; to talk loudly.
To dig, as a ditch or a pit; kohi, eli, kulepe, ekuia a awaawaa.
A ditch, trench or pit dug deep; a hole; a cave.
A famine, or the consequences of a famine.
Long, narrow excavation, trench, ditch, gully; to dig a ditch or furrow.
Safety, in football. See lala, muku.
Pas/imp. of ʻawaʻa.

chants.chtran: The high chief is a furrowed reef.
chants.chtxt: Papaioa ʻāwaʻahia ka lani.

definitions.dtxt: Same as ʻāwa liʻi, a variety of kava. It is said that the god Kāne brought the first ʻawa to Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava with long, light-green internodes and reddish nodes. Also ʻawa maha kea, ʻawa mākea.
A variety of kava.
A herring-like fish, sometimes called tenpounder or tarpon (Elops hawaiensis); according to some, a medium-sized awa fish.
Sour; bitter; sharp; pungent, as rum, pepper, orange skin, etc.; unpleasant to the taste; salt, as seawater; brackish; no ka awaawa o ka wai, hookoni.
MET. Hard to deal with.
Harsh in manners, as a person.
A mist; a spray. See AWA above.
Bitterness; sourness; pungency to the taste.
To be bitter, etc. See AWA.
Var. spelling of awāwa.
Redup. of ʻawa 2; bitter, sour, tart, acid, fermented, brackish; bitterness, sourness. Fig. Un-pleasant, disagreeable, harsh, bad-tempered; unpleasant or tragic experience, anguish.

example_txt.txt: iā Makaliʻi lau ʻawaʻawa o Puna
during the Makaliʻi season, innumerable disasters in Puna

definitions.dtxt: To embitter, make bitter or sour; bitter tasting.
Redup. of ʻawa 3. Pō Puna i ka ua a ka ʻawaʻawa (FS 225), Puna is darkened in the bitterly cold rain.
To dig; to throw up dirt; to root, as a hog; kohi, eli, awaa, kulepe, ekuia a awaawaa.
To make a groove; awaawaa waena, to make a hole in the center.
Uneven, furrowed, craggy.
Muscular.
Pas/imp. of ʻawaʻawa 1, 2.
Bitter, sour. Fig. Crabbed in nature, bitter, ungrateful.
Bitterness.
Ridge and gulch on the eastern side of upper Mānoa Valley, Honolulu. (Kiʻihelei boasted of having an affair with kahalaopuna. As punishment, gods turned him into the ridge and gulch. See ʻAihualama.)
Peak in the Koʻolau Range, Oʻahu, above Maunawili.
Pond near Moanalua, Honolulu, and street named for it. (TM)

definitions.der: [Lit. doubly bitter. (An alternative interpretation is awaawalua, double valley.)]
definitions.dtxt: Valley, southeast Niʻihau.
Valley and trail, Hanalei district, Kauaʻi.
To speak in a rude, harsh manner; rudeness. Pule ʻāwaha, a prayer to bring misfortune.
A mistake; an error, when the physician thought that a god had the direction of the disease or sent it.
To miss; to overlook; to make a mistake.
Bitter, like gall; like the apuawa; he mulemule.
A mist or spray. See AWAAWA and AWA.
The passive of awa for awaia, h inserted. Gram. § 48. To be bitter to the taste.
Hoo. To make bitter, severe; to be hard in treatment of men. mET. TO cause to be laborious, painful, toilsome.
Bitterness; sourness; ka awaawa, ka mulea.
Pas/imp. of ʻawa 2, 3. ʻAwahia nohoʻi ka ʻōlelo! What bitter words!
Toxic.
A variety of kava with long internodes.
Surly; regardless of everybody; obstinate; perverse.
Unwilling to attend to one’s duty; regardless of the will of the gods and the duties of religion; he aia, lokoino.
Bay west of Kalaupapa peninsula, Molokaʻi.
Similar to ʻawaʻawahua; ingratitude, meanness; to be mean, ungrateful, embittered, resentful. See make ʻawahua iho. Manaʻo ʻawahua o lākou (Nak. 110), their bitter thoughts.
A bundle or something tied up; lewa ka awai o ka paipu.
A place to stand on when addressing a multitude.
A raised platform; a scaffold; a pulpit.
Name of a disease; a swelling in the groin; he awai ma ke kumu o ka uha.
A bunch; a cluster; he awai kalo, a bunch of kalo; he awai huihui waina, a bunch of grapes.
To bind or tie up.
Rostrum, pulpit, speaker’s platform, dais, scaffold. Ka ʻāwai lāʻau, a pulpit of wood.
Bundle, bunch, cluster, as of tied objects.
See ʻawaiāhiki.
A swelling in the groin; a bubo. See AWAI.
Swelling in the groin, bubo; to have such a swelling. Also ʻaukoʻi, ʻauwaihiki, ʻāwai, ʻēwai, hahaʻi.

To bind securely, fasten, as of the marriage tie. Ua awaiāulu ʻia nā ʻōpio, the young people were united in one. Awaiāulu ʻia ke aloha me kuʻu lei pikake, bound securely is my love for my pikake lei [my child].
Good spirits, as the messengers of Kāne, who guarded people from evil ghosts and managed the rain, winds, and weather. (Malo 104)
Kava root dug ceremonially by a priest and held up (kū) towards heaven while chanting a prayer of consecration and eulogy, after which the root was termed ʻawailani.
A large awa, milkfish.
Same as makou 1, all kinds of buttercups.
Noon, midday; to be at noon, to become noon.

example_txt.txt: E awīwī ke awakea maila kākou.
Hurry, we are almost at noon.

definitions.dtxt: The time of day when the sun is the highest; noon; midday.
The name of the god who opened the gate of the sun; o Awakea ka mea nana i wehe ke pani o ka la, kahi i noho ai o Kaonohiokala.
Living together a great distance off and a long time ago; loihi loa o ka hele ana a me ka noho ana ma kahi hookahi; kahiko, liuliu.
Bay and land section, Keāhole qd., North Kona, Hawaiʻi. See Maniniʻōwali.
Gingerbread. Sh. ʻawapuhi + malakeke.
Probably same as ʻawa papa kea. (HP 202)
Same as ʻawa nēnē, a spotted variety of kava.
A variety of kava with green internodes of medium length.
Ship harbor or anchorage, port.
Avoirdupois.
