To pull steadily and carefully, as a fisherman afraid of losing his fish. Awala i ke aho.
To work steadily and with energy; awala ae la ia me ka huki ae i kana hee iluna o ka waa, he pulled steadily and drew his squid into the canoe.

To throw a knife or stock with a back flip; to throw back the head so as to grab dangling food with an open mouth. Cf. wala, to tilt. ʻO ka ʻāwala ʻana me nā miki poi, throwing back the head to grab dabs of poi.
To pull back steadily, as a line. Fig. To throw oneself into work.

definitions.der: [Lit. young kava plant or many branches]
definitions.dtxt: Gulch, Kahakuloa qd., West Maui.
A young kava plant (root, stem, and leaves) used as an offering to the gods.
See awa 1.
Same as ʻalaʻala wai nui 1, a succulent related to kava.
A, burning, and wale. Burnt very much; burnt of itself.

To burn for no particular reason; susceptible to combustion; spontaneous combustion; overcooked. E ʻā wale loa auaneʻi hoʻi ka iʻa ā ʻono ʻole ka ʻai ʻana, the fish may be cooked too much and not delicious to eat.
Name of a hard stone out of which kois were made.
Same as ʻawaakāne, a variety of kava.
Type of hard stone from which adzes were made.
A place where the bones of chiefs were hid; he iwi kau i ka awaloa.
Place where bones of chiefs were hidden, as in a cave.
Eight; the number eight; also ewalu. See WALU.
Eight (usually in counting in a series).
Land sections, Keāhole, Kailua, and Kohala qds., Hawaiʻi. Coastal area, Lahaina qd., Maui. Ancient surfing area, Honolulu (Finney and Houston 28).
Name for ʻawa ākea, ʻawa mākea at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava.
A variety of kava with short internodes and light-green stalk, reported at wainiha, Kauaʻi. (HP 202)
A variety of kava with smooth, white stalk.
A variety of kava with short, dark-green internodes and whitish nodes, called ʻawa papa mōʻī at Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
A variety of kava with short yellowish-green internodes and hairlike roots, named for the mokihana plant because of its fragrance, and yielding a strong brew; famous on Kauaʻi. (HP 202)
A variety of kava with long, spotted internodes. Also ʻawa kua ʻea.

A variety of kava with short internodes and spotted stalk. This name may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, mōʻī, and kea (or keʻokeʻo), the last being the commonest variety, and whitish in general appearance.

Wild ginger (Zingiber zerumbet), a forest herb with narrow leaves arranged along a stalk 30 to 60 cm high, bearing on a separate stalk small yellowish flowers in an oblong head, and having aromatic underground stems; a native of India. The root was used to scent and dye tapa. Also ʻawapuhi kuahiwi, ʻōpuhi. several varieties are listed below.

example_txt.txt: ginger leaves yellow quickly [of things that pass too soon]

definitions.dtxt: A variety of sweet potato.
A type of taro (no data). (FOR. 5:683)
Street, Mānoa, Honolulu.
The ginger root; the bastard ginger, the smell odoriferous, used for dyeing.
Same as ʻawapuhi Pākē.
Liparis hawaiensis, a small, endemic orchid with two large ovate leaves and small flowers.
Same as kāhili 4.
The white ginger (Hedychium coronarium), a large herb from India, both wild and cultivated in Hawaiʻi. White fragrant flowers, popular for leis and perfume, are borne in heads at tips of leafy stems.

Torch ginger (Phaeomeria speciosa), a large herb, from the East Indies, grown in Hawaiʻi for its ornamental pink or red cone-shaped flower heads. These are borne on long stems separate from the longer leafy stems.
See ʻawapuhi.

The shell ginger (Catimbium speciosum), a large ornamental herb from East indies. Clusters of irregularly bell-shaped flowers that are white and marked with red and yellow bend downward from the top of leafy, arching stems, which are 1.5 to 3.5 m high.
The yellow ginger (Hedychium flavescens), similar to ʻawapuhi keʻokeʻo and similarly used, but the flowers are yellow.
Ginger (Zingiber officinale), yielding a valuable commercial root spice. The plant looks much like ʻawapuhi kuahiwi and probably comes from southeast Asia. Also ʻawapuhi ʻai.
The red ginger (Alpinia purpurata), an ornamental plant having a long flower spike with many red bracts. It is a native of some islands of the western Pacific.
The opposite of mauna. A valley; he kahawai; a low, level place with high ground on each side.
The space between two prominences.
The space between the fingers of the hand and the toes of the feet.
The space between the branches of a river; he wahi poopoo loihi, a long deep place. See WA.
Valley, gulch, ravine. Cf. kuawa.
To make a groove, furrow.
Valley, gulch.
A variety of kava, an offshoot of ʻawa hiwa, with joints green on one side and dark on the other. (HP 202) Lit. watery kava of the bird.
Canyon. See Hakaʻama.
See Wāwāmalu.
Rift valley. Pae awāwa māwae. Series of rift valleys.
U-shaped valley.
A burden; that which is carried.
The tails of the squid; na awe o ka hee.

To carry; to bring, as it is followed with mai or aku; e awe aku, to carry off; e awe mai, to bring here; generally written lawe. PASS. To be borne, carried. Hookahi mea ana i awe aku la mai ko kakou alo aku; alaila, puolo ae la a paa, awe mai la aloko nei, then tie up the bundle fast, bring it in here.
Strand, thread; thin, soft.

definitions.der: [Note both awe and ʻawe in Hawaiian, awe and kawe in PCP]
definitions.dtxt: Wake of a ship.
Pack, knapsack carried on the back; to carry on the back. Cf. ʻauamo, hāʻawe. hōʻāwe To carry on the back; a burden so carried.
Tentacle, Cf. ʻawe puhi, ʻawe ule.
Backpack, knapsack. Also pāiki hāʻawe, pāisi hāʻawe.
Pas/imp. of ʻawe 1.
Beautiful; handsome; applied to men and women.
Well mixed; applied to poi.
White; slimy, as the fæces in some diseases. See WALEWALE.
The curling of the water in the wake of a ship.
The track or wake of a ship.
The tails or arms of a squid; he waiu no ka hee malalo o ke aweawe.
Tied up in a bundle; bound tight; he laulau aweawe no ka haawe.
Hoo. To make small; to diminish; to render of small account; e maawe.
Tenacious, sticky, threadlike, adhesive; glueyness, threads. Cf. aweawe poi. hōʻawe.'awe caus/sim.

chants.chtran: The sun’s rays on the plain
chants.chtxt: Ke aweawe ʻōnohi i ke kula

definitions.dtxt: Wake, as of a ship.
Redup. of ʻawe 1; pack knapsack; straps for a bundle; strips, as of wauke; runners, as on a vine; tentacles.
Tentacle.
Spotted; variegated with spots of different colors; he aweawea ulaula; obscure; not plain; aweawea ka lohe.
Dimly to the sight; not plainly, seen; faintly; ike aweawea aku la oia he wahi onohi ma Koolau, o Hawaii. Laieik. 26.
A glimpse; a half sight of an object.
The seeds of green fruit, as squashes, melons, etc.
To see in a slight degree; to catch a glimpse of an object.
To act the part of a weawea or procurer; to act the pimp. See WEAWEA.

Faint trace, spot, glimpse; faint, dim; streaked, faded. ʻĀweʻaweʻa koko aliʻi (Kep. 127), trace of royal blood. ʻĀweʻaweʻa lono, dim recollection. ʻIke ʻāweʻaweʻa, to see fleetingly, to know but have slight knowledge; faint glimpsing, slight knowledge. Ua ʻike ʻāweʻaweʻa aʻe nei au i ua manu nei, I caught but a fleeting glimpse of this bird. hoʻāweʻaweʻa Caus/sim.
A kind of seaweed.
Trace, small amount. Kumumea ʻāweʻaweʻa. Trace element.
Traces of blood, as in vomit.
Drip of poi; an insult to the chiefs of Hawaiʻi, playing on the name of their chiefs, Keawe, with implication that poi is excreted in a sticky chain.
Hemoglobin. Comb. ʻawe + hā; Māori kawehā.
Stream, Hilo and Honomū qds., Hawaiʻi. Gulch, east Lānaʻi, and alternate name for lōpā surfing area, Lānaʻi.
Deceitful; dishonest; parsimonious.
Deceit; dishonesty; one who refuses to pay a forfeit.
To hide rather than share wealth (perhaps related to weka, squid ink).
Deceitful; dishonest; parsimonious.
Deceit; dishonesty; one who refuses to pay a forfeit.
A species of fish; he puhi awela; a variety probably of the kala.
Young stage of the hou fish, Christmas wrasse (Thalassoma fuscum).
Heated, hot.

A flowerless variety of sugar cane, named for the fish; it is green and yellow striped, becoming flushed with rose in the sun; the internodes are barrel-shaped and the leaves variegated. (HP 221, 224) Also puaʻole.
A variety of sugar cane, a bronze-yellow mutant of ʻāwela. Also uleʻohiʻu, uluhui. (HP 221)
Escaping, as a fish from a net; ke kukai awelawela; he poniu, he kaihi.
A species of fish; he puhi awela; a variety probably of the kala.
Redup. of ʻāwela 2.
The running of a man sent on an errand; aka, i lilo ka awele ka pahu i kekahi nana ke eo.
Same as hāwele, to tie.
Goal, mark, line, goal post. (AP)
Average, pro rata.
Average; mean, in math. ʻAwelike o ka ua. Average rainfall. ʻAwelike māmā holo. Average speed. ʻAwelike nuipaʻa ʻātoma. Average atomic mass.
See WELU. Torn; ragged; worn to holes, as a kapa; he wahi kapa awelu kona i haawiia’ku.
Ragged, worn-out, torn; worn out garment. ʻĀwelu moena, ragged mat.
To be torn; to be ragged, as a kapa; nahaehae, weluwelu.
Redup. of ʻāwelu.
Chromosome.
Applied to some fish; a iho aku la i ka paeaea aweoweo. Laieik. 206.
A shrub or small tree resembling pig-weed, sometimes eaten by Hawaiians.
Name of a species of reddish fish. See ALALAUWA.
Various Hawaiian species of Priacanthus, red fishes, sometimes called bigeye. Young are called ʻalalauā and ʻalauwā.
A variety of sugar cane named for the fish.
Same as ʻāheahea (Chenopodium oahuense).
A seaweed.
Asbestos.
Eel tentacle, but referring to the octopus, a euphemism for ʻaweule.
A native variety of taro, often growing wild; good for poi, but too acrid for table taro; the corms are shaggy and fibrous outside, the flesh white with yellow fibers. Also māʻauea.

definitions.der: [Lit. strand (through which) electricity runs. Cf. mea uholo uila. See ʻūkake uila]
definitions.dtxt: Brush, i.e., a contact that supplies electric current to a commutator.
Lone octopus tentacle, said to wave in order to entice and ensnare a victim.
A species of wild or mountain kalo; called also the mamauea.
Same as ʻāweu.
A plant, used to stop bleeding.
Same as ʻuwīʻuwī, an herb.
A glimpse; an imperfect sight.
To have a glimpse of a thing. See AWEAWEA.
Same as ʻāweʻaweʻa.
A glimpse; an imperfect sight.
To have a glimpse of a thing. See AWEAWEA.
Redup. of ʻāwiha.
Ka poe awihi hoowalewale, enchanters.
To wink; to ogle; to look obliquely; to eye; to look at one with jealousy.
To wink, ogle. See saying, lihilihi 2. Kō ʻoukou poʻe ʻāwihi hoʻowalewale, your deceiving enchanters.
Redup. of ʻāwihi.
IMF, Be quick; hasten.
To hurry, be quick, swift. E ʻāwiki mai ʻoe! Hurry up!
A vine bearing black berries about the size and shape of American blackberries; they are used as a medicine, operating both as an emetic and cathartic; ke okole o makiki.
Redup. of ʻāwiki.
A vine (Canavalia spp.), native to Hawaiʻi, related to the maunaloa (C. cathartica), but with narrower pods; used for small, temporary fish traps. Also puakauhi.
Same as kōʻeleʻele, a seaweed.
To mix together different ingredients.
To make a garment of different textures of cloth.
To wind; to twist about a thing; to entwine.
To be agitated with conflicting emotions. See WILI.
To mix, interweave, entwine; mixed, agitated. Cf. koʻi ʻāwili. Koko ʻāwili, mixed blood.
Alligation (an old arithmetic term). ʻĀwili kaulua, alligation alternate.
Point, Hoʻōpūloa qd., South Kona; ancient surfing area, Puna district, Hawaiʻi (Finney, 1959a:51). See Kawili.
The intensive of awili above.
Redup. of ʻāwili 1.
Sharp, bold, forward. Cf. kīwini, wini.
Land section and gulch, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi. See Naeʻole. Falls and stream, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
To quicken; to hasten; to expedite; to accelerate. SYN. with wikiwiki.
A small native herb (Centaurium sebaeoides, syn. Erythraea sebaeoides), with white or pale pink flowers, in the gentian family.
To hurry; speedy, swift, quick, fast.
Bahamas; Bahamian. Also Pahama.
Bahrain.
To boil; to seethe. The corresponding Hawaiian word is hoolapalapa.
Boiled; seethed.
Tobacco; e puhi baka, to smoke tobacco.
Baltic. Ke kai ʻo Balatika. Baltic Sea.
Barley, a species of grain.
Ballet. Also pālē, hulahula pālē.
Barents. Ke kai ʻo Baleneta. Barents Sea.
Balm, an odoriferous plant.
Banda. Ke kai ʻo Banada. Banda Sea.
Bangladesh.
Brandy, an intoxicating drink distilled from wine.
Brazil; Brazilian. Also Palakila.
Barium.
Butter.
Butter.
A bath, a Hebrew measure.
A bear, a wild ferocious animal.
A half shekel, a measure of weight.
Puka kona kaula ma ka belaki ma ka ono o ka maha. Anat. 28.
Belarus.
A bell; bele gula.
Belize; Belizean.
Blue; the color blue.
Benzene.
Show bread.
Leavened bread.
With hu ole. Unleavened bread.
The twelve loaves of bread set by the Jewish priest every Sabbath on the golden altar.
A beryl, name of a precious stone.
Of or like a beryl.
Bering.
A broom, an instrument for sweeping.
To broom; to sweep with a broom. The Hawaiian equivalent is kāhili.
Beta.
The Hawaiian pronunciation for beef, and should properly be written bifi. An ox or cow; the general name for neat cattle.
See BIPI.
See BIPI.
See BIPI.
Bipi with kuapuu, humpback. The bison (in the United States of America, the buffalo.) Lam.
Bisulfate.
Bitumen, a mineral slime.
A bowl; a dish. The Hawaiian word is ipu.
Bolivia; Bolivian.
Bosnia. Bosenia me Hesegowina. Bosnia and Herzogovina.
Botswana.
Bulgaria; Bulgarian. Also Pulukalia.
The name of a game.
Burkina Faso.
Burma; Burmese. Also Puruma.
Burundi.
A bushel, a dry measure of thirty-two quarts. Ana Hon. 60.
Bhutan; Bhutanese.
Butane.
One who serves; a deacon; a deaconess.
North Dakota; North Dakotan. Also Kakoka ʻĀkau,
South Dakota; South Dakotan. Also Kakoka Hema.
A species of deer; the fallow deer; the pygarg.
A deer; a stag.
Abbreviation for Dekemapa (December). See Kekemapa.
Var. of Kekemapa (December). Abb. Dek.
Delaware; Delawarean. Also Kelauea.
The name stands in connection with metals. In modern times bdellium is a gum.
See DAMA above.
Denmark; Dane; Danish. Also Kenemaka.
A dragon. He is called a serpent and satan in verse 9.
A drachm, a small weight.
Name of a little bird; a swallow.
The devil; the tempter.
Gr. See DAIAKONA. A deacon, an officer in a church.
