definitions.dtxt: With wahine. A female deer; a hind.
Diazinon.
Djibouti.
Tribute; tribute money.
definitions.notes: Note: The word hapaha is used in the late editions of the New Testament.

definitions.dtxt: Dieldrin, a kind of insecticide. Cf. ʻalidirina. See lāʻau make.
A small Hebrew measure; a deal.
Dioxide.
Disulfide.
Hua dudima, a mandrake.
Chald. A dulcimer, an ancient instrument of music.
In law, custom; toll paid for the privilege of receiving foreign merchandise.
definitions.notes: Note: Waiwai auhau is used for dute in the last editions of the New Testament.

definitions.dtxt: From; away; e holo e lakou, they will flee from; e puhi e, blow away; i kai lilo e, at sea afar off.
Other; another; strange; new; mea e, a stranger, a strange thing; kanaka e, a stranger; often SYN. with malihini.
Synonymous with and a contraction for ae; yes. E, yes, is more familiar, and not so dignified and respectful as ae. See AE.
To enter, as into a couentry or city.
To dash upon, as waves upon the deck of a ship; aohe o kana mai o ka nui o na ale i e maluna o ka moku. See EE.
After a word ending in a, 'e is a contraction for ae.
Part. marking imperative/intentive mood. See e (verb) ai, e (verb) ana, Gram. 5.4.
Agentive part. By, by means of (follows a pas/imp.). (Gram. 9.9)

example_txt.txt: Ua ʻāhewa ʻia ʻoia e ke aliʻi.
He was blamed by the chief.

definitions.dtxt: Infinitive part. used before certain subordinate verbs. (Gram. 5.4)
See ē 1.

By. As a preposition, it is mostly used after passive verbs to express the agent; as, ua ahewaia oia e ke alii, he was condemned by the chief. Many verbs have no sign of a passive voice, the construction of the sentence alone determines it, and the e thus situated helps determine the point as much as anything; nui loa hoi ka poe daimonio i mahiki aku e ia. Gram. § 105,11.
E standing before nouns marks the auihea or vocative case; it also often follows the same case; as, e ka lani e, 0 chief. Gram. § 105, 8.

definitions.notes: Note: E is mostly used at the beginning of an address, and ea in the middle, or if a single sentence, only at the end.
definitions.dtxt: E is used also to call or invite attention to what one is about to say; a contraction, perhaps of ea.

E following either active, passive or neuter verbs signifies before hand, and serves to mark a kind of second future tense of the verb; as, lohe e au, I heard before; hiki e mai oia, he had arrived first. Gram. § 190, 2d.

E is the sign of the imperative mood, And generally of the infinitive also, though after hiki and pono the e of the infinitive is changed into ke. Gram. § 191 and 193. E is also the sign of the future tense. Gram. § 190, 1.
Prefix to numerals, inanimate, as ʻekahi, ʻelua, ʻekolu.
Vocative part.; a second ē often follows the head word for emphasis. Ē is shortened to e before third-person pronouns: see e ia nei, e lākou ala.
Intensifying part., as in the common exclamation Auē nohoʻi ē! (Gram. 7.5)
Alas!

example_txt.txt: That was a really hard lesson, yeah?

definitions.dtxt: A word used only at the end of a sentence or phrase, with meanings such as: Yeah; right; isn't that so? (Commonly pronounced the same as the French hein which carries the same meaning.)

Different, strange, peculiar, unusual, heathen (Biblical), other; away off, elsewhere; beforehand, already, before, premature, in advance (sometimes translated ‘had’ and called by Andrews [Gram. 1.4] a sign of the pluperfect tense, although it is used after the imperative mood). Cf. ʻē aʻe, ʻano ʻē, mea ʻē. ʻĀina ʻē, foreign land. He ʻē! How strange! [It] is gone, past! Holo ʻē lākou, they fled beforehand (away, elsewhere). Keiki hānau ʻē, prematurely born child. Hele ma kahi ʻē! Go away! Get out ʻIke ʻē lākou, they already knew. I kahi ʻē ka ua, waele ʻē ke pulu (saying), when the rain is elsewhere, open up beforehand the mulch [prepare for rain before it comes].
Yes (unemphatic, as in mild agreement and indicating that one has heard; cf. ʻae).
The letter “e”.
Key of A (music).
Dirty; dusty, as when the air is full of dust.
Strong smelling, as meat or food kept too long. See EAEA.
Windy; noisy; without effect; he ea ka waha i ke ao ana i ke keiki hookuli, wahapaa; noisy; clamorous; assenting to the commands of a parent, but not obeying; disobedient.
The expression of a call to one’s attention, as aloha oukou, ea, to which a reply is expected; generally ae. aloha.

E-A is used in answer to a call, more familiar and disrespectful than eo. Ea is also used by a speaker to call the attention of his hearers to some particular point which he is about to state; its frequency of use is according to the taste of the speaker; it is brought out generally, in the middle of a sentence. Sometimes it commences a speech.
A species of fish, somewhat similar to the hilu, aawa and poou.
A species of turtle much valued on account of the shell.
definitions.notes: Note: The ea was forbidden to women to eat, under the kapu system.

definitions.dtxt: The shell itself; he ea kuu wakawaka. Put for ivory.
Dirt; dust raised by the wind.

chants.chtxt: Ea me he opua hiki kakahiaka la, Me he mea la o Hoku o Mahealani. Ka hukiku o ka waa la i ka lae.

definitions.dtxt: In music, the highest part; the air.
Ku ka ea o Lahainaluna i ka lepo; dust raised by the wind, but not a whirlwind.
Takes ke for its article. Spirit; vital breath; the breath of life.
Life itself; oiai ke ea, while life lasts.
The natural breath of life. E kaili aku ke ea, to die.
The breath of man or beast. Nani ka lokomaikai o ke Akua I kona haawi ana mai i ke ea o ke kanaka. SYN. with hanu.
He makani ku malie, oia ka makani e hanu ai kakou, the breathable air.
The thrush or aphthæ, a disease of children; art, ka.
To raise up, as a person bowed down.
To lift or throw up.
To raise up, as from the grave.
To mount or go up upon, as an ancient bed.
To rise up, as water.
Hoo. To be thrown or raised up, as land out of the ocean; ua hoea mai na aina mai loko mai o ka moana, the land was thrown up out of the ocean.
To rise in sight, as a cloud. 1 Nal 18:44. To heave in sight, as a ship; a hoea mai makai aku o Hilo, she hove in sight off Hilo.
To rise up, as out of the water.
To stir up, excite, as the affections; ia manawa ka hoea ana mai o ka hai, at that time was the exciting of other’s love.

Fume. Also ea puka. Āohiohi ea. Air resistance, i.e., the force of air against a moving object. Ana mīkā ea. Barometer. Pōhaku puka ea. Air stone, i.e., the porous rock in an aquarium that creates tiny bubbles at the surface of the water to facilitate the exchange of gases. Pūnuku ea make. Gas mask, as used during World War II.

example_txt.txt: hoʻihoʻi i ke ea o Hawaiʻi

definitions.dtxt: Sovereignty, rule, independence.

example_txt.txt: to deprive of rights of livelihood
Ua mau ke ea o ka ʻāina i ka pono.
The life of the land is preserved in righteousness. [Motto of Hawaiʻi]
He palupalu lākou, he ea hele wale aku.
They were flesh, a wind that passes away.
Kāʻili ʻia aku ke ea o ʻAberahama.
Abraham gave up the ghost; Lit. the breath of life was snatched away.

definitions.dtxt: Life, air, breath, respiration, vapor, gas; fumes, as of tobacco; breeze, spirit. This ea, as well as ea 1, 3, 4, is sometimes pronounced or sung ʻea. Cf. eamāmā, eaolamāmā.
To rise, go up, raise, become erect. Cf. aea, eʻea, hōʻea.

example_txt.txt: ke ea ʻana o ka ʻai, ka iʻa
ʻAʻole hoʻi au e ea maluna o koʻu wahi moe.
I will not go up into my bed.

definitions.dtxt: To smell. Also ʻea. Cf. maea, māeaea.
Hawksbill turtle (Chelone imbricata), both land and sea species; the shell of this turtle.
Reddish-brown, as the color of the ʻea shell. Cf. ʻea mālani, ʻea ʻula.

A general term for infections and infectious diseases; coated tongue, sometimes accompanied by sore throat, the thrush disease of children. Many diseases of miscellaneous nature begin with ʻea and are listed below.

example_txt.txt: ʻOia kamaʻilio aku a ʻea ka waha, ʻaʻohe lohe ʻia mai.
While talking on until the tongue is coated, yet no one pays any attention [a metaphor to show exasperation].
Kū ka ʻea i ka moana.
The spray rises in the sea.

definitions.dtxt: Spray. Cf. ʻeʻa, dust. These words are sometimes interchanged.
Vocative interj. usually at the beginning or end of utterances. (Gram. 12)
Var. of ea 4, to smell.
Noisy; to yell, whoop; whoop.

example_txt.txt: A waiho i ka ʻea nā iwi o kama hele.
The traveler’s bones are left in the air [said of one dying in a foreign land].

definitions.dtxt: Var. of ea 2, 3.
Melody, tune. (air). Also leo. See entries below and mū hōlapu pale ʻea pau, ʻōnaehana pale ʻea, ʻukulele ʻea honu.
Plastic. Niʻihau. Kanaka ʻea. Mannequin. ʻEke ʻea. Plastic bag (preceded by ke). Cf. pūʻolo pepa. Tuko paipu ʻea. Plastic pipe cement. Also tuko paipu.

Dust, dirt, dust cloud, spray (ʻeʻa and ʻea 4 are probably interchanged at times). Kōwelo ʻeʻa, dust streamer. Kū ka ʻeʻa i ke kula, the dust cloud rose over the plain. ʻŌkaʻi ka ʻeʻa, ʻōkaʻi huakaʻi ʻula, a marching cloud of dust, a red procession on the march [warriors with feather cloaks].
Mountain banana patch. Līlā ka maiʻa o ka ʻeʻa, wili ka ʻōkaʻi, spindly is the growth of the mountain banana patch, the blossom container twists [even a spindly plant may bear fruit].
A fish similar to ʻaʻawa, but with dark flesh.
Isn't that so? That’s it! ʻOia, ʻeā? Is that so? Ua hele aku ʻoia i Honolulu, ʻeā, she went to Honolulu, you know. ʻEā, e aha ana ʻoukou? Say, what are you up to? Pēlā, ʻeā? It’s that way, is it?
Song refrain. See ex., wawalo and Gram. 12. Also ʻeāʻeā.
Gas.
Different, other, another, else.
Air, breath, air current. Some confusion exists in the uses of eaea, ʻeaʻea, and ʻeʻaʻeʻa.

example_txt.txt: He iʻa no ka papaʻu, he loaʻa wale i ka hopu lima; he iʻa no ka hohonu, noho i ke eaea.
Fish of the shallows, gotten merely by catching in the hands; fish of the depths stay in the high waves [some tasks are easier than others].

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ea 3; to rise; high waves.
Redup. of ea 4; a smell, as of seaweed; to smell.
Dignified; honorable; high. SYN. with hanohano, hiehie, eaea kai. Me he wawae, kuhaka la ka eaea.
Aerated; aerobic, i.e., living, active, or occurring only in the presence of oxygen. See hōʻeaea.
Redup. of ʻeʻa 1, dust; dusty; obscure, darkened, cloudy, shady; to cloud, overshadow (sometimes confused with eaea and ʻeaʻea).
To be covered with dust, as one out in the wind where the dust is flying; eaea na kamalii o Lahainaluna i ka lepo.
To cover the eyebrows, as a fisherman, to shade the eyes while looking into deep water for fish; ka lawaia nui i eaea na kuemaka i ehuehu na lihilihi.

example_txt.txt: ka lawaiʻa nui i ʻeaʻea nā kuʻemaka, i ʻehuʻehu nā lihilihi
the great fisherman whose brows are sprayed with sea and whose lashes are reddened [admiration of a fisherman]

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻea 4, spray; encrusted with spray (sometimes confused with eaea and ʻeʻaʻeʻa).
Dignified, honorable. (And.)
A bird (no data).
At end of verses in some chants that maintains rhythm and affords pleasure in repetition, something like English tra-la-la.

chants.mltran: ♫  Beautiful indeed the pandanus, tra-la, of Naue by the sea, tra-la.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Nani wale nā hala, ʻeāʻeā, o Naue i ke kai, ʻeāʻeā.

definitions.dtxt: That which is covered with sea drops or the spray of the sea.

definitions.der: [Lit. six-pack plastic. ʻEa ʻekeʻeke koloaka. Six-pack soda ring. ʻEa ʻekeʻeke pia. Six-pack beer ring]
definitions.dtxt: Six-pack ring, i.e., the plastic ring which holds the cans together.

See E. E, sign of the future tense, and aha, what. How? what? used with the future, as heaha is with the present and past; eaha ia oe? how will it be with you? what will become of you? Eaha ana oukou? what will you be about?
Condition of frequent colds.
Great hunger, perhaps due to diabetes.
Dizzy spells, dizziness; latent ʻea disease (KAM. 64:103).
Impaired vision, perhaps labyrinthitis.
Charge card.
A disease, perhaps secondary lues (KAM. 64:115).
Condition of listlessness.

definitions.der: [Lit. plastic (for) placing clothes. See uea kau lole, lāʻau kau lole, mea kau lole]
definitions.dtxt: Hanger, when made of plastic.

definitions.der: [Lit. tortoise with back fitted into sections]
definitions.dtxt: A variety of ʻea, a land tortoise.
Disease with swelling symptoms.
Severe headaches, perhaps due to high blood pressure.
A type of ʻea described as evanescent. (KAM. 64:103)
Light-brown in color. See ʻea 2.
Gas.
Oxygen.
Jaundice, hepatitis.

definitions.der: [Lit. pineapple plastic (from the plastic used when planting pineapples). See hāliʻi ʻea]
definitions.dtxt: Polyethylene.
Dizziness, vertigo.
Fume. Also ea.
Wine-colored, such a color.
Osteomalacia, gradual softening of the bones.
Acute childhood ʻea disease. (KAM. 64:105)
Ebony, a species of black wood.
Name of the garden planted for our first parents.
Caressing; inviting; kind; he makamaka ee, he iike, he lokomaikai, he koe ole, aole wawau.
He hulu ee no ka manu oo, that is, the yellow feathers under the wing (or the ee) of the oo, oia ka lei hulu manu.
Hoo. A rising; a sweeping; as, kai hoee.
Maloo, kaee; dry; not wet.
Out of sight; at a great distance. See E.
Opposite to; adversely; against.
The armpit. See POEE and POAEAE. Same under the wing of fowls.
Hard, stiff, dry. Cf. kaʻeʻe.
To log on, log in, as of a network or other computer system. Cf. lele.
To climb on, mount, get on, go aboard, board, embark; one who climbs, mounts, boards; step. Cf. eʻe kuahiwi, eʻe moku, hikieʻe. Kai eʻe, tidal wave.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻēʻe akula ia i ka noho maluna o kona hoki.

definitions.dtxt: To rise or swell, as surf; to mount, as a surfer mounts a wave.
Same as aʻa 2, to extend greetings.
See E, to dash upon. To mount; to get upon anything higher, as a horse; to leap upon; to get on board a ship; ee aku la maluna o ka moku; to get into a carriage. To go aboard a vessel.
Hoo. To receive on board a ship; to put upon, as a saddle upon a horse. Kin, 22:3. To set or put one up, as upon a horse.
To pass from one carriage to another. Ee maluna o ka waa; ee maluna o ka lio. See AE, 4.

example_txt.txt: He ʻēʻē wale nō kona manaʻo.
E pale ana i ka wawā lapuwale, a me ke kū ʻēʻē ʻana i ka mea i kapa hewa ʻia he naʻauao.
Avoiding profane babblings and oppositions of the thing falsely called science.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻē 1; contrary, peculiar, opposite; adversely.
To keep away from, avoid.
Yellow underwing feathers of the ʻōʻō, a bird, as used in featherwork.
Armpit. Also pōʻaeʻae, poʻēʻē; see kuiʻēʻē.
Quick ready, expert. He ʻeʻea nō kona kūlana, he is quick in his ways.
A bird, said to be an adult ʻalaiaha. (KL. line 307)
Quick; ready; expert.
Redup. of ea 3; to rise up frequently, as in water; to bob up and down. Eʻea aʻe ke poʻo o ka honu i ka ʻilikai, the head of the turtle appeared again and again on the surface of the sea.
To rise up frequently. See EA.
Redup. of eʻe 1; to keep climbing over everything, as an active child; mischievous.
To rise up. See EE, to mount. To rise up from one’s seat to steal something. Hence,
To be mischievous.
The top of a tree when cut off.
Same as hehi, to step on. ʻEʻehi ihola ia a paʻa, he placed his feet down and stood firm.
To tramp up; to kick up, as dust. See EHI and HEHI.
Overcome with fearful reverence, terror-stricken, awe-stricken; awe-inspiring, solemn; fear, reverence, awe, terror; wierd.
Art., ke. Fear; dread; reverence; awe.
A vision.
Fearful; dreadful; awful.
Trembling with fright, occasioned by a dream or vision.
Passive, h inserted, for eeia. See E, another; strange. To fear greatly; to be afraid; to be dreadful.
To lop the ears, as an animal, through fear or shame.
Applied to men whose countenances droop with fear; kindred with makau, but stronger; also written ehia.
Redup. of ʻehu 5; reddish; a number of ʻehu persons. Pala ʻeʻehu, to turn red or yellow, as leaves or fruit (riper than pala hāʻama).
Same as ehuehu, healthy.
Offensive, filthy, fly-ridden. (And.)
Some of the words of a filthy song sung at a great day of the Princess.
Var. of pepeiao, ear. Mō ka ʻeʻeiao o ka puaʻa, cut off is the ear of the pig.
Same as ʻeʻei. (AP)
Some of the words of a filthy song sung at a great day of the Princess.
To creak, crackle. Cf. ʻaʻina, ʻuʻina.
To creak; to grate, as one thing against another; to crepitate. See UUINA.
Same as ʻEka 2, a wind.
Excellent, etc. See EKE.
Excellent; nice; applied to a canoe, etc. See EKE.

example_txt.txt: ʻeʻeke maila i ka wela o ke ahi
shrinking back from the heat of the fire

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻeke 2. Cf. mūʻeʻeke.
Name given for a hard-shelled crab (no data).
A starting from fear; a shrinking from the contact with fire or any fearful object.
The shrinking or contracting of a rope in length.
A species of crab in the sea.
To start away, as a person from danger; to shrink back.
The motion of one’s hand when he has burnt his finger.
To twinge or writhe, as with great pain.
To start, as with fear; e puiwa; eeke mai la ia i ka wela i ke ahi.
To tap a drum slowly, as to accompany a chant.
To drum with the fingers on the pahu and sing at the same time.
Same as ʻekuʻeku. Ē Kānepuaʻa, e ʻeʻeku e kūlapa, e hoʻowali, o Kānepuaʻa, root, and make ridges and furrows.
To climb mountains; mountain climber.
Same as ʻeleʻele 1, but used chiefly in old chants. Ka manu ʻeʻele koi (FOR. 5:99), the black bird begged.
Concave, i.e., hollowed or rounded inward, as the inside of a bowl. Sh. redup. of kaʻele. Cf. ʻeʻemu. Aniani ʻeʻele. Concave mirror. Aniani kaulona ʻeʻele. Concave lens.
Stormy. Kū ʻia ka malama ʻeʻelekoa, weathered the stormy month [to have endured hardships].

Redup. of ʻelekū; blackened or darkened, as leaves or fruit due to maturity or to pelting by storms; dark, gloomy, as clouds. Ma ia malama ua ʻeʻelekū ka lani i nā ao ua … a ua ʻeʻelekū hoʻi nā lau o nā lāʻau a me nā mea ulu i ke oʻo (Kep. 93), in this month the sky is dark with rain clouds … and the leaves of trees and growing things are dark with maturity. Ma ia malama o Nana, ua pau ka ʻeʻelekū o ka lau o nā lāʻau i ka noke a ka ua ma nā lā o ka hoʻoilo (Kep. 89), in this month of Nana, the dark bruising of the leaves of trees by the pelting of the rains of the days of winter has ceased.
Redup. of ʻelo; drenched, soaked. hōʻeʻelo To wet, drench, soak; tearfully sulky, as a crying child. Ua hōʻeʻelo, drenching rain.
Loitering; to dilly-dally.
Name of a storm from the northeast of Waimea, Hawaiʻi. (And.)
A storm at Waimea from the northeast.
To board a ship; ship passenger; immigrant.
Convex, i.e., curved or rounded, as the exterior of a sphere or circle. Cf. ʻeʻele.
Shy, timid, wary, wild, afraid, fearsome, untamed; to shy away. Cf. ʻena 2, hāʻeʻena. ʻEʻena Hāʻena i ke ehu kai, Hāʻena is fearsome because of sea spray.
Extraordinary. Cf. ʻē 1. He ʻeʻena a mīkolohua ka ʻōlelo, impressive and eloquent in speech. Kani ʻeʻena ka pahu i ka moana, the drum sounds weirdly over the ocean.
O ka pua eena ole ia o ka moku? Wild; untamed, as children in a school.
Skillful; applied to birds and fish that discover the snare or net.
To tremble for, as for one in danger; eene aku i ka mea aneane haule.
To be astonished at, or ashamed of one for lying or committing other evil.
To tremble for one violating the kapu of the chiefs, as a child ignorantly climbing on the person of a chief, which was death.

Extraordinary, incomprehensible, abnormal, deceitful, peculiar, as persons with miraculous powers; such persons. Many ʻeʻepa characters in mythology were born in strange forms, as a plant, an animal, or a piece of rope. Cf. ʻepa 1, ʻepaʻepa, kino ʻeʻepa. The menehune, Nāwā, and Nāmū of Waolani in Nuʻuanu Valley were ʻeʻepa. Trickery or deceit that passes comprehension is also ʻeʻepa. hōʻeʻepa Mysterious, mystifying, incomprehensible. Hōʻeʻepa wale hoʻi nā hana a kēlā keiki, that boy’s behavior is certainly mysterious.
See EPA. Forgery; deceit; treachery.
Goblin.
To crawl, creep, as an insect. Cf. ʻeu 2.

Shuddering sensation of revulsion (less strong than mania); to rise in horror, flinch (sometimes interpreted as a portent). ʻEʻeu ka ʻili o ke poʻo, the scalp of the head flinches. ʻEʻeu aʻela ka hulu o ka ʻīlio, the dog’s hair bristles [in anger].
Alert; ready to obey orders.
To make a wry face, pout, as in derision; to protrude the lips mockingly.
Ewa, ewaewa; to mock; to make mouths at; to vex.

Hurt, in pain, painful, aching, sore, pained; pain, injury, ailment, suffering, soreness, aching; to hurt, pain, cause suffering or pang. See mea ʻeha. Gram. 4.4. ʻEha koni, throbbing ache; Fig. Throbbing love. He ʻeha konikoni i ka puʻuwai, the heart throbs with agony [of love]. ʻEha i ka ʻeha lima ʻole, aching with an ache not inflicted by [human] hands [love]. ʻAʻole e ʻeha ke keiki o Kauaʻi iā ʻoe (FOR. 5:411), you won't hurt the Kauaʻi lad. E ʻeha ana ʻoia iaʻu, I will hurt him. ʻEha o ke kua, backache. Nāna wale nō ka ʻeha, ā koe ke kaikuaʻana huhū (FOR. 4:37), only he inflicted pain, until [only] the angry older brother was left. hōʻeha To inflict pain or punishment, to hurt, oppress.
Pain; soreness of any kind; sorrow; suffering of punishment; a hurt; affliction.
Sore; painful; hurtful.

To be hurt; to be sore; to be painful; to suffer; eha ka naau, the heart is pained. Hoo. To suffer in any way, as in sickness or pain, or by punishment according to law, justly or unjustly. Fig. To cause hurt; to grieve one.
Four; four times. See ex., hā 1.
Four; the number four. See AHA and HA.
Same as ēhē.

chants.chtran: A genital chant, oh, oh, for ʻIolani, oh, oh
chants.chtxt: He wahi maʻi ēhē, ēhā, no ʻIolani, ēhē, ēhā

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻeha; great pain, agony, tribulation, many small pains; painful. ʻEhaʻeha ka naʻau, feelings are hurt. hōʻehaʻeha Redup. of hōʻeha; to torment, distress. Hōʻehaʻeha naʻau, heart-breaking, tragic.
Suffering; torment; pain; grief.
Intensely painful. 1 Nal 12:4.
Painfully; grievously.
Conj. 13 of eha. Hoo. To give pain; to afflict. To chastise; to punish. To grieve, i.e., to cause grief to one. To vex.
To breathe hard, pant. Cf. hā, breath.
To loll; to pant, as a dog or hog after violent exercise, or with heat. See AHAHA.
The Chinese lace-necked, or ring-necked dove (Streptopelia chinensis), an early introduction to Hawaiʻi, said to be named for its call ʻeha kō, prolonged pain.
Street, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu. (TM)
Easily hurt, sensitive, having feelings easily hurt; to hurt for no reason.
Huluiia mai kuu lani kuu alii ehe.
A hard, dry cough; to cough. He kunu ʻehē, a racking cough.

Syllables repeated in chants at ends of verses, affording pleasure by repetition or sameness of sound harmonizing with repetition of sameness of drum beat; similar in function to English tra-la-la but different in mood, tending to be more serious. Cf. ēhā

chants.chtran: Here is David, ah, ah, the greatest of descendants, ah, ah.
chants.chtxt: Eia nō ʻo Kāwika, ēhē, ka heke aʻo nā pua, ēhē.

definitions.dtxt: To call; to call aloud; perhaps the imperative mood of hea, to call. See KAHEA.
Redup. of ʻehē.
Pertaining, or belonging to a cough; mai eheehe.
To cough; to cough slightly; to hack.
Song refrain. (Elbert and Mahoe 67)
To laugh merrily, giggle in glee; laughter. Ehehene kō ʻaka i ka leʻaleʻa, your laughter is merry because of joy.
Syllables repeated for musical effect at end of verses, similar to ēhē.
Var. of ehehene 2.
Wings. Cf. ʻēheu.
A wing. See EHEU.
Carved parallel or undulating lines on a tapa beater and on tapa. (AP)
See HEHENA.
Wing, as of bird, kite, or airplane; winged, soaring on wings; to fly, take wings (Kel. 140). Also ʻēkeu, pēkeu. Cf. ʻeheheu, ʻekekeu, pekekeu.

example_txt.txt: ka uhi ʻana mai o nā ʻeheu o ka pō
the covering of the wings of night [nightfall]

definitions.dtxt: To flap the wings; to lift up or stretch the wings; to undulate the arms in a hula imitating a bird in flight; to flap the arms, shrug the shoulders; to pull up shoulders proudly, hence to be proud.
Rim of a hat.
Pectoral fin, as of a shark.
Flipper, as of turtle.
See Kaʻēheu.

The wing of a fowl; na mea eheu, winged animals. Fig. Care; protection; eia no au iloko o na eheu o ko kaua makuahine; the wing, as of an eagle. Oukou, e na hoa (scholars of the Sem.) o na eheu o ke kakahiaka nui. Eheu takes both forms of the article ka and ke. See EHEHEU.
As wings; as if with. wings.
See pihi wili ʻēheu.
Street, Puʻunui, Honolulu. (TM)
Name recorded for adult stage of hāpuʻu fish.
To tread upon; to trample down; to kick. See HEHI and HAHI.
See EEHIA.

Inter. How many, how much, what price; also used with the meaning of no matter how many or much, so very much or many, just a few. ʻEhia ou pāpale? How many hats have you? ʻEhia o kou pāpale? How much [money did you pay] for your [own] hat? ʻEhia o kāu pāpale? How much [money] for your hat? Hola ʻehia? What time is it? ʻEhia ka luhi, he mea ʻole ia iāia, however tired, it doesn't matter to him. ʻEhia nō lā, pau kēlā hana nui, in just a few days that big project was finished. ʻEhia nō lū ʻana, pau ke kālā, just a few reckless spendings, the money was gone. ʻEhia ua mea aloha, ʻo wau! Woe is me! ʻEhia mea aloha i ke keiki, so much pity for the child. (Gram. 10.4)
How many?
How, what, as in asking about any kind of measurement. ʻEhia ka lōʻihi o kēlā pākaukau? How long is that table? Niʻihau. Also he aha.
To slander; to spread evil reports of one. See AHIAHI.
Seven; seven times.
Seven; also ahiku and hiku.
Reddish; sandy; applied to the hair.
Somewhat crooked, warped; not in sound mind. (Similar to but perhaps less strong than hipa and hepa.)
A crook.
Crooked.
To crook; to bend.

Stone pile (FS 107), especially as used to mark land boundaries; stone image; heap of stones under water (at times fishermen block one end with a net and drive the fish in from the other end), also umu, imu; pillar; red-hot stones put inside dressed animals in cooking (also pōhaku ʻeho). Lonokaʻeho (FS 209), Lono-the-stone [name of the god with eight stone foreheads, vanquished by Kamapuaʻa].
Swelling or ulcerous sore, as caused by friction under the arm, tumor. See kuaʻeho.
A stone idol; he akua o Lonokaeha.
A collection of stone gods.
A monument; a stone pillar set up as a memorial. Name of a pile of stones set up to attract the attention of fishermen.
A swelling or bunch internal, a kind of disease.
Name of a stone put inside of an animal in cooking.
Redup. of ʻeho, stone pile. (And.)
See EHO, 3.

definitions.der: [Lit. let the hero of Mānoa return, [it’s] evening]
definitions.dtxt: Name of a lua stroke. (E- is sometimes omitted.)
Red or sandy haired; ruddy in countenance; florid.
Hoo. To drive away; to scare away, as hogs or hens.
Same as ʻehu 1–4. See kēhu.
Same as ehuehu 2, thriving.
Caus/sim.
Water or water mixed with fragrant herbs used in sprinkling or gently rubbing a patient to revive him from fainting.
Var. name for ʻolapa 2, Cheirodendron trees.
Pollen. See entries below and hoʻēhu pua.

Spray, foam, mist. (Many older people say ehu for ʻehu 1–4, which is probably the older form; note lack of glottal stops in such forms as ehuehu, ʻehuehu, kaiehu, kēhu, kuehu, luehu, puehu.) See ex., moi 1.

example_txt.txt: foam of sea where moi fish are found
i ka ʻehu nō o ka lāʻau
in the spray of the war club [of a swift or terrible blow]
to send spray flying [to lose one’s temper]
Na ke kea ka ʻai, kū ka ʻehu o nā waʻa liʻiliʻi i ke keiki o Kuaihelani.
The white [pebble] wins, the child of Kuaihelani stirs the spray of small canoes [an old kōnane game chant].

definitions.dtxt: Dust; dusty.

example_txt.txt: a dusty path [this might also be interpreted as a faint path: see ʻehu 4]

definitions.dtxt: Pollen.

example_txt.txt: he ʻehu wāwae no ka lani
a trace of the high chief’s steps [rain, rainbow]

definitions.dtxt: Faint, difficult to see; wisp.

Reddish tinge in hair, of Polynesians and not of Caucasians; one with ʻehu hair; reddish-brown complexion said to be characteristic of some ʻehu people; ruddy. (This ʻehu is invariably pronounced with an initial glottal stop.) Cf. ʻeʻehu, ʻehuʻehu.

example_txt.txt: He ʻehu, he nani kona mau maka.
Ruddy and of a beautiful countenance.

definitions.dtxt: The spray of the surf.
The steam of boiling water. See MAHU and KEHU.
One of the servants of the king.
The dust of evening. Fig. Twilight, old age.
Lit. The red of the evening.
An epithet of old age.
Same as ʻahuʻawa (Cyperus javanicus).
A species of strong grass or rush from which cords are made; also written ahuawa.

Animation varying from fury and storm to power and majesty; violent, furious, powerful, animated; violence, fury, anger, majesty, animation. Waiho kāhela i ka laʻi ā ahiahi ehuehu mai, lying stretched out in the calm until at evening full of animation. Ā ka laʻi a ʻEhu lā, ehuehu ʻoe ē ka lani lā (song for Kalākaua), and the calm of ʻEhu, you, o chief, appeared with majesty. Kū ana ʻo Mauna Loa, kuahiwi ʻalo ehuehu (song), stands Mauna Loa, hill resisting storms.
Healthy, vigorous. Less used than ahuahu.
A kind of rock, used for adzes. (Malo 19)
A strong wind blowing severely; aka huhumanu ehuehu ka makani, inoino lepolepo ka moana; hakukai ka ale o ka moana i ka ehuehu o ka makani.
Darkness arising from dust, fog or vapor.
Angrily; furiously; in a raging manner, as the wind. See EHU. Ku ehuehu, huhu, inaina.
Animated, violent. Kiʻiʻoniʻoni ehuehu. Action movie.

Redup. of ʻehu 1–4 (this form was perhaps once ehuehu and is sometimes pronounced thus still). Kuʻu hoa i ka ʻehuehu a ka noe, my companion in the spray of mist. Ke ʻehuehu nei nā ʻale, the billows rise in waves [of flaring temper]. ʻEhuehu kai, noho ka moi, where the sea foams, the moi fish lives.
Redup. of ʻehu 5. ʻEhuʻehu nā lihilihi, reddened eyelash.
Hīnano-blossom pollen.
Sea spray, foam.
Name of a wind of Hālawa, Molokaʻi. (FOR. 5:103)
Streets, Waimānalo, and between Makapuʻu and Koko Head, Honolulu; beach park and surfing area, Lāie qd., Oʻahu.
The dust of morning. Fig. Dawn, youth, a shower that clears quickly.
Lit. The red of the morning; an epithet of youth. See EHUAHIAHI.
Visible airborne particles, as from a spray can. Comb. ehu+ kīkina. See kīkina.
Hair black at the roots that shades out to reddish at the tips, said to be characteristic of some ʻehu people.
Dust; dusty.
Dust. Also ehu.
Inertia. Comb. ehu+ ō.

Vigor. Ke mālama pono ʻia ke olakino, he ehuola ke kino no ka wā lōʻihi o ke ola ʻana. When you keep your health in good condition, your body will have vigor for a long time in your lifetime. Sh. ehuehu+ ola. Cf. hāʻehuola.
Chalk dust. Cf. ehu lepo.
Flower pollen.
Spray from water.
Var. of eia, especially before words beginning with a-. Ei au, ē Laka, here I am, O Laka.
Var. of ai 1, coition.
Rather frequent variation of the anaphoric ai (ai 3) in fast speech, but seldom if ever found so in printed form.
A particle of place; here; similar to eia; ei ae, here; close by; ei ae, ke hele mai nei, here, he is coming now.

Here, here is, here are, present (as response to roll call). Cf. ʻeiʻa, Gram. 4.6. Numerous idioms are listed below. Eia ʻoe, so you have come; well, here you are. (In a kindly voice eia ʻoe may be an affectionate welcome, but in an angry voice it indicates displeasure.) Eia ʻoe ke hōʻike ʻia aku nei, you are hereby notified.
This place. Ke eia me ke eia aku, the here and the hereafter [phrase introduced by missionaries; sometimes pronounced ka ʻeia).
Here; in this place; used in answer to the question auhea oe? Ans. Eia wau la, here am I.
definitions.notes: Note: Eia, here, is in contrast with aia, there.

definitions.dtxt: This. SYN. with keia.
Emphatic variation of eia: here! here it is!
Here close by, here approaching. ʻO Kamapuaʻa eia aʻe, ua hiki mai nei (FS 247), here comes Kamapuaʻa, he’s coming now.

Approaching, nearby, soon. Eia aku ʻo Nāmaka, here is Nāmaka coming. Kō mākou noho ʻana me Winona mā, eia aku nō a eia mai, our dwelling and that of Winona and her family, they are close. Eia aku nō a eia mai, paʻa kēia mea hana, in no time this work will be finished. He hele mai nō e ʻike, eia aku, eia mai, does come to visit every once in a while (every so often).
Here, here it is; you over there, you. Cf. e ia nei.
And, finally, behold. Eia hoʻi, ua hewa wau, lo, I have sinned.
And again, furthermore.
Wait a moment. Eia iho a hōʻea mai, wait a moment, [it] will be arriving.

So at last, then. Koʻu moe akula nō ia i ka ʻona a ka ʻawa, eia kā, ua hapai ʻia mai au a loko nei o kou hale, I was just sleeping then with the drunkenness of the kava, and then I was carried here to the inside of your house.
But withal, moreover, furthermore.
Same as eia ala.
But, furthermore, however.
Pronoun. You (sg.), you there (as between husband and wife, often affectionate and replacing such terms as darling; shortened vocative e + pronoun ia + zero-demon., Gram. 8.2).
But, furthermore, however.
Scorched.
Short for e ia nei.
Comp. pron. This one, present; this person; this thing.
Here, here it is. Ei neʻi ka wai, here’s the water.
Nine, nine times.
See waoʻeiwa.
See IWA. Nine; the number nine; also written aiwa.
Costiveness; filth.
Name of a sea breeze at Kona.
Dirty; unclean; foul.
Costive; filthy.
Curly, as a Negro’s hair.
An acre (of land); a measured quantity.

Dirty, foul, fecal (KAM. 64:109); filth, dirt, soil. See ex., kūlepe 1. Kaha ʻeka, foul spot [poor soil]. Ua hoʻoleilei nā wai ona i ka wai ʻeka, whose waters cast up mire. hōʻeka To soil, make dirty.

Name of a wind at Kona, Hawaiʻi. Ka makani kūkulu peʻa nui, he ʻEka, the ʻEka wind, that sets up big sails [good for fishing]. He ʻEka, ka makani hoʻolale waʻa o nā Kona, the ʻEka breeze calls forth the canoes of the Kona districts [good fishing].
A variety of bananas. (PH 173)
Acre.
Hand of bananas. Compare maiʻa for pejorative connotations. E painuʻu ʻoe me nā mahalo a pala hinu nā ʻēkā maiʻa (Kel. 138), you brag with praise of bright and ripe banana hands [worthless bragging].
The upper part of a bunch of bananas; he lila wale no mai ka eka luna a hiki i ka pola.
Agar, a gelatin-like product of certain seaweeds used as a thickening agent.
Redup. of ʻeka 1. Cf. hāʻekaʻeka. ʻEkaʻeka ka lole, the dress is dirty. ʻEkaʻeka nā hana, filthy deeds.
Hawaiian name for a Japanese variety of taro (adado) grown in Hawaiʻi. (HP 32)
See EKA. Dirty; covered with filth; very dirty.

The bird’s-nest fern (Asplenium nidus), widespread in the tropics, forming large rosettes and in some forests perching on branches of trees. The fronds are large, entire, sword-shaped. The black midrib is used like the ʻamaʻu fern for decorating pandanus hats. Also ʻākaha. This fern is sometimes called ʻēkaha kuahiwi, mountain ʻēkaha, to distinguish it from the mosses or from ʻēkaha kū moana.
A moss growing on rotted trees. Also limu ʻēkaha.
Same as ʻēkaha kū moana.
Name of a parasitical plant.
Name of a hard kind of bush which grows in the sea.
Also the name of a fern-like plant.
Street, Wilhelmina Rise, Honolulu. (TM)
Same as pākahakaha, a small fern.
Juvenile or small form of bird’s-nest fern. Cf. ʻēkaha.
Var. name for limu loloa and limu uaua loli.
Name of a species of seaweed.
Name of a plant, large, long leaf.
See ʻēkaha 1.
“Black coral” (Antipathes grandis), used medicinally.
Type of tapa.
Land section, wind, and cave near the head of Lepelepe Gulch, Kamalō qd., south Molokaʻi.
Gulch, Honouliuli, Oʻahu.
A native fern (Elaphoglossum alatum), with entire, narrow fronds 24 to 64 cm long and with, close, parallel veins. The spore-bearing fronds are similar but smaller. Cf. hoeamāui.
One, once. Cf. kahi, ʻakahi.
To separate easily, as a nut from its shell.

example_txt.txt: Ke pūlehu kūpono ʻoe i ka hua kukui, a i ke ʻano o kou kīkē ʻana i ka iwi, e ʻēkakaʻa wale mai nō ka ʻiʻo mai ka iwi mai.
If you broil the kukui nut well, as you break open the shell, the meat will separate easily from the shell.

definitions.dtxt: Var. of kēkake, donkey. See iākake.
The rolling of a stone down a pali; kaa ka pohaku, ula ka pali, he ahaia? he ekaku.
Church (the organization, not the building; usually pronounced ʻekalesia).
A church; a body of professing Christians. Gr. εκκλησία
He ekalesia, a church member.
Excellent; nice; applied to canoes; perhaps to other things.
Sack, pocket, bag, basket; bag-shaped fish net; scrotum. (Often preceded by ke; many types are listed below.)
To cringe, shrink from, draw away from, flinch, wince; to become smaller, shrink.
A pocket; a bag; a small sack. Eke kala, a money bag; a purse. SYN. with hipuu.
Name of a kind of net; properly, the bottom or bag part of the net.
Bag (preceded by ke). See entries below and pūʻolo.
Land section, Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi. Crater and peak (4,480 feet high), near the border between Lahaina and Wailuku qds., West Maui.
Var. of ʻākea, canoe hull; boom on the right side of a double canoe (Ii 129).
Plastic bag (preceded by ke). Cf. pūʻolo pepa.
Excellent; nice, etc. See EKE.
A piercing, stinging pain.
Displeasure, arising from an offense.
The feeling one has when that which he prizes is spoken against or injured.
Hurt; pained, as the striking at something hard.
To be in pain; to be pained, as the bowels on pressure.
To be pained, as the mind stung by an offense.
To brush off, as a fly or insect.
Small bag or sack, pocket, purse, scrotum.
Redup. of ʻeke 2; fussy, overexacting, cranky, particular.
A herringbone design, as in mat plaiting or in the pāpale ʻie.
Name of a wind of the island of Kaʻula. (FOR. 5:99)
Six-pack, as of drinks. Niʻihau. Cf. ʻope. See pahu, pūʻolo, ʻea ʻekeʻeke.
To be too short. Hoo. To shorten; to make short. See EKEKEI.
Billfold, wallet, small purse.
Holder for stone in the sling (maʻa), sometimes a kind of woven basket, but in smaller slings merely a kind of noose.

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻohe ʻekeʻekemu wale ʻo kēlā kanaka.
That person hardly answers at all.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻekemu.
Icecap.
Sleeping bag (preceded by ke). Also ʻeke moe.
Male supporter, jockstrap.
Gunny sack.
A wing; the wing of a bird. See EHEU and EKEU.

Short, as a dress or fishline (probably a redup. of ʻeke 2 + -ʻi, transitivizer: Gram. 6.6.4). Cf. mūʻekekeʻi. Lima ʻekekeʻi, short sleeve. Lole wāwae ʻekekeʻi, shorts. Ihu ʻekekeʻi, short wrinkled nose. hōʻekekeʻi To shorten; to pucker up, wrinkle, as the nose.
Short; too short; shorter than something else; applied to clothes, strings, etc.
Avenue, Puʻunui, Honolulu. (TM)
Eskimo.
Short for ʻekeʻekemu.
To open or move the lips, as in speaking, but without sound.
Coin purse (preceded by ke).
Wings. See ʻēheu 1. Nā hulu ʻekekeu, wing feathers.
A wing; the wing of a bird. See EHEU and EKEU.
A wing, etc. See EKEKE above.
Flour sack or sack of unbleached muslin (kūkaenalo), as formerly used for poi.
Avenue, Ala Wai section, Honolulu.
Plant listed (no data). (KL. line 78)
Mail pouch, mailbag.
Ethereum.
See pihaʻekelo, mynah bird.
Wind name. See ʻOluʻEkeloahoʻokaʻamoena.
Gunny sack, burlap.
Bladder (preceded by ke).
Akimbo.
Sleeping bag (preceded by ke). Also ʻeke hiamoe.
To answer briefly, speak but little; taciturn. ʻAʻole i hiki ke ʻekemu iki mai kona poʻe hoahānau, and his brethren could not answer. ʻEkemu ʻole, tacit.
To open, as the mouth.
To utter by the organs of speech.
To speak audibly or intelligibly.
To speak out; to reply to a question.
To answer in reply.
To come forth in any way.
To operate as a cathartic.
Agent. Uku ʻēkena commission, agent’s fee.
Also Edena Eden. Kīhāpai o ʻEkena, garden of Eden.
Handbag, hand basket, briefcase.
Mattress cover (preceded by ke).
To bend over, crouch, as to hide oneself or an object. Fig. Secretive, as in love affairs; to keep a secret. hōʻekepue Caus/sim. E hōʻekepue ana ʻoe i ke aha? Why are you so secretive?
A bird (no data). (KL. line 355)
Proud; haughty; applied to a person neatly dressed, who despises others. SYN. with HAAHEO.
Same as ʻēheu 1, 2. (Cf. Easter kekeʻu, shoulder.)
A wing of a bird. SYN. with eheu. See EKEKE and EKEKEU.
Basket, as on a bicycle (preceded by ke). Niʻihau. See ʻie.
A type of banana. (KAM. 76:38)
Hot-water bag.
Ace.
Ace, in volleyball. Also ʻai hāʻawi wale.
Bayonet. Cf. kī, to shoot, and ʻēlau waikī.
Place where ti plants grow.
See ELAUEKI. Pertaining to the top of a ki leaf.
Hawaiian tern (Anous sp.). Cf. noio.
A stench that draws flies; bad-smelling.
See EEI. A word used in a dirty mele.
Some of the words of a filthy song sung at a great day of the Princess.
Var. of weko, bad-smelling.
Dirt; filth, etc. Spoken of a person unwashed.
Dirty; filthy, as in former times, when it was kapu to bathe. See EKA.
Same as koa haole, false koa (Leucaena leucocephala), a plant.
Street, ʻĀina Haina, Honolulu. (TM)
Opposite. Sh. ʻē + ʻokoʻa. ʻĒkoʻa me. To be the opposite of. Ua ʻēkoʻa ka ʻeleʻele me ke keʻokeʻo. Black is the opposite of white.
Redup. of eko; extremely bad-smelling.
Dirt; filth, etc. Spoken of a person unwashed.
Dirty; filthy, as in former times, when it was kapu to bathe. See EKA.
Same as ʻakoko and koko, shrubs and trees.
Three; three times. Cf. kolu, ʻakolu.
Three; the number three; also akolu. See KOLU.
See laina ʻekolu mika, ʻaʻena ʻekolu mika.
Acorn. Also hua kumu ʻoka.
To root, as a pig. Fig. Prow of a canoe.
To root, as a pig; (motio foeti in utero;) to dig in the ground, as a plow. Laieik. 107.
Pas/imp. of ʻeku. Ē Kānepuaʻa, ʻekua i uka, ʻekua i kai (Kep. 59), O Pig-Kāne, root inland, root seaward.
Ecuador; Ecuadoran, Ecuadorean, Ecuadorian. Also ʻEkuakola.
Ecuador; Ecuadorian.
Ecuador; Ecuadoran, Ecuadorean, Ecuadorian. Also ʻEkuaadora.
Kini ʻEkuakolia. Equatorial Guinea.
Nuku ʻekue. King Kong finch (Chloridops regiskongi). See hona, ʻainohu Kauō, ʻainohu Nīhoa.
Redup. of ʻeku; to soften the earth, as for planting (Kep. 155).
A species of fish.
Digging place. Aia i ʻō ka ʻekulēkū a lākou, over there is their digging place.
Ale.
Together with; along with; likewise; thus; in like manner; as also; the same; alike; the same as; penei, elaa ka mea ole ana. See LAA.
Var. of ʻālaʻa, a tree.
Together with; along with; likewise; thus; in like manner; as also; the same; alike; the same as; penei, elaa ka mea ole ana. See LAA.
Ginger ale.
Similar to e lākou nei, but persons addressed are farther away.

Pronoun. You (pl.), you there (usually affectionate). (Shortened vocative e + pronoun lākou + zero demon.: Gram. 8.2) E lākou nei e peʻe hoʻopue nei, ʻaʻole ʻo ʻoukou lohe i ke kani o nā pū (Kel. 81)? O you who are hiding crouched over here, don't you hear the sound of the guns?
Insect, bug. (Wallis Futuna ngarara)
Same as lama 1, ebony.
El Salvador; Salvadoran, Salvadorian.
Tip, point, end, top, extremity, extreme, snapper (of whip). Also wēlau.
Wisp of breeze.
Bayonet, spear point, short spear.
The straight top of a tree, or of a sugar-cane.
The end of one’s finger; the point of a bayonet: the bearded part of a spear.
The commencement of a breeze of wind.
The pointed end of a substance. See WELAU and WELELAU.
Crown, as on a pineapple.
Tongue tip.
A bayonet. See ʻēlau waikī.
The top of the ki leaves.
Gun bayonet.
An intensive added to many words; very; much; greatly, etc.
Old. See ʻelehine, ʻelekule, ʻelemakule, lāʻele.
Prefix to names of directions used by priests; see below.
Black (less used than ʻeleʻele). Cf. also ʻeʻele, pāʻele.
Embryo. ʻEle Kū, embryo of Kū [said of a child born on the night or day of Kū].
Short for kaʻele 1.
Water hole, dark spring covered with growth. Cf. kele.
To be dark; black; to be dark colored; not clear.
Ke Kai ʻEle. Black Sea.

example_txt.txt: The taro is blighted by insects.

definitions.dtxt: Plant louse, aphid; germ, blight; blighted, as by ʻeleao. Fig. Troublemaker.
A native fungus (Gnomania iliau), parasitic on leaf sheaths of sugar cane.
Time of light, daylight, a term used in kuwā prayers, as to indicate that a new house is free from taboo and may be occupied. Cf. ʻeleua, kuwā 2.
Door at the leeward end of a house. Cf. ʻeleua.
Name of a worm that destroys food; he ilo, he mea e make ai ka ulu o ka ai.
Aphid, a kind of insect. Meli ʻeleao. Honeydew, i.e., a sweet juice secreted by aphids.
Land section, Waikāne qd., Oʻahu.
Period of darkness.
Perhaps same as ʻakiʻaki, a seaweed. Maui.
Black, dark, the black color of Hawaiian eyes. Also ʻeneʻene.
To blacken, darken, become dark.
Variety of tapa said to have originated at Kaumakani, Maui; it was dyed with candlenut, pāʻihi, and black mud.
Long, filamentous, green, edible seaweeds (Enteromorpha prolifera). Some kinds are among the most popular in Hawaiʻi, being eaten raw as condiments at feasts. Called pīpīlani on Maui.
A cooking banana (a form of Musa xparadisiaca), valued for shiny black skin of trunk, used for designs worked into pandanus mats and hats. Also hinupuaʻa.
Same as hinupuaʻa and naioea, varieties of taro.
Same as māikoiko, a variety of sugar cane.
A variety of sweet potato.
Darkness; ua like ka eleele me ka uliuli.
See ELE. Dark colored; black; blue; dark red; brown. See ULIULI; also LIPOLIPO.
Darkly; without much light; ke hele eleele nei au, I walk in darkness,

Village, ditch, small-boat harbor, landing, and elementary school, Kōloa district, Kauaʻi; Port Allen was called ʻEleʻele Landing until 1909 when it was renamed in honor of a Honolulu merchant, Samuel Cresson Allen (Stroup 35). Land section, Wailuku qd., West Maui.
Black crepe worn for mourning.
Redup. of ʻelekū; unattractively dark and ugly, coal-black.
Easily broken; similar to helelei; pohaku eleku.
Unhandsome; unsightly; applied to a homely, lean, or insignificant person; a good for nothing man.
To fly to pieces; to break easily. See ELEKU below.
A taro cultivar. (TC 3)
Coal-black.
Agitated, turbulent, tumultuous. ʻEleʻelepī ka waha, blabber-mouth.
Same as ʻelepī.
Dashing different ways, as waves affected by different winds.
Applied to men of different minds; as, eleelepi ka waha o kanaka.
Redup. of ʻeleu; vivacious, energetic, lively. hōʻeleʻeleu Caus/sim.; vivacious, energetic, full of life.
Stream, tributary of Waimea Stream, Oʻahu.
Var. of ʻekekeʻi, short.
Shortness; want of length; i ka elehei, i ka mumuku.
Too short for the purpose designed; one leg too short; as an oopa, wawae pokoli. See EKEKEI.
Anger; rage.
Angry; very angry; in a raging manner.
Mutilated, deprived of some essential part; mayhem. Cf. manuheʻu.
Angry. (AP)
Old woman. See luahine.
Coal-black, jet-black, all black. See chant, ʻelemoe.
Priests' name for west.
Slate or ash-colored pumice. Cf. lehu.
Silt. Sh. kelekele + hune.
Blue-black, shiny black. Fig. Select, choice. He mea ʻeleʻī kēia i koʻu manaʻo, this is choice, in my opinion.
Same as ʻelehonua.
Same as ʻelelani.
To bear a grudge. Ua ʻeleiki wale aku nō ia i nā hoahānau, he nursed a little grudge against the cousins.
To go after secretly and speedily; agile, spry; the name of a famous runner of Maui (FOR. 4:483–7).
To go after anything privately, as a mouse after poi.
Elk.
The elk; an animal. Lam.
Moose. (elk).
Planting medium. Sh. kelekele + kanu. Cf. lepo kanu meakanu.
Var. of ʻekekeʻi, short.
Coarse vesicular basalt.
Stone polisher or rubber made of this rock.
Entirely black, coal-black, said jokingly of dark people, including Negroes. See chant, ʻelemoe.
Priests' name for north.
A species of stone; he pohaku eleku, a brittle stone.
Easily broken; similar to helelei; pohaku eleku.
A good for nothing man; a coward; applied to a homely, lean or mean insignificant person. See ELEELEKU.
To fly to pieces. See ELEELEKU.
Old fellow, old chap. Cf. the common ʻelemakule. ʻEleu nō kahi ʻelekule, the old fellow is spry.
Small crabs (Xanthidae spp.).
Priests' name for east.
Var. of welelau, tip.
Messenger, delegate, ambassador, envoy, any diplomatic representative. Also ʻalele.
A messenger; one sent by authority. An ambassador; ka mea i hoounaia’ku; a representative to transact the business of another; one sent to carry news. Often SYN. with luna.
A cockroach; elelu liilii, the small cockroach; elelu papa, the flat, broad cockroach.
Elector, as in the United States Electoral College.
Letter, written message.
Same as alelo, tongue.
Art., ke. The tongue of man or beast; the organ of speech; the instrument of communicating good or evil. See ALELO and LELO.
Double-tongued, deceitful; trickster. Mai puni ʻoe, he elelo lua, don't believe, [he] is deceitful.
A tongue-tied person.
Tongue-tied.
Cockroaches (Blattidae).
A cockroach; elelu liilii, the small cockroach; elelu papa, the flat, broad cockroach.
Land section, Hālawa qd., Molokaʻi.
A cockroach that has shed its skin and is light (kea) in color; a term of ridicule for an unclean white person.
A large American cockroach (Periplaneta americana).
American cockroach (Periplaneta americana).
A cockroach, kitchen roach.
German cockroach (Blattella germanica).
Burrowing cockroach (Pycnoscelus indicus).
Australian cockroach (Periplaneta australasiae).
A cockroach. (Malo 41)
Road, Kuliʻouʻou, Honolulu.
Large, brown cockroaches, such as the American cockroach (Periplaneta americana), and the somewhat smaller Australasian cockroach (P. australasiae).
An expert taro farmer (no data). (FOR. 5:681)
Loam. Sh. kelekele.
Old man; to become an old man; old (of males). See saying, hopena. hōʻelemakule To behave like an old man; to pretend to be an old man.

An old man; an aged man; olelo ino aku la ia i kekahi mau elemakule, he spoke reproachfully to certain old men; ukiuki iho la ua mau elemakule la. Mostly applied to persons; sometimes to things—the works of creation.
definitions.notes: Note: The same idea applied to an old woman would be luahine.

definitions.dtxt: Old; aged; decaying, as men advanced in life, but often indefinite. When one has not seen a child for some time, and the child has grown considerably, he exclaims, ka, ua elemakule no, why, he has become an old man.
To be or become old; to have the evidence of decay; mostly applied to men; sometimes, Fig. To other things.
Plural of ʻelemakule.
Name of a four-footed animal in the sea.
Same as ʻalamihi and ʻelepī, a small black crab.
Hermit (MK 7) Probably French.
Var. of alamimo, quick.
Tapering.
To snatch without being seen, as by a thief. Maʻaneʻi iho nei nō kuʻu ʻekeʻeke, eia kā ua ʻelemio ʻia aku nei, my purse was right here, and then it is snatched away.
Tapering to a point.
To taper off to a point.
Dark, still, as sea or forest.

chants.chtran: Sea green, jet-black, sacred black, silent black, tumultuous black.
chants.chtxt: Kai ʻōmaʻo, ʻelekū, ʻele hiwa, ʻelemoe, ʻelewawā.

definitions.dtxt: Priests' name for south.
Buttocks.
Koʻe ʻelemuku. Nematode.
Street, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu. (TM)
Peat. Sh. kelekele + nanahu.

A species of flycatcher with subspecies on Hawaiʻi (Chasiempis sandwichensis sandwichensis), Kauaʻi (C. sandwichensis sclateri), and Oʻahu (C. sandwichensis gayi). The Kauaʻi subspecies is also called ʻāpekepeke. This bird was believed to be the goddess of canoe makers, hence the saying ua ʻelepaio ʻia ka waʻa, the canoe is [marked] by the ʻelepaio [an ʻelepaio bird pecking slowly on a tree trunk for insects signified that the trunk was insect-ridden and not suitable for a canoe (see kani 1); the saying may be applied to any failure]. The name also refers to one who craves fish but does not go fishing, as the cry of the bird was thought to suggest ʻono ka iʻa, ʻono ka iʻa, fish is delicious, fish is delicious.
A native variety of taro; the leaves are mottled with white. (HP 17).
A species of bird. Laieik. 29. Also,
A species of kalo with spotted leaves.
Street, Kāhala, Honolulu. A Hawaiian bird, Chasiempis sandwichensis.
Elephant.
The elephant.
The sea elephant; a seal; a walrus.
Sea elephant.

definitions.der: [Lit. elephant of the sea. Also palaʻo]
definitions.dtxt: Walrus.
Woolly mammoth.
Pīʻai ʻelepeli. Elderberry.
Same as ʻalamihi, eleʻelepī, and ʻelemihi, a small black crab. See kono ʻelepī.
Name of a four-footed animal found in the sea.
Humus. Sh. kelekele + popopo.
Active, alert, energetic, lively, nimble, quick, dexterous, agile, spry, sprightly, prompt. Also ʻuleu. hōʻeleu Caus/sim.; to animate, stir into action, animated.
Alert.
A dark-skinned people said to be descended from a chief of this name.
A hard stone, sometimes used as a fish god.
Darkness of rain or rain clouds.
A new house before it has beem made noa, or free from taboo. Cf. ʻeleao 3.
Door on the weather end of a house. Cf. ʻeleao 4.
Ancestor or aged male of a family.
A major illness (no data).
Grayish black.
A rare type of dark-gray or perfumed tapa. (FS 18–9).
A kind of kapa; kapa eleuli no Puna.
Hill (1,145 feet high), Kaunakakai qd., north Molokaʻi.
Dark and tumultuous, as sea or forest. See chant, ʻelemoe.
Elevator.
Same as alawiki, to hurry.
To dig, excavate. Also ʻali, pāʻeli.

To loosen or break up earth; to dig in the ground, as a pit, hole or ditch; e kohi; e eli oukou i ka lua a poopoo, dig the pit until it is deep; alaila, e kanu aku i ka laau, then plant the tree; ua eli lakou i ka auwaha a hohonu, they dug a ditch very deep.
Pas/imp. of ʻeli.

Redup. of ʻeli; to dig often. Fig. Firmly rooted, profound, deep, as a taboo, or its removal; reverence. ʻAmama, ʻeliʻeli kapu, ʻeliʻeli noa (Kep. 55), the taboo is over, profound has been the taboo, profound is the freeing. ʻEliʻeli kau mai, may a profound reverence alight [solemn supplication at the end of prayers]. Ā ʻeliʻeli kūlana i Hawaiʻi, and are firmly rooted in Hawaiʻi.
Elieli kapu, elieli noa.
To dig repeatedly.
Eritrea.
Five; five times. Cf. lima, ʻalima.
Five; the number five; also alima. See LIMA.
Nā Hui Nui ʻElima. The Big Five, i.e., the five corporations that controlled most of the sugar industry in Hawaiʻi.
To dig a trench so that rain water will run off. (FS 211)
Wet, soggy.
Caus/sim.
Wet; to soak, as kapa with rain; pulu kahi kapa i ka ua elo wale, a kapa was wet with rain, and all soft.
Redup. of ʻelo, very wet, drenched. See ex., Kūlanihākoʻi. hōʻelo.ʻelo Caus/sim. Ka ua hōʻeloʻelo, a drenching rain.
Very wet. See ELO. Ua pulu eloelo wale ko lakou aahu i ka waimaka, their robes were soaked soft with their tears.
To moisten; to make wet; o Kaelo keia malama, ke eloelo nei na huihui i ke kai, o Kaelo ia ke eloelo nei i ka ua.
To be wet; dirty; defiled.
To crumble to pieces.
Two; twice Cf. lua, ʻalua. ʻElua aʻu hele ʻana i laila, I went there twice.
Two; the number two. See ALUA and LUA.
Kūlana ʻelua. Runner-up, second place.
Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu. (TM)

definitions.der: [Lit. two equal sides. Huinakolu ʻelua ʻaoʻao like. Isosceles triangle]
definitions.dtxt: Isosceles.
Bicameral, as a legislature. ʻElua hale o ka ʻahaʻōlelo. The legislature is bicameral. Cf. aupuni ʻaoʻao ʻelua.
A Molokaʻi name for ʻūlei, a shrub.
Street, Kalihi Kai, Honolulu. (TM)
God with us; Emmanuel; a name of Jesus Christ.

Place, Woodlawn, upper Mānoa, Honolulu. (Named for Nathaniel B. Emerson [1839-1915], author of Unwritten Literature of Hawaiʻi and Pele and Hiiaka, who owned property there. He was the son of the Reverend John S. Emerson, a missionary who arrived in 1832; TM)
Emerald.
Empire.
Embassy.
Ambassador.
Emperor. Aupuni ʻemepela, empire.

example_txt.txt: Ka pae mauna kai ʻo ʻEmepela

definitions.dtxt: Emperor.
Name of a precious stone. An emerald.
To diminish, reduce, depreciate, grow smaller, subside, wane, decrease, recede, ebb; to lose vigor, droop, lower; low, reduced, thin; reduction, decrease, loss; mitigated. See ex., manoninia.
To reduce, diminish, lessen, draw back, curtail, discount.
Cheap.
To lower the price, cheapen; cheap.
Flat (in music).
In music, a flat; the character b.
To fall behind, as one of several persons walking together.
To decrease in number.
To retire back; ebb; subside, as the tide; to diminish in quantity.
To take an humble place after occupying one higher.
To think one’s self of little consequence.
To despond; to flag, as the mind or spirits; to fail, as the courage.
Hoo. To diminish. To shorten; to make few; to sink back with fear; ke hoemi nei lakou i kau hana.
Depleted, as a species. Also lāhulu emi.
See entries below and woela emi. Au emi. Recession, i.e., a period of reduced economic activity. ʻŌnaehana mīkā emi. Low-pressure system, in meteorology. Cf. ʻōnaehana mīkā piʻi.
Redup. of emi 1, 2; lowering, decreasing, diminishing, dwindling, lagging slowly; backward. hoʻēmiemi Caus/sim.; to retreat, lag, hesitate; to lower a price, to bargain.
See above. To fall behind, etc.; e emiemi iho la lakou i ka uala nui a hahai ae la i ke anamiu o ka uala.
Backwardly; lazily; falling behind; mai hele emiemi i hope, mai hopohopo, mai makau, e hele aku i mua, do not fall behind, tremble not, fear not, go ahead.
Greatest decrease, in math. Cf. piʻi kiʻekiʻe loa.
To return, go backward, withdraw, back up. hoʻēmi hope Caus/sim. Hoʻēmi hope i ka waʻa, to back water.
Less than, in math. Also ʻoi aku ke emi. Cf. nui aʻe.

definitions.der: [Lit. the running speed decreases. Cf. emi māmā holo, hoʻēmi i ka māmā holo. See also piʻi ka māmā holo, hoʻopiʻi i ka māmā holo]
definitions.dtxt: To decelerate; decelerated.
To go backward with stooped back, as from the presence of a chief.
To go backward.
Emir.
Emir. Also ʻemira. Aupuni ʻemila. Emirate. Also aupuni ʻemira. ʻEmira ʻAlapia Hui Pū ʻia. United Arab Emirates.

definitions.der: [Lit. decrease (of) progress. Cf. emi ka māmā holo, piʻi māmā holo]
definitions.dtxt: Deceleration.
To lose weight rapidly, as due to sickness.
A waiting, delay; to wait, delay (often used with a negative). ʻAʻohe i ʻemo, hiki ana ke kaʻa, in hardly any time at all, the car arrived.
A waiting; a delay.
To be long; to delay; to put off; not much used, except with the negative ole; as, emoole, which see below.
A native grass (Eragrostis variabilis) 30 to 90 cm high, with long narrow flowering panicles, growing on open slopes and ridges. Also kalamālō, kāwelu.
Without delay, immediately, suddenly, in no time at all, quickly. (FS 11,) (Gram. 11.1)
Quickness; dispatch; he hikiwawe. Suddenness.
Emo and ole. Quickly; soon; active; punctual; aole emo! O how quickly!
Suddenly.
An addition of water, as for mixing poi. Kauaʻi.
To shoo away.
To rid plants of weeds. hoʻēmu Caus/sim. (Malo 199)
To cast away; to throw away. Hoo. The same; e hookuke, e kipaku.
Red-hot, glowing. Fig. Raging, angry; anger. ʻEna aloha, intense affection or longing. Piʻi ka ʻena, to feel anger. hōʻena Caus/sim.
Shy; to shy. Mai ʻena i ke kanaka i laka aku, do not shy away from a person who is attracted [treat kindness with kindness].
Abundance, plenty. Cf. Onelauʻena.
Opening in the clouds said to be like the jaw of the aʻu swordfish and a sign of rain. (Malo text, chapter 6, section 6)
Red hot; raging, as fire; epithet of an oven when red hot; applied also to anger.
Angry; wild; untamed, as an animal; full of fury.
Jealous, as a bird of a snare, or fearful, as a villain of good men; threatening, as some kinds of clouds that threaten a storm.
To be in a rage, as in anger.
To burn, as fire; ua ena loa ka ula o ka mai, the sick person is red with heat; ke ena loa ae nei, wena.

Road, Waikīkī, Honolulu, named for the son of John 'Ena (a Chinese merchant) and High Chiefess Kaikilani; the son was privy councillor under Queen Liliʻuokalani and cofounder and president of the Inter-Island Steamship Company. (TM)
Redup. of ʻena 1, 2; glowing, red-hot, raging.

chants.chtran: Growth at Malama glowing with ʻilima [leis]
chants.chtxt: ʻEnaʻena ulu o Malama i ka ʻilima

example_txt.txt: Ua hōʻaʻā ʻia ke ahi e kuʻu inaina, a ʻe ʻenaʻena ʻia.
A fire is kindled by my anger and shall burn.

definitions.dtxt: To cause heat, heat; to rouse to anger.

All species of cudweeds (Gnaphalium), members of the daisy family, small herbs having small inconspicuous flowers and more or less white woolly stems and leaves. Formerly Hawaiians stored feather standards, kāhili, with native species (G. sandwicensium and G. hawaiiense) to repel insects. Called pūheu on Niʻihau.
A raging, furious heat.
To burn, as a raging fire; to be hot. Spoken of anger.
To be strongly offensive to the smell, as the stench of a dead carcass; enaena ka pilau o ka lio make; ua enaena Kilauea i ka pele.
Hoo. To heat, as an oven.
To break wind foully; such action. Probably Lit. flowing abundance. E hele ʻoe i ka ʻenakōī, go and break wind [a vulgar insult].
Stormy wind. Mahina ʻino kēia, ke kau nei ka ʻena makani. this is a stormy month that wind furies come.
Windmill.
Gale, stormy wind; whole trees in motion and inconvenienee felt in walking against the wind, in meteorology. See makani.
Enamel.
First attempts of an infant to move; to draw up knees and push elbows, to crawl, creep.
The commencement of a child’s creeping.
To creep, as a child first attempting; ua ene ke keiki, the child has begun to creep.
To creep along; to get near an object; ane aku la au e pehi i ka pohaku. Hoo. Hooene aku la na kahuna i ka laau halalo.
Var. of ʻeleʻele, black.
Redup. of ʻenemi. Ā ʻeneʻenemi hoʻi i kona noho hanohano (Nak. 30), opposing his position of honor.

Technology. Sh. ʻenekini + mea hana. Cf. ʻoiʻenehana. Mea ʻenehana. Technician. Luna ʻenehana. Production engineer, as for movie or video production. Hope luna ʻenehana. Assistant production engineer. Manakia ʻenehana. Production manager. Mea ʻenehana kani. Sound technician. Mea ʻenehana kiʻi. Graphics technician.
See ANEHE. To be ready to do a thing; prepared for it; enehe aku no ka lima e lalau, the hand was ready to catch hold; enehe aku la laua e holo aku.
For nei; here; this place; this neighborhood. Mahea ko enei kamalii? where are the children of this place? See ANEI, here.
Enceladus, a small moon of Saturn.
Incarnation. Ma ka miterio o Kou ʻEnekerea Hemolele, through the mystery of Thy Holy Incarnation.
Engine.
Pani ʻenekini. Hood, as of a car or truck.
Engineer. ʻEnekinia mīkini. Mechanical engineer.
Civil engineer.
Maneuvering engine, as for a spacecraft.
England, English person; English (of England). Also Pelekāne. Cf. Pelekānia.

Enemy; to feel enmity; to be an enemy. Note that the Hawaiian stress is on the second syllable, contrasting with stress on the first syllable. He wahine ʻenemi wale ʻia (Kep. 105), a woman who has enemies without cause. Kona poʻe ʻenemi (FOR. 5:385), his enemies. E lilo wau i ʻenemi no kou poʻe ʻenemi, I will be an enemy of your enemies. hōʻenemi To feel animosity or enmity; to make an enemy.
An enemy. He mea e ku e ai.
Redup. of ene. Enene akula ke kama iki, the little child makes creeping movements.
To dilate, as nostrils.
9th conj. of ene. To move itself, as a thing of life.
To bore a small hole in order to make a larger.
To file or rasp gently.
Hoo. To move itself, as a chicken in the shell. Lam.
Var. of nenue, a fish.
Var. of ʻenekini, engine.
Wild, untamed, fearful of people, shy. hōʻeno Easily frightened, shy, wary, coy; to cause to be wild.
To be wild; easily made afraid, as an animal partially tamed. See Hoo.
Redup. of ʻeno; very wild, etc. Cf. māʻenoʻeno. No ke aha ʻoia i ʻenoʻeno ai? Why was he so wildly excited?
See MAENOENO.
A species of worm, large and striped. See ANUHE. On Maui it is called peelua. He puko, he peelua.
definitions.notes: Note: The word is used for worm, generally in a moral sense, that is.

definitions.dtxt: A poor, helpless, despicable creature.
Worms. Applied to men.
A caterpillar.
A species of worm, large and striped: A hoomakaukau ke akua i wahi enuhe i ka wanaao. God prepared a worm when morning rose next day.
A worm, generally, in a moral sense, as a poor, helpless, despicable creature; Pehea la hoi ke kanaka, he enuhe. How much less a man, who is a worm.
A caterpillar: E hoouna i na lio e like me na enuhe huluhulu. Cause the horses to come up like rough caterpillars.
Caterpillar, as of hawk or sphinx moths (Sphingidae). Fig. A rapacious person. Also ʻanuhe, nuhe.
Carnivorous caterpillar (Eupithecia spp.).
Cutworm.
The introduced silkworm (Bombyx mori).

To lose, be defeated, beaten (if followed immediately by an animate subject and then by i-iā marking agent); to win, beat; winning, victory (in other environments). Mea eo, winner, victor. Inā kāua i kilu a i eo ʻoe iaʻu, alaila, ʻo kou kino ka uku, a i eo wau iā ʻoe, ʻo koʻu kino ka uku (FS 275), and if we play quoits, and I defeat you (lit., you are defeated by me), your body is the pay, and if you defeat me (lit., I am defeated by you), my body is the pay. Eo iaʻu ka hākōkō, I won the wrestling match. Nā ʻai eo (FS 283), the winning points. Ua eo au, I won.
To gain or win in a bet or wager; ua eo wau ia oe, I have gained you, i.e., the bet. Laieik. 97. E ko.
To give as an equivalent in a bargain; to have made an honest, bona fide bargain; no ka mea, eo ko kaua kuai ana me ka ae like.
Full of food, as a calabash (but not as full as pihaʻū). ʻUmeke ka ʻeo, a full calabash [a well-filled mind].
To agree. Ua ʻeo like lāua e hele, they agreed to go.
A calabash or other vessel brimful of food; he aloha i ka. ipu ka eo.
Yes, I am here (in answer to a call by name, or to a name chant in one’s honor).

example_txt.txt: Ua eō aku au i kuʻu makua.
Eō e Liliʻu i kou inoa.
Liliʻu, answer to your name song.

definitions.dtxt: Call; to call, answer.
The answer to a call.
See O. To answer to a call; to say here to one calling. No ka mea, ua eo kakou i ke Akua; penei ko kakou eo ana ia ia.
Var. of ʻaʻoe, no, not.
(adv. phrase) for eole e kala; long ago; not lately.
Same as ʻeho 1.
Stretching or reaching up to heaven, i.e., very high; eolani na kia o ka moku kiekie.
If not … would have. (Gram. 11.1) ʻEʻole au e ʻike aku nei iā ʻoe, inā ua make ʻoe (FS 101), if I hadn't seen you here, you would have been killed.

If not for … would not have. ʻEʻole koʻu holo, pakele au, if it were not for my running, I would not have escaped. ʻEʻole nō ia, if it weren't for him [in derision, meaning that he thinks nothing can be done without him].
Six; six times. Cf. ono.
Six. See AONO. Simple form, ono.
Six inches, i.e., a warm-up exercise for sports such as volleyball.
False; deceitful.
Name of a Hebrew measure; an ephah.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ka poʻe hoʻokiʻekiʻe ua ʻepa wahaheʻe mai lākou iaʻu.
The proud have forged a lie against me.

definitions.dtxt: Tricky, mischievous, dishonest; deceit; to deceive. Cf. ʻeʻepa, haku ʻepa.
To deceive, cheat.
Also epa. Ephah. See ex., hua pale.
One who is false to his trust.
An act of villainy; fraud, or artifice.
Falsehood; forgery, by getting property in the name of another; haku epa, one who speaks falsely to the hurt of another.
To be deceived; to be led into error.
To be deceitful.
To steal.
To backbite; e wahahee, e hoopunipuni, e alapahi.
Hoo. To act basely or treacherously; also, epaepa with hoo; auhea oukou e ka poe i kapa ae nei, he pono ka hooepaepa? Epa wahahee, to get up a lie or false report.

To fake out, in basketball. ʻEpa aku nei ʻo ia ma ka ʻākau, ka hema; kaha ihola ʻo ia ma waena o nā kūpale ʻelua. He faked to the right, the left; he made the drive right through the two defenders. See pākī ʻepa.
Part of a fish’s tail above and below the cleft. Cf. epaepa huila.
Redup. of ʻepa 1; frequentative and intensive. (GP 46)
See EPA.
Propeller blade.
Ephphatha; let it be opened.
Phase. ʻEpaki mahina. Phase of the moon (Western concept).
Apron.
Apron. Also pale kuene.
Stanza.
Science. (Greek epetema.) Also akeakamai. Kauhelu ʻepekema. Scientific notation. Kanaka noiʻi ʻepekema. Scientific researcher.
Episcopal; Episcopalian., Less common than Hoʻomana Pīhopa.
Epsom. Paʻakai ʻepesoma. Epsom salt.
Epistle.
Same as pīhopa, bishop.
Epiphany.
Ephod. Pūliki ʻia i ka ʻēpoka olonā, did wear a linen ephod.
An ephod; a part of the official dress of a Jewish high priest.
Ebony.
Spouse. Ka ʻepukāne o ka Virigine Hemolele, the spouse of the Holy Virgin.
Estonia.
Ethyl. ʻĀkeka ʻeto. Ethyl acetate.
To live; to crawl here and there, as worms in a putrid, dead body; eu ka ilo, apuupuu ka ili, eu ka nalo, eu ka naio, eu mai ka opae; e nee, e kolo paha.
To steal; not quite so strong as aihue.
To trouble by asking favors.
A rising up to do something; aole ana eu ae, he did not get up, i.e., did not exert himself.
definitions.notes: Note: Ka eu also means a peculiar sensation of the skin, a creeping numbness, like maeele or malanai; holo ka eu ma ka lae.

definitions.dtxt: In the abstract, mischief; theft; murder, and the like. Laieik. 104.
To rise up, as one who has been sitting.
To ascend from an humble to an exalted situation.
To excite or stir up one to do a thing. O aku la o Poki ia Kalaiwahi, eu, hoi kaua ma Oahu, Poki said to Kalaiwahi, come on (up,) let us two return to Oahu.

Hoo. To collect; to call out, as a company of soldiers on an emergency; to excite to tears; ia manawa, e hoeu ana ke aloha, e hoolale ana i na wai maka. The root, eu. is often doubled, giving intensity; as, hooeueu, to excite, stir up, rouse to action. See EHEU.
Spelling occasionally found for e, part. + u, plural prefix (see FOR. 5:507). No ke kāne a me ka wahine eu kaʻawale ai (Kep. 65), for the man and wife to be separated.

Mischievous, naughty, playful, as a child; rogue, rascal, scamp; mischief; hoot of an owl ʻaumakua warning of imminent danger (also same as hōʻeu (a)). Cf. hūʻeu. E ʻeu, get going; get a move on. Piha ʻeu, roguish scamp; full of fun or humor. Nui ka ʻeu o nā maka, eyes full of mischief.
Disobedient; mischievous; he wahapaa.
Lane, Iwilei, Honolulu. (TM)
Evangelist; evangelistic.
Evangelical; gospel. Haʻi ʻeuanelio, to preach the gospel.
The gospel; the life and labors of Jesus Christ as described by one of the Evangelists. Gr. ευαγγέλιο
The system of salvation as revealed in the New Testament. Ke kauoha hou, ka olelo maikai.
See ue, hula step. (This is sometimes said today as a chant ending, but is probably an innovation.)
Exciting, rousing, alert, lively, animated, aroused. ʻEuʻeu ka puapua o ka moa, animated tall feathers of the chicken [full of exuberance].
To encourage, stir, rouse, excite; vivacious, spirited. See chant, puʻuwai.

definitions.dtxt: A stirring up; an excitement.
13th conj. of eu. Hoo.

Also eukalitia Eucalyptus tree. Also nūhōlani, palepiwa.
Eurasia; Eurasian. Ka Una Honua ʻEulāeia. Eurasian Plate.
Europe; European.
Europa, a moon of Jupiter.
Europe. See entry below. ʻEulopa Hikina. Eastern Europe; Eastern European. ʻEulopa Komohana. Western Europe; Western European.
Top of tree or plant; trimmed hedge top; cutting; to top, cut or crop off, as top branches.
A kind of taro, qualified by the terms keʻokeʻo and kohu uauahi.
See ULU, to grow. A branch cut off to be planted again; a layer.
The top and branches of a tree which are cut off and left as good for nothing.
To cut or crop off a branch with some smaller branches; e oki aku i ka eulu me na lala liilii; “no ka lau ka eulu pipili ka lani, oki ka honua.” See ULU, to grow.
Top of a tree or plant.
Eunuch. Biblical.
Gr. A eunuch; one castrated. Gr. ευνούχος
To open; to take off, as a man takes off irons from one confined.
To burst open.
To dash upon, as a wave does a double canoe by rising between them.
Gr. The gospel; the history of Jesus Christ; the news of salvation. See EUANELIO.
Unstable, swaying, wandering; strayed. Cf. māewa.
Crooked, out of shape, imperfect, ill-fitting. Fig. Incorrect, unjust. Cf. paʻewa.

chants.mltran: ♫  The fitting of the scallops is imperfect.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Ua ʻewa ka pilina a ka nihoniho.

definitions.dtxt: One-sided, crooked; to cause not to fit.
Place name west of Honolulu, used as a direction term. See ex., kuhi 1, ʻū 1.

example_txt.txt: to go in the direction of ʻEwa

definitions.dtxt: Eve. Fig. Woman.
To crook; to twist; to bend out of shape.
To act improperly; to pervert.

To mock; to vex; to trouble. Hoo. Hooewa ae mahope kuai ka hale; e hoewa ae ma ke kua; e hoewa aku ma ke kala; hoewa nuku mua; he sneered at the house and afterwards bought it; it was crooked on the back side, it was crooked at the end, it was crooked in front. Anat. Generally in the reduplicated form.
Kulanui Kaiaulu o ʻEwa. Leeward Community College.

Plantation, plantation town, elementary school, and quadrangle west of Pearl Harbor, Oʻahu. (Kāne and Kanaloa threw a stone to determine district boundaries. The stone was lost but was found later at Piliokahe. See PE, ʻewaʻewa; Ii 98; Sterling and Summers 1:8; UL 84)

example_txt.txt: looked at with disfavor, eyed askance
Oʻahu with indifferent eyes [a term of reproach to Oʻahu people, said to have been said by Hiʻiaka when her Oʻahu relatives refused to help her mend a canoe for a journey to Kauaʻi]
ʻAʻole anei ʻewaʻewa ʻole ko ʻu mau ʻaoʻao? ʻAʻole anei ʻo kō ʻoukou mau ʻaoʻao ka i ʻewaʻewa?
Is not my way just? Are not your ways unjust?
Hoʻokō au ia kauoha me ka ʻewaʻewa ʻole.
I carried out this instruction without a flaw.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of ʻewa 1; irregular, biased, unequal, unjust.
Sooty tern (Sterna fuscata oahuensis); forehead and sides of head white, rest of head black; upper parts black, white beneath. Also ʻewaʻewa iki.
Injustice; a turning aside from right.
Unequal; unjust; irregular in structure, as an irregular bone. Anat. 4.
Grinning or expressing anger; applied to the mouth and eyes; as, he maka ewaewa, he waha ewaewa.
To mock; to vex; to render one uncomfortable.
To act unjustly or unrighteously; to pervert justice.
Hoo. To cause mockery; vexation, etc.See MAEWA and MAEWAEWA.
Unjustly, respecting persons in judgment. With partiality.
Puʻuwai pana ʻewaʻewa. Cardiac arrythmia.
A lohe oe i ka leo o ka ewaewaiki e hoonene ana. Laieik. 149. The imaginary voice of a female spirit who had died, and her unborn infant with her.
Name of a bird on Hawaii.
Same as ʻawaiāhiki, swelling in the groin.
Perhaps a var. of ʻauwai, ditch (noted in 1848 land claim, Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi).
A swelling under the armpit or groin; also awai; he auwakoi.
Eight; eight times. Cf. walu, ʻawalu.
Eight; the number eight; also awalu and walu.
Var. spelling of ʻeuanelika.
Var. spelling of ʻeuanelio.
Eve.

i ke ēwe ʻāina o ke kupuna

The navel string.

To grow again after being cut off, as a stalk of sugar-cane; ke ewe ka aa; alaila kukulu na 'lii a pau i ewe ai, he heiau hoouluulu ua ia.

Cry of ʻEweʻeweiki, a legendary woman who died in childbirth and who is said to return at night as a ghost and make this cry, which is followed by a nā cry like that of an infant, an omen that a birth is imminent.
Kinsmen, lineage; pertaining to the family, having a family. Hānau ke ēweewe, he ēweewe kona (KL. line 524), born were those of the lineage, of the lineage they.

Abdominal aorta. Cf. ewe o luna

The love, affection and remembrance one has for the place, of his birth and where he has spent his first years; o ke aloha mai ia oukou me ke ewewe o ka noho pu ana, malaila mai no ke aloha ana ia oukou.
Ka pae moku ʻo Fakalana. Falkland Islands, Falklands.
Flour; ground grain.
Bread; baked flour; hua falaoa, wheat; grain generally. It is often written palaoa.
Faroe. Ka pae ʻāina ʻo Falo. Faroe Islands.
To fry; to cook in fat. Also written as parai in older texts, but now spelled palai.
France; French. Also Palani. See Palani.
Burakina Faso. Burkina Faso.
Fair. Also hōʻikeʻike.
To fry; to cook in fat. See palai.

Ferrosoferric oxide.

Finland; Finn; Finnish. Also Finilana.

paragraphs: A pau ka Moikeha olelo ana, alaila, wae ae la oia i na kanaka e hele pu me Kila. O Kamahualele, laweia ae la oia i hoa hele no ke alii, ma kona ano keiki hookama. O Kapahi a me Moanaikaiaiwa, laweia ae la laua i mau hoewaa. O Kipunuiaiakamau ma, elua laua, laweia ae la laua he mau hookele, a he mau kipu no hoi. Ina e holo loa ana na waa i mua a aneane e kuia aku paha i uka, alaila e kahea auanei o Kamahualele: “E Kipunuiaiakamau ma, ia olua!” Alaila e kipu auanei laua, emi hou na waa i hope, a nolaila i kapaia ai ko laua inoa mamuli oia ano Kipunuiaiakamau. O Kaukaukamunolea ma, elua laua, ua laweia laua i mau kiu (pailata), o lakou na kanaka o Tahiti mai i hoouna pu ia me Kila. A ma keia holo ana o Kila, makemake ae la kekahi mau kanaka o Kauai e hele pu me ia, o Hooholoku ma, elua laua. A ma ka makemake hoi o Kamahualele, lawe ae la oia ia Kuaiwilu laua o Kuaineno, he eiwa paha ko lakou nui, o ke alii, umi lakou.

After imparting these words of advice, Moikeha picked out the men who were to accompany Kila on this voyage. Kamahualele was selected as his companion, he being Moikeha’s foster-son. Kapahi and Moanaikaiaiwa, were selected as the paddlers. Kipunuiaiakamau and his companion were selected as the navigators and sailing masters. In case the canoe was likely to run aground, Kamahualele would call out: “Kipunuiaiakamau, hold on!” Then he and his companion would back water and the canoe would go backwards. This is the reason why these two men were named Kipunuiaiakamau. Kaukaukamunolea and his companion, two of them, were selected as pilots. These were the men that were selected to accompany Kila on his voyage to Tahiti.

When he was about ready to sail, some of the Kauai people expressed their desire to accompany him on his voyage, Hooholoku and his companion. And upon the expressed wish of Kamahualele he was permitted to take Kuaiwilu and Kauineno, making about nine in this company together with the chief, making it ten all told.
definitions.title: History of Moikeha

paragraphs: A o na kanaka hoi i hoi malu ai i ka po, na hoewaa i holo pu mai me Kaialea, a me kekahi kanaka i hoouna hopeia mai e Hooipoikamalanai, hoi aku la lakou a hiki i Kauai; ninau mai la o Hooipoikamalanai: “Auhea hoi ko oukou nui?” I aku la lakou: “I mai oukou-e, he pono keia hoi ana mai nei, aole paha he pono. O Kaialea, aia ke paa la i loko o Pakaalana, a o ka poe hou ae nei hoi, ke paa pu la lakou, aole i ikeia ko lakou ola; ina no i make la, make mai la no. Na ke akua ko lakou ola, ke ola mai o nei mau la.”

A lohe ae la o Hooipoikamalanai laua o Hinauu i keia mea, kaumaha loa iho la o laua naau. I iho la laua: “He mea kupanaha, ke uhai mai nei ka ponalo ia kaua; alua paha auanei keiki a kaua e make. E pono no paha ia kaua ke hele luahine i ka moana a ike aku i kahi i waiho ai na iwi o ka kaua keiki, a make aku kaua ma kahi e make ai o ka kaua keiki. O ahaina kaua ke hele a make aku, aole o kaua ua loihi ko kaua mau la.” A no ia manao paa o Hooipoikamalanai e holo i Hawaii, lawe ae la laua i mau hoa holo no laua a nui, i mau moepuu e make pu aku ai me Kaialea. Ua manewanewaia ke poo o na kanaka a me Hooipoikamalanai ma.

In the meantime those men who had returned secretly to Kauai, Kaialea’s paddlers and the man who had charge of the canoe, arrived there and were questioned by Hooipoikamalanai: “Where are the rest of you?” They replied: “Don’t think that our return means well; no, there is nothing to rejoice over. Kaialea is in confinement in the temple of Pakaalana, as well as some of the people that came later. They are all in confinement. We cannot speak of their fate. If they have been put to death, then they are dead by this time. If they are still living, then they live through the mercy of God.”

When Hooipoikamalanai and Hinauu heard this they were greatly distressed, and said: “This is indeed strange; evil has somehow followed close upon us. Is it possible that we are to lose a second son? It is far better for us to cross the ocean in our old age, if by doing so it would be possible for us to look on the place where the bones of our son are laid, and then die there and be laid with him. Why should we not go, then, and die there with him, since we have enjoyed life so long?”

As Hooipoikamalanai was thus determined to go to Hawaii, she and her sister took several companions along on their journey to die with Kaialea. The heads of the people who were to accompany on this journey, as well as the heads of Hooipoikamalanai and her sister, were then shaved as a sign of their grief.
definitions.title: History of Moikeha

paragraphs: MAHOPE iho o ke kuahaua ana, ma kekahi la ae, he la kauila nui ia no ka heiau; ma ia po iho nae, hele mai la ke alii, a me na kahuna nui o ke alii, a me ka poe e pili ana i na kahuna nui no ke kai ana a ka aha i ka hale i kapaia he mua. I ke kai ana o ka aha ia manawa i mua, a hiki i ke kau, ma ka waenakonu o ka po, ua maikai ke kai ana o ka aha, aole i loaa ke kina.
