A treading upon; a trampling down; an overturning.
To tread upon; to trample down; to tread out, as grain. To stamp with the feet. To tread or trample upon. See EHI and HEHI.
Fricative, in linguistics. Onomatopoeia.
Redup. of hahi.
Freq. of the foregoing. To tread or trample upon frequently.
A kind of fish. (And.)
Name of a species of fish.
Antennariv Commersonil, a kind of fish.
Same as hehina.
Lacking in flesh, thin; to fail, of an invalid.
To become poor in flesh; to fail; to want strength; e wiwi iho ma ke kino.
Same as homa 1, 2.
Hereditary stalk; established people with inherited land.
Var. of hehu, seedling or plant (see ex., mānewanewa 2).
To clear, smooth; to purge, as the bowels. hoʻohahu To smooth, level off; to give a purge; cathartic purge.
Having taken so much drastic medicine that nothing is left in the bowels.
Same as halo 1. (AP)
The tail fin of a fish. See HUELO.
Redup. of hahu 2.
To be vain; proud.
To put or place in, as in a box; hai aku i ke alii o lakou iloko, then they put their chief inside.
Simulative prefix similar to haʻa-. See haikea, hailawe, hailepo, hailuku, haipule, haiʻula, haiwa, Gram. 6.3.3.
See akahai.
Offering, sacrifice; to offer, sacrifice. Cf. hai ʻai, haialo, haiau, haipule, heiau.

example_txt.txt: Hai nō ʻo ʻAikanaka iā ʻoe i luna o ka lele.
ʻAikanaka will sacrifice you on the altar
to offer human sacrifice; to kill for a human sacrifice

definitions.dtxt: Same as hahai, to follow.
To hire, employ.
Name of a particular form of gathering dead bodies slain in war.
A broken place; hence,
A joint of a limb; ka hai a mawe, the elbow joint.
Name of the god of the poe kuku kapa.
A sacrifice at the altar.
Kū i ka hai. Freelance.
To break or snap, as a stick; broken; fracture, joint, break. (Cf. haki, moku, nahā, wāhi.) hoʻohaʻi To cause a break.
To say, tell, mention, state, declare, confess. Cf. haʻina, haʻi pōkole. Ka haʻi ʻana, the telling, annunciation. Kona haʻi maoli ʻana i kona hewa, the true confession of his offense.
Edge, border (not used with the articles). Lepo ma haʻi o ke kalo (Kep. 155), dirt on the edge of the taro.
Coquettish, flirtatious; to flirt. Ke holo mai nei ʻo Halaki haʻi ʻē nā pua i ke kula, as Charlotte rides along, the youngsters of the plains had become coy. hoʻohaʻi Caus/sim.
To sway, bend. Kāna hele hoʻohaʻi lua ʻana ma ka ʻaluheʻe nohoʻi maʻō a maʻaneʻi, her swaying walk, sagging this way and that.
House. Kauaʻi.

Someone else, another person; another place, elsewhere (rare). (Not used with articles: Gram. 8.2) No haʻi, for someone else. Aia nō iā haʻi nā ʻāina o mākou, other men have our lands. Hoʻolei ke ʻaʻā apau ma haʻi ā maikaʻi, throw all the stones somewhere else so [the garden] will be fine.
Expression, in math. See entries below and haʻihelu, haʻilula.
Kelepona kāki iā haʻi. Third-party call; to make such a call.
Often SYN. with hae. See above. To break, as a bargain or covenant.
To break open; separate, as the lips that are about to speak.
To speak of; to mention.
To tell; declare; confess; relate. Ke hai ole, not to tell; to keep secret.
To break off; to stop doing a thing; as, aole hai ke hoihoi aku, he does not cease (begging) though sent away.

The ha of this word is sometimes doubled, then it has the form of hahai, to follow, but its signification is to break away or tear away; as, hahaiia ka lepa a ua poe kahuna la, the ensign of those priests was broken away.
Or adj. Gram. § 15, 14:3. Another; another person; no hai, for another; ia hai, to another. Hookahi no makamaka, o oe no, aole o hai, one only friend, thou art he, there is no other.
Pas/imp. of hai 2, to pursue.
Retainer or follower of a chief. Cf. haiā kāne, haiā wahine.
Same as haihaiā.
An assemblage; a number, especially of persons; it is used as a prefix to other words.
Deviation, in math. Comb. haia + hū. Cf. haiakonu. Haiahū kūmau. Standard deviation.
To do over again.
To tie up a bundle of food anew; to tie up, as fagots.
To cook over again.
Food offering; to offer vegetable food.
Male retainer of a chief.
Normal, in math and science. Sh. haia + waenakonu. Cf. haiahū. Ili haiakonu. Normal distribution.
To break, of billows. Fig. To surge, of emotion.
Name of a hard rock used for making adzes.
Same as haiā 1.
Stream, Waiheʻe, Oʻahu.
Street name.
To gather, crowd, flock; in great numbers, as ripening fruit. Cf. mū 3. Ua haiamū ʻia aʻe nā huina alanui, the street intersections are crowded.
Although this headword occurs in Andrews, no definition is given. See haiamū.
Pas/imp. of haiamū.

Caucus, i.e., a meeting of political party leaders to determine policy, choose candidates, etc. Hālāwai nā ʻaoʻao kālaiʻāina ma kahi kaʻawale ma ka haiamui no ka hoʻoholo ʻana ʻo wai ana lā nā luna o ia mau ʻaoʻao no kēia makahiki. Political parties meet separately in caucus to decide who will be their party leaders for the year. Comb. hai- + a + mui.
Street name.
To describe, tell the nature of.
Adjective.
definitions.notes: Note: Written as one word.

definitions.der: [haʻi, to declare, and ʻano, the meaning or quality]
definitions.dtxt: Grammatical term — an adjective.
Sermon, lecture, instructive discourse; to give advice.
A modern word; hai, to declare, and ao, to teach. A sermon; a public declaration of religious truth.
Day sacrifice; to sacrifice by daylight.
Hai, sacrifice, and ao, day. A sacrifice offered in the daytime in distinction from haipo, a night sacrifice.
Var. of heiau. Cf. hai, to sacrifice.

Female retainer of a chief. Papaiʻawa aʻela ʻo ʻAiwohikupua me kona mau kaukaualiʻi a me nā haiā wāhine ona e hoʻopau i kāna ʻōlelo hoʻohiki (Laie 475), ʻAiwohikupua and his lesser chiefs and the women of the household made ceremonial kava offerings to put an end to his oath.
Wicked woman, concubine.
See HAIA, a company, and WAHINE, woman. The united assemblage of a number of wives of one man exclusive of the favorite one among several.
A wife of secondary quality; not a favorite wife. A concubine. A kept mistress.
To multiply wives; as, nani kona haiawahine ana, wonderful his multiplying wives.
Hydrochloric. ʻAkika haidorokoloriku. Hydrochloric acid.
Street name.
A variety of ʻaʻawa lelo, a fish.
A species of fish.
Var. of kaiehu 1.
To preach the gospel; evangelist.
To show one’s self haughty, strutting, lascivious.
To feign one’s self out of his senses in order to escape death from one upon whom he has practiced sorcery.
Proud; vaunting; lascivious.
Street name.
Same as hahai, to follow.
To follow; to pursue; to chase. See HAHAI.
To run a race.

example_txt.txt: to break the bones of people [in fighting]
E haʻihaʻi iho ʻoe i kāna ʻauamo.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of haʻi 1; brittle; limbering exercises, as for the hula; massage in chiropractic; quavering; breaking, rising and falling of the voice; a style of singing with a breaking voice; to break, as a law.

example_txt.txt: ma ka leo kauō, hoʻānuʻunuʻu, ā hoʻohaʻihaʻi
with loud voice, vibrating, rising and falling

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim. to break, as waves.

example_txt.txt: my friend [with whom I] talk flirtatiously

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of haʻi 2; to speak quietly back and forth; to murmur (Kel. 70).
A state of brittleness; liability to break. Anat. 2.
See HAI, to break. A breach, or breaking of a law.
See HAIHAI, to break. Brittle; easily broken.
See HAI, to break. To break; to break in pieces; to break, as a yoke. To break off, as the branch of a tree. To crush, as a flower. Laieik. 142.
To break, as a law or command.
Hoo. To tease; to vex; to make one cross; to provoke.
To go through the process of separating the flesh from the bones of a dead person; to dissect; ua haihai o Kamehameha, alaila hoi mai o Liholiho mai Kawaihae mai.
See HAI, to speak. To consult or talk together, as two or more persons on business.
To court the favor of the gods, or rather perhaps to use various arts, as by getting herbs and medicines and offerings to prevent the gods from hearing another’s prayers.
Wicked person; wicked, unholy. Ka poʻe haihaiā, the unholy. E māhuahua ai ka haihaiā (2 Tim 2.16), to increase unto more ungodliness.

To prevent the gods from hearing a rival’s curses by acting insane (eating poison, going naked), thus diverting the god’s curses to himself and freeing the victim; with his superior mana he turns the curses away from himself and on to the rival sorcerer (KAM. 64:140–1); to prevent gods from hearing by offering herbs and medicine (And.).
Ungodliness.
See AIA. Ai repeated to give intensity and h inserted. Wicked; unreasonable; vile. Profane. Ungodly.
By holding the shoulders, to make a person’s bones crack audibly; a form of chiropractic; to do so; to break bones.
Osteopathy; to practice osteopathy.
To break the law. Also ʻaʻe kānāwai. Cf. pale kānāwai.
Verb (old name).
Hai, to declare, and hana, to do, i.e., to declare something done. In grammar, a verb; a modern word.

Numerical problem (as 2+3); equation (as 2+3=5). Comb. haʻi + helu. See haʻi, haʻilula. Haʻihelu hoʻoili. Chi-squared distribution, in math. Haʻihelu kemikala. Chemical equation. Haʻihelu kemikala kaulike. Balanced chemical equation. Haʻihelu lālani. Linear equation. Haʻihelu pāhoʻonui lua. Quadratic equation. See hahaina pāhoʻonui lua.
Equivalent expression, in math.
Operator, as a sign in a computer mathematical operation.

To paraphrase orally. E Mānai, e haʻi hou mai i ka moʻolelo i haʻi ʻia aʻe nei ma kekahi ʻano ʻokoʻa. Mānai, retell the story that was just told another way. Lit. retell in another way. See kākau hou ma kekahi ʻano.
Combinatorial coefficient, in math.
Noun.
Hai, to declare, and inoa, name. In grammar, the word delcaring the name; a noun or substantive.
Common noun.

definitions.der: [Lit. noun referring to someone or place]
definitions.dtxt: Proper noun.
Same as haikaika.
To gasp.

To make faces; a grimace of defiance and contempt; the corners of the mouth were drawn back tightly, the teeth separated, chin and lower teeth twisting from side to side; perhaps the figure-eight mouthed images were inspired by this violent fighting expression. Cf. ikaika, strong.
A less violent grimace than haikaika; to make faces, cause to make faces.
To mock by making wry faces; to make another word by the transposition of letters.
Grinning; expressing anger; he haikaika kona maka ame kona waha.
Permutatorial coefficient, in math.
Severe cramps, said to have often proved fatal.
Asthma. (FOR. 6:451)
Name of a fatal disease of which waiiki was the medicine.
Cramps, less severe than haikala.
Name of a disease equally fatal with haikala, in which the same medicine was used.
Street name.
Same as hōʻike, to show.
Same as hākea, pale, and hākea, a type of banana.
A type of tapa (no data).
Same as hōʻikeʻike.
Street name.

Narrow, pinched; limitation, restriction (in fast speech, haiki). Hāiki ka noʻonoʻo, hāiki ka ʻike, narrow minded. Aia nō i kahi hāiki, just there in a narrow place [said of an unborn child]. Ka hāiki o ka manawa, limitations of time. Kona wā i hāiki ai i ka pōloli, the time he was pinched with hunger. Haʻihaʻi pua o kuʻu manawa ē, eia wau lā ua hāiki (Laie 521), broken flowers of my heart, here I am in straits. hoʻohāiki To contract, shrink, restrict, curtail, narrow. Kekahi mau hoʻohāiki o ka lawaiʻa ʻana, certain restrictions on fishing.
Pahuhopu hāiki. Objective.
To be pinched for want; to be pinched with hunger. To be desolate; bereaved. Laieik. 142.
Ha and iki, small. See IKI.
Narrow, as a passage; pinched; scanty.
Suffering for want of food.
To grin; to make wry faces. See HAIKAIKA.
Redup. of hāiki.
Hyacinth.
Hydrogen. Haikokene lua ʻokikene lua. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
Street name.
The kāhili flower (Grevillea banksii), so named because first planted near the town of Haʻikū, Maui. Also kāhili, and ʻoka pua ʻulaʻula on Niʻihau.
Haughty, conceited.

Land division and point, Honomū qd., Hawaiʻi. Land section, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi. Quadrangle, land section, village, elementary school, park, reservoir, ditch, East Maui. Valley, Kāneʻohe qd., Oʻahu.
Same as ʻoka kilika, silk oak.
Street name.
Street name.
To tell of ancestors; a chant concerning ancestors, genealogy.
Land section, Haʻikū qd., East Maui.
Interj. A call to lift a canoe or to rally together in any work.
Same as hōlapu. Hailapu ke aloha, love flares.
To exchange, barter.
To exchange, as in barter; to give one piece of property for another.

To barter. Ma mua o ka hoʻopaʻa ʻana i ka ʻōnaehana kālā, ʻo ka hailawe ʻana ka hana maʻamau a ka poʻe o Hawaiʻi nei. Before establishing the cash system, the barter system was prevalent among those living here in Hawaiʻi. Ka hailawe ʻana. Barter system.
To tell clearly.
See LOEA. Ingenuity; skill in doing a thing.

example_txt.txt: He limu ka iʻa, hailepo ka lani.
If seaweed is the marine food, the chief pales [sometimes limu is a bad omen].

definitions.dtxt: Ash-gray pallor; to have this pallor.
An ancient pestilence. (Malo 246)
One of the sting rays, perhaps hīhīmanu.
A name of a disease or sickness in former times.
Name of a large living creature of the sea. See HEHIMANU and HAHALUA. It was forbidden to women to eat under penalty of death.
Hai, to break forth, and lepo, dirt.
To evacuate the bowels.
To be sick with the disease called hailepo.
Na maka o kekahi poe e hailepo ana, nolaila no ka hailepo ame ka olelo ihaiha.
A temple.
To cry out suddenly; to give an alarm.
To gasp; to pant for breath. See AILI.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: Ke kau mai nei ka haili aloha.
a cloud bank that recalls to mind

definitions.dtxt: Same as haliʻa.
To cause, produce a recollection or premonition; to challenge (Nak. 12).
Spirit, ghost; dim, indistinct.
To assume a ghostly form; dim.
Yellow band, as on the tail of ono, the fish.
Ha and ili, skin; surface.
A spirit; a ghost.

The impression of something fondly remembered; halialia wale mai no ke aloha, hoanoano wale mai no me he haili la e kau iho ana maluna, love brought the fond remembrance, it brought solemnity as if a spirit rested on him; lele ke aka o ka manao, leleiaka i ka lani; lele ae la ka haili o ka ia nui iluna.
Forest area near Hilo, Hawaiʻi; timber was brought from here to build a church of the same name, said to have been built by Kuakini (RC 390). Road, Pacific Heights, Honolulu.
Same as hāʻiliʻili. Ka pali hāʻili kauā (KL. line 2094), the cliff that curses the outcast.
Pas/imp. of haili 1.
To be frightened; to start suddenly from fear.
See HAILI and AKA, shadow. A ghost; a spirit. See HAILI.
Shadowy form of a ghost.
To revile, curse, blaspheme, speak evilly.
Cursing; profane language; he hoino.
Root probably hai, to speak, and ili (see ILI, hoo 7), to use profane language.
To revile the gods; to swear profanely; to curse.
To speak disrespectfully of one.
To reproach; to blackguard; to revile.
To boast.
Same as lili, jealous.
To have the feelings of sorrow and affection on the death of one very dear; ua make hailili e.
Street name.
Distance from the elbow to the end of the fingers.
Hai and lima, the break of the arm, i.e., the elbow. In measure, the distance of the elbow to the end of the fingers; half a yard or a cubit.
Street name.
Street name.
A shellfish resembling the wana, but with short spines, possibly Tripneustes or Echinometra.
Recollected dream, vision.

A small native fern (Schizaea robusta) found in high mountain wet areas believed to be the plant form of the sorcery goddess Pua; sometimes used as a psychological remedy to ward off the evil influence of Pua. Hawaiʻi. Also ʻoāliʻi makaliʻi.
Street name.
Var. of hailepo 3, a sting ray.
Answer to a problem, solution, key. ʻO ka haʻiloaʻa o ka hope o ka helo naʻau, key to the supplement of the mental arithmetic.
Hai and loaa, to obtain.
A key or answer to a question; a declaration of what one has found out.
The name of a little book called a key to an algebra.
A key or clue to intricate propositions.
The card game high-low-jack-and-the-game.
The card game high-low-jack-and-the-game.

Divination, casting lots, throwing dice; to test (also used interchangeably with hōʻailona). Hailona ʻo Moikeha i nā keiki āna, i akaaka kō lākou mea ikaika a koa (FOR. 4:161), Moikeha tested his children to discover their strength and valor.
A mark, sign, character representing a thing, as a letter representing a sound; an arithmetical sign, etc.
A lot in casting lots. Whatever is used in casting lots.
To cast or draw lots. To distribute by lot.
To certify by actions that something will be done.
To make a signal for some purpose.
In modern times, to play at dice. See HOAILONA.
Street name.
To tell the news, to spread a report.
Name of a star.
Hai and lono, the news. To tell the news; to spread a report; aohe a hailono iki. I. e., none at all (escaped) to tell the news.
ʻOihana haʻilono. Journalism.
To stone. Fig. To hurt the feelings. Ua kokoke lākou e hailuku mai iaʻu, they be almost ready to stone me.
A stoning to death; killing one by stoning him.

Hai and luku, to slaughter. To stone. To stone to death. To pelt with stones; okena ae la ke alii e hailuku i ua poe la, the king sent word to stone to death those persons; e hoonou, e hooulua, e ahuku.
Formula, in math and science. Comb. haʻi + lula. See haʻi, haʻihelu. Haʻilula kemikala. Chemical formula.
Same as malule, weak, limp.
Soft; effeminate; deliberate at work; weak in body or person; haimalulu i ka ua a ka naulu, weakened by the rain of the mist.
To state an opinion, testify.
To tell of the times.
The Times (name of a publication).
A thin, delicate white tapa.
Name of a species of white kapa rather thin.
Name of the school book used at Lahainaluna in teaching chronology.
Matrix, i.e., a rectangular array of numbers, symbols or functions which are often added or multiplied according to certain rules. Sh. haʻihelu + hoʻomaulia.
Fascination, interest. Ka haʻimoeipo o kona mau hoʻokaʻau, the fascination of his wit.
ʻŌlelo haʻi mua. Foreword, preface, as in a book. Also ʻōlelo mua. Cf. ʻōlelo hoʻākāka.
Street name.
Offering, sacrifice. Cf. hai, to sacrifice.
Land section, Hāmākua qd., Hawaiʻi.

A saying, declaration, statement, explanation; answer, as to a riddle; confession; solution; the two (or sometimes more) last verses of a song that usually begin with the word haʻina and that repeat the theme of the song, or the name of the person to whom the song is dedicated; to sing the haʻina of a song; to tell, confess. Cf. haʻi, to speak. Haʻina hou, to sing the haʻina again. Haʻina ʻia mai ana ka puana: see puana 1.
A breaking, as of a stick or law; a break.
Verb. Cf. haʻina kekeʻe, haʻina kōkua, haʻina ʻokoʻa, haʻina pili.
A speaking; a declaration; a conversation.
definitions.notes: Note: The ideas of speaking, declaring, etc., seem to be nearly connected in Hawaiian with breaking.

definitions.dtxt: A breaking, as of a stick or other thing; a breaking of a law.
Hai, to speak, and ana. A speaking; a declaration.
A verb formed from the contracted hai ana. See HAI. To tell; to relate; to declare; to speak.
To break, as a command; as a law. See HAI 1.
To break, as a stick; hence,
To reject; to destroy; to take no care of, as one sick.
Cruel, unmerciful, heartless; to abuse, treat cruelly. Mai hainā wale i ka holoholona, do not abuse the animal. Mea haina, cruel person, tyrant.
To abuse; to be stingy of food; to withhold food from those who deserve it.
Cruel; unmerciful; hard hearted.
Solution, answer to a problem. See ʻimi hāʻina. Hana a loaʻa ka hāʻina. To solve.
Handkerchief, napkin (rare).
A handkerchief; a napkin. Also spelled hainika.
Neckerchief.
Neckerchief.
Pocket handkerchief.
Pocket handkerchief.
Paper handkerchief, cleaning tissue.
Irregular verb.
Prayer removing the taboo on land after the taxes had been collected (an example of a pule hainaki is in Malo 146–7).
Quarter of a roasted pig reserved for priests at the laukini service (Malo 174); to offer such.
The name of a prayer on gathering in the property tax for the chief.
Helping or auxiliary verb.
Directional adverbs, as mai, iho, aku, aʻe.
Adverb.
To talk with animation.
Breaking wave.
Neuter or intransitive verb.
Transitive verb, active verb.
Transitive verb, active verb.
Verbal adjective.
Transitive active verb.
Transitive passive verb.
Intransitive verb.
Recitation of prayers.
To bend the head forward.
Var. of hainakā. Pāpale hainikā, turban, mitre.

Crater and hill, Kailua qd., North Kona, Hawaiʻi. A house platform formerly here was said to mark the home of the god Kū and his wife Hina. An ʻohiʻa tree called Kūʻohiʻalaka grew here; it was the tree form of KūA large furrow marks the position of the tree.
Street name.
Same as haʻiinoa.
See KINAUNAU, Kam.
Street name.
Same as nīnole, pliant.
To incite, encourage, stimulate.
To stimulate, as with a drug> Cf. kūlale.
To give drink.

example_txt.txt: the cliff that drinks of the sea [rising from the sea]
ā hoʻohāinu ihola i nā hipa

definitions.dtxt: See INU. Hoo. To give drink to one; to cause to drink.
definitions.notes: Note: The syllable ha is often inserted between the causative hoo and the verb. See HA.

definitions.dtxt: To preach salvation or eternal life; one who so preaches.
Hai, to declare, and ola, life; salvation.
One who preaches or declares there is salvation for men.
The declaration of such a fact.
Unbreakable, inflexible, stubborn.
Hai, to break, and ole, not. Bold; hard; impudent; unpacified; stubborn.
Speech, address, lecture, sermon; to orate, preach, make a speech; speaker. See ex., lūlā.
Hai, to declare, and olelo, word.
A preaching; a declaration of the word (of God.)
To make a speech or an address. Laieik. 115.

Speech. See hōʻike haʻi waha, mikolololehua. Haʻiʻōlelo hōʻike. Oral report, presented as a speech. Haʻiʻōlelo hoʻohuli manaʻo, Persuasive speech. Haʻiʻōlelo kūhahaʻi. Narrative speech. Haʻiʻōelo mikolololehua. Expressive speech, speech to entertain.
Eulogistic speech.
To tell omens, prognosticate, as by observing clouds; soothsayer. Nā mea haʻi ʻōuli ma ka malama, the monthly prognosticators.
A prognostication from observing the sky. Kindred with kilolani and kilokilo hoku.
Hai, to declare, and ouli, the sky. To prognosticate; to declare future events from observing the heavens.
Hyperion, a moon of Saturn.
Pest, as any plant or animal detrimental to humans or their interests. Sh. hailepo + pilikia.
Night religious service, sacrifice.
Name of a sacrifice offered in the night in distinction from haiao.
To speak or report briefly, Haʻi pōkole mai ma ka waha, orally summarize.
Street name.
Stem of a gourd leaf, as used in medicine.
Ha, the butt-end of a leaf, and ipu, a gourd. The stem of a gourd leaf used in medicine.
Stream, Keʻanae qd., East Maui.
Street name.

Religious, devout, pious, reverent; piety, a pious person; to worship; to hold prayers or service, as to consecrate a heiau; church service. Ka pule a kāu kauā nei e haipule ai i mua o kou alo, the prayer which thy servant prays before thee.
A devotee; one addicted to worship; a pious person; a saint.
Hai, to speak, and pule, to pray.
To speak or say a prayer to the gods.
To worship visibly.
To exhibit the character of a worshipper; to practice religious rites. Ina e makemake oe e haipule, if you wish to practice religious duties.
To consecrate a temple; to prescribe the forms of religion; nana (na ke alii) e haipule na heiau poo kanaka, oia hoi na luakini.
Piety; profession of religion; outward worship.
Pious; devout; religious; religiously disposed; a ike mai o Vanekouva he alii haipule o Kamehameha, etc., when Vancouver saw that Kamehameha was religiously disposed, etc.
High, height. Cf. ʻiuʻiu. (FS 201)
Same as hāʻula.
The red or yellow appearance of the dust raised by a whirlwind; the same to some extent in a waterspout.
Street name.
To plant far apart, as taro, coconut.
Word-of-mouth, verbal, oral; to tell verbally.
Oral. Cf. palapala. See moʻolelo haʻi waha. Hōʻike haʻi waha. Oral report. Kaʻaʻike haʻi waha. Oral communication. Moʻokalaleo haʻi waha. Oral literature.
Street name.
All native species of Cyrtandra, slender soft-wooded forest shrubs with white tubular flowers. Sometimes called kanawao keʻokeʻo. See ʻilihia.
Easily broken, brittle.
To tell without reason.
To flirt readily, with little reason.
Hai, of another. Another’s only.
Street name.

Shelf, perch, platform; roost, as for chickens; fish spear rack; rack for suspending water gourds and other household objects; rack attached to booms of double canoe to hold spears and other objects; ladder (see alahaka, haka ʻūlili).

example_txt.txt: a perch for birds to light upon [a promiscuous woman]

definitions.dtxt: Recipient; medium, oracle, one possessed.
Crested feather helmet, so called because the crest perches on the helmet.
Hole, breach, open space, vacancy; empty, vacant, full of holes or spaces. Cf. hakahaka, ʻolohaka.
To make openings holes, spaces; to create space; full of holes. Fig. Hungry.

example_txt.txt: to stare or examine carefully as one walks
Ua haka malū aku kona mau maka i ka mea ʻilihune.
His eyes are privily set against the poor.

definitions.dtxt: To stare, gaze.
To place wood in a ground oven, to lay an oven fire.
Heart, hearts, in a deck of cards.
A hole; a breach, as in a side of a house; hence,
A ladder, i.e., the cross sticks and spaces between.
An artificial hen-roost; hanaia i haka no ua moa la e kau ai.
A building not tightly inclosed, having many open places.
To stare at. Fig.
To look earnestly at a person or thing for evil.
To set one’s eyes upon a thing with desire. Often connected with pono as an intensive. SYN. with nana, and sometimes with maka.
A haka mai na moa ma ka lani.
Full of holes or crevices; many spaces.
Heart, i.e., the shape.
Drive, Kamehameha Housing area, Kalihi Kai, Honolulu. (TM)
Same as hakakā
To quarrel; to spar; to dispute; to contend. See HAKAKA.
Coastal flat, Hālawa qd., north Molokaʻi.
Grand Canyon. (Hualapai elder river.) Also ke awāwa kūhōhō nui ʻo Hakaʻama. Ka muliwai ʻo Hakaʻama. Colorado River. See Kololako.
Breach, as in mist.
Wind associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
Probably for haka ae. To be unsound; to be weak; frail; applied to a person out of health; applied to other things deficient in strength.
Same as hakakaʻe.
To delay, detain. (And.)
To delay; to detain.

Redup. of haka 4; vacant space, vacancy, room; blanks, as in a questionnaire; gap; thin, emaciated, especially of one with hollow chest or sunken features. He lawa ke kino, ʻaʻohe hakahaka, a strong body, not emaciated. Cf. pani hakahaka. Hakahaka nā maka, hollow-eyed. Niho hakahaka, teeth with gaps. Uea hakahaka, wire screen, window screen. Kohala ihu hakahaka, Kohala of the extended nostrils [climbing the Kohala mountains makes one breathe hard]. hoʻohakahaka Full of openings and spaces; to make open spaces, holes. ʻAʻole i hoʻohakahaka ʻia kou pepeiao, thine ear was not opened.
Same as haka 1. Cf. keʻahakahaka.
That which is full of holes or open spaces.
Want; deficiency; loss.
Empty room; place unoccupied; me or ma ka hakahaka, in the place of. He hakahaka ka naau for pololi, hunger. One in the place of another.
See HAKA. To be full of holes; unsound; cellular; to be hollow, as a bone. Anat. 4. To be empty.
Hoo. Fig. To be open; to be penetrable, as the ear to sound, i.e., to listen. E hoohakahaka i ka pepeiao i wahi e komo ai ka olelo.
See kaʻele, pani hakahaka, paʻi hakahaka.
Rainbow with much green color.
Ghostly voice, spirit voice.
Disk space, as on computer hard drive or floppy disk. Ua lawa kūpono ka hakahaka pā o kēia pā malule. There is just enough disk space on this floppy disk.
To walk with measured steps, as one weak. See AKAHELE.
Street name.
Container, bag, named for Haggai, who carried a bag with holes [spoken humorously].
Stem, stalk.
Var. of hākui 1, 2.
Probably similar to kaʻi 1; to move along, as rain. Hākaʻi lua nei i ke anu o Waiʻaleʻale (FOR. 5:705), venturing again into the cold of Waiʻaleʻale.
Nasal cavity.
Shelf for calabashes; frame from which calabashes were hung.
Street name.
Myrtle.
To fight, quarrel; fight, duel, strife. Hakakā ʻōlelo, dispute, argument. hoʻohakakā To provoke a fight.
A fighting; a quarrel; a contention; a controversy.
See HAKA. To quarrel; to contend; to fight. But often only in words. To debate.
Hoo. To set at variance; to cause strife; e hoohakaka ana i na bipi.
Cockfight. Also hākā moa.
Type of lua fighting in which the contestants did not use their hands, but fought with feet, legs, shoulders, head.
Frail, weak; thin, as tapa or a dress.
To rend; to tear; to separate into parts. See HAKA and KAE.
Bloated, swollen.
To be swelled. See KUHAKAKAI.
Duel with swords.
Pistol duel.
Perch, shelf.
Shelf. Haka kau puke. Bookshelf.
To straddle. Fig. A tall thin person.
A place to hang things upon.
A thin, spare, tall man.
Haka, a ladder, and kau, set up.
To be suspended, as on a haka.
To stand with a slender footing, as on the edge of a canoe looking for squid; ke hakakau la ke kanaka me he kioea la, the man stands like a kioea (a long-legged bird.)
Drying frame or rack.
Dish rack.
Same as lona, canoe rest.
Name of the stools on which double canoes were placed when out of water; also ake.
To stand intently watching, as a thief [said to be the name of a legendary rat thief]; to stand precariously, as at the edge of a cliff.
To stand intent upon any sound, like a thief.
To be ready to fly from the approach of any one; e kau me he iwa la i ka lai, e lele aheahe malie ana.
Ke hakakaupili me he iwa la ia ka lai,
Ke aka lele au a ka la hiki ole,
Ola ka maka ia Kohala pali uka.

definitions.der: [Lit. owl-resting perch (owls perched in a pandanus grove here)]
definitions.dtxt: Congregational church at Huelo, Haʻikū qd., East Maui.
Crowded, overlapping, entangled.
To stand on stilts, as a spider.
To stand on stilts; to stand, as a spider on long legs.
To stand huddled or crowded together.
Plump.
Structure, as of a molecule. Comb. haka + kino.
Frame, platform, as for drying fish.
A frame for drying fish for the chiefs which are kapu.
Street name.
Ends of a house, gable. Also kala.
The gable end of a house. See KALA. Aia mahea ia? aia ma ka hakala o ka hale.
Wooden trough, flume. (FOR. 6:546)
Debilitated, weak, as from age or sickness.
Syllabary. Comb. hā + kā + lā + mā. See huahakalama.
Street name.

Village, land division, bay, gulch, and stream, Honomū qd.—the 1946 tsunami waves reached heights of 37 feet here and destroyed a sugar mill (Macdonald and Abbott 257–258); elementary school in the town of Hilo, Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
Street name.
Name of a star associated with Hanakauluna, considered a sign of pestilence or calamity; also the name of a legendary place.
Altar platform, especially where human sacrifices were laid.
High. Mai piʻi aʻe ʻoe i ka lālā kau hakalī o ʻike ʻia kou wahi hilahila, don't climb to the topmost branch lest your private parts be seen [do not act superior].

Slow, dilatory [used idiomatically]. Hākālia nō ā, as soon as. Hākālia nō ā ao, ʻo kō mākou hele nō ia, as soon as it became day, we went. ʻAʻole hākālia pau kēia, not long, this will be finished. E hākālia anei kekahi mea iā Iēhowa? Does Jehovah have to wait for anything? hoʻohākālia To delay, slow down; slow, dilatory; hesitation. Mai hoʻohākālia aku ʻoe, don't delay.
A difficulty in doing a thing; meeting with obstacles; a detention; he hewa nui, o keia hakalia o lakou, the great error was this slowness of them. See explanations in the next.
Hakaia, the l inserted. Gram. § 48. To be hard; difficult to accomplish.
To be dilatory; slow in doing a thing; ua hakalia ka amo ana o ka maka, slow was the winking of the eyes.
Hoo. To defer or put off doing.
Long in doing a thing; dilatory; slow; taking too much time; also,
Careless; unthinking; holo makou me ka hoopiipii mau ana ame ka hakalia.
Street name.
Showy, pompous, vain, as of one’s attire.
No definition given.
Clothes rack, as on wheels in a clothing store. Also hao kau lole.
Var. of hakanū.
Same as hākalalū.
Extreme old age when one is no longer able to walk; hele o mea akauka hakalunu.
Street name.
Name of a constellation.
Same as hakakāamoa 1,2. hoʻohākā moa Caus/sim.

definitions.der: [haka, to quarrel, and moa, a fowl]
definitions.dtxt: Cock-fighting; the name of a game practiced in former times; o ka hakamoa kekahi mea makemake nui e na 'lii.
Pharynx, in anatomy.

example_txt.txt: laryngopharynx, i.e., the lower part of the pharynx adjacent to the larynx
nasopharynx, i.e., the portion of the pharynx behind the nasal cavity and above the soft palate
oropharynx, i.e., the lower part of the pharynx contiguous to the mouth

definitions.dtxt: Cochlea, i.e., inner ear cavity.
Same as hoʻokanea.
Same as hoʻokanea.
To be worthless, useless; uselessness. See nele. He hakanele kēlā, that’s worthless.
Thin; spare in flesh; ua hakanele oe i ko oukou hiki ana mai; applied to man and beast.
Same as hākaneno.
To be swelled; puffed up; e maimai, e ukeke.
Weak, sick.
Street name.
Silent, sullen; struck dumb, as in amazement. hoʻohakanū To cause silence; silent.
Naked, nude.
To go naked; to walk about destitute of clothing.
Decaying, as taro in the field or a few days after cooking. Cf. kaokao.
Hole for inserting mast in a canoe.
Net that enclosed a calabash. (Malo 91)
Haka, to quarrel, and olelo, word. To lay blame upon one; to accuse falsely.
Name of one whom a chief employs to report the errors of the people; the epithet of parents in governing their children, having the right to sustain and govern them.
Medium or one possessed, who speaks; one who reports to a chief, especially the misdeeds of others.
To quarrel, argue violently.
Code style, as in computer program.
Darkness. (FOR. 6:371)
To observe carefully, stare.
See HAKA. To look earnestly at; to look steadfastly; to direct the eyes upon.

definitions.notes: Note: These two words are often written separately as well as together, and then pono is used as an intensive adverb.
definitions.dtxt: To stare or gaze at; to be amazed; to see something to be wondered at.
See HAKA. To fight; to contend.
To fight together, as two cocks; to practice cock-fighting.
Street name.
To protrude, as bones or cliff ridges. See ex., kōlīlā.
Same as haka kau, perch, shelf.
To look slim and tall, as a person whose flesh is wasted from his limbs.
Slim; tall; poor in flesh.
Poetic name for the rainbow.
Ladder, trestle.

definitions.der: [Lit. mouth open space. Cf. puka niho]
definitions.dtxt: Oral cavity.
See Hoo. To resist; stand against. See KE and HOOKEE. To displace; put aside; put away.

Packed full, protruding, bulging, cramfull, swollen. Hakē ka paʻi ʻai o ka Malulani, the Malulani [ship] is overloaded with bundles of hard poi [uncomplimentary reference to a pregnant woman]. hoʻo.-hakē To pack full, cram, push; to break, as a boil.
Street name.
Same as haʻakea 1.
A variety of banana.
See KEA, white. Pale, as one sick.
Street name.
Same as hākea 1; faded, wan, fair, blond.
Same as haʻakei. Hākei nā moku kaiāmū (FOR. 6:398), the hushed islands are in glory.
Slimy, snotty; mucus, slime. Cf. kelo.
Hanging down in swelling or pendulous bunches, as the mucus from the nose of a child; applied to swellings of internal parts, as the uterus; hakelo or hakelokelo ka hupe.
Hanging down in swelling or pendulous bunches, as the mucus from the nose of a child; applied to swellings of internal parts, as the uterus; hakelo or hakelokelo ka hupe.
Whitish.
Same as haʻi 1. Haki wale, easily broken, fragile. He koʻokoʻo haki wale, an easily broken staff [a weak leader].

See HAI, k inserted. To break, as a piece of wood; to break, as with the hands. To break, as a bone. PASS. Hakia for hakiia. to be broken. Fig. Applied to the punishment of wicked men. To break, as the teeth. that is, one’s power crushed.
definitions.notes: Note: The word applies mostly only to such things as are somewhat brittle.

definitions.dtxt: That which is easily broken; haki wale, brittle.
Crease, as on a pair of pants. Niʻihau. Also ʻopi.
Same as hoʻokī 1. ʻO kō lāua ʻiʻo, hākī koko nei ʻo Kalua (chant), their own flesh was Kalua, [their] blood issue.
Pas/imp. of haki.
Pass. of haki. See above.
Pin, nail, spike; to fasten, nail. Cf. kākia.
A pin; a nail. SYN. with makia and kakia.
Bloody stools. (KAM. 64:111)
Same as haʻihaʻi 1. Malaila ia i hakihaki ai i nā pua, there he broke the arrows.
13th conj. of haki. To break in pieces, as wood; to break frequently.
Same as hakina.
To tie, bind. Cf. -kiʻi.
To tie fast; to make fast by tying. See NAKII.
Redup. of hākiʻi. See nīkiʻi.
To tie fast; to make fast by tying. See NAKII.
Same as kikili, thunder.
To observe closely, spy on, reconnoiter, snoop, eavesdrop. Cf. kilo. Hākilo, ihola lākou iāia, they watched him.
To observe narrowly; to watch closely and attentively.
To look at what one is about to do. To watch one’s actions or conduct, generally to find occasion, or with some evil design.
To eaves-drop or listen secretly, expecting something bad; ua hakilo aku au ia mea ma e ohumu ana.
To act the spy. See the root KILO. To watch, as a thief does if any one sees him.
Street name.
Street name.
Broken piece, remnant, portion, balance, section, scrap, fragment; fraction, as in arithmetic. See ex., palena.
Contraction for haki ana, a breaking. A piece broken off; a piece of a thing; a remnant; hakina ai, a piece of food. A part; a portion, etc.
Fraction, in math.
Gulch, ʻĪlio Pt. qd., south Molokaʻi. See Puʻuhakina.
Food fragment, scrap, morsel.
Geologic fault, as San Andreas Fault.
Improper fraction.
Proper fraction.
Common fraction.
Portion of a word, syllable.
Used for syllable in the music Gamut.
Reciprocal number.
Decimal fraction.
Mixed number.
Var. of haʻinau.
Bay and land area, north Kahoʻolawe, where the fish demigod ʻAiʻai set up an altar (kūʻula) on a bluff looking out to sea (HM 22).
To limp, hobble, amble.

Valley, land division, and stream, Waikāne qd., Oʻahu. Kahaʻi, a famous navigator, lived here and traveled to Sāmoa to bring back seeds and breadfruit; he was so respected that Kamehameha I in 1795 lowered the sail of his canoe in honor of his memory. (Sterling and Summers 5:38a.)
To spy, examine, look.
See KIU. To spy out; to look at; to examine; alaila, hakiu like iho la lakou i ka mea a lakou i iini ai.
Fragile, easily broken. Cf. nahā wale, pāloli.
The leaf of the sugar-cane; wakawaka o Mano e moku ae ka hako.
Street name.
Dignified, noble, honorable.
To be dignified in one’s bearing; to appear honorable; to be noble in form; ua hako kona helehelena, ma kona mau maka.
To carve out a pathway, as a passage through coral or as a water course.
Same as ʻākoʻakoʻa, coral.
Redup. of hako.
See HAKO. Portly; dignified in appearance; noble in person.
Street name.
Same as hakukoʻi; agitated; paraphimosis. See Kūlanihākoʻi. Hākoʻi ka wai a ka neki, water agitated among the rushes [one in love]. hoʻohākoʻi Caus/sim.
An action productive in children of paraphimosis.
To dash, as water against water.
To be agitated, as water carried in a dish unsteadily; hakoi ka wai.
To be unsettled, as one’s thoughts when in trouble.
Heavy; weighty, as luggage, etc.; kaumaha, koikoi; heavy; burdensome.
Heavy, as the heart.
Street name.
Redup. of hākoʻi. ʻO ka ʻale hākoʻikoʻi, agitated billows.
To rise or swell up, as water.
Ma ka haale o ka manao e pii iluna me he wai la e hakoikoi iloko o ka manawa, through the overflow of thoughts rising up like water, the affections flow within.
Wrestling; to wrestle. Mea hākōkō, wrestler, fighter. (FOR. 6:369)
A wrestling; contention of strength between two persons to cause each other to fall; eia kekahi lealea, o ka hakookoo, here is one pastime, wrestling.
definitions.notes: Note: Hawaiians write the word in both the forms hakookoo and hakoko. The last syllables are equally long and accented.

definitions.dtxt: To wrestle; to contend with another to cause him to fall.
Ancient type of sitting wrestling, the object being to topple over the opponent; to wrestle thus.
Same as hākonakona.
Scorched or dried black, as breadfruit which hangs on the trees long after the season is over, when one side becomes parched and black with the sun; he hakona ka hua ulu.
It applies also to the side lying long on the dirt; the other side is kua paa.
Parched, as a blemished bread-fruit; unhealthy condition of a banana when the skin adheres to the pulp, supposedly after the plant has been touched by the ʻakōlea fern.
Same as kākonakona 1. Niʻihau.
Rough; dark; clouded; uneven.
Same as hoʻokoʻokoʻo.
A wrestling; contention of strength between two persons to cause each other to fall; eia kekahi lealea, o ka hakookoo, here is one pastime, wrestling.
definitions.notes: Note: Hawaiians write the word in both the forms hakookoo and hakoko. The last syllables are equally long and accented.

definitions.dtxt: To wrestle; to contend with another to cause him to fall. Fig.
Street name.
Lord, master, overseer, employer, owner, possessor, proprietor. A chief was often addressed as ē kuʻu haku, my master. See Hakuohawaiʻi.

The pandanus or screw pine (Pandanus odoratissimus), native from southern Asia east to Hawaiʻi, growing at low altitudes, both cultivated and wild. It is a tree with many branches, which are tipped with spiral tufts of long narrow, spine-edged leaves; its base is supported by a clump of slanting aerial roots. The pineapple-shaped fruits are borne on female trees whereas the spikes of fragrant, pollenbearing flowers are borne separately on male trees. Many uses: leaves (lau hala) for mats, baskets, hats; the yellow to red fruit sections for leis, brushes; male flowers to scent tapa, their leaflike bracts to plait mats (see hīnano). The aerial root (uleule) tip is a good source of vitamin B and cooked in ti leaves was used medicinally, although unpleasant tasting. The tree is called pū hala. The hala lei is much liked today but formerly was not worn on important ventures because hala also means failure. For the same reason some persons will not compose songs about hala. Types of hala are listed below. Pineapples are hala plus qualifier. See ex., pō 2.

Hills, Hilo, Hawaiʻi. Hina, Māui’s mother, gave this area to her daughter, Hinakeahi, goddess of fire. A famine occurred and Hinakeahi ordered her people to dig an earth oven. She placed herself in the oven and lit the fire. She then sank through the oven stones down to the underworld and became a gushing stream. On the second day she emerged as a pool near the sea, and on the third day a spring burst forth. She washed herself and returned to the oven, ordering the people to open it. They found abundant food (Westervelt, n.d.: 157–161). See Pōhakunui, Puʻuhonu.

To carry, fetch, bear. Cf. hali ukana.

definitions.dtxt: To cause to carry.
Contraction of halii. That which is spread down, as a mat, a carpet, a cloth spread out.
To bear; to carry; to convey; hali mai, to bring; hali aku, to take or carry away.
To bear, as a burden.
To carry, as a child.
To carry, as an armor bearer.
To bear the sin of others.
A symptom; a premonition; the first beginning of a feeling; ke kau e mai nei ia'u ka halia o ka makau, ame ka weliweli. Laieik. 180.
Street name.
Pas/imp. of hali.
Same as hākālia.
Pass. of hali for haliia. To be carried; borne, etc.

Sudden remembrance, memory, especially of a loved one; fond recollection; premonition; to recall, recollect fondly. Haliʻa aloha, cherished or loving memory; to remember fondly. hoʻohaliʻa To evoke reminiscence or recollection; remembrance; to remind.
To have a fond recollection of a person or thing. Laieik. 116. See next.
Redup. of hāliʻa. See ex. manawa 2. hoʻohāliʻaliʻa Caus/sim.
The rising of a fond recollection of a person or friend in the mind; ke kau mai nei ka halialia aloha ia lakou; malaila no ka halialia aloha ana, there was the beloved recollection. Laieik. 34.
Beloved; cherished; remembered with affection; ka manao halialia a'u i ka manao i ke ao, I have a fond remembrance of the desire for instruction.
To have a recollection of a friend; e halialia ana no nae ke aloha ia'u ma na wahi a kaua i ao ai.
To become intent, as the mind, or fixed, as thoughts which keep one wakeful.
To spring up, as thoughts or affections in the mind; halialia ke aloha. See LIA.
Street name.

Redup. of hali; to transport, transmit. Moku halihali, ferry. Moku halihali koa, troop transport. Moku halihali mokulele, aircraft carrier. ʻO wau wale nō ke halihali i kēia poʻe kānaka apau, I alone bear all these people.
The frequentative of hali. To convey frequently; to bring; to carry.
To carry from place to place.

A covering, spread; to spread, as a sheet. E hāliʻi ana ka hau mai ka piko o Mauna Kea (Laie 479), the snow from the summit of Mauna Kea was spread. Hāliʻi ihola i ka palaoa, to spread wheat. Kā hāliʻi, asphalt surface.
The out or under side of leaves of certain plants; the under or dried leaves of plants; laele.
To spread out and lay down, as a sheet or mat.
To spread upon or over, as a garment; to spread or cover over, as snow over the tops of the mountains. Laieik. 112.
To spread out, as grass or hay.
To expose to view as something that had been concealed.
To spread, as grain upon a cloth. To spread over, as a sheet.
Stream and falls, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi.
Plastic sheeting, general term. See ʻea painaʻāpala.
To spread the knees.
Stingy.
To be hard; disobedient; stubborn.
To be thick.
Redup. of hāliʻi.
See HALII. To spread out or over frequently.

Land division, village, and Congregational church at Kāheka, Pāʻia qd., East Maui. Area in downtown Honolulu near the present Library of Hawaii, former name of the palace grounds and the home of Boki and Liliha and other royalty. (Ii 148; RC 271–272)
Street name.
Bedspread or sheet.
Bedsheet. Also hāliʻi pela.
A spring on Lehua Island.
Land section near Hīlea, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. Natural rock salt was procured here. An old wagon trail for hauling salt is still visible.
Street name.
Rug, as for living room or any large room. Also moena. See moena weleweka, pale papahele.
Mattress cover.
To spread over pili grass, said poetically of a rain shower.
To spread over a region, as a shower, like the spreading of a mat; haliipili i ke kula o Lele, the shower extends over the plain of Lahaina.
Street name.
Alike, similar.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻohālike mai ʻoe e like me kēia kiʻi.
Make a copy of this picture.
ʻAʻole hoʻi ʻoe i hoʻohālike aʻe nei me Dāvida kaʻu kauā.
You are not like David, my servant.

definitions.dtxt: To compare, contrast, make alike, resemble, copy; artificial.
To liken; to resemble; to be like.
definitions.notes: Note: Like is the root, hā is euphonic. Gram. § 48 and 211, 2.

definitions.dtxt: To give equally; to equalize in disposing of things.
Hoo. With me, to compare; to do as one does; to resemble some one in conduct See LIKE.
Redup. of hālike; to exemplify. hoʻohālikelike Redup. of hoʻohālike; comparison, resemblance, similarity, impersonation; to equalize, match, impersonate. Mea hoʻohālikelike, example.
To bud, spring forth; to shed a shell, as a crab.
Airmail; to send by airmail. Comb. hali + lele. Leka halilele. Airmail letter. Poʻoleka halilele. Airmail stamp.
Sundial shell, members of the Architectonicidae family.
Street name.
Appearance, bearing, resemblance.
Weak, as plants. (Kep. 95)
Hali and ana. A bearing or carrying; hence,
A bearing, or personal appearance; form; more generally halinalina. See LINA.
Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
Street name.
Redup. of hālina 1, 2.
See HALINA. Resemblance or similar appearance; he helehelena like.
Fluorescent, as colors. Sh. hāweo + lino. Cf. hāweo. ʻĀkala hālino. Fluorescent pink.
To turn, look, hearken, incline, have regard.

That he may incline our hearts towards him, to walk in all his ways.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
What the fundament is wiped with; a word which Kamehameha applied to Keoua when he threatened to join kings against him.
To turn towards or from, as mai or aku is used.
To turn one’s attention to a thing; to turn round to look.
To turn the ear; to listen.
To turn aside from following one.
To turn from a direct road. With pepeiao, to listen.
To turn towards one with love and respect; manao iho la au e haliu ae i ka Haku, I determined to turn to the Lord.
Hoo. To cause to turn, as the attention or care.
Street name.
Pas/imp. of hāliu. E Lono ē, hāliua mai kō alo i oʻu nei (prayer to Lono), O Lono, turn your face to me here.
To carry baggage; porter.
Redup. of hāliu.
Fins between gill plate and ventral fin.
Motion of the fins or hands in swimming; motion of rubbing; to rub, polish. E like me ka mea ʻauʻau, i halo aku i nā lima e ʻau, as the swimmer spreads forth his hands to swim.
Harrow.
The motion of the fins of a fish in swimming; the motion of the side fins of a shark; the motion of rubbing or polishing.
To peer, as with the hands shading the eyes; to peep. He ao hālō (Malo 146), a peering cloud.
To turn; to look; to look at; a halo aku la au mahope; to sweep round.
To spread out, as the hands in the act of swimming.
To look out; to peep; to look slily or shy.
To rub, grind or polish.
Land section, Kaunakakai qd., north Molokaʻi.
Street name.

Poetic name for lauloa taro.

Hill (4,084 feet high), Waipiʻo qd. Hawaiʻi. Drive, Foster Village subdivision, Hālawa, Waipahu qd., Oʻahu, a name suggested by Mary Kawena Pukui in 1958; it is the name of the son of Wākea, the first man. Translations are 'long breath' or 'long life'.
Same as hāloa 2.
Turbulent, rough, crowded, jammed.
Roughness.
To be rough or uneven, as with stones.
Suction cup fin, as beneath the stomach of an ʻoʻopu.
To well with tears, form pools.
To be about to weep; to have that deep feeling that exists just before the tears flow.
Redup. of hālo ʻi; tearful.
The state of feeling just as one is about to weep; deep internal feeling.
Weeping; shedding tears; ka maka haloiloi o ka ohia, the weeping eyes of the ohia.
To be about to weep; to have that deep feeling that exists just before the tears flow.
To shed or pour out tears.
To wipe the eyes when weeping; to wipe the tears of grief; me ka haloiloi i ko lakou waimaka no ke aloha. See HALOKOLOKO.
Loose-fitting, not tight.
Sprained or broken, as a limb.

To be about to weep; to have deep affliction. See HALOI.

Street name.

Applied to lazy, useless persons.
Peering; place from which to peer, place to peer at, lookout. (FOR. 5:91), (FOR. 6:389).

Land sections, Kalapana and Makuʻu qds., Hawaiʻi. Point, southeast Kahoʻolawe. Cove and blowhole lookout, Koko Head qd., and land section and hill (836 feet high), Waiʻanae qd., Oʻahu; street, Kapālama section, Honolulu.
Street name.
A variety of sweet potato.

To be thin; lean, as a person poor in flesh.
Hollow, dip, furrow, groove, pit; pitted, full of holes.

To ambush, lie in wait, waylay, spy, provoke trouble. hoʻohālua Same as above; ambush. ʻŌlelo ʻoluʻolu aku kekahi i kona hoalauna me ka waha, akā ma ka naʻau, ua hoʻohālua iāia, one speaks peaceably to his neighbor with the mouth, but in [his] heart, [he] lies in wait.
To lie in wait for one. Hoo. To lie in wait in order to kill or injure one.
Stripe, ripple; striped, ridged, seamed, streaked, wrinkled. Cf. ʻālu ʻa.
Pattern on the surface of a tapa beater or tapa. This term may follow types of beaters, as koʻeau hāluʻa, mole hāluʻa, pūʻili hāluʻa. It also precedes types of beaters, as listed below.
Var. of hānuʻa; see nuʻa 1.
Empty, as the stomach. Oʻahu.
A ripple on the water; the rising up of water by the wind; he nao kuku.
A streak, stripe or seam, as of a stocking.
Striped; seamed; streaked; he lole halua; he kilika halua.
Tapa-beater design.
Street name.
Tapa-beater design, said to resemble a pandanus lei and consisting of interlocked triangles.

Softness; weakness; flexibility.

To be soft; flexible.
To be weak.
Same as hāluʻamanamana.
Tapa-beater design.
Tapa-beater design. The panels between the hāluʻa lines are enhanced by regularly spaced small triangles.
A tapa-beater design. The triangles of the niho manō pattern are bordered by oblique lines pāwehe.
Halua and po, night.
To lie in wait in darkness.
Hoo. To waylay; to lurk for one; to lie in wait for a person with a design to kill him. See HALUA.
To make sturdy, as a banana plant (a word used in ancient prayers). E hāluapou ka paʻa o ka ʻāhui, sturdy the holding of the banana bunch.
To plant out bananas.
Tapa-beater design.
A tapa-beater pattern with circular motifs (pūpū). Also kōnane pūpū.
Redup. of halu.
To breathe heavily.
To be thin; lean, as a person poor in flesh.
To be hungry for food.
To be greedy after what is another’s; to confiscate property, as chiefs in ancient times.
See LULI. To turn; to twist; to shake.
To clatter, bang, thud, rattle, plop; to strike the side of the canoe with the paddle.
To wallow, as a hog; to render turbid. Ka puaʻa … i kona haluku ʻana i loko o ke kiʻo lepo, the pig … to her wallowing in the mire.
To crowd, rush; crowded. Haluku ka ʻai a ke aku, the bonito rush to eat.
To wallow in the mire, as a hog.
To lap water, as a dog; e kope i ka wai me he ilio la.
To use the paddle in rowing.
Redup. of haluku 1–3. Kekahi wahi hālukuluku o ke alanui, a crowded part of the street.
To fall, as a heavy shower with a heavy sound; to drip, as water in a shower-bath.
Street name.
A sea urchin with longer spines than those of the wana. (KL. line 21)

A calm; stillness, as the sea without wind.
To become calm, as wind after blowing.
Place, Mānoa, Honolulu. (TM)
Same as lulelule.
Ha and lule, to be shaken. To be weak; yielding; to be flexible.
Same as luli.
See LULI. To turn; to twist; to shake.
To roar, thunder; roar explosion, loud noise, racket.
Same as above; to produce a roaring noise.
A legendary man-eating bird. (FOR. 4:65)
The name of a fabulous bird in ancient times killed by the chief Waukulenuiaiku; o halulu, o ka mani kani halau.
A noise of a chariot and horsemen rushing to battle. The noise of rushing water. The sound of thunder or wind. Halulu hekili.

To roar; to rage; to roar, as thunder; as the sound of a heavy wind; to roar, as the sea. Halulu aku la ka pohaku i ke kahakai, the rock thundered off to the sea shore; halulu ana o laua ma ka puka o ka hale, shook violently the door of the house.
Heiau in Puna, Hawaiʻi, and at Kaunolū, Lānaʻi (HM 92, 496). Land division and lake, south central Niʻihau. Probably named for the legendary man-eating bird halulu.
Street name.
Same as haluhalu 2.
To summon men to work.
To summon men to work.
To breathe hard, as when the nose is filled with mucus.
To snore.
Same as lupalupa, flourishing.
Street, Foster Village, Hālawa, Waipahu qd., Oʻahu. Name suggested by Mary Kawena Pukui in 1958.
Street name.
To open, as the mouth.
Redup. of hāmau.
Quadrangle, district, ditch, ditch trail, golf course, forest reserve, and mill, northeast Hawaiʻi. Ditch, Haʻikū qd., East Maui. Poetic (Hawaiʻi): kuhi loa, long corner. (UL 122)
The name of two districts of land; one on the northeastern side of Hawaii, and the other on the northeastern side of Maui.
Street name.

definitions.der: [Lit. Hāmākua of the bowers fragrant with pandanus]
definitions.dtxt: Name of a lua fighting stroke.
Former district and land division, Haʻikū qd., Maui.
Former district and land division, Haʻikū qd., Maui.
To tie the hair in a topknot.
To raise up and stand erect, as the hair with the fingers, etc.
Hammer, mallet; to hammer.
A hammer.
Sledge hammer.
Wooden mallet or hammer.

Open, as a door or obstruction; to open, gape, yawn. Uē hāmama, to cry loudly. Hāmama ka puka, the door is open. Uwoki ʻoe e hāmama ana ka waha i ka makani, be careful lest your mouth be open to the wind [and you will have cause for weeping]. hoʻohāmama To open, expose; to pretend to open, yawn. Ua hoʻohāmama loa lākou i kō lākou waha iaʻu, they opened wide their mouth against me.
See HAMA. Open; disclosed.
The 9th conjugation of the verb hama. To open wide, as a door; to open, as the mouth. See HAMA.
To gape, as the earth.
To open, as a door, box or book.
Hoo. To cause to open; to open wide. Fig. To cause to open the mouth.
Openly; standing open, as a door.
Wide open. See hemo.
Stream, Waiheʻe, Oʻahu.
Fork; branching, forked.
Street name.
Street name.
Same as mani 1. Hapawalu liʻiliʻi, hāmani wale nō, tiny eighth of a dollar, so smooth [a mere nothing].
Humbug; to humbug. Hamapaka ʻia kahi kāpena, pau ka ʻike i ka ʻāina (song), the captain was humbugged, no more was land to be seen.
Silent; silence; hush. Cf. iʻa hāmau leo, lehua hāmau.

chants.mltran: ♫  Hark, people, the angels sing.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Hāmau ē nā kānaka, mele mai nā ʻānela.

definitions.dtxt: To silence, hush.
A species of the ohia tree.
Silent, as a person who refrains from speaking. Restraining speech.
Silently.
With the imperative form e hamau, to keep silence as an act of worship.
Imper. Silence; hush; be still. Alaila, hea mai la ia makou, i mai la, hamau kakou, then he called to us and said, let us be still.
Silence; silent. E hāmau (kō ke kahua)! Quiet (on the set)!
Street name.
To concentrate, as silently.

The two native species of Antidesma, medium-sized trees with hard wood, in the euphorbia family; leaves more or less ovate, fruits in grapelike clusters, purple, one-seeded. Formerly the wood was used for anvils for preparing olonā fiber, the fruit to color tapa red. Also haʻā, haʻāmaile, hamehame, mehame.
Ham. Also ʻūhā hame, puaʻa hame.
Name of a tree supposed to be very superior for the finest cabinet work.
Street name.

Device, doohickey, gadget, gizmo, thingamajig, i.e., something made or used for a particular purpose. Loaʻa kekahi hāmeʻa no ka hoʻāwīwī ʻana i ke paʻi ʻana. There’s a device for speeding up the printing. Comb. hā- + meʻa (Tongan for mea). See entries below and maomeka, mauhaʻa, mea hana. Hāmeʻa huakomo. Input device, as on a computer. Hāmeʻa huapuka. Output device.
Gas generator, i.e., a device used for producing gases as in a chemistry lab.

definitions.der: [Lit. device (for) testing. Cf. mīkini hoʻāʻo. Hāmeʻa hoʻāʻo iho. Battery tester (not a machine)]
definitions.dtxt: Tester, as a battery tester.
Block and tackle, an arrangement of pulleys and rope or cable used to lift or haul.
Character, as in a story; role, as in a play or movie. Comb. hā- + meʻe.
Same as hame 1.
Calm, quiet.
To make calm, as the surface of the sea.
Street name.

Anointed, smeared; to anoint, stain, rub, as with oil; to besmear, plaster, stroke gently, pet, fondle, caress; to struggle, as a drowning man; to put on, as gloves (Kel. 134); to spread, as butter; to plane smooth. Fig. To flatter; compassion.

nā hale lāʻau i hamo ʻia ā hinuhinu

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
To thrust through or split asunder, as with a spear.

example_txt.txt: E hamo ʻia iho ana ua koa nei.
E hamo iho ana ʻo Kawelo i ka ihe.

definitions.dtxt: A variety of sweet potato. (HP 141)
Anointed; plastered; besmeared; ina hele ke kanaka me ke poo hamo palolo, if a man went with head besmeared with white clay; mea hamo, ointment; perfume.
To stroke over with the hand; to wash the face; to rub or brush, as in cleaning clothes.
To besmear with blood; to plaster with lime; to anoint with oil. Or ointment.
To bend or crook the arm, as in doing the foregoing things; to crook round; to bend round, as an oval surface.
To be exactly circular, as a good calabash; ua hamo ka ipu. See Ana. Hon. 10.
Street name.
Village, beach, bay, surfing area, and land division, Hāna, Maui. This is perhaps a shortening of Haʻamoa, an old name for Samoa.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: Ua huli pū aʻela ka waʻa, ā hamohamo ana ʻoia me ka hokua.
The canoe upset, and he struggled at the crest of the waves.
Me kona leo kū i ke aloha e ʻī aku ana ma ka hamohamo ʻana.
In his voice filled with compassion [he] spoke soothingly.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hamo 1; to pat. See saying, Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974: Hamohamo.
Caus/sim.
Name of an office executed by one of the servants of the king.
Freq. of hamo. To rub; to feel frequently; to touch; to rub the hand over a surface.

definitions.der: [Lit. rub gently (as the sea on the beach). Aia akula paha i Waikīkī i Hamohamo i ka ʻimi ʻahuʻawa, maybe just at Waikīkī at Hamohamo looking for ʻahuʻawa sedge (disappointment, failure; all one does is ‘rub’ and this is ‘bitter’ [ʻawa]). See ʻŌhua; Appendix 8.1]
definitions.dtxt: Area near ʻŌhua Avenue, Waikīkī, Oʻahu, once belonging to Queen Liliʻuokalani.
Same as mole 2; smooth, plain features.
Rounded and smooth, as the edge of a board.
Small, as the eyes; he maka hamole.
Whitewash, plaster; to plaster; one who plasters, bricklayer.
Ribbed tapa; to stain or dye with red, as tapa.
A kind of kapa colored or stained red; similar to kuaula.
Street name.
To eat voraciously, devour, eat scraps; fragments, scraps. Cf. amu 2.
To destroy; to consume, as by fire. ʻAi hamu, to destroy, as by sorcery. Ua pau aku ka hapa nui o kō lāua lako hale i ka hamu ʻia e ke ahi, most of their household goods were destroyed by fire.
The refuse of food.
To eat fragments of food; to eat the skin; to pick bones; to scrape up and eat what is left; e ai hamu.
Omnivore; omnivorous. Comb. hamu + ʻakoʻa (var. of ʻokoʻa).
Insectivore, insectivorous. Comb. hamu + ʻelala.
Redup. of hamu 1, 2. Maʻaneʻi nō kahi puaʻa a mākou kahi i hamuhamu ai, here is where our pig was eating all sorts of things.
To crumble up into fragments.
To eat fragments. See HAMU.

Cannibal, among animals, insects, etc. Nui nā ʻano holoholona ʻāhiu he hamuhika ke ʻano, a pēlā e hoʻēmi ʻia ka nui o kā lākou mau keiki ponoʻī e ola a hiki i ka piha ʻana o ke ola ʻana. Many types of animals in the wild are cannibalistic by nature, and the number of their own young who achieve a full life is diminished in this way. Cf. ʻai kanaka (dic.). Homeka hamuhika.
Carnivore; carnivorous. See entries below.
Personal attendant of a chief, as a taster.
The class of persons about a chief; a distinct class of persons with superior privileges.
Herbivore; herbivorous. Comb. hamu + lau. Hamulau lāʻau. Browser, i.e., an animal that eats twigs and leaves. Hamulau mauʻu. Grazer, i.e., an animal that eats grass.
To whisper, murmur, hum; whispering.
A low indistinct rumbling sound; an indistinct sound of conversation.
Street name.
Redup. of hamumu. Ka hamumumu a nā kauwā āna (2 Sam 12.19), the whispering of his servants.
To talk in a low indistinct manner; to whisper. To talk in a low voice just above a whisper.
Scavenger; to scavenge. Comb. hamu + pela.
Cliff separating Wailau and Pūkoʻo valleys, Hālawa qd., Molokaʻi.
Name of the middle post of a house; pou hana.
Name of the white or wauki kapa.
Street name.
Bay, valley (only in place names, as Hanalei, Hanapēpē. Also Hono-, as in Honolulu). (Gram. 8.1; Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974, 245–7,.)
Nominalizing suffix. Cf. ʻana 3, Gram. 6.6.2.
Prefix of many place names (also Hono-).

Work, labor, job, employment, occupation, duty, office, activity, function, practice, procedure, process, deal, incident, reason, action, act, deed, task, service, behavior; to work, labor, do, behave, commit, make, manufacture, create, transact, perform, prepare, happen; to develop, as a picture; to have a love affair (FS 115); to induce by sorcery; to handle (as a court case); to conduct (as a class). (Translated by many English words, but seldom by ‘work’.) Cf. hana wale, and many examples below.

definitions.dtxt: Worthless; provoked. Cf. hana wale.

Work; labor; duty; office; calling; trade, etc.; hana mana, a miracle; hana a ka lani, the doing or the work of the chief.
To do; to work; to cause; used in the most extensive sense; to act; to labor.
To make; to do a thing; to affect; to produce. To perform a duty; to cause a thing; to build, as an edifice.
To form for a particular purpose.
To observe a ceremony; to keep a command. PASS. To cause to be done, i.e., to become.
To be or become warm. See this in the compounds HAHANA, MA or MEHANA, HANAHANA, and KOEHANA.

Hana is qualified by other words; hana paa, to bind; imprison. Hana is often used in a causative sense. Hana hou, to proceed to do again, or something similar. Hana make, to destroy; kill. Hana kanawai, to keep a law. Hana is often causative of the following verb. Hana ino, to do badly. Hana kumu ole, to do without cause. Hoo. To cause or compete. To work; to afflict. To refresh; to renew.
To take, as a test. Also kākau. Cf. haku i ka hōʻike.

example_txt.txt: Nui kaʻu mau hana e hana ai i ke kaona i kēia lā.
I have a lot of errands to do/run in town today.

definitions.dtxt: Queen Emma’s summer home, upper Nuʻuanu, Honolulu, named for a demigoddess, probably built in 1847 by H.A. Peirce and sold to John Young II, uncle of the queen and son of John Young, adviser to Kamehameha I. Queen Emma inherited the property and used it as a summer retreat and social center. In 1890 it was sold to the Hawaiian government and in 1911 the surrounding area was made a public park. In 1915 the Daughters of Hawaiʻi renovated the house and now maintain it as a museum open to the public for a fee. (HM 214, 220; PH 138)

definitions.notes: Note: NOTE. The translators of the Hawaiian Bible have used the word in the active sense for want of a better term, but Hawaiians seldom do; it mostly expresses the act of separation of the child from the mother; hence in a neuter or passive sense often, there was born to or for (such a one) so and so.

Generation; relative whose relationship was established several generations previously; ancestry, birth. Hanauna like, relative of the same generation; of the same generation, contemporary. Makuahine hanauna, aunt, female cousin of one’s father or mother. Keiki hanauna, nephew, niece. Kaikuahine hanauna, female cousin of a male. Pili ma ka hanauna, related through having a common ancestor. Nā makua kāne hanauna (FOR. 4:161), uncles, fathers, brothers and male cousins. ʻŌpio ʻAmelika o ka hanauna Kepanī, American youth of Japanese ancestry.
For hanau ana. Is used for relations in general. Equivalent to hoahanau. See.

NOTES.—It was formerly the practice of the chiefs to punish offenders for all offenses less than death, by stripping them entirely of their property; this practice continued until the people had a written code of laws.

A rather common native variety of taro; the leaves are narrow, the piko, leaf attachment, light, and petioles light green. This taro supplies some gray commercial poi and lūʻau greens. It was formerly used both medicinally and in religious ceremonies, as for dedicating new fish nets. According to HP 17, it is a domesticated form of wild ʻāweu. The name may be qualified by the colors hāʻulaʻula and keʻokeʻo. Var. names reported include ʻahakea, haʻakea, and hāʻawikea.

White person, American, Englishman, Caucasian; American, English; formerly, any foreigner; foreign, introduced, of foreign origin, as plants, pigs, chickens; entirely white, of pigs (Malo 37; perhaps Malo actually means of foreign introduction). See kolea 1. References in traditional literature are few, but these have been noted: He haole nui maka ʻālohilohi (FS 201), a big foreigner with bright eyes [referring to Kamapuaʻa, the pig demigod]. Hānau ke poʻo haole, he haole kēlā (KL. line 505), born was the stranger’s head, that was strange. Hoʻokahi o Tahiti kānaka, he haole (Kualiʻi chant, FOR. 4:375) only one people in Tahiti, foreigners. ʻĀina haole, foreign land. ʻŌlelo haole, European language, especially English. hoʻohaole To act like a white person, to ape the white people, or assume airs of superiority [often said disparagingly, especially of half-whites]. Hoʻohaole ʻia, Americanized, Europeanized; to have become like a white person or have adopted the ways of a white man. (Marquesan haoʻe is probably a loan from Hawaiian.)
A person with a white skin; hence, a foreigner; but Hawaiians say haole eleele for a negro.
definitions.notes: Note: The foreigners who arrived first at the islands were white persons.

definitions.dtxt: A person from a foreign couentry; an alien.
