To stammer or be slow in speech, as an aged person; ma ka olelo a na elemakule, ua lohi ke kamailio ana, hapakue ka waha i ka olelo.
To stammer. See HAPAKUE.
To daub, blot, besmear; to spread, as butter. Fig. To defile, defame.

example_txt.txt: Hāpala ka ʻele, na ke kea ka ʻai.
The black is smeared, the white gets the score [in a kōnane game].
ka makani hāpala lepo o Pāʻia
ua hāpala ʻia i ke kaikea

definitions.dtxt: To besmear, etc.
Same as pala 1, ripe.
See PALA. To defile externally; to disfigure; to besmear.
To daub; to paint; to plaster with lime.
To be satiated, i.e., stained, as with blood.
To be soft, as kalo killed with cold or drought; ua hapala ke kalo, ua pala ke kumu.
Redup. of hāpala.
Shovel, trowel.
A shovel or trowel.
Trowel, as used for digging.
Fifth; one fifth.
One-fifth; a fifth part of a thing.
Street name.
A small portion, very few. Cf. hapa nui. He nui ka waiwai i lilo no ka ʻīlio, ā he hapa loa ka waiwai loaʻā hou mai ā ia, a lot of wealth is spent on dogs, very little value is obtained in return.
Half, half dollar; in two portions.
One-half; a half part. This word is used specifically for half a dollar as hapaha is for twenty-five cents.
Street name.
Half dollar. Also hapalua.
Half gallon.
Ten-dollar gold piece.
Semiannual. Ma ka hapa makahiki e uku ai, to be paid semiannually.
See papa hapamalu.
Micro-, a prefix meaning one millionth (u). Comb. hapa + miliona. Abb. hml. Hapa miliona kekona. Microsecond, in math.
Medium rare, as meat. Makemake wau i kaʻu pipi kōʻala he hapa moʻa. I like my grilled steak medium rare. Also moʻa hapa.
Helu hapa moeā. Complex number, in math. Cf. helu maoli, helu moeā.
Front-end, in math.
Sample, as a small part of a larger whole. Sh. hapa + ʻāpana. Cf. laʻana. Hāpana pono koho. Random sample. Nā kiʻina ʻohi hāpana. Sampling methods.
Response, as to a stimulus. Comb. hā- + pane.
Street name.
Majority, most; quorum; greatest or largest portion. Cf. hapa loa. Ka hapa nui o ka manawa, most of the time.
ʻAoʻao hapa nui. Majority party, in politics.
One sixth.
Rock stratum covered with thin earth; shoal; shoal water, coral flat; shallow. Fig. Superficial.
To grope, feel the way, reach for, extend out; to experience, feel.

example_txt.txt: Hāpapa hewa ka malihini makamaka ʻole.
A stranger without friends gropes vainly.
ʻO ka makapō wale nō ka mea hāpapa i ka pō uli.
Only the blind grope in the dark night.
ʻAʻole hoʻi i hāpapa ikaika loa mai nā ʻeheu ʻiniʻini a ke kēhau.
Did not feel very strongly the pinching wings of dew.

definitions.dtxt: Stick for catching ʻio hawks; the crosspieces were gummed and a live bird was tied as a decoy.
A stratum of rock covered with thin earth; a stony place.
Earth covered with stones.
Shallow, as earth above the rock; shallow; not deeply planted, as seed; o kahi hapapa i ulu ole a mae koke.
Gulch, Puʻuokali qd., Maui. Mountain, Waiʻanae Mountains, Oʻahu.
Street name.
Same as hāpapa 1, 3.
Very shallow, etc. See above.
Nano-, a prefix meaning one billionth (n). Comb. hapa + piliona. Abb. hpl.
Partly finished, incomplete, as work.
Signature, handwriting, autograph.
Feeble with age; aged person.
Ha, breath, pau, all, and ea, life.
Short breath; applied to invalids and aged persons.
Weakness; feebleness.
Same as hapa ʻuʻuku.
Tenth part, tithe; five cents, nickel.
A tenth part; a tenth.
definitions.notes: Note: This word has been used erroneously by Hawaiians to mean a small coin, six and a quarter cents, which is not a hapaumi of any known coin; hapaumi is ten cents, or one-tenth of a dollar; hapawalu is one-eighth of a dollar, or twelve and a half cents; hapaha is one-fourth of a dollar, and hapalua is one-half of a dollar.

definitions.dtxt: Nickel, i.e., five cents. Cf. nikala.
Tenths; deci-, a prefix meaning one tenth (d). Abb. hʻm. Also keki-. Cf. hapaʻumi. ʻAukā helu hapa ʻumi. Tenth strip, in math.
Shabby, dingy, sooty, dilapidated.
Besmeared; dirty; obscured, as glass, furniture, etc.; ua hapaupau ke aniani, ua hapaupau ka papa, e holoi ae.
Dull, not shiny.
Minority, small portion; less.
Kākoʻo hapa ʻuʻuku. Affirmative action. ʻAoʻao hapa ʻuʻuku. Minority party, in politics.
A shellfish, Theodoxus vespertinus.
Hapa and wale, only. Only a part; a few; a small portion.
One eighth; eighth part; a coin worth twelve and a half cents; a piece of silver money.
The eighth; the eighth part of a thing; specifically, the sum of twelve and a half cents.
Street name.
Incorrect, faulty, inaccurate; to break, transgress (Kep. 49). hoʻohape Caus/sim. ʻŌlelo hoʻohape mai, to speak incorrectly.
See hapenuia.
Wrong; incorrect.
To limp. ʻO ka hāpeʻepeʻe o ka hele, e ʻōnaha ai nā wāwae (FOR. 5:111), going with a limp and bowlegged. See also Nak. 79.
Hubble. Ka ʻohenānā lewa lipo ʻo Hāpela. Hubble space telescope.
Same as napele, soft. Cf. pele 2.
Happy New Year. Lānaʻi, Molokaʻi nui a Hina, hape hapenuia (song). Lānaʻi, great Molokaʻi [child] of Hina, happy, happy New Year.
Short, as a piece of wood or clouds (see ex., wehiwa 2).
Partially blind.
Dim-sighted; almost blind; blear eyed, as one who cannot see clearly; hapopo ka maka.
Decomposed, putrefied. Comb. hā- + popopo. See hoʻohāpopopo.
Same as pou, short.
Same as ōlaʻi, pumice.
Name of a soft porous kind of stones.
Redup. of hāpou 1.
Blurred; darkened or whitened over, as the eye; e like me poaeae; hapoupou ka maka. See HAPOPO.
Name of a vegetable eaten in time of famine.
Clan, subtribe. Māori. Cf. ʻalaea, nāki.
Street name.
Flowering season.
Street name.
To huddle. Cf. pupue 1.
A medicinal plant (no data); a kind of fiber used for nets.
A kind of fish. (And.)
Name of a species of fish.
To gather up everything; to collect together indiscriminately good and bad; to scrape together.
Foolish, nonsensical talk.
To speak foolishly; to talk nonsense; ma ka hapukaohiohi ana paha a ka waha me ka poe Kauai la.
To collect, gather together in haste or indiscriminately and usually for oneself. Makapehu ke ao, ke hāpuku wale lā nō i ke koʻeko ʻe, swollen clouds collecting aimlessly in the chill.
Indiscriminately foolishly. Hāpuku ʻohoʻohi, to talk foolishly. ʻOhi hāpuku ka makapehu o Kaunu, the hungry ones of Kaunu grab at anything [of gossip].
Crane (for moving objects); bucket attached to a crane.
To gather up everything; to collect together indiscriminately good and bad; to scrape together.
To be crowded together, as thoughts in the mind; pilikia iho la oloko, hapuku, hapuku mai la ka manao ana.
Street name.
Spring, pool, puddle Fig. Child, as representing continuation of life.
Harpoon.
A dirty puddle of water. See KIO, HALOKOWAI, etc.
Bay, beach, State park, and land division, Puakō qd., Hawaiʻi.
Harpoon. To harpoon (an animal), to use a harpoon.
Street name.
Redup. of hapuna 1. (Nak. 82)

An endemic tree fern (Cibotium splendens, formerly called C. chamissoi), common in many forests of Hawaiʻi, as at Kīlauea Volcano, and now frequently cultivated. These ferns grow about 5 m high, and the trunks are crowned with large, triangular, lacy-looking fronds up to 2.7 m long, their light brown stems rising from a mass of silky, golden pulu (wool). Young stems were formerly used to make hats; the pulu was used as a dressing and to embalm the dead and later as stuffing for pillows and mattresses. The starchy trunk core has been used for cooking and laundry, the outer fibrous part to line or form baskets for plants. Young shoots are called pepeʻe. Also hāpuʻu pulu.
Grouper, a fish (Epinephelus quernus). The young stage is hāpu ʻupuʻu or ʻāpu ʻupuʻu. See ʻeheʻula.
Budding. Fig. Child, baby; young, as of squid (rare).
A variety of taro, also hāpuʻupuʻu, that may be qualified by the colors ʻeleʻele, hāuliuli (favored by planters), kea or keʻokeʻo, lena, and ʻulaʻula. (HP 17, 18, 32)
Name of a species of large fern; the root is eatable in time of famine. See KAHAPUU.
Name of a species of fish.
Many; abounding; plenteous.
To be many; to be multitudinous; to abound in plenty; thick together.
Street name.
An endemic tree fern (Cibotium chamissoi, formerly called C. menziesii) much like the hāpuʻu and also known as hāpuʻu, but bearing stiff blackish hairs on the frond stems. Also ʻiʻi.
Dryopteris paleacea var. fusco-atra, a much smaller endemic fern (not a tree) with dark hairs at stems' base. Also ʻiʻi.
Same as hāpuʻu 1.
Young hāpuʻu ferns that have not yet developed trunks.
Young stage of hāpuʻu fish.
Same as ʻāpuʻupuʻu; rough, bumpy, pimpled; impediment, as of speech; to speak with an impediment; obscured, as by mist.
A mound, as for playing marbles. Also haʻapuʻu, hoʻopuʻupuʻu.
Same as hāʻupuʻupu, sweet potato sprouts.

Same as hāpuʻu, taro: the plant is said to be distinguished by its leaf stems: yellow-green above, and dark brownish on lower half. The corms yield good light-colored poi, the leaves good greens. This name is qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, keʻokeʻo, and maoli. (HP 17, 32)
Name of a species of fish. See HAPUU.
See HAPUU, many. To be numerous; hapuupuu ke lelo o Hilo i ka ua.
To be undecided as to what one has said; to be not plain as to the meaning of something said; ua hapuupuu kana olelo, aole akaka; ke hapuupuu nei ka manao, mahope paha akaka.
Name of an unclean animal; a hare.
Suffix in chemical compounds and terms: -ate.
Street name.
Dirty, unpleasant. Cf. hauʻeka, haukaʻe, haumia, hauna, Gram. 6.3.3.
Ruler (nonproductive, mostly in proper names, such as in the common names Haulani and Haunani). (Gram. 6.3.3)

A lowland tree (Hibiscus tiliaceus), found in many warm countries, some spreading horizontally over the ground forming impenetrable thickets, and some trained on trellises. The leaves are rounded and heart-shaped, the flowers cup-shaped, with five large petals that change through the day from yellow to dull-red. Formerly the light, tough wood served for outriggers of canoes, the bast for rope, the sap and flowers for medicine. Of the two varieties of hau, a rare erect one (hau oheohe) was grown for its bast and a creeping one (hau) was planted for wind-breaks. (HP 196) See ʻau hau.
Cool, iced; ice, frost, dew, snow (see ex., ʻale 1); a cool breeze; to blow, of a cool breeze. Cf. kēhau.
Same as hahau 1; to hit, smite, beat, tap.
Same as hahau 2; to lay before; to offer, as a sacrifice or prayer.
A soft porous stone, as used for polishing calabashes.
Mother-of-pearl shell.
Name of a tree or large bush; the bark was sometimes beaten into a fine species of kapa called kapa hau. Laieik. 112.
definitions.notes: Note: This word has several forms. It usually takes ke for its article instead of ka; but the ke is sometimes united with it, and then it becomes kehau. This however requires a new article, which would be ke, ke kehau; but this article also sometimes adheres to the noun, and thus requires a new article still; hence the different forms of the word: hau, kehau, and kekehau, all of which take corresponding articles.

definitions.dtxt: A kind of dance used for lascivious purposes, accompanied by singing.
Name of the land breeze that blows at night; hence, any cool breeze; he hau kekahi makani mauka mai, un manao ia mai loko mai o ke kuahiwi kela makani.

The general name of snow, ice, frost, cold dew, etc.; i hoomanawanui ai hoi kaua i ka hau huihui o ke kakahiaka, when we two also persevered in the cold frost of the morning; hau paa, hoar frost. In the same verse hau is rendered dew; snow.
The rough bristles of a hog when angry; huhu ka puaa. ku ka hau; hence,
Anger; applied figuratively to men.
Name of a species of soft porous stone.
Street, Kalihi Kai, Honolulu. (TM)

To snort, bray, puff; to chatter, as the teeth; to choke with sobs. Cf. puhaʻu. Haʻu ka waha, to puff for breath. Haʻu ka waha i ka makani, to puff to the wind [of one who scolds]. ʻO Kona i ka paka ʻona, ke haʻu iho ʻoe, kūnewanewa, Kona with the intoxicating tobacco, a draw and you stagger [a Kona lover is not forgotten]. He hoki hihiu … e haʻu ana i ka makani, a wild ass … that snuffeth up the wind.
To swallow; to gulp down, as the smoke of tobacco.
To inhale; to snuff up, as the wind.
To snort, as a horse.
Pas/imp. of hau 3; a blow, stripe; to whip. ʻO ka haua hoʻi no ke kua o ka poʻe lapuwale, stripes indeed for the backs of fools.

chants.chtran: I’ve been smitten by your love
chants.chtxt: Haua iho nei au e kō aloha

definitions.dtxt: Pas/imp. of hau 4.

chants.chtran: Greetings to you, O Hiʻiaka … to whom is sacrificed a pig nose [a whole pig].
chants.chtxt: Aloha ʻoe, ē Hiʻiaka … i haua ʻia i ka ihu o ka puaʻa.

definitions.dtxt: A whipping; a stripe; a chastisement.
To whip; to apply stripes to one; to chastise. See HAHAU.
Gulch, east Lānaʻi.
Pas/imp. of haʻu.
Street name.
Bitter, cold. Ke anu hauaʻiliki, the bitter cold.
Name of a handsome surfer of Kauaʻi who vainly wooed Lāʻieikawai (Elbert, 1970, 214–5); also a place name on Kauaʻi.
Pali and peak, Airport qd., Molokaʻi.
Var. spelling of hauwalaoʻa.
Gulch, Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi.
A yearning; a strong feeling for one. See HAUUPU.
Defiled, filthy, smutty.
Hau and eka, filthy. To be defiled; to be filthy; unclean.
Glauber salts, sulphate of soda.
Hau, frost, snow, ice, and eli, to dig. Name of the native Glauber salts which are dug up out of caverns in the rocks on the Island of Hawaii.
Calcareous earth resembling chalk or plaster.
Slate pencil sea urchin (Heterocentrotus mammillatus). Also hāʻueʻue peni, pūnohu.
Name in some localities for hāʻukeʻuke, sea urchin.
Ringworm.
Tangled, snarled; untidy, confused.
Lashing, as of adze to handle; to lash. (hau 3 + -hana, nominalizer: Gram. 6.6.2) Cf. imu hau hana. Pale hauhana, cloth protecting (pale) lashing of ʻiako, outrigger boom, to the canoe float.
To lay stones in a wall; to build with stones.

example_txt.txt: E hoʻohauhau mai ʻoe i ka lau hala a kāua i palupalu.
Beat our pandanus leaf so as to soften it.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hau 3, to hit. hoʻohauhau Same as above.
Cool, as food. Cf. hau 2.
Same as hauna, bad odor.
To strike; to smite; to beat. See HAHAU.
See HAU, cold, etc. Cool, as where the heat is separated from a thing.
Redup. of haʻu.
A refrain in dance songs, usually fast, and perhaps related to haʻu. Hoʻolewa aʻe ʻoe, haʻuhaʻu ē (song), dance, puff, puff.
Pas/imp. of hauhau 1. Koʻi hauhaua, tapping adze.
To carry to and from, as gossip.
Redup. of hauhili.
Swelling of the groin.
Same as hauna.
Strong smelling; offensive to the smell. See HAUNA.
Same as hāuna.
To sob.
Slush.
Same as ʻakiohala, a shrub.
A shrub or herb (Abutilon grandifolium). Niʻihau.

An endemic genus of small trees (Kokia, four species), in the hibiscus family. The leaves are leathery, round, with three to seven shallow lobes. The flowers are large and red, and have three broad bracts at the base. See kokiʻo 2.
A kind of hau hele shrub.
Pas/imp. of hau 3.

Same as hilikau. Cf. huikau. Hauhili ka hana, disorderly work. Hauhili kāna ʻōlelo, mixed, contradictory in his speech. Hauhili ka ʻai a ke kāweleʻā, the kāweleʻā fish takes the hook and tangles [the lines; of a tangled situation]. hoʻohauhili Caus/sim.; to cause confusion, as in speech.
Probably similar to hauhilikī.
Carelessness in doing a thing; no ka mikioi o ka hana, aole no ka hauhili, for the niceness of the work, not for the slovenliness.
Diverging from the straight path; blundering; false; not to be depended on for truth.
Crooked or blind, as a path in the bushes. See HILI.
To bind up; to tie up, as a bundle; e hauhili a paa, bind it up tightly. See HILI.
To snarl, entangle.
Var. of hauhoa.
Street name.
To tie, lash, bind; to saddle, as a horse.
Zuben Elgenubi, a star.
Slang term for haole, perhaps related to hole, to fidget, squirm; it might also be said of a drunk, over-persistent lover, or mischievous child.

A word known only in the chant called Haui ka lani, (FOR. 6:368–410); according to Andrews (FOR. 6:368), an ancient, poetical name for hāʻule which he translates “fallen” but more probably hau, to strike + -i, transitivizer. A more accurate translation of the chant’s title is “the chief is struck down.” (Gram. 6.6.4) A less plausible interpretation is hau i ka lani, offer to the royal chief.
The title or epithet of a chief, as noble, a descendant of kings, etc.; o Haui ka lani, ke alii kiekie, he kumu alii.
Sea area near the wharf at Hilo, Hawaiʻi. Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
Street name.
Tapa sarong dyed with ʻōlena.
Out (said in gambling).
In gambling, when one wins he says hauka; a foreign word perhaps.

Stained, smeared, smudged, defaced, sordid; to besmirch, stain, smear; defiled, as taboo food cooked with common food; babbler. Cf. ʻaeʻa. hoʻohaukaʻe Caus/sim.; to spoil, as a ballot. Fig. To defile a reputation.
Filthiness; carelessness; also,
A mean fellow; a babbler; a trifling talker.
Slovenly done; foul; unclean; impure; wicked.
See HOOKAE. To deface; to blot out; to squander; to behave shamefully.
To do a thing carelessly; ina e hauhili a haukae ka oukou hana, if you do your work in a slovenly and careless manner.
To be filthy; dirty in appearance.
A kind of hau tree.
Street name.
See HAUKAE.
See HAUKAE.
Street name.
To strut. Cf. kalalī 1.
Dressed in one’s best.
Ice cream.
Same as kamumu.
Hau and kamumu, a rustling sound.
The confused noise of a multitude; ua uhiia kona leo e ka haukamumu leo o ka aha, his voice was drowned by the confused noises of the multitude. Laieik. 22
The low or indistinct conversation of two persons. Laieik. 80.
Street name.
Hospital.
Choppy, as the sea. (And.)
The state of the sea in a chopped sea something like the kai kupikio, very difficult to urge a canoe through it.
Var. of hāʻukeʻuke 1–3.
See UKAUKA 2, to eat. A ringworm.
Same as kawewe. Haukawewe ke kolopā, nāueue nā hao pine, the crowbars clitter-clatter; the iron pegs shake. Haukawewe hoʻi nā ʻōmaka wai o Kūlanihākoʻi, the stream sources of Kūlanihākoʻi pour down.
Same as hāʻukeʻuke 1–3.
Same as nāʻuke, to search for lice. Cf. hāʻule 4.
The sea-egg. See HAUKEUKE.
The act of hunting lice; ka haule ana i ka uku poo.
To hunt, as for prey; to fall upon; to catch; e hauke uku, to hunt lice in one’s head.
White snow, snow.
Hau, snow, and kea, white. The white snow; the whiteness of snow in cold countries; ka haukea o Maunakea.
To quiver, shiver, (Nak. 78)
A shivering with the cold.
Cold; shivering with cold.

To shiver with the cold; to be contracted with cold, as the muscles; haukeke mai ana ka lehelehe, minomino na lima, eleele ka lihilihi, the lips quivered with the cold, the hands were wrinkled, dark were the eyebrows; to be in pain with the cold.
Street name.
An edible variety of sea urchin (Colobocentrotus atratus). The teeth were used for medicine. (KL. line 23) Varieties are qualified by the terms kau pali (cliff-perching), kai ʻina, and ʻulaʻula.
Ringworm.
Motif on tapa stamp.
Name of a small insect that adheres to the skin of persons, similar to the ane; haukeuke, he ane, he mea e pili ana ma ka ili o ke kanaka, ua like me ke kane.
Name of a shell fish that has many prongs two or three inches long.
The name of a small sea animal.
To swing back and forth with a bang or clatter; to click as the teeth; to bounce back and forth, as breasts.
Hāʻukeʻuke iwi loloa Same as hāʻueʻue 1.
To shiver much and intensely with the cold.
Sport. See ʻuao haʻuki.
Pudding made of arrowroot starch and juice extracted from baked ti root. Cf. haukō, haupia.
Track and field. Nā haʻuki Helene. Track and field events.
A pudding made of arrowroot starch, coconut cream, and sugar-cane juice. Cf. haupia.
Point, Lahaina, Maui. Perhaps.
Icecap, as at the Arctic. (Kep. 183)
Shave ice, snow cone.
Street name.
Land section, Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi; see Hōkūʻula. Coastal area, north shore, Kamalō qd., Molokaʻi.
Floater, as on a fish net.
A kind of hard hau tree.
See Kahaukomo.
Hawthorne. Pīʻai haukona. Hawthorne berry.
Five species of a native genus (Hibiscadelphus) of medium-sized trees, related to the hau; rare plants, with heart-shaped leaves and curved, red, yellow, and green flowers.
Street name.
Road, upper Mānoa, Honolulu, and the site of the Lyon Arboretum.
Street name.
Reddish.
See limu hāʻula.

example_txt.txt: nā ʻōlelo haulalapa a ka waha
scorching, sizzling words of the mouth

definitions.dtxt: To blaze, scorch, sear.
The high ascending blaze of a large fire. See LAPALAPAAHI. E ku haulalapa, e lapalapa.
Iceberg, floating ice.

definitions.der: [Lit. ruling royal chief (this meaning is based solely on historical evidence: see hau- 2)]
definitions.dtxt: A personal name.
To surge, as the sea; to plunge, as a canoe; to ply back and forth; restless, constantly on the move. Fig. To dissipate.
Uneasy; seeking freedom from restraint; restive; he mauli haulani.
To root, as a hog; to plunge, as a canoe.
To be restless in one’s grasp; to squirm; e oni; to try to free one’s self when held fast.
Street name.
Balsa.
Reddish, pink.
Dark red, formerly said of dark bay horses.
See ULA, red. To be a little red; a haulaula ka waha i ka laau.

To fall, drop, tumble down; dropped. Cf. hina, to fall from an upright position, and hāʻule, to drop down. Hāʻule hua, to lay an egg. Hāʻule lio, to fall off a horse. Hāʻule wale, to fall prematurely, as fruit. He keiki hāʻule wale, a miscarriage. Hāʻule ka ua, the rain falls. hoʻohāʻule To drop, cause to fall. E hoʻohāʻule au i ka ua maluna o ka ʻili o ka honua (1 Nal 18.1), I will send rain upon the earth.

To lose, fail, forget, die, neglect; loss, failure, defeat. Ka hāʻule ʻole o ka manawa, without loss of time. Hāʻule ka heihei, to lose a race. No ka hāʻule o ka uku, because of failure to pay. Kekahi mea hāʻule, that which was lost.

To begin to do. Hāʻule i ka hewa, to fall into sin, as by adultery. Pau ka moʻolelo hōʻināʻinau, hāʻule ihola lākou kōnane (FOR. 4:57), after the interesting story, they began to play kōnane checkers.
To delouse, look for louse. See hāʻuke, FOR. 5:541.
A thing lost; dropped. Kekahi mea haule.
To fall; to fall from a perpendicular state; to stumble; to fall down.
To come upon one, as a new set of feelings; to come to or arrive at a place; to encamp; a haule lakou i Kailua.
To loosen; to let go; to unfold.
To become void; to lack; to fail; to be wanting; to fall dead.
To overturn; to destroy; to seek after; to fall upon for destruction.
To fail in coming to pass or to be fulfilled, as a promise. To fall, as one to fail in his moral or religious character.
Hoo. To cause to fall; with ua, as rain, i.e., to cause to rain.
To throw one’s self down on to a thing. To cause to fall, i.e., destroy, as an army. To be rendered void, as a law.
To lose, as in sports. Cf. eo. Māhele hāʻule. Consolation bracket, as in a sports tournament.
Deadfall, a kind of animal trap.
Pas/imp. of hāʻule.
To miss, fall or lag behind. Ua hāʻule hope mākou i ke kaʻa, we missed the car.
A variety of sweet potato.
A freshwater alga found in taro patches.
Street name.
Fall, autumn.
Autumn, fall. See māuiili.
Street name.
A falling, dropping. Hōʻiliʻili i nā haʻulena o kāu ʻai, to gather the gleanings of your harvest.
Contracted from haule ana. A falling, that is, whatever falls; a gleaning.
To fall, surrender.
Redup. of hāʻule 1–3.

This word is used idiomatically with lele and hoʻolele, and may be related to mauli. Lele ka hauli, greatly shocked, astonished, moved, startled, frightened. Auwē! lele kā hoʻi koʻu hauli, oh, how startled I am. He kaua hoʻolele hauli, alarm; shocking events.
Blackish, swarthy, dark.
Bruise. Ka hāuli o ka mea hewa ʻole, he nalowale koke, a bruise inflicted on an innocent person vanishes quickly.
Small fish with formerly transparent body beginning to darken; embryo of human or animal.
See ULI. Anything of a dark color; the dark shadow of an object; dark clouds; the deep blue sky.
A stain upon a person’s character; ka hauli o ka mea hewa ole, e nalowale ia, the stain upon a person’s character without fault will soon vanish.
Dark; swarthy; tawny; shadowing; darkish; shady.
Cool, having lost warmth.

Hau, iron, and liilii, little. A factitious word got up by Hawaiian cooks, and means, to broil on the gridiron; they call the gridiron hauliilii, i.e., little irons; with some, SYN. with hoomakaukau, to get ready.
To shiver. Cf. līlī.
Redup. of hāuli 1.
To darken.
A fish (Gempylus serpens), sometimes called the snake mackerel.
Name of a species of fish.
The intensive of hauli. To be dark, etc.
To be in a slight state of commotion; applied to the rippling of the sea when the wind just begins to blow.
A variety of hāuliuli, a fish.
Descendant, offspring.
Blurred eyes of a rat, said of very old persons; an aged person.
Epithet of an advanced state of old age, when the eyes are dim, the steps totter, and the breath short.
Street name.
Quiet.

Student, pupil, apprentice, recruit, disciple. Perhaps Lit. to lay before one a ball of masticated food (māna); also see hau- 2. Haumana aʻo ʻoihana, technological student, trainee, apprentice. Haumana komo hou, new student, freshman. hoʻohaumāna To act as a pupil, become a pupil; to make pupils of.
A scholar; an apprentice; a disciple.
To be or act, as a scholar.
Hoo. To teach, as one teaches scholars; to make scholars or learners of persons.
To teach them some art, or convey to them some knowledge they had not before.
To instruct, as a scholar or apprentice in any art or handicraft.
Haumāna mua puka. Undergraduate student. Haumāna muli puka. Graduate student. Hoʻonaʻauao haumāna lololo. Gifted education, as a school program. Loiloi holomua haumāna. Student assessment.
Street name.
Probably similar to haumanumanu.
Same as manumanu, irregular, dull; ugly. Haumanumanu ka ipu ʻinoʻino, misshapen is the imperfect gourd [an ugly person; a warning to a mother to mold the body of her baby].
Full of holes, cracks or crevices. See MANU.
Name of the mother of Kekauakahi, the war god.
Street name.
A kind of stone used for adzes.
Uncleanliness, filth, defilement, abomination; defiled, indecent, obscene, vile, lewd, unclean, contaminated, sordid. (hau- 1 + -mia, pas/imp.)

example_txt.txt: Moe ihola me ia, a hoʻohaumia iāia.
Sleeping with her and defiling her.

definitions.dtxt: To pollute, defile, befoul, besmirch, contaminate.
Contagion; ceremonial defilement from contact or contiguity to dead bodies.
Morally, from various wicked practices.
Things forbidden under penalty of death, stronger than kapu; uncleanness, etc. Defilement.
To defile; to pollute; to be either morally, physically or ceremonially unclean. Hoo. To defile naturally, morally. Or ceremonially, to stain; defile.
Unclean; impure.
That which defileth.
Pollution.
Unpleasant odor, as of spoiling fish or meat, or volcanic sulphur; stench; tainted. (Hau- 1 + -na, nominalizer.)

example_txt.txt: same as iʻa hoʻomelu; see melu

definitions.dtxt: To cause an offensive odor; to use strong-smelling bait to attract fish; to smell such an odor.
The strong offensive smell of meat.
Strong smelling; offensive to the smell.
Fishpond on inner side of Loko-Waka pond, Keaukaha, Hawaiʻi.
Same as hau 3, 4; stroke, blow; offering; to mend a net; to toss, as a kilu quoit (Laie 483). See hāuna lāʻau.
The striking of the hand or other substance in playing the kily; a i ka umi o ka hauna kilu, a laua. Laieik. 114.

Panic, riot, roughhouse, brawl, tumult, commotion, confusion, hubbub. Ka leo o kēia haunaele, the noise of this tumult. hoʻohaunaele To provoke panic, riot; agitator. Hoʻohaunaele i nā ʻaha hoʻokolokolo, contempt of court.
The excitement and disturbance of war.
Any popular commotion or disturbance.
To flee in war; to suffer the consequences of such flight; that is, to forsake houses, homes, and the general loss of all comforts.
To be in confusion, as in a mob or general disobedience to laws.
To be in doubt or perplexity of mind.
Hoo. To stir up the people; to make popular disturbance in a government.

Civil unrest. Hoʻāla ʻia aʻela he haunaele kūloko ma ke kūlanakauhale no ka nui loa o nā hihia ma waena o ka poʻe e noho ana ma ia wahi. Civil unrest was created in the city due to the tremendous amound of tension between the people who live in the area. Trad.
Wind name.
Point and area, Hālawa qd., Molokaʻi.
Name of a star in the Milky Way.
Same as naku 1, to root, wallow.
Defensive middle guard, nose guard, nose tackle, in football. Dic., new mng.
Stroke or thrust of the war club.
A slightly offensive odor.
A strong offensive smell, but less so than hauna; he wahi pilau uuku. See HAUNA.
Street name.
Street name.
Lane and former land area, Kalihi Kai, Honolulu; name of a heiau in Kalihi; see ʻUmi.
Street name.

Glacier. Ka hauneneʻe ʻana. Glaciation. I ka hauneneʻe ʻana, paʻapū nā kuahiwi a me ka ʻāina i ka hau no nā makahiki he nui ka lōʻihi. In glaciation, the mountains and land become covered with ice for a period of many years. Ka Pāka Aupuni ʻo Hauneneʻe. Glacier National Park.
Name of a cold wind.
Street name.
A line, as used in lashing a mat canoe cover; to add a new weft in plaiting. Moena hāunu ʻole o ka nahele, mats of the forest without added wefts [a bed of forest ferns and greenery].
Same as unu kupukupu: see unu 2, altar.
Hill and former place of refuge, Waimānalo, Oʻahu.
A rare variety of hau, a tree, with a straight trunk.
Hau wood handle attached to net used for ʻiao fish.
A kind of fish net.
Chilled to the bone, stiff with cold; frost, ice, cold; icy wind.
A medicine made of hau bark for women in labor.
A kind of palsy or perhaps stiffness of the limbs, as when one is chilled with cold; having been long in the water.
Name of a medicine given to women in labor, similar to slippery elm.

Ridge, Waimea qd., Kauaʻi. Gulch, northeast Lānaʻi. Ancient surfing area, Lahaina, Maui (Finney and Houston 28); an off-shore stone here is believed to have been a woman who was fleeing from her enemies when the gods turned her into a stone. See Hikinaakalā.
Street name.

definitions.der: [Hau, frost, dew, etc., and ole, not]
definitions.dtxt: Without dew, as a barren place.

Happy, glad, gay, joyful; happiness, enjoyment, joy. The common expressions Hauʻoli Makahiki Hou, Happy New Year, and hauʻoli lā hānau, happy birthday, are translations from English. Hauʻoli mau, always happy, cheerful. hoʻohauʻoli To cause happiness, gaiety, joy. Mea hoʻohauʻoli, entertainment, pleasure, treat.
Joy; rejoicing; gladness.
Joyous; glad.
Hau and oli, to sing. See OLI. To sing; to rejoice. To express joy by singing; to be joyous. Hoo. To cause joy; to make glad.
Streets, Pāwaʻa section, Honolulu, and Kailua, Oʻahu.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: ʻO kou kānāwai kaʻu e hauʻoliʻoli nei.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hauʻoli.
Intensive form. To take delight in; to rejoice in.
Street name.

definitions.der: [Lit. cool [wind] of Māʻihi (a wind goddess whose full name was Māʻihiʻalakapualono, fragrant sacred Māʻihi [child] of Lono)]
definitions.dtxt: Name of a wind associated with Kailua quadrangle, Hawaiʻi.
Hau-stick handle of mālolo (flying fish) net.
Name of a species of fish net.
Soft limestone.
Street name.
Same as ʻopo.
What is put together in good order; a good, well finished work.
To lay in good order, as stones in a wall; to stand evenly; he wahi i nini, i kumanoia a maikai.
Same as ōwī 1, a verbena. Niʻihau.
To eat heartily or voraciously. Ka haupa ʻana, feasting.
This should probably be haʻupā. **
To open and shut, as scissors, jaws.
To eat much; to swell up, as the stomach from eating too much.
To be greedy in eating.
To act, as the jaws in eating fast. See UPA.
Street name.
See Kahaupalemo.
To play hide-and-seek; hide-and-seek.
The play of children, hide and seek.
To play hide and seek; e peepee akua; to play hide and seek, as children.
Pudding formerly made of arrowroot (pia) and coconut cream, now usually made with cornstarch. Cf. haukō.
The substances of arrow-root and cocoanut mixed together and baked for food.
To mix together (pia) arrow-root and cocoanut and bake it; to cook arrow-root and cocoanut together.
The lower end of the breast bone; the place where the ribs unite.
The thorax. See HOUPO.
Street name.
To soften the earth, as for planting.
Parachute. Sh. puhaʻu + poho.
The sudden excitement of the passions.
definitions.notes: Note: This word was used in a moral philosophy for conscience, or the internal monitor; o ka mea i nanea palaka ka haupu, alaila aole e ole kona hewa. Afterwards lunamanao was used.

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
To recollect, recall, remember.

chants.mltran: ♫  You are what I have remembered.
chants.mltxt: ♫  ʻO ʻoe kaʻu i hāʻupu aʻe nei.

definitions.dtxt: To cause to recollect, recall.
To excite; to stir up, as the affections or passions.
To suffer with anxiety; to be much excited or moved; ua haupu honua ae la ka makaula, the prophet was much excited. Laieik. 157.
To rise up suddenly in the mind, as a thought.
To stir up one to recollection; alaila, e haupu ia lakou me ka homanao.

Peak and ridge, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi (PH 107), probably named for a demigod (see Pōhakuokauaʻi), also called Hoary Head. Bay, peak, and ridge, Pelekunu Valley, Kamalō qd., Molokaʻi, the fortress of Kapeʻekauila who abducted Hina (HM 464); she was rescued by her sons Kana and Nīheu. The hill stretched, but Kana defeated it by using five stretching bodies: human, rope, convolvulus vine, banana, and spider web (HM 466). The hill was lifted up by turtles. Also called Hāʻupukele. About 200 yards into the bay are some rocks as much as 100 feet high. It is said that a giant, Kana, walked down the ridge after defeating an enemy and kicked these stones into the water (Jarrett 21). See Keoloʻewa, Kūkaʻiwaʻa, Mōkoholā. Land section, Pearl City, Oʻahu.
Snowflake.
Same as puʻuhau.
Any hard bunch or protuberance on the joints or limbs.
Redup. of hāʻupu; to recall again and again.
Sprouts from sweet potatoes. Also hāpuʻupuʻu, hāʻapuʻapu.
Redup. of haupuʻu.
A hard protuberance on the joints, as on the fingers or wrists. See HAUPUU.
Swollen, as the ground by frost; uneven, as with bunches of hail, or with heaps of salt in the salt-pits.
Land section, village, forest reserve, homesteads, settlement, stream, elementary school, beach park, and playground, Kahana qd., Oʻahu.
Street name.
Deep affection for one; a yearning over a beloved object. See HAUAPU and HAUPU.
Frozen yogurt. Cf. haukalima (dic.). See waiūtepe.
To gabble, gossip, chatter, babble, hubbub, fuss.
To gabble where all talk and none hear.
To get into confusion, as an assembly disagreeing in opinion; alaila hauwalaau loa ae la ka lehulehu, then the multitude fell into great confusion. See WALAAU.
A confused, excited din; to sound thus. (The following words are confused at times: uluaoʻa, walaʻau, wanaoʻa.)
Redup. of hauwalaʻau.
See the foregoing. Noise, as of many talking or bawling at once without cause or meaning.

Mere gabbling without cause; make ka alii o Nunu ma Koolau, kahaha kahi poe, i mai kanaka, he hauwalawalaau wale no, when the chief Nunu died at Koolau, some were astonished, but the people said there was nothing but a great talk. See WALAAU.
Same as wanaoʻa.
To extend; to stretch out. See WANAOA.
Same as wawā; medley of simultaneous talking. hoʻohauwawā Caus/sim.; provocative of loud noise.
Confusion; disorder, as a multitude talking at once.
To talk in vain, confusedly or in disorder. See WAWA.
To cry, tease, nag, fret. hoʻohauwene Caus/sim.; to tease others.
Defiled, unclean, filthy, daubed with excrement.
To be daubed with excrements; to be defiled; to be in a pitiable state.
To wallow in troughs, as a rough sea.

A sea urchin (Tripneustes gratilla). Fig. Of no character or substance, perhaps so used because of the sayings hāwaʻe kai nui, sea urchin with much juice [and little meat, hence useless], and he hāweʻa ʻiʻo ʻole, sea urchin without meat [or brains]. Varieties of sea urchin are qualified by the terms maoli (natural) and poʻo hina (gray-head).
A kind of stone, used as sinkers for octopus lures.
Sprouts from sweet potatoes.
Name of a famous evil sorcerer. See lauhue 1, for figurative meaning.
The white sea-egg.
Awkward, as in diving and spattering the water much; hawaekainui ke kanaka i ka luu.
General name for small lobsters.
Sprouts from sweet potatoes.
A species of small lobster.
Redup. of hawa; a taunt in a children’s game.
Filthy; dirty; especially with such dirt as sticks to one. See HAWA.
To generate steam in an earth oven by pouring on water (Kep. 163); to purify with water.
Temporary long, gabled house in which priestesses assembled for purification ceremonies. (Malo 178)
Sewer.
A variety of sweet potato.
Pertaining to the place or business of steaming food in an oven.
To pour or dash water on to an oven to increase the steam; i hale palima, hale hawai ma ka la hookahi.
To pour water on an oven when heated to generate steam.
Water trough or pipe, aqueduct, flume.
A pipe for conveying water; a lead pipe, hose, etc.

Hawaiʻi (both the island and the group of islands); Hawaiian person; Hawaiian. Elsewhere in Polynesia, Hawaiʻi or a cognate is the name of the underworld or of the ancestral home, but in Hawaiʻi the name has no meaning; see Pukui, Elbert, and Mookini, 1974. See saying, kuauli. hoʻohawaiʻi To act as a Hawaiian; to ape or imitate Hawaiians.

Name of the largest island of the Hawaiian group, and gives name to the group. From time immemorial the people have called themselves “ko Hawaii,” and the islands “ka pae aina o Hawaii,” “na moku Hawaii,” etc.
Hawaiʻi; Hawaiian. Keʻena Kuleana Hawaiʻi. Office of Hawaiian Affairs (OHA). Kula kaiapuni Hawaiʻi. Hawaiian-medium school. Papa kaiapuni Hawaiʻi. Hawaiian-medium class.

Largest island in the Hawaiian group, 76 miles wide, 93 miles long, with an area of 4,038 square miles and a population in 1970 of 63,468. Hilo is the major town and county seat. County and collective name for the entire island group (1970 population 769,913). This name occurs in many parts of Polynesia (Havaiki: New Zealand, North Marquesas; ʻAvaiki: Cook Islands; Savaiʻi: Sāmoa). In some areas, but not in Hawaiʻi, it is the name of the homeland, or of the underworld to which the dead went. Epithets for the island of Hawaiʻi: Hawaiʻi nui a Keawe, great Hawaiʻi of Keawe (a chief); Hawaiʻi kua uli (PH 222), green-backed Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
Broad or large Hawaii; i kane na ke kaikamahine alii o Hawaiiakea. Laieik. 168.
Street name.
Street name.
Subdivision of Honolulu developed by Henry J. Kaiser, including golf course, recreation center, and drive. Streets here are named for localities on other islands.
Gulch, north Lānaʻi.
Street name.
Name of a legendary figure believed by some to have discovered Hawaiʻi, but see Barrère, 1969; place name.
Name of a line for ulua fishing in 17 or more fathoms of water.

Ancient surfing area, Hanalei district (?), Kauaʻi (Finney, 1959a:52). College on the Kailua side of the Nuʻuanu Pali, Oʻahu, established by four Protestant churches and incorporated in 1963; first classes were held in 1967. In 1971 there were 170 students. See Puʻuhawaiʻiloa. Ridge and street, Niu, Honolulu. Channel northwest of Nihoa Island.
Full-blooded Hawaiian.
Sewerage pipes, sewage system.
To lie, bluff.
Lying; deceitful; no confidence in.
Weak, soft, boggy. Cf. nāwali.
A place where vegetation grows around a salt pond.
Redup. of hāwali.
A place where vegetation grows around a salt pond.
A kind of slimy, sticky fish.
Same as hāwanawana.
To whisper; to speak in the ear; to speak in a low voice.
To whisper; whispering. See kānāwai.
Whispering; low talk in the ear; soft conversation.
To whisper, etc. See HAWANA. A huki iho la ia ia, e hawanawana i kona pepeioa, he pulled him towards himself to whisper in his ear; to consult against one.
Street name.
Nut of the loulu, native palm, considered delicious to eat; also the tree itself. Also wāhane. Lau hāwane (Nak. 77), loulou leaves.
A small, fine, red seaweed (Polysiphonia spp.), consisting of branching filaments forming dense tufts.
The name of the palm cocoanut.
The fruit of the tree otherwise called loulu; the fruit is eatable; its leaf made into hats.

example_txt.txt: I make nō he hāwāwā, ʻauhea nohoʻi nā lima e ʻau mai?
The unskilled die, where are arms to swim with? [Skill saves life.]
A ke hoʻomake nei ka huhū i ka mea hāwāwā.

definitions.dtxt: Unskilled, awkward, clumsy, incompetent, blundering; blunder, incompetence. Cf. waʻawaʻa. See saying, ʻō 2.
Awkwardness; ignorance; without skill or energy to obtain it.
Awkward; unapt; unskillful; ignorant; rude; weak in knowledge. Mea hawawa, a silly person.
See HAWA. To be awkward; foolish; ignorant; not to know how to do things.
Street name.
Point and station, Lahaina qd., Maui, perhaps named for the famous drum brought by Laʻamaikahiki from Kahiki. (HM 356)

To tie, bind, lash, make fast; to snub, as cattle; net lashing, as for a hue wai, gourd; thong. Fig. Umbilical cord; to eat. E hāwele ʻoukou ʻo kēlā kanaka kēia kanaka i kāna pahi kaua, gird ye on every man his sword.
A type of tapa (no data).
A tying on; a binding on.
To lengthen; to lengthen by tying on a piece; e loloa ae; hence,
To tie or lash on with a cord or string.
To bind or secure by tying; to fasten by tying.
To bind on, as shoes or sandals. To tie or fasten on, as a sword. As the cover of a vessel. As armor generally.
To shoe; to put on shoes.
Gulch, Kaupō qd., Maui.
White lime, as used for dressing hair and turning the hair brown. Hāpala ʻia i ka hāwena, bedaubed with white lime [one whose gray hairs have not brought wisdom].
A substance similar to chalk; chalk.
Hoariness; the whitishness of gray hair; a hoary or gray head; hapala ia i ka hawena, daubed with whitishness.
Applied to a gray headed man who has but little wisdom.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: placed in a position of glittering horror

definitions.dtxt: Glowing. Fig. Distinguished, honored (used after hano).
Glowing, as in the dark; phosphorescent. Cf. hālino.
Me ke kau i ka hano hāweo. Summa cum laude, with highest honors, as in academics.
Redup. of hāweo.
To rumble, clatter, patter, as rain; rumbling. (GP 78) Cf. kawewe.
To pour down, as the sun; to vibrate, as heat.
A rustling indistinct sound; a slight rumbling sound.
To make a monotonous rustling sound, as one moving his feet, drumming with his fingers, etc.; nehe, neneke. See UE and UEUE.
Wave, in scientific usage. See entries below and hoʻolaulā hawewe, laulā hawewe, ʻanini laulā hawewe.
Transverse wave, i.e., a wave in which matter vibrates at right angles to the direction in which the wave moves. Cf. hawewe papamoe.
Solar energy wave.
Sound waves, as used in measuring ocean depths. See hoʻopapā hohonu. Ikaika hawewe kani. Amplitude, i.e., the amount of energy in a sound wave. Kōā hawewe kani. Sound wavelength.
Compressional wave, i.e., a wave in which matter vibrates in the same direction as the wave moves. Cf. hawewe ʻaleʻale. See ulu, wele.
Street name.
Village and land section, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi. (PH 89)
Name of a weapon used in war; hawane, he laau hanaia i he kaua.
Indefinite article. A, an; to be a, have (with a possessive). (Gram. 10.2) He kanaka maikaʻi ia, he is a good person. He kaʻa koʻu, I have a car.
Art. The indefinite article, answering somewhat to English a or an. For its various uses, see Gram. § 66, 111, Rule 6th, Syntax, etc.
Grave. Ka ʻeho no ka hē o Rāhela, the pillar for Rachel’s grave.
General name for caterpillar. Cf. ʻanuhe, kāhē.
To scrape, rub, polish.
Swish, as of a whip; murmuring sound of wind or running water; to swish, sough. Ka hē o ka makani, the swish of the wind.
Upper part of a crab’s leg.
Poi from the center or core of taro, formerly reserved for chiefs, as it had not come into contact with dirt (Kep. 165).
Edges of the mouth of the square uhu (parrot fish) net.
Dividing line between lands.
Hollow container in which canoe paint was mixed.
The letter “h.”
Hay.
Hoʻohē Same as hōhē, cowardly.
A grave; a place where one person is buried. A sepulcher; he lua kupapau.
A dividing line or boundary between lands.
Name of the little worm that eats the leaves of the cocoanut and the palm-leaf pandanus.
To roar, as a strong wind, such as roars down the ravines; he leo o ka makani kauaula ka'u i he iho nei, ke nee nei i na kahawai.
Street name.
To call, name; to sing or recite a name chant; to give a name to. Cf. ʻauihea, kāhea.

example_txt.txt: Ua hea aku au i kona inoa ʻo Laʻakea.
Ke hea mai ʻoukou iaʻu, he kumu.

definitions.dtxt: Misty, clouded, smoky, obscure. Cf. Kona Hea.
Bank, as of a river. (Kep. 91)
Which (in questions and after other words). Cf. ʻāhea, ināhea. Ka mea hea? Which thing? Ka manawa hea? Which time? When? Ka hale hea? Which house? (Gram. 8.5)

Where? (Usually following prepositions i, ma, mai, no, ʻo; mahea is often written as one word.) I hea ka puke? Just where is the book? Mahea ka puke? Whereabouts is the book? Mai hea mai? Where from? No hea ʻoe? Where are you from? Ā e hele ana ʻoe ʻo hea (FOR. 5:219)? Where are you going? Aia i hea ka puke? Where’s the book (sometimes shortened to aihea)? ʻO kēia lio ā ʻo kēlā lio, mahea ʻoe? This horse or that horse, which for you? (See also ʻauhea.)
A call; a calling out; a cry.
To call; to give an appellation. SYN. with kapa. To call to one; to call one.
To choose; to appoint.
To sing or recite a mele; ina ku ke kanaka i ka hea mele ana, if any man stand up for reciting a mele. See KAHEA.
He ua hea. See UA. s. A cold rain. See KONAHEA, cold rain. See KONA.
Used as a suffix to various words, as paapuhea, meaning perhaps heavy or smoky.

Which? what? when? where? referring to place, where; ka hale hea? what or which house? ka manawa hea? when? what time? etc.; it is declined like a noun. See Gram. § 160 and 165. It takes also other prefixes; as, auhea? pehea? etc.

Stained red, inflamed, reddened; flattened and destroyed, as by lava; blood red; a blood sacrifice, as hog or man. Cf. heka, kiliheʻa, kīpalaheʻa. Kā ia heʻa hala o Kaliʻu (song), this destroyed pandanus of Kaliʻu is struck [Pele’s destruction of Hiʻiaka’s pandanus trees].
Sore eyes; inflamed eyes.
To be red or sore, as inflamed eyes; to be stained or colored red.
To eat up entirely; to leave nothing uneaten.
definitions.notes: Note: This was applied to the last hog that was sacrificed on the eighth day at the dedication of a heiau. The hog itself was called puaa hea, as it was to be entirely eaten up. Should any person refuse to eat of it on this occasion, he would be immediately sacrificed; or if any part of the hog should be left after all had eaten, they would all die by some dreadful judgment.

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
Kauaʻi name for kāwaʻu, a kind of Zanthoxylum. Cf. aʻe.
See aha.
To what; to ask what; heaha mai la kekahi, heaha ia? a certain person whatted (asked what) is it? Gram. § 37. See AHA.
He and aha. Lit. A what? what? why?
Of scorn. What does it amount to? It’s of no value. (Perhaps nanā is from he ʻahi kananā, a phrase describing a fierce fighter; cf. nanā.)
Also wesenanā. He aha sananā, he mauʻu Hilo (Kel. 138)? What does it amount to? It’s just Hilo grass.
Street name.
To call frequently and hospitably; to welcome; friendly, hospitable, genial. He leo heahea, a hospitable calling voice. Kēlā pali heahea, walowalo i ke kanaka, that calling cliff summoning men.
Warm, tepid, insipid. Cf. ʻāheahea, mūhea, ʻōheahea.
See HEA. To call; to call frequently; to call out; to call for help with earnestness.
To imprint with spots, stains; smeared, as with red earth. Pulu au i ka huna kai, kai heʻaheʻa i ka ʻili (song), wet by spray of sea, sea that reddens the skin.
See heʻa.
See HEAHEA. Warm, etc.; bald.
A calling; a voice of calling; aole nae i loaa ka heaheaia mai. Laieik. 91.
Lazy; loitering behind.
To give a name; to chant a name chant; to call a name in hospitable welcome; to call the roll; roll call; name chant.
Street name.
Heiau, Lahaina, Maui.
Street name.
Street name.
Corpse, especially of one slain in battle; victim, human sacrifice; carcass, remains.

example_txt.txt: he heana kanaka, he pihana kamaliʻi
a calling of people, a gathering of children

definitions.dtxt: Calling, as in greeting.
The dead body or corpse of one or more slain in battle. A carcass of any dead animal. See HE, a grave.
Human carcass, human sacrifice, an insulting name for kauwā, outcasts.
Street name.
Place where fishermen set a basket fish trap, as for hīnālea.
Exocarpus spp., native shrubs and small trees (sandalwood family), with more or less leafless, jointed branches. Also au 12.
Name of the place where fishermen set the basket in catching fish; the place was artificially built; alaila kukulu hou i mau heau—ma ka hema o ka mokupuni, me ke kukulu heau no.
Street name.
A term or space of seven days; a week a space of seven years.
Octopus (Polypus sp.), commonly known as squid.

example_txt.txt: octopus given for sickness caused by sorcery, as octopus (heʻe) would cause the sickness to flee (heʻe) or spread out (mahola)

definitions.dtxt: To slide, surf, slip, flee. Cf. heʻe nalu, pūheʻe. See ex., puʻe one.

example_txt.txt: ʻO ka mea i hilinaʻi aku iāia, aʻole ia e heʻe.
He that believed did not make haste.

definitions.dtxt: To cause to slip, slide, flee; to put to flight, rout.
To melt, flow, drip, soften; to skim, as milk. Cf. heʻeheʻe, heheʻe.
To hang down, as fruit; to sag; to bear breadfruit. See ex., ule 1.
Line that supports the mast, stay.
The squid, from his slippery qualities.
The rope that supports the mast; a stay.
A flowing, as of blood or other liquid.
A flight, as of a routed army.
A bloody issue. catamenia; he hee koko ka wahine; heeholua, to slide on the holua, a pastime among the ancients; heenalu, a playing on the surf-board.
To melt; to change from a solid to a liquid substance; to run, as a liquid; to flow, as blood or water.
To slip or glide along; to melt away; to play on the surf-board. Laieik. 91. See HEENALU.
To flee through fear; ke kaua ana, o ka poe i hee, makau lakou; to flee; to be dispersed in battle.
To melt; applied Fig. to the heart; to be fearful; cowardly.
To be disappointed. To dip up and pour out water; to skim off the scum, as cream, etc. See AUHEE.
Imperatively, hee aku paha, be off; go about your business; contraction perhaps for hele.
To skim, as milk. Waiū heʻe. Skim milk.
Squid (local definition); octopus (Haole definition). Cf. mūheʻe.
Street name.
To leach, i.e., the action of liquid percolating through layers of soil thus removing nutrients from the soil. Cf. hoʻoheʻeaholo.
To ski, in snow. See heʻe wai.
To bleat.
To bleat, as a goat.
Redup. of heʻe 2–4; avalanche (rare). hoʻoheʻeheʻe Redup. of hoʻoheʻe; to slide, slip.
Breast disease, with caking and great pain during nursing.
A boil; a sore emitting matter. See HEHE. Root hee.
An avalanche or pali slidden down; earth or dirt fallen down from a steep side hill.
The 13th conj. of hee. To flow or melt away; to disappear; to become liquid; to flee in battle; to dip up water with a cup. Hoo. To melt away, as an army; hence, to flee; to run.
A word used in enforcing the highest kapus.
To be filled with awe; to tremble with fear. See EEHIA.
See hōlua.
Hee and holua, a machine something like a sled upon which the ancients slid down hill; a pastime among the ancient Hawaiians. See HOLUA.

Land division and bay noted for surfing, Kailua qd., Hawaiʻi. This is probably the Heʻeia in the song composed for Kalākaua: Aia i Heʻeia lā, ka nalu e heʻe ai, there at Heʻeia, the waves to surf on. A holua sled course ended here. Village, elementary school, playground, land divisions, stream, and fishpond covering 88 acres, Kāneʻohe and Mōkapu qds., Oʻahu. During a battle with people from Leeward Oʻahu, a tidal wave is said to have washed (heʻe ʻia) the natives out to sea and back, after which they were victorious, thus fulfilling a prophecy. In ancient times, souls were judged here and divided into two groups: the white, who went to Heʻeiakea, and the black, who went to Heʻeiauli. Heʻeia is also the name given by the goddess Haumea to her foster child, the grandson of ʻOlopana. (PH 90)
Street name.
Land division, Heʻeia, Oʻahu.)
Land division, Heʻeia, Oʻahu.)
Name of a species of fish.
Flow of blood, hemorrhage, menstrual flow.
A flowing of blood; any great flow of blood; specifically, the catamenia.
A variety of large red octopus (Octopus ornatus); it was rarely eaten because of its bitter taste, but was sometimes used as medicine.
Name of a species of large squid found in the ocean, not eatable; he hee nui loa ia ma ka moana, he mea ai ole ia.
Squid beginning to decompose, with a pinkish color and a bad odor, liked by some.
Squid that has been cured with salt, and is red.
Ramp, as for skateboarding. Cf. alahiō.
To ride a surfboard; surfing; surf rider.
A playing on the surf, a pastime among the ancients; the name of their play on the surf.
To slide down the surf; to play on the surf-board. See below.
Street name.
Season when nehu fish run; to run in schools, of nehu. Ke kai heʻe nehu o ʻEwa, the sea of ʻEwa with its nehu schools.
The name of a species of small fish; he uahuki heenehu na ka lawaia.
Name of a misty rain observed off the coast of Hilo when nehu fish are running.
Each of two posts at the back wall of the ancient house, visible at the door.
A stroke in lua fighting.
An octopus settled on the ocean floor with tentacles spread out.
Tiny, young octopus that clings to rocks along sea pools, especially in certain seasons.
Street name.
To surf toward the mouth of a stream or up the stream.
A long-headed, long-tentacled octopus (Octopus ornatus), very tough, tenderized only by much pounding; now called the night octopus.
A fish of the squid genus.
Octopus slightly decomposed. Also heʻe mākole.
Body surfing; to body surf.
To water ski. Lit. slide (on) water. See heʻe hau.
Miscarriage; to have a miscarriage.
Hee and wale, only. To melt easily; to flee, as a coward in time of danger.

example_txt.txt: Waipiʻo is drowsy in the mist.
He hoʻopunipuni mau kō Kerete … ʻōpū heha.
The Cretans always lie and are … slow bellies.

definitions.dtxt: Lazy, indolent, drowsy; weariness following sexual gratification.
Lazy; indolent; slow in work; opu heha. Translated slow bellies. SYN. with ulana. Molowa i ka hana, manaka.
The upper calabash of a drum.
A kind of bird (no data). (KL. line 348)
Burst of laughter, guffaw; to guffaw.

example_txt.txt: Ka ʻaka hehē a ka manu a Kaiona.
The loud laughter of the birds [people] of Kaiona.

definitions.dtxt: To laugh; to mock; to deride.
A boil, running sore; ulcerous; botch, boils.
A swelling ulcerated on the skin.
Ulcerous; belonging to a boil; mai hehe.
Molten; that which has been cast.
See HEE. To run or flow out, as an ulcer or the contents of a boil.
Hoo. To melt or cause to become liquid, as metals by heat. See HEEHEE.

example_txt.txt: E heheʻe auaneʻi ka poʻe āpau e noho ana ma Kanaʻana.
All the people of Canaan shall melt away.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of heʻe 2–4; to slide, sag, fade; landslide, avalanche; soft, watery, melting.

example_txt.txt: E hoʻoheheʻe ʻoe i ʻehā ʻapo gula.
Thou shalt cast four rings of gold.

definitions.dtxt: To melt, liquefy, cast, dissolve, soften; to slide, especially to slide by jerks, as on a hōlua, sled, or ti-leaf slide.
Discharge, as of pus; fluid. He maʻi heheʻe, a boil.
To melt.
With mai, a running sore.
Hoo. Liquid; thin; flowing; melting.
To melt, as metals; to liquefy any solid substance.
To soften, as the heart; to make fearful.
Hoo. To melt and cast into any figure. To cause to be soft; unstable; e lewa.
To flow; to run, as a liquid metal; he pohaku i hoohehee wale ia no. See HEE.
Redup. of heheʻe 1, 2.
See Gram. § 225. A poetical form of the verb hee, to flow away, i.e., to fade, as the colors of calico; hehehee i ka wai, to fade by washing.
Redup. of hewa; a mistake by many.

Type of pāʻū (no data).
See HEI. To entangle in a net, as fish or birds in a snare.
Pas/imp. of hehei.
Redup. and intensifier of heleleʻi.

chants.chtxt: Ua wāwahia, ua nāhāhā, ua heheleleʻi ka papa i Pualei ē

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of helo; reddish, bright, showy. hoʻohehelo Caus/sim. Nā pāpale hulu manu like ʻole o nā aliʻi e hoʻohehelo ana i ka ʻōnohi o ka lā, the hats of the varying bird feathers of the chiefs shining brightly within the eyeball [sight] of the sun.
Hoʻohehelo Proud, especially of one’s appearance or dress.
To be like the helo or ohelo, a reddish brown; hence,
To be good looking; grand; proud.
Rouge, blush, as makeup.

Insane, raving mad, crazy, possessed; insanity, madness; lunatic, maniac. Kai hehena, raging sea. E hahau mai ʻo Iēhowa iā ʻoe i ka hehena, and Jehovah shall smite you with madness. hoʻohehena Caus/sim. ʻO kāna mau hana lapuwale, he mea hoʻohehena i ka noʻonoʻo maikaʻi, his wretched actions drive a sane mind mad.
A madness.
A mad person; hana iho la e like me na hehena ame na holoholona, they acted like madmen and brutes. See EHENA.
Insane; crazy; delirious; raving mad.
To be mad; crazy; insane.
Maʻi hehena. Maniacal delirium.
A swaggering or swishing walk; swishing, as of a skirt; to whirl, swish, strut. hoʻoheheo Caus/sim.; to swish, swirl; to swish up and down on the foot, as a child.
E peeaniki, e koheo, e pueo. Kamak.
Street name.

To stamp, tread, trample, pedal, step on; trampling. Fig. To repudiate, deny, desecrate, loathe, break (as taboo). Also hahi. Hehi ʻia, downtrodden. Hehi berita, to trample on a covenant. Kaʻa hehi wāwae, bicycle. Kahi hehi palaoa, threshing floor. Ka hehi ʻana i ka lā Kāpaki, desecration of the Sabbath day. Hehi nō ka mea māʻona i ka waihona meli, the person full of food loathes the honeycomb. Hehi i ka pili, to repudiate a relationship, as to in-laws after a spouse’s death.
A treading; a place for treading; kahi hehi palaoa, a thrashing floor where grain was trodden out.
To tread upon. To trample down. See EHI. With kapuai.
To put the foot upon, a symbol of subjection.

To trample upon, i.e., disobey or disregard, as a law; hehi na mea a pau maluna o ke kanawai o ka aina, everybody trampled upon the law of the land; hehi berita, to trample upon or disregard a covenant.
To loathe, as a full person his food.
Pas/imp. of hehi.
Redup. of hehi.
Misstep; to make a misstep.
To step firmly, stamp; to make a misstep and come down hard. Ua hehi ʻino ʻoia no ka huhū, he stamped his foot in anger.

To break rules or taboos, disregard the rights of others, trample on their rights, trespass; willful; trespassing, violation. Ka hehikū wale ʻia o kekahi ʻōlelo hoʻoholo, the breach of any regulation.
Street name.
Footrest; any place on which to step or tread; a stepping, treading.
To thresh wheat; threshing. Lit. tread flour (Eng.).
Rain name associated with Poʻokū, Kauaʻi.
A cob; a corn cob.
To uproot, dig up, put to flight, drive away, evict, shoo. E hehu aʻe ʻoia i ka ʻIseraʻela mai loko aʻe o kēlā ʻāina maikaʻi, and he shall root up Israel out of this good land.
Young seedlings or plants, as for transplanting; sucker. Cf. ilo 2.
A purge, as of water and juice of gourd stems used as an enema; to purge.
Ceremony to drive away evil influence.
Pile, as of rocks. (GP 100)
A tree pulled up for transplantation.
Mist; steam; vapor; spray from the sea. See EHU and HEHUKAI.
Name of a medicine.
To pull up by the roots; to root up.
To root out, as a people; malia paha i hehuia makou i poe nana e kuhikuhi i na iwi o ka poe kahiko, perhaps we shall be rooted up as those who shall point to the bones (land-marks) of the ancients.
To pull up for transplanting; to transplant.
To carry manure for the good of a transplanted tree.
To summon to work or to war; to warn out.
Seedling, as of ʻilima plants. See kauwowo.
See EHU. Hehu and kai, the sea. The spray of the sea.
He and huna, small particle, and kai, sea. The spray of the sea.
Street name.
Net, snare, stratagem, ruse; to ensnare, entangle, catch in a net; to festoon with leis. See kāhei 1, 2.

example_txt.txt: to infatuate, cast a spell, enchant, beguile; spellbound
ka hoʻohei ʻana i nā pua
E hoʻohei aʻe ʻoe i kānaka.

String figure, cat’s cradle; to make such. Many kinds are listed by Dickey.
Motion of hands and fingers, especially of the dying, (Some persons did not make string figures, hei, at night because of the association of the figures with the motions of death.)

example_txt.txt: Ka ʻike a ka makua, he hei na ke keiki.
The knowledge of the parent is absorbed by the child.

definitions.dtxt: Adept, deft; to absorb, as knowledge or skill.
Var. of hai, to sacrifice. Cf. haiau, heiau.
Water oozing from a cliff and trickling down. Cf. hī 2.
A net; a snare for entangling and taking an animal; applied to men.
A draught of fish. Luke 5:4.
Game caught in hunting.
A cat’s cradle. Bal.
The form of hanging greens about the house of the gods to render the sacrifices acceptable; i mea e hoohiwahiwa aku.
A wreath of green leaves. Fig. An ornament; o ke akamai o ka makuakane, e lilo no ia i hei na ke keiki, the wisdom of the father, it shall become a wreath for the child.
To entangle, as in a net.
To be insnared or entangled with difficulty.
To catch and entangle one by the neck or legs; i mea e hei ai ka a-i, ka wawae paha.
Hoo. To catch in a net. Fig. To entrap, entangle, etc.; ua makau au i ka mea kii mai ia'u e hoohei aku, I am afraid of him who shall come to entrap me.
Addiction; addicted.

example_txt.txt: Ua hei ʻo ia i ka paka.

definitions.dtxt: Same as mīkana, papaya.
A variety of sweet potato usually called ʻuala hēʻī.
Same as maiʻa Polapola, a wild banana.
The name of the pawpaw tree; also called mili.
Also the name of the fruit.
Pas/imp. of hei 1.
Piece of hair, tooth, fingernail, small bone, or the like of a deceased beloved, kept and offered food in order to please the spirit of the deceased.

Pre-Christian place of worship, shrine; some heiau were elaborately constructed stone platforms, others simple earth terraces. Many are preserved today. Several types are listed below. A heiau is a high place of worship. See hei 5. Hale heiau, house of worship.
A small secret room in the large temple.

A large temple of idolatry among Hawaiians; a temple for the worship of one or more of the gods; e kukulu oe i mau heiau no na akua, no Ku, no Lono, no Kane ame Kanaloa, build thou some temples for the gods, for Ku, for Lono, for Kane and Kanaloa.
The heiau was one of the six houses of every man’s regular establishment—the house for the god; eono hale o na kanaka, he heiau, oia kekahi, men had six houses, the heiau (temple) was one.
In the Bible, a high place of worship.
Land section, northeast Kahoʻolawe.
Heiau for treating sick.

definitions.der: [Lit. heiau for the increase of food crops]
definitions.dtxt: Heiau where first fruits were offered to insure further growth.
Heiau where fish were offered to insure good fishing.
Heiau where offerings were made to insure rain.

Heiau for stopping rain, or (less frequently) for bringing rain. One such heiau named Imukāluaua (rain-baking oven) was in the Kaunakakai quadrangle, Molokaʻi; a land section in Puna, Hawaiʻi, also has this name. Rain in leaf packages is said to have been baked in an oven.
Small temporary heiau covered with tapa stained green (maʻo), used for the hoʻoulu ʻai ceremony to bring food. (Malo 158)
Heiau where human sacrifices were offered. (FS 159)
A heiau used for services to bring success in war.
A servant to a prophet who reported his declarations.
Helper or apprentice to a priest.
Race, as foot race, canoe race, horse race; to race. He kanaka ikaika e heihei ana, a strong man running a race. hoʻoheihei To run swiftly, take part in a race, pretend to race, cause to race.
Redup. of hei 1–3; to festoon, drape. Cf. pāʻū heihei. hoʻoheihei To ensnare, entrap; to mend, as a net or wire fence.

To enthrall, enchant. Noho ʻoia mehe mea lā ua heihei ʻia, he sat like one entranced; enchanted; in a daze. hoʻoheihei Caus/sim.; to fascinate, flirt; to ward off possible sorcery by imitating the gestures of the kahuna.
Hoʻoheihei To beat, as a heiau drum; sound of heiau drum.
To run, as in a race; to run a race.
Hill, Kalapana qd., Hawaiʻi.
A race with the hoolua; a sliding down hill on a hoolua.
Relay race. Also kūkini hoʻoili. See maile hoʻoili.
Footrace.
Heihei and nalu, surf. A riding the surf in the way of a race between two or more persons; an ancient pastime.
A race between two or more canoes; practiced much in former times.
A sacred place, as one where a priest stayed in seclusion to await a message from the gods, usually a small house on the heiau. (UL 74)
Haiti; Haitian.
Red, sore, inflamed, bleary. Cf. heʻa, pīheka.
Sore; red, as inflamed eyes; eyelids turned out by inflammation.
Street name.
Redup. of heka.
Sore; red, as inflamed eyes; eyelids turned out by inflammation.
Street name.
Anchor, stone anchor, towline, line for fastening boats; warp; to anchor, make fast, tow; taut, stretched, anchored. Hekau o ka pōloli, the taut intensity of hunger.

To come upon, happen, befall, strike. Hekau auaneʻi i ka lae ʻaʻā, you will strike a rocky point [trouble]. He nui nā pōʻino i hekau aku maluna o kekahi poʻe, lots of trouble happens to some people. ʻO ka lanakila kiʻekiʻe i hekau iho, complete victory resulted.
A large strong rope for fastening boats, canoes, etc.
Epithet of a large strong rope; he kaula hekau; strong; firm.
To tie with a rope.
To make fast, as in anchoring a boat or cask, by tying to stones or rocks under water. Laieik. 124. Aole e lilo, ua hekauia.
Paperweight. Hoʻokau ʻia ka hekau pepa i luna o ka puʻu pepa i ʻole e puehu i ka makani. The paperweight was put onto the stack of papers so that they wouldn't scatter in the wind.
Fallen, as the countenance with shame.
Faded; wilted, as a plant.
Angry; cross; reluctant.
Best, greatest, foremost. See ex., manomano.

definitions.dtxt: Top gourd in a hula gourd drum. Cf. ʻolo 1.
Feathered top of an ʻulīʻulī, hula rattle.
Nail, pin, rack, as for hanging objects in a house.
Triangular sail, topsail. Also peʻa heke.
Shy, sensitive. Cf. ʻōheke.
Same as hekeheke. Cf. ʻuheke.
A nail or pin to hang things on.
One thing up over another; a sail drawn up over another sail.
Plump.
Weak; faint; destitute of energy.
Hike; to go on a hike. Sh. hele + keʻehi, also metathesis of keʻehi. Cf. holoholo wāwae. Ala hekehi. Hiking trail. Kāmaʻa hekehi. Hiking shoe. Mea hekehi. Hiker.
Hectare, a metric unit of land measurement. Also heketare. Abb. ht.
Plump.
Hakake, leilei, pokole.
Jet. Sh. hele + kikī. Mokulele hēkī. Jet airplane.
Redup. of hekili. Ke kau nei ka malu, hekikili i luna, a shade spreads, thundering above.
Thunder; to thunder. Fig. Passion, rage. See hakikili.

nā hekili o ke kuko ʻino
Ke hekili mai nei ke Akua nani.

definitions.dtxt: To cause thunder; threatening thunder storm.
A variety of taro.
A variety of sweet potato.
Art. ke. Thunder; a voice from the clouds.
Anything terrible, raging, terrific; uhi paapu mai la oia i na hekili o ke kuko ino. Laieik. 196.
To thunder. Hoo. To cause to thunder.
See manu hekili.
Point, Olowalu qd., Maui.
Street name.
Street name.
Street name.
Thunder without rain.
Hecto-, i.e., a prefix meaning hundred. Also pāhaneli. See entries below.
Hectogram. Abb. hkkal.
Hectoliter. Abb. hkl.
Hectometer. Abb. hkm.
Same as kuawa 1, valley. Malu hekuawa, valley shade.
A steward.
Grave.
He, a grave, and kupapau, a dead body. A grave; a place for depositing a corpse.
Redness of the eyelids; rawness, as of scraped skin; to be red or raw.
To spread, as the arms. Cf. helahela, kāhela.

Hula step: one foot is placed at about a 45-degree angle to the front and side, with the weight on the opposite hip and with that knee bent; the foot is then returned to the original position and the step is repeated with the other foot; to dance thus.
Redness of the corner of the eye; partial blindness; o ka paholehole o ka ili, helahela ino ka poe i hana pela.
Redup. of hela 1, 2; widespread.
Redness of the corner of the eye; partial blindness; o ka paholehole o ka ili, helahela ino ka poe i hana pela.

definitions.der: [Lit. a sky, or a royal chief]
definitions.dtxt: Area near Keauhou, Kona, Hawaiʻi; name of a Congregational church there. Ridge, Kamalō qd., south Molokaʻi.
Street name.
Street name.
To go, come, walk; to move, as in a game; going, moving; a gadabout. Fig. To die. Cf. hele wale, hele wāwae.

example_txt.txt: hele nō ā ka poʻe ʻōpiopio
extending even to the young people
This is your move [as in the kōnane game].
the path of the sun; circuit of the sun
E hoʻohele aku ʻoe i ka uaki.

definitions.dtxt: To cause to move, set in motion; to start, as a clock; to manage; to walk someone else or force oneself to walk.

He has become angry, fat, drunk.

[Bring] a fresh tablecloth, so that this room will be greatly improved.

definitions.dtxt: To become, get; like, in a state of, similar (frequently followed by ā).

example_txt.txt: to eat in an imitative fashion

definitions.dtxt: To imitate, pretend; imitative, pretending.

example_txt.txt: Hele ā pau kēia, ua hala nā makahiki ʻelua.
By the time that is finished, two years will be gone.

definitions.dtxt: When, by the time that (usually followed by ā).

example_txt.txt: to run here and there or continuously

definitions.dtxt: Following others bases, imparting idea of everywhere, here and there, continuously.

To tie, bind, lash, make fast; noose, snare.

example_txt.txt: Ua kama ʻia i nā kaula a i hele ʻia.

definitions.dtxt: To divide, cut apart. Cf. mahele.
A noose; a snare for catching birds. See PAHELE.
A going; a passing on; a journey; a course.
To move in any way to a large or small minute distance; the quality of the motion is expressed by other words.
To walk; to go; to move.
To act; to exhibit moral conduct.
To stretch, as a string or rope.

Hoo. To cause one to go or pass on. To desire or pretend to go on; to depart; aole nae e pono ia laua e hoohele wale i na pohaku hoohele; hele kue, to go against, as an enemy. Hele wale, to be or to walk about naked. See HELEWALE. Hele e, to go before; ke hele aku nei ke keiki, the child grows, i.e., increases in stature; hele liilii, helelei, to scatter; to separate. See the compounds.
Priest’s helper.
Pas/imp. of hele 1, 6. Helea kāua (Nak. 117), let’s go.
To put a noose around the head of a shark; i helea ka o kai o ka lani.

definitions.der: [Lit. snare by the sun (the hill blocks the rays of the setting sun)]
definitions.dtxt: Hill at Nānākuli, Waiʻanae qd., Oʻahu.
To go drifting along. (FOR. 5:509)
To flow like water. Ke heleāwai nei ke koko, blood flows like water.
The planet Uranus, formerly called Hershel for its discoverer, Sir William Hershel, in 1781.
The correct spelling should be Heleʻekela. See below. **
Uranus.
Redup. of hele 7; to cut up, divide; divided; filled with ruts, as a road.
Hoʻohelehele To help someone walk; to take walking, as a dog. Cf. hele 1.
See HELE. To go through; hence, to cut up; to divide asunder, as with a knife or shears. See MAHELE.
Redup. and intensifier of helei 1, 2.
Features, face. Kona helehelena maka, his face.
The external appearance of a person, his form, contour; especially the face of a person. With maka, the appearance of the face. Helehelena o ka poino, face of sadness. Laieik. 142.
To go wrong, take the wrong path, go astray, err.
To go suddenly, early, or for no apparent reason.
To tie or bind beforehand, as in preparation for a journey.
Hele and honua, preceding; going before. To precede; to go before; to do previously.
Hele, a noose or snare, and honua.
Younger brother or sister; descendant of a younger brother or sister; to go behind.
To straddle. hoʻohelei Caus/sim. Noho hoʻohelei i ka ʻūhā, to sit with legs stretched far apart [considered indecent].

Stretched sideways, as the mouth; pulled down, as an eyelid with a finger (these were signs of contempt); inflammatory disease of the eye with a drawing down of the lower lid. See saying, maka helei. hoʻohelei To pull down, as the eyelid; to stretch, as the mouth.
Inflamed; opened, as the eye, so as to turn the lid out; he maka helei, an inflamed eye.
To open or spread open, as the legs; to straddle. See KUHELEI. A specific word, and rather indelicate.
To say no by a signal, that is, by pulling down one corner of the eye slyly.
To go from house to house, gad.
Heretic.
Hele and kikaha.
To act in ignorance of what is doing; to walk in obscurity.
To wander a long way off; a proverbial expression, mai noho a helekikaha aku, act not without object. See KIKAHA.
To go quickly, fast.
See KIKI. To act hastily; to do quickly; to go in a hurry.
Walkathon. Comb. hele +
Helicopter. Niʻihau. Also mokulele helekopa.
To walk upright, wade.
To go by fits and starts, jerk.
Street name.
Herald.

To go freely, i.e., to have freedom to go wherever one pleases, to have the run of the place. He hele lanakila wale nō mākou i kō mākou noho ʻana i ke kākela o ke keiki aliʻi. We were given the run of the house while we stayed at the castle of the prince. Trad. (20,000 Lekue ma Lalo o ke Kai). Cf. noa.
Quick-bearing kind of sweet potato. (KAM. 76:27)

definitions.der: [Probably PPN felelei, a reciprocal derivative of lele]
definitions.dtxt: Falling; scattered, as rain, tears, grain; crumbling, as the earth; dilapidated; to shed, as a dog’s hair. Cf. heheleleʻi. Mea heleleʻi, small change [money]. I kāna lūlū ʻana, heleleʻi ihola kekahi ma kapa alanui, in his sowing, some fell by the wayside. hoʻoheleleʻi To scatter, sow; to fall, as rain. Ke hoʻoheleleʻi mai nei, it’s beginning to rain.
Scattered; dropping or falling, as tears; halawai oia me kana keiki me ka waimaka helelei, she met with her son with flowing tears.
Broken or crumbled, so as to separate. Crumbling, as dirt; he lepo helelei.
Hele and lei, to throw away.
To scatter, as any small articles; to spill, as water.
To distill, as dew, i.e., to fall upon one, as music or a speech.
To slaver with one’s spittle.
To scatter, i.e., to fall, as seed sown. Hoo. To cast or throw away, etc.
Stream, Hāna qd., Maui. Probably.
Spacewalk. Lit. walk (in) space.

To go or come far; to go with no hope of returning. Haʻina ka puana, no ka lani hele loa, tell the refrain, for the king gone forever [song for Kalākaua, who died at San Francisco]. Kū ā hele loa, to get up and go without thought of returning [spoken in anger this can mean: get out and stay out].
Tract, Mōkapu qd., Oʻahu.
Street name.
To travel together, of two.

To go to a place for the first time or as a stranger. Ka hele malihini ʻana mai kēia ao aku a hiki i kēlā ao, going for the first time from this world to that world [the Hawaiian title of The Pilgrim’s Progress].

definitions.der: [Lit. many snared or many going. See Halemano]
definitions.dtxt: Stream, elementary school, reservoir, ditch, and camps, Wahiawā and Haleʻiwa qds., Oʻahu.
Street name.
Street name.
To travel in the mountains; mountain climber.
A rare native variety of dry-land taro, with dark purplish petioles and white corms; grown on Hawaiʻi. (HP 18, 32) Also piko ʻeleʻele.
To go ahead; older sibling, descendant of an older sibling, senior.
Da capo (musical term).
Street name.

example_txt.txt: In no time at all the work was finished.

definitions.dtxt: Going. (See idiom, oneʻā and below.)
Same as helehelena.
Greek, Grecian, Greece.
Greece; Greek, Grecian. See haʻuki Helene.
See hoʻohelehele ʻōlelo.
Get out! Go away!
Imperat. Hele and pela, thus; so.
Be gone; be off; get out; go just as you are; often more full; thus, e hele loa pela, get you gone clear away.
Hoo. To cast out; to throw away; to drive off.
Street name.
To go with, accompany.
Var. of hāleu.
A vulgar word for the welu used in wiping the fundament.
Halloween. Also lā hoʻomākaʻukaʻu. Pū heleuī. Jack-o'-lantern. Also palaʻai heleuī.
Street name.
Stone anchor, anchor. Huki i ka heleuma, to weigh anchor.
Hele, to move, and uma, to grasp.
The stone anciently used as an anchor to hold a canoe.
In modern times, an anchor of a vessel; aole i kuu ka heleuma o ka moku, the anchor of the ship was not let down. Fig.

Kinipōpō hele wale. Kill, in volleyball.
Hele and wale, in the condition one is in naturally. See WALE.

definitions.dtxt: To go about destitute of clothing; to be naked.
To be poor; destitute of comforts. See ILIHUNE.
To go or be anywhere without any fixed purpose; helewale mai nei au, I happened to come along here.
To walk, go on foot, hike; pedestrian. (Hawaiian pidgin ‘walk feet’ is probably a loan translation.)
Quick step, quick time; to go fast.
Halley. Ka hōkū puhipaka ʻo Hēli. Halley’s comet.
Street name.
Helicopter.
Introduced, sweet-scented heliotrope (Heliotropium arborescens syn. H. corymbosum). Cf. hinahina 3.
To face about; a military term. See HALIU.
Street name.
To move back and forth rapidly; jerky pushing or sawing motion. Cf. helohelo, hula helo, ʻilihelo, ʻōhelo 2, 3.
Ramrod.
Red, as ʻōhelo berries; rosy. Cf. hehelo, helohelo, ʻōhelo. Kai helo, a red sauce made of fermented shrimps, salt, and coconut cream.

Red as the ohelo berry; reddish brown.

Shot used in shooting birds.

definitions.dtxt: To count, number, compute, take a census, figure, enumerate, list, include, impute; to assess, as taxes; to chant a list of names, as of genealogy; including, counting, enumeration, census, list, rate, number, figure, total, inventory; statistics. Cf. heluhelu, huahelu, uē helu.
Caus/sim.; numerator, in fractions; a telling, explanation.
Arithmetic, score, reckoning, account; serial; volume (in a series); numbered.

To scratch the earth, as a hen; to dig with the fingers; to paw the earth, as an angry bull. See māhelu.

Even numbers and totals, without fractions.

Factor, as in arithmetic.
Composite number.
Prime factor.

To read; to con over and over; to read in or from a book.
To recount; to make mention of some past transaction.
To proofread.
To take turns reading, read in turn.
Cardinal number. Cf. helu kaʻina.

To skim read. Comb. heluhelu + redup. of pākā. Ka heluhelu pākākā ʻana. Skim reading.
Abacus.
An arithmeticon, a frame with strings of counters, used as an aid in solving questions in arithmetic; a modern word.
Constant, in math.
Addend, in math.
Subtrahend.
Multiplier.

Census, a periodic official enumeration of a population and its characteristics. Ma ʻAmelika Hui Pū ʻia, mālama ʻia ka helu kanaka i kēlā me kēia ʻumi makahiki. In the United States, the census is conducted every ten years.

definitions.der: [Lit. number placed unevenly. See helu kaulike]

Even number.
Even number. See helu kauʻewa.

Upper division, as a course at a college or university. Pono nā haumāna e hele nei no ka kēkelē laepua e komo i loko o nā papa helukiʻe. Students pursuing a bachelor’s degree must take upper-division courses. Comb. helu + kiʻe. Cf. heluhaʻa. Papa helukiʻe. Upper-division course.
Transcendental number, in math.
Divisor.
Divisor, in math.
Multiple.
Rate of interest.

Zip code. See entry below.
