Prime number.
Prime number, in math. Helu kumu kūlua. Twin primes. Hua helu kumu. Counting number.
Combination, as for a lock. Cf. laka helu.
To skip count, in math.

Frequent-flyer number, as used in airline promotions. Inā e hoʻopihapiha ʻoe i ka pepa no ka helu lele pinepine, hiki iā ʻoe ke ʻohi i nā mile a loaʻa kahi kikiki manuahi. If you fill out the frequent-flyer number form, you can accrue miles until you get a free ticket.
Roman numeral.
Double number; dual number, as in grammar.
Double number, same number used twice, in math. Cf. kaulua.
Multiple, in math. Also māhua. Helu māhua like. Common multiple. Helu māhua like haʻahaʻa loa. Least common multiple.

Carbon dating, radiocarbon date. Ma ka helu makahiki kalapona ʻana, hiki ke ʻike ʻia ka wā i paʻa mai ai kekahi pōhaku a i ʻole ka wā i hana ʻia ai kekahi mea koehana. By carbon dating, the time a rock was formed or the time an artifact was made can be determined.
Time, recorded duration; to time, as speed, duration, etc. He aha kou helu manawa ma ka holo kikī haneli ʻīā? What was your time on the hundred-yard dash? Lit. count time. Cf. helu uaki. See uaki.
Real number, in math.

Old land division near the Royal Hawaiian Hotel at Helumoa Street, Waikīkī, and site of a heiau where Kahahana was sacrificed. (Chickens scratched to find maggots in the victim’s body. The supernatural chicken, Kaʻauhelemoa, flew here from Kaʻau Crater in Pālolo. li 17, 93.)
Street name.
Imaginary number, in math. Cf. helu hapa moeā, helu maoli.
Number, count, total sum, amount; grade or mark (evaluation). He aha ka heluna o kāna poʻe moa? What is the total number of his chickens?
Helu and ana. Gram. § 34.
A numbering, counting, etc.; hence,
A number, i.e., the result of counting. Ua like ka heluna o kona mau niho me ko ka lio, the number of his teeth is like that of a horse.
Amount. Also helu. See helu heluna.
Mental arithmetic.
Mental math. Lit. mind counting. Also makemakika naʻau.
Atomic number. See huna ʻāne.
Demand, i.e., a desired commodity within the consumer’s ability to pay. Hoʻolako me ka heluna makemake. Supply and demand.
Grade or mark, as in school; number of a grade (class), enumeration.
Large number; plural number.
Exclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
Inclusive plural, as in Hawaiian grammar.
Mixed number, in math, as 3 3/4. Lit, mixed number.
Whole number.
To count down, as in launching a rocket; countdown. Lit. lift-off count.
To count by, as helu pālua, to count by twos; helu pākolu, to count by threes; helu pāʻumi, to count by tens.
Counting game with chants; to play this game.
Odd number.
To count ballots; election teller.
Heart rate, pulse rate.
To count or recite in order or consecutively.
Whole number or integer, in math. Helu piha ʻiʻo. Positive integer. Helu piha ʻiʻo ʻole. Negative integer.
List of the nights of the moon in the old Hawaiian calendar; to count the nights.
Perfect number.
Quotient, in division.
Quotient.
Irrational number, in math. Helu puʻunaue koena ʻole. Rational number.
Composite number.
To tell time. Also helu uāki. Cf. helu manawa.
Inventory.
Hotline.
To speed read. Cf. kāwawe.
definitions.notes: Note: Written as one word.

definitions.dtxt: Abbreviation used in surveying for hema, south.
Street name.
Left, left side.
South, southern.

Left; applied to two opposite things; as, lima hema, the left hand, in distinction from lima akau, the right hand; welau hema (in geography), the south pole; opposed to welau akau, the north pole; kanaka lima hema, a left-handed man.
definitions.notes: Note: In marking the cardinal points of the compass, a Hawaiian will place himself back to the east and his face to the west; hence, his right indicates the north and his left the south.

definitions.dtxt: South. Abb. Hm. Kōʻai hema. Counterclockwise. Poepoe hapa hema. Southern hemisphere.
Place, ʻĀina Haina, Honolulu.
Awkward, clumsy, unskilled, inexpert, incompetent, unprepared, inefficient, inexperienced; lack of skill; to not know well.

He was most neglectful of the teachings of the grandparents.
a bailer left unnoticed [a skilled person whose services are not used]

definitions.dtxt: To neglect, not care for; careless, negligent, defective, deficient, ignorant.
Want, need, necessity; lacking, destitute, needy. Ua hemo nā hemahema, the needs are met.
Want; need; necessity.
See HEMA. Left-handed; hence,
Awkward, as a left-handed man; un-skillful; inexpert.
Hoo. Dull of apprehension; ignorant.
Wanting; lacking; destitute.
See HEMA. To be destitute of; to want. I makaukau ko oukou hoi ana, aole e hemahema, that you may be supplied on your return and not be destitute.
Hoo. To make destitute; to deprive of; pehea kakou e hoohemahema nei i ko kakou ola? how are we depriving ourselves of our living?
Street name.
Hemlock.
Street name.
Loose, separated, untied, unfastened, open, satisfied (see ex., hemahema 2), discharged, divorced, opened, weaned; taken off, as clothes. Cf. puhemo 1,)

The store is open in the evening.

hoʻohemo i ka ʻono o ka lama

definitions.dtxt: To loosen, undo, unfasten, disconnect, take off, set at liberty, liberate, free, abort.
Var. of ʻōhemo 1, weak, feeble. Cf. puhemo 2.
A loosening; a separation of things once united; ua like ka hemo me ka makili.
Loose; separating.
To loosen; to untie, as a rope; to cast off.
To come out; move away; depart; to turn off, as a tenant; to dispossess of one’s land.
To loosen, i.e., to sail, as a vessel; to set sail.
To break loose from restraint or confinement; to break over a boundary.
To break off a habit; to wean, as a child; i hemo ke keiki i ka waiu, let the child be broken off from the milk, i.e., weaned.
Hoo. To loosen, etc.; to put away, i.e., divorce, as married persons; he wahine i hoohemoia. See OKI and HOOKI.
Open, as for business; unlocked; ajar. See entry below and hāmama.
To be open, as for a play in basketball. See hoʻohemo.

definitions.dtxt: Faint, scanty, feeble, hungry, gasping, as of one near death.
Hemo and e, strangely, i.e., very much. Faint; hungry; gasping; near dissolution of soul and body; dying; hemoe ke aho, the breath is very loose. See E.
Redup. of hemo 1; separation, loosening. hoʻohemohemo Caus/sim.; to take off.
A separating; a going off; a loosening.
Freq. of hemo. To loosen often or very much.
To be weak from fear; to be unfastened.
Hoo. To take away; to separate; to take off.
Hemo and lea, joy; cheerfulness. To consent cheerfully to one’s going for, or doing a thing; to bid him God speed; ka ae pono ia aku; ka hele ana aku me ka pono.
Street name.
Perfect, faultless, flawless, holy, immaculate, saintly, pure in heart; complete; perfection, virtue, goodness, holiness; angel, person without fault.

definitions.dtxt: Without restraint.
The perfection of a thing.
Virtue; holiness. A separation from what is evil; goodness; a state of glory.
Perfect; faultless; holy; complete.
Hemo, to loosen, and lele, to jump or fly off; to be separate from some other thing; hence,
In a natural sense (the defect of a thing is supposed to have been separated), to be complete; perfect; fully finished.
In a moral sense, to break or separate from what is wrong or evil. In this passage the lele is evidently used as the intensive of hemo, i.e., to be entirely separated.
To be perfect; lacking nothing; completed, as a work. Also in a moral sense.
To be perfect in moral rectitude. To be holy; perfect.
Hoo. To perfect; to finish.

Shoo, be off, scat (perhaps from move). hoʻohemū To drive off, scare away, as hens.
To scare or drive away, as fowls, pigs, etc.
To sound indistinctly, as a voice. Ka leo o ka lawaiʻa e hemuwā mai ana, the indistinct voice of the fisherman.

Buttocks; mons pubis; hollow of the thigh; nakedness. E wehe ʻia auaneʻi kou hena, your nakedness shall be uncovered. hoʻohena To see, feel, or handle the hena; to take off one’s clothing and expose the hena.
The hollow of the thigh. The buttock; the nakedness of a person. The place of the kauha intestine. Anat. 52. The mons veneris.
Var. of henehene 1.
Redup. of hena.
See HENEHENE.
See HEENALU.
Street name.
Mons pubis.
Slope, as of a hill. ʻIke ʻoe i ka nani a ʻo Himela, ka hene waiʻolu lawe mālie (song), you see the beauty of the Himalayas, gentle slopes that become so calm [note hene 1 for alternate translation].
Same as henehene; to snicker. Cf. pūhene 1. Hene iki, to laugh a little, giggle, snicker. Hene ka ʻaka, to giggle. hoʻohene Same as hoʻohenehene, to tease.
Var. of kīhene, basket.
A bundle, as of potatoes or other things done up for carrying. See KIHENE.
To laugh at; to mock; to deride. See HENEHENE.

To laugh at, ridicule, mock, tease, snicker, giggle; mockery, laughter. Henehene kou ʻaka, kou leʻafeʻa paha (song), your laughter is merry, perhaps your gaiety. Ua henehene aku iā ʻoe, has despised you. Ua henehene mai iā ʻoe ka mea lohe. lest he that hears put you to shame. hoʻohenehene To tease, laugh at, jeer, banter, ridicule.
Redup. of hene, slope. (KL. line 545)
Disdainful; foolish; insipid; aka, i ka poe hewa, he mea henehene ia e lakou ka nani o ke Akua.
To laugh in derision; to mock; to treat a person or thing with contempt.
To cast off and forsake as worthless or contemptible.
To be secretly pleased when another falls; applied to wicked men when a good man falls into sin. With the passive heneheneia, to be the subject of ridicule.
Hoo. To laugh scornfully; to reproach. E henehene mai ka make ia lakou, death mocks them.
Mockery; contempt. Superciliousness; haughtiness.
Street name.
Continental slope. Cf. holopapa mokuhonua.
Inner side of the thighs where they join the body on either side of the genitals; groins.
See NIPOA. Feeble; debilitated; weak.
Street name.

Same as henoheno. hoʻoheno To cherish, love, caress; affectionate, demonstrative of affection; expression of affection, as a song. Hoʻoheno hoʻi kēia wahi keiki, this little child is so affectionate. Nona nei hoʻoheno, this song is for him.
Hoʻoheno Decorative plaiting on mat, fan; to decorate thus.
Street name.
Street name.
Lovable, sweet. hoʻohenoheno. Caus/sim.
Street name.
To anoint, etc. See HINU.
Pilina henua. Relative location, in geography. Cf. kuhikuhina.
Shining; glittering; polished.
See HINUHINU. To be smooth; to be polished.
To be shining.
Knob of any kind, as of a door; end of the penis, prepuce. Cf. pūheheo; pūheoheo 2.
To depart in haste. I ʻaneʻi iho nei ʻo Kū ā ua heo aku lā, Kū was here and departed quickly.
Proud, haughty (less common than haʻaheo). Cf. heheo. hoʻoheo Proud, vaunting, vain; to show off, boast.
The semen masculinum; e olu ka puu, i olu ka heo?
Proud; haughty; used mostly with the causative haa. See HAAHEO and HOOHEO.
To be in haste, as an assembly to disperse.
Street name.
Same as heo 1, and pōheoheo, knob. Eia kāu ʻo ka heoheo, so much for you, a knob [a curse, usually accompanied by a vulgar gesture imitative of the genitalia].
The glans penis; applied to men and to some animals; within the prepuce; loaa ka heoheo.

Artistic, i.e., esthetically appealing or having artistic talent. Ua heona kāu mau kiʻi; he kanaka heona maoli ʻoe. Your pictures are esthetically pleasing; you're really an artistic person. Cf. hoʻoheona, pāheona.
To be in haste, as an assembly to disperse.
To be in haste to go, as one afraid or not welcome.
To be in doubt what way to go.
Street name.

Idiot, moron, imbecile; partial paralysis of the vocal organs causing indistinct articulation; feebleminded, moronic. Hepa ka ʻōlelo, indistinct speech; to make a slip of the tongue. hoʻohepa Caus/sim. ʻŌlelo hoʻohepa, idiotic talk; to mispronounce or misconstrue language.
A shaking of the limbs; the palsy; a sitting in silence.
Mischievous; false; lazy; nani ke kanaka hepa.
Redup. of hepa. hoʻohepahepa Caus/sim.
A person so diseased that he cannot help himself; applied to the palsy.
Street name.
See PANOA. Dry and parched, as land.
Week; seven years. Cf. pule.
Hebrew.
A Hebrew; a man of the Hebrew race. One of the descendants of Abraham; mostly used as an adjective.
Hebrew; pertaining to the Hebrew people. Also pertaining to the Hebrew language.
Street name.
Pale yellow, of the domesticated ʻilima flower. Also pia.
See PUE. A pushing on or along; the rapid flow of a current.
Herschel; the planet of that name. See Astronomia.
Heroin. Ua waiho aku ʻo Marvin i loko o ka haukapila no ka lapaʻau ʻana i kōna hei i ka heroina. Marvin was laid up in the hospital for treatment for his heroin addiction.
Witch. German. Nananana hese ʻeleʻele. Black widow, a kind of spider. Also nanana hese ʻeleʻele.
Herzogovina. Bosenia me Hesegowina. Bosnia and Herzogovina.

Down or fine hair, fuzz, loose fibers on certain fruits or leaves, quicksilver or mercury on back of a mirror, hairlike growths or spines on sugar cane stalks or cactus; fuzzy, downy; to begin to grow, as a youth’s beard or pubic hair; to sprout, of seedlings. Kū ka heu, piʻi ka heu, the fuzz bristles [anger]. Kuʻu keiki o ka lā heu ʻole, child of my beardless youth [Kamehameha’s term for his first child, Kaōleiokū]. ʻŌkalakala heu pānini, bristling with fine cactus spines. hoʻoheu Caus/sim.; to grow, sprout, germinate; pubescence.
Hoʻoheno a. To bleach b. Cap. Name of a strong wind threatening to be a gale.
Down or fine hair.
A youngster; a young man, from his down or first beard; kuu kane o ka wa heu ole, my husband from the time of youth (without a beard.) Laieik. 204.
The quicksilver on the back of a looking-glass; holoi lakou i ka heu o ka aniani, they washed off the quicksilver of the glass.
The work first done, the speech first made, the first movement in an affair.
The first shooting of beards in boys; he keiki heu, a child bearded.
To begin to grow, as the beard; he kanaka opiopio wale no, akahi no a heu.
Hoot, as of an owl; to croak, hoot.
Deep-throated sounds made in Hawaiian chants and prayers; to chant thus.
With a sharp break in pronouncing, to sing, as birds; to sound, as the voice of birds; to sound, as the voice of spirits with sweet sounds.
Fine bits of broken or ground glass; mercury on glass made into a mirror.
Redup. of heu.
Redup. of heʻu 1, 2.
With a sharp break in pronouncing, to sing, as birds; to sound, as the voice of birds; to sound, as the voice of spirits with sweet sounds.
To split, as a cane.
To treat one badly; to use harshly.
To act the villain. See HAUKAE.
Street, Makiki, Honolulu, perhaps named for a chief living at the time of Kamehameha (RC 312).
Street name.
Beautiful, comely, attractive. (AP)
Good.
Street name.
A reedlike grass, a bent grass (Agrostis avenacea, synonyms A. retrofracta and Calamagrostis forsteri), originally found in Australia, and now found through Polynesia; Panicum heupueo on Niʻihau.
Probable Hawaiian name for pili uka, a grass.
Street name.
Mistake, fault, error, sin, blunder, defect, offense, guilt, crime, vice; wrong, incorrect, wicked, sinful, guilty; to err, miss, mismanage, fail, mis-.

example_txt.txt: Ua ʻai hewa au i ka mea ʻono.
I ate the cake by mistake.
nā hewa i kūpono i ka make
Ua hewa ʻo Pua iā Kū.
E hele ana ʻoe i hea? E au ike hewa.
Where are you going? Just drifting aimlessly [said if one doesn't choose to answer the question].
to make errors in speech on purpose
Mai ʻai ʻoe ia mea, ua hoʻohewa ka ʻāina nou.
Eat not this thing, cursed is the ground for your sake.

definitions.dtxt: To cause one to do wrong, cause or feign a mistake; to blame, condemn. (Cf. the more common hoʻāhewa, to condemn.)

example_txt.txt: He hewa kā ʻoe ke kūʻai i ʻāina, loaʻa ke kahua paʻa?
Why not then buy land and get security?

definitions.dtxt: Is it wrong to? Then why not?
Offended, annoyed.

chants.mltran: ♫  Conceal the love, don’t tell, lest it be heard, and some people be offended.
chants.mltxt: ♫  E hūnā ʻoe i ke aloha, mai haʻi, a lohea ʻia auaneʻi, hewa kahi poʻe.

example_txt.txt: to look until one can see no more; to flirt with the eyes
to speak too much or hastily
E hea i ke kanaka e komo maloko e hānai ai a hewa ka waha.
Call the person to come in and feed until his mouth can take no more [hospitality].

definitions.dtxt: To the point of satiety; to be in great quantities; to do excessively. See ex., wai 1.
Error; wrong; sin; vice; often connected with ino and hala.
The fruit or consequence of sin, i.e., punishment; overthrow. He mau hewa lele wale, little vices that spring up of themselves and are not punished.
Wrong; improper; sinful; wicked.
To be wrong; to be in the wrong; to act or to be in error.
To sin, i.e., to go contrary to right; to transgress. To be viciously inclined.
Hoo. To accuse; to find fault with; to complain. See AHEWA.
To condemn; to reprove.
To be under a curse; to be accursed.
Erroneously; wrongfully; hele hewa, to go wrong; to miss the right way. Fig. To commit sin.
See entry below and hoʻoholo i ke kū i ka hewa, kaha pela hewa, keʻehi hewa, palena ʻāluna o ka hewa.

A great many, very, vast, in great quantities. He nui hewahewa nā mea nani a kēia home, there are many, many beautiful things in this home. ʻAʻole o kana mai i ka hewahewa o nā mea ʻai, there were boundless quantities of food.
Crazy, demented, wild, aimless; to fail to recognize. Cf. kala hewahewa. Kā hewahewa, he ua (FS 37), hit wildly, it’s raining [let the fight begin]. hoʻohewahewa To fail to recognize.
A mistake of one person or thing for another.
Derangement of mind from sickness.
Sullen silence.
Crazy; unsound in mind; mad.
See HEWA, to be wrong. To make a mistake; to commit an error; mostly used in the causative.
Hoo. To forget one’s appearance or name.
To mistake one person for another.
To be deranged in mind; to be silent and unsociable through alienation of mind.
Street name.
Logic error, as a message on a calculator display that shows an operation is not logical.
Abbreviation for hapa haneli (centi-).
To cast or troll, as for bonito, ʻahi, and kala.
Dysentery, diarrhea; to flow, hiss; to purge. Ka hī koko, a bloody flux. hoʻohī Caus/sim.; to purge.
A flowing away; a purging, as in dysentery.
The name of the disease called dysentery; he hi ka mai.
A hissing sound, as the rapid flow of a liquid; hikoko, a bloody flux. See HIKOKO.
To droop; to be weak.
To flow away, as the contents of the bowels in a dysentery; to purge.
To blow out with force any liquid from the mouth.
The passive termination of many verbs instead of ia; as, pauhia for pauia. Gram. § 48.
Desire, delight. Cf. hiamoe.

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻole i pau koʻu hia i ka nani o Hilo.
My delight in the beauties of Hilo is endless.
Ua mau ka hia a ka poʻe a ka hale e noho.
It was still the desire of the people of the house to stay.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
How many? How much? (Follows ʻa-, ʻe-, or pā-.) (Gram. 10.3)

definitions.der: [PPN -fia [see ilihia, kilohia] and PPN -sia [see ʻawaʻawahia, hulihia]]
definitions.dtxt: Pas/imp. (Gram. 6.6.3)
To make fire with the fire-plow; the act of making fire thus.
Shuttle or needle for making nets; to knot or fasten the meshes of a net; to form a network; to bind, as house rafters (FOR. 5:651).
A reflecting; the act of thinking.
The person who catches or entangles fish in a net.
Roving; unsteady; also entangled.
To rub two sticks one upon another to obtain fire. See AULIMA and AUNAHI. E hana i ke ahi me ka aunahi, a maluna iho ka aulima, alaila kuolo me ka anai ana i mea e a i ke ahi.
To reflect; to think.
To run about as wild; to strut about.
To entangle; to catch, as in a net; eha ai i ka upena.

Indisposed to sleep, wakeful, sleepless; insomnia. E hiaʻā ana no kona aloha, sleepless because of his being in love. hoʻohiaʻā To cause sleeplessness. He mea hoʻohiaʻā ke kope, coffee causes sleeplessness.
Sleepless; desiring to sleep, but cannot.
To lie awake; to be sleepless; restless while attempting or wishing to sleep; e hiaa ana no kona aloha, he was wakeful on account of his love. Laieik. 205. See ULUKU 2.
To be absent from one, as sleep; to be sleepless, as one troubled in mind.
Pleased with, delighted with; delightful, pleasing.

chants.mltran: ♫  Thought is delighted when inhaling your fragrance.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Hiaʻai ka manaʻo ke honi aku i kou ʻala

definitions.dtxt: To delight, enchant, entrance.
Strong desire; a desire which keeps one awake during the time of sleep; applied to the mind; o ka hiaai o ka naau.
Street name.
Greatly pleased or delighted, most delightful; appetite for delicious food.
Same as the more common hiaʻā. See ex., hana aloha.
Street name.
Faded, gray, hazy. Cf. ahia, faded.
Var. of hiehie. hoʻohiahia Caus/sim.
Goodness; honor; nobility.
See HIE and HIEHIE. To be honorable; to be honored; noble; to be respected.
Fading; transitory; soon done.
Redup. of hiʻa 1, 2.
See HIA, to rub two sticks for fire. To obtain fire by rubbing two sticks.
The recitation of legends.
A particular kind of mele or song.
The company of gods belonging to Pele; among the class called akuanoho.
To recite legends or fabulous stories. See HIIAKA.
Shuttle or needle for making a fish net, sometimes of bone.
Name of a place in the sea beyond the kaiuli, and inside the kohola.
The name of the fish caught in such a place.
Street name.

To cast for bonito; bonito casting. Pā hī aku, mother-of-pearl lure for bonito. ʻO ka hī aku ka lawaiʻa nui a ʻUmi-a-Līloa (FS 173), casting for bonito was the principal means of fishing of ʻUmi [son] of Līloa.
Hoo. To be greedy of food; to eat largely of all kinds of food.
Same as hiaʻai. hoʻohialaʻai Caus/sim. Koʻu nanea hoʻohialaʻai, my delightful relaxation.
To eat heartily.
Restless, furtive. Maka ʻā hialele (Kep. 184), staring, furtive eyes.
Street name.
Food offering to the gods.
To stir, as a fire; to signal with the hands.
Street name.
Well trained, skilled. ʻO mākou nā ʻōlohe āiwaiwa hialoa ma ka lā, we are the most wondrously skilled experts of the day.
Bald temple.
Same as ʻuhalou, a weed.
Street, ʻAʻala section, Honolulu.

Sleep; to sleep, fall asleep, asleep. Kona hiamoe ʻana, his sleeping. Holoholona hiamoe, sloth. Hiamoe i ka make, to sleep in death, die. hoʻohiamoe To put to sleep, lull to sleep, to pretend to sleep; soporific. Lāʻau hoʻohiamoe, sleeping tablet or drug.
Sleep; deep sound sleep; rest in sleep. SYN. with moe.
Hiamoe, the sloth, an animal of South America.
Hi, to droop, a, until, and moe, to prostrate.
To lie asleep; to sleep; to fall asleep.
To rest in sleep; e hiamoe i ka make, to sleep in death, i.e., to be dead. To die.
To fall prostrate, as if asleep.
A little sleep, nap; to take a nap.
To oversleep, sleep deeply; death, eternal sleep. Cf. moe loa.
Fast asleep; deep sleep.
To sleep well. E hiamoe pono ʻoe. Good night; sleep well. Also e hiamoe maikaʻi ʻoe; a hui hou i kakahiaka.
Street name.
Depression or hole, as under water. Hiana ulua, hole frequented by ulua.
Street name.
Stems by which tubers are attached to vines. (Kep. 99) Cf. ʻanakiʻu.
Street name.
Foremost, expert. He āiwaiwa, a he hiapaʻiʻole aku kēlā ma nā mea apau, he palena ʻole ka ʻike me ka ikaika, a wonder, a foremost expert in all things, unlimited knowledge and strength.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: E pepehi nō wau i nā hiapo apau.
I will smite all the first-born.

definitions.dtxt: First-born child; first born, oldest.
To have the privileges of a first-born; to act as a first-born; to treat as a first-born.

The first born of parents. See MAKAHIAPO. Panina, the youngest child, or mulihope; first of several children. In opposition to mulihope; me ka leo o na keiki hiapo, aole me ka leo o na keiki mulihope.
The first born of animals as well as of men. Hiapo is also opposed to muli or muli loa.
Equatorial Countercurrent, in oceanography.
To have an affinity for (something). Comb. hia- (to be disposed to) + ʻume.
Street name.

Attractive, distinguished, dignified, noble, becoming. Cf. māhie. ʻAʻohe hie o kēnā pāpale iā ʻoe, that hat is not becoming to you. Pau ka hie, no longer attractive. hoʻohie To make or cause to appear distinguished; distinguished, stately, regal; delightful.
To be good; excellent; grand; used mostly in compounds.
Street name.

Redup. of hie; superb. hoʻohiehie To beautify, make distinctive, beautiful, elegant; distinguished in manner or appearance. ʻO ke aloha … ʻaʻole hoʻi e hoʻohiehie, charity … does not act elegantly. Hoʻohiehie launa ʻole, showy, superlatively decorated, gaudy, gorgeous.
Hoo. Dignity in appearance; honor.
Pride; haughtiness; overbearing conduct.
Neat; tidy; good; lively.
Proud; haughty; o na mea hoohiehie ame na mea lealea.
To be excellent or good in appearance; maikai loa ke nana aku.
Hoo. To show a splendid appearance; hence,
To be proud; self dignified; haughty.
To be regardless of others; to act shamelessly or unseemly.
Street name.
Kind of soft porous stone used to smooth and polish utensils; it is harder than the ʻana stone, which is used on wood.
Hyena.
Speckled bird of prey.
A hyena.
Name of a species of stone, soft and porous.
Street name.
Obliquely, indirectly, sideways. (FOR. 6:495)
Street name.

To entangle, creep, spread, intertwine, intermingle; entanglement, web, snare. Cf. pohihihi. Hihi ka lani, intermarried, of chiefly families. Lāʻau hihi, vine. hoʻohihi To cause entanglement; to entwine, entangle.
A large-meshed fish net.
Hoʻohihi To take a fancy to, admire greatly, be enraptured with. Hoʻohihi ka manaʻo i ka nani o Kahana, the mind is entranced with the beauty of Kahana.
The running, spreading out, the entwining or creeping of vines, or a thick growth of vegetation.
A cause of entangling; an offense; a cause of offense. This last sense mostly in the form hihia.
Thick together, as grass; as vines; as men.
To branch or spread out, as vines, or as the limbs of a tree; to grow thick together; ka pikopiko, ua hihi; hihi pea ka lewa. Laieik. 168.
To be satisfied; to have enough.
Pāma hihi. Rattan.
Redup. of hī 2; to hiss.

Entangled, interwoven, involved, perplexed, hampered, rank, snarled, obscure and difficult to understand (Kep. 167); snarl, entanglement, kink, thicket, difficulty, problem, trouble. Ka hihia paʻa o ka nahele, the dense thicket of the forest. Nui nā kumu hihia ma nā maka, lima, wāwae. kino (ma ka hula), there are many sources of difficulties [immoralities] from the eyes, hands, feet, body (in the hula). hoʻohihia To get into difficulties, entangle, perplex, beset with trouble, complicate. Ka hoʻohihia ʻana o kēia kanaka iā kākou, this man is a snare to us.
Lawsuit or case before the court, trial, Cf. hihia kalaima, hihia waiwai.
A difficulty; a thing perplexed; a cause of trouble.
A thicket of forest; ka hihia paa o ka nahele. Laieik. 94.
Difficult; perplexing; troublesome.
That is, hihiia, pass. of hihi. To be perplexed; entangled, either physically or morally.
To be in a state of difficulty or perplexity.
To be lost by going astray; to turn this way and that for relief.
To be offended.
Hoo. To entangle; to be the cause of trouble.
To be entangled; to be led astray; to be the cause of evil to one.
To entrap one in his speech; to be offended.
Problem or difficulty, as in the plot of a story. See hopena holo.
Criminal case.
Street name.
A plant with small yellow flowers. (And.)
Name of a plant with small yellow flowers.

The swamp fern (Ceratopteris thalictroides), an edible, somewhat succulent fern, distributed through the tropics. It grows in mud or water, as around taro patches, in tufts about 30 cm high. The fronds are triangular and are finely divided into long, narrow parts. Young fronds are eaten with fresh-water shrimps. Also palai kahawai.
The name of a plant sometimes eaten for food.
The name of a species of fish.
Civil case.
Redup. of hihi 1.
To come or go, of many people. Cf. hiki 3, hihiki.
Redup. and intensifier of hina, to fall.
To tangle up, as a rope or string; to tangle, as the hair; ua hihia na mea a pau, ua hihikaeka ma ka leo mana; to tangle or perplex one in speaking.
Glaucus. Sh. hīhīwai + kai.
Redup. of hiki, to come, go.

chants.chtran: At last has come desire
chants.chtxt: ʻAkahi a hihiki ka makemake

definitions.dtxt: Same as kākalaioa 2, 3, kinds of brambles.
Name of a legendary koa tree on Kauaʻi that was said to have no trunk.
See Kahilikolo.
Net made of strong cord used for shark fishing. (Malo 213) Also kāhala.
Various sting rays (Dasyatidae) and eagle rays (Aetobatus narinari). Also lupe.

example_txt.txt: He nui ka hīhīmanu o kā lāua mau anaina hoʻokipa i hāʻawi ai.
Hīhīmanu nohoʻi nā hale kūʻai i nā mea kūʻai o nā mea like ʻole.
The stores are magnificent with all sorts of things for sale.

definitions.dtxt: Lavish, magnificent, elegant; elegance.
A Kauaʻi peak. (FS 75) See saying, keha.
Name of a large, broad, soft living creature found in the sea; it was forbidden to women to eat under penalty of death. See IHIMANU.
Peak, Hanalei district, Kauaʻi. (FOR. SEL. 75)
Street name.
Redup. and plural of hina, to fall.

example_txt.txt: E hoʻohihina nohoʻi ke kino i mua a i hope, i ka ʻākau a i ka hema.
The body sways forward and back, to the right and to the left.

definitions.dtxt: To cause to fall; to sway to and fro.
Entanglement, spreading. Cf. hihi.
Falls, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
Street name.
Soft whistling sound, gust or draft of wind; to whistle.
See also hihiʻo 5.
A dream or vision, as while dozing; to dream while dozing; to whistle or sough, as wind.
A vision. A dream.
See HIO. To sleep; to fall asleep.
To dream; e paa ka maka a ike ka uhane, to shut the eyes and see with the soul, that is, to have a vision.
To fall asleep again after waking.
To sleep soundly.
To blow; to rush violently, as a strong wind. See PUAHIOHIO.
Jungle, tangled thicket; entangled. Fig. Bewilderment, grief.
Spider web, cobweb. Maka hihi pūnāwelewele, dim, lifeless eyes.
Wild, untamed. hoʻohihiu To cause fear, frighten.
Rare, uncommon. Hana hihiu, unusual or rare work. Maka hihiu, a person of exceptional merit or lineage.

Wild; untamed; strange; unfriendly; unsocial; often applied to animals that have been once tamed, but have become wild. Hihiu is the opposite of laka, tame. Na holoholona hihiu ame na holoholona laka; he ilio hihiu hae, a wolf.
See HIU 3. To be wild; untamed, as an animal; to be wild and savage, as men.
To mistake in speaking, as one untaught.
Street name.

definitions.der: [PPN sisi, PNP sisiwai: cf. Samoan sisivai in Pratt]
definitions.dtxt: Endemic grainy snail (Neritina granosa), in both fresh and brackish water, eaten both cooked and raw. Also wī, if in fresh water.

example_txt.txt: a night for hīhīwai [a lucky time]

definitions.dtxt: A shellfish (Neritina vespertina). Also hapawai. See hūai 1.
A pelagic grapsid crab, probably Grapsus tenuicrustatus.
A tide in the high-tide zone.
The name of a four-footed animal living in the sea.

To hold or carry in the arms, as a child; to bear; to nurse or tend a child (Hawaiians did not carry children unrelated to them, and commoners did not touch a chief’s child; carrying a child symbolized love, kinship, and affection). Cf. Hiʻiaka, hiʻialo, hiʻikua, hiʻilani, hiʻilei, hiʻimoʻopuna, hiʻipaka, hiʻipoi, hoʻohiʻi Caus/sim.
Same as kūpoki, a plaiting process.
Tall, as cliff or mountain. Kuʻu kaikuaʻana o ka pali hiʻi, my older brother of the tall cliff.

To lift up; to bear upon the hips and support with the arms, as a child; to hold, as a child on the knees. To carry in the arms and on the bosom; ike ae la oia i ke kaikamahine e hiiia mai ana. Laieik. 10. To nurse; to tend, as a child. Kanik. 2:22.
Flats, east Lānaʻi.
Pas/imp. of hiʻi 1.

chants.chtran: O children of Hawaiʻi, sustained by the constant action of the cool Kalaʻiākea wind
chants.chtxt: E nā keiki o … Hawaiʻi, hiʻia i ka hana mau ʻia e ka makani anu Kalaʻiākea

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
First part of the names of the twelve younger sisters of the goddess Pele; the youngest and most famous was Hiʻiakaikapoliopele. See PH.
A rare variety of taro with bronze-red leaf and stem, used in medicine.
A variety of sweet potato.
A general name of the gods of volcanoes. See HIAKA. O Hiiaka ke akua i hookahe mai i ke koko ma ke poo o kona kahu.

Crater, Kīlauea, Hawaiʻi, named for Pele’s many sisters called Hiʻiaka, the most famous being Hiʻiakaikapoliopele (Hiʻiaka in the bosom of Pele), who journeyed to Kauaʻi to fetch Pele’s dream lover, Lohiʻau (PH). This name is spelled Heake on some maps.
A rock beyond the seawall (between the Kona Inn and the end of the wall) at Kailua Village, Kona, Hawaiʻi. (FOR. SEL. 14-15)
definitions.notes: Note: One of Pele’s Hiʻiaka sisters lived here. In one legend the stone is the shark form of a priest turned to stone in response to an enemy’s prayer to Pele. See Kaiwi

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
Carried in the arms, as a beloved child. Kuʻu lit i hiʻialo ʻia, my beloved child carried in my arms.
Nearby, in front. See ex., hiʻikua.
Street name.
Hook used for kala, a fish, and baited with kala, a seaweed.
Name of a species of fish-hook.
See HIKAU. To throw, as a stone at a person or thing; hiikau aku la na kanaka i ka pohaku, the men threw stones at them; similar to nou.
Street name.
Carried on the shoulders, as a beloved child.
In back, far. Hele ʻia i hiʻikua i hiʻialo, gone far and near.
Name of a star said to rise on the night of Hoaka and to vanish on the night of Muku in the month of Welehu.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: E halelū aku ʻoukou iā Iēhova, ē kō nā ʻāina apau, e hiʻilani uku iāia.
Oh sing psalms of praise to Jehovah, those of all nations, praise him.

definitions.dtxt: To nurse or care for, as an infant; to admire, exalt, praise, extol in poetry; praise.
Praise; exaltation; deference paid to one dignified.
Hii, to lift up, and lani, on high.
To nurse or take care of, as an infant chief.
To exalt; to praise; to admire. See HOOLANI and HOONANI.
To admire and obey, as a servant does his master.
Street, Tantalus, Honolulu. (TM)
Stream, Kāneʻohe, Oʻahu.
Street name.
To lift, carry.
Name of the highest waterfall in Hawaiʻi, and one of the highest in the world, with a vertical drop of about 300 m, at Waipiʻo Valley, Hawaiʻi. See Elbert and Mahoe, p. 49, for a famous song.

Falls, Waipiʻo Valley, Hawaiʻi. This is the highest free-fall waterfall in Hawaiʻi and one of the highest in the world, with a vertical drop of about 1,000 feet. The fall is now usually dry, as the stream is diverted for irrigation. (Macdonald and Abbott 174; for songs, see Elbert and Mahoe 49, 94; UL 120) Street, Pacific Heights, Honolulu.
Street name.
To carry, tend, and cherish a beloved child (lei).
Name of a star that rises and vanishes at the same times as Hiʻikua.
To bear a grandchild in the arms; to be a grandparent (a term of pride and affection). Ua hiʻimoʻopuna ʻoia, he has the joy of being a grandparent.
To care for a child; to instruct a child.
Aole no ia e hiipaka o ka wahine ke kane waiwai.
Street name.
Street name.
To tend, feed, cherish, as a child. E hiʻipoi ʻoe iā lākou ma kou umauma, carry them in your bosom.
Hii and poi, to protect.
To tend and feed, as a young child.
To feed and defend, as a chief does his people.
To take in the arms, as a child. To carry in the bosom, as a child.
To take care of and provide for generally; spoken of God’s care of men; ke hiipoi mai nei ke Akua ia kakou.
Redup. of hiʻipoi. Mālama pono ʻoe i kuʻu aloha, hiʻipoipoi ʻia ma kō alo (love song), take good care of my love, cherishing always in your presence.
See HIPUUPUU.
Abbreviation for hikina, east.
A prefix meaning self- or auto-. See entries below.
Same as hīkākā. E hele hīkā ana maluna o nā kukuluaeʻo, going unsteadily on the stilts. He au e hīkā ana i ka ʻāina, a current spreading about the land.
To tilt back, as the head. Hikaʻa lani, to look heavenward.
To stagger, totter, reel; spreading, as vines; unsteady gait.

example_txt.txt: Ka mea i ʻona, e hīkākā ana maloko o kona luaʻi
A drunken man staggering in his vomit.
Ā e hoʻohīkākā aku ʻoia iā lākou mehe mea ʻona lā.
And he makes them stagger like a drunken man.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
Bent round; curved; crooked.
Staggering; walking unsteadily.
To stagger; to reel in walking, as a drunken man. To stagger, as a man carrying a heavy burden.
To wander; to go astray.
Hoo. To cause to stagger, i.e., to walk in darkness.
Gibberish; to talk gibberish; to speak a foreign language, especially English.
A word used in the kaki or namu, unintelligible except to those taught.
Comb. hika- + piliolana. Autobiography; autobiographical. Moʻolelo hikapiliolana. Autobiography, autobiographical story.
To pelt, throw. Lāʻau hīkau peʻa (FS 93), blows hurled crosswise.
To throw stones at one. See HIIKAU. Hikau is perhaps the best orthography.
Name of an unknown person, used something like so-and-so, usually followed by mā. Ua lalau aku i kauhale o Hikaua mā (Kel. 134), [he] has wandered off to So-and-so’s house.

Name of the wife of the famous legendary navigator, Pākaʻa and of the coastal area, Molokaʻi, where she lived. She was lost during labor pains and her husband searched vainly for her, hence the saying applied to fruitless endeavors, Hikauhi i Kau-manamana, Hikauhi is at Kaumanamana [another place on Molokaʻi].
To no purpose; of no use, etc.; aia ko'u waa hikauhi ma Molokai; hikauhi oe a holo e ka moku; hele a hikauhi.

Coastal area, gulch, fishpond, and reef passage, Airport qd., south Molokaʻi. This was the name of the daughter of Chief Hoʻolehua and his wife ʻĪloli. She became the wife of Pākaʻa and mother of the famous Kūapākaʻa. (Nakuina 33; RC 37; Rice 77; Summers 63) See Kaumanamana. For meaning, see PE, hikauhi.
Similar to keʻa 1, 2. Na Pele ia hīkeʻa maila i Kīlauea, Pele blocked [the way] at Kīlauea.
Street name.
Names of cardinal directions, stars, and portions of the sky, perhaps because of movement (hiki 3) of the sun. See below.

example_txt.txt: no longer able to do; impotent
He can come; he may [has permission to] come.

definitions.dtxt: Can, may; to be able; ability; possible. Cf. hiki nō, hikiwale, hikiwawe, Gram. 4.4.
All right, O.K. (in sense of “able to do”), certainly, surely (used alone or preceding nō).
To get to or reach a place, come, arrive, approach, appear, arise. Cf. hikina. Ā + hiki followed by a word expressing time or place, is often translated: to, until.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻi maila ia ā hiki i Waikīkī.
He came back to [until arrived at] Waikīkī.
Ua paʻa ia ʻōlelo ā hiki i keia wā.
This story has been preserved until this time.
to happen suddenly, unexpectedly, by chance.
Ua hiki ka lā, aia i luna.
The sun has risen, there [it] is above.
to rush, come fast, speed up, expedite

definitions.dtxt: To cause to come, arrive, appear.

example_txt.txt: nā makahiki kanalima e hiki mai ana

definitions.dtxt: Next.

example_txt.txt: E hiki mai ʻoe i ka pakeke.

definitions.dtxt: To fetch, carry back and forth (less used than lawe).
To vow, swear, take an oath, promise; to administer an oath; vow, oath, promise, pledge. See ʻōlelo hoʻohiki.

example_txt.txt: firm oath; to bind under oath
a violent oath [such as pau Pele, pau manō, translated under manō]
He administered the oath to me
nā haole hoʻohiki a me nā haole hoʻohiki ʻole
foreigners naturalized and not naturalized [or alien]
make i ka hoʻohiki i kānāwai
Hoʻohiki ihola ia i ka hoʻohiki.

definitions.dtxt: To peel, pry off. See mahiki 5 and ʻōhiki 1.
To come to; to arrive at, as connected with mai or aku.
To be able to do a thing; to accomplish a purpose; to prevail. Hiki is often used with other verbs as a kind of helping verb. Gram. § 171.
Hoo. To cause to come; to bring forth; to produce.
To take an oath; to affirm a thing on an event as true.
To call or give a name to. To name or speak of with approbation.
To mention in one’s prayers. Pilem. 4.

To vow; to consecrate; to set apart; to promise a thing especially to a god; to set apart as sacred. Hoohiki ino, to desecrate; to treat with contempt; hoohiki wahahee, to swear falsely; to take a false oath. See HOOHIKI.
Kelepona kāki hiki. Collect call; to make such a call. ʻOhi hiki. COD, cash on delivery.

definitions.der: [Lit. to come or to be able]
definitions.dtxt: Street, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
To aim carefully, as with stone, spear, or gun.
Probably the same as ikiʻalamea, a disease.
Long-range, long-term. Comb. hiki + ā + loa. Papa hoʻolālā hikiāloa. Long-range plan, long-term plan. See papa hoʻolālā. I ka hikiāloa. In the long run.
Zenith.
The rising and coming to the zenith, as the full moon; i ka mahina hikialoalo.
Medium-range, medium-term. Comb. hiki + ā + lōpū. Papa hoʻolālā hikiālōpū. Medium-range plan, medium-term plan. See papa hoʻolālā.
Spittle passed from a dying master, according to the belief that his knowledge was thereby handed on. Naʻu kekahi wahi hikianakopili, give me a little knowledge [before you die].
Name of a star, described as medium-bright and near the equator; visible from April to September; used as a guide to mariner and fisherman.
Street name.
Short-range, short-term. Comb. hiki + ā + poko. Papa hoʻolālā hikiāpoko. Short-range plan, short-term plan. See papa hoʻolālā.
Life-long. Comb. hiki + ā + puaaneane.
A (luakini heiau where human sacrifices were made) of Kamehameha I at Kealakekua, Hawaiʻi; Captain Cook was received here as the god Lono; now a State monument. (RC 256 for text and drawing; UL 36)
Street name.
Kauaʻi name for the star Hikianalia.

definitions.der: [Lit. possible to mount. Maluna o kou hikieʻe, upon your bed]
definitions.dtxt: Large Hawaiian couch.
An approach of one; a coming near to.
A bridge over a stream.
A raised platform for sleeping; a sort of bedstead or couch; a place for a bed.
To approach to; to draw near.
To bridge over a stream.
Redup. of hiki 3; to come repeatedly, as voices. hoʻohikihiki Caus/sim.
Redup. of hiki 5, to fetch and carry; to fetch repeatedly or a little at a time. hoʻohikihiki Caus/sim.
Late, as registration for a conference. Lit. arriving after. See hiki mua. Kāinoa hiki hope. Late registration.
Binding, tying; to tie, bind, make fast. Cf. hīkiʻikiʻi, nākiʻi, mūkiʻi. Hīkiʻi ihola ia i kāna keiki iā ʻIkaʻaka, he bound his son Isaac.
To tie; to fasten by tying; to bind, as a person. To bind, as a prisoner; to tie, as a rope or cord to anything. See NAKII. To bind on, as a sandal; to tie up, as a purse.
A binding; a tying; a fastening.
Redup. of hīkiʻi.
See HIKII. To tie; to bind strongly.
Pas/imp. of hīkiʻi.
Name of a star; according to some, Sirius.
Name of a star. Also ʻĀikikauelono.
Street name.
The star Sirius.
To lean back, relax. Ua ʻia kāua e ka ua, hikikiʻi kāua i Kananā, we are rained on, let’s lean back and relax at Kananā [pun on kāua, we two, and ka ua, the rain].
To spread, as mist; to rain, especially a slanting rain. Hikikiʻi ka noe i nā pali, the fog slants by the cliffs.
Street name.
Portion of the sky immediately above the horizon.
Hiki and ku, to rise. The place of the sun’s rising; poetically, the east. See HIKINA.
Valley, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.

To jump or start from shock, to gasp; shock, perturbation. Hikilele aʻela ʻo Laʻieikawai, he moeʻuhane kā (Laie 523), Laʻieikawai awoke startled, but it was a dream. hoʻohikilele To startle, shock. He mea hou hoʻohikilele, shocking news.
A sudden coming upon; a rising up quickly; a sudden frig[illegible].
Hiki and lele, to jump; to fly.
To wake suddenly from sleep. To wake with affright.
To jump or start suddenly from surprise or fear.
To do a thing suddenly and in haste; to be weak with fear from any event.
Hoo. To wake up a person from sleep.
To come by surprise, as one army upon another.
Hoo. Quickly; suddenly.
Star name, perhaps morning star. (FOR. 5:119)
Street name.
West. Lit. come to rest.
Poetical name of the west; place of (the sun’s) lying down.
Ridge and valley, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
To come ahead or beforehand.
Pre-, early, beforehand, as registration for a conference. See hiki hope.
Progress, advance; to progress.
Street name.
East.
Orient.
Coming, advent.
East. Abbreviated Hk.
The full form is, ka hiki ana (a ka la), the coming (of the sun), i.e., the east; the place of the sun’s rising.
The eastern; ma ka aoao hikina o Hawaii, on the eastern sale of Hawaii.
Eastwardly.
Lane, Iwilei, Honolulu. (TM)
Place of refuge (puʻuhonua) near the mouth of the Wailua River, Kauaʻi; also called Hauola.
Northeast.
Southeast.
Middle East; Middle Eastern.
Street name.
All right, O.K., certainly, surely, it can be done. Cf. hiki 2.
Impossible, unable, can't or unable to do; inability, regrets.
To force one’s way, as through a crowd or undergrowth.
Wind name associated with Hālawa, Molokaʻi.
Street name.
Easy. He mea hikiwale nō kēia, this is easy to do.
Hiki and wale, merely. What has happened; come by chance; without design.
To come accidentally, alone, or without any particular purpose or reason.
Quickly, speedily, suddenly, prompt, quickly done; possible to do quickly; doubletime (military command).
To accelerate, hurry, hasten.
Sadr, a star.
Meaʻai hikiwawe. Fast food. Hale ʻaina meaʻai hikiwawe. Fast-food restaurant.
To do quickly; to be quick or smart in doing a thing. Hoo. To cause quickness; to make dispatch.
Quickly; speedily; without delay.
See KIWI. To crook; to bend.
Bloody dysentery, hemorrhoids; ulcers, emerods.
Hi and koko, blood. A flowing of blood; specifically applied to a disease of the anus called emerods. A dysentery; a bloody flux.
Tattoo brand on the forehead of a kauā outcast, or on the forehead of the caught seducer of a high chief’s wife. (See figure 1, Malo 70)
Name of a servant marked in the forehead; o ka poe kauwa i hoailonaia ma ka lae, ua kapaia he kauwa hikoni.
To pick, as an ʻukulele or guitar. Also panapana.
Seven, seventh (usually preceded by the numerical prefix ʻe). Cf. Nāhiku, the Big Dipper.
The seventh in order; i ka hiku o ka malama. Gram. § 115, 2, 4. As a cardinal, seven.
To throw aimlessly, carelessly.
Many. He hikuhiku nā kini akua, the hosts of gods are many, many.
Confusion of sounds. (And.)
A noise; confusion by many voices.
Street name.
Same as hilahila 1. hoʻohila Caus/sim.
Heel. Hila ʻauliʻi, high heels. Hila haʻahaʻa, low heels.
Hill. Cf. kuahiwi, mauna. Kaimana Hila, Diamond Head.

Bashful, shy, ashamed, abashed, embarrassed; shame, bashfulness. Cf. puahilahila. Kou wahi hilahila, your private parts. Hilahila ʻole, shameless, brazen. He maʻi nui ka hilahila, shyness is a great disease. hoʻohilahila To make ashamed or embarrassed; to disgrace, humiliate; shameful, bashful, timid. Hana hoʻohilahila, disgraceful behavior or acts. Hoʻohilahila nohoʻi ʻoe iaʻu, you've made me ashamed; I’m ashamed of you.
Same as iholena, a banana.
Shame; a blushing of the face; confusion attendant on shame.
Ashamed.
To be ashamed; to be put in confusion; to be ashamed of.
Hoo. To cause shame; to make ashamed.
To have that quick agitation which arises from shame; confusion, suffusion of the face.
Shamefully.
To exalt, praise.
A word used in the prayers of the ancients, meaning not very clear. See LANAHILAI.
Street name.

To reel, lean or tilt sideways. Ua hele ā hilala nā kia, kikiʻi ka peʻa i ka makani, the masts lean over, the sails tilt in the breeze. hoʻohilala Caus/sim.; to cause to swing back and forth; to lean over, tilt.
To bend; to crook; to bend from a straight line. See HIKIWI.
Dysentery caused by eating laulele greens; name of a famine during the sandalwood-cutting days when farms were neglected and the people lived on laulele greens.

Careless, shiftless (named for the people of Hīlea village, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi, reported to have brought poorly prepared poi to a chief). Hīlea i kalo ʻekaʻeka, Hīlea of the dirty taro [a saying applied to anyone careless or inefficient in work].
Lazy; indolent; doing nothing.
Village, gulch, and land division, Honuʻapo qd., Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi. (See PE.)
Land section below Makanau hill, Honuʻapo qd., Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
Land section, Honuʻapo qd., Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
To braid or plait, as a lei or candlenuts; a braid, plaiting, string. See lei hili. Ka hili ʻana i ka lauoho, the plaiting of the hair.

To turn aside, deviate, miss the way, wander, stray. Cf. hilikau, pūhili. Mea hili i hope, straggler. Ua pā hili, rain blown by wind in various directions. Mai hili ʻiʻo paha au inā ʻaʻole kēia kamaʻāina, I might have gone quite astray had it not been for this native of the place. hoʻohili Caus/sim.; to lead astray.
To whip, smite, thrash, switch, bat; batter, as in baseball; stroke, as in fighting. Mea hili kinipōpō, batter. hoʻohili Caus/sim.; to pretend to whip, to whip gently.
Bark used in dyeing, as hili kukui, hili kōlea, hili noni; the dark-brown dye made from this bark; a tapa dyed with hili; to dye with hili.
A general name for barks used in dyeing; as, hili kolea, hili koa, etc.
A black dye for coloring kapas made of kolea bark.
The principle of tanning in koa and other barks.
Turning; wandering aside.
To braid; to plait, as a wreath; to braid, as the hair. To string, as kukui nuts; e hili kukui.
To turn over and over, as in braiding; to twist; to spin; to tie on, as Hawaiians formerly tied or braided their kois on to the handles.
To deviate from the path in traveling; to wander here and there. To miss one’s way.
To droop; to flag. See MILO and WILI.
To smite, as with a sword or the hand.

To spike (the ball), in volleyball. Niʻihau. Also pākī. See kuʻi puʻupuʻu, pākī, paʻi pālahalaha, ʻai hele wale. Hili laina. Line spike. Hili ʻaoʻao. Angle spike. Manawa hili. At bat, up (to bat), in baseball.
Pas/imp. of hili 1–4. He kīʻoki o ke kīkākapu, ʻo ka iʻa kapu hīlia au ʻawahia, stripes of the kīkākapu, the sacred fish, smitten with bitter bile.
A native bird (no data).
Offshore area extending from Pākanaka Pond through Kalamaʻula, south central Molokaʻi. (Mullet were so numerous that fishermen kicked them ashore with the sides of their feet [kā wāwae].)
In devious ways; to ramble; be indirect. See ex., neʻikū.
Hili and au, current. To wander; to go astray morally; to do wrong; he ikaika hiliau, strong to do evil.
Var. of ʻilieʻe, plumbago.
A shrub having a powerful stimulant corrosive bark. See ILIHEE.
Four-strand braid; to braid thus.
Tangled, confused; entanglement, confusion; to become entangled; to trip or fall. Hili hewa ka noʻonoʻo, mental confusion. Hili hewa ka wāwae, to stumble, trip.
Redup. of hili 1–3. hoʻohilihili Redup. of hoʻohili.
Redup. of hili 4; dark red or brown (less dark than hili 4). Hilihili honu, turtle coloring Fig. Wealthy. hoʻohilihili To dye.
See HILI, coloring barks. To color or dye red, or any dark color.
Red or brown in color; shaded; dark.
Rich; wealthy.
Street name.
To grope here and there.

Mixed, snarled, entangled; to mix, snarl. See saying makau. Hilikau nā wāwae, to stumble. Hilikau ka noʻonoʻo, to have confused or bewildered thoughts. hoʻohilikau Caus/sim. Hoʻohilikau i nā wāwae, to trip someone.
Tripping in one’s walk; stumbling.
Varying in one’s story; e lauwili, e lalau.
Walking cross-legged.
To accuse much, and falsely; to say and unsay.
To hit carelessly, at random. (Gram. 6.5)
Same as Kahilikolo and Kahihikolu.
Var. of hihikolo 2, a legendary tree.
A three-strand braid; to braid such.
To lash against, whip. Makani hilikua ʻeʻena nā pali (song), wind lashing furiously against the cliffs.
Pali, pali trail and road, and peak (2,249 feet high), Kīlauea qd., Hawaiʻi. (Macdonald and Abbott 316)
Name of a star and of a Hawaiian month (same as Māhoe Mua: see month).
The name of a Hawaiian month; the tenth month of the Hawaiian calendar.
Street name.

To believe, trust; to lean on, rely on; trust, confidence. ʻŌlelo hoʻoholo hilinaʻi, vote of confidence. He aha kēia hilinaʻi āu e hilinaʻi nei? What confidence is this wherein you trust? Hilinaʻi Kaʻū, kālele iā Puna; Hilinaʻi Puna, kālele iā Kaʻū (saying), Kaʻū is dependent, supported by Puna; Puna is dependent, supported by Kaʻū [Kaʻū and Puna depend on one another, said also of persons who do so].
Trust; confidence; a leaning against or upon.
What is leaned upon, as a table; a bed or place for reclining.
Hili and nai, to strive for.
To lean upon; to lean against.
To trust in; to have confidence in one’s word.
Street name.
Name of the eleventh month (Molokaʻi) eighth (Kauaʻi), or tenth (Alexander); same as Māhoe Hope. Cf. alanui.
Name of the ninth month among Hawaiians.
Same as Hilina Ehu.
Name of the eleventh Hawaiian month.
Street name.
The name of the eighth month.
Same as heliokalope, heliotrope.
Square braid of eight or sixteen strands. (And.)
Ailment of the bowels or stomach, accompanied by gas pains. (And.)
A square braid of eight straws.
A sickness of the bowels; sickness of the stomach; fullness of the stomach.
Four-strand braid; to braid such.
Three-strand braid; to braid such.
To wander or grope aimlessly in the dark.
Street name.
Sound or call of a wind instrument, as the conch shell. hoʻohiliu To blow a conch or wind instrument.
The voice of a shell or trumpet; the sound of one blowing a wind instrument.
Helium.
Street name.
To twist, braid, spin; twisted, braided; threadlike; faint streak of light. See lei hilo.

example_txt.txt: Ua hilo ʻia i ke aho a ke aloha.
Braided with the cords of love.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
First night of the new moon. See Malo 35.
Name of a famous Polynesian navigator for whom the city and district may have been named. See sayings, Hilo (Eng.-Hawaiian)
Same as mauʻu Hilo, Hilo grass.
Gonorrhea; a running sore.
A variety of sweet potato.
See iwi hilo.
The name of the first night in which the new moon can be seen, as it is like a twisted thread; o hilo ka po mua no ka puahilo ana o ka mahina.
An issue; a running sore.
Spun; twisted. Iwi hilo. Anat. 16.
To twist, as a string on the thigh; to twist with the thumb and fingers.
To spin; to turn, as in twisting. See HILI, MILO, WILI, etc.
Aʻa kino hilo. Femoral vein. Aʻa puʻuwai hilo. Femoral artery. Iwi hilo. Femur, i.e., the long bone of the thigh.

City (1970 populalion 26,353), bay, district, harbor, golf courses, schools, and ancient surfing area (Finney and Houston 26), Hawaiʻi. Three sections of Hilo town are: Hiloone (sand Hilo), near the sea; Hilo-Hanakahi, an inland section toward Keaukaha, named for a chief famous in song (Elbert and Mahoe 50; PH 27); and Hilopalikū (Hilo of the upright cliff), east of the Wailuku River (PH 29). (See PE, Kanilehua.) Perhaps named for the first night of the new moon or for a Polynesian navigator. Forest reserve in Hilo and Hāmākua districts; trail in Hilo and Puna districts. (For a saying, see Appendix 8.1) Street, Wilhelmina Rise, Honolulu, named for Hilo crab grass (TM).
To lengthen a speech or story by inserting new matter; to embroider or spin out a tale.
Sweet juice of ti root. (And.)
The sweet juice of the ki root, especially when there is but little and very sweet.
See HILO.
Ancient surfing area, Lānaʻi. (Finney 53)
Street name.
Street name.

Various species of reef fishes of the genus Coris. The name hilu may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, lauwili, melemele, moelola, pano (probably same as uli), pāniʻo, pilikoʻa (Paracirrhites forsteri), hawkfish), ʻula, uli. See saying, noʻenoʻe 2.
Quiet, reserved, well-behaved, decorous, unobtrusive, easygoing; such a person (a child born to a woman who craved hilu fish during her pregnancy was thought to be of this desirable type).
Strange.
Name of a species of fish, spotted, variegated with colors.
Still; quiet; reserved; dignified; a word of commendation; hilu ka noho ana o mea.
Neat; elegant; powerful; magnificent.
Street name.
Elegant, beautiful. hoʻohiluhilu To beautify, bedeck, decorate. Hoʻohiluhilu kula, golden finery, jewelry.
See HILU. The excellent; the glorious; the powerful.
Excellent; nice; beautiful.
Himalayas. See song, hene 2.
Street name.
Hymn, any song not used for hulas; to sing a hīmeni.

example_txt.txt: Ā hīmeni aku ka poʻe hīmeni.

definitions.dtxt: From Gr. A hymn; a song in sacred worship; a mele in praise of Iehova.
From Gr. To hymn; to sing a hymn.
To sing in harmony.
Vocal solo.
Trio (musical).
Street name.

To fall, tumble, or topple over from an upright position (cf. hāʻule, to drop); to be “controlled,” as a disease (KAM. 64:102); to fall morally; to throw down; a falling (a loaʻa-type word; see Gram. 4.4).

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻole naʻe he hina o ke kanaka o Kākuhihewa i nā kaikuaʻana o Kawelo.
But the older brothers of Kawelo did not throw Kākuhihewa’s man.

definitions.dtxt: To throw, cause to fall, knock down; to lean over.
Italics, probably so called because italics slant.
To blow in a straight course, of wind. Ke hina maila ka makani mai uka mai, the wind is now blowing steadily from the uplands.
Gray- or white-haired; gray. Cf. ʻāhina.
Hin (a Hebrew measure).
A goddess.
Name of a goddess. See HINAHELE.
A hin, a Hebrew measure.
A leaning; a falling; a causing to fall; a stumbling.
Gray; hoary; applied to the head; oho hina. Gray, as the beard; he umiumi hina.
To lean from an upright position. To fall; to fall down, as a house. To fall morally, as a person from a state of uprightness; to relapse or decline from a state of rectitude.
To slant over; to throw down, as a person.
To offend; to be offended.
Falls at 3,250 feet elevation, Kamalō qd., Molokaʻi, named for the goddess Hina, the mother of Molokaʻi. See Keanaohina.
Same as naʻenaʻe, shrubs or trees.
Name of a legendary goddess.
A species of small fish.
The blossoms of the hala fruit; the leaves which inclose the hala fruit.
Aromatic; fragrant, as the fruit and blossoms of the hala tree.
Street name.
Often called simply Hina; the goddess of fishes, mother of Aiaiakuula; Hinahele laua o Kuula na 'kua lawaia, mai Hawaii a Niihau.
Street name.
The silversword (Argyroxiphium sandwicense). See ʻāhinahina 2.

Florida moss (Tillandsia usneoides), an air plant, growing on tree branches and hanging baskets, forming masses of gray, thread-like stems and leaves. It is often substituted for the heliotrope (below) as the flower of Kahoʻolawe, and so called. Also ʻāhinahina and ʻumiʻumi-o-Dole, Dole’s Whiskers.

Native heliotrope (Heliotropium anomalum var. argenteum), a low, spreading beach plant, with narrow, clustered, silvery leaves and small, white, fragrant flowers. As designated by the Territorial legislature in 1923, it represents Kahoʻolawe in the leis of the islands; it is used for tea and medicine. Called nohonoho puʻuone on Niʻihau.
Native geraniums (Geranium cuneatum var. tridens and other native silvery geraniums), shrubs or small trees of the high mountains, with ovate, toothed leaves and red or white flowers. Cf. nohoanu.
Native artemisia (Artemisia australis). See ʻāhinahina 3.
Gray, grayish.
A variety of sugar cane, gray-green with a rosy flush, the whole covered with a wax bloom; pith dark brown; looks like lahi 2. (HP 224, 225)
Redup. of hina 1.
Gray; grayish.
Withered, as fruit ready to fall.
Dusty miller (Artemisia stelleriana), a perennial herb in the daisy family, from northeastern Asia and eastern North America. The leaves and stems have a white, velvety covering and are aromatic.
A native Hawaiian plant of the water-leaf family (Nama sandwichensis). Niʻihau.
Same as pōhinahina 2, the beach vitex.
Same as hinahina 5, artemisia.
Same as hinahina 3, a beach (kahakai) heliotrope.
An unidentified plant.
An unidentified plant.
Basket or container made of braided ʻie vine, pandanus, or other material; a kind of basket fish trap, as used for shrimps, eels, hīnālea and ʻoʻopu. Also hīnaʻi hoʻoluʻuluʻu or hīnaʻi hoʻomoe iʻa.
A container braided out of the ie and other materials; a basket.
Basket, in basketball; basketball net. See hao, hupa, kuku, pōhīnaʻi.

example_txt.txt: Komo mau kāna mau kī ʻana i ka hīnaʻi.
His shots always make it into the basket.

definitions.dtxt: A Hawaiian star and month name. See ʻumeke, month.
Name of the seventh Hawaiian month.
A round basket or container, as braided around a calabash.
A round basket; a basket braided around a calabash; hinaihooluuluu.
Wire fish trap.

A rock or peak also known as Queen Victoria’s Profile on Mt. Hāʻupu, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi. (Pele’s sister Hiʻiaka and Hina competed to win chief Kāhili; Hina won because her sarong was so highly scented with mokihana berries. The name Hina is said to be engraved as a petroglyph, sometimes awash, at Kīpū Kai, Kauaʻi.)
Handkerchief.
Neckerchief. Niʻihau.
Former site for dancing, maika, the kilu sexual game (RC 106), and fighting (mokomoko), Kapaʻau, Hawaiʻi.
Pocket handkerchief. Niʻihau.
Type of stone laid near the coral pile (umu) to attract fish; it was flat on one side and rounded on the other, and was believed to attract manini and young of other fish which resembled it in color.
See HINA and KULAINA, to push over. To partially fall down.
Hina, goddess, kulu, to drop, as rain, and ua, rain. The goddess of rain; has two sisters, viz.: Hinakealii and Hookuipaele.
Street name.
Name of a star.
Street name.
Thin, sickly.
Street name.
To blow favorably, as wind. See ex., pēlā 1.
To blow from aft, as wind favorable for sailing.

Small- to moderate-sized, brightly colored wrasses, family Labridae. In addition to those listed below, hīnālea may be qualified by the terms ʻeleʻele, līpoa, lolo, nīʻau, nuku ʻiʻiwi, nuku ʻiʻiwi ʻula, nuku ʻiʻiwi uli, nuku loa, nuku loa ʻeleʻele. Cf. ōpule. Hīnālea was eaten raw as an aftertaste for kava. It was prepared in the iʻa hoʻomelu fashion with kukui nuts and chili pepper; as this had a somewhat offensive smell, the phrase ipu kai hīnālea, dish of hīnālea sauce, was applied rudely to one with unpleasant breath, especially if he had the iʻa kui, nasal discharge.
A variety of taro.
A species of fish.
Applied to a basket for catching fish; hinai hinalea.
Yellowtail coris, Coris gaimard, up to 46 cm. See ʻakilolo.
Bird wrasse, Gomphosus varius, 23 cm.
A saddle wrasse up to 20 cm. long (Thalassoma duperreyi).
A blacktail wrasse up to about 18 cm. long (Thalassoma ballieui).
Cleaner wrasse (Labroides phthirophegus), a kind of fish.
Falls (280 feet drop), Hanalei qd., Kauaʻi.
Point, Hālawa qd., north Molokaʻi.
Name of a chief in whose time occurred a famous deluge called kai a ka Hinaliʻi; the Biblical flood. See saying ʻiliki 1.
Name of a star that appears in the month of Hilinehu and follows in its course the star Polowehilani.
The name of a person (chief) in whose time there occurred a universal deluge or kai a ka Hinalii; hence kaiakahinalii is at present used for the flood of Noah. See also ke kai a ka Hulumanu.
Hina, gray, and lii, very little. Very little gray, as the hair; whitish.
Street name.
Street name.
Var. of hīnano.
The blossoms of the hala fruit; the leaves which inclose the hala fruit.
The leaves inclosing the hala fruit. See HINAALO.
The flowers of the hala tree.
Aromatic; fragrant, as the fruit and blossoms of the hala tree.
Place, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu. (TM)
Achernar, a star.
Name of a star, said to be the tutelary star of Hāna, Maui.
Street name.
To lie down to sleep; to lie low, as of smoke; to drop dead.
Hina, to fall, and moe, to lie down. A place of death; often applied to the volcano.
Young of ʻoʻopu, a fish, formerly caught in nets and greatly relished. ʻAi wale i ka hinana, ka iʻa kaulana o ka ʻāina, eat readily of the hinana, the famuous fish of the land. See saying, pā ʻili.
Name of a very small fish, the young of the oopu.
Point, Airport qd., north Molokaʻi.
Same as hīnau.
Street name.
Male pandanus blossom. Moena hīnano, very fine mat made of the bracts of the hīnano. Cf. ʻahu hīnano.
Street, Kapahulu section, Honolulu.
Type of pāʻū (no data).
Var. of Hinamālailena, a star.
Var. of hinapē.
Too weak to stand alone.
Street name.
To fall together, of several; to topple.
A rare native variety of upland taro, with green leaves, reddish leaf juncture (piko), dark-green petioles, and white corm. (HP 18, 32) Perhaps same as lauloa uliuli.
A variety of sweet potato.
Street name.
Thin, fine, as hair. Probably obsolete except in names.
Cinder cone (6,252 feet high), Hualālai, Hawaiʻi.
A kind of seaweed.
To begin to gray, of hair.
Same as hīnawe, nānawaū, hīnewanewaū.
Same as hīnawenawe.
Thin, feeble, weak, spindling, slender, puny, debilitated.
Thin; spindling; slender. See UNIHI.
Street name.
Gaudy, showy, splendid.
Female, feminine. Cf. wahine, kaikamahine, kaikuahine, luahine.
Strutting; proud of one’s appearance.
A moss listed by Rock.
Hindu.
Var. of hīnawenawe.
Weak, feeble, delicate.
To be small; thin; feeble.
Redup. of hini; indistinct, faint, as a voice.
A variety of land shell. See hinihini konouli, hinihini kua mauna, See ex., māpu.

chants.chtran: Like the voice of a hinihini, blown softly by the gentle breeze
chants.chtxt: Mehe leo no ka hinihini, ka pā hane i ke ahe mālie

definitions.dtxt: Cooked greens, as of ʻāheahea, pōpolo, pakai.
See HINI. Speaking in a small, thin voice; a whispering; hanehane.
See HINI and UHINI. Thin; slender; pointed.
A land shell (Succinea casta orophila).
A land shell (Succinea casta).
Air upland moss (no data).
See HENIPOA and NIPOA. Heavy, as the eyes when drowsy or very sleepy; he maluhiluhi.
Street name.
Oil, grease, ointment; oily, greasy; smooth and polished, lustrous, slick. Cf. maka hinu.
Ointment; substance for besmearing; momona, mea poni, etc.
Smooth; greasy; polished; dazzling with brightness; anointed.
To anoint; to besmear, as with oil or grease.
To be smooth; shining.
To slip; to slide easily.
To anoint. See KAHINU.
Pas/imp. of hinu. I hinua i ke kukui o Lilikoʻi a paheʻe, polished smooth with the kukui of Lilikoʻi.
Street name.

Intensification of hinu; bright, glossy, shining, lustrous, glittering, as of polished stones or shells; splendid; splendor. A me ka ʻaila hoʻi, i mea e hinuhinu ai kona maka, and oil to make his face to shine. hoʻohinuhinu To shine, polish; to show off (Kel. 130). Keiki hoʻohinuhinu kāmaʻa, shoe sinner, bootblack. Hoʻohinuhinu mikiʻao, fingernail polish. Eʻ hoʻohinuhinu ana ʻa Keola i kona kāmaʻa, Keola is polishing his shoes.
Var. of hiluhilu. hoʻohinuhinu Var. of hoʻohiluhilu. Ua hoʻohinuhinu loa ʻo Makaliʻi i kāna wahine, ā ua nani loa (FOR. 4:81), Makaliʻi bedecks his wife and [she is] very beautiful.
Bright; shining; splendid, as red cloth; glittering, as polished stones.
See HINU. To shine as if anointed with oil. To glisten; to be bright; to sparkle.
Grease, as used in machines or for tools with moving parts. Comb. hinu + kele.
Same as maiʻa ʻeleʻele or ʻeleʻele, a mountain banana with shiny black trunk. See also hinu.
A native variety of upland taro. Also eleʻele.
Street name.
A sweep or gust of wind; to blow in gusts.
Inside corners of a house, said to be so named because ghosts came whistling in at the corners. Hio kala (FS 29), inside angle of gables.
To break wind silently. Cf. pūhiʻu.
To fall sideways, lean, slant, slope, incline, leaning, oblique, diagonal. See pahiō, wele 1. Kaha hiō, an x signifying “times” in multiplication. hoʻohiō Caus/sim.
A slanting wind, i.e., a wind down a hill.
The inside corner of a (grass) house, i.e., slanting two ways.
A howling confused noise.
The comb of a cock.
Eructatio ventris.
Leaning; oblique; kaha hio; any line which is not parallel, nor perpendicular, nor horizontal, is hio. Ana. Hon. 4.
To lean over; to slant; to incline from a perpendicular; hence,
To be one-sided; to swing to and fro.
To lean upon; to trust in.
To wander. Hoo. To cause to wander. Mea hoohio, a wanderer.
Italic. Also hua hiō. See entry below and uakeʻe hiō, hoʻohiō.
Mākala kū hiō o loko. Internal abdominus oblique muscle. Mākala kū hiō o waho. External abdominus oblique muscle.
Restless, active, flighty. See ex., palawili.

Discovered, existence revealed. Ua hiʻohia ʻo Hawaiʻi nei no kō nā ʻāina ʻē iā Kāpena Kuke. Hawaiʻi was discovered for foreigners by Captain Cook. Comb. hiʻo (Tah., look) + -hia. Cf. kaunānā. Mea hiʻohia. Find, as an archeological find.
To whistle softly; to blow softly, draw in the breath, as of one eating hot food.
Gibberish; to jabber. See hiohio haole. Namu hiohio, English talk.
Lure for trolling, said to be named for its whistling sound tripping over the water.
Name of a species of fish-hook.
To draw the breath into the mouth, as one eating a hot potato; hence,
To eat in a hurry.
Ruddy, bright red.
Bright red; ula hiohio.
To lean every which way. hoʻohiōhiō Redup. of hoʻohiō.
To jibber jabber in the white man’s language, so called because English seemed full of whistling (hiohio), sibilant sounds.

chants.chtran: Indistinct voice of rain on the plants, shishing English
chants.chtxt: Palalē ka leo o ka ua i luna o ka nahele, e hiohio haole ana
chants.chsrc: Chant for Ka Haku o Hawaiʻi

definitions.dtxt: To level off, as a flower bed. (Kep. 157)
Redup. of hiolo. hoʻohiohiolo Caus/sim.; to hang or drape festively.
Redup. of hiona.
Features, as of a face or landscape; sight, aspect.
Hio and ana, the leaning. The features of a person; his peculiar gait; the form, external appearance. Face; presence. SYN. with helehelena.

Effects, as in special effects. Hiʻohiʻona naʻiau. Special effects. See kani keaka. Luna hiʻohiʻona naʻiau. Special effects coordinator, as for movie or video production. Hiʻohiʻona paʻi. Printer effects, as on a computer printer. Hoʻonaʻiau (i ka hiʻohiʻona). To add special effects.
Street name.
To sleep, lie at ease, lounge, relax (this word sometimes replaces moe in poetry because moe suggests the sleep of death).

example_txt.txt: Ua kau ke keha i ka uluna, ua hiʻolani i ka moena.
The head rests on the pillow, stretching out on the mat [relax after work is done].

definitions.dtxt: To lie stretched out with laziness; to sit at ease, as a chief; to be in a posture of thought; e pio na wawae, e lele pio.
Place, Pauoa, Honolulu.
To tumble down, collapse; overthrown, defeated; collapse, landslide, falling. E hiolo ana nā kapu kahiko, the ancient taboos collapse. hoʻohiolo To overthrow, demolish, raze.
A tumbling down; a sliding away; a falling over.
Hi, flowing, and olo, to vibrate.
To tumble down, as a wall. To fall over, as a house.
To stumble or fall down, as a horse.
To roll away, i.e., pass away in forgetfulness; i ole e hioloia kona inoa.
To become useless or void.
Hoo. To throw down; to overthrow; to destroy, as a fortification.
To make void; to set aside, as a law.
Pas/imp. of hiolo. hoʻohiolohia Caus/sim.
Street name.
Leaning, slanting. ʻAno ʻē hoʻi ka hiona o kēlā kumu niu, what a peculiar angle that coconut tree has.
General appearance, as of a person; impression. Cf. hiohiona. Pehea kāu hiʻona ʻana i kēia mea? How does this appear to you?
Personal appearance; face, countenance, etc. See HIOHIONA. Anat. 5.
General appearance, impression; feature. Cf. hiʻonaina. See entries below. Hiʻona na ke kanaka. Man-made topographical feature.
Land section between Puʻumakani and Kaʻalāiki, Kaʻū, Hawaiʻi.
Contour, as the elevations of a particular place; land feature, as a mountain, valley, etc.; topography. Palapala hiʻona ʻāina. Topographic map.
Landscape. Sh. hiʻona + ʻāina. Cf. hiʻona. See kāhiʻonaina.
Cross section, in math.
Texture.

Body of water; water form or feature, as a lake, pond, river, etc., in geography. ʻO ka hiʻona wai, he muliwai, he loko wai, he kahawai, he wailele, a pēlā aku nō. A water feature can be a river, lake, stream, waterfall, and the like. Cf. hiʻona ʻāina.
Redup. of hīʻō.

definitions.der: [Lit. Without leaning; me ka haipule mau i ke Akua me ka hioole]
definitions.dtxt: With stability; firmness.
Hoo. He olelo hoohipa, a kind of mele.
Street name.
Var. of hepa, imbecilic.
Sheep.
A little bundle.
A blunder in speaking; the use of words out of their ordinary meaning.
Hoo. A falsehood.
To blunder in speaking. Hoo. To falsify.
Sheep.
Same as puka wai, a coconut eye that is or may be pierced for drinking.
Hip, hip, hurrah! Cheers! (Eng., hip.) ʻEkolu hipahipa no ka mōʻī, three cheers for the king!
To be joyful; to express gladness.
Ram. Hipa kāne ʻakolu ona makahiki, three-year-old ram. Hipa kāne wāwahi, battering ram.
Hipa, sheep, and kane, male. A ram. Ili hipakane, a ram skin. Gram. § 95. Fig. Hipakane wawahi, a battering ram.
The star Aries.
Lamb.
Hipa, sheep, and keiki, the little one. A lamb. See KEIKIHIPA.
definitions.notes: Note: The word lamb is rendered in Hawaiian by both forms, hipakeiki and keikihipa.

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
See PAPALALE. A speaking with readiness and correctness, without a tone, and not through the nose; o ka hana maiau hipapalale ole, noiau papalale ole.
Street and area in lower Mānoa, Honolulu. A heiau near here where human sacrifices were offered had this name (Sterling and Summers 6:133). For three awards, see lndices 740.
Street name.
Hippopotamus.
Gr. The river-horse. The hippopotamus.
Hippopotamus.
A knot; a fastening; anything tied. Fig. E wehe oe i ka hipu naaupo, o make auanei oe.
To tie in knots, as the string of a bundle or bag.
Resting place, as in the shelter of a tree or cave.
Falls, Hālawa Valley, Molokaʻi.
A concealed snare for plovers.
A kind of snare for catching birds; ka hipuka no na manu hihiu; kau aku la ia i ka hipuka pahele.
Knot, bond, fastening; to tie a knot. Hīpuʻu o ka male, bonds of matrimony. hoʻohīpuʻu To tie, bind.
Tied bundle, purse; to bundle up.
A knot; a fastening; anything tied. Fig. E wehe oe i ka hipu naaupo, o make auanei oe.
A bag for carrying small things in, as money; a purse.
Hipuu kala, in the English translation, a crisping pin.
Knotty, as a string tied up in knots; tied fast; applied to men, mischievous.
To tie in knots, as the string of a bundle or bag.
Knot. See entry below.
Bow, as ribbon or string. Cf. lei ʻāʻī pewa.
Redup. of hīpuʻu 1, 2.
What is tied up in knots or made fast.
See HIPUU. Tied; fastened; knotty, as tied in knots; he hipuupuu kahi malo o kahi alii, the malos of some chiefs were tied up in knots.
See HIPUU. To tie up in knots; hence, to tie up in a bundle.
To tie fast; to gird around, as with a sash; aole kakou i like me na kanaka kiai alii a hipuupuu kahi malo, we are not the men who guard the king, belted up with sashes.
Suffix in chemical compounds and terms: -ite.
Street name.

To throw or fling violently; to haul energetically with ropes; to get into action, as play or sport; to pursue with energy, as love-making. Hiu ā wela, ardent and persistent love-making; to take by storm. Hiu aku nei ʻoia i ka puʻupuʻu, he swung into action with his fists. E kū i ka malo ā hiu (Malo 146), stand up with [your] malo and go to it. Hiu nō au ā naʻu ʻoe, I’ll sweep you off your feet. hoʻohiu Caus/sim.
To elevate, hoist, as by block and tackle. hoʻohiu Caus/sim. Ua hoʻohiu ʻia ka moku i luna o ke alahukimoku, the ship was lifted onto the marine railway.
Stones used in games of kōnane, kinepeki, and āneo, usually polished and flat.
Stream, Waiʻanae Valley, Oʻahu.
Hind part or tail section of a fish, considered less delicious than the head or front section. See saying, pau 1.
Caudal fin.
To break wind. Same as pūhiʻu.
To motion with the hands in a way destructive to the addressee. (KAM. 64:141)
The tail of a fish, but not SYN. with huelo.
The practice of sorcery.
The name of the counter or iliili used in playing konane or konene; ina he hiu, a he aneo paha, a he lalani, a he punikihi paha, aia no i ko laua mau lunamanao.
To seize; to grasp hold of, as a rope.
To throw a stone with violence.
To be wild; untamed, as an animal.
To cry, as a sailor does in pulling a rope; hence,
To haul down a ship for repairs.
To practice sorcery.
To move the hiu (see the s.) in playing konane, a game.
Many of these definitions seem to be confused with the modern spelling hiu.
Tails, as in coin toss. Also ʻaoʻao hiʻu. See entry below and pana hoʻolei, poʻo.
Tip of a leaf, as hala. Also welelau. Cf. poʻo.
Chip, as used in poker, checkers, counting, etc.
Street, Kalihi Waena, Honolulu. (TM)
A game something like checkers, played on a board with five squares.
Menstrual. He koko hiua, menstrual blood.
He mea ula hiua; name of a game played on a board of four squares.
See HIU. To practice sorcery.
To play the game konane.
Redup. of hiu 1, 2; to pelt repeatedly; to tug, lift again and again.
Last bits of odds and ends; remnants of matting strips that must be cut off after plaiting is finished; ends of knots in plaiting; wispy end of a braid. Cf. hiʻu, tail.

Fishtail fern (Nephrolepis biserrata cv. furcans), a kind of sword fern, with forked divisions (pinnae). In Kaʻū, leis are made by combining pinnae of this fern (or whole frond) with flower sprays of wāpine (Lemon verbena).
Whole fish used as bait for trolling.
A single fishtail. Fig. Limited knowledge.
A fresh-water ʻoʻopu fish with a pinkish tail (hiʻu kole). It is taboo to some because it is believed related to the moʻo lizard gods. Also ʻalamoʻo, hiʻuʻula, and nuʻukole.
Hiu and malolo, the flying-fish. The tail of the flying-fish.
Canoe stern. Fig. A straight tree suitable for a canoe.

Water purification festivities on the second night of the month of Welehu (near the end of the year). The people bathed and frolicked in the sea or stream after midnight, then put on their finest tapa and ornaments for feasting and games. (Kep. 97, 193–4)
“Water-tailed,” said of one allegedly descended from a shark. (GP 10–1)
The name of the ceremony of bathing in cold water in the worship of some of the gods.
A kind of ʻahi, a tuna fish.
Entirely black, as of pigs offered to the gods, a desirable blackness contrasting with uli and ʻeleʻele, which have pejorative connotations. See polohiwa and its associations with the god Kāne.
Choice. See hiwahiwa.
A term qualifying coconuts and kava; see niu, ʻawa.
See ʻAeʻaeahiwa.
Any black article supposed to be acceptable to the gods as an offering; hence,
A precious valuable article.
Applied to persons; keiki hiwa, a dear child.

Black; clear black; applied mostly to that which was used in sacrifice to the gods, as a black hog; ina i eleele a puni ka hulu, he hiwa pa ia puaa; a black cocoanut, a black kapa, etc., and always considered valuable; hence,
Dear; valued; beloved; precious; he puaa hiwa, he niu hiwa, he awa hiwa.
To be of a black color, such as was considered precious or valuable in sacrifice; to be of a clear or pure black.
Corpulent, fat. Cf. ʻāwaʻawaʻa 2.
See MOMONA. Large; fat, as a large fleshy person; applied only to persons.
Street name.

Precious, beloved, esteemed, petted, darling, indulged; favorite. See ex., luxury. Ka Mesia, ka hiwahiwa a ke Akua, the Messiah, the chosen of God. hoʻohiwahiwa To honor, adorn, decorate; to display, as the flag; to treat as a favorite; festive. He mea hoʻohiwahiwa i ke akua, a thing to honor the gods. ʻO ka mea hoʻohiwahiwa i kāna kauā mai kona wā ʻuʻuku mai, he who delicately brings up his servant from his childhood.
A person or thing greatly beloved; applied mostly to animals or children; a pet; a beloved one. The beloved one.
See HIWA. Thick; dense; black, as a cloud; glossy black.
Acceptable; desired by any one.
Very precious; greatly esteemed. Greatly beloved.
Meek; docile; he keiki hiwahiwa ia.
See HIWA.
An all-black pig with white hoofs and white tips of tail, ears, and nose.
Street name.
Esteemed chief; beloved child or favorite; royal favorite.
Coal-black, entirely black, solid-black. (A puaʻa hiwa might have a few white hairs, but none at all were on a puaʻa hiwa paʻa.)
Street name.
Skinny, bony, thin, angular. Cf. iwi. hoʻohiwi To be downright skin and bones.
Sharp ridge of a mountain. Cf. more common kuahiwi.
The flat or depressed summit of a protuberance.
To diminish, as a swelling; to flatten down, as a protuberance; ua hiwi mai. See the compounds POOHIWI and KUAHIWI.
Redup. and intensifier of hiwi 1.
Abbreviation for hikina (east).
Abbreviation for hapa kaukani (milli-).
Abbreviation for hekokalame (hectogram).
Abbreviation for hapa kiliona (pico-) and hekolika (hectoliter).
Abbreviation for hekomika (hectometer).
Abbreviation for hola (hour).
Abbreviation for hema (south).
Abbreviation for hapa ʻumi (deci-).
Abbreviation for hapa miliona (micro-).
Caus/sim. marker before glottal stop and short vowel or before long vowel or vowels, as ʻike, hōʻike, ʻā, hōʻā, hōʻāʻā. Gram. 6.4.
Marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-, but commonly found before words beginning with a glottal stop followed by a long vowel, as ʻāpuka, hoʻāpuka.

definitions.der: [PPN foaki, PCP soo: cf. Penrhyn soo, Yasuda 15]
