definitions.dtxt: To give, transfer, go (followed by directionals). No caus/sim. derivation with hō has been noted. For the word often written hooho, see oho.

example_txt.txt: E hō mai i ka ʻai.
Ē ke aloha, hō mai he leo.
O my love, give your voice.

chants.mltran: ♫  Let’s turn the nose of the horse toward the candlenut grove.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Hō aʻe kāua i ka ihu o ka lio i ka ulu kukui.

definitions.dtxt: To wheeze, breathe hard.
Hoe, colter of a plow. Me kāna hō, a me kāna koʻilipi with his colter and his axe.

This syllable (see the two articles above) has a meaning of its own, and as such may enter into compound words; but very often, as will appear, it is a contraction of hoo. (See Hoo.) The contraction is made before all the letters, but mostly where the word commences with some of the vowels, especially with the letter o.
The asthma; the lowing of cattle, etc.
A farming utensil; a hoe; the colter of a plow.
To cry out in a clamorous manner.
Hoo. To cause the voice to be raised; to raise the voice to a high pitch.
To speak together, as in voting viva voce; to proclaim; to shout acclamation of approval.
To shout in triumph. Hooho olioli, to triumph over one.
To cry out for fear; to cry out in distress.
To wheeze; to breathe hard, as in the asthma; to snort; to blow, as a horse. See HOOHO in its place.
To transfer, i.e., to bring here or carry away, according as it is followed by mai or aku. See MAI and AKU. Gram. § 233 and 234. As, ho mai, bring here; ho aku, carry away.
To bring; to present. To give or put away, as money at interest.
To carry or cause to be conveyed; to transport; to remove.
To produce; to bring forward, as food on to the table.
Marker of the caus/sim.; same as hoʻo-; occasionally found before words beginning with i-, as ikaika, hōʻikaika.
Unsteady; movable. See HIA.
Street name.

Companion, friend, associate, colleague, comrade, partner, mate, peer, fellow, antagonist (if followed by a word such as kaua or paio). Cf. hoahānau, hoa hele, hoaloha, hoa paio, and saying, cold 1. Kona hoa, his friend. Hoa a ka Hale o nā Lunamakaʻāinana, member of the House of Representatives. hoʻohoa To make friends.
To tie, bind, secure, rig; rigging, lashing. See hoa waʻa.
To strike with a stick or club; to club; a club.
Same as mamo 1, the honey-creeper.

Hoʻohoa To challenge, dare, provoke; daring, defiant. Cf. uahoa. Hoʻohoa nā manu hanina, the quiet birds are daring. Hana ka iwi a kanaka makua, hoʻohoa mai, get maturity into the bones before issuing a challenge.
A companion; a fellow; a friend; an assistant. It is found in many compounds; as, hoapio, a fellow prisoner; hoamoe, a bed-fellow; hoahele, a traveling companion, etc.
A tying; a binding.
To tie; to secure by tying; to bind; to wind round, as a rope or string; to rig up, as a canoe; a ma ka wa e hoa ai ka waa, he kapu ka hoa ana. See A and HOHOA. Alaila, hoaia ka pou me ka lohelau:
To strike on the head with a stick.
To beat, as kapa with a stick on a stone.
To strike, as in fighting.
To drive, as cattle.
To turn on, as a light, radio,TV, etc. Cf. hoʻopio.
To set on fire, burn, ignite, etc. See ʻā 1.
To drive, as cattle or fish; to herd. See -ʻā.
To talk much. See ā 1.
See hōʻā īpuka hale.
Ho for hoo, and a, to burn.

To kindle a fire; to burn, i.e., to cause to blaze; to make a light. Laieik. 77. To rage, as a flame of love; ua hoaia ke ahi, enaena o ke aloha wela, the raging fire of hot love blazed forth. Laieik. 204.
To comb or dress the hair or the head.
To cast or throw away; e hookuke; hence,
To commit mischief, as a child.
To enable to develop roots. Comb. hoʻ- + aʻa. Also hoʻoaʻa. Hōmona hoʻāʻa. Rooting hormone.
See aʻa 1, root, vein, etc.
To look about or search in confusion, stray, wander; disconcerted. E hōʻāʻā ana i nā makaaniani, looking in confusion for the spectacles.
To blunder, stray. See ʻāʻā, demented.
To kindle, light. See ʻaʻā 1.
A mistake; a blunder; an error.
The kindling, i.e., small pieces of fuel used in kindling a fire.
See Ho for hoo, and AA, to blaze. To kindle; to cause to burn.
To stare; to look about in doubt. See AA, to be bold.
To mistake; to blunder; to go astray.
To challenge; to dare; to provoke.
Street name.
To kindle fire.

definitions.der: [ho for hoo, a, to burn, and ahi, fire]
definitions.dtxt: Fire kindlings; the materials for causing a fire to burn; e imi mua oe ia no ka hoaahi, ana.
Fire kindlings, materials for kindling fire.
To put clothing on someone else; to dress, supply with clothing, clothe.
To clothe. See ʻaʻahu.
Ho for hoo, and aahu, to clothe. To clothe; to put on a garment; to give kapa or clothes to one.
Eating or dinner companion.
Hoa, companion, and ai, to eat. An eating companion; a guest.
Street name.
Tenant, caretaker, as on a kuleana. Ou poʻe hoaʻāina (FS 141), your tenants.
Hoa and aina, land.
A person to whom the hakuaina or konohiki commits the care of his land.
A husbandman; a tiller of the ground.
To act surly, to pretend to be cross.
Surly. See ʻaʻaka 1.
Toilet water, liquid spice, scented extract.
Companion of a chief, fellow chief, chief descended from the god Kāne (FOR. 6:266). Fig. The gods.
Var. spelling of hoaloha.
Hoa, companion, and aloha, to love. A friend. A beloved companion; ia wa, ua lilo ko Hawaii nei i poe hoaaloha no na misionari, at that time the Hawaiians became friends to the missionaries.
To stare, etc. See ʻaʻā maka.

definitions.der: [ho for hoo, aa, bold, and maka, eye]
definitions.dtxt: To beg for a thing by looking wishfully at it.
Caus/sim of ʻaʻana.
To act the bully, bluff, defy, boast of courage that may be lacking; to challenge, take risks, act bold or defiant, dare.
To boast, defy. See ʻaʻano.
See the verb. Forward; presumptuous; defying punishment.
Proud; daring; obstinate; self confident.
A factitious word; ho for hoo, aa, to dare, and no, a particle of affirmation, indeed; truly; hence, to have confidence in one’s self; to brag; to express bravery.
To form a cup of the hollow of the hand; to fold a leaf into a cup.
See ʻaʻapu.
Ho for hoo, and aapu, to warp; bend up. To make a cup of the hollow of the hand; e hoaapu ae i kou poho lima, make the palm of your hand into a cup.
To make fine, soft. See ʻae 3.
To rise. See ʻae 4.
Caus/sim of ʻae.

example_txt.txt: A hot glowing fire that pulverizes.

definitions.dtxt: To make fine, pulverize, refine, soften.
To yield, as in traffic.
To break taboo. See ʻaʻe.
Caus/sim of ʻaʻe.
To cause to wander; to wander. Na ke kaumaha i hōʻaeʻa iāia mai ke one hānau mai, it was grief that caused him to wander from his homeland. See ʻaeʻa.
Ho for hoo, and aea, to wander about. To pretend to wander; to make as though one was a wanderer or vagabond in order to accomplish a particular object.
Street name.
A chant with lengthened vowels. See aeae.
To make soft, fine, etc.
Land section and point, ʻEwa, Oʻahu.
definitions.notes: Note: A stone called Pōhakupili (clinging rock) is on the edge of the cliff on the boundary of Hōʻaeʻae and Waikele; it belonged to the gods Kāne and Kanaloa

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
To make or braid ʻaha; to tie up a calabash.
To braid. See ʻaha 2.
Ho for hoo, and aha, a cord. To make or braid together the strings for a calabash; to tie up a calabash; e hoaha i ka ipu.
Same as ʻahaʻaha 2.
To sit or stand thus.
To sit cross-legged, à la Turk, in eating.
To be proud; high-minded; he kanaka hoahaaha.
To be bent up; stunted; crooked out of shape.
To feast, give a feast.
Ho for hoa (one a dropped), and ahaaina, a feast. A fellow feaster; one at the same feast.
Ho for hoo, aha, collection, and aina, to eat. To cause a collection for eating; to make a feast.
Street name.
Fellow worker, colleague, partner, accomplice.
Hoa, companion, and hana, to work. A fellow laborer in any kind of business.
Cousin; brother or sister, as a church member. Kona hoahānau, his cousin. Hoahānau Kamika, Smith Brothers [as the name of a firm].
Hoa, companion, and hanau, to be born. A companion by birth; a kindred; some blood relation; a relative; a brother in an extensive sense. In a modern sense, a fellow professor of religion.
Relative of one’s own generation.
Hoa, companion, and hanauna, relations. Relatives of one’s own clan, tribe or nation. See HANAUNA.
Schoolmate.
Street name.
Traveling companion, fellow traveler. (In Iosua 14.8 “kou hoa hele” seems to be the Hawaiian translation of “my brethren.”)
Hoa and hele, to go. A fellow traveler.
Relatively prime numbers, i.e., numbers which share one factor between them, and that factor is 1, in math.
To blame, condemn. See ʻāhewa.
See AHEWA and HEWA. A finding or pronouncing guilty of a crime or wrong; to condemn.

To impeach, i.e.formally accuse (a public official) of misconduct in office. He mea koʻikoʻi maoli ka hana hewa a ka pelekikena e pono ai ke kū ʻo ia i ka mea i hoʻāhewa ʻia ai. The misdeeds of the president must have been very serious if he was found guilty of the things he is being impeached for. Trad. Cf. kīpaku luna kālaiʻāina.
Street name.
See ahiahi, evening.
Ho for hoo, and ahiahi, evening. To darken; to obscure; to cause a thing to be obscure in vision; to be neither clear nor dark.
To darken, to obscure; to be neither clear nor dark.
Quickness; rapidity.
One who has escaped a place of protection.
See aho, breath.
Ho for hoo, and aho, breath.
To give breath, i.e., deliverance from immediate danger; to put one in safety from danger.
To be quick; to hasten; to do quickly.
To kindle a fire.
To tie ʻaho to the frame of the roof.
See ʻaho, thatch.
Ho and aho, a string.
To make or twist strings for a house.
To tie aho on to a building. See AHO.

Redup. of hoa 3; a rounded tapa beater (also called hohoa, pepehi); rapid beating, striking, as of tapa or pandanus leaves; a stick beater for washing clothes. Fig. Bad-tempered. Keu hoʻi kēia a ke kanaka hoahoa, this person certainly beats the beater [in rage]. hoʻohoahoa Caus/sim.
A striking, smiting, etc.
The name of the mallet with which kapa (the wauki) was beaten.
See HOA, to strike. The freq. conj. of hoa. To strike or smite frequently.
To break fuel, as Hawaiians did before they had axes.
To cause the hair to stand erect; e hookuku ae i ka lauoho iluna.
A burning fire; a blaze; a bright light.
To cause a fire to burn; to make a blaze; to make a shining light.
Redup. of hoaka 3–5.
Comb of a rooster.
Poetic: hoa, companion, and aloha, love. Those who converse often together, who are chief friends and love each other.
Shipmate.
See ahonui.
Hoa, companion, hoo, causative, and ilina, an inheritance. A fellow heir to an inheritance.
Hoa, friend, hoo, causative, lau, the number 400, kanaka, men.
A friend of the increase of men; one friendly to the multitude.
The multitude itself; aloha oe e kuu hoahoolaukanaka o kahi kanaka ole, good morning my friend of the people where there are none.
To collect, pile. See ahu.
An assemblage of things; a collection.
A collecting, as of property; a gathering together.
Dislike; contempt for a thing.
Ho for hoo, and ahu, a collection of things.
To cause a collection or gathering together.
To lay up, as goods for future use.
To collect articles; to lay up in heaps.
To lay up against one, as anger; e hoahu ana i ka huhu maluna o kela poe.
To esteem lightly; to despise; to contemn; to dislike; to be dissatisfied with.
Disagreeable; unsatisfactory.

To lay away, store away, accumulate. Waihona hoʻāhu kālā. Savings account, as in a bank. See lumi hoʻāhu, waihona hoʻāhu, waihona kālā. Hōkeo hoʻāhu. Library, i.e., a temporary buffer for storage of codes or information in a computer program.
Shield building; to build a shield (volcano). Lit. pile up shields.
Street name.
Associate.
Joining, suture, joint. Cf. hoa 2, and below.
The union of things sewed together; ka hoopili ana ma na hookuina.
In anatomy, a suture; a joining; hoai manawa, coronal suture; hoai kaupaku, sagittal; hoai kala, lambdoidal; hoai maha, temporal suture, etc.
This spelling may be confused with hōʻai.**
To feed, give food to, board.
To breed, as a horse. (Probably PPN haʻi.)
To feed. See ʻai, food.
Ho for hoo, and ai, food.
To stir up; to mix; to make poi thin with water that it may be fit for eating.
To unite two things together, as by stretching or sewing kapas together.
To be singular in one’s conduct or deportment.
A soft clear white light; a pure light; abstract, whiteness.
White; clear; shining.
Ho for hoo, and aiai, to be white.
To be clear; white; shining.
To cause to be white, etc., i.e., to whiten; to clear off rust or dirt from a substance that it may shine.
To be clear, as the unclouded moon; to be shining, as a light.
To be proud; to be lifted up with pride.
To release, as war captives.
Caus/sim of ʻaiʻaiā.
Pawnshop.
See ʻaiʻē.
Kumu hōʻaiʻē. Credit, as at a bank or store.
Credit union.
Lambdoidal suture.
A friend on terms of reciprocity.
The house where such friends reside or meet.
Ho for hoo, ai and kane. See AIKANE.
To commit the sin against nature; to commit sodomy; applied to either sex.
To be an intimate friend of the same sex, i.e., to give and receive favors from one of the same sex. Laieik. 81.
To act the part of an aikane or intimate friend.
To make friends, as two persons about to fight. Laieik. 47.
Sagital suture.

To treat contemptuously; to rejoice over the misfortunes of others; sarcastic, contemptible. Hōʻaikola nohoʻi nā lāʻau kaʻa maluna ou, the fir trees rejoice at thee. Hōʻaikola nohoʻi kāu hana you do such contemptible things.
A sneer; a sneering expression of approval.
A contemptuous cheering, calling one good fellow, well done, etc.; in an ironical sense, ku no ka akaiki o lakou ame ko lakou hoaikola ana, their chuckling and their false cheering hit us.
Ho for hoo. See AIKOLA, AKOLA and NAIKOLA.
To express triumph over one with contempt for him; to cause contemptuous treatment; to triumph over one with expressions of vanity and contempt.
To blackguard; to triumph over another’s ills; to reproach; ua hoaikola mai o Palu ia oe; to rejoice or triumph over.
To perplex; to bring one into difficulty.
To desire to have one put to death.
Similar to hoa aliʻi. (PH 53, 65)
Street name.
Signpost, tall stop sign, any pillar or large object with a sign, or serving as a marker; image on the wall surrounding a temple.

Sign, symbol, representation, insignia, emblem, mark, badge, signal, omen, portent, target, credential, token of recognition, a lot that is cast; title (legal); depth sounding; to mark; to take a depth sounding; to draw lots. Cf. hailona, kila 2.

example_txt.txt: hōʻailona kūʻauhau, hōʻailona no ke kūlana
family crest or coat of arms
badge or emblem of royalty, sceptre
emblem or trophy of victory, trophy
ka pana ʻana aku i ka hōʻailona

definitions.dtxt: See ʻailona.
See the verb. A mark; a signal; a sign of something different from what it appears to be.
A sign or forerunner of something coming to pass or expected.
A part representing the whole.
Something whose real signification is different from the appearance.
A sign; a pledge; a distinguishing mark. A signet.
A target; a mark to shoot at.
A lot cast, as in casting lots; ma ka hoailona, by lot.
A scepter; a badge of authority. See next word.
See HAILONA. To sound the depth of water, i.e., to throw the lead.
To mark; to set a mark upon one.
To cast lots for a thing. In modern times, to play at dice.
Sign, as traffic signs. Cf. papa hoʻolaha. See entries below.
Symbol, sign, as in math. To symbolize, stand for. See entry below and pihi hōʻailona.

example_txt.txt: Inā hoʻi he huahelu ʻokoʻa ka mea i hōʻailona ʻia e ka A, e like nō hoʻi ka hana ʻana.
Even if A symbolizes a different number, the process is the same.

definitions.dtxt: Algebra. Haʻi hōʻailona helu. Algebraic expression.
Sign or emblem of victory. See -ʻailona.
Clef, in music. Hōʻailona mele leo kāne. Bass clef. Also leo kāne. Hōʻailona mele leo wahine. Treble clef. Also leo wahine.
See HOAILONA above, and MOI, sovereignty. A scepter; a badge or emblem of regal authority.
Temporal suture.
Coronal suture.
Ho for hoo, a, to burn, and imu, oven. To kindle a fire in the oven; to heat the oven.
Street name.
Sweetheart, mate, spouse.
Same as hāinu, hoʻohāinu, to give to drink. Kaʻū.
See AIPOOLA and PUUPOOLA. To gulp up wind from the stomach after eating heartily.
Same as hoaka ʻīpuka hale.
In Hawaiian pathology, the names of a class of diseases, all fatal; the waiiki the only remedy used.
Ho for hoo, and aipuupuu, which see. To act the aipuupuu; to serve out provisions; to distribute food.
Street name.
Crescent; arch, as over door of ancient house (Kep. 101); crescent-shaped design at base of temple drum; crest, as on a helmet.
Second day of the month. (Kep. 101)
Brightness; shining, glittering, splendid; to glitter, shine, flash as lightning, become daylight; to flame. Fig. Glory. Also ʻoaka.

example_txt.txt: to fly glittering, as fire sparks
Mai hele ma ʻō e hoaka ai i ke kai o holo ka iʻa.
Don't go over there and cast your shadow in the sea lest the fish run away.

definitions.dtxt: To cast a shadow; to brandish, as a spear, to drive away, ward off, frighten. Cf. aka 1.
To open, as the mouth.

example_txt.txt: The spirit has flown [of death; the glory of the land has departed].

definitions.dtxt: Spirit, apparition, ghost (FOR. 6:370).
Disease of the abdomen, perhaps appendicitis, rupture (followed by a qualifier). See hoaka ʻīpuka hale, hoaka kākala. Other qualifiers reported are hāwele, kū, kū kahi, kū lua.
Brightness; shining; a glittering; a flaming torch. Nahum. 2:3. Glory, as of a people, i.e., their liberty; freedom.
A name of one of the kapu days; the second day of the moon.
The crescent of the new moon; the hollow of the new moon.
The arch or lintel over a door.
In speaking, a defense; an apology.
To lift up; to lift up, as a spear in fighting.
To drive away; to frighten.
To open; to open the mouth in speaking. See OAKA.
To glitter; to shine; to be splendid. Nahum. 2:3.
See entries below. Pae moku hoaka. Island arc.
Point, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
To shadow, as on computer or in typesetting. Comb. hoʻ- + aka. See aka.
To provoke laughter; laughter. Cf. hoʻomākeʻaka.
See ʻaka, to laugh.
Ho for hoo, and aka, to laugh. To cause one to laugh; to laugh; to be pleased.
To covet; to desire earnestly.
To covet; to desire earnestly.
To clarify. See akaaka, clear.
Also written hoʻākāka.
To cause laughter, create mirth, jeer, ridicule, pretend to laugh; comic. ʻŌlelo hōʻakaʻaka, witticism, amusing speech. Kiʻi hōʻakaʻaka, cartoon.
See ʻakaʻaka, to laugh.
Ho for hoo, and aka, to laugh.
To cause laughter; to cause one to laugh.
To laugh at; to mock; to reproach.
See akahele.
Neighbor, not necessarily next door. See kaiahome.
Ruptured appendix, appendicitis (not certain).
In Hawaiian pathology, the names of a class of diseases, all fatal; the waiiki the only remedy used.
An explanation; an opening of what is intricate.
Ho for hoo, and akaka, clear; explicit. To make plain; clear; to render explicit; to explain; to interpret.
To explain, clarify. See ʻaoʻao hoʻākāka. ʻŌlelo hoʻākāka. Introduction, as in a book. Cf. ʻōlelo haʻi mua.
Expressed; stated; proved; rendered explicit; approved.
Name of a disease, generally fatal.
In Hawaiian pathology, the names of a class of diseases, all fatal; the waiiki the only remedy used.
A disease (ruptured appendix?).
Bracelet of tusks of hog or dog.
Same as hoaka kākala.
Coauthor, writing associate.
Street name.
Arch over a door, lintel.

Arch, as the Arch of Triumph in Paris.

See Kualakaʻi.
Street name.
Childhood playmate.
Fellow man.

definitions.dtxt: Fellow soldier, enemy.
Hoa, companion, and kaua, war.
A fellow soldier.
One against whom a soldier is fighting; an antagonist; hoapaio.
Lover, delightful companion.
Hoa, companion, and kauwa, a servant. A fellow servant.
Street name.
See ākea.
Ho for hoo, and akea, broad. To make broad or wide; to cause enlargement; hence, to deliver from difficulty.
To extend, as text in computer word processing. Cf. hoʻohāiki.
Enlargement; escape; deliverance.
Caus/sim of ʻaki.

To withhold from the landlord his due; hoaki i ka hakuaina.
A fellow soldier; one under the same leader. See HOAKAUA.
Place, Waiʻalae, Honolulu. (TM)
Street name.

Ho for hoo, and akoakoa, to assemble.
To assemble; to come together, as men.
To collect, as things generally. See AKOAKOA.
Street name.
Companion of a god, godly companion.
Hoa, companion, and kuka, to consult. A fellow counsellor; an adviser.
Consultant, counselor, adviser, one with whom one confers and deliberates. Kona hoa kūkākūkā, his counselor.
Hoa, companion, and kuka, to consult. A fellow counsellor; an adviser.
Street name.
Schoolmate.
Kiule hoa kupa. Jury of peers, as in court trials.
Street name.
See ala, to waken, rise up.
Ho for hoo, and ala, to rise up.
To raise up from a prostrate position.
To awake from sleep; to cause one to awake.
To raise up; to excite; to stir up; applied to the mind.
To rouse one to action.
To format, initialize, as a computer disk. Cf. hoʻonohonoho.
To perfume.

Redup. of hoʻāla; to keep awake; to awaken or reawaken; to incite to action. Cf. ʻoālaala. He mea hoʻālaala ke kope, coffee is something that keeps [one] awake.
The intensive of the foregoing.
Ho for hoo, ala, road, and kaa, to roll. To cause to roll; to roll along a road.

To stir one asleep so as to wake him; to punch; to touch; to shake so as to waken one; hoalalahia aku ua kane hele loa nei au la.
Street name.
Neighbor, close associate or friend.
Hoa, companion, and launa, friendly. A companion on intimate terms; an intimate friend always near. One in the habit of rendering kind offices; a neighbor.
Caus/sim of ʻalawa.
Hoa, companion, and lawaia, a fisherman. A fellow fisherman; a fishing companion.
Fellow laborer or worker, helper.
Hoa, companion, lawe, to bear, and hana, work. A fellow laborer; a fellow workman; a helper; an assistant. See LAWEHANA.

definitions.dtxt: Sharer, partner.

definitions.dtxt: One who works with another; a partner in labor.

To stir up waves, agitate, confuse; to cause tumult.

That which may be waved. Mohai hoali, a wave-offering.

To offer, as a sacrifice.
To stir up, as ashes.

Street name.

See HOALI 2. To offer frequently to the gods.
See aliali, clear.
Ho for hoo, and aliali, to whiten. To make white, as snow or paper.
To scar, deface.

Street name.
Same as hoa aliʻi.
A contraction for hoaalii or hoa'lii. The companion of the king or high chief; kukuluia i hale kamala no ka hoalii, a moe no ka hoalii ma ua hale la.
See aliʻi, chief.

definitions.der: [ho for hoo, and alii, chief; king]

Companion or contemporary of equal status.
Like term, in math. Cf. paukū, hua paʻa.
Street name.
Caus/sim of ʻalo. I ka hoʻalo ʻana, presentation, as to a monarch.
To shun, dodge, avoid, escape, omit, skip; omission; to alternate or place irregularly, as strips of thatch (FOR. 5:651).

Ho for hoo, and alo, to dodge.
To shun or avoid; to escape from. To pass over or by.
To skip over, as in counting; ka hana i kekahi la, ka noho wale i kekahi la, to work one day, to do nothing one day. See ALO.
To alternate, as in computer program.
Fellow sharer, receiver, partaker.
A fellow receiver; a partaker with one.
One who receives as much as another; ka loaa like.
See HOALO. To dodge or pass by frequently.
Friend. Cf. aloha. Kona hoaloha, his friend. hoʻohoaloha To make friends, be friendly, befriend.
A contraction for hoaaloha. A friend; a beloved companion; one on friendly terms. See HOAALOHA.
Street name.
Rare var. of hoʻālohaloha
Ho for hoo, and aloha, to love.
See ālohaloha.
Ho for hoo, and aloha, to love.
To love; to fondle; to cherish.
To give thanks for something received.
To make suit to; to pay respects to. To apply to for a favor. Laieik. 72.
Var. of hoʻālohaloha.
To slacken, loosen, hang down, bend down, stoop; depression, slack. Kī hōʻalu, slack key.
See ʻalu, depression.
Flexibility; pliableness; humility; a bending down.
Yielding; bending; loose; hanging down.
Ho for hoo, and alu, flexible.
To be flexible; to loosen; to hang down.
To bow down; to make low; to be humble; to courtesy. See ALU.
Place, Makiki Heights, Honolulu. (TM)
Street name.
To slacken, loosen; to make gathers, as in a skirt; a gatherer, as on sewing machines; yielding, loose, flexible, soft.
See ʻaluʻalu, loose.
Softness; a yielding to any pressure; humility.
Hanging loosely; bending down; yielding.
See HOALU and ALU. To be soft; flexible; yielding.
To bow down; to be humble.
Fellow worker, especially one helping to rear a child. Cf. luhi.

definitions.dtxt: A companion or fellow laborer in any work or business, whether there be much or little fatigue; eia keia, e o'u hoaluhi.
Street name.
Roommate.
Street name.

To begin to ripen. Fig. Adolescents beginning to mature. Usually called hāʻama.
To begin to ripen, as ohias and other fruit, but not yet soft.
Street name.
Emulation, as in a computer printer.
Fellow citizen.

To let, as in math problems; to assign a value or power.

definitions.dtxt: Sleeping companion, bedfellow.

Hone, whetstone, grindstone; to rub, grind.
To brandish, as a whip; to threaten. Hoana e hoʻeha, assault and battery.
Joining, joint, binding. See hoa 2.

Same as kōkala, porcupine fish.
A hone; a whetstone; a grindstone.
He hoana e paa ai ka waa, a polishing stone for finishing a canoe.

To rub, as with a stone; to grind, as with a grindstone. See ANAI. But hookala is more often used for grinding, i.e., for sharpening tools.
To make believe; to make pretense.

A crooking; a bending; an undulating motion; protuberances. See ANAPUU.
See HOANA, to grind. To twist; to bend; to undulate, as the air.
See anaʻē.
To lay up; to stow away for future use.

A tall, slim, stoop-shouldered man.
Anything like a humpbacked person. See KANAHUA.

Caus/sim. of ʻanahua.
Grindstone, rolling grindstone.
A grindstone. See HOANA.
To turn a grindstone; to grind or sharpen, as an edged tool.
To unitize, in math.
Light from reflection; a bright flashing light, like lightning; any reflected or sudden light.

To caper, cavort; to twist and turn the body, especially in the finale of a hula with rapid hip movements.

To turn, as on hinges.
To bend, as a flexible piece of timber; to form a curve. See ANAPAU.
A crook; a bending; a protuberance.
A crooking; a bending; an undulating motion; protuberances. See ANAPUU.
See HOANA, to grind. To twist; to bend; to undulate, as the air.
To throw up in heaps.
See HOANAANAPUU above. To crook, as a piece of timber; to be uneven, as a rope of unequal size; to project; to make an angle. See ANAPUU.
Street name.
See ani, to beckon.
To wave something.
Street name.
See the verb. Pride; self confidence; a high, daring spirit. See HOAANO and AANO. Boasting of one’s bravery. See HAANO.

Hoano e, to set apart for a particular purpose, either good or bad; to keep back; to conceal; to embezzle property.

A neighbor; one who resides with or near by another.

To update, as a computer program; to refresh, as a computer screen. Cf. hoʻopuka hou loa.

Fellow worker.

See HOAKI.

Close, intimate, or personal friend.

To move gently a little; to dodge.

To offer a sacrifice; to courtesy.

To converse. See HOAUHEEHEE.
To conjugate, decline. Ka hōʻaui ʻana, declension, conjugation.

To tag or strike out, in baseball. Comb. hō- + ʻauka. Cf. ʻauka.
To make attractive, neat.

Nice; well dressed; straight as a stick; skillful; mikioi, palawaiki, hoakamai.

To pass the night.
A cherishing; a fondling, as a child or a pet animal; fondness; attachment.

To fondle; to cherish in the bosom, as a child or a pet.

A companion of a messenger; one who accompanies a messenger.

To flock, collect. See ʻāuna.

To make a ditch, plow a furrow; to cut a wedge or fork.

Redup. of hōʻauwaha.
Street name.

All Hawaiian species of the genus Pittosporum, trees and shrubs with narrow leaves clustered at branch ends, and thick-valved fruits containing many seeds surrounded by a sticky substance; considered poisonous (KAM. 64:124, 140). Cf. ʻaʻawa hua kukui. Also hāʻawa.

To make bitter to make a concoction of leaves or bark to extract dye colors.
Name of a tree or shrub.
Ho for hoo, and awa, bitter.
To cause bitterness; to make bitter to the taste.
To be hard; to be cruel; to oppress; more often hoawaawa.
Lane, McCully and Bingham sections, Honolulu, named for native trees and shrubs of the genus Pittosporum.
Street name.
Canoe companion, mate.
Canoe rigging, tackle.
The tackling or rigging up of a canoe, tying on the ako, etc.; o ka aha, he mea hoawaa ia, a e holo ai.
To embitter, make bitter or sour; bitter tasting.
Bitterness to the taste. Fig. Hardship.
Bitterness; sourness; badness.
A rising in the stomach from sourness or other causes.
Bitter to the taste; severe; cruel; hard.
Ho for hoo, and awaawa. See AWA.
To be bitter to the taste; to make bitter; to cause bitterness.
To be hard; to be cruel; to embitter one’s life; to curse.
For hoawaia, passive. To be bitter; to cause bitterness; to cause sadness, sorrow, suffering. See AWA and AWAHIA.
A kind of hoʻawa (Pittosporum kauaiense), a tree to 12 m high, found only on Kauaʻi, with large leaves to 25 by 8 cm, more or less downy beneath, and with quadrangular fruits 1.3 cm in diameter.
See awāwa, valley.
Ho for hoo, and awawa, a ditch. To make a ditch or furrow. See AWAWA.
To carry. See ʻawe, pack, burden.
Ho and awe, a burden. A burden; a weight carried on the back.

To carry on the back; a burden so carried.

Anything made small or diminished.
A reddish color; an indistinct color, like the sea at times.
Faded; discolored.
I kikohukohu hoaweawea a ke kai.—Mele.
To discolor; to be colored a reddish brown, like red that is faded.
Street name.

Paddle, oar; to paddle, row. Fig. To travel, get to work, continue working. Kāna hoe (FS 21), his paddle. Hoe aku i ka waʻa, paddle ahead the canoe [do your share; continue; keep going]. hoʻohoe Caus/sim.; to have a canoe paddled.
To draw in the breath and expel it with a whistling sound, as when tired.
A bird reported by Kepelino as being the size of the ʻōʻō and black and gray.
A paddle for a canoe; an oar for a boat.
Street name.
Pas/imp. of hoe 1; let’s get started, go ahead.
To arrive.
Land section and stream, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi. (FOR. SEL. 114) Valley, Waimea district, Kauaʻi.
To approach.
To aerate. Comb. hoʻ- + eaea. See eaea.
Probably same as ʻekaha ʻula fern, but according to some it is Elaphoglossum pellucidum, a smaller Elaphoglossum than the ʻēukaha ʻula.
To wet, drench, soak; tearfully sulky, as a crying child. Ua hōʻeʻelo, drenching rain.
Mysterious, mystifying, incomprehensible. Hōʻeʻepa wale hoʻi nā hana a kēlā keiki, that boy’s behavior is certainly mysterious.
To inflict pain or punishment, to hurt, oppress.
To hurt. See ʻeha.
Dangerous weapon.
Ho for hoo, and eha, pain. To cause pain; to give pain.
Same as ʻoehaʻa Fig. Unreliable, unstable. Hoehaʻa nohoʻi ua Oʻahu maka ʻewaʻewa, unreliable are the Oʻahu people who avert the eyes.
Pain; distress, either of body or mind; vexation; perplexity.
Painful; distressing; difficult; troublesome.
Ho for hoo, and ehaeha, the reduplication of eha. To give pain, bodily or mentally; to vex; to harass; to get one into perplexity; to oppress.
Street name.
A West African vine, the bleeding heart (Clerodendrum thomsonae), with red and white flowers, grown for ornament.
See ʻēheu, wing.
Street name.
Redup. of hoe 1; paddling back and forth.
Redup. of hoe 2; a plaintive prolonged sound, as of the nose flute. Cf. hoene 1.
Shoulder blade (used after iwi).
See lipi hoehoe.
A wind instrument among Hawaiians somewhat resembling the flute.
See HOE. The shoulder-blade, from its resemblance to a canoe paddle; ka iwi ma ke kumu o ka iwi uluna.
See HOE, a paddle. To row a canoe or boat here and there.
Same as hoe 2.
See HOEHOE above and ANA. To play softly on the hoehoe; hence,
To be joyful. See HOENE.
To bore; to pierce through in boring; e hoehoena iloko o ka pepeiao.
Tide.
Redup. of hoene 1.

definitions.dtxt: To pierce the ear lobes with acid. (And.)
Poor, destitute, sick. (And.)
To be poor; destitute; sick.
A name for a Niʻihau pāwehe design in plaiting.
To drive or shoo away; to stir, as a fire. Cf. ehuehu 1.
To drive, stir. See -ehu.

To do a thing quickly.

To soil, make dirty.
See ʻeka.
A paddle with a blade narrower than the hoe nanue.
To shorten; to pucker up, wrinkle, as the nose.
See ʻekekeʻi.
Caus/sim of ʻekepue. E hōʻekepue ana ʻoe i ke aha? Why are you so secretive?
To blacken, darken, become dark.

Ho for hoo, and eleele, dark. To make black; to darken.
Caus/sim of ʻeleʻeleu; vivacious, energetic, full of life.
Robbery; a lying in wait to rob one; deceit; treachery.
To behave like an old man; to pretend to be an old man.
To animate. See ʻeleu.
Caus/sim of ʻeleu; to animate, stir into action, animated.
Catalyst, i.e., a substance which increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being permanently changed itself. Lit. animate reaction. Also ʻūmōʻauiwawe.
