Urging; throwing in.
To urge on; to push along; to cram down; e ohiki iloko.
To kindle up, as a flame; o ke ahi nana e hoelo wela.
Caus/sim of ʻelo; wet, soggy.
To press on; to urge forward.
Caus/sim of ʻeloʻelo. Ka ua hōʻeloʻelo, a drenching rain.
To reduce, diminish, lessen, draw back, curtail, discount. Hoʻēmi kino, hoʻēmi momona, reduce in weight.
Cheap. hoʻēmi To lower the price, cheapen; cheap. Kūʻai hoʻēmi, reduction sale. Hoʻēmi panakō, bank discount.
To reduce, diminish, cheapen. See emi 1, 2.
Ho for hoo, and emi, to lessen.
To cause a diminution; to lessen.
To shrink; to become blunt, as an edged tool.
To return backwards; to fall behind.
To drive back; to put down.

Discount; to discount, as a price for merchandise. Ke loaʻa kēia kūpona iā ʻoe, he loaʻa mai ka hoʻēmi iā ʻoe ma ka hale kūʻai. If you have this coupon you can get a discount at the store. ʻEhia ka hoʻēmi o kēia uaki? What’s the discount on this watch?
Kūkā hoʻēmiemi. Plea bargain, as in the negotiation of an agreement between a prosecutor and a defendant.
See HOEMI. To shrink back, as the mind; to doubt; to hesitate.
T o decelerate. Lit. cause to decelerate. Cf. emi ka māmā holo. See also piʻi ka māmā holo, hoʻopiʻi i ka māmā holo.
To diet, reduce. See papaʻai.
Vowel reduction, in linguistics. See pua woela and entries under woela.
Ho for hoo, and emu, to throw away. To cast away; to banish; to send away; to drive off; to drive off as one drives off hogs.
Paddling. Aia nō i kāu hoena, it’s up to you to paddle [to decide, start].
Caus/sim of ʻena.
Ho for hoo, and ena, to rage, as fire.
To cause to burn; to glow with heat.
To be in anger; to exhibit a high degree of anger. See ENA.
To cause heat, heat; to rouse to anger. Ua hōʻaʻā ʻia ke ahi e kuʻu inaina, a ʻe ʻenaʻena ʻia, a fire is kindled by my anger and shall burn.
To glow, as stones red hot in a fire. See ENA.
Same as hoe nenue.
Street name.
A soft sweet sound, as of song; to sound softly, rustle, sough, as the wind.
Var. of ʻowā 5. Mākahi hoene, a net mesh somewhat larger than the width of a finger.
To use a douche or enema; enema, medicine, injection, abortion. Nā hoene wai ʻakika hoʻomake ʻanoʻano puponika, acid solution for killing bubonic germs.
A syringe.
To give an injection; e halalo; to administer medicine.
Pleasure; enjoyment; o ka hoene ku o ka uwe a ka lani.
To sing; to be joyful; to play well on an instrument.
To feel animosity or enmity; to make an enemy.
A type of paddle named for nenue fish, with broad and round blade.
Easily frightened, shy, wary, coy; to cause to be wild.
Ho for hoo, and eno, to be wild. To run as wild; to be scary, as an animal once tame, but has become wild. See AHIU.
Street, Kalihi Waena, Honolulu. (TM)
Street name.
To deceive, cheat.
To deceive. See ʻepa.
Ho for hoo, and epa, to deceive. To deceive; to cheat; to act basely in everything. See EPA.
Freq. of hōʻepa. To act out a general bad character; to steal; to cheat; to slander, etc. See EPA.
Street name.
To stir up. See ʻeu.
A. To stir up, incite, animate, encourage, bestir.

example_txt.txt: Hōʻeu, kukupu, ʻīnana, kū i luna o ka moku.
Bestir, grow, animate, rule the island.

definitions.dtxt: B. Cap. Name of a star.
A bird name (no data).
Ancient surfing area, Kaimū, Hawaiʻi (Finney and Houston 26), now called Kaimū.
To encourage, stir, rouse, excite; vivacious, spirited. See chant, puʻuwai.

chants.chtran: Your animated genital
chants.chtxt: Kō maʻi hōʻeuʻeu

definitions.dtxt: Rally; inspirational meeting.
Steering paddle or oar, rudder, helm. He hoe uli, just a steering paddle [a wagging tongue].
A rudder.
One-sided, crooked; to cause not to fit.
See ʻewa, crooked.
Ho for hoo, and ewa, to turn aside. To be one-sided; to lean over; to sway to and fro like an old grass house in the wind.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: ʻElua nō āna mau hoe waʻa.

definitions.dtxt: Oarsman, paddler; to paddle a canoe.
An oarsman; one who rows a boat or paddles a canoe. Laieik. 35.
To row or paddle a canoe.
A measure, both hands full, used in giving out food, small fish, etc.; a small measure box or calabash.
To grasp; to seize hold of with the hand; to hold fast; e puili.
Street name.
Same as hani 1. Hohani me ka ʻōʻō i ka puʻe, soften the hill with the digging stick.
Cowardly; coward, cowardice. (FS 81) He kaua kamaliʻi, he hōhē wale, a battle of children, just cowards [quarrels of children are not worth worrying about].
Fear; terror.
A coward.
Fearful; timorous.
Probably for hoohee. To be afraid; to flee. To flee from fear. To be overcome or routed; aole e hohe ka ilo ma ka lua ahi, e ai mai no.
Faint-hearted; weak.
A fleeing without cause; cowardice.
Street name.
A native fern (Dryopteris glabra) with rather finely divided fronds.
To sink down, as a canoe in the water.
To leap or slide down, as one from a pali.
To jet, as water into a canoe where there is a hole; ke hoho mai la ka liu.
To snore, snort, bray, heehaw, splash, gurgle, breathe hard, draw in mucus. hoʻohohō Caus/sim.; to cause a snort.
Snow; the spray of water from a cataract.
The distant sound of a small cataract.
See Ho, to breathe. To snore; to breathe hard; to gurgle, as one breathing through water in the throat.
To snort, as a horse; alaila, hoho mai ka lio.
To cry out; to shout after. See HOOHO.
Same as hoahoa, tapa beater, washing stick.
A cane; a staff; a war club, an instrument for knocking down an adversary. See PAHOA.
See HOA, to strike. To strike repeatedly on the head with a stick.
To beat kapa after coloring that it may be soft; hohoa kapa, to beat kapa with a stick on a stone.
To strike, as in fighting.
To smooth kapa out by beating; applied to the first process in beating.
Redup. and plural of hoʻi 1, to leave.
See HOI, to return. To return again. Gram. § 209.
Redup. of hoʻi 1, to leave; to return often.
Wheezy. Cf. FOR. 4:169.
Redup. of hoka 1, 2. hoʻohohoka Caus/sim.
See HOKA. To be ashamed.
Neutral, as particles in an atom. Redup. of hoki. See ikehu uila hohoki. See also ʻāne, ʻine. Huna hohoki. Neutron.
Street name.
To spread out, unfold, unfurl, as tapa, mats, clouds, wings; to extend, stretch, diffuse. Cf. hola, maʻihohola, pāhola.
Open; opened; unsealed; me ka palapala i hoholaia, with an open letter.
See HOLA, to spread out. To unfold and spread down, as a mat; to spread out, as a kapa or garment; hohola i ke kapa.
To spread out, i.e., to smooth a cloth that has been ruffled.
To spread out, as a net.
To spread up, i.e., to make up, as a bed.
To spread or stretch out, as the visible heavens. To spread out, as the clouds.
To stretch out, as the hand. To spread out, as the wings of a bird.
To spread over, as darkness or dark clouds.
To calm; to soothe; to prepare to hear or receive information.
To open; to enlighten the mind.
To set forth; to manifest.
To make a gesture or stretch out one’s hand in speaking. See UHOLA and MAHOLA.
Redup. of hole 1, 2.
See HOLE, to skin; to peel. To peel off the skin, as a banana; to skin, as an animal.
To peel; to rub; to file off.
Redup. of holo, to run, sail. hoʻohoholo Caus/sim. Hoʻohoholo ʻia akula ka hūpē i loko, snuffle up mucus.
See HOLO, to run; to sail. To run; to sail; to glide swiftly.
PASS. To be driven swiftly by the wind. lak. 3:4.
To put out one’s hand to take a thing. See HOHOLA 6.
Redup. of holu 1.

chants.chtran: The ʻāhihi shrub sways in the wind
chants.chtxt: Hoholu ka ʻāhihi i ka makani

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of homa.
Reduced in flesh; poor; lean.
See HOMA, lean. To be poor in flesh; to be lean.
Acrid odor, unpleasant body odor of perspiration; to smell thus. Cf. honohono 5; pepeiao hohono. hoʻohohono To cause or produce such an odor.
A strong offensive smell; a stench; the smell of anything.
To smell strongly, as tar or burning sulphur; to cause a strong offensive smell.

definitions.der: [Probably PPN fonu, full, as of liquid; PCP fofonu, deep]
definitions.dtxt: Deep, profound; depth, soundings. He kanaka hohonu o ka ʻike, a man with profound knowledge. hoʻohohonu To deepen.
The deep, i.e., the sea; the depth.
Deep, as a pit; as a well.
To be deep, as water; deep down, as a pit.
To be full, i.e., deep, as the sea at full tide.
Height or depth, in math. Also ana hohonu. Cf. ākea, laulā, loa, lōʻihi. See kiʻekiʻe.

example_txt.txt: ʻEhia ʻīniha ka loa, ka laulā a me ka hohonu o kēnā pahu?
How many inches is the length, width and height of that box?

definitions.dtxt: Tall, thin.
Long, thin, slender or spare, as a man; he kanaka hohopa, a thin slender man.
See OHULE, bald. Bald, as the head; baldheaded.
Street name.

Bitter yam (Dioscorea bulbifera, synonym D. sativa), a vine with cylindrical stem, heart-shaped leaves, small tuberous root, round aerial tubers. The tubers, used only in times of famine, need long washing to make them fit to eat. Called piʻoi on Kauaʻi. See Kauluhoi.

example_txt.txt: Ua ua paha, ke ulu nei ka hoi.
Perhaps it’s been raining, the hoi is growing [said when someone looks happy, a play on hoi 1 and hoi 2].

definitions.dtxt: Same as hoihoi. Kū ʻole i ka hoi, not suiting; displeasing.
The name of a vine bearing a bulbous root, eaten in time of scarcity, acrid to the taste.
To leave, go or come back; to cause to come back. Cf. hoʻi hou.

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻole e hoʻi kō wahine ia mau hana.
These things won't cause your wife to return.

definitions.dtxt: To enter, as an institution or last resting place.
A parting chant to which hula dancers dance as they leave the audience.
Marriage of a chief with the daughter of a brother or sister; to do so (a means of increasing the rank of the offspring). (Malo 55)
Particle intensifying preceding base. See kāhoʻi, nohoʻi, Gram. 7.5.
Also, too, besides. (Gram. 7.5)
Part. expressing doubt, uncertainty. (Gram. 7.5)
The name of a state of marriage among chiefs.
To return; to go back; with hou, to return again; imperatively, e hoi, and o hoi, go back; return.
Also; besides; moreover; indeed; an intensive word; no hoi, also; besides.
To revert, as in computer program.
Pas/imp. of hoʻi, to leave.
Niʻihau name of a sea tern.
Caus/sim of ʻieʻie.

Intensive of hoʻi 5 (often written as two words). (Gram. 7.5) E hele hoʻihā kāua, well, let’s go then. Maikaʻi hoʻihā, very good indeed. I Hawaiʻi hoʻihā me Pele e noho ai (FS 239), then stay at Hawaiʻi with Pele.
Afar off; at a very great distance. See LOIHI.
Street name.
See ʻihi, sacred.
To treat thus; to hallow.

Tapa or pandanus fitted into a hoop and placed on the head of an attendant (kahu), serving as a holder for a food container from which the chief or favorite child was served, a means of bestowing high honor.
See iho, to go down, and -iho.
Street name.

Pleased, interesting, entertaining, happy, joyful, amused; pleasure, happiness, joy, delight, enjoyment, interest, cheerfulness. Hoihoi ʻole, unpleasant, unenthusiastic, unhappy, uninterested, dispirited, dull, boring, to dislike. Mea e hoihoi ai, treat, pleasure. hoʻohoihoi To entertain, amuse, charm, delight, encourage, please.
Joy; gladness; good feeling; rejoicing; cheerfulness. Gratification in a thing. Me ka hoihoi, me ka hauoli ame ka manao lana, with good feeling, with joy and with hope.
Glad; joyful; gratified; well pleased.
To be pleased; to rejoice; to be joyful.
Hoo. To refresh; to assist; to give pleasure. To be greatly consoled.
To reprove.
To return, send back, restore. Cf. hoʻi 1. E hoʻihoʻi aku ʻoe i ka lio iā Kale, take the horse back to Charles. Pēlā anei ʻoukou e hoʻihoʻi aku ai iā Iēhowa? Do you thus requite Jehovah?
In a neuter sense, to return; to go back; used for hoi.
See HOI. Used actively, to return a thing to its former place; to restore; to bring back.
To send back; to dismiss.
To change one thing for another.
To return; to restore, as a rebellious people to their allegiance.
To return an answer; e hoihoi i ka olelo.
To save, in volleyball. Niʻihau. Also lou. Haʻawina hoʻihoʻi. Homework.
Restoration, as of sovereignty; to restore sovereignty. Lā Hoʻihoʻi Ea, Restoration Day.
To undo, as in computer program. Cf. hoʻokaʻawale, hoʻōki.
To go back, return, retreat, revert, backslide, deteriorate morally. Poʻe lālā hoʻi hope, backsliding members [of a church].
Hoi, to return, and hope, backwards. To go back after an advance; to return to former practices after a reformation; to revolt, as one taken captive; to turn back.
To go or come back, return.
Repeat sign in music.
In music, name of the character signifying a repeat.
Hoi, to return, and hou, again. To return again.
Stinginess; closeness in dealing; hard and cruel oppression upon the weak and poor.
Ho for hoo, and ii, parsimonious.
To save; to gather together little things.
To be close; parsimonious; pinching in a bargain.
To squeeze or work out of another some little favor.
To be hard upon; to oppress; applied to begging for charitable purposes; o ka hookohukohu ame ka hoii a kanaka no ke Akua. See II and KAII 3.

To strain and grunt as during real or false pain or exertion; labor pains. Fig. Stingy. No ka nui o ka iʻa, hō ʻiʻī nā lawaiʻa i ka huki ʻana i ka ʻupena, because of the great number of fish, the fishermen groaned as they pulled on the net.
Caus/sim of ʻiʻī. (often used with maka).
See ʻiʻī, tight.
Caus/sim of ʻīʻī. to cause to sour.
See ʻīʻī, sour.
Ho for hoo, ii, to be hard, and maka, face.
To forbid or discountenance iniquity openly, but favor it secretly in practice.
To play the hypocrite. See HOII.
Street name.

To make a great effort, work hard, encourage, animate, strengthen, fortify, try, strive, strain; calisthenics. Hoʻoikaika Kalikiano, Christian Endeavor Society. Hoʻoikaika kino, body-building exercise. Pili hoʻoikaika kino, relating to body building, athletic. Pōhaku hoʻoikaika, stones lifted as a test of strength. E hoʻoikaika ana au e hana i kēia, I’m going to make a great effort to do this. Ua hoʻomaka ʻia nā hoʻoikaika pāloka ʻana mawaena o nā kālaiʻāina ʻekelu, political campaigns were begun by three political parties;
See ikaika, strong.
Part. Very, great (often written as two words). He uʻi hoʻi kau, very beautiful indeed. (Gram. 7.5)
See Ehoʻikauʻiomānoauaahiahi.
Street name.
To show, exhibit. For the many important meanings see ʻike.

example_txt.txt: description, example, illustration; to tell the nature of, describe
shortened review, synopsis, sketch, summary, outline, resumé

definitions.dtxt: To show, make known, display, tell, exhibit, reveal, indicate, inform, report, notify, explain, testify, cause to know or seen, discover, announce, allege; acquaint; testimony, notice, information; identifying characteristics, as of land claims; proof, token guide, exhibition.

example_txt.txt: false witness; to lie, commit perjury
false witness; to lie, commit perjury

definitions.dtxt: Witness, as in court.
School commencement; to hold commencement.
Congregational convention of various Sunday Schools with singing and recitation.
That which shows or is shown; an exhibition, as of a school; a witness of an event; a witness in a court of justice. SYN. with ikemaka, also hoikemaka, an eye-witness. Pilip. 1:8.
Exhibiting; showing; making plain.
Ho for hoo, and ike, to know.
To cause to know; to make known.
To show; to make a display; e unihi, e puka iwaho; to put outside for appearance; to exhibit; to explain, as a language.
Openly; visibly; clearly.

example_txt.txt: oral report, presented as a speech
to take a test; also kākau i ka hōʻike

definitions.dtxt: To report. Cf. hōʻike haʻi waha, hōʻike palapala.
Display, as on computer screen. See entries below.
Pas/imp. of hōʻike. Ē Kāneikawaiola hōʻikea mai i ke ola (prayer), O Kāne-of-the-living-water, bring forth life. (PPN kitea).
Revelation (Biblical). See ʻike.
A showing; exhibiting.
The name of the last book in the Bible, Revelations.
Oral report. Also ʻōlelo hōʻike. Cf. hōʻike palapala.
Geography.
Geography. Nā kuhikuhina hōʻike honua. Geographical coordinates.
Key caps, on computer program.
Given, as in a math problem.
To display, exhibit, as in a museum or show; entertainment, play, fair, exposition, circus, carnival, show of almost any kind; demonstration. (PPN kitekite).
Display, exhibit, specimen.
See ʻikeʻike for the many meanings.
Ho for hoo, and ike, to know. To know, more particularly than hoike; to make known clearly; to communicate knowledge; to point out truths or facts.
To show and tell, as in a preschool or elementary school class.
Fair. Also fea. See entry below and papa hōʻikeʻike.
Zoo.
Aquarium. Cf. pahu iʻa.
To prewrite, as part of the writing process, i.e., introducing the topic through brainstorming, discussion, presentations, etc. Lit. show ideas. See kūkā ma ka pūʻulu.
Chronology.

definitions.der: [Lit. first-try test. Cf. hōʻike muli aʻo]
definitions.dtxt: Pretest.

definitions.der: [Lit. after-teaching test. Cf. hōʻike mua aʻo]
definitions.dtxt: Posttest.

definitions.der: [Lit. report (by) writing. Cf. hōʻike haʻi waha]
definitions.dtxt: Written report.

A native vine (Smilax sandwichensis), growing wild in the mountains; the leaves are heart-shaped, shiny, with longitudinal veins, much like the hoi but bearing tendrils; the roots are tuberous and not palatable. Also akaʻawa.
Pain of hunger. Cf. houpo lewalewa.
To collect; to bunch together, as fish in a net.
See ʻili.
Ho for hoo, and ili, to strike; to hit.
To cause to bring or to come upon one.
To place upon, i.e., to put on board a ship.
To strike upon, as a ship upon a rock; to go ashore; to strand.
To fall to one, as property from a parent; to inherit. See ILI.
To cause poverty; to behave as if poor. He hōʻilihune kona noho ʻana, he lives as if in poverty.
See ʻilihune, poor.
Ho for hoo, and ilihune, poor; destitute.
To make one poor; to deprive one of his property.
To be humble; lowly. See ILIHUNE.
Street name.
To gather, collect, pile up, save, store away, glean, assemble; collection. Aia hōʻiliʻili ʻoe i nā huawaina, when you gather the grapes. He hōʻiliʻili poʻoleka, a stamp collection.
To collect. See ʻiliʻili 2.
Ho for hoo, and iliili, to collect.
To collect together, as things of any kind in one place.
To lay up; to heap together.
To collect. See hōʻiliʻilina.
Collection. Comb. hōʻiliʻili + -na. Hōʻiliʻilina poʻoleka. Stamp collection.
To cause poverty. He keiki hōʻilikole, a child that makes paupers [of the parents, as with expenses].
Ho for hoo, and ilikole, raw skin. Like the foregoing, only more strong. To make very poor; to deprive of all comforts. See ILIKOLE.

Heir, inheritance, legacy, estate, heritage, bequest; successor (so used in the official English version of the Constitution of 1852, Article 25). Hoʻoilina mōʻī, heir to the throne, crown prince or princess. Palapala hoʻoilina, will. Hoʻoilina ʻōlelo, a will made verbally; one entrusted to speak for another. Kona mau hoʻoilina, his heirs.
See ilina.
To grade or level, as a road.
Var. spelling of hoʻoilo. See ilo 2 and -ilo. Ka hale hoʻīlo, the winter house.
Land term of unknown meaning used in the 1840s, perhaps a winter-time plot.
The season of the year answering to winter in more northern latitudes.
Winter, the stormy season, from the interruption of regular trade winds. Hoilo is used in opposition to kau, the hot or summer season. The word is also written hooilo.
Wientry; pertaining to winter.
To go or come with no thought of returning; to go permanently.

To guess before hand; to predict something future; especially, to predict evil; to tell one when he was sick that he would die; i hoiloilo mai o mea ia'u e make, a ua ola; to give up a sick person to die as incurable.
See ʻīloli 1.

To feel the discomforts of pregnancy; to suffer emotional disturbance; to yearn for an absent lover; to be imbued with (often used favorably). Ka leo ʻolu hōʻīloli o ka waipahē (Kel. 10), sweet voice alive with tenderness. Hōʻīloli ke kai, the sea rages.
Street name.
Caus/sim of ʻimi.
See ʻimi, to look for.
Ho for hoo, and imi, to seek. To search diligently.
To cause to wink; to wink to get one to wink back.
See ʻimo, to wink.
Street name.
Returning, coming back; return.
Farewell gift, as to a parting guest after a feast.
See INA. To ease off; to hang down; to crook.
See inaina 1, wrath, and inaina 2.
Ho for hoo, and inaina, anger. To cause hatred; to stir up anger; to provoke one to anger.
Caus/sim of ʻīnaʻinau. See ex., hāʻule 3, hoʻokokoe. He mau hōʻināʻinau no nā keiki hoʻopāpā, interesting bits concerning the boys who played at contests of wit.
See ʻināʻinau.
Stream, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi.
See ʻīnana.

To animate, give life to. ʻO ka honua nui a Kāne i hoʻīnana a ʻahu kīnohinohi (Kep. 123), the great earth that Kāne gave life to and clothed decoratively. Ō hoʻūlu ʻoe, ō ʻīnana ʻoe, hoʻīnana i ke ola (prayer, PH 150), inspire, animate, give life.
Caus/sim of ʻinau. Hōkū ʻimoʻimo hōʻinau (Kel. 10), stars twinkling merrily.
Curse, defamation; to curse, revile. ʻŌlelo hōʻino hoʻonalonalo, veiled insult, slur.
To insult, malign, persecute, abuse, dishonor, defame, speak evil. Hōʻino wale, needlessly defame, damn. Hoʻopau hoʻoʻino ʻia, dishonorably discharged [as from the armed services].
See ʻino 1–4.
Reproach; contempt.
Berena hoino, bread of affliction.
Ho for hoo, and ino, bad.
To curse one. To vex; to harass; to harm; to injure; to cause reproach.
To make filthy; to defile. See INO.
Mai olelo hoino, do not revile.
That which is contemptible; a reproach; contempt.
To mar, deface, disfigure, break, damage, ruin, speak evil of.
Ho for hoo, and inoino (see INO), to deface. To disfigure; to sadden; to disguise, as the face by austerity.
See inu, to drink.
Ho for hoo, and inu, to drink. To give drink; to cause one to drink; generally written hohainu.
Street name.
Same as ʻuaʻu kani.
To become fleshy; to form a corm, fruit, tuber; to grow thick, as a stem.

chants.chtran: Truth from out of the night, formed flesh above, formed fruit above.
chants.chtxt: Mai ka pō mai ka ʻoiaʻiʻo, i hōʻiʻo i luna, i hua i luna.

definitions.dtxt: To take things in earnest or seriously.

A large native fern (Diplazium [Athyrium] arnottii) with subdivided fronds. The young fronds are eaten raw, much liked with raw fresh-water shrimps or with salted salmon. Only Orientals cook this fern. It was formerly sold in the market. It will not grow at low altitudes. Cf. pohole, the Maui name.
A species of plant, the tender leaves of which are used for herbs.
To iodize. Comb. hō- + ʻiokine. See ʻiokine.

A native fern (Dryopteris stegnogrammoides syn. Stegnogramma sandwichensis), resembling the kikawaiō, having large pinnate fronds, but the tip tapering to a point instead of forming a separate lobe. Young fronds are eaten raw, like those of the hōʻiʻo.
To behave like a rat; ratlike. Fig. To steal, cheat, lie in wait in order to assail.
Ho for hoo, and iole, a mouse. To cause to rush upon; to seize, as a cat does a mouse; to hold fast.
To force; to compel.
Ho for hoo, and iomo, to fall into the water without spattering. To bung up; to stop, as with a cork or bung.
To insulate. Comb. hō- + ʻīpale. See ʻīpale.
Ho for hoo, and ipo, a paramour. To commit fornication or adultery secretly.
Ho for hoo, and ipo, a paramour. To commit fornication or adultery secretly.
To make lofty, sacred; to elevate; shy, reserved.
Fear; trembling; anxiety.
Ho for hoo, and iu, to lay a kapu.
To lay a kapu upon a person, place or thing; to consecrate such person, place or thing to a particular purpose.
To create fear, as fear was connected with this kapu.
To be afraid. See IU.
Caus/sim of ʻiwi.
Ho for hoo, and iwi, crooked. See IWI.
Disappointed, thwarted, baffled; disappointment, frustration. Ā hoka! Serves you right! Good for you [insulting]! hoʻohoka To cause disappointment, chagrin; to frustrate, thwart, put to shame.
To squeeze, strain, as kava or liquids through fibers. Hoka ana lākou i ke ahu ʻawa (Ii 150–1), they were straining kava dregs [they were disappointed, a pun on hoka 1].
A mistake in understanding one’s words.
A blunder; carelessness in doing a thing.
Destitute; poor.
Blundering; careless.
To squeeze; to press; to take hold of; to gather up.
To search or look after; to examine into.
To strike; to attack.
To be destitute; to perish; to be destroyed.
To fail; to be disappointed. To fail; to forsake.
To be ashamed through a failure. Mai hoka au imua ona, e ole ka ekemu ana o ka waha.
Hoo. To put to shame. To be disappointed; to be mocked.
Same as hoʻokā. See kā 1. Ua ʻane hōkā ke anu i ka malama o Kāʻelo (Kep. 89), the cold really strikes during the month of Kāʻelo.
Dizzy; a dull ache, as in head or stomach.
For hookaa. See KAA. To cause to roll.
Mai hele i ahuawa, hokaawa; aka, pakele ae nei paha au i keia la.
To strain kava; a kava strainer.
To smudge, smear, blot.
For hookae. See KAE, to rub or blot out. To seize hold of awkwardly; to blunder in doing a thing.
To erase; to blot out.
To smite; to kill.
Redup. of hōkaʻe.
Redup. of hoka 1, 2. hoʻohokahoka Caus/sim.
See HOKA before. To feel demeaned; to be ashamed; hokahoka wale iho no ka mea haku ole, he is ashamed of himself who has no master.
Redup. of hōkai.

example_txt.txt: Kuha ihola ia ma ka lepo, ā hokahokai ihola i ke kuha ma ka lepo.
He spat on the ground and made clay of the spittle.

definitions.dtxt: To mix, as ingredients.
See HOKAI 3. To stir up; to mix, as two ingredients.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: Hōkai ua lawaiʻa o ke kai pāpaʻu, he poʻopaʻa ka iʻa e hoʻi ai.
A fisherman who blunders about in shallow water, takes home poʻopaʻa fish [easy to catch but not desirable].

definitions.dtxt: To confuse, disturb, meddle, mix up, spoil, interfere; to blunder along; nuisance, bother, confusion, disorder.
To cause confusion, mix up, bother; to blot out the memory.
Unprepared.
Disorderly; mischievously; wickedly.
For hookai. See KAI, hoo. To drive; to drive away; to banish; to dash, as a melon on the ground and break it.
To disregard; to squander; to misspend.
To turn upside down; to destroy; to blot out. To destroy utterly.
To put away; to do mischief generally; mea hokai, a destroyer.
To interfere, disturb, as would a child; to annoy. See kake 1.
Redup. of hōkake; to roil, as mud.
Hokalalu na holoholona ia mau malama.
Same as kakale, watery.
Mastoid infection.
A hard concretion in the flesh; a kernel; he mau wahi anoano ma ke kumu pepeiao, a malalo o ke a lalo.
The loss of appetite.
Thin in flesh; meager.
Hosanna.
Hockey. French. Hōkē alanui. Street hockey.
Street name.
Hotel.
See huila mūhune.
Same as hōkeo 1. Hōkelo ua, container for catching rain.
Container, general term.
Cloud chamber, i.e., a scientific device which detects nuclear particles through the formation of cloud tracks.
Bubble chamber, in chemistry.
Hottentot.
Street name.

Long gourd calabash, as used to hold food, clothing, fishing gear; any cooking pot. Fig. An empty container, a trifle. Cf. hōkeo kani. He wahi hōkeo wale nō, just an empty container [to have or know nothing].
To cherish secretly, as love. E hōkeo iho i ke aloha (song), cherish the love.
A variety of sweet potato.
The lower of two gourds which compose the drum.
He hulilau, a calabash to put clothes in when traveling on a canoe.
Kit, as of equipment needed for a particular activity. Cf. kini lapaʻau, kini poho ea, poho lāʻau pōulia.
Library, i.e., a temporary buffer for storage of codes or information in a computer program.
Database, as in a computer program; data bank, an organized collection of information, in math. See ʻikepili. Polokalamu hōkeo ʻikepili. Database program.
Wind instrument, as in a band.
Mule, ass.
Barren, of a woman. Modern.
An ass; a mule. Hoki keiki, a young ass.
definitions.notes: Note: Hoki is the Hawaiian pronunciation of the English word horse, which was first used, but afterward lio was applied to a horse, and hoki was applied to the ass and the mule.

definitions.dtxt: Same as hoʻokī. See kī 3.
Thin, wasted; tuberculosis, wasting sickness; consumption. Cf.
The phthisic. A consumption; a pining sickness.
Lean, low or thin in flesh.
See KII, also HOOKII. To dissolve; to pine away, as a diseased person. To pine away, as with the consumption.
Probable redup. of hōkī. (PH 121)
Same as hōkiʻi.
To be sick and famished away.
Street name.
Small gourd whistle; flute, pipe; to whistle.
A pipe; a whistle; some musical wind instrument played with the mouth.
For hookio. To play the pipe; to whistle.
Street name.
Gourd whistle; flute, pipe; to whistle.
An ancient wind instrument among Hawaiians, the pipe; among the Hebrews.
For hoʻokiokio. To pipe; to play on the pipe.
To whistle with hands cupped over the mouth; such a whistle. (Pūeoeo is said to be the sound of the whistle.)
Fat, fleshy, as thighs, buttocks, or calf.
To strike, threaten.
The fleshy movable part of a fat person or animal.
The buttock; applied to men and fat animals.
The inside of the thighs; ua pili na hoko, or ua hui na hoko on account of fatness.
The under part of the thigh.
Large; fat; rolling; applied to the thighs of men, women and fat animals.
To imitate.
Redup. of hoko 1, 2.
Large; fat; rolling; applied to the thighs of men, women and fat animals.
To market (something), i.e., to make available and promote the sale of a product. Comb. hoko (Māori, buy, sell) + -na.
Thin in flesh; meager. See HOKII.
A word; a thought; something rising in the mind; he wahi hoku iki ko'u no keia mea.
The asthma. See HOKII.
Night of the full moon. When this moon set before daylight it was called Hoku Palemo, Hoku that slips away. When it set after daylight it was called Hoku Ili, grounded Hoku. (Malo 32) Cf. hōkū, star.

example_txt.txt: the full moon of the night Hoku

definitions.dtxt: Hoʻohokuikalani n. Name of the daughter of Wākea and Papa. Hoku may be compared to Tahitian hotu, to produce fruit and Tongan fotu, to appear.
The name of the fifteenth day of the month.
Street name.
Star.
A star; hoku lele, a comet; ka poe hoku o ke kaei, the planets. The twinkling orbs of heaven.
Street name.

Nape of the neck, shoulders; main stem of a vine (Kep. 157). He kanaka hokua kano, a person with hard, strong shoulders. He nalu haʻaheo i ka hokua o ke kanaka, the proud surf at the nape of a man’s neck [a wind from the back, and a pun on hokua 2].
Tip of high waves, crest. See ex., hamohamo.
To lift up. (Kel. 152)
The lower and back part of the neck where it joins the shoulders.
The back between the shoulders.
A division of men at work; a party; a company where a number of men are divided into several companies, one of them is called a hokua.
Crest of a wave. Also hokua o ka nalu, hokua o ka ʻale. Cf. honua.
Street name.
Planet.
A moving or wandering star, i.e., a planet.
Street name.
Street name.
Probably same as alanuionāhōkūhoʻokele.
Street name.
Same as hōkū ʻaeʻa.
Street name.
Same as Hōkūloa. Called Hōkūaliʻiwahine in Kep. 83.
Hoku and amoamo, to wink. The twinkling or winking of the stars.
The motion of the winking of the eyes. See next word.
Street name.
Morning Star, Venus when seen in the morning. Also Hōkūloa, Hōkūaliʻi.
Hoku and ao, light. The morning star; the bright star; the planet Venus when it is the morning star. See also HOKULOA.
Street name.
Street name.
Same as hōkū ʻaeʻa.
Hoku and hele, to move. A planet. See HOKUAEA.
Planet. Hōkūhele Iowiana. Jovian planet. Hōkūhele o waho loa. Outer planet.
A design on Niʻihau mats.
See HOKU, asthma. Having the colic.
Filled with anger or unpleasant sensations; hokuhoku au iloko—e ake e hele a hookolokolo.
To breathe hard; to wheeze as one stuffed with food.
The star Sirius.

Hoku, star, hookele, to steer, and waa, canoe. Name of a star, the appearance of which was the signal for sailing on a voyage; a i ka wanaao, i ka puka ana o ka hokuhookelewaa, at the dawn of the morning, at the appearance of the star. Laieik. 36.
The name of a star that appeared just before the birth of a high chief.
Street name.
See Hoku.
Street name.
Street name.
Hoku and imoimo, to wink. Same as above.
Street name.
A Hawaiian constellation, perhaps Boōtes.
Starfish. Cf. more common peʻa.
Starfish.
Street name.
Land sections, Kailua and Honuʻapo qds., Hawaiʻi; named for a star called Hōkūpōkano. Heiau, Kamalō qd., south Molokaʻi.
Evening Star.
Evening Star or Sirius. Also Hōkūʻōpae.
Street name.
Southern Cross.
Jack, as used in the game of jacks. See kimo.
Morning Star. (Kep. 83)
Discomfort preceding bowel discharge; to suffer this. Fig. Angry, agitated.
Street name.
Elementary school, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Street name.
A navigational star, probably Arcturus; a zenith star above Hawaiʻi. (Kep. 83) Lit. clear (or happy) star. Also Leʻa.
Street name.
An unidentified star.
Street name.
Shooting star, meteor, any moving star.
Hoku and lele, to fly. A meteor.
Street name.
Moving star, planet.
Place near Laupahoehoe, Hawaiʻi, where ʻUmi hid his god when he was living incognito and in poverty. (FOR. SEL. 126)
Street name.
Street name.
Small star, asteroid.
Street name.
Same as Hōkūao. (Kep. 83)
Venus.
Hoku and loa, great. The morning star. See HOKUAO, also MANANALO.
Asteroid. Sh. hōkū + naʻinaʻi (Tah., small). Kāʻei hōkūnaʻi. Asteroid belt.
A name for the Milky Way. (Kep. 83)
Street name.
Peak, Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi.
Congregational church at Paʻauilo, Hawaiʻi.
Same as Hōkūkauʻōpae. (GP 34)
Street name.
Name of a constellation, perhaps Leo or the head of Cetus.
Street name.
North Star.
Sparkler, as fireworks.
See Hoku.
Street name.
Name of a star.
Street name.
Comet.
A comet. See the next word.
Comet. Cf. hōkū welowelo.
Street name.
Satellite star.
Satellite star. Cf. ukali, poelele.
Street name.
A star, perhaps Mars, but see Auhaele.
Mars. Also Hōkūʻulapīnaʻau.

Hill (4,115 feet high), Haukoʻi, Hawaiʻi, said to have been lifted out of the sea by a turtle and where Lonoikamakahiki of Hawaii defeated Kamalālāwalu of Maui (FOR. SEL. 188). Hill (1,400 feet high), Līhuʻe district, Kauaʻi. Coastal area, Hāna qd.; hill (2,504 feet high), Lahaina qd.; land division, Makawao, Maui.
Mars. Sh. Hōkūʻula + Holoholopīnaʻau (to differentiate from other stars called Hōkūʻula). Also Hōkūʻula.
Street name.
Street name.
Street name.
Shooting star, comet.
Shooting star. Cf. hōkū puhipaka.
A comet from its tail of light. A comet is also called by Hawaiians hokupuhibaka, tobacco-smoking star; also hokuhueloloihi, long-tailed star.
Heiau on cliff of Kaluahine, Hawaiʻi. See Koaʻekea.
Same as hohola, to spread. Cf. kauhola, mahola, pāhola.
Same as ʻauhuhu; to drug fish with this poison. ʻUpena hola, net used with this poison. Hele nō i ka hola iʻa i ka lā, go to poison fish in the daytime [more efficient to work by day]. Niʻihau.
Groin (rare, in chants, KAM. 64:124)
Hour, time, o'clock. Hola ʻehia kēia? What time is it?
The name of the root and stalk of the auhuhu, a poisonous and intoxicating plant, the bark of which was used in poisoning or intoxicating fish so they could be caught. See AUHOLA and AUHUHU.
The name of the system of fishing when they were to be caught by poisoning.
To poison or intoxicate fish with the hola or auhuhu.
To open; a hola ia ka waha a palahalaha; to spread out. See HOHOLA and UHOLA.
Hour. Abb. hl. See palena pau.
Pas/imp. of hola 1.

chants.chtran: A white tapa spread over the sea
chants.chtxt: He kapa kea i holahia lā i ke kai

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hola 1, 2. See papa holahola kānāwai laʻa.
See HOLA above. To poison or intoxicate fish.
See HOLA, to spread out. To spread out; to smooth; to smooth, as a kapa or cloth; to make up, as a bed.
Applied to the mind, to calm; to soothe; to open; to enlighten. See HOHOLA and UHOLA.
To blossom, as a flower or adolescent growing into maturity. Kaʻū. Holāholā wale ʻia aʻe nō ā pau ka pupuka, just having blossomed with an end to ugliness.
On time. ʻAʻole ʻo ia i hōʻea mai i ka hola kūpono; ua lohi ʻo ia. S/he didn't arrive on time; s/he was late.
Same as hola 1.
Street name.
Name of a mythical place. Stars observed by priests were Hōlanialiʻi and Hōlanikū.
Holland; Dutch.
Street name.
Street name.
To pass by, refuse to recognize.
To pass by; to run on.
Street name.
Same as hoʻolapa. See lapa 1, 2.
For hoolapa. See LAPA, a ridge. The act of rising or boiling up; the swelling or rising of a blister.
To disturb, roil; to spread, as fire. Fig. To flare, as anger. See saying, makaʻā. Ua hōlapu aʻe ke ahi ma Alanui Fremont, the fire spread on Fremont Street.
To stir up; to mix water and dirt; to make water dark colored by putting in dirt.
See mū hōlapu pale ʻea pau.
A collection or multitude of people assembled.
One person together with a collection of fowls, or other animals.
Street name.

To skin, peel, file, rasp, make a groove; to strip, as sugar-cane leaves from the stalk; furrow. Cf. papa hole, pohole, puhole, penis. Hole Waimea i ka ihe a ka makani (name song for Kamehameha I, Elbert and Mahoe 52), Waimea strips the spear of the wind [the wind refers to warriors, and the song describes their making of spears].
To squirm, twist, turn, fidget; to caress passionately. Cf. pīhole.
A bruise; a scratch or break in the skin. See POHOLE.
To curse.
To peel off; to skin; to flay.
To rasp; to file; to rub off.
To scratch or break the bark of a tree or skin of the flesh.
To notch the end of a spear; to make grooves, as in a kapa beater; hole ie.
Pas/imp. of hole 1, 2.
To nibble at food.
Redup. of hole 1, 2. ʻŌlelo ka waha, holehole ka lima, the mouth talks, the hand strips [of one who speaks as a friend but does unfriendly deeds].
To mix different feathers in a lei; mingling, as feathers.

See HOLE, to peel. To peel; to strip off, as the skin from the flesh; as the flesh from the bones; holehole iho la lakou i na iwi o Lono, they skinned the bones of Lono (Captain Cook), that is, separated the bones from the flesh.
To separate one thing from another.
Pas/imp. of hole 1. (FOR. 5:509)
To strip flesh from the bones, as formerly done with the dead, Fig. To tell evil of one’s relatives or reveal confidences.
Street name.

A small native tree (Ochrosia compta) related to the hao (Rauvolfia) and closely resembling it, but the leaves thicker, the yellow flowers fragrant, and the twinned fruits yellow and much larger. Formerly, bark and roots yielded a yellow dye for tapa.
Tapa dyed with hōlei; to dye thus.
An introduced yellow dotted cloth.
A variety of sweet potato.
Name of a tree used (bark and root) to color yellow.
To open; to gape open, as the eyelids, or as the labia feminarum.
Pali and ancient village, Puna qd., Hawaiʻi. A supernatural rat, ʻĀpua, lived here; he was shot by Pikoiakaʻalalā. Street, Diamond Head section, Honolulu. (TM)
To strip aerial roots of the ʻieʻie vine for baskets or plaiting.
See above. The name of those who prepared the ie for braiding or weaving.
Those who in connection with preparing the ie, also pounded kapa; a me ka poe holeie kuku kapa.
Hole, to peel, and ie, a vine. To peel the bark from the ie used in basket making.
See also the definition of hole iʻe.
To groove or carve figures in the iʻe tapa beater.
Holy Roller.
Place, Pālama, Honolulu.
Street name.
Same as hoʻoleʻoleʻo.
Street name.
To sprout, as plants or a youth’s beard.
To ask indirectly, seek to open conversation, search. ʻOi holi mai nei ʻo Lei, a noi maoli, Lei started with indirect hints, then asked directly.
The first appearance of a thing, as the first coming out of the beard of a young man.
To commence or start first; to go forward.
To beg earnestly, in such a manner as that one cannot be denied.
Weak, spindly, puny. (KL. line 371)
See -lili.
Immature and inferior, as breadfruit falling prematurely.
Haul in! Help!
Street name.
Two species of small, rare, endemic trees (Cryptocarya) in the laurel family, found only on Kauaʻi and Oʻahu.
Constantly in mind and thought.
Same as hōliʻoliʻo.
Rain name associated with Hawaiʻi and Oʻahu.
Same as liʻoliʻo 1; dazzled, as the eyes by sunlight.
Street name.

To run, sail, ride, go; to flow, as water; to run, as for political office; to slide, as an avalanche; fleet, fast; double time; landslide; to fare, progress. Cf. holoholo, holo i mua, holo lio, holomoku. Holo nui, to run fast, gallop. Holo ka hana, fast work. Ua holo ka ulu ʻana o ka pēpē, the baby is growing fast. Ka mea e holo ana, whatever goes; however it goes or happens. Pehea ka holo ʻana? How is it going? What fortune? hoʻoholo To sail, run; to cause to run, sail, run free, as a horse; to ride, as a horse; to add water, as to poi; to flush, as a toilet; to drive, as a carriage. Hoʻoholo ʻāwīwī, to speed up, accelerate. Hoʻoholo moa, to slide the moa dart. Hoʻoholo kāmelo, to ride camels. Hoʻoholo i ka wai o ka lua, to flush the toilet.

Decided, determined, agreed upon, settled, approved, passed, enacted. Ua holo kō kāua manaʻo, we have agreed. Ua holo ke kumu kūʻai, the price is agreed upon. hoʻoholo To decide, determine, enact, pass, resolve, enforce, appraise, settle, conclude; to manage, as a business; decision, judgment. Cf. ʻōlelo hoʻoholo. E hoʻoholo ʻia, be it resolved. Ka hoʻoholo kūʻokoʻa, independent judgment. Kōkua ʻia a hoʻoholo ʻia, seconded and carried. E hoʻoholo ʻia e ka Mōʻī, be it enacted by the King. Hoʻoholo i ke kānāwai, enforce the law. Hoʻoholo hou ʻana i ka waiwai, reappraisal of property. Hoʻoholo ʻia ka ʻōlelo hoʻopaʻi no ka hewa, convicted of an offense.
Noose.
Running hula step to the side; similar to kāholo except that the feet are not necessarily brought together.
A long bundle, as of hard poi.
To sew, as a break in a gourd calabash. See holoholo 2, and kāholo 2.
Holes in edge of a canoe, through which lashings were passed to hold a canoe cover in place. (Malo 135)
Diagonal pole or strut attached to the inner side of the roof framework and extending obliquely from the upper end of a rafter at one corner to the lower end of the rafter at the other corner.
Loss of a pebble in the kōnane game. (FOR. 4:57)
Hall.
Hoʻoholo Grooved piece above the door frame, in which the door slides.
A running; a racing; a going; a moving.
A bundle; holo ai, a bundle of food.
Running; moving; sailing; racing; he lio holo, he moku holo.
To go fast; to move generally, like hele.
To travel in any way, i.e., to run or ride or sail.
To put or thrust in, as the hand into the bosom.
To flee away; to go swiftly.
To run, as the thought, i.e., to decree; to decide.
Hoo. To ride on horseback, or on a camel.
To cause to ride, i.e., to carry in any vehicle, as a carriage.
To slip; to cause to slide down, as an avalanche.
To stretch out, as the hand for taking anything; to reach forth, as the hand.
Hooholo manao, to take council; to consult. See No. 4.
To promise; to agree with; to pass, as the sentence of a judge.

definitions.notes: Note: The common formula is, ua holo ka manao, the thought goes, or a shorter form is, ua holo, it runs, i.e., the vote is carried.
definitions.dtxt: To decide by vote of a deliberate body; ua hooholo, it was voted; it passed; it was decreed.
Run. See holoē, māmā holo, ʻai holo. Holo ʻekolu haneli ʻīā. Three hundred-yard run.
Pas/imp. of holo 1, 2.
To dispense, provide in measured quantities. Sh. hō + loaʻa, also Tah. hōroʻa [to give]. See ʻūhōloʻa.
Var. spelling of holowaʻa.
See ʻāʻā 3.
Destitute of property or of friends.
Holo and aa, the small roots of trees. Hence, to make a mistake; to run here and there; to go wrong; to blunder. See HOAA.
Steam-driven.
Street name.
Food bundle, especially ti-leaf bundle of hard poi. Cf. paʻi ʻai, pūkeleʻai.
A bundle of baked kalo.
A wrapper to carry food in.

To swim like a fish; to get the bends; to drown, sink; the bends, caisson disease. (Gram. 8.7.2) Inu ʻoe ā holoāiʻa (Kel. 138), drink until [you] swim like [a] fish. hoʻoholoāiʻa Caus/sim. ʻO ke ʻano e hoʻoholoāiʻa ʻia ai ka moku kaua, mamuli ia o kona hoʻopahū ʻia ana aʻe, the way the warship was sunk, because of being bombed.
Running long jump.
Street name.
To gallop.
Kaʻa holo ʻāpuʻupuʻu. Any off-road vehicle, e.g., ATV, 4x4, dirt bike, etc. Also kaʻa ʻāpuʻu.
To flow like water. See limu holoāwai, Gram. 8.7.2.
Hallway. Also holo.
To ice skate, ski. Lit. ice run. Kinipōpō holohau, ice hockey.
To ice skate. Lit. run (on) ice. Kāmaʻa holo hau. Ice skate.
To run to and fro; bustle.
To dart this way and that, as children at play; to veer at an angle, miss.

chants.chtran: Stand about, look about, let your eyes see the moon, run this way, run that way, you are big, big your body.
chants.chtxt: Hoʻokūkū, hoʻonānā, nānā kō maka i ka mahina, holohiʻa aku, holohiʻa mai, nui nō ʻoe, nui kō kino.

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
To go for a walk, ride, or sail; to go out for pleasure, stroll, promenade.

example_txt.txt: e holoholo ana ma ka mahina ʻai

definitions.dtxt: To take someone out for a drive or excursion; to escort; to help walk, as a child or invalid.
Basting; to baste, sew. hoʻoholoholo Caus/sim.; to make large running stitches. Lopi hoʻoholoholo, basting thread.
A net into which fish run (holoholo) after being frightened; to fish with this net.
An old Hawaiian game of kicking a ball to which feathers were attached; to play this game.
The name of a game among the ancient Hawaiians.
definitions.notes: Note: This double form, holoholo, has most of the senses that are attached to holo.

definitions.dtxt: See HOLO. To walk; to walk about.
To sail or run to and fro. To go about from place to place.
Hoo. To cause to ride, etc.
Traveling, in basketball; to travel.

example_txt.txt: Ua lilo ke kinipōpō iā Waiākea no ka holoholo ʻana a ke kūkahi o Hilo.
The ball was turned over to Waiākea after the point guard for Hilo traveled.

definitions.dtxt: Star name (no data). (Kuhelani.)
Redup. of holoi.
See HOLOI. To rub with pressure and quick motion; to rub off dirt; to rub down smooth.
To go for a drive or ride. See song in Elbert and Mahoe 53–4. hoʻoholoholo kaʻa To take someone for a drive or ride.
Redup. of holokake; blown, as by wind.
Ke ai holoholokakeia la e ka makani.
Redup. of holokē.
See HOLOKE, to rub against. To strike upon; to light upon easily; to touch; to rest upon, as the ends of a rainbow. Laieik. 16.

Heiau at Wailua River, Kauaʻi, said to be the oldest on the island and to be named for a foster parent of Kawelo; it was a place of refuge (Ii 138), restored by the Kauaʻi Historical Society and Bishop Museum in 1933. Hill, Waikiʻi qd., Kohala, Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
See HOLO and LIO, a horse. A rider on a horse; a horseman; cavalry.
Redup. of holo lio; to go horseback riding.
Redup. of holomoku 1, 2; ocean trip, cruise.
See HOLO, to sail, and MOKU, ship. A sailor; one who rides in a ship.
Animal, beast, insect.
A trip, excursion, ride. Cf. ipu holoholona.
See HOLOHOLO and ANA, a running about. A four-footed beast; generally applied to domestic animals, but often to wild ones.

See entries below and hoʻomalu lawaiʻa a me ka hahai holoholona. Hoʻomalu holoholona lōhiu. State wildlife official. Also luna hoʻomalu holoholona lōhiu. Loea holoholona lōhiu. Wildlife expert. ʻĀina Hoʻomalu Holoholona Lōhiu o Hawaiʻi. Hawaiian Islands National Wildlife Refuge. ʻAhahui Makaʻala Holoholona. Humane Society. ʻOihana Iʻa me ka Holoholona Lōhiu o ʻAmelika. US Fish and Wildlife Service.
Carnivorous animal.
Mammal.
Herbivorous animal.
Sloth, sleeping animal.

definitions.der: [Lit. animal (with) backbone. See holoholona iwi kuamoʻo ʻole]
definitions.dtxt: Vertebrate animal.

definitions.der: [Lit. animal without backbone. See holoholona iwi kuamoʻo]
definitions.dtxt: Invertebrate animal.
Insect, flying creature.
Wildlife.
To gossip, slander, bear tales, tattle; tattler, talebearer, spreader of gossip. hoʻoholoholoʻōlelo Caus/sim.
A tale bearer. A tattler. This is often written in two words.
See HOLO and OLELO, talk. To slander; to tell tales to the disadvantage of another; to propagate false reports.
Name of a star, perhaps Mars.
The Hawaiian name of the planet Mars.
Stroll; to go for a stroll. Lit. stroll (by) foot. Cf. hekehi.
Course for hōlua, sledding.
Shuttle run. Lit. transfer run. Cf. kūkini hoʻoili.
Ua holohua ka manao.
To glance off, fly off obliquely, miss, fail to hit the mark.
To wash, clean, scour, scrub, rub, erase, wipe (Biblical); washing, erasure.
To have washed, cleaned; to pretend to wash.
Washed; cleansed by washing or wiping.
To wash with water, as clothes; to separate the dirt from a thing.
To scrape or clean the dirt from the feet.
To brush clothes; to wipe; to cleanse.
To blot out, as a writing.
To clean in any way; holoi a maloo, to wipe clean.
To delete or clear, as in computer program.

example_txt.txt: E holoi i ka ʻikepili e kū nei.
to backspace, as on an IBM computer; to delete, as with delete key on a Macintosh computer

definitions.dtxt: Mīkini holoi pā. Dishwasher. Kopa mīkini holoi pā. Dishwasher soap. Pena holoi. Primer for PVC pipe cement.
Name of a legendary star (Kep. 77) that guided Hawaiʻinui on his return to Kahikihonuakele after discovering Hawaiʻi.
Pearl and Hermes Reef. Lit. (Hawaiian monk seal that) swims in the rough.
Shampoo.
Street name.
To progress, advance, surpass, go ahead; progress, advancement; successful. Also holomua. hoʻoholo i mua To promote, cause progress; advancement, success.
Stream, Hāna qd., Maui.
To speed recklessly.
Street name.
To ride in a car or carriage. hoʻoholo kaʻa To drive a car or carriage.
To ride majestically.
Lane, Lanakila section, Honolulu.
Street name.
One-way, as a street or trip. E makaʻala i nā alanui holokahi o ke kaona ke kalaiwa ʻoe ma ia wahi. Be careful of the one-way streets in town when driving through there. Lit. one ride. Cf. holo puni.
Sailor; to sail to foreign lands. Kauwō ulupau ka holokahiki, the sailor drags anchor everywhere.

Holo and kahiki, a foreign couentry. Epithet of a Hawaiian sailor who has visited foreign countries; ua tausani paha na holokahiki no Hawaii aku, there were thousands perhaps of sailors from Hawaii: o Lehua ka inoa o ka holokahiki nana i hoolike iwaena o Vanekouva ame Kamehameha, Lehua was the name of the sailor to foreign countries who interpreted between Vancouver and Kamehameha.
Street name.
Seaman, seafarer; to sail on the sea; sea voyage or cruise. Nā holokai, seafaring men.
Holo and kai, sea. One who rides on the sea; a seaman; na holokai, seafaring men.
Not secure, loose, not tight.
To roller skate. Lit. run (on) wheeled shoes. See kāmaʻa huila.
To run here and there; helter-skelter.
Holo and ke, to strike against. To run or rub against some opposing object.
To be stopped short, as the mind in a course of thought or investigation; a holoke ka noonoo, a kukapikiio ka manao ke loaa ole.
Runoff, as water running from the land into the sea.
Same as hālokeloke, loose.
To creak; to crepitate or grate, as the two ends of a broken bone against each other.
Street name.
Street name.
To dart, as a bird.
To run or sail swiftly; headlong. Cf. kikī holo.
To run or sail swiftly; to run headlong.
Dash, sprint. Lit. swift run.
Holo, to go, and kohana, destitute of clothes. To go about naked; to be destitute of clothes, not even a malo.
Street name.

A loose, seamed dress with a yoke and usually with a train, patterned after the Mother Hubbards of the missionaries. Cf. the muʻumuʻu, which formerly was not yoked and has no train or seam. Both garments are frequently made of gaily patterned material.
Cloak, mantle.
Evenly plump, stout and symmetrical. Cf. kolopū, pahupū.
Some kind of a garment; a long flowing garment. A cloak.
Street name.
Upper edge of an ʻōpelu fish net.
To trot, as a horse; to jounce.
To trot, as a horse.
To ride roughly or uneasily.
A round-yoked holokū.
The la is a particle. Ke holo la oe e manao ua hoka makou, you, O thought, have supposed that we are ashamed.
Street name.
Mission. Hoʻopau akula ʻoia i kona hololani ʻana, he finished his mission.
To skate with rollerblades. Lit. run (on) wheeled ridges. See kāmaʻa lapa huila.
Street name.
To succeed, fare well; successful.
A ride, as at a carnival or amusement park.
To correspond.
Street name.
To ride horseback; horseman, rider. Ka wahine holo lio, the woman rider. hoʻoholo lio Same as above; horseman; to make a horse run.
Holo, to ride, and lio, horse. A rider of a horse. Hoo. A horseman; a rider on a horse.
Film movement, as in a movie or video camera.
To run, sail, move in two ways. Fig. Hypocrite; deceitful.
Creeping or running both ways, like the crab; aole e like me kou manano ka muhee. ka hololua.
Holo and lua, double. To go or move two ways; to go both ways, like the crab; as the muhee, the papai, etc.
Street name.
Street name.
Breezy, airy.
Street name.
To decide, determine. See holo 2. hoʻoholo manaʻo Caus/sim. Ka poʻe i hoʻoholo manaʻo, those who took counsel.
Street name.
Same as holokai.
Street name.
Sailor, passenger, anyone who sails; to sail, take a sail or ocean trip. hoʻoholomoku To sail.

Rush or torrent, as of water; to rush, break forth, overflow. Fig. Overwhelming. Holomoku ke koho ʻia ʻana o ka mōʻī, the king was elected by an overwhelming majority. Ua holomoku aʻela ka heluna nui o kō Honolulu mau kini no kekahi hale kūʻai, most of the Honolulu populace rushed to a certain store.
A sailor; a seaman; ka halepule no ka poe holomoku ma Honolulu; he mau mea holomoku, seamen.
A rushing, as of water; an overwhelming; applied to the wicked.
Holo and moku, ship. To sail on a ship.
To rush along, as a torrent.
Same as holomoku 2.
A long fitted dress, a combination of holoku- and muʻumuʻu, a name probably coined after World War II.
Street name.
Same as holo i mua; improvement, progress.
To improve. He mau manaʻo e holomua ai ka hana. Suggested improvements. Loiloi holomua haumāna. Student assessment. ʻAukā holomua. Fill bar, in computer program.
A running, sailing, traveling; performance. Ka holona a kuʻu lio, the running of my horse.
A double bar to show the end of a piece of music.
In music, a close; the end of a tune.
Unskilled, far from expert; novice, amateur, beginner. (FOR. 4:293)
Drive-through, as at a restaurant or bank. Comb. holo + -na + kaʻa. Cf. holona makani.
Breezeway, as an open area between buildings. Comb. holo + -na + makani. Cf. holona kaʻa.
Var. of hoʻolono, to hear.
Street name.
Whole, entire, complete, total, all, absolute, altogether; entirely; paramount, supreme; entity. He aliʻi holoʻokoʻa, a chief over all.
Same as holoholoʻōlelo. hoʻoholoʻōlelo Caus/sim.
Holo, to run, and paani, to play. To run and play like chlldren.
To sail about for pleasure.
To skate, skid.
A pain that nearly shuts off (pani) the breath.
Street name.

Shelf, ledge, rack, frame on which tapa and other articles were laid; flooring. Kau holopapa, to place on the rack; one of chiefly blood (even though he did not know his genealogy), so called because he was entitled to place his belongings on a separate rack so that they might not be defiled by the possessions of others (Malo 56).

To spread, overrun, prevail, overcome, control, defeat; everywhere, completely. Holopapa ka hana, work done successfully. He niuhi ʻai holopapa o ka moku, the niuhi shark that devours all the island [a powerful warrior].
Holo and papa, a board. A shelf made of sticks in the corner of a room where kapas and other articles were laid.
A raft for floating logs, boards, stones, etc.
A bridge over a small stream.
An arch over a space.
To rule; to control; to overcome; to prevail over; used where one man conquers several others.
Continental shelf. Cf. hene mokuhonua.
To windsurf. See papa peʻa.
To ride horseback while wearing the sarong known as pāʻū; a pāʻū rider.
Street name.
To trot.
Jogging; to jog.
Street name.
To pass off successfully, succeed, accomplish; successful; success. Ua holo pono kaʻu huakaʻi, my mission was successful.
Wind famous at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
Street name.
To sail or travel around, circumnavigate; everywhere. Alanui holo puni, belt road. He pilikia holo puni kēia, this is a trouble that goes everywhere.
To run a lap, take a lap; to circulate, as blood; round trip.
Reckless, mad running; to tear madly, as a frightened horse; to speed recklessly, as an auto.
Street name.
Draft, air current, as in the mountains.
Makani uka, wind from behind; he kio, pali wauaka ma ke kua, makani holouka.
Same as holokē.
Thrust through a cleft.
War engine.
Holowa kaa, certain engines for throwing missiles in war.

Trough, especially vessel in which kava was mixed; oblong box, coffin, chest, cradle; furrow, as for planting sugar cane. Holowaʻa waiho aniani, handmade mirror fitted into a wooden frame, as of wiliwili wood. Kau i ka lani ka holowaʻa ua o Hilo, placed in the heavens is the rain trough of Hilo [admiration for one of regal bearing].
Sheath covering coconut flowers. Also lolo.
Shuttle into which the bobbin of a sewing machine is slipped after it is filled with thread.
A kind of fish net.
Holo and waa, canoe. A box; a chest; a trunk; a coffin; a cradle.
A species of fishing net.
A trough; a watering trough.
Form or mold, as for making adobe bricks.
Powder horn.
Street name.
Water ditch or course; to run in such courses; watery. Ua holowai nā kahawai, the streams run swiftly.
A coward; one fleeing without cause.
Holo, to run, and wale, freely. To flee without cause or danger; to act the coward.
To go about destitute of clothing, i.e., in a state of nature.
Long, thin. Cf. ʻaha 5.
A broad axe; a hoe; an adze; koiholu, an adze.
The depth of the sea; the deep ocean; the flood tide.
Street name.

Springy, pliable, resilient, as a mattress; to sway, as palm fronds; to ripple, as waves; to play back and forth; bumpy, as an airplane ride. Cf. hoholu, holu nape, nolu. Ke one holu, the sand carried back and forth [by the sea]. Ua holu mai ke kai i kō lāua mau kino, the sea lapped upon their bodies. hoʻoholu Caus/sim.; to bend, move up and down, sway.
Name of a star.
Name of a fish god.
See koʻi holu.
Soft; to soften. Pāpaʻi hōlū, soft-shelled crab.
To bend, as an elastic stick; to arch over.
Street name.
Pas/imp. of holu 1.
Prayer for luakini dedication. (FOR. 6:27)

Sled, especially the ancient sled used on grassy slopes; the sled course. Papa hōlua, sled. Heʻe hōlua, to ride a hōlua sled; the hōlua course; Fig. An expression of pride in descent from certain chiefly families at Waipiʻo, Hawaiʻi, who were famous for their skill with the hōlua sled.
A smooth path on a side hill for sliding down.

definitions.notes: Note: To play with the holua was an ancient pastime among Hawaiians.
definitions.dtxt: The name of the sled or sledge for sliding down hill.
The name of the strong north wind, generally in the winter.
To glide down on a sledge; to play the holua.
Cabin and cave on the Halemauʻu Trail, Haleakalā Crater, Maui. Way, Kalihi Uka, Honolulu.
Sled, for snow.
Sliding downhill on ti leaves; to do so (a children’s sport).
Village, elementary school, land sections, and bay, Kailua qd., Hawaiʻi. (Ii 6)
Street name.
Street name.
Redup. of holu 1; flexible. Kai holuholu, sea rising and falling. hoʻoholuholu Caus/sim.
Ductile; elastic; springy, as a sword blade.
See HOLU.
Soft, flexible, limp; soft-shelled, as an egg or crab; hanging loose, as fat.
A variety of sweet potato.
Var. of hōlule 1.
To oppress. (And.)
To oppress.
Mid-tide.
Redup. of hōlū; corpulent.
Redup. of hōlule 1.
Street name.
To sway, wave; swaying. Ka holu nape a ka lau o ka niu (song), the swaying of the fronds of the coconut.
Disappointed. Kū mawaho o ka pā o Homa, standing outside Holmes’s yard [said of one who is disappointed, a play on the name Holmes].
Thin, flabby; hollow, as cheeks.
To hold a canoe to its course in a rough sea.
Beat of paddle on canoe side, as in rhythmic paddling while fish are driven into a net.
Thin in flesh; poor; hollow; applied to the cheeks.
Disappointed; baffled.
To be poor; to be thin in flesh; to make one’s self poor.
To be disappointed; to be baffled in one’s efforts to do a thing.
Redup. of homa 1–4.
See HOMA. To be destitute; to be bereaved.
To be thin; to be poor.

See HO for hoo, and MAI, a verbal directive, used mostly in the imperative. Lit. Cause to be this way; hand this way; give this way; bring here. Homai i wahi wai inu na'u, give me here some water to drink.
Stream and land division, Kawaihau district, Kauaʻi.
To naturalize, i.e., admit to citizenship of a couentry. Comb. hoʻo- + makaʻāinana. Ka hoʻomakaʻāinana ʻana. Naturalization.
Emaciated, thin.
Home. Ka home kaupoku ʻole, the home without a ridgepole [a prison, ship, or place occupied by man that is not actually a home; an unhappy home].
Home; place of one’s family and residence.
Mākau nohona home. Home economics, as a course at school.
Homestead.
Detention home.
Sand lizard, snail.
Land snail. Homeka hamuhika. Cannibal snail. ʻAi ka homeka hamuhika i kōna ʻano lāhui ponoʻī o ka homeka. Cannibal snails eat their own species of snail.
Congregational church at Hāna, Maui.
Cemetery at Hilo, Hawaiʻi. Place, Nuʻuanu, Honolulu.
Street name.

Home rule; the name of the political party composed of native Hawaiians formed in the early years of Hawaiʻi as a territory. This party ended in 1912 after Kuhiō was elected delegate to Congress. (Daws 294–5) See ex., wela 1.
Home rule, i.e., self-government or limited autonomy, as in a city or county.

example_txt.txt: Ua loaʻa ka ʻAoʻao Home Lula ma Hawaiʻi nei a paʻa akula ʻo Kūhiō ma ka ʻoihana ʻelele no ka ʻAhaʻōlelo Lāhui.
The Home Rule Party existed in Hawaiʻi until Kūhiō took the office of delegate to Congress.

definitions.dtxt: Homeopathic.
A homer, a Jewish liquid or dry measure.
Semi-weekly newspaper in Hawaiian and published 1901–02.
A snail.
Withered, stunted, puny, feeble; to wither, dry or shrivel up.
See OMI. Withered; sick; unfruitful, as a plant; sick, as a person.
See OMIOMI. To spring up, as a seed planted, but with feeble strength and produce nothing.
Redup. of hōmī.
Street name.
Hormone. Hōmona hoʻāʻa. Rooting hormone. Also hōmona hoʻoaʻa. ʻŌnaehana hōmona. Endocrine system, in biology.
Same as hōpue, a tree.
A variety of taro.

definitions.der: [Lit. name of a tree frequented by this finch]
definitions.dtxt: Grosbeak finch (Chloridops kona) - an extinct species of finch. Cf. hōpue. See nuku ʻekue, ʻainohu Kauō, ʻainohu Nīhoa
Land section, Kailua qd., Kona, Hawaiʻi. A heiau here was called Kualani (chiefly back)(FOR. 4:588)
Street name.
Street name.
Surfing area, Kawaihae, Kohala qd., northwest Hawaiʻi. (Finney, 1959a:108)
Quadrangle, land section, village, bay, surfing areas (summer south-swell and winter north-swell), forest reserve, and elementary school, South Kona, Hawaiʻi. See Haleokeawe.
Street name.
Sweet and soft, as music; sweetly appealing, as perfume or a memory of love; to sound softly; to tease, play pranks; mischievous.

example_txt.txt: ke kani hone a ka waiolina
the sweet sound of a violin
This child keeps up a teasing cry.

chants.mltran: ♫  Brought by the moani breeze, spreading sweetly to the sea.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Na ka moani lā i hali mai, hone ana i ke kai.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim.
Honey. Wili i ka hone, to extract honey.
Tenon of a wall post (KAM. 76:97)
Lane, Kapālama section, Honolulu.
Street name.
Dirt; the matter in the intestines not voided. See HONOWA.
Street name.
Redup. of hone 1; melodious.
Playing tricks; teasing; fretting; not letting one alone.
See HONE. To be trickish; to be mischievous.
Honeysuckle, a low, twining shrub (Lonicera japonica), from East Asia, with short-stemmed, oval leaves and fragrant tubular flowers that open white and turn yellow.
Street name.
Saucy, impudent.
Impudent; undaunted; not afraid.
See HONE and KOA, to be bold. To rail; to be saucy.
To attract. He lāhui kanaka hōnēnē i nā mea ʻino (Kep. 75), a race of people attracted persistently by sinful things.
To beg earnestly. See HOLI.
Street name.
To kiss; a kiss; formerly, to touch noses on the side in greeting. Hele akula ʻo Iakoba, a honi aʻela iāia, Jacob came near and kissed him. hoʻohoni To cause or pretend to kiss.
To smell, sniff, scent; a scent, hoʻohoni Caus/sim.
To touch, as a match to a combustible.
A salutation; a kiss. Mele.
A touch as of a match to a combustible.
A shaking of hands at parting, etc.
Commanding a complimentary salutation to one; e haawi i ko'u honi ala aloha ia lakou, give them my sweet loving kiss, i.e., affectionate salutation.
To touch; to apply a combustible article to the fire.
To smell, as an odor. To smell any perfume; to snuff, as a candle.
To feel the influence of, as the roots of trees do the water.
To salute by touching noses (the ordinary way of saluting among Hawaiians); honi iho la i ka ihu. Laieik. 203.
To kiss; to salute by kissing. To embrace on parting; applied to various forms of salutation, as good-by, shaking hands, etc.
Pas/imp. of honi 1–3. Ua honia wale i ke ʻala o ka maile, to have inhaled indeed the fragrance of maile.
Redup. of honi 1–3; to kiss or smell repeatedly, sniff.
A loud kiss; to kiss loudly.
To throw a kiss; such a kiss.
Same as honi 1–3.
Name of a tapa dyed with turmeric and worn as a sarong.
Soft, yielding. Cf. lina.
See ONINANINA and UNINANINA. Fat; plump; round, as a fleshy person.
A “puzzling” smell: said if the smell is out of place, as that of gardenias in a canoe at sea, interpreted as a warning of danger (Nānā 58)
To stitch, sew, mend, patch; a joining, as of mountains. Cf. pāhonohono. E hono ana i kā lākou mau ʻupena, mending their nets.
Back of the neck, brow of a cliff.
Bad smelling (less common than hohono). Cf. mimi hono.
Rite at the end of kapu loulu rituals during which chiefs sat without shifting positions while a kahuna prayed for as long as an hour. (Ii 44)
A stitching; a sewing; a joining together; ka hono o na aina o Maui, the uniting of the lands of Maui.
The back of the neck.
The name of a kapu when every man must hold his hands in a particular posture.
The name of a place where the wind meets some obstruction and is reflected back; oia kahi hono e hoi mai ai ka nui o ka makani.
To stitch; to sew up; to mend, as a garment or a net.
To join; to unite together by sewing or stitching.

Bay, gulch, valley (as a part of place names such as Honolulu, Honokōhau, Honoliʻi, Honomanu; also in the poetic phrase nā Hono a Piʻilani, the bays beginning with Hono- of Piʻilani [a chief who ruled the bays on Maui, Molokaʻi, and Lānaʻi that were visible from Lahaina]. Hana- occurs similarly as in Hanalei and Hanauma. See Gram. 8.1.
Prefix to many place names (also, Hana-). (Appendix 5.2)
Same as kūkae, excrement, and an insulting epithet for commoners.
See HONEA and HONOA. The matter contained in the intestines.

definitions.notes: Note: This is the proper and polite name of excrements.
definitions.dtxt: Excrements; human fæces; used mostly in reference to chiefs.
See HONOWA.
See HONO and AI, the neck. The back of the neck.
Var. for hūnōai.

See HONOWAI below. A uniting; a bringing together and causing a new relationship; mostly brought about by marriage; as, makua honoai, a parent by marriage, or a parent-in-law; makua honoai kane, a father-in-law; makua honoai wahine, a mother-in-law.
definitions.notes: Note: The orthography honoai is better than honowai. See also the word HUNOAI.

definitions.dtxt: Street name.
Highway around southwest Maui.
definitions.notes: Note: Six West Maui bays whose names begin with Hono- (bay) and the islands seen from them (Kahoʻolawe, Lānaʻi, Molokaʻi) were ruled by Piʻilani and are famous in song; the six bays are Honokahua, Honokeana, Honokōhau, Honokōwai, Honolua, Hononana. Piʻilani’s daughter, Piʻikea, married ʻUmi in the early 1500s. See Kihaapiʻilani

definitions.dtxt: Honduras; Honduran.
Street name.

Wild spiderflower (Gynandropsis gynandra), a cosmopolitan tropical hairy annual weed, native to Africa, in the caper family, 30 to 90 cm high, leaves five-parted; flowers spider-like, white with a purple tinge; fruit narrow, cylindrical capsule with many seeds. Also ʻiliʻohu.
Village, Honomū qd., land sections, Honomū and Mauna Kea qds., Hawaiʻi.
Street name.
Short for honohono kukui.

The wandering Jew or dayflower (Commelina diffusa), known in many temperate and tropical countries, a creeping weed, rooting at the joints, and bearing grasslike, ovate leaves and small bright-blue flowers. Also honohono wai, and mākolokolo. Cf. honohono ʻula.
A very rare native mint (Haplostachys haplostachya), a downy erect herb with oblong or narrower leaves and white flowers.
See ʻokika honohono.
Same as hohono, bad-smelling.
A children’s game; the child locked fingers of two hands and thrust them into the sand, letting the sand out through a small opening.
Name of a weed, very thrifty in growth and very hard to kill.
Bad smelling. See HOHONO.
The basket grass (Oplismenus hirtellus), a creeping grass that originated in America, called kukui because it is often found under kukui trees. Also honohono maoli.
A variety of honohono.
Same as honohono kukui.
Land section inland from Loko-Waka, Hilo qd., Hawaiʻi.
Wandering Jew or zebrina, an ornamental, now naturalized, native to Mexico (Zebrina pendula).
Same as honohono 2.
Street name.
Land section, landing, school, and ancient surflng area, Kohala qd., Hawaiʻi. (Finney and Houston 26)
Cavern, sea cave. (AP)
Town name, Hāmākua, Hawaiʻi.
A water course.
Town and elementary and high school, Hāmākua qd., Hawaiʻi.
Village, bay, and ancient surfing area (Finney and Houston 26), Keāhole qd., Hawaiʻi. House sites, fishponds, and heiau have been found here. Litbay tossing dew. Same as Honokōhau.
Point, Kohala or Waipiʻo qd., Hawaiʻi.

A very active former of caus/sim. derivatives; see Gram. 6.4. Hoʻo- is treated as a prefix because it occurs only before bases; unlike prefixes, however, it takes the stress of a word, as does the following base; thus hoʻouna, to send, bears stress on the u and on the first o. Hoʻo- usually precedes stems beginning with the vowels i- and u- and all the consonants except the glottal stop. Important meanings follow:
Causation and transitivization, as pono, correct; hoʻoponopono, to correct.
Pretense, as kuli, deaf; hoʻokuli, to feign deafness.
Similarity, as kamaliʻi, children; hoʻokamaliʻi, childish.

No meaning, as kāholoholo, to hurry; hoʻokāholoholo, to hurry. The meanings of some hoʻo- derivatives are quite different from the meanings of the stems, as maikaʻi, good; hoʻomaikaʻi, to congratulate. Hoʻo- derivatives are defined under the bases. Delete hoʻo- and see the bases.

This word is the causative prefix to verbs; as, malu, to shade, hoomalu, to cause a shade, to overshadow; pono, good, right, hoopono, to correct, to make right; akea, to be broad, hooakea, or hoakea, to cause to be broad, i.e., to extend, enlarge, etc. See Gram. § 33 and § 212, and the conjugations 7, 8, 11, 12, 15 and 16.

This prefix, though originally adapted to the verb, continues its influence though the verb with its causative prefix becomes a noun, adjective or adverb. Ua hele oia i ka hoike, he has gone to the exhibition; he kanaka hoopunipuni, a man causing deception, i.e., a deceitful man; olelo hooino iho la, he spoke causing reproach, i.e., he spoke reproachfully. Before words whose first letter is a vowel, the last o of the hoo frequently coalesces with the vowel of the word following, particularly before a, e and o; as, hoano for hooano; hoole for hooole, etc. (See the preceding pages from the word hoaa to hoo.) Some words have haa for their causative prefix instead of hoo; as, haaheo for hooheo (from heo, pride), to be haughty. This form seems to come from the Tahitian dialect. A few words take both forms for their causative, as hoonui and haanui, from nui, to be large. Hoawi, to give, is used for hooawi, but haawi is used oftener than either.

Strictly speaking, hoo in a Dictionary should not begin a verb, but verbs having this prefix should be set in their places, and their meanings be modified by the hoo as it occurs; as, ike, to know, etc., hoo. or ho., to cause to know, to show, to exhibit; ikeia, to be known, hoo., to be made known, to be shown; ikeike, to know clearly, hoo., to make known clearly or frequently, etc.; but a large class of words have been found beginning with the causative prefix hoo, whose roots are not known or have not come to light, or are out of use. It is true, such a root might be assumed as being in existence or having once existed, as Greek Lexicographers often assume an obsolete theme; but there would be much danger in Hawaiian of getting the wrong word: hence, we know not where to put such roots unless we retain the hoo for the beginning of the word. This occasions some repetition, but it is hoped it will not be a serious inconvenience. The following words beginning with hoo are such as were first found in that form and whose root was not known. They are now retained in that form because many are other parts of speech than verbs. Where the words beginning with hoo have been defined under their roots, the definitions here will be very short and the reader referred to the root.

definitions.notes: Note: It appears from this and other words that the causative prefix haa is more ancient than hoo, for we have here lulu, to shake, and haalulu as a causative form, and this seems to have been incorporated with the word: since, however, the more modern causative hoo has been prefixed, thus the word has two causatives.

To invent. See hakuhia.
Caus/sim. Hoʻohākuʻi i koʻu naʻau, shocking to my heart. Hoʻohākuʻi nākolo, blow echoing and reechoing.
Caus/sim hākuʻikuʻi.
Caus/sim of hakukele. To make something wet and lumpy, muddy.
To cause to miss; to dodge, turn aside; to pass, as time.
To cause to sin, lead astray; to fail to do.
See hala, to sin, and hala, to pass.
See HALA, to miss; to pass on. To cause to miss the mark; to dodge; to turn aside.
To transgress; to go beyond.
To pass by the house of a friend; mai hoohala oe ia ia. do not miss him, i.e., in throwing a spear at a man.
Street name.
To criticize, complain, find fault, correct, negotiate (rare), suggest; correction, complaint; critical. Hoʻohalahala ʻole, uncomplaining.
To criticize. See halahala.
See HALA and HALAHALA. To refuse assent to the terms of a bargain; to break off a bargain; to be displeased with the proposed conditions of another; to break a promise.
To turn aside; not to listen to what one says.
To find fault with a proposal or offer.
A complaint without cause; an unreasonable objection to a proposal.
See HOOHALA above and LA, day. Lit. To cause the day to pass away.
To pass off the time; to spend the day.

To endure for the present day; applied to sick persons; ua pono kou mai? Ans. Aole, he hoohalala wale no, no ka make. Applied to the hungry; he ai anei ka oukou? Aole, he hoohalala wale no—he kamau ea. Applied also when one has but a little food, just enough for the day.
To pass the time. See -hala manawa.
Caus/sim of hālana. Me aʻu i hoʻohiki ai, ʻaʻole e hoʻohālana hou nā wai o Noa i ka honua, I have sworn that the waters of Noah shall go no more over the land.
To make numerous. Hoʻohālau i ka hale a piha i nā makamaka, fill the house full with friends.
Street name.
To arrange a meeting.
Street name.
To lodge in a house; to receive in a house. E hoʻohale ʻia aku, he makamaka ola, extend the hospitality of the house, [he is] a friend who extends appreciation.
See hale, house.
See HALE, house. To rest in a house; to stay in a house; to receive one into a house; to lodge; to solicit one to be a host or friend. See HOAIKANE.
Caus/sim of halehale.
Intensive of hoʻohale. To sink down, as the stomach when hungry, or like a house roof fallen in.
To be hungry; to suffer with hunger.
To entertain, as a guest or friend; hospitable.
See HALEKIPA. To entertain, as a guest; to receive into one’s house, as a friend.
To convert into a storehouse; to store in a house; to serve as a storehouse.
See HALEPAPAA. To shut up one in a tight house; to inclose; to secure by putting in a tight house; to store; to put in a store-house.
To cause to carry.
See HALI, to carry. To cause to bear; to carry.
To transfer to another person or to another place.
To carry the words of one to another; to put words together.
Street name.
To evoke reminiscence or recollection; remembrance; to remind.
See haliʻa, recollection.
To stir up, as anger; hoohalia mai i ka inaina.
Caus/sim of hāliʻaliʻa.
See puke hoʻohaliʻa makahiki.
Intensive of hali. To carry or bear, as a burden; to carry frequently.
Street name.

To compare, contrast, make alike, resemble, copy; artificial. Hoʻohālike kolohe, counterfeit resemblance. Hoʻohālike me ka haole, to ape a white person. Hoʻohālike mai ʻoe e like me kēia kiʻi, make a copy of this picture. ʻAʻole hoʻi ʻoe i hoʻohālike aʻe nei me Dāvida kaʻu kauā, you are not like David, my servant.
See hālike, alike.
See LIKE and HALIKE. To cause to be like; to resemble; to make similar.
Redup. of hoʻohālike; comparison, resemblance, similarity, impersonation; to equalize, match, impersonate. Mea hoʻohālikelike, example.
A resemblance; likeness; a similarity.
Freq. of the foregoing. See HALIKE. To make alike; to divide equally; to equalize.
Caus/sim of hāliu. E hoʻohāliu aʻe ʻoia i kō kākou naʻau iāia e hele ma kona mau ʻaoʻao apau, that he may incline our hearts towards him, to walk in all his ways.
Caus/sim of halu.
See HALU. To be or become poor or thin in flesh.

Same as above; ambush. ʻŌlelo ʻoluʻolu aku kekahi i kona hoalauna me ka waha, akā ma ka naʻau, ua hoʻohālua iāia, one speaks peaceably to his neighbor with the mouth, but in [his] heart, [he] lies in wait.
See hālua, to ambush.
An ambush; an ambuscade; Poe hoohalua, liers in wait.
To watch an opportunity for mischief; to lie in wait. Either to kill or rob.
To act as a spy; to go secretly to do a thing; to rob; to watch for an opportunity to see or speak to a person. Laieik. 77.
Freq. of hoohalu. See HALU and HAHALU. To be poor in flesh; to be thin; to be hungry.
Same as above; to produce a roaring noise.
See HALULU. To cause a roaring like thunder, or a heavy wind; to rage; to make a rumbling sound.
To open, expose; to pretend to open, yawn. Ua hoʻohāmama loa lākou i kō lākou waha iaʻu, they opened wide their mouth against me.
See hāmama, open.
To silence, hush.
Caus/sim of hamo.
See hamo, anointed.
See HAMO, to rub. To cause a rubbing, as with the hand; to besmear, as with oil.
Caus/sim of hamohamo.
See the above. To feel with the hand frequently; to rub over; to anoint.
Street name.

To use, employ, cause to work, carry out, administer, manage, encourage; use, employment, management, administration. Luna hoʻohana, manager, administrative head. Noho hoʻohana, to act or serve as manager. Nā mea hoʻohana, tools, implements, or anything to work with.
To tease, provoke, nag, plague; one who teases or provokes.
See hana, work, and hana, worthless.
See HANA, to work. To cause to work; to do service for another; to compel to work, as a slave; to encourage to work.
See entry below and helu hoʻohana, wā hoʻohana.
Land use, in geography. Lit. use land. Komikina Hoʻohana ʻĀina o ka Mokuʻāina. State Land Use Commission.
To cause a rebirth, baptize.
To act as midwife, deliver a baby; to reproduce.
See HANAU, to bring forth young. To cause to bring forth, as a female.
definitions.notes: Note: The word was mostly used in connection with the application of medicines designed to effect premature parturition.

definitions.dtxt: In modern times hoohanau has been used in the sense to beget or cause to be born; not used by Hawaiians themselves in this sense.
To cause an avalanche, slide; to flatten.
Street name.
To touch, graze, hint.
See hani.
See HANI, to approach. To come near to so as just to touch; to pass softly by.
To hint at, give a hint. ʻŌlelo hoʻohani. Hint.
Freq. of hoohani. To tempt slightly to adultery; to make gentle advances.
See HOOHANIHANI. Also, to turn a little so as to allow one to pass in a narrow road.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻohanini i Mānā ka wai ʻōpua.
The water of the cloud banks pours down at Mānā.
Ua hanini anei kō lākou akamai?

definitions.dtxt: To overflow, etc.; to cause an overflow.

See HANINI and NINI, to spill. To pour or run out, as water from a vessel; to cause to flow, as water; also, as tears; ua hoohaniniia na mapuna waimaka, the fountains of tears overflowed. Laieik. 203.
To dump.
Same as hoʻohanohano.
See HANO, to be still; undisturbed. To honor; to exalt; to be vain; to be haughty; to be self-glorious.
