Same as above.
See MALOKA, to be sluggish; to be stupid. To be dull; to be stupid in mind; to disregard any important truth; to be unbelieving; to disobey the command of a chief.
Street name.
Caus/sim of malolo.
To cease work for a time, recess; to adjourn temporarily. Cf. lā hoʻomalolo. Hoʻomalolo kaua, truce.
See malolo, to rest.
The name of the day before the la kapu; hence under the christian system, the la hoomalolo is Saturday, i.e., the day before the Sabbath.
To dry out, dehydrate, blot; to season, as lumber; tracing, as of genealogy (FS 115). See pepa hoʻomaloʻo ʻīnika.
See MALOO, parched; dry. To cause to dry up, as water; to wither, as a tree or flower; to make anything dry.
Street name.
See malu, shade.

See entries below and ʻāina hoʻomalu. Wā hoʻomalu. Probation, in law. Luna wā. hoʻomalu. Probation officer. ʻĀina Hoʻomalu Holoholona Lōhiu o Hawaiʻi. Hawaiian Islands National Wildlife Refuge. ʻAha Hoʻomalu Lawaiʻa o ka Pākīpika Komohana. Western Pacific Fishery Management Council. ʻŌnaehana Hoʻomalu ʻĀina Kūlohelohe. Natural Areas Reserves System (NARS).
Lāʻau hoʻomālū. Barbiturate.
Making or causing peace between differing parties; mohai hoomalu, a peace-offering.
See MALU, a shade, peace, etc. To rule over, especially in a peaceful way; to govern quietly; to make peace.
Same as hoʻomāluhiluhi.
Street name.
To cause or give peace, protect; to arbitrate between warring parties.
To cause fatigue, exhaust, tire; tiresome, exhausting, toilsome. ʻAʻohe waiwai o ka hele ʻana, he hoʻomāluhiluhi, there’s no use going, it wears one out.
To tire. See māluhiluhi.
State wildlife official. Also luna hoʻomalu holoholona lōhiu.
Street name.

To make lax, limp, weak; to relax, weaken, enfeeble; to shed a hard shell, as of a crab; to change from a caterpillar into a butterfly; to metamorphose. Cf. lāʻau hoʻomalule kino. Wai hoʻomalule, water of relaxation [liquor].
To change from one form to another; to metamorphose, as a caterpillar into a butterfly.
To molt, as a crab its shell. Cf. māunu.

To quarantine. Hoʻomalu maʻi ʻia nā holoholona i lawe ʻia mai i Hawaiʻi nei mai nā ʻāina ʻē mai no kekahi kōā o ka manawa. Animals brought to Hawaiʻi from other lands are put in quarantine for a period of time. Hale hoʻomalu maʻi. Quarantine station.
To overshadow, cast a shadow; shade; darken, as by a cloud. Nā kerubima nani e hoʻomalumalu i ka noho aloha, the cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat.
Overshadowing; shading, as clouds that run low; he ao hoomalumalu.
To conserve, i.e., to use or manage wisely, as natural resources. See maluō.
Street name.
To lighten, as a load; to ease pain; to cheer. E hoʻomāmā ʻoe i kou kaumaha, ease your grief.
Caus/sim of mamae., to weaken.
To protect; to make shady; to cast gloom.
To keep away, keep one’s distance; to go far; to remove someone to a distance. Hoʻomamao lani, taboo of unapproachability, of some very high chiefs.
See mamao, far.
To cause to get stuck, to stall.
Street name.

To place in authority, empower, authorize. He bila e hoʻomana ana i ke koho ʻia o nā luna mākaʻi, a bill authorizing the election of district sheriffs. ʻO nā kānāwai i hoʻomana hou ʻia, laws re-enacted. b. To worship; religion, sect. Hoʻomana Kepanī, Buddhist; Buddhism. Hoʻomana kiʻi, idolatry, idol worship. Hoʻomana Naʻauao, Christian Science. Hoʻomana o Iesu Kristo o nā Poʻe Hoʻāno o nā Lā Hope Nei, Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. Hoʻomana Palani (Farani), French religion; Catholicism. Hoʻomana Pīhopa (Bihopa), Episcopalian religion; Lit. bishop’s religion. Hoʻomana Pōʻaono, Seventh Day Adventist; Lit. Saturday religion.
See mana, power.
Callus; callous. Kauaʻi.
See MANA, superhuman power. To ascribe divine honors; to worship; to cause one to have regal authority.

Monotheism; monotheistic. Hoʻokumu ʻia nā hoʻomana Mohameka, Iudaio, a me ke Kalikiano ma luna o ke kumu aʻo o ka hoʻomana akua kahi. The Muslim, Jewish, and Christian religions are based upon the principle of monotheism. Cf. hoʻomana akua lehulehu.

definitions.der: [Lit. religion (with) numerous gods. Cf. hoʻomana akua kahi]
definitions.dtxt: Polytheism; polytheistic. Ma ka hoʻomana akua lehulehu o ka nui o nā lāhui Polenekia, mālama nui ʻia kekahi akua ma mua o kekahi. In the polytheistic religions among most Polynesian people, some gods are venerated more so than other gods.
Same as above; to cause boredom. Mai hana hoʻomanakā ʻoukou, don't work in a such a bored, indifferent fashion.
Idolatrous; to worship images.
The practice of worshipping idols; idolatry; called figuratively in Scripture, whoredom. Also vanity; a vain service; idolatry.
See HOOMANA above and KII, an idol. To worship idols; to worship any god except Jehovah.
To appease, assuage, or mollify, as a god; to neutralize, as a curse.
To remove bitterness or saltiness, as of overly salty salmon.
See mānalo, sweet, and mānalo, appeased.
See MANALO, sweet; free from taint. To purify; to sweeten anything from salt or any unpleasant taste or smell.
Caus/sim of mānalonalo.
To desalinate, desalinize salty water.
To impart mana, as to idols or objects; to deify; superstitious.
Superstitious. See manamana.
To stretch out, extend; to loosen, as a grip.
Street name.

To remember, recall, commemorate, reflect deeply on, meditate. See ʻōlelo hoʻomanaʻo. Hoʻomanaʻo aloha, to remember with affection. He hoʻomanaʻo, in memoriam. Mea hoʻomanaʻo, souvenir, keepsake, reminder, memorandum. Kia hoʻomanaʻo, monument, memorial tablet. He mau ʻōlelo hoʻomanaʻo, notes.
See manaʻo.
See MANAO, to think. To turn the mind upon; to call to mind; to cause to consider; to remember that which is past.
To cause a sensation of horror, grief.
A reflection on the past; sorrow for the past.
See MANAONAO, to lament. To call up the past with sorrow; to think or reflect on the past.
Caus/sim of manawaleʻa.
See MANAWALEA, alms. To appease by a gift; to give alms to the poor; to relieve the distressed.
See manawanui, patience.
To harden, raise calluses; to strengthen, make steadfast.
See MANEA. To render callous; to harden; he mea ia na ke kalaimoku e hoomanea i kanaka i haalele ole i ke alii.
To cause to itch; to tickle.
Caus/sim of māneʻoneʻo.; to tickle, titillate.
See MANEO, to itch. To scratch where it itches; to tickle.
To tickle.
Same as hoʻomanewanewa.
To display violent grief; to free oneself from black magic and regain health by extravagant conduct, as going nude or eating of filth or drinking ʻauhuhu juice.
To treat unkindly.
To cause sleepiness, drowsiness.
To increase; to do repeatedly or persistently. Koi hoʻomano, to keep asking and insisting. Ka hahai e hoʻomano ai (FOR. 4:47), following persistently.
See MANO, a shark. To act the shark; to be greedy.
To be continually at; to persevere in, as one in begging.
To tease with importunity.
To behave as a shark; to eat ravenously; to pursue women ardently.
See MANO, a shark. To act the shark; to be greedy.
To be continually at; to persevere in, as one in begging.
To tease with importunity.
To increase.
To thicken.
Caus/sim of manoninia. Kaniʻuhū a hoʻomanoninia no kō kākou lāhui, no ke emi ʻana mai, grief and sadness for our race, for its decreasing.
Caus/sim of manuheʻu.
See MAOA, pain; lameness. To have lameness in the hip joint; to be weak in the muscles of the thigh.
See MAOE and MAOI, forward; bold. To be impertinent; to speak or ask for a thing; to give a hint of one’s desire.
To act bold, impertinent.
See MAOE and MAOI, forward; bold. To be impertinent; to speak or ask for a thing; to give a hint of one’s desire.
To make streaks, cut grooves.
To cause to open the mouth, speak, etc. Hōʻomaʻoma i ka waha, to open the mouth; to work the mouth but not sing with others, to pretend to sing.
To paint green, make green.
To darken; to make a black or blue color. See OMAOMAO.
See MAONA, satisfied with food. To feed to satiety; to fill with food; to be satisfied with eating.
Fatiguing.

To understand, make plain or clear, tell clearly, cause to understand, pay attention in order to understand; to certify, inform, remember, recollect, recall, think about, remind, believe in, realize, ascertain, take care of, recognize, discover. (Depending on context, many translations are possible; for substitution of maopopo for hoʻomaopopo, Gram. 4.4) Hoʻomaopopo ʻē, to understand ahead, anticipate; inkling. Hoʻomaopopo ʻole ʻia, misunderstood, unintelligible, uncared for, unclear. E hoʻomaopopo aku ʻoe, i ka hola ʻehia kākou e hele ai, find out what hour we are going. E hoʻomaopopo aku ʻoe e hele mai i kēlā ʻapōpō, remind [him] to come tomorrow. E hoʻomaopopo mai ʻoe i kēia mea e aʻo ʻia aku nei, pay attention and comprehend these things being taught you.
See maopopo.
He mea hoʻomaopopo kēia. For your information. Also i maopopo iā ʻoe, i mea e maopopo ai ʻoe.
Caus/sim of māpu.
Irreconcilable; opposite in natures, as fire and water; as virtue and vice.
Street name.
To continue, keep on, persist, renew, perpetuate, persevere, last. See nuku hoʻomau. Hoʻomau ʻia, continued. E hoʻomau hou ʻia aku i ka laikini, renew the license.
To make fast, as an anchor in sand; to snag; to cause to be retarded, grounded, wagered, stopped.
To mate for the purpose of having children. Hoʻomau keiki, to unite in order to conceive, as of ceremonial marriage of high chiefs for purpose of begetting children of high rank.
See mau 1–3.

See MAU, to repeat. To be constant; to be immovable; to perpetuate; to make fast, as an anchor in sand or rocks; to keep perpetually in action; to persevere; to go forward; hoomau aku la laua i ka hele. Laieik. 101.
To dampen, moisten, irrigate, soak, saturate, baste; to shade, cool.
See MAU and MAUU, wet; moist. To moisten; to wet, as with dew; to soak.
To be cool; to be agreeable; to be refreshing.
To be lazy; to be idle.
To lay or place one thing on top of another. See MAUAE.
Var. of hoʻomahuakala.
To be lazy; to spend the day; to be indolent; to go about doing nothing.
To accuse falsely; to laugh with scorn.
To oppress, burden.
To bear a grudge, cherish revenge. Kūʻē (kaua) hoʻomauhala, feud. Mai hoʻomauhala i nā keiki, do not bear any grudge against the children.
An old grudge; cherished revenge. Laieik. 69.
See HOOMAU, to perpetuate, and HALA, offense. To keep long enmity against one; to retain long the memory of an offense; to seek revenge long after an offense.
To bruise, sprain, beat down, as by heavy rain or sea; to crush, as a leaf for a poultice; to cause a sprain; to ripen bananas by burying in a leaf-lined pit.
Continual; perpetual. See HOOMAU.
To ask over and over, mull over in the mind.
To become sore again; to oppress more.

To cause fainting; to faint; to feign fainting. Ā ua hoʻomaʻule hoʻi iā mākou no kō mākou mau hewa, and has consumed us because of our iniquities. Hoʻomaʻule ka lemu (FOR. 6:27), relax the buttocks [as during rituals].
To cause calluses; to oppress, overwork.
See HOOMAU and LEHO, a callous bunch. To cause one to work hard; to oppress; to make one work all day and every day without wages.
To calculate. Comb. hoʻomau (make secure) + -lia. Also huli a loaʻa, huli.
Redup. of hoʻomau. E hoʻomaumau i ka ʻikena (song), continue seeing [one another].
Caus/sim of maʻūmaʻū. See ex., mūkī.
To waste, spend carelessly, abuse; to help oneself lavishly, as to drinks. Hoʻomāuna i ke kino, to waste the body, as in dissipation.
To waste, squander.
Waste; useless destruction of property.
See MAUNAUNA and MAUNA. To waste, as property; to spend uselessly; to consume; to destroy without regard to expense.

To give nothing of value (probably related to the Fig. meaning of mauʻu Hilo. ʻO ka mea e hoʻomanawaleʻa aku, ā momona ia, a ʻo ka mea e hoʻomauʻu aku, e hoʻomauʻu ʻia, mai ʻoia (Johnson 1976, p. 288), he who freely gives shall be enriched, and he who gives nothing of value shall receive nothing of value.
To moisten, dampen, wet, as earth about plants.
To make a crack, furrow.
To come into the midst of a company of people or things; a i ka au hou ana o ka mea i komo i ka pua, hoomawaena mai oia.

To talk in a roundabout way, as to obtain information or conceal the truth; to hint at, trifle, joke, allude, pretend, act. Hapai hoʻomea aʻe (Kep. 159), to carry with pretended [groans from exertion]. I hoʻomea wale aku nei nō au, I was just hinting, joking, talking generally.
See MEA, to trouble; to effect. To cause something; to do something; to make pretense; to deceive; to disappoint; to make trouble.

example_txt.txt: to pretend to give [with the intention of taking back]
He manu hulu meamea ʻo Keawe.

definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim of meamea.; to bluff, pretend, disguise.
Simulation, in math. Cf. hoʻokūkohukohu.
Preparing for the Sabbath. See HOOMALOLO.
definitions.notes: Note: Formerly hoomeha was applied to a la kapu, but is now used as synonymous with la hoomalolo, the day before the Sabbath, i.e., Saturday.

definitions.dtxt: See MEHA, to live alone. To stay at home from work; to cease from work.
Global warming, greenhouse effect.
To make a track; to follow a track, trail, trace; to lead up to deviously, as in asking a favor.
See meheu, track.
To outline, as type on computer or in typesetting. Comb. hoʻo- + meheu. Cf. mahaka. See meheu.
Street name.
To cause to sing or chant.
See MELE, a song. To cause or make a song; to sing a mele; to be joyous; to rejoice.
To color or paint yellow.
To prepare this club; to use this club.
To cause a decomposition, to leave (as fish) until decomposition begins. Iʻa hoʻomelu, fish, such as hīnālea, slightly decomposed, then salted and seasoned with kukui-nut relish, chili peppers, etc.
See melu, soft.
To make dull; dull.
Caus/sim of menemene.
See MENE, to have pity. To be dear to one; to have compassion upon; to pity; to treat tenderly, as a beloved one.
To build by laying one thing on top of another.
To pressurize. Comb. hoʻo- + mīkā. Hoʻomīkā ʻia. Pressurized.
To act as a missionary; to ape the missionaries; to be a goody-goody.
To do neatly; to work with skilled craftsmanship; to handle daintily.
Lapaʻau hoʻomiki uila. Shock therapy.
To season, salt. Hoʻomiko ai me ka paʻakai, season with salt.
Caus/sim of mikomiko.
To cause urination; to help to urinate, as a child.
To curl, twist. Hao hoʻomimilo, metal hair curler. Hoʻomimilo i ka lauoho, to have hair curled.
To cause to smile; to smile a little.
Creased; to make a crease. Hoʻomiona ʻia kēlā pāpale, that hat is creased.
Caus/sim of miona.
Short for hoʻomoku, to cut, etc.
To cook, bake.
See moʻa, cooked.
See MOA, cooked. To cause to be cooked; to be thoroughly baked.
Channel between Lehua and Nihoa islands.
To tear or snatch away; to steal.
Explanation, definition; to explain clearly, clarify, define.
See AKAKA, clear to the mind. To cause to be very plain to the mind; to make one understand what may be intricate; to explain. See HOAKAKA.
See MOALAALA, to rise up to go. To be busy about; to go from house to house; to be forward; to be impertinent.
To make an impression; scar, tracing, groove.
To accompany, as a cock with hens; to care for, protect, cherish.
Street name.
To camp, camp (see ex., ʻīpuka). Hele akula lākou … ā hoʻomoana ma ʻEtama, they want … and encamped at Etham.
See moana, campground, and moana, broad.
To spread down, as mats.
To camp. Cf. ʻāpoʻe. Kahua hoʻomoana. Campground. Kaʻa hoʻomoana. Camper; camping vehicle.
Encamped; kahi hoomoana, a camping place; a camp.
As if hoomoena. To spread down mats for staying over night; hence,
To encamp, as travelers; to encamp, as soldiers. See also MOANA.
Street name.

To put to sleep, to lay down; to set, as a hen or fish net; to offer, as a sacrifice; to deposit, as in banks; to bring down, as a club (FS 241); to “drop” a matter; to defer, postpone, rest a while; to table, as a motion; to lay, as bricks or cement; to subscribe, as to a newspaper. As an epithet for Kalākaua, moe probably refers to the kapu moe. Cf. hoʻomoemoe. Hoʻomoe kimeki, to pave. Koa hoʻomoe, reserve militia (term used in 1845).
See moe, to sleep, and moe, to marry.
Caus/sim of moe. See ex., kāoʻo.
To arrange a match. Huakaʻi hoʻomoe wahine (FS 157), trip to arrange for a bride. Hoʻomoe ā ipo, to cause to take as a sweetheart or lover.
See MOE, to lie down. To cause to lie down; to prostrate in adoration.
To speak of one’s sleeping with another, that is, of marrying together. Laieik. 66.
To lie down to rest; to rest one’s self by lying down.
To incubate, hatch (eggs). Niʻihau. Mīkini hoʻomoe hua. Incubator (for eggs). See kanaka hoʻomoe paipu.
To imagine deliberately. E hoʻāʻo ʻoe e hoʻomoeā he tika ʻoe. Try to imagine that you're a tiger. Cf. moeā.
To lead into adultery.
To cause to lie down; to hush or put to sleep; to arrange a match; to set a line or net; to pretend to sleep. Cf. hoʻomoe. ʻUpena hoʻomoemoe, net set in the sea.
To cause to lie down.
To hush or put to sleep.
To place artefacts with the dead. Mai lawe wale i nā mea i hoʻomoepū ʻia, don't wantonly take things placed with the dead.
Street name.
To open, unfold, spread, recover, develop, evolve; development, etc. Ua hoʻomohala ʻia kona naʻau kānalua, his doubting heart began to feel courage.
To open; to unfold or blossom, as a flower.
To spread, as a kapa or sheet. See HOOMAHOLA by a change of syllables.
To have a little hope, as one disappointed; ua hoomohalaia kona naau kanalua. Laieik. 93.
To unfold, as one’s inward desire; to rage, as lust. Laieik. 196.
Mākau hoʻomohala manaʻo. Productive-thinking skill. Nīnau hoʻomohala manaʻo. Open-ended question.

Economic development. I ka wā o ka pupū o ka mohala ʻana o ka hoʻokele waiwai o ka Mokuʻāina, pono e ʻimi i nā ʻano like ʻole o ka hoʻomohala waiwai ʻana. Whenever the State’s economic growth is weak, other types of economic development must be sought. Lit. develop wealth. ʻOihana Hoʻolālā a me ka Hoʻomohala Waiwai o ka Mokuʻāina ʻo Hawaiʻi. Hawaiʻi State Department of Planning and Economic Development.
Street name.
To slacken, relax; to cause relaxation, ease.
See MOHALU, to be at ease. To entertain in one’s house; to invite to one’s house.
To lie at ease; to rest securely.
To break; to crack. See next word.
To crack; to break, as the auamo or stick on which things are carried on the shoulders of men.
See MOHOLA and HOHOLA. To spread out widely; to unfold, as the growing of a plant.
See HOLE, to peel. To peel; to strip the skin from an animal; to peel the bark from a tree. See UHOLE.
To litter, scatter, cause disorder or untidiness.
To flood, fill with water.
This is probably for hookomo, or it may mean, to cut short. A hoomoko ka wai ma na pae.
Street name.
To cut and divide; a cutting, division, separation.
To place one over a moku, district. (FOR. 6:377)
A cutting or a dividing, etc.
To cause a division; to cut and divide, as a land.
To divide, alienate. Hoʻomokuāhana i kā lākou mau alelo, confuse their tongues.
To smooth.
To cause delay; to delay.
See MOLE, smooth. To be shorn close; to be cut smooth.
To cause to linger; to be slow; to be behind.
To refuse; to be unwilling.
To smooth.
Intensive of hoʻomole.
To feign laziness; to waste the time of others; lazy.
See MOLOWA, inactive. To be indifferent about a thing; to be indisposed to do a thing, especially to work; hence,
To be lazy; to be idle.
Same as hoʻomoamoa. (Nak. 80)
To cook.
Redup. of hoʻomole; to hesitate; reluctant. Hoʻomomole ma ka hāʻawi kālā ʻana, slow about paying.
See HOOMOLE above. To be smooth.
To fatten, fertilize. Hoʻomomona lepo, fertilizer; to fertilize the soil.
To sweeten; candy.
To fertilize. Cf. kīpulu. Mea hoʻomomona lepo. Fertilizer. Mea hoʻomomona lepo kāʻokoʻa. Complete fertilizer, i.e., fertilizer which contains the six necessary elements for plant growth.
To follow a course, continue a procedure.

To continue or persevere in laying taxes upon the people; to follow up a pursuit; ame ka hoomoo o na puu waiwai, to urge or force people to give their property for such purposes as the rulers need; e kaukolo, e hookoikoi.
Caus/sim of moʻolelo. (FOR. 6:523)
To mold, shape.

example_txt.txt: Hana ihola ʻo Kū, ʻo Kāne, ʻo Lono i ka lepo kele, hōʻomoʻomo ihola a paʻa.
Kū, Kāne, Lono made muddy earth, molded it firm.

definitions.dtxt: See ʻomoʻomo.
To model, mold, or shape, as clay.
To beat raw bast into moʻomoʻo.
To claim a moʻopuna relationship; to address and treat as a moʻopuna, as from affection.

See UKIUKI, hot and bad smelling. To cause an offensive smell; to reek with offensive smells, like an old and dirty ship, or like the breath of a tobacco smoker; to be warm or stifled for want of pure air.
Same as above; multitude, crowd; to cause a gathering. A pae aʻe i Kaimū, hoʻomū nā kānaka (chant), landing at Kaimū, people gathered.
See mū 2, 3.
See MU, to shut the lips. To sit silent; to be speechless; to make no reply; to refuse to answer. See MUMULE, like the English to be mum.
A calabash for fish.
Street name.
To push forward, to do something first; to claim to be senior; to advance to seniority; to give the rights of seniority to a junior.
To push forward; to act as senior.
To make bitter.
To be bad tasted to the palate; to be offensive to the taste; to be bitter; to be brackish.
Freq. of hoʻomuʻe.
To collect together. See MUMUHU.
To make a low humming sound.
See MUKA, tasteless; insipid. To be tasteless; to be insipid; ono ole.
To be insipid; to be tasteless.
Caus/sim of mūkā.
Same as above.
See MU. To hold in the mouth without swallowing.
To hold the mouth silent from speaking.
See MUHU, to hum. To collect; to assemble together, as men; to gather together, as other things.
To make a low indistinct noise; to sound like an indistinct low hum.
Caus/sim of mumuku.
See MUKU, to cut short. To cut short; to cut too short; to break off. See MUMUKU.
Caus/sim of mumule.
See MUMULE, to be dumb. To be silent; to be dumb.
To be out of one’s mind; to be crazy; to be insane.
To collect together in great numbers; to be thick together, as swarms of flies.
To cause a collection; to heap together.
To gormandize.
Street name.

To relieve pain, soothe, comfort, quiet, appease, lull, placate, make calm, pacify, console, find solace; to end, as a taboo; to settle a claim. Hoʻonā wale, to attempt to pacify without effect; to try vainly to assuage, allay pain, grief. Poʻe hoʻona kuleana ʻāna, board of commissioners to quiet land titles. Komikina Hoʻonā ʻĀina, land commissioners who settle land claims.
See nā, calmed.
See NA, to be quiet. To cause ease; to give quiet from pain.
To obtain a refuge from danger.
To search or look for a place. See NANA.
To settle, as a claim. ʻAha hoʻonā ʻāina. Land court. ʻŌnaehana hoʻonā ʻāina. Land registration system.
To cause intoxication or dizziness; to feign intoxication or dizziness; intoxicating.
Intoxicating. See more common hōʻonaʻona.
Same as hōʻaikola, contemptuous, contemptuousness. (Kel. 26, 28)
To educate, instruct; educational, instructive, civilized. Ua hoʻonaʻauao ʻia ʻoia, he was educated. Kuʻu home hoʻonaʻauao, my home of learning.
See naʻauao.
Alternative education, as a school program.
To cause or feign ignorance; ignorant.
To cause shortness of breath.
See NAE, to breathe hard. To breathe hard; to puff like one traveling fast up hill; to be fatigued.
Caus/sim of naele.; to soften, as earth for planting.
See NAELE. To cause to be thick, as mud; to be muddy.
To break open; to crack, as dried mud.
Freq. of hoʻonae.
To smash, shatter, crack, split; to take a purgative.
See NAHA, to crack or break, as glass. To break or crack, as glass.
To cause to operate, as a cathartic.
See NAHE, thin; soft. To be low; to be flat; to be thin; to be humble.
To cause a blundering, wandering, as by misdirecting; to procrastinate, waste time through blundering.
See NAHILI, to be awkward; to be slow. To lengthen out; to make long, as a road by going a circuitous route, or by losing one’s way.
To hesitate; to linger.

example_txt.txt: ʻAʻohe, waʻa hoʻonahoa o ka lāʻino.

definitions.der: [Lit. no canoe defiant of a stormy day [do not venture in the face of danger]]
definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim of nahoa.; to challenge.
See NAHOA, strong; bold. To be hard; to be strong; to be bold, as a soldier.
To turn a deaf ear; to refuse to listen. See HOONEHOA.
To chase, cause to run.
See NAHONAHO, to be deep. To be set deep in the head, as the eyes; to be deep, as a pit.
To bite, cause a stomachache; to pretend to bite.
See NAHU, to bite; to gripe. To snap, as corn parching; to crack, as a pistol; to make a report, as fire-arms.
See the above. To snap at, as a dog.
To be in labor pains.
To be seized by sudden pain.
To add special effects. Comb. hoʻo- + naʻiau. Usu. hoʻonaʻiau i ka hiʻohiʻona. See naʻiau, hiʻohiʻona naʻiau.
To persecute.
To show contempt, as by destruction. ʻAʻohe koe i ka hoʻonaikola ʻia e ka makani (FOR. 4:476), nothing survived the contemptuous destruction by the wind.
See AIKOLA and HOAIKOLA. To cause to triumph over an enemy; to rejoice at a victory.
To treat with contempt, as a conquered one.
See HOONAE, to pant. To sob; to breathe hard.

To change (a letter of the alphabet) from capital to lower case. Comb. hoʻo- + naʻinaʻi. See hoʻomaʻaka. Kaha hoʻonaʻinaʻi. A line drawn diagonally through a capital letter to indicate that the letter is to be written in lower case, in proofreading.
Caus/sim of nakaka.
To make a rattling or rustling noise. ʻO wai kēlā e hoʻonakeke maila i nā pā? Who is that rattling the dishes?
Caus/sim of nakele.
See NAKELE, soft; slippery. To make boggy, as land; to be soft and shaky, as a miry place.
Caus/sim of nākelekele.
Caus/sim of naki.
See KOA, a soldier. To be bold; to be brave; to act the soldier; to be fearless; to be daring.
See KOLO, to crawl, and NAKOLO. To run along; to spread, as ink on paper.
Caus/sim of naku.
To suffer gas pains. Hoʻonākū nā mauna, kaʻahē nā mokupuni (birth chant for Kamamalu), the mountains are in distress, the islands gasp for breath.
Caus/sim of nākuʻi.
See KUI, to sound abroad. To make a rumbling noise; to tremble.
To spread out, as a sound from a place.
To cause to fall in drops, as rain; as perspiration. Laieik. 118.
See KULU, to drop. To drop down, as rain; to drip from the clouds, as rain.
To cause to be lost; to conceal, secrete, put out of sight.
See NALO, to disappear. To be lost; to vanish; to be out of sight; with wale, to be forgotten.

Hidden; to cause to disappear, camouflage. Cf. manaʻo hoʻonalonalo, ʻōlelo hoʻonalonalo. Kuhikuhi hoʻonalonalo, to speak in an enigmatic way or with hidden meaning so that only the confidant understands.
Freq. of hoʻonalo.
To camouflage. Comb. hoʻo- + nalo + peʻe. See nalopeʻe.
To form waves.
See NALU, the surf. To cause a swell of the sea on shore; to rise, as the surf; to act, as the sea when the wind and tide are contrary.
To cause a pain in head or stomach. Hoʻonalulu hoʻi keiki, the children give [me] a headache.
To turn a deaf ear; to refuse to listen; to disregard. See HOOMAEAEA.
To pretend to speak in a foreign language, to mutter, mumble, speak gibberish.
See NAMU, to speak rapidly. To speak in an unintelligible manner.
To find fault behind one.
Street name.
Aggressive, looking for a fight, threatening; to antagonize.
See NANA, to bark; to growl. Angry; cross; reluctant.

To act cocky, strut about looking for a fight. Ua hoʻonanā hele ke keiki ma ka pā pāʻani. The boy went strutting around the playground looking for a fight. Niʻihau. Lele hoʻonanā. Aggression, as a threat of attack by one couentry upon another. Cf. lele kaua.
To cause to look, show. Hoʻokūkū hoʻonānā, nānā kō maka i ka mahina (children’s game chant), stand about, look, let your eyes see the moon.
See NA and NANA, to hush; to quiet, as a child. To calm; to quiet, as a child; to hush up a difficulty; to ease a pain; to comfort; to console.
To enrage.
The modern spelling should probably be hoʻonānaʻa.**
See NANA and LANA, to float, and AU, tide; current. To cause to float on the surface of water; to swim standing or erect; to float here and there as the current goes.
See NAHILI, slow; lagging. To go in a crooked manner; to wander about; to mistake the road.
See NANAHO, deep down. To be deep.
To be strong; to be tight.
See NAHU, to bite, and NANAHU and LANAHU, a coal of fire. To char, as wood; to make coal; to burn wood to charcoal.
To bite; to sting like a burn.
To turn into charcoal, as burnt wood.
See NAHU, to bite, and NANAHU and LANAHU, a coal of fire. To char, as wood; to make coal; to burn wood to charcoal.
To bite; to sting like a burn.
In the modern language, there may be confusion between nānahu and nanahu — see both entries.**
Caus/sim of nanaka.
See NAKA and NANAKA, a crack; a crevice. To be full of cracks, openings or chinks.
To be unstable; not firm, as a bog.
See NANAKI and NAKII, to tie; to fasten. To bind; to tie up.
Caus/sim of nanana. Hoʻonanana ka manu e lele, the bird flutters its wings to fly.
Caus/sim of nanauha.
To be strong; to be hard; to be tight; to drag; to draw.
To cause to be weak and unhealthy.
To make riddles, speak in parables.
See NANE, a riddle. To put forth a riddle; to propose something mysterious for explication.
Street name.
To pass the time in ease, peace, and pleasure; to relax, lounge, repose; absorbed, contented. He hana hoʻonanea ka hoʻokani pila, playing a musical instrument is pleasant.
See nanea 1.
See NANEA, easy; quiet. To be easy; to be contented; to be satisfied with one’s self; to be indifferent to the future.
ʻOihana o nā Pāka a me nā Hana Hoʻonanea. Department of Parks and Recreation.
Street, Mānoa, Honolulu.
Same as above; puzzling, riddling; figurative. See ʻōlelo hoʻonanenane.
Puzzling. See nanenane.
Street name.

To beautify, adorn, trim, decorate, glorify, honor, exalt, praise, adore; decorative, glorifying. Nāmea hoʻonani, decorations of any kind. Hoʻonani kākou iā Ia (hymn), let us adore Him. Mea hoʻonani kino, any bodily adornment, as jewelry.
See nani 1.
See NANI, also LANI, beautiful; glorious. To glorify; to praise; to exalt; to honor.
Me ke kau i ka hano hoʻonani. Magna cum laude, with high honors, as in academics.
To beautify, adorn.
Intensive of the above. To be proud; to be vainglorious; to be haughty; to be arrogant.
To act the spendthrift; to waste property.
To put on makeup. Niʻihau. Also hoʻouʻiuʻi.
See NANUE, to swell up. To tremble; to shake. See NAUE.
To cause delay.
See nāpai, to bend in. To crook; to bend; to arch.
Caus/sim of nape.
See NAPE, bending; flexible. To bend; to crook; to bend, as an elastic stick.
Same as above; to wound, to make soft; to digest, as food.
See NAPELE, to hurt; to wound. To make a wound on the head; to swell, as the effect of a wound; to swell out, as the belly.

To be soft and yielding, as a boggy, miry place; to shake, as a bog; to soften, as the food in the stomach; o ka opu, oia kahi e hoonapele ai i ka ai, the stomach is the place to soften the food. Anat. 51.
Intensive of hoʻonapele.
To straighten; to make straight.

To cause to shake, revolve, sway, rock; to disturb. Ka ua hōʻoni, hoʻonaue i ka puʻu koʻa, the rain sways in a dance and shakes the coral pile. No ke aha lā ʻoe i hoʻonaue mai ai iaʻu?, Why have you disquieted me? Cf. ue 1.
See NAUE, to vibrate. To cause to rock; to reel to and fro; to shake, as the earth in an earthquake.
To move a little; to shove along. See NAWE and NAUWE.
To cause to sway back and forth.
Freq. of hoʻonāueue. To rock; to shake to and fro.
Causing irritation; aggravating, annoying, exasperating, provoking.
See UKI and NAUKI. To fret; to provoke; to make one angry.
Caus/sim of nāuki.
Redup. of hoʻonauki; to provoke, annoy.
See hoʻonauki. To provoke; to make angry.
To provoke to anger by taunting and teasing.
See NAULU, to vex. To vex; to provoke. To vex.
See nā and hoʻonā with wale. To comfort; to attempt to quiet without effort.
To cause weakness; to enfeeble; to feign weakness. ʻO ke anu ka mea hoʻonāwali i ke kino, cold is what weakens the body.
See NAWALI, weak; feeble. To be weakly; to be sickly; to have little strength.
To totter when one walks; to be thin; to be flexible.
Caus/sim of nāwaliwali.
Intensive of hoʻonāwali.
Same as above. Ma ke kamaʻilio hoʻonāwele ʻana, by speaking softly.
See nāwele, fine; small; thin. To make very little; to be fine, like the threads of a spider’s web; to spin, as a spider its web.
Street name.
Teasing, fretting, appealing.
See nē, teasing.
To tease; to fret; to ask for food, as a child.
See one, sand.
Name of a soft porous stone.
See nea, to desolate. To make desolate; to sweep off all; to destroy wholly. See NEO and NEONEO.
To take all away; to dispossess one of everything; to take all the fruits of one’s land.
Street name.
To cause to move, shift, hitch along, push ahead.
See neʻe, to move along.
See NEE, to move. To move; to shove along; to rub against.

example_txt.txt: a circle around a word or words with an arrow going from the words to the place where they are to be moved, in proofreading

definitions.dtxt: To move, as files in computer program.
To slide, without flipping or turning, as a geometric figure, in math. Cf. hoʻohuli.
To back up, as a car. Hoʻoneʻe hope i ke kaʻa, back up the car.
To cause progress. Nā hana hoʻoneʻe mua, improvements [as to property].
Caus/sim of neʻeneʻe.
See neʻe, to move along. To push along; to move frequently; to shake.
See hoʻonahoa. To be severe; to be bold; to act the soldier; to be brave.
Caus/sim of nei.
See neʻi, to move. To move, as people in a tumult; to move, as trees by the wind.
Caus/sim of neʻineʻi.
See neʻi and hoʻoneʻi. To crowd one upon another; to move along, urged by others.
To make dirty, soil.
To deprive, make destitute; to deny, impeach. Ka hoʻonele i ke kanaka i kekahi mau pono, the forfeiture by the individual of some rights. Hoʻonele ʻia lāua i ka ʻai, they lacked food.
See NELE, destitute. To deprive one of something; to make destitute; to deprive of.
Same as above.
To polish, smooth. Hoʻonemo ka wai i ka pōhaku, the water wears the stone smooth.
See NEMO, to smooth over. To be polished; to be made smooth; to be nice and good.
To make smooth; to polish.
Caus/sim of nene.
Hoʻonēnē kaua (FS 139), rumors of war, talk or threats of war.
The voice of a cricket.
To chirp, as a cricket; to sing, as a cricket.
Ka leo o ka ewaewa iki e hoonene ana. Laieik. 149.
To lay waste, devastate, make destitute; desolation; turning to naught.
See NEO, to be silent. To make silence; to hush; to be still.
To be silent from loneliness or desolation.
To be in a wild, lonely place.
Deforestation; to deforest.
Redup. of hoʻoneo. Aia ʻike ʻoukou i ka mea ʻino e hoʻoneoneo ai, when you see the abomination of desolation.
See hoʻoneo. To hush to stillness; to be still.
To be still or quiet for want of people.
To cause plumpness, swelling; plump.
Caus/sim of newa.
Street name.

To bestir, cause to move, shake, disturb, jiggle. See ex., wilimoʻo. Mai noho ʻoe ā hōʻoni i ka wai ua lana mālie (hula chant), do not stay to disturb the water floating peacefully. He moʻolelo hōʻoni puʻuwai, a heart-stirring story.
See ʻoni, to move.
To make smooth and even, as in carving; to remove all vestige of vegetation.
Caus/sim of niania.
See NIA, baldheaded. To make smooth or fair the outside; to be smooth, as a baldhead.
To make fair pretenses.
To blame or accuse falsely. See NIANIA.
To ask questions often and frequently; to question; hooniele.
Var. of hoʻoniniau. Hoʻonianiau i ka naʻauao, quiet, persistent pursuit of knowledge.
Following swiftly and silently; continuing; prolonging; copying, imitating. Hoʻoniau akula ka makāula i kāna pule ʻana, the prophet continued on and on with his prayer.
See NIAU, to sail genteelly. To copy or follow those whose conduct is upright; to do rightly.
To go away and leave one’s company secretly, generally for some evil purpose; a no keia mea (ka ikea ana o ke kahoaka o Laieikawai), hooniau aku la ka Makaula i ka pule ana. Laieik. 26.
Questioning, especially by leading up indirectly rather than directly; quizzing; curious; curiosity.
Caus/sim of nihinihi. ʻAi hoʻonihinihi, to pick at food, as a finicky person; to eat with careful observance of taboos.
See NIHINIHI. To be full of ridges; to diminish upward.
To take slender hold of a thing, as from fear of filth.
To eat sparingly; e ai hoonihinihi.
To lay stones interlocking; to set stones, as in a fence.
Stones inserted in a bank; a stone wall or hedge.

See NIHO, to indent; to set in. To lay stones in a wall; to lay stones in the wall of an embankment, as the lower side of a road, that is, to insert stones into a bank like teeth in the gums. See NIHO, tooth.
To make into a toothed, scalloped, notched design; to make teeth; to carve an irregular notched edge.
To soil, make dirty. He keu ʻoe a ke keiki hoʻoniku ʻaʻahu, never was a child like you for getting clothes dirty and smelly.
See NINA and LINA, soft to the touch. To be soft to the touch.
To be wet and tough, as cold land.
To be weak and feeble, as one recovering from sickness; pili i ka mea ua ola, aole ola loa.
Not to have full cheeks, as one sickly. See PAPALINA.
Freq. of hoʻonina. See NINANINA and LINALINA.
To ask a question; to have questions asked; to ask indirectly.
Redup. of hoʻoniau. Ka hoʻoniniau ʻana iā Lohiʻau, pursuit of Lohiʻau.
Caus/sim of ninihua.
Caus/sim of niniʻo.
To cause dizziness; to spin, as a top.
Redup. of hōʻoni.
Straightness; that which is correct; upright; me ka hoonioniolo o ka manao kekahi, some with correctness of opinion.
See NIONIOLO, correct; straight. To be morally straight; to be upright; to be correct in practice.
To be correct in principle; to have right views.
To go without carrying anything, while others perhaps are heavily loaded; kaumaha lakou, a he hoonioniolo kana hele ana. He kanaka haaheo ka!
To fix, establish firmly. E hōʻonipaʻa loa wau iā ʻoukou, I will plant you securely.
Street name.
To cause sleepiness, make drowsy. E hoʻonipo ʻia ana e ka hiamoe iki, made drowsy by a light sleep.
To make love, court, woo, yearn for. ʻO ka holu nape a ka lau o ka niu, hoʻonipo ana lā i ke ehu kai (song), swaying dipping of the coconut leaves, making love in the sea spray.
See nipo 1, 2.
To cause to spin, whirl, stir. He kaʻao hoʻoniua puʻuwai no Kamiki, a heart-stirring story about Kamiki.
For hoohono. See HONO, to mend, as a garment or a fish net. To join together, as in mending a net; to unite, as in tying sticks together.
To think; to look at attentively; to be sharp upon.
Street name.
To tempt the appetite; to make tasty, season.
See ʻono, delicious.

To cause to cease, as a taboo; to free from taboo; to repeal, revoke; to adjourn, as a meeting; to prostitute, as one’s daughter. Ua wehe ʻākea ʻia ka noa o nā wahi apau o ke kūlanakauhale, the restrictions on all parts of the city were opened up completely.
See NOA, the cessation of a kapu. To cause to cease, as the force of a kapu; to put an end to a kapu.
To cause a burning.
To keep continually burning, as a fire; e hoomau i ke ahi; to burn continually, as a volcano.
See NOE, mist; fine rain. To make thin or small, like a head with few hairs; to be small, like fine rain.
Redup. of hoʻonoe. Cf. lāʻau hoʻonoenoe.
See NOENOE, mist. To make small or fine, as small dots on paper.
To attend, as the mind to little things.
To cause to be red; to be of a reddish color.
To shine with brightness; to be red.
To have a different form.

example_txt.txt: to set bones; a bone setter
he kānāwai e hoʻonoho ana i aupuni
an act to provide a government

definitions.dtxt: To take up residence; to install, establish, provide, seat, locate, arrange, pack, regulate, convey, carry, appoint; to place in authority; to set, as type.
To summon a spirit to possess.
See noho.
The name of a species of fish-hook.
See NOHO, to put down; to place. To set in order; to place rightly; to regulate.
To set up, as printer specifications for a computer.
To rename, in math. Lit. arrange place value.
Redup. of hoʻonoho; to pretend to be possessed by a spirit; to arrange, classify, organize.
In the phrase hoonohonoho akua, the act of setting up or worshipping the poe akua noho; hana ino nui ia kekahi poe hoonohonoho akua, a mahuka lakou ma kahi e aku.
To settle; to establish; to collect together; to arrange.
To format, as a document in a computer program. Cf. hoʻonohonohona, hoʻāla.
Format, as in a computer program. Comb. hoʻonohonoho + -na. Cf. hoʻonohonoho. Hoʻonohonohona pilikino. Custom format.
No definition given.
Caus/sim of noho paʻa.
To arrange, put in order. Hoʻonoho papa i ka ʻōlelo, a talk thoroughly covering an entire subject.
To let down, as the sails of a ship.
See NOI, to beg. To beg; to ask something of another.
Caus/sim of noke.
See NOKE, to be energetic. To work energetically and perseveringly; to be acute in searching for the means to secure an end; to act with energy and intelligence.
Used perhaps for none, to snore.
Caus/sim of nolu.
To cause to munch, move along.
Redup. of hoʻonome; to move the lips silently, as though speaking to oneself. E hoʻonomenome ʻoe i kō waha ā hiki i ka wā e pau ai kuʻu oli ʻana, mouth your words until I finish my chant.
To work slowly and with disinterest; to be a slowpoke.
To create a disturbance, cause trouble, incite.
To joggle; to rustle; to disturb.

To integrate, i.e., incorporate (parts) into a whole. He noniakahi kekahi mau polokalamu kamepiula ma ka hoʻononiakahi pū ʻana i nā hana kikokiko palapala me ka hōkeo ʻikepili, a me kekahi mau ʻano o ka lako polokalamu pū kekahi. Some computer programs are integrated by integrating word processing functions together with database and other software functions. Comb. hoʻo- + noniakahi. See noniakahi.
Caus/sim of nonō.
To nurse jealousy and ill will; to hate.
To chirp like a bird; to warble; to sing.
To coo like a dove.
To growl, as a dog.
To grunt like a hog.
To snort, as a horse.
Promptness; readiness; having a supply. See KUONOONO.
For hooonoono. See ONO, ready. To be ready; to be prompt; to be mature; to act the man.
To make tasty, flavor, create a desire. Hōʻonoʻono ʻai, appetizer, condiment, dressing, relish, hors dʻoeuvre. Hōʻonoʻono lau ʻai, salad dressing.
To make tasty. Mea hōʻonoʻono. Flavoring.
To cause to think, reflect; reminiscent, recalling to mind, remembering. Cf. more common hoʻomanaʻo.
See noʻonoʻo, to think. To cause to think upon; to remember; to consider; to reflect upon.
To throw, pelt; to put forth physical effort; to strain; to pretend or cause to throw. Cf. haʻanou.
See NOU, to throw a stone. To throw a stone; to pelt with stones; to throw, as missiles.
To loosen; to send forth.
See haʻanoʻu.
Caus/sim of ʻonou.
To moan, groan, sigh, hum, roar, etc. Ka ua ʻawaʻawa e hoʻonū lā i uka, the bitterly cold rain pattering in the uplands.
Street name.
To heap up; to give generously and continuously; to indulge, as a child; surging, rising in swells, as the sea.
A treading; vigorous exercise.
To tread upon continually; to do over and over again; to act with energy and perseverance.
Redup. of hoʻonuʻa. ʻUla Kalaeloa i ka lepo a ka makani, hoʻonuʻanuʻa i ka lepo (chant), Kalaeloa is red with the wind’s dirt, encrusted with dirt.
To be ennobled; to be honored; to be rich.
To cause to sulk; to sulk.
See NUHA, silent; taciturn. To be idle; to be lazy; to be indisposed to do anything.
To sit still, as a person unable to walk.
To be disabled.
A palsied person; one disabled from palsy.
Intensive of hoʻonuha.
Redup. of hoʻonuha.
Street name.

To enlarge, increase, multiply, magnify, exaggerate, add to, dilate; multiplication; to increase in volume, of music; crescendo mark in music. Hoʻonui leo, loud speaker. Hoʻonui ʻōlelo, wordy, verbose, padded, prolix; to exaggerate, boast, enlarge on the truth; to talk excessively.
See nui 1.
See NUI, to be great. To cause to enlarge; to grow big; to increase.
To boast; to brag. See HAANUI.
Multiplication; to multiply. See entries below and helu hoʻonui kemikala. Kaha hoʻonui. Multiplication sign. ʻAnopili ʻole o ka hoʻonui. Zero property of multiplication (preceded by ke).
Enrichment; to enrich, i.e., to increase knowledge. Lit. increase knowledge. Puke hoʻonui ʻike. Enrichment book, challenge book.
See pahu hoʻonui leo.
Intensive of hoʻonui.
Factorial, in math. Comb. hoʻonui + pā + ʻanuʻu. ʻEono hoʻonui pāʻanuʻu. Six factorial (6!).
Ham. To multiply through, in math.
To twist the face to one side.
Same as hoʻolupalupa. Ua piha kā kākou mau mele me nā hoʻonupanupa ʻana a ia mea, he aloha, our songs are filled with lush [descriptions] of that thing, aloha.
To eat heartily (see saying koʻu 1).
Greediness after food; a voracious appetite; a seizing food with eagerness.
Greedy after food.
See NUU and ANUU, a raised place. To be greedy in eating; to eat to great fullness; to gormandize; applied to a single person. See HOOKUKU. Hence,
To swell: to rise up, as one’s stomach from great eating.
To begrudge the food another eats.
To insert, put in, pierce, cause to pierce.
To walk stooped; to cause to stoop; to imitate a stooped person.
See hōʻoiʻoi. Assuming; desirous of appearing at the head; conceited; vain.
To harden, stiffen, resist, strengthen. Hōʻoʻoleʻa kino, to strengthen the body, as with physical exercise; calisthenics.
Caus/sim of oloolo.; to elongate.
See ʻoluʻolu and hōʻoluʻolu. To comfort; to console one in affliction and pain; to give to body or mind; to please.
To shape concavely; to turn down the rim of a hat on both sides of the face so that the front is like the flare of a bonnet.
See ʻoʻoma, concave.
Chisel.
To cause lameness, to feign lameness.
See ʻoʻopa, lame.
Street name.

About the same as pā 4; to touch; to try out, test. E hele aku ʻoe e hoʻopā i ke kahuna pule, go and see if you can get the minister to help, put a “touch” to him. Pōhaku hoʻopā, touchstone. Hoʻopā iki, to touch lightly or cautiously; to eat or drink sparingly.
To procure barrenness, as by prayer or medication.
See pā, to touch, and pā, barren.
See PA, to touch. To cause to touch; to take hold of; to hit; to strike.
To cause such aching.
To cause to squeeze.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: i hoʻopaʻa mai iā lākou iho
to bind themselves [as under contract to a chief]
Hoʻopaʻa ihola lāua ā ʻelua i berita.
The two together sealed a covenant.
to keep the minutes; to record a story
Ua hoʻopaʻa au i mau noho no māua i ka ʻaha mele.
I reserved some seats for us at the concert.

definitions.dtxt: To make fast, firm, hard, tight, solid; to bind, attach, moor, snub, hold fast to, hold back, keep, restrain, confine, detain, withhold, reserve, close, catch; to learn, memorize, master, study, complete, fix; to record, as music; to plug or seal, as a hole; to subscribe, as to a newspaper; to order, reserve, register; to insist on, persist; to insure; to bolt, as a door; to muzzle; drummer and hula chanter (the memorizer); insurance. Cf. hoʻopaʻa haʻawina, mea hoʻopaʻa, ʻōlelo hoʻopaʻa.
See paʻa 1.
See PAA, fast; tight. To make fast; to bind; to keep tight; to detain.
To tie or fasten a thing; to make tight.
To stop one’s speech; to be silent; you have said enough. Laieik. 65.
To record, as on a cassette. Also ʻoki.
To set, as margins or tabs on a computer file or typewriter.

example_txt.txt: E hoʻopaʻa i nā kāwāholo ma kēlā me kēia ʻumi kaʻahua.
Set the tabs every ten spaces.

definitions.dtxt: To turn off, as water.
To study the lesson; studious.
To make a prisoner. Hoʻopaʻahao pono ʻole, false imprisonment.
To freeze (something). Sh. hoʻopaʻa i ka hau. Cf. paʻahau.
Same as paʻakikī; to cause hardness, obstinacy; to pretend to be hard, stubborn.
Stubbornness; disobedience.
See PAAKIKI, hard morally and physically. To hold fast to one’s opinion; to be obstinate; to be unyielding.
To have no respect to other’s feelings, person or property.
To be hard in the treatment of others; to be hard hearted.
Hoʻopaʻakope Copyright; to copyright.
To cause to clot, congeal, etc.
Copyright; to copyright.
To encode, encrypt, as computer data. Comb. hoʻo- + pāʻālua. See hoʻokala pāʻālua, pāʻālua.
To keep a memorandum, make a record of thoughts, memorize.
To make a budget. E hoʻopaʻa kākou i moʻohelu kālā no ka pāʻina Kalikimaka. Let’s make a budget for the Christmas party.
To memorize.
To make sport, cause to play, joke, playful. He mea hoʻopāʻani, a game.
Life insurance; to get life insurance.
To argue, dispute; argument, quarrel.
See paʻapaʻa 1, 4.
See PAAPAA, to dispute. To be hard upon others; hence,
To dispute pertinaciously; to contend; to quarrel; to have a mental contest.
To make a crackling sound, etc.
To cause pain to be soothed; to entertain.
To make crowded, covered with, stifling, etc. Ua hoʻopaʻapū lākou i kō waena ou me ka haunaele, they filled those around you with violence.
To concentrate, i.e., make less dilute. Cf. hoʻokaiaka. See paʻapūhia.
To enslave, overwork, treat as a drudge.
To insure property; property insurance.
To build up an embankment, row, cluster.
To cause to land, reach shore. Hoʻopae malū, to smuggle, bring in secretly. Waiwai hoʻopae malū ʻia, smuggled goods.
See pae, cluster, and pae, to land.
See PAE, to go ashore. To cause to arrive at land; to go ashore from a canoe, boat or vessel.
To float ashore, as anything at sea.
To throw up on a bank of a kalo patch.
A desire and an effort to obtain another’s property; a species of robbery.
See PAE, to misunderstand. To hear indistinctly through some noise; to misunderstand what is said; to be partially deaf.

To bring on line, as a computer system. Ua hoʻopaʻeʻe ʻia maila ka ʻōnaehana ma hope o ka hoʻoponopono ʻia e ka luna pūnaewele. The system was brought on line after the network supervisor fixed the problem. Comb. hoʻo- + paʻeʻe. Cf. hoʻopahemo. See paʻeʻe.
To cause to go astray, mislead, misrepresent.
To blacken, etc.
See PAELE, to be dirty. To besmear; to defile; to make dirty; to blacken. Figuratively, to disturb with other thoughts and reflections. Laieik. 142.
To cause such digging.
Redup. of hoʻopāʻeli.
To build up a paepae (platform) or a taro embankment; to finish a space in quilting.
Redup. of hoʻopae.
See HOOPAE above. To be driven or dashed on shore by the surf; to ride ashore through the surf.
To be noisy, as a distant sound; to talk loudly.
See paʻē, to sound. To make a loud boisterous noise in conversation; to talk with a loud voice so that everybody can hear.
To cause to be crooked, wrong, etc.
See paʻewa. Crookedness in dealing; so dealing as to get the advantage; also, in conversation, a perversion of truth or an erroneous statement. It is often connected with robbery and murder.
Redup. of hoʻopaʻewa.
To cause swollenness; to hoist the shoulders; to strut.
Sceptical. He kanaka hoʻopāhala, he manaʻoʻiʻo ʻole (Kep. 107), a skeptical person of no faith.
To mystify, bewilder, cause wonder, puzzle; transfigured. Hoʻopāhaʻohaʻo ʻia ihola ia i mua o lākou, he was transfigured before them.
To cause to slip, slide; to make smooth, slippery; to smooth with oil, as the hair; to lubricate. See ex., kū 13.
See paheʻe, slippery.
See PAHEE, to slip. To slip; to slide; to fall prostrate; to fall down; to slide, as the feet in a slippery place.
See kele hoʻopaheʻe.
Caus/sim of pāheʻeheʻe.
Intensive of hoʻopāheʻe.
To cause to be ensnared; to ensnare, deceive.
See pahele, to ensnare. To ensnare; to take or catch with a snare.
Var. of hoʻopakelo.
Same as pāhemahema; to cause awkwardness, to fake lack of skill.
To cause to slip, slacken, loosen, etc.
See HEMO and PAHEMO, to loosen. To loosen; to slip off, as an axe from the helve.

To take off line, as a computer system. Na ka luna pūnaewele i hoʻopahemo i ka ʻōnaehana i hiki iā ia ke hoʻouka i kekahi mau lako polokalamu hou ma luna o ka pūnaewele. The system was taken off-line so that the network supervisor could install some new software onto the network. Comb. hoʻo- + pahemo. Cf. hoʻopaʻeʻe. See pahemo.
Redup. of hoʻopahemo.
Caus/sim of pāhenehene.

Touch pass, in basketball; to make such a pass. Hoʻopāhiʻa ʻia aku nei ke kinipōpō e Nalu iā Piko, a laila, iā Kekua. The ball was touch passed by Nalu to Piko, and then to Kekua. Comb. hoʻo- + pāhiʻa.
To tell lies.
To cause such a wind; to blow, as such a wind, etc.
To make shiny, etc.
Caus/sim of pāhiwa.
To cause to spread, have spread.
See pahole, to peel off. To peel; to pull off, as the skin of a banana.
To rub; to polish.
To do a thing with indifference.
To have mended, etc.
Redup. of hoʻopāhono.
To cause to push, etc.
See PAHU, to mock; to push away. To mock; to deride; to treat with contempt.
To defend off; to push away.
To snap, as parching corn.
To beat the pahu or drum.
To frighten, as one who carries the report of death or calamities.
To explode, set off, as dynamite or firecrackers; to blast, blow up. Mokulele hoʻopahū nui, large bomber.
To spoil, wreck.
To move sideways; to sail to windward.
To strengthen; to confirm.
To sail in a zigzag manner; to beat against the wind.
To dance.
To cause to gush forth.
To exhaust the soil; to let the land rest and lie fallow.
To have a nightmare; nightmare; to haunt; to bring bad luck; unlucky.
Redup. of hoʻopahū; to drum or stamp with force; to squeeze certain types of small fish so they burst.
A drumming or thrumming on a pahu or drum; a thumping; aole wau i moe iki, i ka hoopahupahu wale ia no a ao wale. Laieik. 198.
See PAHU. To snap, as corn in the fire; to crack or make a report, as a pistol.
To beat the drum.
To do a thing very quickly or rapidly.
Street name.
To encourage, cause to rouse, etc.
See pai.

A. To slap, hit, punish, chastise, fine, pay back, seek revenge; punishment, revenge, fine, penalty. ʻŌlelo hoʻopaʻi, sentence (penalty). Ka mea hoʻopaʻi koko, avenger of blood. b. Design with 12 to 18 ruled parallel lines on a tapa beater. Hoʻopaʻi hāluʻa, sets of parallel lines on a beater at right angles.
See paʻi, to slap.
An avenger; ka hoopai koko, an avenger of blood.
See PAI, to strike. To strike back; to revenge; to treat one as he treats us.
To pay back; to punish; to punish according to law.
To stir up; to excite; to reward either good or evil.
To make similar; to copy the clothing or manners of another, to ape, mimic, imitate.

Detention, as punishment at school. Ua pono nā keiki kolohe e holoi i ka lumi lua i hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa. The rascal kids had to clean the bathroom for detention. Lit. punish (by) detaining. Cf. hoʻokuʻu no ka manawa. Hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa i ka wā kula. In-school detention. Hoʻopaʻi ʻauʻa muli kula. After-school detention.
To peel.
To make a significant gesture by putting the thumb between the fingers.
To give a warning with the hand.
To tempt, or to kuamuamu; eia na olelo hou e hewa ai, o ke kake, o ka olelo Kauai, o ka hoopaiho lima.
To rub the skin from the arm; to skin.
To make crooked.
This word is said to be peculiar to Kauai.
Caus/sim of paikau.
See pā, to touch, and iki, little. To touch lightly or softly; to move gently; to move a very little.
Caus/sim of pailani.

To cause nausea, vomiting; nauseating, sickening, revolting, disgusting, loathsome. Nā mea lele ʻē aʻe apau e kolo ana, me nā wāwae ʻehā, he mea ia e hoʻopailua ʻia e ʻoukou, all other flying things that creep, which have four feet, shall be an abomination unto you.
See pailua, nausea.
Sickness at the stomach; disgust; loathing.
A disgusting sight; an abomination.
See PAILUA, nausea. To be sick at the stomach; to nauseate.
To dislike greatly; to be displeased with.
Caus/sim of paio. (FOR. 6:487).
To enrich, i.e., to improve the nutritive value of something. Comb. hoʻo- + paiola. Hoʻopaiola ʻia. Enriched.
Redup. of hoʻopai; to promote, cheer, lobby; promotion, agitator.
To lobby, i.e., to conduct activities aimed at influencing public officials or legislation.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻāhewa nui ʻia nā luna aupuni no ka lawelawe ʻana no ka poʻe hoʻopaipai.
Political leaders are often accused of catering to lobbyists.
sickness or trouble due to the displeasure of the ʻaumakua, family god

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hoʻopaʻi.
To cause to cheat.
To shape into a low, wide door or bowl.
See PAKAKA, to be smooth. To make smooth; to swell up, as a swelling of the skin; hence,
To be smooth and shining; to swell, as the belly so as to be smooth.
To glide smoothly, as over a surface.
Caus/sim of pākakaʻa.; to mill around.
To talk gibberish.
See KAKE and PAKAKE. To practice the kake.
To talk unintelligibly except to those instructed in a kind of mystical language.
To talk like a foreigner without learning his language.
To cause bad luck.
To bring destitution or poverty. He mea hoʻopakaneo ka piliwaiwai, gambling causes poverty.
Same as pakauʻaʻaka; provocative of crankiness.
See AKA, to laugh. To cause one to laugh; to create laughter; to make sport.
To cause to be brittle, weak.
See PAKE, to push away. To partition off; to guard; to defend; to push away; to allow to escape.
To imitate or act like a Chinese.
To cause to exceed. Na ia mea i hoʻopākela aku i kona ʻike, it was this thing that made his knowledge great.
To rescue, save or deliver from danger, free; to protect; to help escape. Hana kinai ahi hoʻopakele, fire-protection work.
See pakele, to escape.
Papa Hana Hoʻopakele Sila. Seal Recovery Program.
See PAKELE, to escape. To cause to escape from; to deliver; to save one from danger.
Caus/sim of pakelo.
See PAKELO, to slip out of. See PAKELE. To slip out of the grasp of a person or thing, as a fish from the hands.
To inject; to give an enema.
To thrust out, slip out, etc.
To increase, exceed. Ua hoʻopākeu ʻia aku nā keneka o ka waiwai kūʻai, more cents were added to the sales value.
See PAKI and PAKE, to resist; to push away. To be hard against; to resist; to push; to crowd out, as an egg about to hatch; to swell out; to urge through any opposing substance.
To splash, spatter, etc.
To act as though one has plenty, to show off, as by spending in a flashy way.
To smash, etc.
To flatten out.
Redup. of hoʻopākiʻi.
To make smooth, as by polishing; to make slippery, as by greasing; to cause to slip and slide.
Redup. of hoʻopakika.
Caus/sim of pākīkē.
Caus/sim of pakikī.
See PAKIKI and PAAKIKI, very hard. To resist; to set against; to stir up; to excite.
To harden; to be or act obstinately.
To skim stones on the surface of the water.
Redup. of hoʻopākī.
Caus/sim of pākiko.
Caus/sim of pākikokiko.
See PAKIO, to drop continually. as rain. To cause to rain frequently; to drop down rain continually.
Caus/sim of pakīpakī.
Redup. of hoʻopakika.
Var. of hoʻopōkole.
See PAKOLE and POKOLE, to be short. To curb in; to restrain; to shorten; to make short.
To burst, etc.
To do over and over; to render commonplace or trite, as a song.
To beat, cause to beat.
Redup. of hoʻopākuʻi. Ua hoʻopākuʻikuʻi ʻia mai kō lāua noho ʻana malaila e nā kānaka, their way of life there received blow after blow from the people.
Caus/sim of pākuʻikuʻi.
To be brisk at work; to work quickly, without laziness.
Redup. of hoʻopakū, to pop, as a Portuguese man-of-war that is stepped upon on the beach.
Street name.
To ripen, turn yellow. Hoʻopala maiʻa, to ripen bananas [as by burying in a pit].
To daub, besmear.
See pala, ripe, and pala, dab.
See PALA, mellow; soft. To make soft; to ripen soft, as dead-ripe fruit.
To stain; to daub; to smutch; to plaster.
To cause to fall, trip, push over; to fall.
To spread, extend, flatten; leveling, flattening. Ke hoʻopālaha maila ka moa maluna o nā hua, the hen spreads out over the eggs.
Redup. of hoʻopālaha 1. Ua hoʻopālahalaha mai ke Akua iaʻu, God has caused me to be fruitful.
See LAHA, to extend. To spread out; to make broad; to widen.
To stain, besmear. Ā hoʻopalaheʻa no wau i koʻu ʻaʻahu apau, I shall stain all my raiment [with blood].
See PALAHEA, dirty.
To defile; to daub over; to stain; to make dirty.
Redup. of hoʻopalaheʻa.
To cause to flee, chase.
See palaheʻe, to shrink from duty. To be lazy; to be unoccupied.
To cause to rot, etc.
To cause to turn, fall.
To turn upside down; to turn over and over.
To be lazy; to be unoccupied.
To have turned the face away, to cause to turn away; ashamed, confused, etc. E hilahila auaneʻi, a e hoʻopalai maka hoʻi ka poʻe, the people shall be put to shame and confounded.
See kīloi hoʻopalai.
To feign indifference; indifferent, etc.
Peeved, resentful. Cf. kaʻeo.
To curve, bend, stoop.
Caus/sim of palalē.
See PALALE, to be slovenly. To speak with another voice; to disguise the voice; to stammer; to vociferate.
Caus/sim of palaleha. to neglect. ʻO ka lima hoʻopalaleha, he mea ia e ʻilihune ai, he becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand.
See PALALEHA, slothful. To be slothful; to be idle; to be careless.
Var. of hoʻopalaleha.
To be idle; to waste time; to be inactive.
To cause nervousness, weakness.
To sound thus.
To guard, protect, as a taboo princess in a pālama.
To cause to go sour, rancid.
To cause a strong offensive smell, as that of tar, sulphur, etc.
To betroth in marriage; engaged.
Betrothed; engaged in marriage, as a woman to a man.
To engage to marry, as a man and woman; to make an agreement of marriage.
To betroth, as parents a daughter; to make a matrimonial alliance.
To cause to tell tall tales.
See PALAU, to lie; to deceive. To lie; to deceive; to act treacherously.
Caus/sim of pālaulau.
To fend or ward off; to separate, partition off; to defend in court; to disown. Ma ka ʻaoʻao hoʻopale, on the side of the defendant.
See pale 1.
See PALE, to ward off. To drive off from; to defend off when attacked; to separate from.
To be or act the defendant in court.
To write protect, as a computer file or disk. Ua hoʻopale kākau ʻia kēia pā e aʻu. This disk has been write protected by me. Lit. ward off writing. Hoʻopale kākau ʻia. Write protected.
To save, rescue.
To cause laziness; same as above.
See PALELA, idle; lazy. To be indisposed to work; to be idle; to be lazy.
To drown, plunge into water, sink.
See PALEMO, to sink in water. To plunge; to cause to sink in water.
Caus/sim of palena.; to confine.
See pale and hoʻopale. To separate; to ward off; to loosen.
To divide in fives; same as above.

Caus/sim of palipali. E ʻeku i ka moku e kupu ā puʻu, e hoʻopalipali ana ke kua, hoʻopalipali ke alo (KL. lines 488–9), root up the land that it may grow high, build cliffs in back, build cliffs in front.
To feign ignorance, act dumb. Also hoʻohūpō.
See PALO, to live idly. To sit speechless, as one watching others; to sit silent and quiet, but with sly and wicked thoughts or intentions.
To cause garrulousness; same as above.
To cause to lick, to lick.
See PALU, to lick or lap water. To lick or lap water with the tongue, as a dog.
To run out the tongue to taste.
To paint or daub over; to blot; to paint, as in painting a map.
Street name.
To divide in two parts; double; pair.
To put two things together, as two letters in reading.
To make soft, pulpy; to reduce to pulp, cook until soft.
Var. of hoʻopaluhē.
See paluheʻe, to soften. To make soft; to cook soft; to cause to flow.
Caus/sim of pāluku.
To soften, weaken, mollify, make pliant or flexible; to feign softness.
See PALU, soft; gentle. To soften; to be soft or tender, as a sick person; to be young and tender; to be weak and flexible.

definitions.der: [PPN fana, PEP pana; the meaning ‘bow, arrow’ is noted only in Marquesan pana and Hawaiian; see Green, p. 24]
definitions.dtxt: Caus/sim of pana.
To seek revenge, reward, etc.
See pānaʻi, revenge.
To colonize, as a land by either people, animals, or plants. Comb. hoʻo- + panalāʻau. Cf. hoʻokolonaio.
Redup. of hoʻopanau.
To cause to seesaw, wander, etc.; to make the vulgar gesture.
Redup. of hoʻopanau.
Caus/sim of pane.
See PANE, to speak in reply. To reply back and forth in conversation; to make a reply to what has been said.
To postpone, delay, put off, defer, procrastinate.
Caus/sim of paneʻe.
Put off; postponed; delayed; uku hoʻopaneʻe, interest on a debt.
See paneʻe, to postpone. To put off; to push out of place; to postpone doing a thing; to delay.
Redup. of hoʻopaneʻe; to keep putting off, etc.
To cause controversy by arguing; same as above.
See pane and hoʻopane above. To speak and reply; to answer each other, as people in conversation.
To cause a closing, pretend to close.
Same as hoʻoniniʻo.
See above. To variegate with colors; to put different colors on a thing; e wai kilikiloia, e panionio.
Same as hoʻoniʻo, streaked.
To be like a cowboy or pretend to be a cowboy.
See pāniʻo, to spot; to paint. To spot; to print, as in printing kapa; to variegate.
To cause darkness; to make mysterious, unknown, unfathomable; same as above.
Caus/sim of panoa.; to cause barrenness.
See PANOA, wild dry land. To be dry, hard and rocky, as a barren dry place.
Desertification, i.e., the processes by which an area becomes a desert, in geography.
Redup. of hoʻopano. ʻEleʻele Hilo ē, hoʻopanopano i ka ua, Hilo is black, darkened in the rain.
See PANOPANO and PAPANO, thick; black; glossy. To make thick and black, as a cloud; to be thick, glossy black.
To regulate.
To cause quarrel, strife; to argue.
Redup. of hoʻopāoni.
Caus/sim of pāono.
To place in rank or file; to put in order, to put in layers, overlay, as shingles; to make a shelf; to pack neatly.
A shelf made by placing sticks across the corner of a room.
The condition of a female with a board tied on to her abdomen to secure her conception; a e hoomaemae i kona hanau keiki.
See PAPA, a row; a rank. To place in rows or ranks, as soldiers; to lay in rank one above another; to pack in order, as clothes in a trunk.
See pāpā, to touch.
For hoʻopaʻapaʻa. To quarrel; to contend; to dispute; to scold.
Pa doubled. See PA, to touch. To touch; to feel; to take hold of; to examine.
To communicate with each other, as husband and wife.
To be intimate with another person’s wife or husband.
To backup, as a file in a computer program. E hoʻopapaʻa i kēia waihona. Backup this file. Comb. hoʻo- + papaʻa.
To make crisp, brittle; to burn, scorch. Hoʻopāpaʻa palaoa, to toast bread. Palaoa hoʻopāpaʻa, toast. Also paʻapaʻa.
To burn; to scorch in the fire, as food burnt black.
To measure depth, as in the ocean. Lit. cause echoes in depths. See hawewe kani.
Redup. of hoʻopaʻi; to move the stomach muscles, as in certain hula dances.
See PAPAI, to strike with the open hand. To move softly or gently; to move lightly.
To touch or strike softly.
Redup. of hoʻopailua; beginning to be nauseated, first symptoms of nausea.
To make vertical. Comb. hoʻo- + papakū. See papakū.
To touch hands as in making an agreement.
See PAPA and LIMA, to touch hands. To touch, join or shake hands as confirmatory of a previous agreement.
definitions.notes: Note: This was an ancient practice among Hawaiians.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hoʻopapau.
To devote oneself, to make an effort to finish up, to concentrate.
Engagedness; devotedness; earnestness and perseverance in a pursuit.
See PAPAU, to be intent. To be all engaged in a thing; to be wholly taken up with it.
To be in earnest in a work or in an affair; to have great anxiety about a thing.
To persevere.
To make a truce or armistice.

To put an end to, finish, get rid of, suppress, terminate, conclude, annul, stop, cancel, revoke, repeal, abolish, consume; to dismiss or discharge, as from work; to use too much, waste; cancellation, finishing; completely, all. Cf. hoʻopau manawa. Hoʻopau ʻana, abolition, cancellation, revocation. Hoʻopau hoʻoʻino ʻia aku, dishonorably discharged [as from the armed services]. Hoʻopau ʻai, to waste food, said figuratively of one not worth his food. Hoʻupau wale, nolle prosequi. E hoʻopau ʻoe i kāu uwe ʻana, stop your crying. E hoʻopau ʻia ā ma kēia ke hoʻopau loa ʻia nei ke kānāwai, the law shall be and hereby is revoked. Ka hoʻopau ʻana o ka ʻaelike, cancellation of contract. Ua hoʻopau ʻia kō Hauaʻīliki naʻau ʻeʻehia, ala aʻela ia ā halo wikiwiki akula (Laie 457), Hauaʻīliki’s heart was completely filled with terror, he jumped and ran swiftly away.
See pau, finished.
See PAU, all. To make an end of a thing; to finish; to complete a work; to cease to work.
To devour; to consume all.
To soil, smudge, make sooty.
To treat as a drudge, overwork, oppress with tedious labor.
To soak, moisten, dampen.
To put on a pāʻū.
See PA-U, a woman’s garment. To put or gird on the pa-u; to bind on one, as a loose garment; to tie around.
Caus/sim of pauaho; to cause shortness of breath, panting, despair, etc. Hoʻopauaho lākou iā lākou iho i ka ʻimi i ka puka, they wearied themselves to find the door.
To make grotesque, odd. Same as hoʻopauaho.
See PAUAKA, to be weary. To work without wages or reward; to be compelled to work gratis; to oppress with hard labor; to work here and there.
To soil, make dirty.
To exert one’s self greatly, as in carrying a very heavy load; to be strong; to be energetic.
Similar to hoʻopaumanawa.
To cause to fall into a deep sleep, as a drug.
To utilize the process of electrolysis. See pā uila.
See LINA, soft; yielding. To work lazily or carelessly because of little or no pay.
To soil, make dirty, smear, pollute, befoul, defile.
See PAUMAELE, to defile. To cause defilement or pollution; to daub over; to foul; to dirty.
To cause great grief, lamentation; to pretend grief.
See PAUMAKO, heaviness of eyes. To have great affection for; to weep over one for grief; to be sad at the loss of a friend or anything valuable.
To waste time. See paumanawa.
To waste time; to play the child after one has grown up; to act foolishly; to live idly.
See HOOPAUMAELE. To defile; to make filthy; to render vile; polluted.
Redup. of hoʻopaʻū.
See hoʻopau and aho, breath. To be nearly out of breath; to pant; to breathe hard.
To be weary in doing a thing; to be discouraged.
Redup. of hoʻopaʻuhia.
See lumi hoʻopaupilikia.
To cause to turn away, snub, etc.
To crush, break fine, mash, pulverize; to cringe, assume a humble or fearful attitude. See ex., kūpaoa.
To drench, soak.
To perfume, anoint.
See pē, crushed; pē, perfumed; and pē, drenched.
Perfumed; anointed with perfumed substances.
See PE, to anoint. To anoint with what is perfumed; hence, to perfume.
See PEPE, mashed; bruised. To break up; to break fine; to scatter abroad; to roll over anything; to mash it.
To tie a bundle. Ā laila hōʻope ʻia maila ā paʻa i ka ʻope, then it was bundled up securely in a bundle.
See ʻope, bundle.
To cross and tie; Fig. To persecute. No ka huāhuā i hoʻopeʻa aku ai lākou iāia, for envy they had bound him.
See PEA, to make a cross; to oppose. To accuse or punish an innocent person; to bring one into difficulty; to deal falsely or unjustly.
Ancient surfing area, Hanalei, North Kauaʻi. (Finney, 1959a:53) Probably.
To beckon or wave, pretend to wave, etc.
To cross the hands behind the back. See peʻa 1.
Redup. of hoʻopeʻahi.
To hide or pretend to hide.
To create confusion; confusion; confusing.
Redup. of hoʻopeʻe; camouflage.
To conceal one’s self; to go off out of sight through shame or diffidence.
To deceive one; to get him into difficulty. See HOOPEA above.
Same as hoʻēheu.
To cause to throw or pretend to throw.
To swell, cause to swell, brag, boast.
Redup. of hoʻopehu; to brag; braggadocio; swollen, billowy, as a cloud.
Full; large; spreading, as clouds: he ao hoopehupehu.
Same as hoʻopēheu.
Caus/sim of peki.
To have kicked, cause to kick, feign kicking, kick.
To befoul, make dirty or filthy, soil, pollute.
To knead.
Caus/sim of peleki.
To cause to spread, extend; same as above.
Caus/sim of pelo.
Caus/sim of pelopelo.
To fold, turn, etc.
To cause to sop, dunk; to dunk.
Redup. of hoʻopenu.
Redup. of hōʻope.
To act like a baby; infantile. Var. of hōpēpē
See PEPE, soft; pliable. To be downcast or ashamed; to be not bold; not confident.
To bend, twist, etc. (Kep. 159)
To cause to beat, strike, kill; to pretend to beat.
Redup. of hoʻopehu; to flex the muscles or make them bulge.
Strong; muscular; energetic; he hoolua nui ke kuaaina, he hoopepehu.
See PELU, to bend over. To cause to bend or double over.
To be in doubt; to be doubtful which way to go.
To talk double, here and there; e lauwili, e olelo pelupelu.
Street name.
To thrust up, etc.
To follow; to attend.
Stingy, extremely economical, frugal; to skimp.
The name of such persons as were economical in regard to food and took care of it in distinction from the wasteful; o ka poe mahiai malama i ka ai. ua kapaia ua poe la, he hoopi aole o lakou wi.
See PI, to be stingy. To be hard; to be close; to be stingy.
To be sour; to be unsociable.
To make such a package.
To cause anger; to cause to shy; to feign anger.
Street name.
Pono To complete, make completely full, clear, intelligible.

To fill, complete, pervade, stuff, eat one’s fill, cram; to fill out, as a growing child; to breed, as of a female animal; to impregnate; to fill, as a tooth; to load, as a gun; to thread, as a needle. Hoʻopiha ʻia i ka pulupulu, stuffed with cotton. Moa hoʻopiha ʻia me ka laiki, chicken stuffed with rice.
See piha, full.
See PIHA, full, as a container. To cause to fill; to fill full, as a container; to put into a vessel until it runs over.
To overflow its banks, as a stream.
Washer, as used in plumbing. Niʻihau. Also pihi hoʻopiha. See entries below.
To supplement, as angles, in math. Lit. fill (a) line. Cf. hoʻopiha kūpono. Nā huina hoʻopiha kaha. Supplementary angles, i.e., two angles whose measures have a sum of 180°.
To complement, as angles, in math. Lit. fill right (angle). Cf. hoʻopiha kaha. Nā huina hoʻopiha kūpono. Complementary angles, i.e., two angles whose measures have a sum of 90°.

To fill, complete; to file, as cards; frame, questionnaire, any kind of form to be completed. Ke hoʻopihapiha maila ke kino o ke keiki, the body of the child is filling out. Aia ʻo mea maʻō, ke hoʻopihapiha maila, so-and-so is over there, stirring up hard feelings with tales. (Cf. hoʻopihapiha ʻōlelo.)
To make a ruffle; ruffler, as on a sewing machine.
See PIHA. To cause to be full; to overflow; to abound.
To swell up, as the stomach from disease.
To be full, as cloth gathered and plaited into a ruffle; hence,
To be full and flowing, as a ruffle.
To stir up dislike for another, to turn against another, as by telling tales or gossip.
Caus/sim of pihō.
To cause anxiety; to worry, excite, astonish.
To sink, drown.
Street name.
To cause to mount, as of male animals; to breed, impregnate.

To cause to rise, promote, mount, come up, raise up, bring forth, utter; to turn into the wind; promotion. See ex., limalima 4. Me ka hoʻopiʻi aku ma ka inoa o kō kākou Haku, and call forth the name of our Lord.

To sue (see ex., mālama ola), bring suit, bring a complaint to one in authority, accuse in court, prosecute, petition; appeal, lawsuit, court case, petition. Cf. palapala hoʻopiʻi. Mea i hoʻopiʻi ʻia, accused. Hoʻopiʻi ʻāina, to have a suit over land matters. Poʻe (mea) hoʻopiʻi, plaintiff. Poʻe (mea) hoʻopiʻi ʻia, defendant, accused party. Hoʻopiʻi poho, suit for damages.
See piʻi 1, 2, 5.
Same as hoʻopiʻipiʻi.
See PII, to ascend. To cause to ascend; to go up; to appear; to protrude above; ua hoopiia ka huelo o ua moo nui nei. Laieik. 103.
To inform the chief of the fault of a person.
To complain to one in authority of one in error or fault.
To accuse before a court of justice.
To ask a favor.
To breed, impregnate. Cf. haʻakipu. See entries below and pākēneka hoʻopiʻi.

Kumu hoʻopiʻi. Complaint, i.e., a legal document that charges someone with having caused harm. Loio hoʻopiʻi. Prosecutor, prosecuting attorney, plaintiff attorney. Mea hoʻopiʻi. Plaintiff. ʻAoʻao hoʻopiʻi. Prosecution, i.e., the prosecuting party in a court case. ʻAha pane hoʻopiʻi. Arraignment, i.e., a court hearing in which a defendant is formally charged with a crime and enters a plea of guilty or not guilty. ʻAlo hoʻopiʻi ʻelua. Double jeopardy, i.e., to be tried in court twice for the same offense.
Caus/sim of piʻi aliʻi.
To accelerate. Lit. cause to accelerate. Cf. piʻi ka māmā holo. See emi ka māmā holo, hoʻēmi i ka māmā holo.
To make a claim for damages, as to an insurance company. See koi pohō.
To crossbreed. Lit. breed diagonally. Cf. hoʻēhu pua kaʻakepa.
Bonus, extra credit, as a class assignment or question on a quiz. Lit, raise grade. Also ʻai keu. Nīnau hoʻopiʻi kaha. Bonus question, extra-credit question. Also nīnau ʻai keu.

To appeal, i.e., ask a higher court to review a decision made by a lower court. Ua hoʻopaneʻe ʻia ka manaʻo hoʻoholo a ka luna hoʻokolokolo ma kahi o ka hoʻopiʻi kūʻē ʻia mai o kōna manaʻo e ka mea i hoʻāhewa ʻia. The judge’s decision is suspended pending an appeal of his decision by the accused. Lit. appeal (in) opposition. See ʻaha pane hoʻopiʻi.
Indictment; to indict. Hoʻopiʻi kūhelu ʻia ke kanaka no ka ʻaihue. The man was indicted on charges of theft. Lit. officially accuse in court.
Same as piʻina. 2. Quilting in a direction away from the quilter. Also hoʻopiʻipiʻi.
See PIINA. The ascent of a hill; a path or road leading up a hill.
To cause controversy, words of anger, etc.
See piʻi, to go up. To ascend; to go up.
To beat against the wind; to sail in a zigzag manner.
To raise the cud, as ruminating animals.
To cause to flow upward, as water out of a spring.
To dehydrate (something). Hoʻopīkaʻo ʻia nā ʻāpana maiʻa ma loko o ka mīkini hoʻopīkaʻo. Banana pieces are dehydrated in the dehydrating machine. Comb. hoʻo- + pīkaʻo. See pīkaʻo.
To dole out in small quantities.
To shorten, shrink; to make, as a lei piki.
To be too short; to shorten.
To allow to spoil, as fish or meat. Cf. hoʻomelu. Iʻa hoʻopilapilau, slightly tainted fish eaten raw with salt and kukui relish.
To cause a stench.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: ke ʻano a me ka hoʻopili ʻia ʻana o nā helu
the nature and application of numbers
ua hoʻopili ʻia ma ka perita maʻemaʻe o ka male
united in the pure bonds of matrimony

definitions.dtxt: To bring together, stick; to attach oneself to a person; united, as friends; to mimic, imitate; to claim a relationship; to put together, as parts of a puzzle. Cf. hoʻopili wale.
See pili, to cling, and pili, to refer.
Caus/sim of pili.
See PILI, to adhere to. To adhere to; to stick to; to cling to.
To put together the parts of a thing.
To attach one’s self to another; to adhere to a person, as a servant or retainer; no ka hoopili mea ai i loaa mai ka ai ia lakou.
To match, as one thing to its counterpart by drawing a line.
Street name.
To cause sorrow, astonishment, etc. I hoʻopilihua ai ʻoia iā lākou i ke kilokilo ʻana, he had bewitched them with sorceries.
To cause trouble, bother, disturb, inconvenience; to lead into difficulty, get into trouble, meddle. Hōʻailona hoʻopilikia, inauspicious omen.
See PILIKIA, crowded close. To get one into difficulty; to lead one into straits; to cause one to be in want.
A person serving another merely for his living.
To attach one’s self to a chief or rich person for the sake of a living; to be a retainer, especially where not much service is required; to serve merely for a living.

Redup. of hoʻopili; to court, woo, make advances (FS 155); to associate in close friendship; to claim relationship, especially if unwarranted. ʻŌlelo hoʻopilipili, figurative language, simile (cf. hoʻopilipili ʻōlelo, below).
See PILI and PIPILI, to adhere to. To put together two or more things into one; to cause them to adhere closely.
To live together in close friendship, as two intimate friends.
To put in opposition; to bring into difficulty.
Imitation. Waiū hoʻopilipili. Imitation milk.
To claim relationship to a chief, as of one only remotely related, or of one desirous of favors.
Word play, punning; to illustrate a point with parables, stories, anecdotes.
To aggregate, i.e., bind together Lit. cause to unite.
Caus/sim of pili wale. Nohona hoʻopili wale, living as a dependent.
To cause a bad odor.
To elevate, cause to climb.
To swim standing upright; to float, as a log perpendicularly.
To rise and pitch, as a vessel in a storm.
Street name.
To conquer, subdue, defeat, make prisoner, capture, overcome.
To put out, extinguish, as a light or fire.
See PIO, to extinguish. To put out; to extinguish, as a fire or light.
To bend, as a stick; to make an arch; to bend over.
To humble; to reduce to servitude; to make a prisoner of; to conquer.
To turn off, as a light, radio, TV, etc. Cf. hoʻā.
To arch, bend, curve, crook.
To cause confusion, consternation, vexation. E hoʻopiʻoloke au i ka naʻau o nā kānaka, I will vex the hearts of the people.
To be in trouble, as the mind.
