I’m going to load the file on the BBS so that you can download it onto your computer.

definitions.dtxt: Attack, raid. Hoʻouka pānaʻi. Counterattack. Pūʻali hoʻouka kaua. Marine corps.
To cause, pretend, or try to follow, accompany, attend, etc.
See UKALI, to follow. To cause to follow; to follow after; to accompany by following.
To bundle up, pack up, load, as freight.
See UKANA, goods to be carried along. To bundle up or pack movable goods.
Frequent. of hoʻouka.
Same as hoʻoukiuki.
See UKI, UKIUKI and NAUKI. To provoke; to do that which will offend.
To provoke, offend, displease, irritate.
See UKI. To cause one to be offended; to insult.
See uku, pay.
See UKU. A recompense; payment; doing justice.
See UKU, reward. To pay or discharge a debt; to pay a fine; to punish or reward; hoopai.
To enjoy, as the union of the sexes.
To form a tenon or post for the crotch of a rafter.
See ULE, to hang down. To cause to hang; to swing.
See ULE. To swing; to hang pendulous; to ease off; to crook or turn down.
To darken, to make blue, green, etc.; to make the skin black and blue; to bruise.
See uli 1, dark.
See ULI, to be dark colored. To make black; to darken; to be green, as the sea; as a forest.
Same as hoʻouli.
Intensive of hoʻouli.
Street name.

example_txt.txt: to increase and preserve the nation [said to be the aim of King Kalākaua]
prayer for the increased productivity of the land

definitions.dtxt: To grow, sprout, propagate; to cause to increase, as the surf. Cf. mea hoʻ oulu, growth, crop.
See ulu 1, 2.
Var. of hoʻūlu.
See ULU, to grow, as a vegetable. To cause to grow, as seeds planted; to sprout; to increase in size, as fruit.
To lift up; to release, as something fast; ma kahi e paa ai ka waa, e hooulu no kekahi kanaka i ka waa.
See entry below and kāmāhuaola, pahu hoʻoulu meakanu.
To sing in order to encourage men to work.
To assemble.
See ULUA, to assemble. To collect; to assemble together, as men; to collect together, as things.
To grow food plants; a prayer to bless crops. Heiau hoʻoulu ʻai, temple where first crops were offered. Kahuna hoʻoulu ʻai, a priest who made such offerings, agricultural expert.
To create confusion, excitement; to incite, stir up bedlam, cause trouble.
To annoy, weary, vex.
See ULUHUA. To give trouble; to weary; to vex; to oppress; to wear out the patience of one; mai hoouluhua i ke keiki.
To cause fish to be numerous, as by prayer.
To inspire canoe haulers by chant and prayer.
Caus/sim of ulukū.
See ulu 1.
E hooululu akua, to make pretensions of being a god, or having a god in one.
To adorn, decorate attractively.
See ULUMAHIE.

To grow by grafting. Nui nā kala like ʻole o nā pua mēlia e pua nei ma ke kumu mēlia hoʻokahi a koʻu hoa noho ma muli o kāna hoʻoulu pākuʻi ʻana mai nā kumulāʻau like ʻole mai. Many different colored plumeria flowers are blooming on one plumeria tree that belongs to my neighbor; he accomplished this by grafting from different trees. See pākuʻi.
Caus/sim of ulu pono. to make grow well, thrive.
To cause passion, possession, etc.
Caus/sim of uluulu. Hoʻouluulu aʻela ʻo Kawelo i nā akua ona (FS 63), Kawelo appealed to his gods.
See ULU and ULUULU, to collect together. To collect together, as men or things; to assemble in one place.
Hula altar where fresh leis were placed during hula instruction.
Ulu, to collect, and waa, canoe. To collect many canoes together in one place.
To bedeck with plants; to adorn, bedeck, decorate.
Caus/sim of uluwehiwehi.
To cast a shadow, overshadow, frown.
Var. of hōʻumeke.
Caus/sim of ʻumiki; to shape a gourd for a drum, as by tying.
See UMIKI, a gourd. To swell out round and full, as a large gourd.
Intensive of hoʻoʻumiki.
To make an umu; to pile in a heap.
To send, bears stress on the u and on the first o. Hoʻo- usually precedes stems beginning with the vowels i- and u- and all the consonants except the glottal stop. Important meanings follow:
To send. See una.
See UNA, to send. To cause one to go on business; to send on an errand.

Ham/iʻoa To send or enter data into a computer database or calculator after it has been typed; enter, as the enter key by the number pad on an extended computer keyboard. E kōmi iā hoʻouna. Press enter. See kāhoʻi, kāhuakomo. Pihi hoʻouna. Enter key (preceded by ke).
To cause weariness.
Intensive of una. To send frequently.
To perform some part in the hoopiopio or anaana.
To ask or urge one to do a thing; aole o'u manao e hoounauna aku ia olua. Laieik. 21.
Caus/sim of une.
See UNE, to pry up. To pry up, as with a lever; to lift by prying.
Frequentative of hooune. To pry up.
To deceive.
See UNOO, not well cooked. To be not sufficiently cooked; hence.
To be raw; to be red, as raw meat.
Freq. of hoʻounoʻo.
Caus/sim of unu; to massage with the palm of the hand and with quick movements rather than gentle pressure.
To place stones; to pave, macadamize.

definitions.der: [PPN unusi, which is PPN unu + PPN -si]
definitions.dtxt: To have something translated, withdrawn, etc.
Caus/sim of huoi.
To jut, project, cause to puncture, etc.
To crush, belittle, flatten, treat contemptuously (Kep. 107).
See ʻupu, to desire. To desire strongly; to covet; to lust after.
To make small, reduce, lessen.
Caus/sim of uwā.
See UWA, to shout. To cause to cry out; to shout; to be clamorous.
See UWAHI. To rise up, as a column of smoke.
Intensive of hoʻouwā.
See UE and UWE. To cause one to cry; to cry out for pain or grief.
See UWE, to cry. To cause to cry; to make one cry.
Caus/sim of uweke.; to open a little.
To open. See WEHE.
To speak in a small shrill voice, like a weak dying person.
To speak in a small shrill voice, like a weak dying person.
To sound, as a bell; to sound, as a musical instrument.
See HOOUEUE. To be fickle; to move about; to shake.
Caus/sim of uwī.
See UWI. To squeak, as new shoes; to grind the teeth.
To cause to shine through small holes. See UWIKI.
The name of a shade tree; he laau malumalu.
See UWI, to wring; to twist. To wring; to squeeze; to twist.
See foregoing 2. Very small holes.
To retch. See ex., haʻanou.
See wā, roar.
To cause to vomit; to make sick at the stomach; to flow off.
To cause to split, crack.
Var. spelling of hoʻoā.
Same as above; to vomit.
The o and a coalescing give the sound of w. See Gram. § 13:7, note.
To dig up, as a trench; to dig, as with an oo or spade.
To wander about without friends; to be destitute.
To dig a trench; to set out, as plants where many are planted together.
Pas/imp. of hoʻowaʻa, to dig a trench.
To act the fool.
Caus/sim of waʻawaʻalia.
Street name.
See wae, to choose.
To covet; to seize; to take with the knowledge, but without the consent of the owner. See HOOKAHA.
Having a disposition to take another’s property; greedy; he hoowaha, he alunu, he hao wale no.
To stretch the mouth with fingers; to stretch out of shape, as the mouth.
Caus/sim of wahāwahā. Cf. waha 1. Hoʻowahāwahā i ka ʻaha, contempt of court.
See wahāwahā.
See WAHA. To make mouths at; to treat with contempt; to ridicule; to hate; to dislike.
Caus/sim of wāhi.
See WAHI, to break, and WAWAHI, to break up. To grind or break to pieces.
See WAHINE, woman. To make special friendship with a woman; applied only to men.
To imitate, as a man, the manners of a woman.
See HOOWAHA above. To rob; to take by force.
See WAHUA, a snare; a trap. To insnare; to entrap.
To move so as to make room.
To disgrace, put to shame.
To cool, make fragrant and cool. Na ka Maʻaʻa i hoʻowaianuhea ā ʻolu wale, cooled by the Maʻaʻa wind so as to be pleasant.
To leave, abandon, ignore, shun; to expose or leave naked. Ua hoʻowaiho maila ia ka pōkiʻi, he shunned the younger brother.
See WAIHO, to lay down. To leave exposed, as a woman her shame; eia kekahi mea e moekolohe ai, o ka hoowaiho.
To sit in a state of nudity; to expose one’s shame. See HOOWAIHO.
Street name.
To enrich, bring prosperity.
See WAIWAI, property. To make rich; to have a supply; to be abundantly provided for; hence,
To be honorable.
Caus/sim of ʻowaka.
To cause to buck, somersault, etc.
To cause talk, start talk or conversation.
To cause pain, wound.
Street name.
Unreliable, fickle, unstable; slippery and amusing, as in speech.
See WALEHAU. To distill; to flow from the nose, as mucous.

To tempt, decoy, lead astray, beguile, fool, entice, take advantage of; tempter, temptation. Hoʻowalewale i nā naheka, to charm snakes. Walewale moekolohe, libidinous soliciting, adulterous tempting. Hoʻowalewale hewa, to seduce, lead into sin.
See walewale.
The deceiver; the tempter.
See WALEWALE, to deceive. To deceive; to insnare; to plot mischief.
To exercise enchantment.
Street name.

To make soft, smooth, as soil, to mix, as poi or dough; to digest. ʻAila hoʻowali pena, paint thinner. ʻUala hoʻowali ʻia, mashed sweet potatoes. Nā lio kaʻinapu hoʻowali lua (chant), graceful, doubly supple horses. Nā mea hoʻowali a loko, digestive organs. ʻŪlei hoʻowali ʻuala, digging stick of ʻūlei wood that softens [the earth for] sweet potatoes [sexual reference].
Redup. of hōʻowala.
Caus/sim of wawā.
To cause such a sound.
Street name.
Redup. of hoʻowehi.
See WEHI, a wreath. To gather a bunch of flowers for ornament.
To fix up ornaments for a person.
See WELA, heat. To burn; to cause to be burned or scorched.
To cook in the fire.
See pahu hoʻowela wai.
See WELA, to burn. To burn up; to consume.
To be lost out of sight.
Redup. of hoʻoweli; to threaten; terrible, fierce.
To frighten. See weli.
Causing fear; a threatening of one or keeping him in fear in order to secure obedience or to extort property.
See WELIWELI. Fearful; threatening; having the quality of exciting fear; he ao hooweliweli, a threatening cloud.
Exciting fear for the sake of obtaining property.
To terrorize.

example_txt.txt: Ke hopu ʻia nei ka mea i hoʻohuoi ʻia no ka hoʻoweliweli ʻana i nā ʻōhua ma luna o ka moku.
The suspect is being detained for terrorizing the passengers on the ship.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of hōʻowē.
Caus/sim of weuweu.; fluff.
To open a little; to make a small aperture; not so much as hoohakahaka.
To hurry, hasten.
See WIKI, quick. To hasten; to hurry; to do a thing quickly.
To wind, coil, twine, drill, turn; to mill about, as a school of fish.
See wili, to turn.
See WILI, to twist. To bind or tie up, as a bundle; to fasten tightly by tying; to tie around.
The name of a certain aha; also hulahula.
See WILI, to bind. To bind or tie up tightly; to tie up in bundles.
To make afraid. See WELIWELI.
To move here and there irregularly.
To move, as clouds with contrary winds.
To cause darkness or obscurity by the commingling of dark clouds.
To sharpen, make a point.
To besmear, soil. To cause to smart. To entangle.
Redup. of hoʻowiʻu.
To cause to be entangled; to entangle, as a kite.
To daub or besmear one with any filthy substance.
Same as pai 5, a fishing basket.
Same as hoʻopai, to slap, punish, chastise.
Street, Kewalo section, Honolulu. (TM)
Street name.
Ho for hoo, and pala, soft. To paint; to daub; to besmear.
To blame one who is innocent.
Ho for hoo, and palapala, to write; to paint. To cause to write badly; to scrawl in making letters with a pen; to daub with a pen.
Sorrow; grief of a husband or wife for the death of a companion.
Street name.

After, behind, last, late, younger, subsequent, residue, next, back, rear, aft, posterior, stern of a vessel, fate (see ex., nalu 2); afterwards; those behind. (This common word usually occurs without a preceding k-word; it frequently follows ma-, usually then pronounced mahape but not so written. Gram. 8.6.

example_txt.txt: afterwards, by-and-by, late, later, hereafter, behind [referring to both time and place]
in back, behind, astern [does not refer to time]
the very last child, the youngest
The people in the rear thought…

chants.mltran: ♫  We are supporters of Liliʻulani.
chants.mltxt: ♫  Mahope makou a Liliʻulani.

example_txt.txt: ka hope o ka helu naʻau
the supplement of the mental arithmetic

definitions.dtxt: Result, conclusion, end, purpose, sequel, consequence, supplement.
Deputy, substitute, assistant, adjutant, representative, surety, successor, proxy, acting officer, supporter, vice-, agent, factor.
Posterior, buttocks.
Second brew of kava.
The end or beginning of a thing; the termination of an extemity; the finishing result or termination of a course of conduct.
A place; stead; office; successor in a place.
The finishing; the close of a period of time.
A particular age or time, in this age of the world.
The time of one’s death; the end of life.
The end, i.e., the consequence or result of an action; ma neia hope aku, from this time on; ma ia hope iho, after that time; hope ole, endless.
Ending; last; na olelo hope, the last words; mea hope ole, without result, i.e., without profit.
Adv. declinable. Gram. § 165, 2 class. Behind; after, etc. See the different cases.
Part of an ʻōpelu net.
See mākala ʻūhā.
Same as hopeʻō.
Object of a sentence.
Subsummary, as in a computer program.
Subfield, as in a computer program. See kahua.
Lieutenant governor.
Substitute or assistant teacher.
Place, Kāhala, Honolulu.
Street name.
Street name.

Result, conclusion, sequel, ending, destiny, fate, consequence, effect, last. He hopena ʻelemakule, the result of being an old man. He hopena luahine, the result of being an old woman. (Both of these sayings are said jokingly of oneself as he advances in years.) Hopena pōʻino, doom, evil fate.
Hope and na for ana. The ending; the bringing to a close.
The end; the hindmost, as the rear of an army.
The end of a series of events.
Conclusion; effect. See entries below and kumu. Hoʻoholo i hopena. To draw a conclusion. Palapala Hōʻike Hopena Kaiapuni. Environmental Impact Statement (EIS).
Outcome; a possible result in a probability experiment, in math. See ʻōpaʻa hopena.
Predictable, as the ending of a story. Lit. obvious ending. Moʻolelo hopena ahuwale. Predictable story.
Railroad terminus.
Resolution or solution, as of a problem in a story, Lit. determined solution. See hihia.
Ideal result, in math.
Allergic reaction. See pāheu.
Wasp, yellow jacket, hornet.
Redup. of hoʻopē; to flatten; humble.
Same as hoʻopēpē.
Humble; depressed; downtrodden, as the people of a hard, cruel chief; o ko ke kuaaina noho ana, he hopepe, he hopohopo, he wiwo wale me ka makau; he hopepe ke ano o na kuaaina.
Ho for hoo, and pepe, to mash fine. To cause to crush, as any substance.
To overbear, as the mind; to humble. See HOUPEPE.
Vice-president.
Acting or deputy head, director, leader.
The back part of the head.
Assistant or deputy treasurer.
Virtual memory, as in computer program.
Assignee (term in will 303, 1875, State Archives).
Barely able to speak; to whisper.
To relapse after recovery from illness, often sick. (And.)
See OPILO. To relapse after a partial recovery from sickness.
To be often sick.
To eat slowly, as an invalid. (And.)
To eat slowly and carefully, as a sick person. See NIOLE.
Same as hopohopo.
To fear; to be afraid; to shrink back through fear.
Street name.
Fully developed, as a lehua flower. See poepoe, popohe. Hōpoe lehua kiʻekiʻe i luna, well-rounded mighty lehua bloom above.
A dancer who was turned into a balancing rock by Pele at Puna, Hawaiʻi.
Stone formerly in the sea at Keaʻau, Makuʻu qd., Hawaiʻi, believed to be Hiʻiaka’s companion turned to stone by Pele; it was moved by the tidal wave of 1946. (FOR. SEL. 216; PH 2; UL 88)

definitions.der: [Lit. anxious (lest) extinct. Also hopo make loa, hopo nalowale loa. Cf. ʻane halapohe]
definitions.dtxt: Threatened, as rare plants or animals.

Anxiety, uncertainty, doubt, fright; uncertain, anxious, in doubt, fearful, perturbed, alarmed, uneasy. Me ka hopohopo hoʻokamani ʻole, with unfeigned diffidence. hoʻohopohopo To evoke or produce doubt, fear, anxiety.
Fear; dread; the feeling of fear.
Fearful; afraid; having the sense of fear.
See HOPO. To fear much; to be agitated by fear; to dread; to be troubled by fear.
Transitive form of hopo.
To seize, grasp, take, catch, capture, arrest; seizure, taking, arrest. Palapala hopu, warrant of arrest. Pakele mai ka hopu ʻia, freedom from arrest.
A taking; a seizing; a catching of one.
To seize upon, as something escaping; to grasp; to catch.
To take, as a prisoner; to apprehend, as a criminal. To hold fast, as something caught.

See ʻai hopu. Kaha hopu. A line written from the end of one paragraph to the beginning of the next paragraph to indicate that the two paragraphs should be combined, in proofreading. Palapala hopu. Arrest warrant, warrant for arrest, i.e., a document issued by a magistrate authorizing an officer to make an arrest.
Pas/imp. of hopu. Hopua mai ka ʻīlīo, catch the dog.
Orange finch (Psittirostra palmeri), the largest of the Hawaiian finchlike forms, found only in the Kona and Kaʻū districts, Hawaiʻi.
A native tree, endemic to Kauaʻi (Urera sandwichensis var. kauaiensis), in the nettle family, with broad-ovate, long-stemmed leaves, and red, clustered, male flowers. Also hona, ōpuhe.
The name of a tree, the bark of which is used like the olona, and made into strings, cords, etc.
Pas/imp. of hopu. ʻO kou maka kūnou, ā, ua hopuhia (PH 66), your bowed head is caught.
Redup. of hopu. See ex., ālulu.
See HOPU. To seize; to grasp frequently; to hold fast firmly.
Rasalhague, a star.
Same as pupuāhulu.
Quickness; dispatch; a sudden effort to do a thing.
See HOPUHOPU and LULU, to tremble. To do something in a state of trepidation.
To prepare in haste, as a room or a house when company unexpectedly arrives.
To catch quickly and shake; to do quickly; to make haste.
No definition given.
Grasping, seizing, taking; arrest.
Pronunciation, accent.
Math sentence, number sentence. Cf. hopunaʻōlelo.
Pronunciation, enunciation.
Paragraph.
Syllable.
Sentence, as a grammatical unit. Cf. hoʻomaka.

example_txt.txt: topic sentence, as of a paragraph

definitions.dtxt: To stall; cause to get stuck (transitive); to balk, resist, hold back; bumpy, rough, as a road. Also haʻapupū.
Emotionally excited, as with hate, love, lust.

For hoopuupuu. See PUU and PUUPUU. To be filled or puffed up with wind, as the bowels, or as a bladder; hopupu ka opu; hopupu ka naau i ka inaina, filled with anger; kai! ka hopupu loko i ke aloha, wonderful! he is internally full of love.
Area at Honohina, Mauna Kea qd., Hawaiʻi, 6,425 feet elevation.
An hour; a particular time; a measure of time.
Exultation; praise.
An exclamation of praise to God.
Name of a species of fish.
Street name.
New, fresh, recent. Kapunahou (place name), the new spring.
Again, more, re- (as in hoʻoponopono hou, re-edit). Hana hou, do again, repeat; encore.
To push, thrust, poke, stab, shove, prick, plunge, ram, jab, drill, bore, pierce, inject. See also houhou. Hou kui, injection needle. Ka hou ʻana o ka ihe (FS 55), the hurling of the spear.
Perspiration, sweat; to perspire, sweat.

Varieties of wrasse (Thalassoma) shallow-water fish, as T. purpureum. The following names have been recorded for the young stages of the hou: ʻāwela, kanaloa, ʻōlali, ʻōlani, pāhouhou, pākaiele, pākaueloa, palaeʻa, pāʻouʻou.
Same as pakaweli, a variety of sugar cane.
Sweat; perspiration.
The asthma; shortness of breath.
New; recent; lately done.
See HOU, new. To be new; to be fresh; to be recent.
To repeat; to do over again. Kanik. To do again as before.
To breathe short; to pant.
To stab; to pierce. To run through the body, as with a spear.
To exert one’s self in casting a spear or javelin.
To dip, as a pen into an inkstand; hou aku la i ka hulu i ka inika; to dip into a liquid. To moisten or soak in water.
To thrust, as the hand into a hole.
To stretch out, as the hand; to draw out; to extend.
To search for something, as the mind; hou wale aku la ka manao i o, i o, e ake e loaa; i.e., to reach after.
Again; recently; anew; afresh.
See puka kikī hou.
To grunt and strain, as with physical exertion (Kep. 159); to mourn.
See ʻū 1.
To moisten, soak, wet.
Caus/sim of ʻualehe.
Same as hoʻohenehene.
To turn this way and that, as in panic.
Redup. of hou 3. Fig. To make cutting or cruel remarks. Ka makani houhou ʻili (song), the wind that makes the skin tingle.
To be blunt; to be obtuse; to be dull, as an instrument.
To be persevering; to continue doing a thing.
To thrust through; to drill; to bore; to pierce.
To open a crack or sliver; to cause to gleam. Hōʻuiki mai i ka maka, to open the eyes just a slit.
To flash, as lightning.
To screw or twist the mouth to one side, as in disapproval or dislike.
See hou 3.
To redden, make red.
Same as mauʻu lāʻili, a native iris. See mauʻu lāʻili.
To redden, make red. Mea hōʻulaʻula lehelehe, lipstick. Mea hōʻulaʻula papālina, rouge.
To shake the ʻulīʻulī; to rattle.
Brand new.

To stir up, inspire, excite, taunt. Pule hoʻoulu, prayer for inspiration. Oli hoʻoulu, taunting chant, as before combat. Ka hoʻoulu hakakā, stirring up fights. Hoʻoulu haunaele, stirring up a mob, agitator.
To collect, assemble, gather together, compile; addition, to add; collection. Hōʻuluʻulu pōkole, brief summary, resumé, synopsis.
See ʻuluʻulu, collection.
An assembly; a convocation.
For hoouluulu. See ULU, to grow. To collect together; to assemble, as people.
To bring together things scattered.
Addition, in math. Cf. hoʻohui.
See ULU 6 and AKUA, god. To set up one’s self for a god; to make pretensions of being a god.
To make or appoint gods.
Summary; to summarize.
Document summary, as in computer program. E hōʻike ʻia ka mea nāna i kikokiko ma ka hōʻuluʻulu palapala. The typist will be shown in the document summary. See hope hōʻuluʻulu palapala.

To assume the shape of a bowl; to assume the shape of fruit, to bear fruit. Fig. To hav enough to eat. E pua ana ka ʻōhiʻa ʻai a hōʻumeke i ka malama o Hinaiaʻeleʻele (Kep. 93), the mountain apple blooms and fruits form in the month of Hinaiaʻeleʻele.
For hooumeke. See UMEKE, a poi calabash. To swell in growing like the calabash gourd; to swell, as fruit in growing.
To have enough; to be supplied with comforts.
Scooping. See ʻupena hōuna.
Caus/sim of ʻunihipii; to deify.
To pave with asphalt. See unukā, kīpapa (dic.).
To pleat, overlap in sewing; to pull up, as a sagging petticoat.
To stab with a knife.
See PEPE, crushed; bruised. To be modest; to be bashful; to act as a backwoodsman; to be diffident; to be crushed, as the mind.
Diaphragm, chest, solar plexus. Lelele ka houpo i ka ʻoliʻoli, the heart leaps for joy. Paʻa ka houpo, the stomach is full. Houpo lewalewa, sagging chest [hunger].
The thorax; the region of the material heart. Laieik. 45.
A palpitation or fluttering of the heart.
The action of the region of the mind; lelele ka houpo i ka olioli, the mind (or heart) leaped for joy.
The heart. See HAUPU.
Diaphragm.
A hungry, empty stomach.
Faintness for want of food.
See HOUPO above and LEWALEWA, movable. To flat down, as the stomach of a hungry person.
To be hungry; to be dizzy for want of food.
To be light or empty, as the stomach.
Strong pulsation in solar plexis, heart attack.
To drill a hole, bore or pierce through.

To recall to someone else, remind; to terrify someone by repeating an unpleasant impending event, especially that one is to be the victim of sorcery; to harp on impending doom. Cf. hāʻupuʻupu, to recall without this pejorative connotation.
For hooupuupu. See UPU, to desire strongly. To tell lies, as in giving a false alarm, or in accusing another in order to clear himself of suspicion.
For hoʻoʻuweke. See ʻuweke, to open wide. To open; to open, as a door; to open, as the mouth; to open wide. See WEHE.
Caus/sim of ʻuwī.
Watery, as thin poi; soggy. Pā hōwai, a dish containing liquids.

A perennial herb (Lagenophora maviensis), found only in marshy high parts of West Maui. The leaves form a basal rosette, from which rises a stalk bearing a round daisy-like flower head with yellow center and white rays.
Abbreviation for hapa piliona (nano-).
Abbreviation for hekekale, heketare (hectare).

To rise or swell, as yeast or souring poi; to ferment, leaven, overflow, percolate, effervesce, boil over; to surge or rise to the surface, as emotion; to gush forth; rising, swelling, outburst. Cf. huaʻi. Perena hū ʻole, unleavened bread. Hū ka ʻaka, to burst into laughter, guffaw. Hū ka pele, to pour forth lava, erupt. Inā hū aku kou ʻuhane i ka po ʻe pōloli, if your soul has compassion for the hungry people. Hū mai ke aloha no ka ʻāina, love for the homeland swells forth. He hū wale mehe wai lā, unstable as water. hoʻohū To leaven, cause to rise, inflate, swell, overflow; yeast, baking powder.
And interj. To roar, grunt, hum, whistle; huh (interj.)! Hū ka makani, the wind whistles or roars [of things going at great speed]. Hū wawā ka nahele, din roaring in the forest [gossip].
A spinning top. Hū oeoe, humming top. Kaula hū, cord used to spin a top, Hoʻoniniu i ka hū, to spin a top.

To depart from the proper course, miss the way. Hū ā puaʻa, off the course like a pig [of one who does not follow a straight and narrow path, as of a drunkard]. hoʻohū To cause someone to deviate from the path; to shoo, drive away, rout.
Gum, as of the ʻōlapa tree.
Commoners as a mass. Ē ka hū, ē ka makaʻāinana, aloha ʻoukou (chant by Kamāmalu bidding farewell to Hawaiʻi), O commoners, O citizenry, farewell to you.
Var. of hui 2, to unite, join. Ē Lono, e hū ʻia mai ka lani me ka honua (prayer), O Lono, join heaven and earth.
That which causes rising, leaven.
A class of the common people, nearly SYN. with makaainana; e ka hu, e na makaainana, etc. Laieik. 21. O ka poe hemahema a naaupo, ua kapaia lakou he hu ka inoa, he makaainana kahi inoa.
A noise; a rustling, as the wind among trees. Laieik. 104.
A top; hu kani, a humming-top.
Fermenting, as beer or new wine.
Leavened, as bread; mea hu, anything leavened. Berena hu ole, unleavened bread.
To rise or swell up, as leaven or new poi; to effervesce.
To swell and rise up, as water in a pot.
To rise up, as a thought; hu mai keia manao iloko o'u, this thought swelled up in me.
To overflow; to run over the banks, as a river.
To burst out, spoken of affection. Or a flow of passion (hence huhu.)
To shed or pour out, as tears. Hu ka uhane, to have compassion.
To ooze out silently.
To circulate, as the story of a murder.
To miss one’s way; to deviate from a direct path.
To come, i.e., to heave in sight; to make its appearance, as a ship at a distance.
To be unstable; to be inconstant.
To whistle, as the wind through the rigging of a ship.
Hoo. To meditate; to indite, as a song.
Overflow error, as on a calculator display.
Yeast; baking powder. See pauka koka.
See manu hū.
Iwi hua. Anat. 6.
A flowing. See No. 8 above. The trail of a pa-u; the trail of a garment; the tucks at the bottom of a gown.
The snapper of a whip.
Street name.

Fruit, tuber, egg, produce, yield, ovum, seed, grain, offspring; meat as in ʻopihi shell or ʻalamihi crab; to bear fruit, tuber or seed; to bear a child; fruitful. For kinds of eggs, see hua ʻaluʻalu, huamakani, hua moa.

example_txt.txt: Ā e hana aku ʻoe iā ʻoukou e hua aʻe.
a medicine for women to induce conception

definitions.dtxt: To bear fruit, reproduce, produce, yield; to sire or give birth; to swell high, as a wave (UL 36).
Round object, as pill or bead. Cf. huaale.

example_txt.txt: ka hua o kā ʻoukou hana

definitions.dtxt: Result, effect; credit, as for a university course.

example_txt.txt: Hoʻohua nō ka make ʻana o ka makua kāne, pau kō mākou ʻike ʻana iāia.
Ever since his father’s death, we've never seen him again.
Hoʻohua nō i ka huhū ʻana o ke kupuna, ʻo ka hele nō ia.
Because of his grandparent’s anger, he departed.

definitions.dtxt: To have as a result, because of, ever since (followed by nō).
Testicles.

example_txt.txt: Ka hele ā pala nā hua i ka moana.
Testicles rot at sea [a sailor lacks a sex partner].

definitions.dtxt: Same as huahua 3, a vulgar gesture.
Word, letter, figure, watchword, rallying cry, note in music; winning word in the Chinese gambling game of chee-fah; type; to speak. Cf. hua helu, hua ʻōlelo.

example_txt.txt: Kāne kū i ke kala, kala i ka hua o ka waha.
Kāne stand to forgive, forgive the words of the mouth.

definitions.dtxt: Name of the thirteenth night of the lunar month. (Malo 35) Kapu Hua, monthly taboo nights of Mōhalu and Hua.
Name of a star.
The bulging of the broadest part of a paddle blade.
See pai hua.
See paʻi hua.
The swelling, growing and maturity of vegetables; name of the moon when perfectly full; the name of that night is akua.
Fruit; offspring; production of animals or vegetables.
A fruit produced; an egg; a kidney, etc. Hua oo, ripe fruit; hua maka, fresh fruit.
The effect, product or consequence of an action; ka naaupo, he hua ia na ka ino, ignorance is the result (fruit) of evil practices.
A summary of one’s wishes; a short sentence; e waiho mai oe i hua na makou, leave for us some short expression; a word, an idea (said to Kamehameha I. when dying.)
A letter of the alphabet; ma ka hua o ke kanawai, i.e., literally; hua kena, an order; a word of command; no keia hua kena a kana wahine. Laieik. 198.
Fruit in several senses; as, hua o ke kino, children; hua o ka aina, increase of the fruits of the land, i.e., means of living; hua o na holoholona, flocks, herds, etc.; hua ala, spices.
A flowing; a going out from; froth; foam, as of one in a fit.
A flowing robe; a train. Hua lole, the skirts of a garment.
Seed, as of grain for sowing.
The human testicles.
To sprout; to bud; to bear fruit, as a tree or vegetable.
To grow or increase in size, as fruit; to increase, as a people.
To swell up, as the foam of water. See HUAHUA.
Hua with huaolelo, to speak; to utter; to produce words.
Hoo. To produce fruit.
To increase, as a people. To be fruitful, as a race.
Corm, as of taro. Trad. See entries below and ʻauhua.
Sound segment, in linguistics.
Hill, northwest Kauaʻi.
Foam, froth, bubble, suds, scum. Huʻa o ka wai, water bubble.

Rim, border, edge, side, hem; ruffles and tucks at the bottom of a dress; tucks in a mat; train of a gown. See mānele huʻa hoʻohiwahiwa. Ākea ka huʻa o ka lole, the bottom of the dress is wide [a full skirt]. Ka huʻa o ka lāʻau (FS 99), the reach of the club.
Suburb, boundary.
Pile, as of mats or tapa. (FOR. 4:63) Also nuʻa.
Same as maʻa 4.
Hoʻohuʻa To insist, persist. Hoʻohuʻa nohoʻi i ka inu lama, persisting in drinking intoxicants.
Hōkelo huʻa. Bubble chamber, in chemistry.
Envy, jealousy; envious, jealous; to stir up trouble due to envy. Cf. māhuā. hoʻohuā To provoke anger or jealousy.
Var. spelling of huā.
Envy; jealously; an envious disposition; making unfounded complaints against another.
See HUA. Envy.
See HUWA. Envious; jealous of success in another; quick to find fault.
See HUWA. To be envious of another; to feel jealous of another; to envy; to hate.
To quarrel with; to be angry with; to be much addicted to evil.
To be displeased at importunity or intercession.
To be small; to be stinted in growing, as fruit.
To pry up.
Very sour, of poi.
To burn intensely.
Tuber. Comb. hua + aʻa.
A rotten egg.
Empty; deficient; rotten.
To dig up something covered in the ground; to open, i.e., dig up, as opening a native oven and take out what is baked; huai oia i kana umu iho, he uncovered his own oven.
To open, as a grave; to disinter.
To open, as a reservoir of winds; to cause the wind to blow; huai mai la Kahiki i ko ipu makani, Kahiki thou didst open thy wind-box.
To open upwards, as the lid of a chest.
To suck or draw up water in drinking, as a beast.
Hoo. To bring a wind; to cause it to blow.
To turn or dig up the ground.
Edible fruit or seed. Hua ʻai mālili, blasted fruit.
An egg that may or can be eaten, or an egg for eating.
Grain; fruit for food.
A kind of wind; huaai malili.
Street name.
Kiwi fruit. Also lahomāpū.
Palindrome, a word or sentence that reads the same backward as forward.
Nutmeg, spice.
Street name.
A leading note in music, the major seventh of any scale, a semitone below the tonic.
Street name.
Pill, tablet.
A pill; a medicine in the form of a little ball, to be swallowed whole.
Inu i ka huaale. To take a pill. Also ʻai i ka huaale. See inu, ʻai.
Sleeping tablet.
Missing letter.
Egg with a very soft shell.
See ʻālualua 2.
Spermatozoon, sperm, in biology. Cf. huaʻine. See keakea (dic.).
Glass bead.
The grain of barley, or simply barley.
To rise up against; to resist; to defend off. HOO. To cause to resist, etc.
Child born out of wedlock, that is accepted by the husband or wife of the parent and treated as his own. Kaʻū.
Var. spelling of hua āelo. See āelo.

See HUA, egg, and ELO, wet, as a kapa; hence, rotten; worthless. See also HUAAELO. To be or become useless, worthless or in vain; e malama hoi, o huaelo ka luhi o ka hoikaika ana, beware, lest the weariness in perseverance be in vain.
Fig. A fig; a bunch of figs.
Syllabary symbol, in linguistics. See hakalama.
Product, i.e., something that has been produced or manufactured.
Half note, as in music.
Quarter note, as in music.
Fallen fruit or seed. Fig. Friendless, uncared for by parents or chief; bastard, illegitimate child (modern); foetus lost through miscarriage.
One prematurely born; an orphan.
Hua, seed, and haule, to drop; to fall. Lit. Seed fallen; prematurely born; hence, friendless; without support; no means of living; set loose from any chief or parent.
The name of a species of sweet potato.
Same as hua hāʻule. Also said of a sweet potato produced from the extended vine as distinguished from the product in the hill.
Name of certain leaves of the potato.
The name of the potato itself.
Hail.
Name for the beach naupaka (Scaevola) plant.

definitions.der: [Lit. thunder egg | hua, egg, and hekili, thunder]
definitions.dtxt: A hail stone; hail.
definitions.notes: Note: It generally thunders during the hail storms on the mountains of Hawaii, hence the supposition that hail was produced by thunder.

definitions.dtxt: The name of a plant used in medicine.

A small native naupaka (Scaevola kilaueae) found only on dry lava near Kīlauea Volcano. It does not exceed a height of 80 cm, has narrow, thick leaves, dull-yellow flowers, and small black fruits that were used to dye tapa. Also papaʻahekili.
Figure, number (the character).
A few, little. ʻEhia āu lei? He mau hua helu nō. How many leis for sale have you? Just a few. He wahi hua helu ia, its of some help [financial].
Figure or number (the character), numeral. See helu Loma, kino huahelu.
Counting number, in math.
Abbreviation.
Abbreviation. Cf. hua inoa.
Starfruit.
Combination, as of a safe.
Type.
Apocope, in linguistics.
See HUAHUA above. Foam or froth, as of the sea or anything causing froth.
A bunch or kernel in the flesh, as in hogs or other animals; especially applied where many huahuas are growing together.
Small swellings about the eye, the forehead and neck.
See HUA, to be envious. An evil eye; looking with disdain upon another; envy.
See HUA and HUAHUWA below. To foam; to froth at the mouth, as one in a fit. To froth, as the sea in dashing ashore.
To turn away in disgust; to hate; to envy. Huahua mai la na punahele mua. Laieik. 31.
Fruitful, productive, prolific; to bear many fruits; to lay many eggs.
Testicles. See insult, loaʻa … kāu.

A vulgar gesture of contempt made by thrusting the thumb between index and middle fingers with the fist clenched, or the fist held up to the face and the eyelid drawn down. With the gesture one sometimes said, “Eia kāu ʻo ka huahua,” “Here’s your huahua gesture.” hoʻohuahua. To make the huahua gesture.

Redup. of huʻa 1; foam, froth, lather, bubbling, frothing. Ua loʻohia ʻoia e kekahi ʻuhane, auē koke nō ia … ā huʻahuʻa aʻe, a spirit seizes him, and he suddenly cried out … until [he] foams. hoʻohuʻahuʻa Caus/sim.
Jelly.
See huʻahuʻa kai.
Kokoleka me ka waiū huʻahuʻa. Chocolate with frothed milk.

example_txt.txt: Ā huāhuā maila kō Pilisetia iāia.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of huā. See ex., peʻa 1, FOR. 4:129, 131.
See HUAHUALAU, also HOOHUAHUALAU.
To open and shut with violence.
To question with a design to entangle; to put one to the torture.

example_txt.txt: Kāua i ka huahuaʻi, e ʻuhene lā i pili koʻolua.
We two in passionate outpour, giggling, clinging two and two.

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of huaʻi; to boil up, as water in a spring; to gush forth, effervesce; culmination of sexual passion.
See HUAI. A violent boiling; a frequent opening.
See HUAI. To boil up, as water in a spring.
To break up; to break forth, as water.
To open frequently that liquid may flow.
To tear or break the skin.

example_txt.txt: …a hoʻomaʻū i ka huʻahuʻa kai i ka vinega.

definitions.dtxt: Sponge.
Sea foam; crest of a wave breaking into foam.
A variety of seaweed.
A sponge.
A coarse, weedy native dock (Rumex albescens) in the buckwheat family. See also pāwale.
Soapsuds.
Floating froth. Fig. An ignoramus.
Interrogation to incriminate, ensnare, or obtain information by roundabout methods, to question or quiz indirectly.
Caus/sim.; to cross-examine.

example_txt.txt: Naʻu naʻe i hoʻohuahualau aku, ā no laila, hū mai koʻu aloha.
I used devious methods and then my love poured forth.
Ua hoʻohuahualau mai ia iā mākou me kāna ʻōlelo ʻinoʻino.
He prattles against us with, his evil words.

definitions.dtxt: Hoo. A deceiving; an endeavor to insnare one; a temptation for one to say something he would not.

To tempt; to try to deceive; to puzzle or try one with questions; to question captiously. Hoo. To make one’s self strange to another; to pretend not to know one. To talk temptingly or deceitfully. 3 Ioane 10.
The same as huahualau.

definitions.der: [huʻahuʻa, froth, and nana for lana, to float Lit. Floating froth]
definitions.dtxt: A reproaching; making use of reproachful epithets; calling one an ignorant nothing.
Var. spelling of huāhuā.
See HUAHUA. Envy. Pilip. 1:15. But huahua is the common orthography.

To disclose, reveal, uncover, as an oven; to disinter, dig up, pour forth, break forth; to churn water, as a ship propeller (hu 1 + -aʻi, transitivizer: Gram. 6.6.4). Cf. poʻo huaʻi. Ke lepo ke kumu wai, e huaʻi ana ka lepo i kai, when the source of water is dirty, dirt is seen in the lowlands [one with dirty thoughts hears dirty words].
To dig up something covered in the ground; to open, i.e., dig up, as opening a native oven and take out what is baked; huai oia i kana umu iho, he uncovered his own oven.
To open, as a grave; to disinter.
To open, as a reservoir of winds; to cause the wind to blow; huai mai la Kahiki i ko ipu makani, Kahiki thou didst open thy wind-box.
To open upwards, as the lid of a chest.
To suck or draw up water in drinking, as a beast.
HOO. To bring a wind; to cause it to blow.
To turn or dig up the ground.
To open, as an imu. Huaʻi i ka imu. To open an imu. Cf. kuʻi i ka imu.
A shellfish of the hīhīwai family.
A kind of seaweed (Codium).
Small letter, small fruit.
Boiling up, opening, uncovering: to gush forth, as lava.
Ovum, in biology. Comb. hua + -ʻine. Cf. huaʻāne. Hoʻokuʻu huaʻine. To ovulate. Lōkino huaʻine. Ovary.
Initial. Cf. hua hōʻailona. See pūlima hua.
Clear as crystal, bright, dazzling, white, shining, flashing. hoʻohuaka To cause a gleam of light, flash, glimmer.
Shadow, reflection. hoʻohuaka To cast a shadow or reflection.
Clear as crystal; clear as pure water, etc.; bright; white; shining.
Street name.
An only child or offspring.
Street name.
Sponge, foam.
See HUA and KAI. The foam of the sea.
A sponge. See HUAHUAKAI.
A large company traveling together.
Hua, foam, and kai, sea. To foam and froth, as the sea; hence,
To boil or be agitated violently.
To travel in large companies, as in caravans. See KAIHUAKAI.
Sponge, the aquatic animal. Cf. ʻūpī (dic.).
Scrambled eggs.
Trip, voyage, journey, mission, procession, parade; to travel, parade. Cf. kaʻi, to lead.
Travels, a long trip; to keep traveling.
A great number of persons traveling together; a caravansera; a troop.
Honor escort.
Tour; to make a tour.
Excursion, field trip. Lit. trip (for) exploring. Also huakaʻi.
Night procession or parade, especially the night procession of ghosts that is sometimes called ʻoiʻo.
Bur.
Tone in music.
Tone, in music.
Street name.
Seed, as of mango; bulb.
Bulb, as of a lily or tulip. ʻŌmaka hua kanu. Bulb tip.
Pile of tapas. See huʻa 4.
Taboo borders, as of a taboo place, or of the taboo enclosure where hula was taught.
Huʻa, foam, froth, and kapu. The rich property about the chiefs and kapu to the people, was called huakapu, forbidden froth.
Full and plump, as a healthy person; well proportioned, as a properly built canoe.
Full; plump, as a healthy man; well proportioned, as a good modeled canoe.
Street name.
Hardness of heart; stubbornness.

See the foregoing. Hoo. Hard-hearted; stubborn; stubbornly bent on wickedness; i mai la me ka olelo hoohuakeeo, he said to me in stubbornness; he hoohuakeeo mamuli o ka hewa, hardhearted in wickedness.
See HUAKEEO.
Printer’s type. See ex., ʻōniu 3.
(In a good sense) fearless; bold; he kanaka huaku, wiwo ole; he olelo huaku ma ka pono, a speech fearless for the right. (In a bad sense) bold; impudent.
Excessive. Hū ā keu i ka ʻino, extremely wicked.
Jacinth.
Gr. A hyacinth, name of a precious stone.
Fructose. He mea hoʻomomona ka huakō ma loko o ka wai meli a me nā ʻano huaʻai he nui nō. Fructose is a sweetener found in honey and many kinds of fruits. Comb. hua + kō. Cf. monakō.
Grace note in music.
Epenthetic sound, in linguistics.
Input, as in a computer program. Comb. hua + komo. Cf. huapuka. See kāhuakomo. Hāmeʻa huakomo. Input device, as on a computer.
Soap bubble.
(In a good sense) fearless; bold; he kanaka huaku, wiwo ole; he olelo huaku ma ka pono, a speech fearless for the right. (In a bad sense) bold; impudent.

example_txt.txt: he ʻōlelo hū ā kū i ka pono

definitions.dtxt: Same as hū ā keu.
Commodity, i.e., anything bought or sold. He kuapo huakūʻai kaʻu ʻoihana. I’m in the commodities exchange business. Comb. hua + kūʻai.
Mandrake.
Kukui (candlenut) nuts. Hua kukui ka iʻa, the fish resemble kukui nuts [describing schools of fish with noses protruding from the water].
Hua and kukui, the name of the candle-nut tree. A kukui nut; the fruit of the kukui tree.
Name of schools of fish that show their heads above water, as the anai.
Alphabet.
Acorn. Lit. oak tree.
Loose; to tie loosely; round, full, swelling; to sag, as cheeks.
To swell out; to be large; to be round; to be full.
To tie; to bind up. SYN. with nakiki.
Curved, warped, oval, twisted.
Applied to surfaces, circular; oval; ili hualala, an oval surface; spherical; curved; equally arched, as the rainbow. Ana. Hon. 10.
Large volcano, Kailua qd., North Kona, Hawaiʻi; it last erupted in 1801. See Huʻehuʻe, Kaʻūpūlehu, Luaomilu, Puhiapele.
Street name.
Offspring of a chief.
A variety of sweet potato.
Street name.
A variety of banana.
Variable, a symbol that can stand for any quantitative value, in math.
Street name.
Var. spelling of huaale.
Seeds of the laulele plant.
Hernia.
The seeds of the plant laulele.
A term expressive of hernia.
Phoneme, in linguistics Lit. language segment. See puana hualeo, puanaleo.
See hua palapala leo hui.
See hua palapala leo kahi.

To scatter dust, especially a method of fighting with a club or spear in which the opponent was blinded by stirring up dust; to hit an underhanded blow. Also huʻelepo. Wili aʻela ʻo Pūpū-ākea i kāna lāʻau, a huʻalepo akula ma nā wāwae o Makakūikalani (FOR. 4:349), Pūpū-ākea twirled his club and scattered dust at the feet of Makakūikalani.
ʻŌhiʻa or ʻōhiʻa ʻai fruit uses as medicine (KAM. 64:103, 141); perhaps also a kind of wood.

Bright, polished, clean, pure, white, glittering, gleaming; morally pure. Ua huali kona kapa e like me ka hau, his raiment was white as snow. hoʻohuali Caus/sim.; to polish. Mehe ʻōlinolino lā ke nānā aku, a me ke keleawe hoʻohuali ʻia, like the brightness of the sun to look upon, and gleaming bronze.
Bright; clean, as a substance polished; bright; polished. Pure whiteness; lole huali, very white cloth; shining.
In a moral sense, pure; undefiled; morally good; applied to the heart.
Glittering, as a sword.
Hoo. Keleawe i hoohualiia, polished brass.
To be bright, as polished metal; to be clean; to glitter with whiteness or purity, as a garment. Hoo. To furbish or burnish.
To strike.
To commence a kapu of a particular kind.
Street, Punchbowl, Honolulu.
Street name.
Small or inferior fruit; runt; small, puny.
Small letter.
Small; diminutive.
Berry.
Grace note in music.
Blasted fruit.
The second crop of fruits, trees or vegetables, or degenerated fruit; ka hualili, huamaili o Kohala.
Street name.
Product, answer, as in arithmetic.
Product, in multiplication.
Trimmings or borders of a garment; hem of a dress.
See HUA and LOLE, cloth. The skirts of a garment.
Edition, as in a computer program.
Small; diminutive. See HUALII.
Loose skin over the eyeball; slight viscous membrane covering the eye.
See maiʻa hua lua.
Musk, as used in making perfume. See wai Lūkini.
Street name.
Upper case (capital) letter. Comb. hua + maʻaka. Cf. hua naʻinaʻi.
A two-note chord.
Same as kūkaeakua.
Tiny, yolkless egg.
Notes in music; words of a song.

Note, in music or on music staff. See entries below and kī, kōkua hua mele. Hua mele laina. Line note. Laina o ke kōkua hua mele. Horizontal line on a musical staff. Also laina o ke kōkua. Wā o ke kōkua hua mele. Space between horizontal lines on a musical staff. Also wā o ke kōkua.
Hua, letter, and mele, to sing. The notes in music; a modern term.
Quarter note, in music.
Dotted quarter note, in music.
Half note, in music.
Dotted half note, in music.
Sixteenth note, in music.
Eighth note, in music.
Whole note, in music.
Chicken egg.
Round-ended bone entering the hip socket.
Type of house with thatch purlins separated by a width of three fingers. (FOR. 5:645)
Same as moa, a native variety of banana.
A variety of sweet potato.
Hua, egg, and moa, a fowl. A hen’s egg.
The name of the round bone that enters the socket of the hip. Anat. 16.
Street name.
Pile of mats. (FOR. 4:63)
Offering to a Congregational church of the first earnings in a new job or undertaking; offerings in gratitude for a particular success, as a big fish catch.
Initial letter, first word.
Gushing forth, overflow. Hala ka huana wai, gone is the rush of water.
Juan De Nova.
Lower case (small) letter. Comb. hua + naʻinaʻi (Tah., small). Cf. hua maʻaka.
Name of the hinahina root when used in hana aloha, love sorcery.
Anagram. Comb. hua + neʻe.
Hua, fruit, and noni, a shrub. The fruit or the apples of the noni; he kaua huanoni kekahi, some fought with noni apples.
Street, Pauoa, Honolulu.
Street name.
Large fruit; to be fruitful, productive.
Capital letter.
Street name.
Street name.
Whole note in music.
Fruitless, unproductive, worthless, sterile, unrewarding.
Lit. Without fruit. Epithet of a person without character, no reputation.
Word, term.
An affront to a family ʻaumakua god. E noʻonoʻo nohoʻi i ka hua ʻōlelo, then think of the affront [that caused the god’s displeasure].
See HUA, a letter, and OLELO, speech. A word in distinction from a speech; in grammar, a word in distinction from a syllable; the words of a song.
Word. See entries below. Mākau huaʻōlelo. Word skill.
Compound word.
Antonym.
Synonym.
Homonym.
A variety of sweet potato.
Street name.
Constant term, in math. Cf. hoa like, paukū.
Character, as of type in a computer program. Usu. hua. ʻAʻole paʻi kēia mīkini paʻi i kekahi mau hua paʻi. This printer doesn't print certain characters.
Scrambled eggs, omelet.

Orange trumpet or sweetheart vine (Pyrostegia venusta syn. Bignonia venusta, B. ignea), an ornamental climber from Brazil, bearing early in the year many deep-orange flowers, hence chestnut-colored or light brown.

example_txt.txt: Ē Kohala i ka huapala kau i ka nuku.
O Kohala with the handsome folk to delight the eyes [lit., to appear at the mouth].

definitions.dtxt: Sweetheart, lover; pretty, handsome.
Chestnut brown.
Street name.
Wheat.
Hua, seed, and palaoa, (flour), bread. The seed of bread, i.e., wheat.
Rye (Secale cereale).
See HUAPALAOA above and ELEELE, dark colored. Hence, rye, as distinct from wheat.
Letter of the alphabet.
Letter (of the alphabet).
Italics.
Consonant.
Vowel.
Capital letter.
Barley (Hordeum vulgare).
Date.
Same as ʻalae huapī.
Bones of the side of the head; side of the head.
The side of the head.
Pōpolo berry. Also ʻolohua.
Output, as in a computer program. Comb. hua + puka. Cf. huakomo. See kāhuapuka.

The red sandalwood tree (Adenanthera pavonina), from parts of tropical Asia and Malaysia, of moderate height and with rather widespreading branches. The tree is planted in parks, and its round, lens-shaped, red seeds are used for leis, and their long, yellow-lined pods for decorative arrangements.
Same as hāpai, a variety of banana.
Var. of hue wai, water gourd container.
Small bay, south Lānaʻi.
Collection of dew or rain water, pool.
Grape, grapes (Vitis spp.).

example_txt.txt: ʻO ka manawa ia o ka hua waina pala mua.
It was the time of the first ripe grapes.

definitions.dtxt: A grape; collectively, grapes; the fruit of the vine.
Street name.
Raisins.
Raisin.
Street name.

definitions.der: [PPN fue, a creeper; PEP fue, gourd]
definitions.dtxt: Gourd, water calabash, any narrow-necked vessel for holding water, flask. Cf. ipu, pōhue.
Quick, as in stealing or deception; light-fingered; to steal, filch, move fast; to work the rope fast in skipping rope; theft (rare). Cf. ʻaihue.
A type of hula dancing, usually at the end of a program, a kind of ʻai ʻami with a revolving of the hips as fast as the drummer can beat time, to see who can dance longest; to dance thus.
A way of connecting net sections by, interlocking meshes.
A thief; one who steals.
Thievish; disposed to steal. Kanaka hue.
A gourd; a water calabash; hue ili, a skin bottle.
To look slily at a thing; to glance with the eye.
To steal; to take secretly what is another’s; hue ae la kekahi kanaka i ka apa lole kukaenalo, a certain man stole a piece of unbleached cotton cloth. See AIHUE.

To remove, lift off, uncover, expose; to unload, as a ship; to open, as an oven; to exhume, push, force, prod; to wash out, as flood waters; to reveal. Huʻe i ke kaona, reveal the hidden meaning. Ua huʻe ka wai i ke pili, the water flowed out over the pili grass. E huʻe mai ʻoe i ke koaiʻe o Makawao, uproot the koaiʻe tree of Makawao [a boast and challenge of the native of Makawao, Maui].
See HU and E. To cause to flow out; to unload, as a ship.
To dig; to throw out dirt, as in digging a pit.
Street name.
Var. of ʻaihue. (FOR. 6:424)

example_txt.txt: Huʻea maila nā pihaʻā moe wai o uka.
The flotsam in the upland stream comes pouring down [of gossip].
huʻea pau ʻia e ka wai

definitions.dtxt: Pas/imp. of huʻe.
Gas, as in the digestive system. Cf. kinoea.

example_txt.txt: E nui ka hūea o ka ʻōpū ma muli o kekahi mau ʻano meaʻai.
You can get a lot of gas in your stomach from certain foods.

definitions.dtxt: Intern, i.e., one who works as an apprentice.
Type of bitter gourd, as used for utensils.
Name of a strong northwesterly wind of the winter months. Also Kiu Inu Wai and Mālua Kiʻi Wai.
Chilled, benumbed, as of one shivering in this wind.
The strong (cold) blowing wind.
Chilled; cold.
To shiver, as with cold.
Street name.
Spreading over; growing thickly like thrifty vines, as the koali (convolvulus).
Spreading over like rain; he ua huehueia no Uli.
The name of the water on Hualalai where the last volcano broke out.
See HUE.
Street name.
Pimples, acne; to have pimples.
A native climber (Cocculus ferrandianus), with oval leaves and bluish one-seeded fruits. The stems were used for twine and for funnel-mouthed fish traps. Also hue ʻie.
Redup. of huʻe; to keep removing; to take out and put in again, as furniture; to overflow repeatedly.
See huʻehuʻe kai.

Village and ranch, Puakō qd., Hawaiʻi. The last flow from Hualālai erupted in 1801 below the ranch at about 1,500 to 1,800 52feet elevation and flowed to the sea (Macdonald and Abbott 51-52). Hawaiians thought Pele started the flow because she wanted awa fish from Kīholo and Kaʻūpūlehu, aku fish from Kaʻelehuluhulu, and breadfruit from the uplands of Huʻehuʻe, and because she was jealous of Kamehameha’s weatlh and honor. Kamehameha, on the advice of a Pele seer (kāula), offered sacrifices and the flow stopped. (RC 184-186; UL 124) See ʻAkahipuʻu.
A wild passionflower (Passiflora suberosa) with small greenish-yellow flowers, small three-lobed or undivided leaves, and blackish fruits 1.3 cm in diameter.
Same as huʻahuʻa kai 1, 2.

example_txt.txt: This is a trivial bit of idea.

definitions.dtxt: Tail end, as of a strip of pandanus plaiting. Cf. huelo.

See HUELO. The tail end of a thing; the last of it; nolaila, ke hai aku nei au i keia wahi huehuelo manao, wherefore, I declare this tail end of a thought (last idea); loaa mai o ka huehuelo wale no, aole o ke kino pu kekahi, I obtained the tail only, not the body with it.
Same as huehue 2.
Demijohn.
Hue and ie, a vine used in basket making. A demijohn, from its case or covering.
Container or bag for liquids made of animal skin. Nā hue ʻili waina kahiko (Iosua 9.4), old wine-skins.
Hue, calabash, and ili, skin. A skin bottle, such as the Asiatics used for containing liquids.
One alone; a single child of a family.

definitions.der: [Lit. royal gourd (referring to the well for Kaʻahumanu’s home). See Pūʻahuʻula, Pukaʻōmaʻo]
definitions.dtxt: Drive, upper Mānoa, Honolulu.
Street name.
Var. of huʻalepo. (FS 89)
Small hula graduating exercises held at noon outside in the dust (lepo).
Tail, as of dog, cat, or pig; train of a dress; tail-end, last. Fig. Inferior. Cf. huehuelo, pewa, hiʻu, puapua.

example_txt.txt: These are the tail ends of Hawaiians.

definitions.dtxt: To lengthen, continue, make a tail; to stream down, as water over a cliff.
A hop vine. (AP)

The tail of a beast or reptile; ke kahili o na holoholona ma ka hope, the fly-brush at the extremity of animals; huelo awa, a sting. Mai noho a makamaka ilio, i ka huelo ka ike, be not friends with the dog, for the tail will show it; the tail. The rump.
An inferior in opposition to poo, a superior.

Village, stream, and point, Haʻikū qd., Maui (see Hakakaupueo). Islet 3.1 acres, Kamalō qd., north Molokaʻi. A game, originated by Papio, was played here; loulu palm leaves were woven into hammocks upon which players were laid and then tossed into the sea. See Leinaopapio. (Ka Nupepa Kuokoa, July 6, 1922)
Street name.
Sting, as of a scorpion.
Tail-like, having tails.
Tail like; having appendages like tails.

A small shrub (Buddleja asiatica), native of southeastern Asia to Java, growing wild in Hawaiʻi, related to the summer lilac. It has narrow leaves and small white flowers growing in long narrow clusters.
Tail end, especially of a junior line of a lineage. (KL. line 525)
Whaleboat.
Australian bluegrass, Andropogon sericeus. Niʻihau.
Cattail.
An edible sweet gourd.
Opening, unloading, flowing, pushing. Cf. huʻe. Hoʻokahi nō huʻena a nā kānaka i kā lākou māpuna hoe, just one push by the men of their paddle stroke.
Very angry.
A wheezing sound, as of asthmatic persons; a prolonged shrill cry.
Name of a sickness causing panting; want of breath.
Street, Puʻunui, Honolulu.
Street name.
A variety of gourd with a short beak.
Street name.
Witty, comical, amusing, funny, mischievous; rascal, rogue.
A bold fearless man; one who excites to action, good or bad; soldier like; he kanaka koa; hueu oe i ke kolohe, you are bold in mischief; a bold energetic man in action; hooeu.
Bold and rapid in eating.
Gourd water container, water bottle.
A water calabash, in distinction from calabashes used for other purposes; a large gourd; any kind of bottle used to contain water.
Street name.
Long-necked water container.
See HUE and WAINA (Eng.), wine. A bottle for wine; a bottle filled with wine.
Gourd water container with constriction about the middle.
Water gourd shaped like an hourglass.
Diphthong.
Chat, talk, rumor; to chat, talk.
Fat, unwieldy; such a person.
A large fleshy person, but weak, indolent and lazy, either man, woman or child.
Something said; a report, but no certainty as to the truth; he wahi olelo i maopopo ole, he lohe laulahea.

To miss the course, digress, fail to penetrate or grasp. Hūhewa ka pōkā, the shot missed the mark. Hūhewa kō lākou lohe, a me kō lākou ʻike aʻo ʻia (Kep. 15), what they heard and were taught was not maintained. Ua hūhewa paha ke Kīnaʻu (song), the Kīnaʻu [ship] has perhaps gone off her course.
To come out of the earth as a spring or an outcrop of ʻalaea dirt. Fig. To rise in revolt.
To pray that the land or couentry might be overturned; huhonua i mana kai ka wai e.
A wood-boring insect, termite; worm-eaten, rotten. E ʻai nohoʻi ka huhu iā lākou e like me ka hulu hipa, and the worm shall eat them like wool.
To pet, cherish, as animal pets. Hānai ā huhu, to raise a pet. Moe kō a ka huhu, dream fulfilled and cherished.
The name of a worm, a moth-like animal that eats cloth.
A worm or bug that bores into wood, rendering it full of holes.
Rotten, as a calabash; worm-eaten, as wood.

Angry, offended, indignant, mad, scolding; anger, wrath; to scold, become angry. See ex., pau pū. Huhū wela loa, very great anger, fury. Piʻi ka huhū, to become angry. hoʻohuhū To provoke anger, pretend anger. Mai hoʻohuhū aku iāia, do not rebel against him.
Anger; wrath; displeasure.
Angry; offended; provoked.
See HU, to rise up; to swell. To be angry; to express angry feelings by scolding, storming, cursing, etc. Hoo. To provoke to anger; to offend. To be crabbed; to be churlish.
Redup. of hū 1; to bulge; to effervesce.
Wood-eating borer. (FOR. 5:169)
Possibly a redup. of hue 2, fast. Huhue nā keiki paniolo (chant), the cowboys were fast.
Probably a redup. of huʻe; to cease, quit. Huhuʻe aku kāua, moe i ke awakea (FS 94–5), let’s stop [fighting], sleep at noon.
Insect-eaten, rotten, worm-eaten, wormy.
See HUHU.
Redup. of hue 2; to filch repeatedly, to steal in company.
See HUE, to steal. A frequentative. To steal frequently; to carry off at many times secretly.
Redup. of hui 1; to meet as equals, as two beautiful persons.
Hawaiian hula by many persons; to hula, of many.
See HULA, to dance. A frequentative. To dance and sing; to dance much and often.
See HULA. To dance and sing and play, as at a hula; e pae, e hula, e like pu.
Redup. of hulei; lifting, tossing about, trotting, sporting, leaping, twisting.
To ride rapidly with a dress fluttering in the wind; to dance with kapas fluttering.
Redup. of huhuli; to turn, seek frequently. See huli 1, 2.
See HULI, to turn. To turn often; to turn, as many persons.
Redup. of huhume.
Redup. of huhuna.
See HUNA, to conceal. To hide often or much; to conceal.
Redup. of hunehune and hune 1, 2; fine, dainty; stripped of all property.
See HUNE, poor; destitute of property. To be poor; to be stripped of all property.

Cluster, collection, swarm, bunch. Also huihui. E noho malalo o ka lāʻau maka, iho mai ka huhui, māʻona ka ʻōpū, sit under a green tree, the cluster falls, stomach is filled [serve a worthy person and you will be rewarded].

example_txt.txt: Hoʻopaʻa i nā mea paʻa o nā Huhui.
Bind the chains of the Pleiades.

definitions.dtxt: Pleiades. Also Huihui.

See HUI. Hu doubled. A bunch; a collection of things, generally qualified by a following word; as, huhui palaoa, a head of wheat. Huhui mau, a bundle of grass; huhui maia, a bunch of bananas; huhui (hoku understood), the pleiades or seven stars. The constellations of stars. See HUIHUI.
Logarithm.
Huhui and helu, arithmetic. Logarithms; the tables of logarithms; ina e imi au maloko o ka huhuihelu, if I should compute by logarithms.
A bunch of kalo.
Ears of grain.

example_txt.txt: A ʻo kā lākou hua waina, he hua waina make, a ʻo nā huhui waina a lākou, he ʻawaʻawa ia.
Their grapes are grapes of poison, their grape clusters are bitter.

definitions.dtxt: Cluster of grapes.
A cluster of grapes.
Redup. of huki; to pull hard or frequently. Pau ke kalo i ka huhuki ʻia, all the taro was pulled up. Koi huhuki, compelling, insistent urge. hoʻohuhuki To pull, cause to pull. Fig. Headstrong.
See HUKI, to pull. To draw frequently; to pull out, as in drawing cuts. Laieik. 72. To pull along.
To dry up, as water; hoomaloo.
To cut down, as a tree; e kua aku.
Redup. of huku.
Full of holes; pukapuka, popopo. See HUHU and HUHUHU.
Hula dance by many; to dance the hula, of many.
See HULAHULA. To sing, dance and practice the forms of the hula.
Redup. of huli 1, 2; to seek, turn, of many and repeatedly.
See HULI, to turn. To turn; to turn up; to search; to look here and there.
Bristling, tousled, as feathers, fur, body hair.
Intensifier of huhulu.

chants.chtran: Tousled were the feathers of the bird in the morning rain.
chants.chtxt: Huhulu iʻi ka hulu o ka manu i ka ua kakahiaka.

definitions.dtxt: Made rough and ugly, as the hair or feathers of an animal in water.
To stand up, as the comb of a cock; to stand up, as bristles; to stand erect, as the hair on the flesh when one is wet and cold.
To be wet and cold; to shiver with cold.
To rise, as fur of an angry dog.
Hulu, hair, and loa, long. To let the hair grow long.
Same as huluhulu weo.
Redup. of hume.
Redup. of huna; particles, fragments.
Redup. of hune 1, 2.
Skin eruption on animals, as hog, dog; to have such.
See HUNE, to tease. To set a trap for one; to entice; to lay a bait.
The sickness of hogs.
Borer, a kind of insect. Comb. huhu + pao.
A wood borer. Fig. Slanderer, defamer.
A slanderer; a backbiter.
Short-tempered, peevish, cantankerous, angry without cause.
Street name.

Club, association, society, corporation, company, institution, organization, band, league, firm, joint ownership, partnership, union, alliance, troupe, team; to form a society or organization; to meet, intermingle, associate, congregate. (Probably hū 7 + -i, transitivizer; cf. Gram. 6.6.4)
To form a society.
To join, unite, combine, mix; combination See hui pū and saying, nāwao 1.

example_txt.txt: to press together, of a crowd; to mingle, as two sides at the conclusion of an athletic competition.
Ka hui ʻia o ka loa a me ka laulā, pēlā e loaʻa mai ai ka ʻalea.
The multiplication of the length and the width, thus is obtained the area.
to connect, as telephone numbers by a telephone operator
ka hoʻohui o ka mīkini humuhumu

definitions.dtxt: To join, as two words; to add a prefix or suffix; to add on, annex, append, unite; to introduce one person to another; meeting of persons; binder.
A plus sign.
Cluster, as of grapes or coconuts; bunch, as of bananas. Also huhui, huihui.
Chorus of a song.

example_txt.txt: Ua loha nā hui o Hāʻupu.
The flippers of Hāʻupu droop [an aged person, a reference to the story of Kana and Niheu, in which a turtle lifted up Hāʻupu hill on Molokaʻi].

definitions.dtxt: Flippers of a turtle.
Var. of huli, to turn, seek.

chants.chtran: Kamohoaliʻi’s canoe turned.
chants.chtxt: Hui iho nei ka waʻa a Kamohoaliʻi.

definitions.dtxt: Small uniting stick in a thatched roof, supporting rod for purlins.
To disperse, as a meeting.
A prayer on the morning after ʻanāʻanā sorcery. (Pronunciation uncertain: perhaps huʻi.)
A uniting; an assembling.
A cluster or collection of things; as, hui maia, a bunch of bananas; hui kalo, a kalo hill; hui waina, a cluster of grapes; hui niu, a cluster of cocoanuts.
The flippers of the sea-turtle.
The small uniting sticks in a thatched house, parallel with the posts and rafters and between them.
Bodily pain; rheumatic pain; niho hui, the toothache.
The name of the prayer on the morning after the anaana. See HUIHUI.
To mix; to unite together, as different things; to unite, as an aha with the spectators; hence, hui ka aha, to break up the assembly. Laieik. 47.
To add one thing to another.
To assemble, together, as people for business.
To agree in opinion; to have a union of thought; ua hui pu ka manao.
To bend; to turn one way then another, as the voice in rising and falling in reading music.
To ache; to be in pain.
Hoo. To add one thing to another; to connect.
To unite, as in a treaty; to make affinity.
To collect together, as men.
To meet; to mingle; to come together, as waters.
To meet, as persons long separated.
To intersect, as lines on a grid, in math. See entries below and kaha huina.
Conference, in sports. Cf. ʻaha kūkā. See Hui Pōpeku Aupuni, Hui Pōpeku ʻAmelika, kuʻikahi.
Nā Hui Nui ʻElima. The Big Five, i.e the five corporations that controlled most of the sugar industry in Hawaiʻi.
Ache, pain; aching, Niho huʻi, toothache.
A prayer.
Cool; cold; chilly, as the morning air from the mountain; i hoomanawanui ai hoi kaua i ka hau huihui o ke kakahiaka; cold, as cold water.
Halloo.
Pas/imp. of hui 2.

chants.mltran: ♫  You are the one who was met, O love.
chants.mltxt: ♫  ʻO ʻoe ka i huia ihola, ē ke aloha.

definitions.dtxt: Name of a surfing wave. (Laie 505)
Ancient surfing place, Hilo district, Hawaiʻi. (Finney and Houston 26) Name of a wave for surfing (Beckwith, 1919:505).
Street name.
Union, as of states or countries into one political entity.
Street name.
Street name.
Street name.
Street name.
Congregational church at Kaupō, East Maui.
Street name.
A kind of stone, as used for making maika stones.
Street name.
Surf opposite the Kona Inn, Kailua, Kona, Hawaiʻi, considered dangerous for surfing but used in ancient days.
Express company.
Pacific Yacht Club.
Credit union.
Insurance company.
Street name.
Mixed, mingled, united, joined; to pool together, as to buy cooperatively.
Caus/sim.
Cluster, collection, bunch.

example_txt.txt: nā hōkū o ka lani a me nā huihui ona
the stars of the heavens and their constellations

definitions.dtxt: Constellation.
Pleaides. Also Huhui.
A bunch; a cluster of things, as stars.
A constellation.
A bunch; applied to kalo. See HUI 2.
The name of the seven stars. See HUHUI.

example_txt.txt: He aloha huʻihuʻi konikoni ana i loko oʻu.

definitions.dtxt: Cold, cool, chilly; numbing, tingling, as love.
To make cold, chill, as by refrigeration.
Cool; cold; chilly, as the morning air from the mountain; i hoomanawanui ai hoi kaua i ka hau huihui o ke kakahiaka; cold, as cold water.
Cold; chilly. See HUI above.
Mixed; manifold; much; many containing the idea of union; aloha huihui, much love.
Cold. See kuʻina.
To gather together like a flock of kōlea birds. Fig. To gather together to help one another in time of trouble.
Constellation.
A name for Pleiades. (HM 368)
A kind of seaweed.
Combination, mixture; composite.

example_txt.txt: ʻEhia huihuina o kēia mau waihoʻoluʻu i hiki ke loaʻa?
How many possible combinations do these colors have?

definitions.dtxt: Redup. of huini 1, 2.
